
       
<EOS>
The
Posthumous
Papers
of
the
Pickwick
Club
<EOS>
The
Pickwick
Papers
 
Charles
Dickens
  
1836
-
-1837
  
Information
about
the
source
     
Chapter
1
.
<EOS>
The
Pickwickians
 
<EOS>
The
first
ray
of
light
which
illumines
the
gloom
,
and
converts
into
a
dazzling
brilliancy
that
obscurity
in
which
the
earlier
history
of
the
public
career
of
the
immortal
Pickwick
would
appear
to
be
involved
,
is
derived
from
the
perusal
of
the
following
entry
in
the
Transactions
of
the
Pickwick
Club
,
which
the
editor
of
these
papers
feels
the
highest
pleasure
in
laying
before
his
readers
,
as
a
proof
of
the
careful
attention
,
indefatigable
assiduity
,
and
nice
discrimination
,
with
which
his
search
among
the
multifarious
documents
confided
to
him
has
been
conducted
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
12
,
1827
.
 
<EOS>
Joseph
Smiggers
,
Esq
,
P*V*P*M*P*C.
 
<EOS>
[
Perpetual
Vice
-
President
---
Member
Pickwick
Club
]
,
presiding
.
 
<EOS>
The
following
resolutions
unanimously
agreed
to
:
---
   
"
That
this
Association
has
heard
read
,
with
feelings
of
unmingled
satisfaction
,
and
unqualified
approval
,
the
paper
communicated
by
Samuel
Pickwick
,
Esq
,
G*C*M*P*C.
 
<EOS>
[
General
Chairman
---
Member
Pickwick
Club
]
,
entitled
"
Speculations
on
the
Source
of
the
Hampstead
Ponds
,
with
some
Observations
on
the
Theory
of
Tittlebats
;
"
and
that
this
Association
does
hereby
return
its
warmest
thanks
to
the
said
Samuel
Pickwick
,
Esq
,
G*C*M*P*C
,
for
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
while
this
Association
is
deeply
sensible
of
the
advantages
which
must
accrue
to
the
cause
of
science
,
from
the
production
to
which
they
have
just
adverted
---
no
less
than
from
the
unwearied
researches
of
Samuel
Pickwick
,
Esq
,
G*C*M*P*C
,
in
Hornsey
,
Highgate
,
Brixton
,
and
Camberwell
---
they
can
not
but
entertain
a
lively
sense
of
the
inestimable
benefits
which
must
inevitably
result
from
carrying
the
speculations
of
that
learned
man
into
a
wider
field
,
from
extending
his
travels
,
and
,
consequently
,
enlarging
his
sphere
of
observation
,
to
the
advancement
of
knowledge
,
and
the
diffusion
of
learning
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
with
the
view
just
mentioned
,
this
Association
has
taken
into
its
serious
consideration
a
proposal
,
emanating
from
the
aforesaid
,
Samuel
Pickwick
,
Esq
,
G*C*M*P*C
,
and
three
other
Pickwickians
hereinafter
named
,
for
forming
a
new
branch
of
United
Pickwickians
,
under
the
title
of
The
Corresponding
Society
of
the
Pickwick
Club
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
the
said
proposal
has
received
the
sanction
and
approval
of
this
Association
.
<EOS>
"
That
the
Corresponding
Society
of
the
Pickwick
Club
is
therefore
hereby
constituted
;
and
that
Samuel
Pickwick
,
Esq
,
G*C*M*P*C
,
Tracy
Tupman
,
Esq
,
M*P*C
,
Augustus
Snodgrass
,
Esq
,
M*P*C
,
and
Nathaniel
Winkle
,
Esq
,
M*P*C
,
are
hereby
nominated
and
appointed
members
of
the
same
;
and
that
they
be
requested
to
forward
,
from
time
to
time
,
authenticated
accounts
of
their
journeys
and
investigations
,
of
their
observations
of
character
and
manners
,
and
of
the
whole
of
their
adventures
,
together
with
all
tales
and
papers
to
which
local
scenery
or
associations
may
give
rise
,
to
the
Pickwick
Club
,
stationed
in
London
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
this
Association
cordially
recognises
the
principle
of
every
member
of
the
Corresponding
Society
defraying
his
own
travelling
expenses
;
and
that
it
sees
no
objection
whatever
to
the
members
of
the
said
society
pursuing
their
inquiries
for
any
length
of
time
they
please
,
upon
the
same
terms
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
the
members
of
the
aforesaid
Corresponding
Society
be
,
and
are
hereby
informed
,
that
their
proposal
to
pay
the
postage
of
their
letters
,
and
the
carriage
of
their
parcels
,
has
been
deliberated
upon
by
this
Association
:
that
this
Association
considers
such
proposal
worthy
of
the
great
minds
from
which
it
emanated
,
and
that
it
hereby
signifies
its
perfect
acquiescence
therein
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
casual
observer
,
adds
the
secretary
,
to
whose
notes
we
are
indebted
for
the
following
account
---
a
casual
observer
might
possibly
have
remarked
nothing
extraordinary
in
the
bald
head
,
and
circular
spectacles
,
which
were
intently
turned
towards
his
(
the
secretary
's
)
face
,
during
the
reading
of
the
above
resolutions
:
to
those
who
knew
that
the
gigantic
brain
of
Pickwick
was
working
beneath
that
forehead
,
and
that
the
beaming
eyes
of
Pickwick
were
twinkling
behind
those
glasses
,
the
sight
was
indeed
an
interesting
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
sat
the
man
who
had
traced
to
their
source
the
mighty
ponds
of
Hampstead
,
and
agitated
the
scientific
world
with
his
Theory
of
Tittlebats
,
as
calm
and
unmoved
as
the
deep
waters
of
the
one
on
a
frosty
day
,
or
as
a
solitary
specimen
of
the
other
in
the
inmost
recesses
of
an
earthen
jar
.
 
<EOS>
And
how
much
more
interesting
did
the
spectacle
become
,
when
,
starting
into
full
life
and
animation
,
as
a
simultaneous
call
for
"
Pickwick
"
burst
from
his
followers
,
that
illustrious
man
slowly
mounted
into
the
Windsor
chair
,
on
which
he
had
been
previously
seated
,
and
addressed
the
club
himself
had
founded
.
<EOS>
What
a
study
for
an
artist
did
that
exciting
scene
present
!
<EOS>
The
eloquent
Pickwick
,
with
one
hand
gracefully
concealed
behind
his
coat
tails
,
and
the
other
waving
in
air
to
assist
his
glowing
declamation
;
his
elevated
position
revealing
those
tights
and
gaiters
,
which
,
had
they
clothed
an
ordinary
man
,
might
have
passed
without
observation
,
but
which
,
when
Pickwick
clothed
them
---
if
we
may
use
the
expression
---
inspired
involuntary
awe
and
respect
;
surrounded
by
the
men
who
had
volunteered
to
share
the
perils
of
his
travels
,
and
who
were
destined
to
participate
in
the
glories
of
his
discoveries
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
right
sat
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
---
the
too
susceptible
Tupman
,
who
to
the
wisdom
and
experience
of
maturer
years
superadded
the
enthusiasm
and
ardour
of
a
boy
in
the
most
interesting
and
pardonable
of
human
weaknesses
---
love
.
 
<EOS>
Time
and
feeding
had
expanded
that
once
romantic
form
;
the
black
silk
waistcoat
had
become
more
and
more
developed
;
inch
by
inch
had
the
gold
watch
-
chain
beneath
it
disappeared
from
within
the
range
of
Tupman
's
vision
;
and
gradually
had
the
capacious
chin
encroached
upon
the
borders
of
the
white
cravat
:
but
the
soul
of
Tupman
had
known
no
change
 
---
admiration
of
the
fair
sex
was
still
its
ruling
passion
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
left
of
his
great
leader
sat
the
poetic
Snodgrass
,
and
near
him
again
the
sporting
Winkle
;
the
former
poetically
enveloped
in
a
mysterious
blue
cloak
with
a
canine
-
skin
collar
,
and
the
latter
communicating
additional
lustre
to
a
new
green
shooting
-
coat
,
plaid
neckerchief
,
and
closely
-
fitted
drabs
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
oration
upon
this
occasion
,
together
with
the
debate
thereon
,
is
entered
on
the
Transactions
of
the
Club
.
 
<EOS>
Both
bear
a
strong
affinity
to
the
discussions
of
other
celebrated
bodies
;
and
,
as
it
is
always
interesting
to
trace
a
resemblance
between
the
proceedings
of
great
men
,
we
transfer
the
entry
to
these
pages
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
observed
(
says
the
secretary
)
that
fame
was
dear
to
the
heart
of
every
man
.
 
<EOS>
Poetic
fame
was
dear
to
the
heart
of
his
friend
Snodgrass
;
the
fame
of
conquest
was
equally
dear
to
his
friend
Tupman
;
and
the
desire
of
earning
fame
in
the
sports
of
the
field
,
the
air
,
and
the
water
was
uppermost
in
the
breast
of
his
friend
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
He
(
Mr
Pickwick
)
would
not
deny
that
he
was
influenced
by
human
passions
and
human
feelings
(
cheers
)
---
possibly
by
human
weaknesses
(
loud
cries
of
"
No
"
)
;
but
this
he
would
say
,
that
if
ever
the
fire
of
self
-
importance
broke
out
in
his
bosom
,
the
desire
to
benefit
the
human
race
in
preference
effectually
quenched
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
praise
of
mankind
was
his
swing
;
philanthropy
was
his
insurance
office
.
 
<EOS>
(
Vehement
cheering
.
)
<EOS>
He
had
felt
some
pride
---
he
acknowledged
it
freely
,
and
let
his
enemies
make
the
most
of
it
<EOS>
---
he
had
felt
some
pride
when
he
presented
his
Tittlebatian
Theory
to
the
world
;
it
might
be
celebrated
or
it
might
not
.
 
<EOS>
(
A
cry
of
"
It
is
,
"
and
great
cheering
.
)
<EOS>
He
would
take
the
assertion
of
that
honourable
Pickwickian
whose
voice
he
had
just
heard
---
it
was
celebrated
;
but
if
the
fame
of
that
treatise
were
to
extend
to
the
farthest
confines
of
the
known
world
,
the
pride
with
which
he
should
reflect
on
the
authorship
of
that
production
would
be
as
nothing
compared
with
the
pride
with
which
he
looked
around
him
,
on
this
,
the
proudest
moment
of
his
existence
.
 
<EOS>
(
Cheers
.
)
<EOS>
He
was
a
humble
individual
.
 
<EOS>
(
"
No
,
no
.
"
)
Still
he
could
not
but
feel
that
they
had
selected
him
for
a
service
of
great
honour
,
and
of
some
danger
.
<EOS>
Travelling
was
in
a
troubled
state
,
and
the
minds
of
coachmen
were
unsettled
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
look
abroad
and
contemplate
the
scenes
which
were
enacting
around
them
.
 
<EOS>
Stage
-
coaches
were
upsetting
in
all
directions
,
horses
were
bolting
,
boats
were
overturning
,
and
boilers
were
bursting
.
 
<EOS>
(
Cheers
---
a
voice
"
<EOS>
No
.
"
)
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
(
Cheers
.
)
<EOS>
Let
that
honourable
Pickwickian
who
cried
"
No
"
so
loudly
come
forward
and
deny
it
,
if
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
(
Cheers
.
)
<EOS>
Who
was
it
that
cried
"
No
"
?
<EOS>
(
Enthusiastic
cheering
.
)
<EOS>
Was
it
some
vain
and
disappointed
man
<EOS>
---
he
would
not
say
haberdasher
(
loud
cheers
)
 
---
who
,
jealous
of
the
praise
which
had
been
---
perhaps
undeservedly
---
bestowed
on
his
(
Mr
Pickwick
's
)
researches
,
and
smarting
under
the
censure
which
had
been
heaped
upon
his
own
feeble
attempts
at
rivalry
,
now
took
this
vile
and
calumnious
mode
of
---
   
"
Mr
BLOTTON
(
of
Aldgate
)
rose
to
order
.
 
<EOS>
Did
the
honourable
Pickwickian
allude
to
him
?
<EOS>
(
Cries
of
"
Order
,
"
"
Chair
,
"
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
"
No
,
"
"
Go
on
,
"
"
Leave
off
,
"
etc
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
PICKWICK
would
not
put
up
to
be
put
down
by
clamour
.
<EOS>
He
had
alluded
to
the
honourable
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
(
Great
excitement
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
BLOTTON
would
only
say
then
,
that
he
repelled
the
hon
gent
's
false
and
scurrilous
accusation
,
with
profound
contempt
.
<EOS>
(
Great
cheering
.
)
<EOS>
The
hon
gent
was
a
humbug
.
 
<EOS>
(
Immense
confusion
,
and
loud
cries
of
"
Chair
,
"
and
"
Order
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
A
SNODGRASS
rose
to
order
.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
upon
the
chair
.
 
<EOS>
(
Hear
.
)
<EOS>
He
wished
to
know
whether
this
disgraceful
contest
between
two
members
of
that
club
should
be
allowed
to
continue
.
 
<EOS>
(
Hear
,
hear
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
The
CHAIRMAN
was
quite
sure
the
hon
Pickwickian
would
withdraw
the
expression
he
had
just
made
use
of
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
BLOTTON
,
with
all
possible
respect
for
the
chair
,
was
quite
sure
he
would
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
CHAIRMAN
felt
it
his
imperative
duty
to
demand
of
the
honourable
gentleman
,
whether
he
had
used
the
expression
which
had
just
escaped
him
in
a
common
sense
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
BLOTTON
had
no
hesitation
in
saying
that
he
had
not
---
he
had
used
the
word
in
its
Pickwickian
sense
.
 
<EOS>
(
Hear
,
hear
.
)
<EOS>
He
was
bound
to
acknowledge
that
,
personally
,
he
entertained
the
highest
regard
and
esteem
for
the
honourable
gentleman
;
he
had
merely
considered
him
a
humbug
in
a
Pickwickian
point
of
view
.
<EOS>
(
Hear
,
hear
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
PICKWICK
felt
much
gratified
by
the
fair
,
candid
,
and
full
explanation
of
his
honourable
friend
.
 
<EOS>
He
begged
it
to
be
at
once
understood
,
that
his
own
observations
had
been
merely
intended
to
bear
a
Pickwickian
construction
.
 
<EOS>
(
Cheers
.
)
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
entry
terminates
,
as
we
have
no
doubt
<EOS>
the
debate
did
also
,
after
arriving
at
such
a
highly
satisfactory
and
intelligible
point
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
official
statement
of
the
facts
which
the
reader
will
find
recorded
in
the
next
chapter
,
but
they
have
been
carefully
collated
from
letters
and
other
MS
.
<EOS>
authorities
,
so
unquestionably
genuine
as
to
justify
their
narration
in
a
connected
form
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
2
.
<EOS>
The
first
day
's
journey
,
and
the
first
evening
's
adventures
;
with
their
consequences
 
That
punctual
servant
of
all
work
,
the
sun
,
had
just
risen
,
and
begun
to
strike
a
light
on
the
morning
of
the
thirteenth
of
May
,
one
thousand
eight
hundred
and
twenty
-
seven
,
when
Mr
Samuel
Pickwick
burst
like
another
sun
from
his
slumbers
,
threw
open
his
chamber
window
,
and
looked
out
upon
the
world
beneath
.
 
<EOS>
Goswell
Street
was
at
his
feet
,
Goswell
Street
was
on
his
right
hand
---
as
far
as
the
eye
could
reach
,
Goswell
Street
extended
on
his
left
;
and
the
opposite
side
of
Goswell
Street
was
over
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
are
the
narrow
views
of
those
philosophers
who
,
content
with
examining
the
things
that
lie
before
them
,
look
not
to
the
truths
which
are
hidden
beyond
.
 
<EOS>
As
well
might
I
be
content
to
gaze
on
Goswell
Street
for
ever
,
without
one
effort
to
penetrate
to
the
hidden
countries
which
on
every
side
surround
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
having
given
vent
to
this
beautiful
reflection
,
Mr
Pickwick
proceeded
to
put
himself
into
his
clothes
,
and
his
clothes
into
his
portmanteau
.
 
<EOS>
Great
men
are
seldom
over
scrupulous
in
the
arrangement
of
their
attire
;
the
operation
of
shaving
,
dressing
,
and
coffee
-
imbibing
was
soon
performed
;
and
,
in
another
hour
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
his
portmanteau
in
his
hand
,
his
telescope
in
his
greatcoat
pocket
,
and
his
note
-
book
in
his
waistcoat
,
ready
for
the
reception
of
any
discoveries
worthy
of
being
noted
down
,
had
arrived
at
the
coach
-
stand
in
St
Martin's
-
le
-
Grand
.
"
<EOS>
Cab
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
you
are
,
sir
,
"
shouted
a
strange
specimen
of
the
human
race
,
in
a
sackcloth
coat
,
and
apron
of
the
same
,
who
,
with

label
and
number
round

,
looked
as

in
some

.
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
waterman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
you
are
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
then
,
fust
cab
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
first
cab
having
been
fetched

the
public
-

,
where
he
had
been

first

,
Mr
Pickwick
and

were

.
   
<EOS>
"
Golden
Cross
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
a
bob
's
vorth
,
Tommy
,
"
cried
the
driver
sulkily
,
for
the

his

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How

that
horse
,
my

?
"
<EOS>
inquired

Pickwick
,
rubbing
his

with

shilling

had
reserved
for

fare
.
   
<EOS>
"
Forty
-
two
,
"
replied

driver
,
eyeing

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated

Pickwick
,
laying
his

upon

note
-
book
.
 
<EOS>
The
driver
reiterated
his
former
statement
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
looked
very
hard
at
the
man
's

,
but
his
features
were
immovable
,
so
he
noted
down

forthwith
.
"
<EOS>
And
how
long
do
you
keep
him
out
at
a

?
"
<EOS>
inquired

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Two
or
three
veeks
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Weeks
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
in

,
and
out

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
lives
at
Pentonwil
when
he
's

,
"
observed

driver

,
"
but
we
seldom
takes

home
,
on

weakness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
account
of
his
weakness
!
"
reiterated

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
always
falls
down
when
he
's
took
out
o
'
the
cab
,
"

,
"
but

,

,

in
werry

,
so
as

ca

werry
well

;

o

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

on
<EOS>
---

ca

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
<EOS>
The
entry
was

Golden
Cross
.
 
<EOS>
Down

,
and
out

.
<EOS>
Mr

,
Mr

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
What
was

man
's

,
when
that

,

Mr

)

<EOS>

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Or

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Come

---
all

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Go

,
Sam
!
---
<EOS>
and

.

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Come

!
"
<EOS>
and

dashed

,

,

's

,

's

,

,

,

,

,
and

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
an

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
'em
under

,
"
suggested

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
smart
for

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Informers
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
on
,
"
cried
the
cabman
,
who
had

.
   
<EOS>
The
mob
hitherto
had
been
passive

of

scene
,
but
as

of
the
Pickwickians
being

was

,
they

to

with
considerable

the

of
enforcing
the
heated
pastry
-
vendor
's

:
and
there
is
no
saying
what
acts

personal

they

,
<EOS>
had
not
the
affray
been

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

fun
?
"

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
informers
!
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ai
n't
you
,

---
ai

?
"
said

,
appealing

,
and
making

through
the

by

.
   
<EOS>
That

in

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

of

,

after

,

.
<EOS>
Here
,
No
.
 
924
,
take
your
fare
,
and
take
yourself
off
---
respectable

---
<EOS>
know
him
well
---
<EOS>
none

---
this
way
<EOS>
,

---
where
's

?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
all

mistake
,

---
never

---
accidents
will

---
best
regulated

---
never
say

---
down

---
<EOS>
Pull
him
UP
---
Put
that

pipe
---
like

---
damned

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
a

string
of
similar
broken

,
delivered

,
the
stranger
led
the
way
to
the
traveller
's
waiting

,
whither
he
was
closely

by
Mr
Pickwick
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
waiter
!
<EOS>
"
shouted
the
stranger
,
ringing

bell
with

,
"
glasses
round
---
brandy
-

-

,
hot

,

,

,
---
eye

,
Sir
?
<EOS>
Waiter
!
<EOS>
raw

-

for
the

's

---
<EOS>
nothing
like

-

for

,
sir
;
cold

-

,

---
<EOS>
damned
odd

,
with
your
eye
against
a
lamp
-
post
---
eh
,
---
very
good
---
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
stranger
,
without

to

,
swallowed

a

full
half
a
pint
of
the

-

-
water
,
and
flung
himself
into
a

with

as
if
nothing

.
   
<EOS>
While
his
three
companions
were
busily
engaged
in
proffering
their
thanks
to
their
new
acquaintance
,
Mr
Pickwick
had
leisure
to
examine
his
costume
and
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
about
the
middle
height
,
but
the
thinness
of
his
body
,
and
the
length
of
his
legs
,
gave
him
the
appearance
of
being
much
taller
.
 
<EOS>
The
green
coat
had
been
a
smart
dress
garment
in
the
days
of
swallow
-
tails
,
but
had
evidently
in
those
times
adorned
a
much
shorter
man
than
the
stranger
,
for
the
soiled
and
faded
sleeves
scarcely
reached
to
his
wrists
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
buttoned
closely
up
to
his
chin
,
at
the
imminent
hazard
of
splitting
the
back
;
and
an
old
stock
,
without
a
vestige
of
shirt
collar
,
ornamented
his
neck
.
<EOS>
His
scanty
black
trousers
displayed
here
and
there
those
shiny
patches
which
bespeak
long
service
,
and
were
strapped
very
tightly
over
a
pair
of
patched
and
mended
shoes
,
as
if
to
conceal
the
dirty
white
stockings
,
which
were
nevertheless
distinctly
visible
.
 
<EOS>
His
long
,
black
hair
escaped
in
negligent
waves
from
beneath
each
side
of
his
old
pinched
-
up
hat
;
and
glimpses
of
his
bare
wrists
might
be
observed
between
the
tops
of
his
gloves
and
the
cuffs
of
his
coat
sleeves
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
was
thin
and
haggard
;
but
an
indescribable
air
of
jaunty
impudence
and
perfect
self
-
possession
pervaded
the
whole
man
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
individual
on
whom
Mr
Pickwick
gazed
through
his
spectacles
(
which
he
had
fortunately
recovered
)
,
and
to
whom
he
proceeded
,
when
his
friends
had
exhausted
themselves
,
to
return
in
chosen

his
warmest
thanks
for
his
recent
assistance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
cutting
the
address
very
short
,
"
said
enough
---
no
more
;
smart
chap
that
cabman
---
handled
his
fives
well
;
but
if
I
'd
been
your
friend
in
the
green
jemmy
---
damn
me
---
punch
his
head
,
---
"
cod
<EOS>
I
would
,
---
pig
's
whisper
---
pieman
too
,
---
no
gammon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This

,

"

<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
"

,

"
my

---
place

---
<EOS>
one

---

,
---

---
<EOS>

---
wo

---
<EOS>
no
go
---
eh
?
"
<EOS>
and

most

.
   
<EOS>
Now

so
happened
that
Mr
Pickwick
and

three

had
resolved

-

;

,

,
where

.
   
<EOS>
"
Up

you
,
"
said

,
assisting
Mr
Pickwick
on
to
the
roof
with
so
much
precipitation
as
to
impair
the
gravity
of
that
gentleman
's
deportment
very
materially
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Any
luggage
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
the
coachman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
---
I
?
<EOS>
Brown
paper
parcel
here
<EOS>
,
that
's
all
---
<EOS>
other
luggage
gone
by
water
---
packing
-
cases
,
nailed
up
---
big
as
houses
---
heavy
,
heavy
,
damned
heavy
,
"
replied
the
stranger
,
as
he
forced
into
his
pocket
as
much
as
he
could
of
the
brown
paper
parcel
,
which
presented
most
suspicious
indications
of
containing
one
shirt
and
a
handkerchief
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heads
,
heads
---
take
care
of
your
heads
!
"
cried
the
loquacious
stranger
,
as
they
came
out
under
the
low
archway
,
which
in
those
days
formed
the
entrance
to
the
coach
-
yard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Terrible
place
---
dangerous
work
---
other
day
---
five
children
---
mother
---
tall
lady
,
eating
sandwiches
---
forgot
the
arch
---
crash
---
knock
<EOS>
---
children
look
round
---
mother
's
head
off
---
sandwich
in
her
hand
---
<EOS>
no
mouth
to
put
it
in
---
head
of
a
family
off
---
<EOS>
shocking
,
shocking
!
<EOS>
Looking
at
Whitehall
,
sir
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
fine
place
---
little
window
<EOS>
---
somebody
else
's
head
off
there
,
eh
,
sir
?
<EOS>
---
he
did
n't
keep
a
sharp
look
-
out
enough
either
---
eh
,
Sir
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
ruminating
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
on
the
strange
mutability
of
human
affairs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
see
---
in
at
the
palace
door
one
day
,
out
at
the
window
<EOS>
the
next
.
 
<EOS>
Philosopher
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
"
An
observer
of
human
nature
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
so
am
I.
 
<EOS>
Most
people
are
when
they
've
little
to
do
and
less
to
get
.
 
<EOS>
Poet
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
friend
Mr
Snodgrass
has
a
strong
poetic
turn
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
have
I
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Epic
poem
---
ten
thousand
lines
 
---
revolution
of
July
---
composed
it
on
the
spot
---
Mars
by
day
,
Apollo
by
night
---
bang
the
field
-
piece
,
twang
the
lyre
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
present
at
that
glorious
scene
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Present
!
<EOS>
think
I
was
<EOS>
;
*
fired
a
musket
---
fired
with
an
idea
---
rushed
into
wine
shop
---
wrote
it
down
---
back
again
---
whiz
,
bang
 
---
<EOS>
another
idea
---
wine
shop
again
---
pen
and
ink
---
back
again
---
cut
and
slash
---
noble
time
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Sportsman
,
sir
?
"
abruptly
turning
to
Mr
Winkle
.
       
<EOS>
[
<EOS>
*
<EOS>
A
remarkable
instance
of
the
prophetic
force
of
Mr
       
Jingle
's
imagination
;
this
dialogue
occurring
in
the
year
       
1827
,
and
the
Revolution
in
1830
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
,
Sir
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fine
pursuit
,
sir
---
fine
pursuit
.
<EOS>
---
Dogs
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
just
now
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
should
keep
dogs
---
fine
animals
---
sagacious
creatures
 
---
dog
of
my
own
once
---
pointer
---
surprising
instinct
---
out
shooting
one
day
---
entering
inclosure
---
<EOS>
whistled
---
dog
stopped
---
<EOS>
whistled
again
---
Ponto
---
no
go
;
stock
still
---
called
him
---
<EOS>
Ponto
,
Ponto
---
would
n't
move
---
dog
transfixed
---
staring
at
a
board
---
looked
up
,
saw
an
inscription
---
"
Gamekeeper
has
orders
to
shoot
all
dogs
found
in
this
inclosure
"
---
would

pass

---
wonderful
dog
---
valuable
dog
<EOS>
that
---
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Singular
circumstance
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
make
a
note
of

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
,
certainly
---
hundred
more
anecdotes
of
the
same
animal
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Fine
girl
,
Sir
"
(
to
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
,
who
had
been

sundry

Pickwickian

on

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
!
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
English
girls
not
so
fine
as
Spanish
---
noble
creatures
---
<EOS>
jet
hair
 
---
<EOS>
black
eyes
---
lovely
forms
---
sweet
creatures
---
beautiful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
in
Spain
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lived
there
---
ages
.
"
<EOS>
"
Many
conquests
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Conquests
!
<EOS>
Thousands
.
 
<EOS>
Don
Bolaro
Fizzgig
---
grandee
---
only
daughter
---
Donna
Christina
---
splendid
creature
---
loved
me
to
distraction
---
jealous
father
---
high
-
souled
daughter
---
handsome
Englishman
---
Donna
Christina
in
despair
---
prussic
acid
---
<EOS>
stomach
pump
in
my
portmanteau
---
<EOS>
operation
performed
---
old
Bolaro
in
ecstasies
---
<EOS>
consent
to
our
union
---
join
hands
and
floods
of
tears
---
romantic
story
---
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
the
lady
in
England
now
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tupman
,
on
whom
the
description
of
her
charms
had
produced
a
powerful

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
,
sir
---
dead
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
applying
to
his
right
eye
the
brief
remnant
of
a
very
old
cambric
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
recovered
the
stomach
pump
---
undermined
constitution
---
fell
a
victim
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
her
father
?
"
inquired
the
poetic
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Remorse
and
misery
,
"
replied
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sudden
disappearance
---
talk
of
the
whole
city
---
search
made
everywhere
without
success
---
<EOS>
public
fountain
in
the
great
square
suddenly
ceased
playing
---
weeks
elapsed
---
still
a
stoppage
---
<EOS>
workmen
employed
to
clean
it
---
water
drawn
off
---
father
-
in
-
law
discovered
sticking
head
first
in
the
main
pipe
,
with
a
full
confession
in
his
right
boot
---
took
him
out
,
and
the
fountain
played
away
again
,
as
well
as
ever
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
note
that
little
romance
down
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
deeply
affected
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
,
certainly
---
fifty
more
if
you
like
to
hear
'em
---
<EOS>
strange
life
mine
---
rather
curious
history
---
not
extraordinary
,
but
singular
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
this
strain
,
with
an
occasional
glass
of
ale
,
by
way
of
parenthesis
,
when
the
coach
changed

,
did
the
stranger
proceed
,
until
they
reached
Rochester
bridge
,
by
which
time
the
note
-
books
,
both
of
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
were
completely
filled
with
selections
from
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Magnificent
ruin
!
"
said
Mr
Augustus
Snodgrass
,
with
all
the
poetic
fervour
that
distinguished

,
when
they
came
in
sight
of
the
fine
old
castle
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
sight
for
an
antiquarian
!
"
were
the
very
words
which
fell
from
Mr
Pickwick
's
mouth
,
as

applied
his

to
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
fine
place
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
glorious
pile
---
frowning
walls
---
<EOS>
tottering
arches
---
dark
nooks
---
crumbling
staircases
---
<EOS>
old
cathedral
too
---
<EOS>
earthy
smell
---
<EOS>
pilgrims
"
feet
wore
away
the
old
steps
---
little
Saxon
doors
---
confessionals
like
money
-
takers
"
boxes
at
theatres
---
queer
customers
those
monks
---
popes
,
and
lord

,
and
all
sorts
of
old
fellows
,
with
great
red
faces
,
and
broken
noses
,
turning
up
every
day
---
buff
jerkins
too
---
<EOS>
match
-
locks
---
sarcophagus
---
<EOS>
fine
place
---
<EOS>
old
legends
too
---
<EOS>
strange
stories
:
capital
;
"
and
the
stranger
continued
to
soliloquise
until
they
reached
the
Bull
Inn
,
in
the
High
Street
,
where
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remain
here
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Nathaniel
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
---
not
I
---
<EOS>
but
you
'd
better
---
good
house
---
nice
beds
---
<EOS>
Wright
's
next
house
,
dear
---
very
dear
---
half
-
a
-
crown
in
the
bill
if
you
look
at
the
waiter
---
charge
you
more
if
you
dine
at
a
friend
's
than
they
would
if
you
dined
in
the
coffee
-
room
---
rum
fellows
---
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
turned
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
murmured
a
few
words
;
a
whisper
passed
from
Mr
Pickwick
to
Mr
Snodgrass
,
from
Mr
Snodgrass
to
Mr
Tupman
,
and
nods
of
assent
were
exchanged
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
addressed
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
rendered
us
a
very
important
service
this
morning
,
sir
,
"
said
he
,
"
will
you
allow
us
to
offer
a
slight
mark
of
our
gratitude
by
begging
the
favour
of
your
company
at
dinner
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Great
pleasure
---
not
presume
to
dictate
,
but
broiled
fowl
and
mushrooms
---
capital
thing
!
<EOS>
What
time
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
referring
to
his
watch
,
"
it
is
now
nearly
three
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
we
say
five
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Suit
me
excellently
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
five
precisely
---
till
then
---
care
of
yourselves
;
"
and
lifting
the
pinched
-
up
hat
a
few
inches
from
his
head
,
and
carelessly
replacing
it
very
much
on
one
side
,
the
stranger
,
with
half
the
brown
paper
parcel
sticking
out
of
his
pocket
,
walked
briskly
up
the
yard
,
and
turned
into
the
High
Street
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Evidently
a
traveller
in
many
countries
,
and
a
close
observer
of
men
and
things
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
see
his
poem
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
have
seen
that
dog
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
said
nothing
;
but
he
thought
of
Donna
Christina
,
the
stomach
pump
,
and
the
fountain
;
and
his
eyes
filled
with
tears
.
   
<EOS>
A
private
sitting
-
room
having
been
engaged
,
bedrooms
inspected
,
and
dinner
ordered
,
the
party
walked
out
to
view
the
city
and
adjoining
neighbourhood
.
   
<EOS>
We
do
not
find
,
from
a
careful
perusal
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
notes
of
the
four
towns
,
Stroud
,
Rochester
,
Chatham
,
and
Brompton
,
that
his
impressions
of
their
appearance
differ
in
any
material
point
from
those
of
other
travellers
who
have
gone
over
the
same
ground
.
 
<EOS>
His
general
description
is
easily
abridged
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
principal
productions
of
these
towns
,
"
says
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
appear
to
be
soldiers
,
sailors
,
Jews
,
chalk
,
shrimps
,
officers
,
and
dockyard
men
.
 
<EOS>
The
commodities
chiefly
exposed
for
sale
in
the
public
streets
are
marine
stores
,
hard
-
bake
,
apples
,
flat
-
fish
,
and
oysters
.
 
<EOS>
The
streets
present
a
lively
and
animated
appearance
,
occasioned
chiefly
by
the
conviviality
of
the
military
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
truly
delightful
to
a
philanthropic
mind
to
see
these
gallant
men
staggering
along
under
the
influence
of
an
overflow
both
of
animal
and
ardent
spirits
;
more
especially
when
we
remember
that
the
following
them
about
,
and
jesting
with
them
,
affords
a
cheap
and
innocent
amusement
for
the
boy
population
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
,
"
adds
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
can
exceed
their
good
-
humour
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
<EOS>
but
the
day
before
my
arrival
that
one
of
them
had
been
most
grossly
insulted
in
the
house
of
a
publican
.
 
<EOS>
The
barmaid
had
positively
refused
to
draw
him
any
more
liquor
;
in
return
for
which
he
had
(
merely
in
playfulness
)
drawn
his
bayonet
,
and
wounded
the
girl
in
the
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
this
fine
fellow
was
the
very
first
to
go
down
to
the
house
next
morning
and
express
his
readiness
to
overlook
the
matter
,
and
forget
what
had
occurred
!
   
<EOS>
"
The
consumption
of
tobacco
in
these
towns
,
"
continues
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
must
be
very
great
,
and
the
smell
which
pervades
the
streets
must
be
exceedingly
delicious
to
those
who
are
extremely
fond
of
smoking
.
 
<EOS>
A
superficial
traveller
might
object
to
the
dirt
,
which
is
their
leading
characteristic
;
but
to
those
who
view
it
as
an
indication
of
traffic
and
commercial
prosperity
,
it
is
truly
gratifying
.
"
   
<EOS>
Punctual
to
five
o'clock
came
the
stranger
,
and
shortly
afterwards
the
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
divested
himself
of
his
brown
paper
parcel
,
but
had
made
no
alteration
in
his
attire
,
and
was
,
if
possible
,
more
loquacious
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
,
as
the
waiter
removed
one
of
the
covers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Soles
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Soles
---
ah
!
---
capital
fish
---
all
come
from
London
-
stage
-
coach
proprietors
get
up
political
dinners
---
carriage
of
soles
---
dozens
of
baskets
---
cunning
fellows
.
 
<EOS>
Glass
of
wine
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
pleasure
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
the
stranger
took
wine
,
first
with
him
,
and
then
with
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
then
with
Mr
Tupman
,
and
then
with
Mr
Winkle
,
and
then
with
the
whole
party
together
,
almost
as

as
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
Devil
of
a
mess
on
the
staircase
,
waiter
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
Forms
going
up
---
carpenters
coming
down
---
lamps
,
glasses
,
harps
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
going
forward
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ball
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Assembly
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
not
assembly
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Ball
for
the
benefit
of
a
charity
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Many
fine
women
in
this
town
,
do
you
know
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Tupman
,
with
great

.
   
<EOS>
"
Splendid
---
capital
.
 
<EOS>
Kent
,
sir
---
everybody
knows
Kent
---
apples
,

,
hops
,
and
women
.
 
<EOS>
Glass
of
wine
,
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
great
pleasure
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
filled
,
and
emptied
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
very
much
like

go
,
"
said
Mr

,

,
"
very

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tickets
at

,
Sir
,
"
interposed

;
"
half
-
a
-
guinea

,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
again
expressed
an
earnest

to
be
present
at
the

;
but
meeting
with
no

,

,

to
the
port
wine
and

,

just

on

.
 
<EOS>
The
waiter
withdrew
,
and
the
party
were
left
to

cosy

of
hours
succeeding

.
   
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
bottle
stands
---
<EOS>
pass
it
round
---
way
of
the
sun
---
through
the
button
-
hole
---
no
heeltaps
,
"
and
he
emptied
his
glass
,
which
he
had
filled
about
two
minutes
before
,
and
poured
out
another
,
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
was
used
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
wine
was
passed
,
and
a
fresh
supply
ordered
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
talked
,
the
Pickwickians
listened
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
felt
every
moment
more
disposed
for
the
ball
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
countenance
glowed
with
an
expression
of
universal
philanthropy
,
and
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
fell
fast
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
're
beginning
upstairs
,
"
said
the
stranger
---
"
hear
the
company
---
fiddles
tuning
---
now
the
harp
---
there
they
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
various
sounds
which
found
their
way
downstairs
announced
the
commencement
of
the
first
quadrille
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
I
should
like
to
go
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
should
I
,
"
said
the
stranger
---
"
confounded
luggage
,
---
heavy
smacks
---
nothing
to
go
in
---
<EOS>
odd
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Now
general
benevolence
was
one
of
the
leading
features
of
the
Pickwickian
theory
,
and
no
one
was
more
remarkable
for
the
zealous
manner
in
which
he
observed
so
noble
a
principle
than
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
The
number
of
instances
recorded
on
the
Transactions
of
the
Society
,
in
which
that
excellent
man
referred
objects
of
charity
to
the
houses
of
other
members
for
left
-
off
garments
or
pecuniary
relief
is
almost
incredible
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
happy
to
lend
you
a
change
of
apparel
for
the
purpose
,
"
said
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
,
"
but
you
are
rather
slim
,
and
I
am
---
"
   
"
Rather
fat
---
grown
-
up
Bacchus
<EOS>
---
cut
the
leaves
---
dismounted
from
the
tub
,
and
adopted
kersey
,
eh
?
---
not
double
distilled
,
but
double
milled
---
ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
pass
the
wine
.
"
   
<EOS>
Whether
Mr
Tupman
was
somewhat
indignant
at
the
peremptory
tone
in
which
he
was
desired
to
pass
the
wine
which
the
stranger
passed
so
quickly
away
,
or
whether
he
felt
very
properly
scandalised
at
an
influential
member
of
the
Pickwick
Club
being
ignominiously
compared
to
a
dismounted
Bacchus
,
is
a
fact
not
yet
completely
ascertained
.
 
<EOS>
He
passed
the
wine
,
coughed
twice
,
and
looked
at
the
stranger
for
several
seconds
with
a
stern
intensity
;
as
that
individual
,
however
,
appeared
perfectly
collected
,
and
quite
calm
under
his
searching
glance
,
he
gradually
relaxed
,
and
reverted
to
the
subject
of
the
ball
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
about
to
observe
,
Sir
,
"
he
said
,
"
that
though
my
apparel
would
be
too
large
,
a
suit
of
my
friend
Mr
Winkle
's
would
,
perhaps
,
fit
you
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
took
Mr
Winkle
's
measure
with
his
eye
,
and
that
feature
glistened
with
satisfaction
as
he
said
,
"
Just
the
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
looked
round
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
wine
,
which
had
exerted
its
somniferous
influence
over
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
,
had
stolen
upon
the
senses
of
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
That
gentleman
had
gradually
passed
through
the
various
stages
which
precede
the
lethargy
produced
by
dinner
,
and
its
consequences
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
undergone
the
ordinary
transitions
from
the
height
of
conviviality
to
the
depth
of
misery
,
and
from
the
depth
of
misery
to
the
height
of
conviviality
.
 
<EOS>
Like
a
gas
-
lamp
in
the
street
,
with
the
wind
in
the
pipe
,
he
had
exhibited
for
a
moment
an
unnatural
brilliancy
,
then
sank
so
low
as
to
be
scarcely
discernible
;
after
a
short
interval
,
he
had
burst
out
again
,
to
enlighten
for
a
moment
;
then
flickered
with
an
uncertain
,
staggering
sort
of
light
,
and
then
gone
out
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
His
head
was
sunk
upon
his
bosom
,
and
perpetual
snoring
,
with
a
partial
choke
occasionally
,
were
the
only
audible
indications
of
the
great
man
's
presence
.
   
<EOS>
The
temptation
to
be
present
at
the
ball
,
and
to
form
his
first
impressions
of
the
beauty
of
the
Kentish
ladies
,
was
strong
upon
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
The
temptation
to
take
the
stranger
with
him
was
equally
great
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
wholly
unacquainted
with
the
place
and
its
inhabitants
,
and
the
stranger
seemed
to
possess
as
great
a
knowledge
of
both
as
if
he
had
lived
there
from
his
infancy
.
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
was
asleep
,
and
Mr
Tupman
had
had
sufficient
experience
in
such
matters
to
know
that
the
moment
he
awoke
he
would
,
in
the
ordinary
course
of
nature
,
roll
heavily
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
undecided
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fill
your
glass
,
and
pass
the
wine
,
"
said
the
indefatigable
visitor
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
did
as
he
was

;
and
the
additional

of
the
last
glass
settled
his
determination
.
   
<EOS>
"
Winkle
's
bedroom
is
inside

,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
;
"
I
could
n't
make
him
understand
what
I
wanted
,
if
I
woke

now
,
but
<EOS>
I
know
he
has
a
dress
-

in

;
and

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
,
"
said

,
"
famous

---
damned

---
fourteen

cases
,
and

another
man
's
---

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

,
"
toss

---
<EOS>
I

;

---
first

---
woman
---
woman
---
bewitching
woman
,
"
and

sovereign
with
the

(
called

a
woman
)
uppermost
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
rang

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

the

in

of
Mr
Nathaniel
Winkle
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

Tupman
,
as

with

;
"
the
first
that
's

our

,
"
and

"
attention
to

of
Mr
Pickwick
in

,

"
P*C
"
 
on

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
P*C
"
"
said
<EOS>
the

---
"
queer
set
out
---
old
fellow
's

,

"
P*C.
"
---
<EOS>
What

"
P*C
"
 
<EOS>
stand

---
Peculiar

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
with
rising

and

,
explained
the
mystic
device
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rather
short
in
the
waist
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
said
the
stranger
,
screwing
himself
round
to

in
the
glass
of
the

,
which
were
half
-
way

.
 
<EOS>
"
Like
a
general
postman
's
coat
 
---
queer
coats
those
---
made
by

---
no
measuring
---
mysterious
dispensations
of
Providence
---
all
the
short
men
get
long
coats
---
all
the
long
men
short
ones
.
"
 
<EOS>
Running
on
in
this

,
Mr
Tupman
's

adjusted

,
or
rather
the

of
Mr
Winkle
;
and
,

Mr
Tupman
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
names
,
sir
?
"
said
the
man
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
was
stepping

to
announce
his
own

,
when
the
stranger
prevented

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
names
at
all
<EOS>
;
"
and
then

Mr
Tupman
,
"
names
wo
n't
do
---
not

---
very

,
but

---
capital

,

wo

---
incog
.
<EOS>
the
thing
---
gentlemen
from
London
---
distinguished

---
anything
.
<EOS>
"
The
door
was

,
and
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
and
the
stranger
entered
the
ballroom
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
room
,
with
crimson
-
covered
benches
,
and
wax
candles
in
glass
chandeliers
.
 
<EOS>
The
musicians
were
securely
confined
in
an
elevated
den
,
and
quadrilles
were
being
systematically
got
through
by
two
or
three
sets
of
dancers
.
 
<EOS>
Two
card
-
tables
were
made
up
in
the
adjoining
card
-
room
,
and
two
pair
of
old
ladies
,
and
a
corresponding
number
of
stout
gentlemen
,
were
executing
whist
therein
.
   
<EOS>
The
finale
concluded
,
the
dancers
promenaded
the
room
,
and
Mr
Tupman
and
his
companion
stationed
themselves
in
a
corner
to
observe
the
company
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
women
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
minute
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
fun
presently
<EOS>
---
nobs
not
come
yet
---
<EOS>
queer
place
---
<EOS>
dockyard
people
of
upper
rank
do
n't
know
dockyard
people
of
lower
rank
---
dockyard
people
of
lower
rank
do
n't
know
small
gentry
---
small

do
n't
know
tradespeople
---
commissioner
do
n't
know
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
little
boy
with
the
light

and

,
in

?
"
<EOS>

Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
pray
---
pink

---
fancy

---
<EOS>
little

---
nonsense
---
<EOS>
ensign
97th
<EOS>
---
Honourable
Wilmot
Snipe
---
great

---
Snipes
---
<EOS>
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
Thomas
Clubber
,
Lady
Clubber
,
and
the
Misses
Clubber
!
"
shouted
the
man
at

door
in

.
 
<EOS>
A
great
sensation
was
created
throughout
the
room
by
the
entrance
of
a
tall
gentleman
in
a
blue
coat
and
bright
buttons
,
a
large
lady
in
blue

,
and
two
young
ladies
,
on
a
similar

,
in
fashionably
-

dresses
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Commissioner
---
head
of
the
yard
---
great
man
---
remarkably
great
man
,
"
whispered
the
stranger
in
Mr
Tupman
's
ear
,
as
the
charitable
committee
ushered
Sir
Thomas
Clubber
and
family
to
the
top
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
Honourable
Wilmot
Snipe
,
and
other
distinguished
gentlemen
crowded
to
render
homage
to
the
Misses
Clubber
;
and
Sir
Thomas
Clubber
stood
bolt
upright
,
and
looked

over
his
black
kerchief
at
the
assembled
company
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Smithie
,
Mrs
Smithie
,
and
the
Misses
Smithie
,
"
was

next

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
Mr
Smithie
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Something
in
the
yard
,
"
replied
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smithie
bowed
deferentially
to
Sir
Thomas
Clubber
;
and
Sir
Thomas
Clubber
acknowledged
the
salute
with
conscious

.
<EOS>
Lady
Clubber
took
a

of
Mrs
Smithie
and

through
her

-
glass
and
Mrs

at
Mrs
Somebody
-
else
,
whose
husband
was
not
in
the

at
