.
   
<EOS>
"
Colonel
Bulder
,
Mrs
Colonel
Bulder
,
and
Miss
Bulder
,
"
were
the
next
arrivals
.
   
<EOS>
"
Head
of
the
garrison
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
in
reply
to
Mr
Tupman
's
inquiring
look
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Bulder
was
warmly
welcomed
by
the
Misses
Clubber
;
the
greeting
between
Mrs
Colonel
Bulder
and
Lady
Clubber
was
of
the
most
affectionate
description
;
Colonel
Bulder
and
Sir
Thomas
Clubber
exchanged
snuff
-
boxes
,
and
looked
very
much
like
a
pair
of
Alexander
Selkirks
---
"
Monarchs
of
all
they
surveyed
.
"
   
<EOS>
While
the
aristocracy
of
the
place
---
the
Bulders
,
and
Clubbers
,
and
Snipes
---
were
thus
preserving
their
dignity
at
the
upper
end
of
the
room
,
the
other
classes
of
society
were
imitating
their
example
in
other
parts
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
less
aristocratic
officers
of
the
97th
devoted
themselves
to
the
families
of
the
less
important
functionaries
from
the
dockyard
.
 
<EOS>
The
solicitors
"
wives
,
and
the
wine
-
merchant
's
wife
,
headed
another
grade
(
the
brewer
's
wife
visited
the
Bulders
)
;
and
Mrs
Tomlinson
,
the
post
-
office
keeper
,
seemed
by
mutual
consent
to
have
been
chosen
the
leader
of
the
trade
party
.
   
<EOS>
One
of
the
most
popular
personages
,
in
his
own
circle
,
present
,
was
a
little
fat
man
,
with
a
ring
of
upright
black
hair
round
his
head
,
and
an
extensive
bald
plain
on
the
top
of
it
---
Doctor
Slammer
,
surgeon
to
the
97th
.
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
took
snuff
with
everybody
,
chatted
with
everybody
,
laughed
,
danced
,
made
jokes
,
played
whist
,
did
everything
,
and
was
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
To
these
pursuits
,
multifarious
as
they
were
,
the
little
doctor
added
a
more
important
one
than
any
<EOS>
---
he
was
indefatigable
in
paying
the
most
unremitting
and
devoted
attention
to
a
little
old
widow
,
whose
rich
dress
and
profusion
of
ornament
bespoke
her
a
most
desirable
addition
to
a
limited
income
.
   
<EOS>
Upon
the
doctor
,
and
the
widow
,
the
eyes
of
both
Mr
Tupman
and
his
companion
had
been
fixed
for
some
time
,
when
the
stranger
broke
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lots
of
money
---
old
girl
---
pompous
doctor
---
not
a
bad
idea
---
good
fun
,
"
were
the
intelligible
sentences
which
issued
from
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
looked
inquisitively
in
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
dance
with
the
widow
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
she
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
---
never
saw
her
in
all
my
life
---
cut
out
the
doctor
 
---
here
goes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
stranger
forthwith
crossed
the
room
;
and
,
leaning
against
a
mantel
-
piece
,
commenced
gazing
with
an
air
of
respectful
and
melancholy
admiration
on
the
fat
countenance
of
the
little
old
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
looked
on
,
in
mute
astonishment
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
progressed
rapidly
;
the
little
doctor
danced
with
another
lady
;
the
widow
dropped
her
fan
;
the
stranger
picked
it
up
,
and
presented
it
---
a
smile
---
a
bow
---
a
curtsey
---
a
few
words
of
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
walked
boldly
up
to
,
and
returned
with
,
the
master
of
the
ceremonies
;
a
little
introductory
pantomime
;
and
the
stranger
and
Mrs
Budger
took
their
places
in
a
quadrille
.
   
<EOS>
The
surprise
of
Mr
Tupman
at
this
summary
proceeding
,
great
as
it
was
,
was
immeasurably
exceeded
by
the
astonishment
of
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
young
,
and
the
widow
was
flattered
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
's
attentions
were
unheeded
by
the
widow
;
and
the
doctor
's
indignation
was
wholly
lost
on
his
imperturbable
rival
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Slammer
was
paralysed
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
Doctor
Slammer
,
of
the
97th
,
to
be
extinguished
in
a
moment
,
by
a
man
whom
nobody
had
ever
seen
before
,
and
whom
nobody
knew
even
now
!
<EOS>
Doctor
Slammer
---
Doctor
Slammer
of
the
97th
rejected
!
<EOS>
Impossible
!
<EOS>
It
could
not
be
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
it
was
;
there
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
introducing
his
friend
!
<EOS>
Could
he
believe
his
eyes
!
<EOS>
He
looked
again
,
and
was
under
the
painful
necessity
of
admitting
the
veracity
of
his
optics
;
Mrs
Budger
was
dancing
with
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
;
there
was
no
mistaking
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
widow
before
him
,
bouncing
bodily
here
and
there
,
with
unwonted
vigour
;
and
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
hopping
about
,
with
a
face
expressive
of
the
most
intense
solemnity
,
dancing
(
as
a
good
many
people
do
)
as
if
a
quadrille
were
not
a
thing
to
be
laughed
at
,
but
a
severe
trial
to
the
feelings
,
which
it
requires
inflexible
resolution
to
encounter
.
   
<EOS>
Silently
and
patiently
did
the
doctor
bear
all
this
,
and
all
the
handings
of
negus
,
and
watching
for
glasses
,
and
darting
for
biscuits
,
and
coquetting
,
that
ensued
;
but
,
a
few
seconds
after
the
stranger
had
disappeared
to
lead
Mrs
Budger
to
her
carriage
,
he
darted
swiftly
from
the
room
with
every
particle
of
his
hitherto
-
bottled
-
up
indignation
effervescing
,
from
all
parts
of
his
countenance
,
in
a
perspiration
of
passion
.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
returning
,
and
Mr
Tupman
was
beside
him
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
a
low
tone
,
and
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
doctor
thirsted
for
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
exulting
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
triumphed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
,
in
an
awful
voice
,
producing
a
card
,
and
retiring
into
an
angle
of
the
passage
,
"
my
name
is
Slammer
,
Doctor
Slammer
,
sir
---
97th
Regiment
---
<EOS>
Chatham
Barracks
---
my
card
,
Sir
,
my
card
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
added
more
,
but
his
indignation
choked
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
replied
the
stranger
coolly
,
"
Slammer
---
much
obliged
---
polite
attention
---
not
ill
now
,
Slammer
---
<EOS>
but
when
I
am
---
knock
you
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
---
you
're
a
shuffler
,
sir
,
"
gasped
the
furious
doctor
,
"
a
poltroon
---
a
coward
---
a
liar
---
<EOS>
a
---
a
---
will
nothing
induce
you
to
give
me
your
card
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I
see
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
half
aside
,
"
negus
too
strong
here
 
---
liberal
landlord
---
<EOS>
very
foolish
---
<EOS>
very
---
lemonade
much
better
 
---
hot
rooms
---
elderly
gentlemen
---
suffer
for
it
in
the
morning
---
cruel
---
cruel
;
"
and
he
moved
on
a
step
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
stopping
in
this
house
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
indignant
little
man
;
"
you
are
intoxicated
now
,
Sir
;
you
shall
hear
from
me
in
the
morning
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
find
you
out
,
sir
;
I
shall
find
you
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
you
found
me
out
than
found
me
at
home
,
"
replied
the
unmoved
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
Doctor
Slammer
looked
unutterable
ferocity
,
as
he
fixed
his
hat
on
his
head
with
an
indignant
knock
;
and
the
stranger
and
Mr
Tupman
ascended
to
the
bedroom
of
the
latter
to
restore
the
borrowed
plumage
to
the
unconscious
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
That
gentleman
was
fast
asleep
;
the
restoration
was
soon
made
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
extremely
jocose
;
and
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
,
being
quite
bewildered
with
wine
,
negus
,
lights
,
and
ladies
,
thought
the
whole
affair
was
an
exquisite
joke
.
 
<EOS>
His
new
friend
departed
;
and
,
after
experiencing
some
slight
difficulty
in
finding
the
orifice
in
his
nightcap
,
originally
intended
for
the
reception
of
his
head
,
and
finally
overturning
his
candlestick
in
his
struggles
to
put
it
on
,
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
managed
to
get
into
bed
by
a
series
of
complicated
evolutions
,
and
shortly
afterwards
sank
into
repose
.
   
<EOS>
Seven
o'clock
had
hardly
ceased
striking
on
the
following
morning
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
's
comprehensive
mind
was
aroused
from
the
state
of
unconsciousness
,
in
which
slumber
had
plunged
it
,
by
a
loud
knocking
at
his
chamber
door
.
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
starting
up
in
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Boots
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Please
,
sir
,
can
you
tell
me
which
gentleman
of
your
party
wears
a
bright
blue
dress
-
coat
,
with
a
gilt
button
with
"
P*C
"
on
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
been
given
out
to
brush
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
and
the
man
has
forgotten
whom
it
belongs
to
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Winkle
,
"
he
called
out
,
"
next
room
but
two
,
on
the
right
hand
.
"
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
sir
,
"
said
the
Boots
,
and
away
he
went
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Tupman
,
as
a
loud
knocking
at
his
door
roused
hint
from
his
oblivious
repose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
I
speak
to
Mr
Winkle
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Boots
from
the
outside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Winkle
---
Winkle
!
"
shouted
Mr
Tupman
,
calling
into
the
inner
room
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hollo
!
"
replied
a
faint
voice
from
within
the
bed
-
clothes
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
wanted
---
some
one
at
the
door
;
"
and
,
having
exerted
himself
to
articulate
thus
much
<EOS>
,
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
turned
round
and
fell
fast
asleep
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wanted
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
hastily
jumping
out
of
bed
,
and
putting
on
a
few
articles
of
clothing
;
"
wanted
!
<EOS>
at
this
distance
from
town
---
who
on
earth
can
want
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gentleman
in
the
coffee
-
room
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
Boots
,
as
Mr
Winkle
opened
the
door
and
confronted
him
;
"
gentleman
says
he
'll
not
detain
you
a
moment
,
Sir
,
but
he
can
take
no
denial
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
odd
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
;
"
I
'll
be
down
directly
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
hurriedly
wrapped
himself
in
a
travelling
-
shawl
and
dressing
-
gown
,
and
proceeded
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
woman
and
a
couple
of
waiters
were
cleaning
the
coffee
-
room
,
and
an
officer
in
undress
uniform
was
looking
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
round
as
Mr
Winkle
entered
,
and
made
a
stiff
inclination
of
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
Having
ordered
the
attendants
to
retire
,
and
closed
the
door
very
carefully
,
he
said
,
"
Mr
Winkle
,
I
presume
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Winkle
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
be
surprised
,
sir
,
when
I
inform
you
that
I
have
called
here
this
morning
on
behalf
of
my
friend
,
Doctor
Slammer
,
of
the
97th
.
"
   
"
Doctor
Slammer
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Slammer
.
 
<EOS>
He
begged
me
to
express
his
opinion
that
your
conduct
of
last
evening
was
of
a
description
which
no
gentleman
could
endure
;
and
"
(
he
added
)
"
which
no
one
gentleman
would
pursue
towards
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
's
astonishment
was
too
real
,
and
too
evident
,
to
escape
the
observation
of
Doctor
Slammer
's
friend
;
he
therefore
proceeded
---
"
<EOS>
My
friend
,
Doctor
Slammer
,
requested
me
to
add
,
that
he
was
firmly
persuaded
you
were
intoxicated
during
a
portion
of
the
evening
,
and
possibly
unconscious
of
the
extent
of
the
insult
you
were
guilty
of
.
 
<EOS>
He
commissioned
me
to
say
,
that
should
this
be
pleaded
as
an
excuse
for
your
behaviour
,
he
will
consent
to
accept
a
written
apology
,
to
be
penned
by
you
,
from
my
dictation
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
written
apology
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Winkle
,
in
the
most
emphatic
tone
of
amazement
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
you
know
the
alternative
,
"
replied
the
visitor
coolly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Were
you
intrusted
with
this
message
to
me
by
name
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
whose
intellects
were
hopelessly
confused
by
this
extraordinary
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
present
myself
,
"
replied
the
visitor
,
"
and
in
consequence
of
your
firm
refusal
to
give
your
card
to
Doctor
Slammer
,
I
was
desired
by
that
gentleman
to
identify
the
wearer
of
a
very
uncommon
coat
---
a
bright
blue
dress
-
coat
,
with
a
gilt
button
displaying
a
bust
,
and
the
letters
"
P*C.
"
"
   
Mr
Winkle
actually
staggered
with
astonishment
as
he
heard
his
own
costume
thus
minutely
described
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Slammer
's
friend
proceeded
:
---
"
From
the
inquiries
I
made
at
the
bar
,
just
now
,
I
was
convinced
that
the
owner
of
the
coat
in
question
arrived
here
,
with
three
gentlemen
,
yesterday
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
I
immediately
sent
up
to
the
gentleman
who
was
described
as
appearing
the
head
of
the
party
,
and
he
at
once
referred
me
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
the
principal
tower
of
Rochester
Castle
had
suddenly
walked
from
its
foundation
,
and
stationed
itself
opposite
the
coffee
-
room
window
,
Mr
Winkle
's
surprise
would
have
been
as
nothing
compared
with
the
profound
astonishment
with
which
he
had
heard
this
address
.
 
<EOS>
His
first
impression
was
that
his
coat
had
been
stolen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
detain
you
one
moment
?
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
the
unwelcome
visitor
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
ran
hastily
upstairs
,
and
with
a
trembling
hand
opened
the
bag
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
coat
in
its
usual
place
,
but
exhibiting
,
on
a
close
inspection
,
evident
tokens
of
having
been
worn
on
the
preceding
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
so
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
letting
the
coat
fall
from
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
took
too
much
wine
after
dinner
,
and
have
a
very
vague
recollection
of
walking
about
the
streets
,
and
smoking
a
cigar
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
I
was
very
drunk
;
---
I
must
have
changed
my
coat
---
gone
somewhere
---
and
insulted
somebody
<EOS>
---
I
have
no
doubt
of
it
;
and
this
message
is
the
terrible
consequence
.
"
 
<EOS>
Saying
which
,
Mr
Winkle
retraced
his
steps
in
the
direction
of
the
coffee
-
room
,
with
the
gloomy
and
dreadful
resolve
of
accepting
the
challenge
of
the
warlike
Doctor
Slammer
,
and
abiding
by
the
worst
consequences
that
might
ensue
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
determination
Mr
Winkle
was
urged
by
a
variety
of
considerations
,
the
first
of
which
was
his
reputation
with
the
club
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
always
been
looked
up
to
as
a
high
authority
on
all
matters
of
amusement
and
dexterity
,
whether
offensive
,
defensive
,
or
inoffensive
;
and
if
,
on
this
very
first
occasion
of
being
put
to
the
test
,
he
shrunk
back
from
the
trial
,
beneath
his
leader
's
eye
,
his
name
and
standing
were
lost
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
he
remembered
to
have
heard
it
frequently
surmised
by
the
uninitiated
in
such
matters
that
by
an
understood
arrangement
between
the
seconds
,
the
pistols
were
seldom
loaded
with
ball
;
and
,
furthermore
,
he
reflected
that
if
he
applied
to
Mr
Snodgrass
to
act
as
his
second
,
and
depicted
the
danger
in
glowing
terms
,
that
gentleman
might
possibly
communicate
the
intelligence
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
would
certainly
lose
no
time
in
transmitting
it
to
the
local
authorities
,
and
thus
prevent
the
killing
or
maiming
of
his
follower
.
   
<EOS>
Such
were
his
thoughts
when
he
returned
to
the
coffee
-
room
,
and
intimated
his
intention
of
accepting
the
doctor
's
challenge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
refer
me
to
a
friend
,
to
arrange
the
time
and
place
of
meeting
?
"
said
the
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
unnecessary
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
;
"
name
them
to
me
,
and
I
can
procure
the
attendance
of
a
friend
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
say
---
sunset
this
evening
?
"
inquired
the
officer
,
in
a
careless
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
thinking
in
his
heart
it
was
very
bad
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
Fort
Pitt
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
saw
it
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
take
the
trouble
to
turn
into
the
field
which
borders
the
trench
,
take
the
foot
-
path
to
the
left
when
you
arrive
at
an
angle
of
the
fortification
,
and
keep
straight
on
,
till
you
see
me
,
I
will
precede
you
to
a
secluded
place
,
where
the
affair
can
be
conducted
without
fear
of
interruption
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fear
of
interruption
!
"
thought
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
to
arrange
,
I
think
,
"
said
the
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
aware
of
anything
more
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
morning
;
"
and
the
officer
whistled
a
lively
air
as
he
strode
away
.
   
<EOS>
That
morning
's
breakfast
passed
heavily
off
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
was
not
in
a
condition
to
rise
,
after
the
unwonted
dissipation
of
the
previous
night
;
Mr
Snodgrass
appeared
to
labour
under
a
poetical
depression
of
spirits
;
and
even
Mr
Pickwick
evinced
an
unusual
attachment
to
silence
and
soda
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
eagerly
watched
his
opportunity
:
it
was
not
long
wanting
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
proposed
a
visit
to
the
castle
,
and
as
Mr
Winkle
was
the
only
other
member
of
the
party
disposed
to
walk
,
they
went
out
together
.
<EOS>
"
Snodgrass
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
when
they
had
turned
out
of
the
public
street
.
 
<EOS>
"
Snodgrass
,
my
dear
fellow
,
can
I
rely
upon
your
secrecy
?
<EOS>
"
As
he
said
this
,
he
most
devoutly
and
earnestly
hoped
he
could
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
swear
---
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
"
interrupted
Winkle
,
terrified
at
the
idea
of
his
companion
's
unconsciously
pledging
himself
not
to
give
information
;
"
do
n't
swear
,
do
n't
swear
;
it
's
quite
unnecessary
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
dropped
the
hand
which
he
had
,
in
the
spirit
of
poesy
,
raised
towards
the
clouds
as
he
made
the
above
appeal
,
and
assumed
an
attitude
of
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
your
assistance
,
my
dear
fellow
,
in
an
affair
of
honour
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
it
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
,
clasping
his
friend
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
a
doctor
---
Doctor
Slammer
,
of
the
97th
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
wishing
to
make
the
matter
appear
as
solemn
as
possible
;
"
an
affair
with
an
officer
,
seconded
by
another
officer
,
at
sunset
this
evening
,
in
a
lonely
field
beyond
Fort
Pitt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
attend
you
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
astonished
,
but
by
no
means
dismayed
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
extraordinary
how
cool
any
party
but
<EOS>
the
principal
can
be
in
such
cases
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
had
forgotten
this
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
judged
of
his
friend
's
feelings
by
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
consequences
may
be
dreadful
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
I
believe
,
is
a
very
good
shot
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Most
of
these
military
men
are
,
"
observed
Mr
Snodgrass
calmly
;
"
but
so
are
you
,
ai
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
replied
in
the
affirmative
;
and
perceiving
that
he
had
not
alarmed
his
companion
sufficiently
,
changed
his
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Snodgrass
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
voice
tremulous
with
emotion
,
"
if
I
fall
,
you
will
find
in
a
packet
which
I
shall
place
in
your
hands
a
note
for
my
---
 
for
my
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
attack
was
a
failure
also
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
was
affected
,
but
he
undertook
the
delivery
of
the
note
as
readily
as
if
he
had
been
a
twopenny
postman
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
fall
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
"
or
if
the
doctor
falls
,
you
,
my
dear
friend
,
will
be
tried
as
an
accessory
before
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
involve
my
friend
in
transportation
---
possibly
for
life
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
winced
a
little
at
this
,
but
his
heroism
was
invincible
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
cause
of
friendship
,
"
he
fervently
exclaimed
,
"
I
would
brave
all
dangers
.
"
   
<EOS>
How
Mr
Winkle
cursed
his
companion
's
devoted
friendship
internally
,
as
they
walked
silently
along
,
side
by
side
,
for
some
minutes
,
each
immersed
in
his
own
meditations
!
<EOS>
The
morning
was
wearing
away
;
he
grew
desperate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Snodgrass
,
"
he
said
,
stopping
suddenly
,
"
do
not
let
me
be
balked
in
this
matter
---
do
not
give
information
to
the
local
authorities
---
do
not
obtain
the
assistance
of
several
peace
officers
,
to
take
either
me
or
Doctor
Slammer
,
of
the
97th
Regiment
,
at
present
quartered
in
Chatham
Barracks
,
into
custody
,
and
thus
prevent
this
duel
!
<EOS>
---
I
say
,
do
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
seized
his
friend
's
hand
warmly
,
as
he
enthusiastically
replied
,
"
Not
for
worlds
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
thrill
passed
over
Mr
Winkle
's
frame
as
the
conviction
that
he
had
nothing
to
hope
from
his
friend
's
fears
,
and
that
he
was
destined
to
become
an
animated
target
,
rushed
forcibly
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
state
of
the
case
having
been
formally
explained
to
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
a
case
of
satisfactory
pistols
,
with
the
satisfactory
accompaniments
of
powder
,
ball
,
and
caps
,
having
been
hired
from
a
manufacturer
in
Rochester
,
the
two
friends
returned
to
their
inn
;
Mr
Winkle
to
ruminate
on
the
approaching
struggle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
to
arrange
the
weapons
of
war
,
and
put
them
into
proper
order
for
immediate
use
.
   
<EOS>
it
was
a
dull
and
heavy
evening
when
they
again
sallied
forth
on
their
awkward
errand
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
was
muffled
up
in
a
huge
cloak
to
escape
observation
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
bore
under
his
the
instruments
of
destruction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
everything
?
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
in
an
agitated
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Everything
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
;
"
plenty
of
ammunition
,
in
case
the
shots
do
n't
take
effect
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
quarter
of
a
pound
of
powder
in
the
case
,
and
I
have
got
two
newspapers
in
my
pocket
for
the
loadings
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
These
were
instances
of
friendship
for
which
any
man
might
reasonably
feel
most
grateful
.
 
<EOS>
The
presumption
is
,
that
the
gratitude
of
Mr
Winkle
was
too
powerful
for
utterance
,
as
he
said
nothing
,
but
continued
to
walk
on
---
rather
slowly
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
in
excellent
time
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
as
they
climbed
the
fence
of
the
first
field
;
"
the
sun
is
just
going
down
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
looked
up
at
the
declining
orb
and
painfully
thought
of
the
probability
of
his
"
going
down
"
himself
,
before
long
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
officer
,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Winkle
,
after
a
few
minutes
walking
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
---
the
gentleman
in
the
blue
cloak
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
looked
in
the
direction
indicated
by
the
forefinger
of
his
friend
,
and
observed
a
figure
,
muffled
up
,
as
he
had
described
.
 
<EOS>
The
officer
evinced
his
consciousness
of
their
presence
by
slightly
beckoning
with
his
hand
;
and
the
two
friends
followed
him
at
a
little
distance
,
as
he
walked
away
.
   
<EOS>
The
evening
grew
more
dull
every
moment
,
and
a
melancholy
wind
sounded
through
the
deserted
fields
,
like
a
distant
giant
whistling
for
his
house
-
dog
.
 
<EOS>
The
sadness
of
the
scene
imparted
a
sombre
tinge
to
the
feelings
of
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
He
started
as
they
passed
the
angle
of
the
trench
<EOS>
---
it
looked
like
a
colossal
grave
.
   
<EOS>
The
officer
turned
suddenly
from
the
path
,
and
after
climbing
a
paling
,
and
scaling
a
hedge
,
entered
a
secluded
field
.
 
<EOS>
Two
gentlemen
were
waiting
in
it
;
one
was
a
little
,
fat
man
,
with
black
hair
;
and
the
other
---
a
portly
personage
in
a
braided
surtout
---
was
sitting
with
perfect
equanimity
on
a
camp
-
stool
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
other
party
,
and
a
surgeon
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
;
"
take
a
drop
of
brandy
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
seized
the
wicker
bottle
which
his
friend
proffered
,
and
took
a
lengthened
pull
at
the
exhilarating
liquid
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
friend
,
Sir
,
Mr
Snodgrass
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
as
the
officer
approached
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Slammer
's
friend
bowed
,
and
produced
a
case
similar
to
that
which
Mr
Snodgrass
carried
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
nothing
further
to
say
,
Sir
,
I
think
,
"
he
coldly
remarked
,
as
he
opened
the
case
;
"
an
apology
has
been
resolutely
declined
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
who
began
to
feel
rather
uncomfortable
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
step
forward
?
"
said
the
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
The
ground
was
measured
,
and
preliminaries
arranged
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
these
better
than
your
own
,
"
said
the
opposite
second
,
producing
his
pistols
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
saw
me
load
them
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
object
to
use
them
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
The
offer
relieved
him
from
considerable
embarrassment
,
for
his
previous
notions
of
loading
a
pistol
were
rather
vague
and
undefined
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
may
place
our
men
,
then
,
I
think
,
"
observed
the
officer
,
with
as
much
indifference
as
if
the
principals
were
chess
-
men
,
and
the
seconds
players
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
we
may
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
;
who
would
have
assented
to
any
proposition
,
because
he
knew
nothing
about
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
The
officer
crossed
to
Doctor
Slammer
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
went
up
to
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
ready
,
"
said
he
,
offering
the
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
your
cloak
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
got
the
packet
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
said
poor
Winkle
.
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
steady
,
and
wing
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
occurred
to
Mr
Winkle
that
this
advice
was
very
like
that
which
bystanders
invariably
give
to
the
smallest
boy
in
a
street
fight
,
namely
,
"
Go
in
,
and
win
"
---
an
admirable
thing
to
recommend
,
if
you
only
know
how
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
off
his
cloak
,
however
,
in
silence
<EOS>
---
it
always
took
a
long
time
to
undo
that
cloak
 
---
and
accepted
the
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
The
seconds
retired
,
the
gentleman
on
the
camp
-
stool
did
the
same
,
and
the
belligerents
approached
each
other
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
was
always
remarkable
for
extreme
humanity
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
conjectured
that
his
unwillingness
to
hurt
a
fellow
-
creature
intentionally
was
the
cause
of
his
shutting
his
eyes
when
he
arrived
at
the
fatal
spot
;
and
that
the
circumstance
of
his
eyes
being
closed
,
prevented
his
observing
the
very
extraordinary
and
unaccountable
demeanour
of
Doctor
Slammer
.
 
<EOS>
That
gentleman
started
,
stared
,
retreated
,
rubbed
his
eyes
,
stared
again
,
and
,
finally
,
shouted
,
"
Stop
,
stop
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
all
this
?
"
said
Doctor
Slammer
,
as
his
friend
and
Mr
Snodgrass
came
running
up
;
"
that
's
not
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
the
man
!
<EOS>
"
said
Doctor
Slammer
's
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
man
!
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
man
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
camp
-
stool
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
the
little
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
the
person
who
insulted
me
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
extraordinary
!
"
exclaimed
the
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
camp
-
stool
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
only
question
is
,
whether
the
gentleman
,
being
on
the
ground
,
must
not
be
considered
,
as
a
matter
of
form
,
to
be
the
individual
who
insulted
our
friend
,
Doctor
Slammer
,
yesterday
evening
,
whether
he
is
really
that
individual
or
not
;
"
and
having
delivered
this
suggestion
,
with
a
very
sage
and
mysterious
air
,
the
man
with
the
camp
-
stool
took
a
large
pinch
of
snuff
,
and
looked
profoundly
round
,
with
the
air
of
an
authority
in
such
matters
.
   
<EOS>
Now
Mr
Winkle
had
opened
his
eyes
,
and
his
ears
too
,
when
he
heard
his
adversary
call
out
for
a
cessation
of
hostilities
;
and
perceiving
by
what
he
had
afterwards
said
that
there
was
,
beyond
all
question
,
some
mistake
in
the
matter
,
he
at
once
foresaw
the
increase
of
reputation
he
should
inevitably
acquire
by
concealing
the
real
motive
of
his
coming
out
;
he
therefore
stepped
boldly
forward
,
and
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
the
person
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
that
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
camp
-
stool
,
"
is
an
affront
to
Doctor
Slammer
,
and
a
sufficient
reason
for
proceeding
immediately
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
be
quiet
,
Payne
,
"
said
the
doctor
's
second
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
not
communicate
this
fact
to
me
this
morning
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
---
to
be
sure
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
camp
-
stool
indignantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
entreat
you
to
be
quiet
,
Payne
,
"
said
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
repeat
my
question
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
who
had
had
time
to
deliberate
upon
his
answer
,
"
because
,
Sir
,
you
described
an
intoxicated
and
ungentlemanly
person
as
wearing
a
coat
which
I
have
the
honour
,
not
only
to
wear
but
to
have
invented
---
the
proposed
uniform
,
Sir
,
of
the
Pickwick
Club
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
The
honour
of
that
uniform
I
feel
bound
to
maintain
,
and
I
therefore
,
without
inquiry
,
accepted
the
challenge
which
you
offered
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Sir
,
"
said
the
good
-
humoured
little
doctor
advancing
with
extended
hand
,
"
I
honour
your
gallantry
.
 
<EOS>
Permit
me
to
say
,
Sir
,
<EOS>
that
I
highly
admire
your
conduct
,
and
extremely
regret
having
caused
you
the
inconvenience
of
this
meeting
,
to
no
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
you
wo
n't
mention
it
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
feel
proud
of
your
acquaintance
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
little
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
afford
me
the
greatest
pleasure
to
know
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
the
doctor
and
Mr
Winkle
shook
hands
,
and
then
Mr
Winkle
and
Lieutenant
Tappleton
(
the
doctor
's
second
)
,
and
then
Mr
Winkle
and
the
man
with
the
camp
-
stool
,
and
,
finally
,
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
---
the
last
-
named
gentleman
in
an
excess
of
admiration
at
the
noble
conduct
of
his
heroic
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
we
may
adjourn
,
"
said
Lieutenant
Tappleton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
added
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Unless
,
"
interposed
the
man
with
the
camp
-
stool
,
"
unless
Mr
Winkle
feels
himself
aggrieved
by
the
challenge
;
in
which
case
,
I
submit
,
he
has
a
right
to
satisfaction
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
with
great
self
-
denial
,
expressed
himself
quite
satisfied
already
.
"
<EOS>
Or
possibly
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
camp
-
stool
,
"
the
gentleman
's
second
may
feel
himself
affronted
with
some
observations
which
fell
from
me
at
an
early
period
of
this
meeting
;
if
so
,
I
shall
be
happy
to
give
him
satisfaction
immediately
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
hastily
professed
himself
very
much
obliged
with
the
handsome
offer
of
the
gentleman
who
had
spoken
last
,
which
he
was
only
induced
to
decline
by
his
entire
contentment
with
the
whole
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
seconds
adjusted
the
cases
,
and
the
whole
party
left
the
ground
in
a
much
more
lively
manner
than
they
had
proceeded
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remain
long
here
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Doctor
Slammer
of
Mr
Winkle
,
as
they
walked
on
most
amicably
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
we
shall
leave
here
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
,
"
was
the
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
trust
I
shall
have
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
and
your
friend
at
my
rooms
,
and
of
spending
a
pleasant
evening
with
you
,
after
this
awkward
mistake
,
"
said
the
little
doctor
;
"
are
you
disengaged
this
evening
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
some
friends
here
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
"
and
I
should
not
like
to
leave
them
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
and
your
friend
will
join
us
at
the
Bull
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
great
pleasure
,
"
said
the
little
doctor
;
"
will
ten
o'clock
be
too
late
to
look
in
for
half
an
hour
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
most
happy
to
introduce
you
to
my
friends
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Tupman
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
give
me
great
pleasure
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
"
replied
Doctor
Slammer
,
little
suspecting
who
Mr
Tupman
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
sure
to
come
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
Cordial
farewells
were
exchanged
,
and
the
party
separated
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Slammer
and
his
friends
repaired
to
the
barracks
,
and
Mr
Winkle
,
accompanied
by
Mr
Snodgrass
,
returned
to
their
inn
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
3
.
<EOS>
A
new
acquaintance
---
the
stroller
's
tale
---
a
disagreeable
interruption
,
and
an
unpleasant
encounter
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
felt
some
apprehensions
in
consequence
of
the
unusual
absence
of
his
two
friends
,
which
their
mysterious
behaviour
during
the
whole
morning
had
by
no
means
tended
to
diminish
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
,
therefore
,
with
more
than
ordinary
pleasure
that
he
rose
to
greet
them
when
they
again
entered
;
and
with
more
than
ordinary
interest
that
he
inquired
what
had
occurred
to
detain
them
from
his
society
.
 
<EOS>
In
reply
to
his
questions
on
this
point
,
Mr
Snodgrass
was
about
to
offer
an
historical
account
of
the
circumstances
just
now
detailed
,
when
he
was
suddenly
checked
by
observing
that
there
were
present
,
not
only
Mr
Tupman
and
their
stage
-
coach
companion
of
the
preceding
day
,
but
another
stranger
of
equally
singular
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
careworn
-
looking
man
,
whose
sallow
face
,
and
deeply
-
sunken
eyes
,
were
rendered
still
more
striking
than
Nature
had
made
them
,
by
the
straight
black
hair
which
hung
in
matted
disorder
half
-
way
down
his
face
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
almost
unnaturally
bright
and
piercing
;
his
cheek
-
bones
were
high
and
prominent
;
and
his
jaws
were
so
long
and
lank
,
that
an
observer
would
have
supposed
that
he
was
drawing
the
flesh
of
his
face
in
,
for
a
moment
,
by
some
contraction
of
the
muscles
,
if
his
half
-
opened
mouth
and
immovable
expression
had
not
announced
that
it
was
his
ordinary
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
Round
his
neck
<EOS>
he
wore
a
green
shawl
,
with
the
large
ends
straggling
over
his
chest
,
and
making
their
appearance
occasionally
beneath
the
worn
button
-
holes
of
his
old
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
His
upper
garment
was
a
long
black
surtout
;
and
below
it
he
wore
wide
drab
trousers
,
and
large
boots
,
running
rapidly
to
seed
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
on
this
uncouth
-
looking
person
that
Mr
Winkle
's
eye
rested
,
and
it
was
towards
him
that
Mr
Pickwick
extended
his
hand
when
he
said
,
"
A
friend
of
our
friend
's
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
discovered
this
morning
that
our
friend
was
connected
with
the
theatre
in
this
place
,
though
he
is
not
desirous
to
have
it
generally
known
,
and
this
gentleman
is
a
member
of
the
same
profession
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
favour
us
with
a
little
anecdote
connected
with
it
,
when
you
entered
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lots
of
anecdote
,
"
said
the
green
-
coated
stranger
of
the
day
before
,
advancing
to
Mr
Winkle
and
speaking
in
a
low
and
confidential
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rum
fellow
---
does
the
heavy
business
---
no
actor
---
<EOS>
strange
man
---
all
sorts
of
miseries
---
Dismal
Jemmy
<EOS>
,
we
call
him
on
the
circuit
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
politely
welcomed
the
gentleman
,
elegantly
designated
as
"
Dismal
Jemmy
"
;
and
calling
for
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
in
imitation
of
the
remainder
of
the
company
,
seated
themselves
at
the
table
.
"
<EOS>
Now
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
will
you
oblige
us
by
proceeding
with
what
you
were
going
to
relate
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
dismal
individual
took
a
dirty
roll
of
paper
from
his
pocket
,
and
turning
to
Mr
Snodgrass
,
who
had
just
taken
out
his
note
-
book
,
said
in
a
hollow
voice
,
perfectly
in
keeping
with
his
outward
man
---
"
Are
you
the
poet
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
do
a
little
in
that
way
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
,
rather
taken
aback
by
the
abruptness
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
poetry
makes
life
what
light
and
music
do
the
stage
---
strip
the
one
of
the
false
embellishments
,
and
the
other
of
its
illusions
,
and
what
is
there
real
in
either
to
live
or
care
for
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
before
the
footlights
,
"
continued
the
dismal
man
,
"
is
like
sitting
at
a
grand
court
show
,
and
admiring
the
silken
dresses
of
the
gaudy
throng
;
to
be
behind
them
is
to
be
the
people
who
make
that
finery
,
uncared
for
and
unknown
,
and
left
to
sink
or
swim
,
to
starve
or
live
,
as
fortune
wills
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
:
for
the
sunken
eye
of
the
dismal
man
rested
on
him
,
and
he
felt
it
necessary
to
say
something
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
Jemmy
,
"
said
the
Spanish
traveller
,
"
like
<EOS>
black
-
eyed
Susan
---
all
in
the
Downs
---
no
croaking
---
speak
out
---
look
lively
.
"
<EOS>
"
Will
you
make
another
glass
before
you
begin
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
The
dismal
man
took
the
hint
,
and
having
mixed
a
glass
of
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
and
slowly
swallowed
half
of
it
,
opened
the
roll
of
paper
and
proceeded
,
partly
to
read
,
and
partly
to
relate
,
the
following
incident
,
which
we
find
recorded
on
the
Transactions
of
the
Club
as
"
The
Stroller
's
Tale
.
"
     
<EOS>
THE
STROLLER
'S
TALE
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
of
the
marvellous
in
what
I
am
going
to
relate
,
"
said
the
dismal
man
;
"
there
is
nothing
even
uncommon
in
it
.
<EOS>
Want
and
sickness
are
too
common
in
many
stations
of
life
to
deserve
more
notice
than
is
usually
bestowed
on
the
most
ordinary
vicissitudes
of
human
nature
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
thrown
these
few
notes
together
,
because
the
subject
of
them
was
well
known
to
me
for
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
traced
his
progress
downwards
,
step
by
step
,
until
at
last
he
reached
that
excess
of
destitution
from
which
he
never
rose
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
man
of
whom
I
speak
was
a
low
pantomime
actor
;
and
,
like
many
people
of
his
class
,
an
habitual
drunkard
.
 
<EOS>
in
his
better
days
,
before
he
had
become
enfeebled
by
dissipation
and
emaciated
by
disease
,
he
had
been
in
the
receipt
of
a
good
salary
,
which
,
if
he
had
been
careful
and
prudent
,
he
might
have
continued
to
receive
for
some
years
---
not
many
;
because
these
men
either
die
early
,
or
by
unnaturally
taxing
their
bodily
energies
,
lose
,
prematurely
,
those
physical
powers
on
which
alone
they
can
depend
for
subsistence
.
 
<EOS>
His
besetting
sin
gained
so
fast
upon
him
,
however
,
that
it
was
found
impossible
to
employ
him
in
the
situations
in
which
he
really
was
useful
to
the
theatre
.
 
<EOS>
The
public
-
house
had
a
fascination
for
him
which
he
could
not
resist
.
<EOS>
Neglected
disease
and
hopeless
poverty
were
as
certain
to
be
his
portion
as
death
itself
,
if
he
persevered
in
the
same
course
;
yet
he
did
persevere
,
and
the
result
may
be
guessed
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
obtain
no
engagement
,
and
he
wanted
bread
.
<EOS>
"
Everybody
who
is
at
all
acquainted
with
theatrical
matters
knows
what
a
host
of
shabby
,
poverty
-
stricken
men
hang
about
the
stage
of
a
large
establishment
---
not
regularly
engaged
actors
,
but
ballet
people
,
procession
men
,
tumblers
,
and
so
forth
,
who
are
taken
on
during
the
run
of
a
pantomime
,
or
an
Easter
piece
,
and
are
then
discharged
,
until
the
production
of
some
heavy
spectacle
occasions
a
new
demand
for
their
services
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
mode
of
life
the
man
was
compelled
to
resort
;
and
taking
the
chair
every
night
,
at
some
low
theatrical
house
,
at
once
put
him
in
possession
of
a
few
more
shillings
weekly
,
and
enabled
him
to
gratify
his
old
propensity
.
 
<EOS>
Even
this
resource
shortly
failed
him
;
his
irregularities
were
too
great
to
admit
of
his
earning
the
wretched
pittance
he
might
thus
have
procured
,
and
he
was
actually
reduced
to
a
state
bordering
on
starvation
,
only
procuring
a
trifle
occasionally
by
borrowing
it
of
some
old
companion
,
or
by
obtaining
an
appearance
at
one
or
other
of
the
commonest
of
the
minor
theatres
;
and
when
he
did
earn
anything
it
was
spent
in
the
old
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
About
this
time
,
and
<EOS>
when
he
had
been
existing
for
upwards
of
a
year
no
one
knew
how
,
I
had
a
short
engagement
at
one
of
the
theatres
on
the
Surrey
side
of
the
water
,
and
here
I
saw
this
man
,
whom
I
had
lost
sight
of
for
some
time
;
for
I
had
been
travelling
in
the
provinces
,
and
he
had
been
skulking
in
the
lanes
and
alleys
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
dressed
to
leave
the
house
,
and
was
crossing
the
stage
on
my
way
out
,
when
he
tapped
me
on
the
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
Never
shall
I
forget
the
repulsive
sight
that
met
my
eye
when
I
turned
round
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
for
the
pantomimes
in
all
the
absurdity
of
a
clown
's
costume
.
 
<EOS>
The
spectral
figures
in
the
Dance
of
Death
,
the
most
frightful
shapes
that
the
ablest
painter
ever
portrayed
on
canvas
,
never
presented
an
appearance
half
so
ghastly
.
 
<EOS>
His
bloated
body
and
shrunken
legs
<EOS>
---
their
deformity
enhanced
a
hundredfold
by
the
fantastic
dress
---
the
glassy
eyes
,
contrasting
fearfully
with
the
thick
white
paint
with
which
the
face
was
besmeared
;
the
grotesquely
-
ornamented
head
,
trembling
with
paralysis
,
and
the
long
skinny
hands
,
rubbed
with
white
chalk
---
all
gave
him
a
hideous
and
unnatural
appearance
,
of
which
no
description
could
convey
an
adequate
idea
,
and
which
,
to
this
day
,
I
shudder
to
think
of
.
 
<EOS>
His
voice
was
hollow
and
tremulous
as
he
took
me
aside
,
and
in
broken
words
recounted
a
long
catalogue
of
sickness
and
privations
,
terminating
as
usual
with
an
urgent
request
for
the
loan
of
a
trifling
sum
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
a
few
shillings
in
his
hand
,
and
as
I
turned
away
<EOS>
I
heard
the
roar
of
laughter
which
followed
his
first
tumble
on
the
stage
.
<EOS>
"
A
few
nights
afterwards
,
a
boy
put
a
dirty
scrap
of
paper
in
my
hand
,
on
which
were
scrawled
a
few
words
in
pencil
,
intimating
that
the
man
was
dangerously
ill
,
and
begging
me
,
after
the
performance
,
to
see
him
at
his
lodgings
in
some
street
<EOS>
---
I
forget
the
name
of
it
now
---
at
no
great
distance
from
the
theatre
.
<EOS>
I
promised
to
comply
,
as
soon
as
I
could
get
away
;
and
after
the
curtain
fell
,
sallied
forth
on
my
melancholy
errand
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
late
,
for
I
had
been
playing
in
the
last
piece
;
and
,
as
it
was
a
benefit
night
,
the
performances
had
been
protracted
to
an
unusual
length
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
dark
,
cold
night
,
with
a
chill
,
damp
wind
,
which
blew
the
rain
heavily
against
the
windows
and
house
-
fronts
.
<EOS>
Pools
of
water
had
collected
in
the
narrow
and
little
-
frequented
streets
,
and
as
many
of
the
thinly
-
scattered
oil
-
lamps
had
been
blown
out
by
the
violence
of
the
wind
,
the
walk
was
not
only
a
comfortless
,
but
most
uncertain
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
fortunately
taken
the
right
course
,
however
,
and
succeeded
,
after
a
little
difficulty
,
in
finding
the
house
to
which
I
had
been
directed
---
a
coal
-
shed
,
with
one
Storey
above
it
,
in
the
back
room
of
which
lay
the
object
of
my
search
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
wretched
-
looking
woman
,
the
man
's
wife
,
met
me
on
the
stairs
,
and
,
telling
me
that
he
had
just
fallen
into
a
kind
of
doze
,
led
me
softly
in
,
and
placed
a
chair
for
me
at
the
bedside
.
 
<EOS>
The
sick
man
was
lying
with
his
face
turned
towards
the
wall
;
and
as
he
took
no
heed
of
my
presence
,
I
had
leisure
to
observe
the
place
in
which
I
found
myself
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
lying
on
an
old
bedstead
,
which
turned
up
during
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
tattered
remains
of
a
checked
curtain
were
drawn
round
the
bed
's
head
,
to
exclude
the
wind
,
which
,
however
,
made
its
way
into
the
comfortless
room
through
the
numerous
chinks
in
the
door
,
and
blew
it
to
and
fro
every
instant
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
low
cinder
fire
in
a
rusty
,
unfixed
grate
;
and
an
old
three
-
cornered
stained
table
,
with
some
medicine
bottles
,
a
broken
glass
,
and
a
few
other
domestic
articles
,
was
drawn
out
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
child
was
sleeping
on
a
temporary
bed
which
had
been
made
for
it
on
the
floor
,
and
the
woman
sat
on
a
chair
by
its
side
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
couple
of
shelves
,
with
a
few
plates
and
cups
and
saucers
;
and
a
pair
of
stage
shoes
and
a
couple
of
foils
hung
beneath
them
.
<EOS>
With
the
exception
of
little
heaps
of
rags
and
bundles
which
had
been
carelessly
thrown
into
the
corners
of
the
room
,
these
were
the
only

in
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
had
time
to
note
these
little
particulars
,
and
to
mark
the
heavy
breathing
and
feverish

of
the
sick
man
,
before
he
was
aware
of
my
presence
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
restless
attempts
to
procure
some
easy
resting
-
place
for
his
head
,
he
tossed
his
hand
out
of
the
bed
,
and
it
fell
on
mine
.
 
<EOS>
He
started
up
,
and
stared
eagerly
in
my
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Mr
Hutley
,
John
,
"
said
his
wife
;
"
Mr
Hutley
,
that
you
sent
for
to
-
night
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Ah
!
"
said
the
invalid
,
passing
his
hand
across
his
forehead
;
"
Hutley
---
Hutley
---
let
me
see
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
endeavouring
to
collect
his
thoughts
for
a
few
seconds
,
and
then
grasping
me
tightly
by
the
wrist
said
,
"
Do
n't
leave
me
---
do
n't
leave
me
,
old
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
She
'll
murder
me
;
I
know
she
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Has
he
been
long
so
?
"
said
I
,
addressing
his
weeping
wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Since
yesterday
night
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
John
,
John
,
do
n't
you
know
me
?
"
<EOS>
"
"
Do
n't
let
her
come
near
me
,
"
said
the
man
,
with
a
shudder
,
as
she
stooped
over
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Drive
her
away
;
I
ca
n't
bear
her
near
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
stared
wildly
at
her
,
with
a
look
of
deadly
apprehension
,
and
then
whispered
in
my
ear
,
"
I
beat
her
,
Jem
;
I
beat
her
yesterday
,
and
many
times
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
starved
her
and
the
boy
too
;
and
now
I
am
weak
and
helpless
,
Jem
,
she
'll
murder
me
for
it
;
I
know
she
will
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
'd
seen
her
cry
,
as
I
have
,
you
'd
know
it
too
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
her
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
relaxed
his
grasp
,
and
sank
back
exhausted
on
the
pillow
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
but
too
well
what
all
this
meant
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
entertained
any
doubt
of
it
,
for
an

,
one

at
the
woman
's
pale

and

would
have
sufficiently
explained
the
real
state
of
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
stand
aside
,
"
said
I
to
the
poor
creature
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
do
him
<EOS>
no
good
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
will
be
calmer
,
if
he
does
not
see
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
retired
out
of
the
man
's
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
opened
his
eyes
after
a
few
seconds
,
and
looked
anxiously
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Is
she
gone
?
<EOS>
"
he
eagerly
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
yes
,
"
said
I
;
"
she
shall
not
hurt
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
Jem
,
"
said
the
man
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
she
does
hurt
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
something
in
her
eyes
wakes
such
a
dreadful
fear
in
my
heart
,
that
it
drives
me
mad
.
 
<EOS>
All
last
night
,
her
large
,
staring
eyes
and
pale
face
were
close
to
mine
;
wherever
I
turned
,
they
turned
;
and
whenever
I
started
up
from
my
sleep
,
she
was
at
the
bedside
looking
at
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
drew
me
closer
to
him
,
as
he
said
in
a
deep
alarmed
whisper
,
"
Jem
,
she
must
be
an
evil
spirit
---
a
devil
!
<EOS>
Hush
!
<EOS>
I
know
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
been
a
woman
she
would
have
died
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
No
woman
could
have
borne
what
she
has
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
sickened
at
the
thought
of
the
long
course
of
cruelty
and
neglect
which
must
have
occurred
to
produce
such
an
impression
on
such
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
say
nothing
in
reply
;
for
who
could
offer
hope
,
or
consolation
,
to
the
abject
being
before
me
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
sat
there
for
upwards
of
two
hours
,
during
which
time
he
tossed
about
,
murmuring
exclamations
of
pain
or
impatience
,
restlessly
throwing
his
arms
here
and
there
,
and
turning
constantly
from
side
to
side
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
fell
into
that
state
of
partial
unconsciousness
,
in
which
the
mind
wanders
uneasily
from
scene
to
scene
,
and
from
place
to
place
,
without
the
control
of
reason
,
but
still
without
being
able
to
divest
itself
of
an
indescribable
sense
of
present
suffering
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
from
his
incoherent
wanderings
that
this
was
the
case
,
and
knowing
that
in
all
probability
the
fever
would
not
grow
immediately
worse
<EOS>
,
I
left
him
,
promising
his
miserable
wife
that
I
would
repeat
my
visit
next
evening
,
and
,
if
necessary
,
sit
up
with
the
patient
during
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
kept
my
promise
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
had
produced
a
frightful
alteration
.
 
<EOS>
The
eyes
,
though
deeply
sunk
and
heavy
,
shone
with
a
lustre
frightful
to
behold
.
 
<EOS>
The
lips
were
parched
,
and
cracked
in
many
places
;
the
hard
,
dry
skin
glowed
with
a
burning
heat
;
and
there
was
an
almost
unearthly
air
of
wild
anxiety
in
the
man
's
face
,
indicating
even
more
strongly
the
ravages
of
the
disease
.
 
<EOS>
The
fever
was
at
its
height
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
took
the
seat
I
had
occupied
the
night
before
,
and
there
I
sat
for
hours
,
listening
to
sounds
which
must
strike
deep
to
the
heart
of
the
most
callous
among
human
beings
---
the
awful
ravings
of
a
dying
man
.
 
<EOS>
From
what
I
had
heard
of
the
medical
attendant
's
opinion
,
I
knew
there
was
no
hope
for
him
:
I
was
sitting
by
his
death
-
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
wasted
limbs
---
which
a
few
hours
before
had
been
distorted
for
the
amusement
of
a
boisterous
gallery
,
writhing
under
the
tortures
of
a
burning
fever
<EOS>
---
I
heard
the
clown
's
shrill
laugh
,
blending
with
the
low
murmurings
of
the
dying
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
touching
thing
to
hear
the
mind
reverting
to
the
ordinary
occupations
and
pursuits
of
health
,
when
the
body
lies
before
you
weak
and
helpless
;
but
when
those
occupations
are
of
a
character
the
most
strongly
opposed
to
anything
we
associate
with
grave
and
solemn
ideas
,
the
impression
produced
is
infinitely
more
powerful
.
 
<EOS>
The
theatre
and
the
public
-
house
were
the
chief
themes
of
the
wretched
man
's
wanderings
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evening
,
he
fancied
;
he
had
a
part
to
play
that
night
;
it
was
late
,
and
he
must
leave
home
instantly
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
they
hold
him
,
and
prevent
his
going
?
<EOS>
---
he
should
lose
the
money
---
he
must
go
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
they
would
not
let
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
hid
his
face
in
his
burning
hands
,
and
feebly
bemoaned
his
own
weakness
,
and
the
cruelty
of
his
persecutors
.
 
<EOS>
A
short
pause
,
and
<EOS>
he
shouted
out
a
few
doggerel
rhymes
---
the
last
he
had
ever
learned
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
in
bed
,
drew
up
his
withered
limbs
,
and
rolled
about
in
uncouth
positions
;
he
was
acting
---
he
was
at
the
theatre
.
 
<EOS>
A
minute
's
silence
,
and
he
murmured
the
burden
of
some
roaring
song
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
reached
the
old
house
at
last
---
how
hot
the
room
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
ill
,
very
ill
,
but
he
was
well
now
,
and
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Fill
up
his
glass
.
 
<EOS>
Who
was
that
,
that
dashed
it
from
his
lips
?
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
persecutor
that
had
followed
him
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
fell
back
upon
his
pillow
and
moaned
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
A
short
period
of
oblivion
,
and
he
was
wandering
through
a
tedious
maze
of
low
-
arched
rooms
---
<EOS>
so
low
,
sometimes
,
that
he
must
creep
upon
his
hands
and
knees
to
make
his
way
along
;
it
was
close
and
dark
,
and
every
way
he
turned
,
some
obstacle
impeded
his
progress
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
insects
,
too
,
hideous
crawling
things
,
with
eyes
that
stared
upon
him
,
and
filled
the
very
air
around
,
glistening
horribly
amidst
the
thick
darkness
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
The
walls
and
ceiling
were
alive
with
reptiles
---
the
vault
expanded
to
an
enormous
size
---
frightful
figures
flitted
to
and
fro
---
and
the
faces
of
men
he
knew
,
rendered
hideous
by
gibing
and
mouthing
,
peered
out
from
among
them
;
they
were
searing
him
with
heated
irons
,
and
binding
his
head
with
cords
till
the
blood
started
;
and
he
struggled
madly
for
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
the
close
of
one
of
these
paroxysms
,
when
I
had
with
great
difficulty
held
him
down
in
his
bed
,
he
sank
into
what
appeared
to
be
a
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
Overpowered
with
watching
and
exertion
,
I
had
closed
my
eyes
for
a
few
minutes
,
when
I
felt
a
violent
clutch
on
my
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
I
awoke
instantly
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
raised
himself
up
,
so
as
to
seat
himself
in
bed
---
a
dreadful
change
had
come
over
his
face
,
but
consciousness
had
returned
,
for
he
evidently
knew
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
,
who
had
been
long
since
disturbed
by
his
ravings
,
rose
from
its
little
bed
,
and
ran
towards
its
father
,
screaming
with
fright
---
the
mother
hastily
caught
it
in
her
arms
,
lest
he
should
injure
it
in
the
violence
of
his
insanity
;
but
,
terrified
by
the
alteration
of
his
features
,
stood
transfixed
by
the
bedside
.
 
<EOS>
He
grasped
my
shoulder
convulsively
,
and
,
striking
his
breast
with
the
other
hand
,
made
a
desperate
attempt
to
articulate
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
unavailing
;
he
extended
his
arm
towards
them
,
and
made
another
violent
effort
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
rattling
noise
in
the
throat
---
a
glare
of
the
eye
---
a
short
stifled
groan
---
and
he
fell
back
---
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
would
afford
us
the
highest
gratification
to
be
enabled
to
record
Mr
Pickwick
's
opinion
of
the
foregoing
anecdote
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
little
doubt
that
we
should
have
been
enabled
to
present
it
to
our
readers
,
but
for
a
most
unfortunate
occurrence
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
replaced
on
the
table
the
glass
which
,
during
the
last
few
sentences
of
the
tale
,
he
had
retained
in
his
hand
;
and
had
just
made
up
his
mind
to
speak
---
indeed
,
we
have
the
authority
of
Mr
Snodgrass
's
note
-
book
for
stating
,
that
he
had
actually
opened
his
mouth
---
when
the
waiter
entered
the
room
,
and
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
Some
gentlemen
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
has
been
conjectured
that
Mr
Pickwick
was
on
the
point
of
delivering
some
remarks
which
would
have
enlightened
the
world
,
if
not
the
Thames
,
when
he
was
thus
interrupted
;
for
he
gazed
sternly
on
the
waiter
's
countenance
,
and
then
looked
round
on
the
company
generally
,
as
if
seeking
for
information
relative
to
the
new
-
comers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
rising
,
"
some
friends
of
mine
---
show
them
in
.
 
<EOS>
Very
pleasant
fellows
,
"
added
Mr
Winkle
,
after
the
waiter
had
retired
---
"
officers
of
the
97th
,
whose
acquaintance
I
made
rather
oddly
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
like
them
very
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
equanimity
was
at
once
restored
.
 
<EOS>
The
waiter
returned
,
and
ushered
three
gentlemen
into
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lieutenant
Tappleton
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
"
Lieutenant
Tappleton
,
Mr
Pickwick
---
Doctor
Payne
,
Mr
Pickwick
---
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
you
have
seen
before
,
my
friend
Mr
Tupman
,
Doctor
Payne
---
Doctor
Slammer
,
Mr
Pickwick
---
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
Doctor
Slam
---
"
   
Here
Mr
Winkle
suddenly
paused
;
for
strong
emotion
was
visible
on
the
countenance
both
of
Mr
Tupman
and
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
met
THIS
gentleman
before
,
"
said
the
Doctor
,
with
marked
emphasis
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
---
and
that
person
,
too
,
if
I
am
not
mistaken
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
bestowing
a
scrutinising
glance
on
the
green
-
coated
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
gave
that
person
a
very
pressing
invitation
last
night
,
which
he
thought
proper
to
decline
.
"
 
<EOS>
Saying
which
the
doctor
scowled
magnanimously
on
the
stranger
,
and
whispered
his
friend
Lieutenant
Tappleton
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
,
"
said
that
gentleman
,
at
the
conclusion
of
the
whisper
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Doctor
Slammer
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
bound
to
kick
him
on
the
spot
,
"
murmured
the
owner
of
the
camp
-
stool
,
with
great
importance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
be
quiet
,
Payne
,
"
interposed
the
lieutenant
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
ask
you
,
sir
,
"
he
said
,
addressing
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
was
considerably
mystified
by
this
very
unpolite
by
-
play
---
"
will
you
allow
me
to
ask
you
,
Sir
,
whether
that
person
belongs
to
your
party
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
he
is
a
guest
of
ours
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
member
of
your
club
,
or
I
am
mistaken
?
"
said
the
lieutenant
inquiringly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
responded
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
never
wears
your
club
-
button
?
"
said
the
lieutenant
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
---
never
!
"
replied
the
astonished
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Lieutenant
Tappleton
turned
round
to
his
friend
Doctor
Slammer
,
with
a
scarcely
perceptible
shrug
of
the
shoulder
,
as
if
implying
some
doubt
of
the
accuracy
of
his
recollection
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
doctor
looked
wrathful
,
but
confounded
;
and
Mr
Payne
gazed
with
a
ferocious
aspect
on
the
beaming
countenance
of
the
unconscious
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
suddenly
addressing
Mr
Tupman
,
in
a
tone
which
made
that
gentleman
start
as
perceptibly
as
if
a
pin
had
been
cunningly
inserted
in
the
calf
of
his
leg
,
"
you
were
at
the
ball
here
last
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
gasped
a
faint
affirmative
,
looking
very
hard
at
Mr
Pickwick
all
the
while
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
person
was
your
companion
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
pointing
to
the
still
unmoved
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
admitted
the
fact
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
the
doctor
to
the
stranger
,
"
I
ask
you
once
again
,
in
the
presence
of
these
gentlemen
,
whether
you
choose
to
give
me
your
card
,
and
to
receive
the
treatment
of
a
gentleman
;
or
whether
you
impose
upon
me
the
necessity
of
personally
chastising
you
on
the
spot
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
really
can
not
allow
this
matter
to
go
any
further
without
some
explanation
.
 
<EOS>
Tupman
,
recount
the
circumstances
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
thus
solemnly
adjured
,
stated
the
case
in
a
few
words
;
touched
slightly
on
the
borrowing
of
the
coat
;
expatiated
largely
on
its
having
been
done
"
after
dinner
"
;
wound
up
with
a
little
penitence
on
his
own
account
;
and
left
the
stranger
to
clear
himself
as
best
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
apparently
about
to
proceed
to
do
so
,
when
Lieutenant
Tappleton
,
who
had
been
eyeing
him
with
great
curiosity
,
said
with
considerable
scorn
,
"
Have
n't
I
seen
you
at
the
theatre
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
the
unabashed
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
strolling
actor
!
"
said
the
lieutenant
contemptuously
,
turning
to
Doctor
Slammer
.
---
"
He
acts
in
the
piece
that
the
officers
of
the
52nd
get
up
at
the
Rochester
Theatre
to
-
morrow
night
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
not
proceed
in
this
affair
,
Slammer
---
impossible
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
!
"
said
the
dignified
Payne
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sorry
to
have
placed
you
in
this
disagreeable
situation
,
"
said
Lieutenant
Tappleton
,
addressing
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
allow
me
to
suggest
,
that
the
best
way
of
avoiding
a
recurrence
of
such
scenes
in
future
will
be
to
be
more
select
in
the
choice
of
your
companions
.
<EOS>
Good
-
evening
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
lieutenant
bounced
out
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
allow
me
to
say
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
irascible
Doctor
Payne
,
"
that
if
I
had
been
Tappleton
,
or
if
I
had
been
Slammer
,
I
would
have
pulled
your
nose
,
Sir
,
and
the
nose
of
every
man
in
this
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
,
sir
---
<EOS>
every
man
.
 
<EOS>
Payne
is
my
name
,
sir
---
Doctor
Payne
of
the
43rd
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
evening
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Having
concluded
this
speech
,
and
uttered
the
last
three
words
in
a
loud
key
,
he
stalked
majestically
after
his
friend
,
closely
followed
by
Doctor
Slammer
,
who
said
nothing
,
but
contented
himself
by
withering
the
company
with
a
look
.
<EOS>
Rising
rage
and
extreme
bewilderment
had
swelled
the
noble
breast
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
almost
to
the
bursting
of
his
waistcoat
,
during
the
delivery
of
the
above
defiance
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
transfixed
to
the
spot
,
gazing
on
vacancy
.
 
<EOS>
The
closing
of
the
door
recalled
him
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
rushed
forward
with
fury
in
his
looks
,
and
fire
in
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
His
hand
was
upon
the
lock
of
the
door
;
in
another
instant
it
would
have
been
on
the
throat
of
Doctor
Payne
of
the
43rd
,
had
not
Mr
Snodgrass
seized
his
revered
leader
by
the
coat
tail
,
and
dragged
him
backwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
Restrain
him
,
"
cried
Mr
Snodgrass
;
"
Winkle
,
Tupman
---
he
must
not
peril
his
distinguished
life
in
such
a
cause
as
this
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
him
tight
,
"
shouted
Mr
Snodgrass
;
and
by
the
united
efforts
of
the
whole
company
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
forced
into
an
arm
-
chair
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
him
alone
,
"
said
the
green
-
coated
stranger
;
"
brandy
-
and
-
water
---
jolly
old
gentleman
---
lots
of
pluck
---
swallow
this
---
ah
!
---
capital
stuff
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Having
previously
tested
the
virtues
of
a
bumper
,
which
had
been
mixed
by
the
dismal
man
,
the
stranger
applied
the
glass
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
mouth
;
and
the
remainder
of
its
contents
rapidly
disappeared
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
short
pause
;
the
brandy
-
and
-
water
had
done
its
work
;
the
amiable
countenance
of
Mr
Pickwick
was
fast
recovering
its
customary
expression
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
not
worth
your
notice
,
"
said
the
dismal
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
they
are
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
to
have
been
betrayed
into
this
warmth
of
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
Draw
your
chair
up
to
the
table
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
dismal
man
readily
complied
;
a
circle
was
again
formed
round
the
table
,
and
harmony
once
more
prevailed
.
 
<EOS>
Some
lingering
irritability
appeared
to
find
a
resting
-
place
in
Mr
Winkle
's
bosom
,
occasioned
possibly
by
the
temporary
abstraction
of
his
coat
---
though
it
is
scarcely
reasonable
to
suppose
that
so
slight
a
circumstance
can
have
excited
even
a
passing
feeling
of
anger
in
a
Pickwickian
's
breast
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
exception
,
their
good
-
humour
was
completely
restored
;
and
the
evening
concluded
with
the
conviviality
with
which
it
had
begun
.
    
Chapter
4
.
<EOS>
A
field
day
and
bivouac
---
more
new
friends
---
an
invitation
to
the
country
 
<EOS>
Many
authors
entertain
,
not
only
a
foolish
,
but
a
really
dishonest
objection
to
acknowledge
the
sources
<EOS>
whence
they
derive
much
valuable
information
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
such
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
merely
endeavouring
to
discharge
,
in
an
upright
manner
,
the
responsible
duties
of
our
editorial
functions
;
and
whatever
ambition
we
might
have
felt
under
other
circumstances
to
lay
claim
to
the
authorship
of
these
adventures
,
a
regard
for
truth
forbids
us
to
do
more
than
claim
the
merit
of
their
judicious
arrangement
and
impartial
narration
.
 
<EOS>
The
Pickwick
papers
are
our
New
River
Head
;
and
we
may
be
compared
to
the
New
River
Company
.
 
<EOS>
The
labours
of
others
have
raised
for
us
an
immense
reservoir
of
important
facts
.
 
<EOS>
We
merely
lay
them
on
,
and
communicate
them
,
in
a
clear
and
gentle
stream
,
through
the
medium
of
these
pages
,
to
a
world
thirsting
for
Pickwickian
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
Acting
in
this
spirit
,
and
resolutely
proceeding
on
our
determination
to
avow
our
obligations
to
the
authorities
we
have
consulted
<EOS>
,
we
frankly
say
,
that
to
the
note
-
book
of
Mr
Snodgrass
are
we
indebted
for
the
particulars
recorded
in
this
and
the
succeeding
chapter
---
particulars
which
,
now
that
we
have
disburdened
our
consciences
,
we
shall
proceed
to
detail
without
further
comment
.
   
<EOS>
The
whole
population
of
Rochester
and
the
adjoining
towns
rose
from
their
beds
at
an
early
hour
of
the
following
morning
,
in
a
state
of
the
utmost
bustle
and
excitement
.
 
<EOS>
A
grand
review
was
to
take
place
upon
the
lines
.
 
<EOS>
The
manoeuvres
of
half
a
dozen
regiments
were
to
be
inspected
by
the
eagle
eye
of
the
commander
-
in
-
chief
;
temporary
fortifications
had
been
erected
,
the
citadel
was
to
be
attacked
and
taken
,
and
a
mine
was
to
be
sprung
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
,
as
our
readers
may
have
gathered
from
the
slight
extract
we
gave
from
his
description
of
Chatham
,
an
enthusiastic
admirer
of
the
army
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
could
have
been
more
delightful
to
him
---
nothing
could
have
harmonised
so
well
with
the
peculiar
feeling
of
each
of
his
companions
---
as
this
sight
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
they
were
soon
afoot
,
and
walking
in
the
direction
of
the
scene
of
action
,
towards
which
crowds
of
people
were
already
pouring
from
a
variety
of
quarters
.
   
<EOS>
The
appearance
of
everything
on
the
lines
denoted
that
the
approaching
ceremony
was
one
of
the
utmost
grandeur
and
importance
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
sentries
posted
to
keep
the
ground
for
the
troops
,
and
servants
on
the
batteries
keeping
places
for
the
ladies
,
and
sergeants
running
to
and
fro
,
with
vellum
-
covered
books
under
their
arms
,
and
Colonel
Bulder
,
in
full
military
uniform
,
on
horseback
,
galloping
first
to
one
place
and
then
to
another
,
and
backing
his
horse
among
the
people
,
and
prancing
,
and
curvetting
,
and
shouting
in
a
most
alarming
manner
,
and
making
himself
very
hoarse
in
the
voice
,
and
very
red
in
the
face
,
without
any
assignable
cause
or
reason
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
Officers
were
running
backwards
and
forwards
,
first
communicating
with
Colonel
Bulder
,
and
then
ordering
the
sergeants
,
and
then
running
away
altogether
;
and
even
the
very
privates
themselves
looked
from
behind
their
glazed
stocks
with
an
air
of
mysterious
solemnity
,
which
sufficiently
bespoke
the
special
nature
of
the
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
three
companions
stationed
themselves
in
the
front
of
the
crowd
,
and
patiently
awaited
the
commencement
of
the
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
The
throng
was
increasing
every
moment
;
and
the
efforts
they
were
compelled
to
make
,
to
retain
the
position
they
had
gained
,
sufficiently
occupied
their
attention
during
the
two
hours
that
ensued
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
time
there
was
a
sudden
pressure
from
behind
,
and
then
Mr
Pickwick
was
jerked
forward
for
several
yards
,
with
a
degree
of
speed
and
elasticity
highly
inconsistent
with
the
general
gravity
of
his
demeanour
;
at
another
moment
there
was
a
request
to
"
keep
back
"
from
the
front
,
and
then
the
butt
-
end
of
a
musket
was
either
dropped
upon
Mr
Pickwick
's
toe
,
to
remind
him
of
the
demand
,
or
thrust
into
his
chest
,
to
insure
its
being
complied
with
.
 
<EOS>
Then
some
facetious
gentlemen
on
the
left
,
after
pressing
sideways
in
a
body
,
and
squeezing
Mr
Snodgrass
into
the
very
last
extreme
of
human
torture
,
would
request
to
know
"
vere
he
vos
a
shovin
'
to
"
;
and
when
Mr
Winkle
had
done
expressing
his
excessive
indignation
at
witnessing
this
unprovoked
assault
,
some
person
behind
would
knock
his
hat
over
his
eyes
,
and
beg
the
favour
of
his
putting
his
head
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
and
other
practical
witticisms
,
coupled
with
the
unaccountable
absence
of
Mr
Tupman
(
who
had
suddenly
disappeared
,
and
was
nowhere
to
be
found
)
,
rendered
their
situation
upon
the
whole
rather
more
uncomfortable
than
pleasing
or
desirable
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
that
low
roar
of
many
voices
ran
through
the
crowd
which
usually
announces
the
arrival
of
whatever
they
have
been
waiting
for
.
 
<EOS>
All
eyes
were
turned
in
the
direction
of
the
sally
-
port
.
<EOS>
A
few
moments
of
eager
expectation
,
and
colours
were
seen
fluttering
gaily
in
the
air
,
arms
glistened
brightly
in
the
sun
,
column
after
column
poured
on
to
the
plain
.
 
<EOS>
The
troops
halted
and
formed
;
the
word
of
command
rang
through
the
line
;
there
was
a
general
clash
of
muskets
as
arms
were
presented
;
and
the
commander
-
in
-
chief
,
attended
by
Colonel
Bulder
and
numerous
officers
,
cantered
to
the
front
.
 
<EOS>
The
military
bands
struck
up
altogether
;
the
horses
stood
upon
two
legs
each
,
cantered
backwards
,
and
whisked
their
tails
about
in
all
directions
;
the
dogs
barked
,
the
mob
screamed
,
the
troops
recovered
,
and
nothing
was
to
be
seen
on
either
side
,
as
far
as
the
eye
could
reach
,
but
a
long
perspective
of
red
coats
and
white
trousers
,
fixed
and
motionless
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
so
fully
occupied
in
falling
about
,
and
disentangling
himself
,
miraculously
,
from
between
the
legs
of
horses
,
that
he
had
not
enjoyed
sufficient
leisure
to
observe
the
scene
before
him
,
until
it
assumed
the
appearance
we
have
just
described
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
was
at
last
enabled
to
stand
firmly
on
his
legs
,
his
gratification
and
delight
were
unbounded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
anything
be
finer
or
more
delightful
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
of
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
,
who
had
had
a
short
man
standing
on
each
of
his
feet
for
the
quarter
of
an
hour
immediately
preceding
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
indeed
a
noble
and
a
brilliant
sight
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
in
whose
bosom
a
blaze
of
poetry
was
rapidly
bursting
forth
,
"
to
see
the
gallant
defenders
of
their
country
drawn
up
in
brilliant
array
before
its
peaceful
citizens
;
their
faces
beaming
---
not
with
warlike
ferocity
,
but
with
civilised
gentleness
;
their
eyes
flashing
 
---
not
with
the
rude
fire
of
rapine
or
revenge
,
but
with
the
soft
light
of
humanity
and
intelligence
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
fully
entered
into
the
spirit
of
this
eulogium
,
but
he
could
not
exactly
re
-
echo
its
terms
;
for
the
soft
light
of
intelligence
burned
rather
feebly
in
the
eyes
of
the
warriors
,
inasmuch
as
the
command
"
eyes
front
"
had
been
given
,
and
all
the
spectator
saw
before
him
was
several
thousand
pair
of
optics
,
staring
straight
forward
,
wholly
divested
of
any
expression
whatever
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
in
a
capital
situation
now
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
round
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
had
gradually
dispersed
in
their
immediate
vicinity
,
and
they
were
nearly
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
!
"
echoed
both
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
they
doing
now
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
adjusting
his
spectacles
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
rather
think
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
changing
colour
---
"
<EOS>
I
rather
think
they
're
going
to
fire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
really
think
they
are
,
"
urged
Mr
Snodgrass
,
somewhat
alarmed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
uttered
the
word
,
when
the
whole
half
-
dozen
regiments
levelled
their
muskets
as
if
they
had
but
one
common
object
,
and
that
object
the
Pickwickians
,
and
burst
forth
with
the
most
awful
and
tremendous
discharge
that
ever
shook
the
earth
to
its
centres
,
or
an
elderly
gentleman
off
his
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
this
trying
situation
,
exposed
to
a
galling
fire
of
blank
cartridges
,
and
harassed
by
the
operations
of
the
military
<EOS>
,
a
fresh
body
of
whom
had
begun
to
fall
in
on
the
opposite
side
,
that
Mr
Pickwick
displayed
that
perfect
coolness
and
self
-
possession
,
which
are
the
indispensable
accompaniments
of
a
great
mind
.
 
<EOS>
He
seized
Mr
Winkle
by
the
arm
,
and
placing
himself
between
that
gentleman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
earnestly
besought
them
to
remember
that
beyond
the
possibility
of
being
rendered
deaf
by
the
noise
,
there
was
no
immediate
danger
to
be
apprehended
from
the
firing
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
---
but
---
suppose
some
of
the
men
should
happen
to
have
ball
cartridges
by
mistake
,
"
remonstrated
Mr
Winkle
,
pallid
at
the
supposition
he
was
himself
conjuring
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
heard
something
whistle
through
the
air
now
---
so
sharp
;
close
to
my
ear
.
"
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
throw
ourselves
on
our
faces
,
had
n't
we
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
---
it
's
over
now
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
His
lip
might
quiver
,
and
his
cheek
might
blanch
,
but
no
expression
of
fear
or
concern
escaped
the
lips
of
that
immortal
man
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
right
---
the
firing
ceased
;
but
he
had
scarcely
time
to
congratulate
himself
on
the
accuracy
of
his
opinion
,
when
a
quick
movement
was
visible
in
the
line
;
the
hoarse
shout
of
the
word
of
command
ran
along
it
,
and
before
either
of
the
party
could
form
a
guess
at
the
meaning
of
this
new
manoeuvre
,
the
whole
of
the
half
-
dozen
regiments
,
with
fixed
bayonets
,
charged
at
double
-
quick
time
down
upon
the
very
spot
on
which
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
were
stationed
.
<EOS>
Man
is
but
mortal
;
and
there
is
a
point
beyond
which
human
courage
can
not
extend
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
gazed
through
his
spectacles
for
an
instant
on
the
advancing
mass
,
and
then
fairly
turned
his
back
and
---
we
will
not
say
fled
;
firstly
,
because
it
is
an
ignoble
term
,
and
,
secondly
,
because
Mr
Pickwick
's
figure
was
by
no
means
adapted
for
that
mode
of
retreat
---
he
trotted
away
,
at
as
quick
a
rate
as
his
legs
would
convey
him
;
so
quickly
,
indeed
,
that
he
did
not
perceive
the
awkwardness
of
his
situation
,
to
the
full
extent
,
until
too
late
.
   
<EOS>
The
opposite
troops
,
whose
falling
-
in
had
perplexed
Mr
Pickwick
a
few
seconds
before
,
were
drawn
up
to
repel
the
mimic
attack
of
the
sham
besiegers
of
the
citadel
;
and
the
consequence
was
that
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
two
companions
found
themselves
suddenly
inclosed
between
two
lines
of
great
length
,
the
one
advancing
at
a
rapid
pace
,
and
the
other
firmly
waiting
the
collision
in
hostile
array
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hoi
!
"
shouted
the
officers
of
the
advancing
line
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
out
of
the
way
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
officers
of
the
stationary
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
we
to
go
to
?
<EOS>
"
screamed
the
agitated
Pickwickians
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hoi
---
hoi
---
hoi
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
only
reply
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
moment
of
intense
bewilderment
,
a
heavy
tramp
of
footsteps
,
a
violent
concussion
,
a
smothered
laugh
;
the
half
-
dozen
regiments
were
half
a
thousand
yards
off
,
and
the
soles
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
boots
were
elevated
in
air
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
had
each
performed
a
compulsory
somerset
with
remarkable
agility
,
when
the
first
object
that
met
the
eyes
of
the
latter
as
he
sat
on
the
ground
,
staunching
with
a
yellow
silk
handkerchief
the
stream
of
life
which
issued
from
his
nose
,
was
his
venerated
leader
at
some
distance
off
,
running
after
his
own
hat
,
which
was
gambolling
playfully
away
in
perspective
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
very
few
moments
in
a
man
's
existence
when
he
experiences
so
much
ludicrous
distress
,
or
meets
with
so
little
charitable
commiseration
,
as
when
he
is
in
pursuit
of
his
own
hat
.
<EOS>
A
vast
deal
of
coolness
,
and
a
peculiar
degree
of
judgment
,
are
requisite
in
catching
a
hat
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
must
not
be
precipitate
,
or
he
runs
over
it
;
he
must
not
rush
into
the
opposite
extreme
,
or
he
loses
it
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
way
is
to
keep
gently
up
with
the
object
of
pursuit
,
to
be
wary
and
cautious
,
to
watch
your
opportunity
well
,
get
gradually
before
it
,
then
make
a
rapid
dive
,
seize
it
by
the
crown
,
and
stick
it
firmly
on
your
head
;
smiling
pleasantly
all
the
time
,
as
if
you
thought
it
as
good
a
joke
as
anybody
else
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
fine
gentle
wind
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
's
hat
rolled
sportively
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
wind
puffed
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
puffed
,
and
the
hat
rolled
over
and
over
as
merrily
as
a
lively
porpoise
in
a
strong
tide
:
and
on
it
might
have
rolled
,
far
beyond
Mr
Pickwick
's
reach
,
<EOS>
had
not
its
course
been
providentially
stopped
,
just
as
that
gentleman
was
on
the
point
of
resigning
it
to
its
fate
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
we
say
,
was
completely
exhausted
,
and
about
to
give
up
the
chase
,
when
the
hat
was
blown
with
some
violence
against
the
wheel
of
a
carriage
,
which
was
drawn
up
in
a
line
with
half
a
dozen
other
vehicles
on
the
spot
to
which
his
steps
had
been
directed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
perceiving
his
advantage
,
darted
briskly
forward
,
secured
his
property
,
planted
it
on
his
head
,
and
paused
to
take
breath
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
stationary
half
a
minute
,
when
he
heard
his
own
name
eagerly
pronounced
by
a
voice
,
which
he
at
once
recognised
as
Mr
Tupman
's
,
and
,
looking
upwards
,
he
beheld
a
sight
which
filled
him
with
surprise
and
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
in
an
open
barouche
,
the
horses
of
which
had
been
taken
out
,
the
better
to
accommodate
it
to
the
crowded
place
,
stood
a
stout
old
gentleman
,
in
a
blue
coat
and
bright
buttons
,
corduroy
breeches
and
top
-
boots
,
two
young
ladies
in
scarfs
and
feathers
,
a
young
gentleman
apparently
enamoured
of
one
of
the
young
ladies
in
scarfs
and
feathers
,
a
lady
of
doubtful
age
,
probably
the
aunt
of
the
aforesaid
,
and
Mr
Tupman
,
as
easy
and
unconcerned
as
if
he
had
belonged
to
the
family
from
the
first
moments
of
his
infancy
.
 
<EOS>
Fastened
up
behind
the
barouche
<EOS>
was
a
hamper
of
spacious
dimensions
---
one
of
those
hampers
which
always
awakens
in
a
contemplative
mind
associations
connected
with
cold
fowls
,
tongues
,
and
bottles
of
wine
---
and
on
the
box
sat
a
fat
and
red
-
faced
boy
,
in
a
state
of
somnolency
,
whom
no
speculative
observer
could
have
regarded
for
an
instant
without
setting
down
as
the
official
dispenser
of
the
contents
of
the
before
-
mentioned
hamper
,
when
the
proper
time
for
their
consumption
should
arrive
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
bestowed
a
hasty
glance
on
these
interesting
objects
,
when
he
was
again
greeted
by
his
faithful
disciple
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pickwick
---
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
;
"
come
up
here
.
 
<EOS>
Make
haste
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
come
up
,
"
said
the
stout
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Joe
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
damn
that
boy
,
he
's
gone
to
sleep
again
.
<EOS>
---
Joe
,
let
down
the
steps
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
rolled
slowly
off
the
box
,
let
down
the
steps
,
and
held
the
carriage
door
invitingly
open
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
came
up
at
the
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Room
for
you
all
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
stout
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
inside
,
and
one
out
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
,
make
room
for
one
of
these
gentlemen
on
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Sir
,
come
along
;
"
and
the
stout
gentleman
extended
his
arm
,
and
pulled
first
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
then
Mr
Snodgrass
,
into
the
barouche
by
main

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
mounted
to
the
box
,
the
fat
boy
waddled
to
the
same
perch
,
and
fell
fast
asleep

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
stout
man
,
"
very

to
see
you
.
<EOS>
Know
you
very
well
,
gentlemen
,
though
you
may

.
 
<EOS>
I
spent
some
ev'nin
's
at
your
club
last

---
<EOS>
picked
up
my
friend
Mr
Tupman
here
this

,
and
very

I
was

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Sir
,
and
how
are
you
?
<EOS>
You
do
look
uncommon
well
,
to
be
sure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
acknowledged
the
compliment
,
and
cordially

hands
with
the
stout

in
the
top
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
how

,

?
"
said

,

Mr

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Charming
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Well
,
that
's
right
<EOS>
---
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
And
how
are

,

(

)
?
<EOS>
Well
,
I
am
glad

;
very

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

---
my
gals
<EOS>
these

;
and
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
's

Miss
,
she

;
and
yet
she
ai
n't
a
Miss
---
<EOS>
eh
,
Sir
,
eh
?
"
<EOS>
And
the
stout
gentleman
playfully
inserted
his
elbow
between
the
ribs
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
laughed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
brother
!
"
said
Miss
Wardle
,
with
a
deprecating

.
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
true
,
"
said
the
stout
gentleman
;
"
no
one
can
deny
it
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
I
beg
your
pardon
;
this
is
my
friend
Mr
Trundle
.
<EOS>
And
now
you
all
know
each
other
,
let
's
be
comfortable
and
happy
,
and
see
what
's
going
forward
;
that
's
what
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
the
stout
gentleman
put
on
his
spectacles
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
pulled
out
his
glass
,
and
everybody
stood
up
in
the
carriage
,
and
looked
over
somebody
else
's
shoulder
at
the
evolutions
of
the
military
.
   
<EOS>
Astounding
evolutions
they
were
,
one
rank
firing
over
the
heads
of
another
rank
,
and
then
running
away
;
and
then
the
other
rank
firing
over
the
heads
of
another
rank
,
and
running
away
in
their
turn
;
and
then
forming
squares
,
with
officers
in
the
centre
;
and
then
descending
the
trench
on
one
side
with
scaling
-
ladders
,
and
ascending
it
on
the
other
again
by
the
same
means
;
and
knocking
down
barricades
of
baskets
,
and
behaving
in
the
most
gallant
manner
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Then
there
was
such
a
ramming
down
of
the
contents
of
enormous
guns
on
the
battery
,
with
instruments
like
magnified
mops
;
such
a
preparation
before
they
were
let
off
,
and
such
an
awful
noise
when
they
did
go
,
that
the
air
resounded
with
the
screams
of
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
Misses
Wardle
were
so
frightened
,
that
Mr
Trundle
was
actually
obliged
to
hold
one
of
them
up
in
the
carriage
,
while
Mr
Snodgrass
supported
the
other
;
and
Mr
Wardle
's
sister
suffered
under
such
a
dreadful
state
of
nervous
alarm
,
that
Mr
Tupman
found
it
indispensably
necessary
to
put
his
arm
round
her
waist
,
to
keep
her
up
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
was
excited
,
except
the
fat
boy
,
and
he
slept
as
soundly
as
if
the
roaring
of
cannon
were
his
ordinary
lullaby
.
   
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
Joe
!
"
said
the
stout
gentleman
,
when
the
citadel
was
taken
,
and
the
besiegers
and
besieged
sat
down
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Damn
that
boy
,
he
's
gone
to

.
 
<EOS>
Be

to
pinch
him
,
sir
---
in

,

;
nothing
else

---
thank

.
<EOS>
Undo
the
hamper
,
Joe
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
,
who
had

by

a

finger

of

,

box

,
and
proceeded

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
we
must

close
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
After

about

the

,

,

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

Winkle

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Plates
,
Joe
,
plates
.
"
 
<EOS>
A

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Joe
,
the
fowls
.
 
<EOS>
Damn
<EOS>
that

;

.
<EOS>
Joe
!
<EOS>
Joe
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
Sundry

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>
"
That

---

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Take

ham
<EOS>
---

<EOS>
Such

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Now
ai

?
"
<EOS>
