<EOS>
"
Capital
!
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Glass

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!

<EOS>

<EOS>
(

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
How

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lor
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aunt

,

,
"
whispered
Miss

.
 
<EOS>
The

very

,
and
the

one
tried
to

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Young
girls
have
such
spirits
,
"
said
Miss
Wardle
to
Mr
Tupman
,
with
an
air
of
gentle
commiseration
,
as
if
animal
spirits
were
contraband
,
and
their
possession
without
a
permit
a
high
crime
and
misdemeanour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
they
have
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
,
not
exactly
making
the
sort
of
reply
that
was
expected
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
delightful
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
said
Miss
Wardle
,
rather
dubiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
permit
me
?
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
in
his
blandest
manner
,
touching
the
enchanting
Rachael
's
wrist
with
one
hand
,
and
gently
elevating
the
bottle
with
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
permit
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
sir
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
looked
most
impressive
;
and
Rachael
expressed
her
fear
that
more
guns
were
going
off
,
in
which
case
,
of
course
,
she
should
have
required
support
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
my
dear
nieces
pretty
?
"
whispered
their
affectionate
aunt
to
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
,
if
their
aunt
was
n't
here
,
"
replied
the
ready
Pickwickian
,
with
a
passionate
glance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
naughty
man
---
<EOS>
but
really
,
if
their
complexions
were
a
little
better
,
do
n't
you
think
they
would
be
nice
-
looking
girls
---
by
candlelight
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
think
they
would
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
with
an
air
of
indifference
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
quiz
---
<EOS>
I
know
what
you
were
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tupman
,
who
had
not
precisely
made
up
his
mind
to
say
anything
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
going
to
say
that
Isabel
stoops
---
I
know
you
were
---
you
men
are
such
observers
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
so
she
does
;
it
ca
n't
be
denied
;
and
,
certainly
,
if
there
is
one
thing
more
than
another
that
makes
a
girl
look
ugly
it
is
stooping
.
 
<EOS>
I
often
tell
her
that
when
she
gets
a
little
older
she
'll
be
quite
frightful
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
you
are
a
quiz
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
had
no
objection
to
earning
the
reputation
at
so
cheap
a
rate
:
so
he
looked
very
knowing
,
and
smiled
mysteriously
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
sarcastic
smile
,
"
said
the
admiring
Rachael
;
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
'm
quite
afraid
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Afraid
of
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
ca
n't
disguise
anything
from
me
---
I
know
what
that
smile
means
very
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
who
had
not
the
slightest
notion
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
mean
,
"
said
the
amiable
aunt
,
sinking
her
voice
still
lower
---
"
<EOS>
you
mean
,
that
you
do
n't
think
Isabella
's
stooping
is
as
bad
as
Emily
's
boldness
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
she
is
bold
!
<EOS>
You
can
not
think
how
wretched
it
makes
me
sometimes
<EOS>
---
I
'm
sure
I
cry
about
it
for
hours
together
---
<EOS>
my
dear
brother
is
SO
good
,
and
so
unsuspicious
,
that
he
never
sees
it
;
if
he
did
,
I
'm
quite
certain

would
break

.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
could
think
it
was
only
manner
<EOS>
---
I
hope
it
may
be
---
"
(
Here
the
affectionate
relative
heaved
a
deep
sigh
,
and
shook
her

despondingly
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
aunt
's
talking
about
us
,
"
whispered
Miss
Emily
Wardle
to
her
sister
---
<EOS>
"
I
'm
quite
certain
of
it
<EOS>
---
she
looks
so
malicious
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
she
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Isabella
.
<EOS>
---
"
Hem
!
aunt
,
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
love
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
SO
afraid
you
'll
catch
cold
,
aunt
---
<EOS>
have
a
silk
handkerchief
to
tie
round
<EOS>
your
dear
old
head
<EOS>
---
you
really
should
take
care
of
yourself
---
consider
your
age
!
"
   
<EOS>
However
well
deserved
this
piece
of
retaliation
might
have
been
,
it
was
as
vindictive
a
one
as
could
well

been

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
guessing
in
what
form
of
reply
the
aunt
's
indignation
would
have
vented
itself
,
had
not
Mr
Wardle
unconsciously
changed
the
subject
,
by
calling
emphatically
for
Joe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Damn
that
boy
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
he
's
gone
to
sleep
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
extraordinary
boy
,
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
does
he
always
sleep
in
this
way
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sleep
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
he
's
always
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
Goes
on
errands
fast
asleep
,
and
snores
as
he
waits
at
table
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
very
odd
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
odd
indeed
,
"
returned
the
old
gentleman
;
"
I
'm
proud
of
that
boy
---
would
n't
part
with
him
on
any
account
---
he
's
a
natural
curiosity
!
<EOS>
Here
,
Joe
---
Joe
---
take
these
things
away
,
and
open
another
bottle
---
d'ye
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
rose
,
opened
his
eyes
,
swallowed
the
huge
piece
of
pie
he
had
been
in
the
act
of
masticating
when
he
last
fell
asleep
,
and
slowly
obeyed
his
master
's
orders
---
gloating
languidly
over
the
remains
of
the
feast
,
as
he
removed
the
plates
,
and
deposited
them
in
the
hamper
.
 
<EOS>
The
fresh
bottle
was
produced
,
and
speedily
emptied
:
the
hamper
was
made
fast
in
its
old
place
---
the
fat
boy
once
more
mounted
the
box
---
the
spectacles
and
pocket
-
glass
were
again
adjusted
---
and
the
evolutions
of
the
military
recommenced
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
fizzing
and
banging
of
guns
,
and
starting
of
ladies
---
and
then
a
Mine
was
sprung
,
to
the
gratification
of
everybody
---
and
when
the
mine
had
gone
off
,
the
military
and
the
company
followed
its
example
,
and
went
off
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
mind
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
as
he
shook
hands
with
Mr
Pickwick
at
the
conclusion
of
a
conversation
which
had
been
carried
on
at
intervals
,
during
the
conclusion
of
the
proceedings
,
"
we
shall
see
you
all
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Most
certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
got
the
address
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Manor
Farm
,
Dingley
Dell
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
consulting
his
pocket
-
book
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
let
you
off
,
mind
,
under
a
week
;
and
undertake
that
you
shall
see
everything
worth
seeing
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
've
come
down
for
a
country
life
,
come
to
me
,
and
I
'll
give
you
plenty
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
---
damn
that
boy
,
he
's
gone
to
sleep
again
---
Joe
,
help
Tom
put
in
the
horses
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
horses
were
put
in
---
the
driver
mounted
---
the
fat
boy
clambered
up
by
his
side
---
farewells
were
exchanged
---
and
the
carriage
rattled
off
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
Pickwickians
turned
round
to
take
a
last
glimpse
of
it
,
the
setting
sun
cast
a
rich
glow
on
the
faces
of
their
entertainers
,
and
fell
upon
the
form
of
the
fat
boy
.
 
<EOS>
His
head
was
sunk
upon
his
bosom
;
and
he
slumbered
again
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
5
.
<EOS>
A
short
one
---
showing
,
among
oher
matters
,
how
Mr
Pickwick
undertook
to
drive
,
and
Mr
Winkle
to
ride
,
and
how
they
both
did
it
 
Bright
and
pleasant
was
the
sky
,
balmy
the
air
,
and
beautiful
the
appearance
of
every
object
around
,
as
Mr
Pickwick
leaned
over
the
balustrades
of
Rochester
Bridge
,
contemplating
nature
,
and
waiting
for
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
The
scene
was
indeed
one
which
might
well
have
charmed
a
far
less
reflective
mind
,
than
that
to
which
it
was
presented
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
left
of
the
spectator
lay
the
ruined
wall
,
broken
in
many
places
,
and
in
some
,
overhanging
the
narrow
beach
below
in
rude
and
heavy
masses
.
 
<EOS>
Huge
knots
of
seaweed
hung
upon
the
jagged
and
pointed
stones
,
trembling
in
every
breath
of
wind
;
and
the
green
ivy
clung
mournfully
round
the
dark
and
ruined
battlements
.
<EOS>
Behind
it
rose
the
ancient
castle
,
its
towers
roofless
,
and
its
massive
walls
crumbling
away
,
but
telling
us
proudly
of
its
old
might
and
strength
,
as
when
,
seven
hundred
years
ago
,
it
rang
with
the
clash
of
arms
,
or
resounded
with
the
noise
of
feasting
and
revelry
.
 
<EOS>
On
either
side
,
the
banks
of
the
Medway
,
covered
with
cornfields
and
pastures
,
with
here
and
there
a
windmill
,
or
a
distant
church
,
stretched
away
as
far
as
the
eye
could
see
,
presenting
a
rich
and
varied
landscape
,
rendered
more
beautiful
by
the
changing
shadows
which
passed
swiftly
across
it
as
the
thin
and
half
-
formed
clouds
skimmed
away
in
the
light
of
the
morning
sun
.
 
<EOS>
The
river
,
reflecting
the
clear
blue
of
the
sky
,
glistened
and
sparkled
as
it
flowed
noiselessly
on
;
and
the
oars
of
the
fishermen
dipped
into
the
water
with
a
clear
and
liquid
sound
,
as
their
heavy
but
picturesque
boats
glided
slowly
down
the
stream
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
roused
from
the
agreeable
reverie
into
which
he
had
been
led
by
the
objects
before
him
,
by
a
deep
sigh
,
and
a
touch
on
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
round
:
and
the
dismal
man
was
at
his
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Contemplating
the
scene
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
dismal
man
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
congratulating
yourself
on
being
up
so
soon
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
people
need
to
rise
early
,
to
see
the
sun
in
all
his
splendour
,
for
his
brightness
seldom
lasts
the
day
through
.
 
<EOS>
The
morning
of
day
and
the
morning
of
life
are
but
too
much
alike
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
speak
truly
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
common
the
saying
,
"
continued
the
dismal
man
,
"
"
<EOS>
The
morning
's
too
fine
to
last
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
How
well
might
it
be
applied
to
our
everyday
existence
.
 
<EOS>
God
!
<EOS>
what
would
I
forfeit
to
have
the
days
of
my
childhood
restored
,
or
to
be
able
to
forget
them
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
seen
much
trouble
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
compassionately
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
said
the
dismal
man
hurriedly
;
"
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
those
who
see
me
now
would
believe
possible
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
paused
for
an
instant
,
and
then
said
abruptly
---
   
"
<EOS>
Did
it
ever
strike
you
,
on
such
a
morning
as
this
,
that
drowning
would
be
happiness
and
peace
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
,
no
!
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
edging
a
little
from
the
balustrade
,
as
the
possibility
of
the
dismal
man
's
tipping
him
over
,
by
way
of
experiment
,
occurred
to
him
rather
forcibly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
so
,
often
,
"
said
the
dismal
man
,
without
noticing
the
action
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
calm
,
cool
water
seems
to
me
to
murmur
an
invitation
to
repose
and
rest
.
 
<EOS>
A
bound
,
a
splash
,
a
brief
struggle
;
there
is
an
eddy
for
an
instant
,
it
gradually
subsides
into
a
gentle
ripple
;
the
waters
have
closed
above
your
head
,
and
the
world
has
closed
upon
your
miseries
and
misfortunes
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sunken
eye
of
the
dismal
man
flashed
brightly
as
he
spoke
,
but
the
momentary
excitement
quickly
subsided
;
and
he
turned
calmly
away
,
as
he
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
There
---
enough
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
see
you
on
another
subject
.
<EOS>
You
invited
me
to
read
that
paper
,
the
night
before
last
,
and
listened
attentively
while
I
did
so
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
and
I
certainly
thought
---
"
   
"
I
asked
for
no
opinion
,
"
said
the
dismal
man
,
interrupting
him
,
"
and
I
want
none
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
travelling
for
amusement
and
instruction
.
<EOS>
Suppose
I
forward
you
a
curious
manuscript
---
observe
,
not
curious
because
wild
or
improbable
,
but
curious
as
a
leaf
from
the
romance
of
real
life
---
would
you
communicate
it
to
the
club
,
of
which
you
have
spoken
so
frequently
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
if
you
wished
it
;
and
it
would
be
entered
on
their
transactions
.
"
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
it
,
"
replied
the
dismal
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
address
;
"
and
,
Mr
Pickwick
having
communicated
their
probable
route
<EOS>
,
the
dismal
man
carefully
noted
it
down
in
a
greasy
pocket
-
book
,
and
,
resisting
Mr
Pickwick
's
pressing
invitation
to
breakfast
,
left
that
gentleman
at
his
inn
,
and
walked
slowly
away
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
found
that
his
three
companions
had
risen
,
and
were
waiting
his
arrival
to
commence
breakfast
,
which
was
ready
laid
in
tempting
display
.
 
<EOS>
They
sat
down
to
the
meal
;
and
broiled
ham
,
eggs
,
tea
,
coffee
and
sundries
,
began
to
disappear
with
a
rapidity
which
at
once
bore
testimony
to
the
excellence
of
the
fare
,
and
the
appetites
of
its
consumers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
about
Manor
Farm
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
shall
we
go
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
consult
the
waiter
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
;
and
the
waiter
was
summoned
accordingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dingley
Dell
,
gentlemen
---
fifteen
miles
,
gentlemen
---
cross
road
---
post
-
chaise
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Post
-
chaise
wo
n't
hold
more
than
two
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
sir
---
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Very
nice
four
-
wheel
chaise
,
sir
---
seat
for
two
behind
---
one
in
front
for
the
gentleman
that
drives
---
<EOS>
oh
!
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
---
<EOS>
that
'll
only
hold
three
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
to
be
done
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
one
of
the
gentlemen
would
like
to
ride
,
sir
?
"
suggested
the
waiter
,
looking
towards
Mr
Winkle
;
"
<EOS>
very
good
saddle
-
horses
,
sir
---
any
of
Mr
Wardle
's
men
coming
to
Rochester
,
bring
'em
back
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
very
thing
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Winkle
,
will
you
go
on
horseback
?
"
   
<EOS>
Now
Mr
Winkle
did
entertain
considerable
misgivings
in
the
very
lowest
recesses
of
his
own
heart
,
relative
to
his
equestrian
skill
;
but
,
as
he
would
not
have
them
even
suspected
,
on
any
account
,
he
at
once
replied
with
great
hardihood
,
"
Certainly
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
enjoy
it
of
all
things
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
had
rushed
upon
his
fate
;
there
was
no
resource
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
them
be
at
the
door
by
eleven
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
The
waiter
retired
;
the
breakfast
concluded
;
and
the
travellers
ascended
to
their
respective
bedrooms
,
to
prepare
a
change
of
clothing
,
to
take
with
them
on
their
approaching
expedition
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
made
his
preliminary
arrangements
,
and
was
looking
over
the
coffee
-
room
blinds
at
the
passengers
in
the
street
,
when
the
waiter
entered
,
and
announced
that
the
chaise
was
ready
---
an
announcement
which
the
vehicle
itself
confirmed
,
by
forthwith
appearing
before
the
coffee
-
room
blinds
aforesaid
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
curious
little
green
box
on
four
wheels
,
with
a
low
place
like
a
wine
-
bin
for
two
behind
,
and
an
elevated
perch
for
one
in
front
,
drawn
by
an
immense
brown
horse
,
displaying
great
symmetry
of
bone
.
 
<EOS>
An
hostler
stood
near
,
holding
by
the
bridle
another
immense
horse
---
apparently
a
near
relative
of
the
animal
in
the
chaise
---
ready
saddled
for
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
they
stood
upon
the
pavement
while
the
coats
were
being
put
in
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
<EOS>
who
's
to
drive
?
<EOS>
I
never
thought
of
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
slightest
fear
,
Sir
,
"
interposed
the
hostler
.
 
<EOS>
"
Warrant
him
quiet
,
Sir
;
a
hinfant
in
arms
might
drive
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
do
n't
shy
,
does
he
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shy
,
sir?-he
would
n't
shy
if
he
was
to
meet
a
vagin
-
load
of
monkeys
with
their
tails
burned
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
last
recommendation
was
indisputable
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
got
into
the
bin
;
Mr
Pickwick
ascended
to
his
perch
,
and
deposited
his
feet
on
a
floor
-
clothed
shelf
,
erected
beneath
it
for
that
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
shiny
Villiam
,
"
said
the
hostler
to
the
deputy
hostler
,
"
give
the
gen'lm'n
the
ribbons
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shiny
Villiam
"
---
so
called
,
probably
,
from
his
sleek
hair
and
oily
countenance
---
placed
the
reins
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
left
hand
;
and
the
upper
hostler
thrust
a
whip
into
his
right
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
-
o
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
the
tall
quadruped
evinced
a
decided
inclination
to
back
into
the
coffee
-
room
window
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wo
-
o
!
"
echoed
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
from
the
bin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
his
playfulness
,
gen'lm'n
<EOS>
,
"
said
the
head
hostler
encouragingly
;
"
jist
kitch
hold
on
him
,
Villiam
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
deputy
restrained
the
animal
's
impetuosity
,
and
the
principal
ran
to
assist
Mr
Winkle
in
mounting
.
   
<EOS>
"
T'other
side
,
sir
,
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Blowed
if
the
gen'lm'n
worn't
a
-
gettin
'
up
on
the
wrong
side
,
"
whispered
a
grinning
post
-
boy
to
the
inexpressibly
gratified
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
thus
instructed
,
climbed
into
his
saddle
,
with
about
as
much
difficulty
as
he
would
have
experienced
in
getting
up
the
side
of
a
first
-
rate
man
-
of
-
war
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
right
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
an
inward
presentiment
that
it
was
all
wrong
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
'em
go
,
"
cried
the
hostler
.
<EOS>
---
"
Hold
him
in
,
sir
;
"
and
away
went
the
chaise
,
and
the
saddle
-
horse
,
with
Mr
Pickwick
on
the
box
of
the
one
,
and
Mr
Winkle
on
the
back
of
the
other
,
to
the
delight
and
gratification
of
the
whole
inn
-
yard
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
makes
him
go
sideways
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
in
the
bin
,
to
Mr
Winkle
in
the
saddle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
imagine
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
His
horse
was
drifting
up
the
street
in
the
most
mysterious
manner
---
side
first
,
with
his
head
towards
one
side
of
the
way
,
and
his
tail
towards
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
no
leisure
to
observe
either
this
or
any
other
particular
,
the
whole
of
his
faculties
being
concentrated
in
the
management
of
the
animal
attached
to
the
chaise
,
who
displayed
various
peculiarities
,
highly
interesting
to
a
bystander
,
but
by
no
means
equally
amusing
to
any
one
seated
behind
him
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
constantly
jerking
his
head
up
,
in
a
very
unpleasant
and
uncomfortable
manner
,
and
tugging
at
the
reins
to
an
extent
which
rendered
it
a
matter
of
great
difficulty
for
Mr
Pickwick
to
hold
them
,
he
had
a
singular
propensity
for
darting
suddenly
every
now
and
then
to
the
side
of
the
road
,
then
stopping
short
,
and
then
rushing
forward
for
some
minutes
,
at
a
speed
which
it
was
wholly
impossible
to
control
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
CAN
he
mean
by
this
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
when
the
horse
had
executed
this
manoeuvre
for
the
twentieth
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
;
"
it
looks
very
like
shying
,
do
n't
it
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
was
about
to
reply
,
when
he
was
interrupted
by
a
shout
from
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Woo
!
"
said
that
gentleman
;
"
I
have
dropped
my
whip
.
"
<EOS>
"
Winkle
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
as
the
equestrian
came
trotting
up
on
the
tall
horse
,
with
his
hat
over
his
ears
,
and
shaking
all
over
,
as
if
he
would
shake
to
pieces
,
with
the
violence
of
the
exercise
,
"
pick
up
the
whip
<EOS>
,
there
's
a
good
fellow
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
pulled
at
the
bridle
of
the
tall
horse
till
he
was
black
in
the
face
;
and
having
at
length
succeeded
in
stopping
him
,
dismounted
,
handed
the
whip
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
grasping
the
reins
,
prepared
to
remount
.
   
<EOS>
Now
whether
the
tall
horse
,
in
the
natural
playfulness
of
his
disposition
,
was
desirous
of
having
a
little
innocent
recreation
with
Mr
Winkle
,
or
whether
it
occurred
to
him
that
he
could
perform
the
journey
as
much
to
his
own
satisfaction
without
a
rider
as
with
one
,
are
points
upon
which
,
of
course
,
we
can
arrive
at
no
definite
and
distinct
conclusion
.
 
<EOS>
By
whatever
motives
the
animal
was
actuated
,
certain
it
is
that
Mr
Winkle
had
no
sooner
touched
the
reins
,
than
he
slipped
them
over
his
head
,
and
darted
backwards
to
their
full
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
soothingly
---
"
poor
fellow
---
good
old
horse
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
"
poor
fellow
"
was
proof
against
flattery
;
the
more
Mr
Winkle
tried
to
get
nearer
him
,
the
more
he
sidled
away
;
and
,
notwithstanding
all
kinds
of
coaxing
and
wheedling
,
there
were
Mr
Winkle
and
the
horse
going
round
and
round
each
other
for
ten
minutes
,
at
the
end
of
which
time
each
was
at
precisely
the
same
distance
from
the
other
as
when
they
first
commenced
---
an
unsatisfactory
sort
of
thing
under
any
circumstances
,
but
particularly
so
in
a
lonely
road
,
where
no
assistance
can
be
procured
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
?
"
shouted
Mr
Winkle
,
after
the
dodging
had
been
prolonged
for
a
considerable
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
?
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
get
on
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
lead
him
till
we
come
to
a
turnpike
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
from
the
chaise
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
wo
n't
come
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
come
and
hold
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
the
very
personation
of
kindness
and
humanity
:
he
threw
the
reins
on
the
horse
's
back
,
and
having
descended
from
his
seat
,
carefully
drew
the
chaise
into
the
hedge
,
lest
anything
should
come
along
the
road
,
and
stepped
back
to
the
assistance
of
his
distressed
companion
,
leaving
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
in
the
vehicle
.
   
<EOS>
The
horse
no
sooner
beheld
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
advancing
towards
him
with
the
chaise
whip
in
his
hand
,
than
he
exchanged
the
rotary
motion
in
which
he
had
previously
indulged
,
for
a
retrograde
movement
of
<EOS>
so
very
determined
a
character
,
that
it
at
once
drew
Mr
Winkle
,
who
was
still
at
the
end
of
the
bridle
,
at
a
rather
quicker
rate
than
fast
walking
,
in
the
direction
from
which
they
had
just
come
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
ran
to
his
assistance
,
but
the
faster
Mr
Pickwick
ran
forward
,
the
faster
the
horse
ran
backward
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
scraping
of
feet
,
and
kicking
up
of
the
dust
;
and
at
last
Mr
Winkle
,
his
arms
being
nearly
pulled
out
of
their
sockets
,
fairly
let
go
his
hold
.
 
<EOS>
The
horse
paused
,
stared
,
shook
his
head
,
turned
round
,
and
quietly
trotted
home
to
Rochester
,
leaving
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Pickwick
gazing
on
each
other
with
countenances
of
blank
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
A
rattling
noise
at
a
little
distance
attracted
their
attention
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
agonised
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
there
's
the
other
horse
running
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
but
too
true
.
 
<EOS>
The
animal
was
startled
by
the
noise
,
and
the
reins
were
on
his
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
results
may
be
guessed
.
 
<EOS>
He
tore
off
with
the
four
-
wheeled
chaise
behind
him
,
and
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
in
the
four
-
wheeled
chaise
.
 
<EOS>
The
heat
was
a
short
one
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
threw
himself
into
the
hedge
,
Mr
Snodgrass
followed
his
example
,
the
horse
dashed
the
four
---
wheeled
chaise
against
a
wooden
bridge
,
separated
the
wheels
from
the
body
,
and
the
bin
from
the
perch
;
and
finally
stood
stock
still
to
gaze
upon
the
ruin
he
had
made
.
   
<EOS>
The
first
care
of
the
two
unspilt
friends
was
to
extricate
their
unfortunate
companions
from
their
bed
of
quickset
---
a
process
which
gave
them
the
unspeakable
satisfaction
of
discovering
that
they
had
sustained
no
injury
,
beyond
sundry
rents
in
their
garments
,
and
various
lacerations
from
the
brambles
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
thing
to
be
done
was
to
unharness
the
horse
.
 
<EOS>
This
complicated
process
having
been
effected
,
the
party
walked
slowly
forward
,
leading
the
horse
among
them
,
and
abandoning
the
chaise
to
its
fate
.
   
<EOS>
An
hour
's
walk
brought
the
travellers
to
a
little
road
-
side
public
-
house
,
with
two
elm
-
trees
,
a
horse
trough
,
and
a
signpost
,
in
front
;
one
or
two
deformed
hay
-
ricks
behind
,
a
kitchen
garden
at
the
side
,
and
rotten
sheds
and
mouldering
outhouses
jumbled
in
strange
confusion
all
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
red
-
headed
man
was
working
in
the
garden
;
and
to
him
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
called
lustily
,
"
Hollo
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
red
-
headed
man
raised
his
body
,
shaded
his

with
his
hand
,
and
stared
,
long

,

Mr
Pickwick
and
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
there
!
"
<EOS>

Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
red
-
headed
man
's
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
far
is
it
to
Dingley
Dell
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Better
er
seven
mile
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it

good

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
tain't
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
uttered

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

"

;
"
I

can
,
ca

?
"
<EOS>
"
Want

"

<EOS>
"
Of

"

,

<EOS>
"
Missus
"
---
roared

,

---
"
missus
!
"
   
<EOS>
A

,

---
straight

---
in

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

,

,

in
his
most

.
<EOS>
The
woman
looked
very
hard
at

;
and

something
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,

"

'm

.
"

Afraid
!
"
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,

"

woan't

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

Most

"

<EOS>

---

.

"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

from
one

to

.
<EOS>
Saying

.
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

he
ca

!
"
 
<EOS>
The
depressed
Pickwickians

,

,

,
following

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
late
in

when
the
four

and

four

into
the
lane

Manor
Farm
;
and

,
<EOS>
the

was

as
they

on
the

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
Torn

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
Mr
Pickwick
cursed
that
horse
:
he
had
eyed

noble

from

with

of
hatred

;

by

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
It

Wardle
,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
Not

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Joe

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

,

,

wo
nt

when

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
,
having

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

a

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

"
Loaded
"
---

.
 
<EOS>
An
old
eight

,

,

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"
and

<EOS>

"
    
Chapter
6
.
<EOS>
An
old
-
fashioned
card
-
party
---
the

's

---
<EOS>
the
story
of
the
convict
's
return
 
Several

the

,

,

---
a

in

,
in

other
great

,
delighted
to

.
   
<EOS>
A
very
old

,
in

---
no

's

---

;
and
various

when

,

,

,

,

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
aunt
,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
On

;

,

,

,

home
-

to
other

's

,
but
of

.
 
<EOS>
A
little

,
Ripstone

-

,

;

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
,
mother
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

,

;
"
I
ca
n't

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

!
"

<EOS>
"

!
"

.

.

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

ai

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

ai

,

<EOS>
"
'
Cept
Mullins
's
Meadows
,
"
observed
the
fat
man
solemnly
.
"
<EOS>
Mullins
's
Meadows
!
"
ejaculated
the
other
,
with
profound
contempt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Mullins
's
Meadows
,
"
repeated
the
fat
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Reg'lar
good
land
that
,
"
interposed
another
fat
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
it
is
,
sure
-
ly
,
"
said
a
third
fat
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
knows
that
,
"
said
the
corpulent
host
.
   
<EOS>
The
hard
-
headed
man
looked
dubiously
round
,
but
finding
himself
in
a
minority
,
assumed
a
compassionate
air
and
said
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
they
talking
about
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
old
lady
of
one
of
her
granddaughters
,
in
a
very
audible
voice
;
for
,
like
many
deaf
people
,
she
never
seemed
to
calculate
on
the
possibility
of
other
persons
hearing
what
she
said
herself
.
   
<EOS>
"
About
the
land
,
grandma
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
about
the
land
?
<EOS>
---
Nothing
the
matter
,
is
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Miller
was
saying
our
land
was
better
than
Mullins
's
Meadows
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
should
he
know
anything
about
it
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
old
lady
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Miller
's
a
conceited
coxcomb
,
and
<EOS>
you
may
tell
him
I
said
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
Saying
which
,
the
old
lady
,
quite
unconscious
that
she
had
spoken
above
a
whisper
,
drew
herself
up
,
and
looked
carving
-
knives
at
the
hard
-
headed
delinquent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
"
said
the
bustling
host
,
with
a
natural
anxiety
to
change
the
conversation
,
"
what
say
you
to
a
rubber
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
it
of
all
things
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
;
"
but
pray
do
n't
make
up
one
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
assure
you
,
mother
's
very
fond
of
a
rubber
,
"
said
Mr
Wardle
;
"
ai
n't
you
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
,
who
was
much
less
deaf
on
this
subject
than
on
any
other
,
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
Joe
!
"
said
the
gentleman
;
"
Joe
---
damn
that
---
oh
,
here
he
is
;
put
out
the
card
---
tables
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lethargic
youth
contrived
without
any
additional
rousing
to
set
out
two
card
-
tables
;
the
one
for
Pope
Joan
,
and
the
other
for
whist
.
 
<EOS>
The
whist
-
players
were
Mr
Pickwick
and
the
old
lady
,
Mr
Miller
and
the
fat
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
The
round
game
comprised
the
rest
of
the
company
.
   
<EOS>
The
rubber
was
conducted
with
all
that
gravity
of
deportment
and
sedateness
of
demeanour
which
befit
the
pursuit
entitled
"
whist
"
---
a
solemn
observance
,
to
which
,
as
it
appears
to
us
,
<EOS>
the
title
of
"
game
"
has
been
very
irreverently
and
ignominiously
applied
.
 
<EOS>
The
round
-
game
table
,
on
the
other
hand
,
was
so
boisterously
merry
as
materially
to
interrupt
the
contemplations
of
Mr
Miller
,
who
,
not
being
quite
so
much
absorbed
as
he
ought
to
have
been
,
contrived
to
commit
various
high
crimes
and
misdemeanours
,
which
excited
the
wrath
of
the
fat
gentleman
to
a
very
great
extent
,
and
called
forth
the
good
-
humour
of
the
old
lady
in
a
proportionate
degree
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
the
criminal
Miller
triumphantly
,
as
he
took
up
the
odd
trick
at
the
conclusion
of
a
hand
;
"
that
could
not
have
been
played
better
,
I
flatter
myself
;
impossible
to
have
made
another
trick
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miller
ought
to
have
trumped
the
diamond
,
ought
n't
he
,
Sir
?
"
said
the
old
lady
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ought
I
,
though
?
"
said
the
unfortunate
,
with
a
doubtful
appeal
to
his
partner
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ought
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
fat
gentleman
,
in
an
awful
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
sorry
,
"
said
the
crestfallen
Miller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Much
use
that
,
"
growled

fat

.
   
<EOS>
"
Two
by
honours
---
makes
us
eight
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Another
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
one
?
"
inquired
the
old
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Double
,
single
,
and
the
rub
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
was
such
luck
,
"
said
Mr
Miller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
was
such
cards
,
"
said
the
fat
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
A
solemn
silence
;
Mr
Pickwick
humorous
,
the
old
lady
serious
,
the
fat
gentleman
captious
,
and
Mr
Miller
timorous
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Another
double
,
"
said
the
old
lady
,
triumphantly
making
a
memorandum
of
the
circumstance
,
by
placing
one
sixpence
and
a
battered
halfpenny
under
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
double
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
aware
of
the
fact
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
fat
gentleman
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
Another
game
,
with
a
similar
result
,
was
followed
by
a
revoke
from
the
unlucky
Miller
;
on
which
the
fat
gentleman
burst
into
a
state
of
high
personal
excitement
which
lasted
until
the
conclusion
of
the
game
,
when
he
retired
into
a
corner
,
and
remained
perfectly
mute
for
one
hour
and
twenty
-
seven
minutes
;
at
the
end
of
which
time
he
emerged
from
his
retirement
,
and
offered
Mr
Pickwick
a
pinch
of
snuff
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
made
up
his
mind
to
a
Christian
forgiveness
of
injuries
sustained
.
<EOS>
The
old
lady
's
hearing
decidedly
improved
and
the
unlucky
Miller
felt
as
much
out
of
his
element
as
a
dolphin
in
a
sentry
-
box
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
the
round
game
proceeded
right
merrily
.
 
<EOS>
Isabella
Wardle
and
Mr
Trundle
"
went
partners
,
"
and
Emily
Wardle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
did
the
same
;
and
even
Mr
Tupman
and
the
spinster
aunt
established
a
joint
-
stock
company
of
fish
and
flattery
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Mr
Wardle
was
in
the
very
height
of
his
jollity
;
and
he
was
so
funny
in
his
management
of
the
board
,
and
the
old
ladies
were
so
sharp
after
their
winnings
,
that
the
whole
table
was
in
a
perpetual
roar
of
merriment
and
laughter
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
old
lady
who
always
had
about
half
a
dozen
cards
to
pay
for
,
at
which
everybody
laughed
,
<EOS>
regularly
every
round
;
and
when
the
old
lady
looked
cross
at
having
to
pay
,
they
laughed
louder
than
ever
;
on
which
the
old
lady
's
face
gradually
brightened
up
,
till
at
last
she
laughed
louder
than
any
of
them
,
Then
,
when
the
spinster
aunt
got
"
matrimony
,
"
the
young
ladies
laughed
afresh
,
and
the
Spinster
aunt
seemed
disposed
to
be
pettish
;
till
,
feeling
Mr
Tupman
squeezing
her
hand
under
the
table
,
she
brightened
up
too
,
and
looked
rather
knowing
,
as
if
matrimony
in
reality
were
not
quite
so
far
off
as
some
people
thought
for
;
whereupon
everybody
laughed
again
,
and
especially
old
Mr
Wardle
,
who
enjoyed
a
joke
as
much
as
the
youngest
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Snodgrass
,
he
did
nothing
but
whisper
poetical
sentiments
into
his
partner
's
ear
,
which
made
one
old
gentleman
facetiously
sly
,
about
partnerships
at
cards
and
partnerships
for
life
,
and
caused
the
aforesaid
old
gentleman
to
make
some
remarks
thereupon
,
accompanied
with
divers
winks
and
chuckles
,
which
made
the
company
very
merry
and
the
old
gentleman
's
wife
especially
so
.
<EOS>
And
Mr
Winkle
came
out
with
jokes
which
are
very
well
known
in
town
,
but
are
not
all
known
in
the
country
;
and
as
everybody
laughed
at
them
very
heartily
,
and
said
they
were
very
capital
,
Mr
Winkle
was
in
a
state
of
great
honour
and
glory
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
benevolent
clergyman
looked
pleasantly
on
;
for
the
happy
faces
which
surrounded
the
table
made
the
good
old
man
feel
happy
too
;
and
though
the
merriment
was
rather
boisterous
,
still
it
came
from
the
heart
and
not
from
the
lips
;
and
this
is
the
right
sort
of
merriment
,
after
all
.
   
<EOS>
The
evening
glided
swiftly
away
,
in
these
cheerful
recreations
;
and
when
the
substantial
though
homely
supper
had
been
despatched
,
and
the
little
party
formed
a
social
circle
round
the
fire
<EOS>
,
Mr
Pickwick
thought
he
had
never
felt
so
happy
in
his
life
,
and
at
no
time
so
much
disposed
to
enjoy
,
and
make
the
most
of
,
the
passing
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
this
,
"
said
the
hospitable
host
,
who
was
sitting
in
great
state
next
the
old
lady
's
arm
-
chair
,
with
her
hand
fast
clasped
in
his
---
"
this
is
just
what
I
like
---
<EOS>
the
happiest
moments
of
my
life
have
been
passed
at
this
old
fireside
;
and
I
am
so
attached
to
it
,
that
I
keep
up
a
blazing
fire
here
every
evening
,
until
it
actually
grows
too
hot
to
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
my
poor
old
mother
,
here
,
used
to
sit
before
this
fireplace
upon
that
little
stool
when
she
was
a
girl
;
did
n't
you
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
tear
which
starts
unbidden
to
the
eye
when
the
recollection
of
old
times
and
the
happiness
of
many
years
ago
is
suddenly
recalled
,
stole
down
the
old
lady
's
face
as
she
shook
her
head
with
a
melancholy
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
excuse
my
talking
about
this
old
place
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
resumed
the
host
,
after
a
short
pause
,
"
for
I
love
it
dearly
,
and
know
no
other
---
<EOS>
the
old
houses
and
fields
seem
like
living
friends
to
me
;
and
so
does
our
little
church
with
the
ivy
,
about
which
,
by
the
bye
,
our
excellent
friend
there
made
a
song
when
he
first
came
amongst
us
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
,
have
you
anything
in
your
glass
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Plenty
,
thank
you
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
,
whose
poetic
curiosity
had
been
greatly
excited
by
the
last
observation
of
his
entertainer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
but
you
were
talking
about
the
song
of
the
Ivy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
ask
our
friend
opposite
about
that
,
"
said
the
host
knowingly
,
indicating
the
clergyman
by
a
nod
