.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
say
that
I
should
like
to
hear
you
repeat
it
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
really
,
"
replied
the
clergyman
,
"
it
's
a
very
slight
affair
;
and
the
only
excuse
I
have
for
having
ever
perpetrated
it
is
,
that
I
was
a
young
man
at
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
Such
as
it
is
,
however
,
you
shall
hear
it
,
if
you
wish
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
murmur
of
curiosity
was
of
course
the
reply
;
and
the
old
gentleman
proceeded
to
recite
,
with
the
aid
of
sundry
promptings
from
his
wife
,
the
lines
in
question
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
call
them
,
"
said
he
,
     
THE
IVY
GREEN
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
a
dainty
plant
is
the
Ivy
green
<EOS>
,
That
creepeth
o'er
ruins
old
!
<EOS>
Of
right
choice
food
are
his
meals
,
I
ween
,
<EOS>
In
his
cell
so
lone
and
cold
.
<EOS>
The
wall
must
be
crumbled
,
the
stone
decayed
,
To
pleasure
his
dainty
whim
;
And
the
mouldering
dust
that
years
have
made
,
Is
a
merry
meal
for
him
.
     
<EOS>
Creeping
where
no
life
is
seen
,
     
<EOS>
A
rare
old
plant
is
the
Ivy
green
.
   
<EOS>
Fast
he
stealeth
on
,
though
he
wears
no
wings
,
And
a
staunch
old
heart
has
he
.
<EOS>
How
closely
he
twineth
,
how
tight
he
clings
To
his
friend
the
huge
Oak
Tree
!
<EOS>
And
slily
he
traileth
along
the
ground
,
And
his
leaves
he
gently
waves
,
As
he
joyously
hugs
and
crawleth
round
The
rich
mould
of
dead
men
's
graves
.
     
<EOS>
Creeping
where
grim
death
has
been
,
     
<EOS>
A
rare
old
plant
is
the
Ivy
green
.
   
<EOS>
Whole
ages
have
fled
and
their
works
decayed
,
And
nations
have
scattered
been
;
But
the
stout
old
Ivy
shall
never
fade
,
From
its
hale
and
hearty
green
.
<EOS>
The
brave
old
plant
in
its
lonely
days
,
Shall
fatten
upon
the
past
;
For
the
stateliest
building
man
can
raise
,
Is
the
Ivy
's
food
at
last
.
     
<EOS>
Creeping
on
where
time
has
been
,
     
<EOS>
A
rare
old
plant
is
the
Ivy
green
.
   
<EOS>
While
the
old
gentleman
repeated
these
lines
a
second
time
,
to
enable
Mr
Snodgrass
to
note
them
down
,
Mr
Pickwick
perused
the
lineaments
of
his
face
with
an
expression
of
great
interest
.
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
having
concluded
his
dictation
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
having
returned
his
note
-
book
to
his
pocket
,
Mr
Pickwick
said
---
   
"
<EOS>
Excuse
me
,
sir
,
for
making
the
remark
on
so
short
an
acquaintance
;
but
a
gentleman
like
yourself
can
not
fail
,
I
should
think
,
to
have
observed
many
scenes
and
incidents
worth
recording
,
in
the
course
of
your
experience
as
a
minister
of
the
Gospel
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
witnessed
some
certainly
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
,
"
but
the
incidents
and
characters
have
been
of
a
homely
and
ordinary
nature
,
my
sphere
of
action
being
so
very
limited
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
make
some
notes
,
I
think
,
about
John
Edmunds
,
did
you
not
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Wardle
,
who
appeared
very
desirous
to
draw
his
friend
out
,
for
the
edification
of
his
new
visitors
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
slightly
nodded
his
head
in
token
of
assent
,
and
was
proceeding
to
change
the
subject
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
but
pray
,
if
I
may
venture
to
inquire
,
who
was
John
Edmunds
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
very
thing
I
was
about
to
ask
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
eagerly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
fairly
in
for
it
,
"
said
the
jolly
host
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
satisfy
the
curiosity
of
these
gentlemen
,
sooner
or
later
;
so
you
had
better
take
advantage
of
this
favourable
opportunity
,
and
do
so
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
smiled
good
-
humouredly
as
he
drew
his
chair
forward
---
the
remainder
of
the
party
drew
their
chairs
closer
together
,
especially
Mr
Tupman
and
the
spinster
aunt
,
who
were
possibly
rather
hard
of
hearing
;
and
the
old
lady
's
ear
-
trumpet
having
been
duly
adjusted
,
and
Mr
Miller
(
who
had
fallen
asleep
during
the
recital
of
the
verses
)
roused
from
his
slumbers
by
an
admonitory
pinch
,
administered
beneath
the
table
by
his
ex
-
partner
the
solemn
fat
man
,
the
old
gentleman
,
without
further
preface
,
commenced
the
following
tale
,
to
which
we
have
taken
the
liberty
of
prefixing
the
title
of
     
THE
CONVICT
'S
RETURN
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
first
settled
in
this
village
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
which
is
now
just
five
-
and
-
twenty
years
ago
,
the
most
notorious
person
among
my
parishioners
was
a
man
of
the
name
of
Edmunds
,
who
leased
a
small
farm
near
this
spot
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
morose
,
savage
-
hearted
,
bad
man
;
idle
and
dissolute
in
his
habits
;
cruel
and
ferocious
in
his
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
the
few
lazy
and
reckless
vagabonds
with
whom
he
sauntered
away
his
time
in
the
fields
,
or
sotted
in
the
ale
-
house
,
he
had
not
a
single
friend
or
acquaintance
;
no
one
cared
to
speak
to
the
man
whom
many
feared
,
and
every
one
detested
---
and
Edmunds
was
shunned
by
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
man
had
a
wife
and
one
son
,
who
,
when
I
first
came
here
,
was
about
twelve
years
old
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
acuteness
of
that
woman
's
sufferings
,
of
the
gentle
and
enduring
manner
in
which
she
bore
them
,
of
the
agony
of
solicitude
with
which
she
reared
that
boy
,
no
one
can
form
an
adequate
conception
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
forgive
me
the
supposition
,
if
it
be
an
uncharitable
one
,
but
I
do
firmly
and
in
my
soul
believe
,
that
the
man
systematically
tried
for
many
years
to
break
her
heart
;
but
she
bore
it
all
for
her
child
's
sake
,
and
,
however
strange
it
may
seem
to
many
,
for
his
father
's
too
;
for
brute
as
he
was
,
and
cruelly
as
he
had
treated
her
,
she
had
loved
him
once
;
and
the
recollection
of
what
he
had
been
to
her
,
awakened
feelings
of
forbearance
and
meekness
under
suffering
in
her
bosom
,
to
which
all
God
's
creatures
,
but
women
,
are
strangers
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
were
poor
---
they
could
not
be
otherwise
when
the
man
pursued
such
courses
;
but
the
woman
's
unceasing
and
unwearied
exertions
,
early
and
late
,
morning
,
noon
,
and
night
,
kept
them
above
actual
want
.
 
<EOS>
These
exertions
were
but
ill
repaid
.
<EOS>
People
who
passed
the
spot
in
the
evening
---
sometimes
at
a
late
hour
of
the
night
---
reported
that
they
had
heard
the
moans
and
sobs
of
a
woman
in
distress
,
and
the
sound
of
blows
;
and
more
than
once
,
when
it
was
past
midnight
,
the
boy
knocked
softly
at
the
door
of
a
neighbour
's
house
,
whither
he
had
been
sent
,
to
escape
the
drunken
fury
of
his
unnatural
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
During
the
whole
of
this
time
,
and
when
the
poor
creature
often
bore
about
her
marks
of
ill
-
usage
and
violence
which
she
could
not
wholly
conceal
,
she
was
a
constant
attendant
at
our
little
church
.
 
<EOS>
Regularly
every
Sunday
,
morning
and
afternoon
,
she
occupied
the
same
seat
with
the
boy
at
her
side
;
and
though
they
were
both
poorly
dressed
---
much
more
so
than
many
of
their
neighbours
who
were
in
a
lower
station
---
they
were
always
neat
and
clean
.
 
<EOS>
Every
one
had
a
friendly
nod
and
a
kind
word
for
"
poor
Mrs
Edmunds
"
;
and
sometimes
,
when
she
stopped
to
exchange
a
few
words
with
a
neighbour
at
the
conclusion
of
the
service
in
the
little
row
of
elm
-
trees
which
leads
to
the
church
porch
,
or
lingered
behind
to
gaze
with
a
mother
's
pride
and
fondness
upon
her
healthy
boy
,
as
he
sported
before
her
with
some
little
companions
,
her
careworn
face
would
lighten
up
with
an
expression
of
heartfelt
gratitude
;
and
she
would
look
,
if
not
cheerful
and
happy
,
at
least
tranquil
and
contented
.
   
<EOS>
"
Five
or
six
years
passed
away
;
the
boy
had
become
a
robust
and
well
-
grown
youth
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
that
had
strengthened
the
child
's
slight
frame
and
knit
his
weak
limbs
into
the
strength
of
manhood
had
bowed
his
mother
's
form
,
and
enfeebled
her
steps
;
but
the
arm
that
should
have
supported
her
was
no
longer
locked
in
hers
;
the
face
that
should
have
cheered
her
,
no
more
looked
upon
her
own
.
 
<EOS>
She
occupied
her
old
seat
,
but
there
was
a
vacant
one
beside
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
Bible
was
kept
as
carefully
as
ever
,
the
places
were
found
and
folded
down
as
they
used
to
be
:
but
there
was
no
one
to
read
it
with
her
;
and
the
tears
fell
thick
and
fast
upon
the
book
,
and
blotted
the
words
from
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Neighbours
were
as
kind
as
they
were
wo
nt
to
be
of
old
,
but
she
shunned
their
greetings
with
averted
head
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
lingering
among
the
old
elm
-
trees
now
-
no
cheering
anticipations
of
happiness
yet
in
store
.
 
<EOS>
The
desolate
woman
drew
her
bonnet
closer
over
her
face
,
and
walked
hurriedly
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
tell
you
that
the
young
man
,
who
,
looking
back
to
the
earliest
of
his
childhood
's
days
to
which
memory
and
consciousness
extended
,
and
carrying
his
recollection
down
to
that
moment
,
could
remember
nothing
which
was
not
in
some
way
connected
with
a
long
series
of
voluntary
privations
suffered
by
his
mother
for
his
sake
,
with
ill
-
usage
,
and
insult
,
and
violence
,
and
all
endured
for
him
---
shall
I
tell
you
,
that
he
,
with
a
reckless
disregard
for
her
breaking
heart
,
and
a
sullen
,
wilful
forgetfulness
of
all
she
had
done
and
borne
for
him
,
had
linked
himself
with
depraved
and
abandoned
men
,
and
was
madly
pursuing
a
headlong
career
,
which
must
bring
death
to
him
,
and
shame
to
her
?
<EOS>
Alas
for
human
nature
!
<EOS>
You
have
anticipated
it
long
since
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
measure
of
the
unhappy
woman
's
misery
and
misfortune
was
about
to
be
completed
.
 
<EOS>
Numerous
offences
had
been
committed
in
the
neighbourhood
;
the
perpetrators
remained
undiscovered
,
and
their
boldness
increased
.
 
<EOS>
A
robbery
of
a
daring
and
aggravated
nature
occasioned
a
vigilance
of
pursuit
,
and
a
strictness
of
search
,
they
had
not
calculated
on
.
 
<EOS>
Young
Edmunds
was
suspected
,
with
three
companions
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
apprehended
---
committed
---
tried
---
condemned
---
to
die
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
wild
and
piercing
shriek
from
a
woman
's
voice
,
which
resounded
through
the
court
when
the
solemn
sentence
was
pronounced
,
rings
in
my
ears
at
this
moment
.
 
<EOS>
That
cry
struck
a
terror
to
the
culprit
's
heart
,
which
trial
,
condemnation
---
the
approach
of
death
itself
,
had
failed
to
awaken
.
 
<EOS>
The
lips
which
had
been
compressed
in
dogged
sullenness
throughout
,
quivered
and
parted
involuntarily
;
the
face
turned
ashy
pale
as
the
cold
perspiration
broke
forth
from
every
pore
;
the
sturdy
limbs
of
the
felon
trembled
,
and
he
staggered
in
the
dock
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
first
transports
of
her
mental
anguish
,
the
suffering
mother
threw
herself
on
her
knees
at
my
feet
,
and
fervently
sought
the
Almighty
Being
who
had
hitherto
supported
her
in
all
her
troubles
to
release
her
from
a
world
of
woe
and
misery
,
and
to
spare
the
life
of
her
only
child
.
 
<EOS>
A
burst
of
grief
,
and
a
violent
struggle
,
such
as
<EOS>
I
hope
I
may
never
have
to
witness
again
,
succeeded
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
her
heart
was
breaking
from
that
hour
;
but
I
never
once
heard
complaint
or
murmur
escape
her
lips
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
piteous
spectacle
to
see
that
woman
in
the
prison
-
yard
from
day
to
day
,
eagerly
and
fervently
attempting
,
by
affection
and
entreaty
,
to
soften
the
hard
heart
of
her
obdurate
son
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
He
remained
moody
,
obstinate
,
and
unmoved
.
 
<EOS>
Not
even
the
unlooked
-
for
commutation
of
his
sentence
to
transportation
for
fourteen
years
,
softened
for
an
instant
the
sullen
hardihood
of
his
demeanour
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
spirit
of
resignation
and
endurance
that
had
so
long
upheld
her
,
was
unable
to
contend
against
bodily
weakness
and
infirmity
.
 
<EOS>
She
fell
sick
.
 
<EOS>
She
dragged
her
tottering
limbs
from
the
bed
to
visit
her
son
once
more
,
but
her
strength
failed
her
,
and
she
sank
powerless
on
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
the
boasted
coldness
and
indifference
of
the
young
man
were
tested
indeed
;
and
the
retribution
that
fell
heavily
upon
him
nearly
drove
him
mad
.
 
<EOS>
A
day
passed
away
and
his
mother
was
not
there
;
another
flew
by
,
and
she
came
not
near
him
;
a
third
evening
arrived
,
and
yet
he
had
not
seen
her
---
,
and
in
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
he
was
to
be
separated
from
her
,
perhaps
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
how
the
long
-
forgotten
thoughts
of
former
days
rushed
upon
his
mind
,
as
he
almost
ran
up
and
down
the
narrow
yard
---
as
if
intelligence
would
arrive
the
sooner
for
his
hurrying
---
and
how
bitterly
a
sense
of
his
helplessness
and
desolation
rushed
upon
him
,
when
he
heard
the
truth
!
<EOS>
His
mother
,
the
only
parent
he
had
ever
known
,
lay
ill
---
it
might
be
,
dying
---
within
one
mile
of
the
ground
he
stood
on
;
were
he
free
and
unfettered
,
a
few
minutes
would
place
him
by
her
side
.
 
<EOS>
He
rushed
to
the
gate
,
and
grasping
the
iron
rails
with
the
energy
of
desperation
,
shook
it
till
it
rang
again
,
and
threw
himself
against
the
thick
wall
as
if
to
force
a
passage
through
the
stone
;
but
the
strong
building
mocked
his
feeble
efforts
,
and
he
beat
his
hands
together
and
wept
like
a
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
bore
the
mother
's
forgiveness
and
blessing
to
her
son
in
prison
;
and
I
carried
the
solemn
assurance
of
repentance
,
and
his
fervent
supplication
for
pardon
,
to
her
sick
-
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
,
with
pity
and
compassion
,
the
repentant
man
devise
a
thousand
little
plans
for
her
comfort
and
support
when
he
returned
;
but
I
knew
that
many
months
before
he
could
reach
his
place
of
destination
,
his
mother
would
be
no
longer
of
this
world
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
removed
by
night
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
weeks
afterwards
the
poor
woman
's
soul
took
its
flight
,
I
confidently
hope
,
and
solemnly
believe
,
to
a
place
of
eternal
happiness
and
rest
.
 
<EOS>
I
performed
the
burial
service
over
her
remains
.
 
<EOS>
She
lies
in
our
little
churchyard
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
stone
at
her
grave
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sorrows
were
known
to
man
;
her
virtues
to
God
.
<EOS>
"
it
had
been
arranged
previously
to
the
convict
's
departure
,
that
he
should
write
to
his
mother
as
soon
as
he
could
obtain
permission
,
and
that
the
letter
should
be
addressed
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
father
had
positively
refused
to
see
his
son
from
the
moment
of
his
apprehension
;
and
it
was
a
matter
of
indifference
to
him
whether
he
lived
or
died
.
 
<EOS>
Many
years
passed
over
without
any
intelligence
of
him
;
and
when
more
than
half
his
term
of
transportation
had
expired
,
and
I
had
received
no
letter
,
I
concluded
him
to
be
dead
,
as
,
indeed
<EOS>
,
I
almost
hoped
he
might
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
Edmunds
,
however
,
had
been
sent
a
considerable
distance
up
the
country
on
his
arrival
at
the
settlement
;
and
to
this
circumstance
,
perhaps
,
may
be
attributed
the
fact
,
that
though
several
letters
were
despatched
,
none
of
them
ever
reached
my
hands
.
<EOS>
He
remained
in
the
same
place
during
the
whole
fourteen
years
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
the
term
,
steadily
adhering
to
his
old
resolution
and
the
pledge
he
gave
his
mother
,
he
made
his
way
back
to
England
amidst
innumerable
difficulties
,
and
returned
,
on
foot
,
to
his
native
place
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
a
fine
Sunday
evening
,
in
the
month
of
August
,
John
Edmunds
set
foot
in
the
village
he
had
left
with
shame
and
disgrace
seventeen
years
before
.
 
<EOS>
His
nearest
way
lay
through
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
's
heart
swelled
as
he
crossed
the
stile
.
 
<EOS>
The
tall
old
elms
,
through
whose
branches
the
declining
sun
cast
here
and
there
a
rich
ray
of
light
upon
the
shady
part
,
awakened
the
associations
of
his
earliest
days
.
 
<EOS>
He
pictured
himself
as
he
was
then
,
clinging
to
his
mother
's
hand
,
and
walking
peacefully
to
church
.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
how
he
used
to
look
up
into
her
pale
face
;
and
how
her
eyes
would
sometimes
fill
with
tears
as
she
gazed
upon
his
features
---
tears
which
fell
hot
upon
his
forehead
as
she
stooped
to
kiss
him
,
and
made
him
weep
too
,
although
he
little
knew
then
what
bitter
tears
hers
were
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
how
often
he
had
run
merrily
down
that
path
with
some
childish
playfellow
,
looking
back
,
ever
and
again
,
to
catch
his
mother
's
smile
,
or
hear
her
gentle
voice
;
and
then
a
veil
seemed
lifted
from
his
memory
,
and
words
of
kindness
unrequited
,
and
warnings
despised
,
and
promises
broken
,
thronged
upon
his
recollection
till
his
heart
failed
him
,
and
he
could
bear
it
no
longer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
entered
the
church
.
 
<EOS>
The
evening
service
was
concluded
and
the
congregation
had
dispersed
,
but
it
was
not
yet
closed
.
 
<EOS>
His
steps
echoed
through
the
low
building
with
a
hollow
sound
,
and
he
almost
feared
to
be
alone
,
it
was
so
still
and
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
round
him
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
was
changed
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
seemed
smaller
than
it
used
to
be
;
but
there
were
the
old
monuments
on
which
he
had
gazed
with
childish
awe
a
thousand
times
;
the
little
pulpit
with
its
faded
cushion
;
the
Communion
table
before
which
he
had
so
often
repeated
the
Commandments
he
had
reverenced
as
a
child
,
and
forgotten
as
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
approached
the
old
seat
;
it
looked
cold
and
desolate
.
 
<EOS>
The
cushion
had
been
removed
,
and
the
Bible
was
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
his
mother
now
occupied
a
poorer
seat
,
or
possibly
she
had
grown
infirm
and
could
not
reach
the
church
alone
.
 
<EOS>
He
dared
not
think
of
what
he
feared
.
 
<EOS>
A
cold
feeling
crept
over
him
,
and
he
trembled
violently
as
he
turned
away
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
An
old
man
entered
the
porch
just
as
he
reached
it
.
 
<EOS>
Edmunds
started
back
,
for
he
knew
him
well
;
many
a
time
he
had
watched
him
digging
graves
in
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
he
say
to
the
returned
convict
?
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
man
raised
his
eyes
to
the
stranger
's
face
,
bade
him
"
good
-
evening
,
"
and
walked
slowly
on
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
forgotten
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
walked
down
the
hill
,
and
through
the
village
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
was
warm
,
and
the
people
were
sitting
at
their
doors
,
or
strolling
in
their
little
gardens
as
he
passed
,
enjoying
the
serenity
of
the
evening
,
and
their
rest
from
labour
.
 
<EOS>
Many
a
look
was
turned
towards
him
,
and
many
a
doubtful
glance
he
cast
on
either
side
to
see
whether
any
knew
and
shunned
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
strange
faces
in
almost
every
house
;
in
some
he
recognised
the
burly
form
of
some
old
schoolfellow
---
a
boy
when
he
last
saw
him
---
surrounded
by
a
troop
of
merry
children
;
in
others
he
saw
,
seated
in
an
easy
-
chair
at
a
cottage
door
,
a
feeble
and
infirm
old
man
,
whom
he
only
remembered
as
a
hale
and
hearty
labourer
;
but
they
had
all
forgotten
him
,
and
he
passed
on
unknown
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
last
soft
light
of
the
setting
sun
had
fallen
on
the
earth
,
casting
a
rich
glow
on
the
yellow
corn
sheaves
,
and
lengthening
the
shadows
of
the
orchard
trees
,
as
he
stood
before
the
old
house
 
---
the
home
of
his
infancy
---
to
which
his
heart
had
yearned
with
an
intensity
of
affection
not
to
be
described
,
through
long
and
weary
years
of
captivity
and
sorrow
.
 
<EOS>
The
paling
was
low
,
though
he
well
remembered
the
time
that
it
had
seemed
a
high
wall
to
him
;
and
he
looked
over
into
the
old
garden
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
more
seeds
and
gayer
flowers
than
there
used
to
be
,
but
there
were
the
old
trees
still
---
the
very
tree
under
which
he
had
lain
a
thousand
times
when
tired
of
playing
in
the
sun
,
and
felt
the
soft
,
mild
sleep
of
happy
boyhood
steal
gently
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
voices
within
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
listened
,
but
they
fell
strangely
upon
his
ear
;
he
knew
them
not
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
merry
too
;
and
he
well
knew
that
his
poor
old
mother
could
not
be
cheerful
,
and
he
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
opened
,
and
a
group
of
little
children
bounded
out
,
shouting
and
romping
.
 
<EOS>
The
father
,
with
a
little
boy
in
his
arms
,
appeared
at
the
door
,
and
they
crowded
round
him
,
clapping
their
tiny
hands
,
and
dragging
him
out
,
to
join
their
joyous
sports
.
 
<EOS>
The
convict
thought
on
the
many
times
he
had
shrunk
from
his
father
's
sight
in
that
very
place
.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
how
often
he
had
buried
his
trembling
head
beneath
the
bedclothes
,
and
heard
the
harsh
word
,
and
the
hard
stripe
,
and
his
mother
's
wailing
;
and
though
the
man
sobbed
aloud
with
agony
of
mind
as
he
left
the
spot
,
his
fist
was
clenched
,
and
his
teeth
were
set
,
in
a
fierce
and
deadly
passion
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
such
was
the
return
to
which
he
had
looked
through
the
weary
perspective
of
many
years
,
and
for
which
he
had
undergone
so
much
suffering
!
<EOS>
No
face
of
welcome
,
no
look
of
forgiveness
,
no
house
to
receive
,
no
hand
to
help
him
---
and
this
too
in
the
old
village
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
his
loneliness
in
the
wild
,
thick
woods
,
where
man
was
never
seen
,
to
this
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
felt
that
in
the
distant
land
of
his
bondage
and
infamy
,
he
had
thought
of
his
native
place
as
it
was
when
he
left
it
;
and
not
as
it
would
be
when
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
The
sad
reality
struck
coldly
at
his
heart
,
and
his
spirit
sank
within
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
courage
to
make
inquiries
,
or
to
present
himself
to
the
only
person
who
was
likely
to
receive
him
with
kindness
and
compassion
.
 
<EOS>
He
walked
slowly
on
;
and
shunning
the
roadside
like
a
guilty
man
,
turned
into
a
meadow
he
well
remembered
;
and
covering
his
face
with
his
hands
,
threw
himself
upon
the
grass
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
had
not
observed
that
a
man
was
lying
on
the
bank
beside
him
;
his
garments
rustled
as
he
turned
round
to
steal
a
look
at
the
new
-
comer
;
and
Edmunds
raised
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
man
had
moved
into
a
sitting
posture
.
 
<EOS>
His
body
was
much
bent
,
and
his
face
was
wrinkled
and
yellow
.
 
<EOS>
His
dress
denoted
him
an
inmate
of
the
workhouse
:
he
had
the
appearance
of
being
very
old
,
but
it
looked
more
the
effect
of
dissipation
or
disease
,
than
the
length
of
years
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
staring
hard
at
the
stranger
,
and
though
his
eyes
were
lustreless
and
heavy
at
first
,
they
appeared
to
glow
with
an
unnatural
and
alarmed
expression
after
they
had
been
fixed
upon
him
for
a
short
time
,
until
they
seemed
to
be
starting
from
their
sockets
.
 
<EOS>
Edmunds
gradually
raised
himself
to
his
knees
,
and
looked
more
and
more
earnestly
on
the
old
man
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
They
gazed
upon
each
other
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
man
was
ghastly
pale
.
 
<EOS>
He
shuddered
and
tottered
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
Edmunds
sprang
to
his
.
 
<EOS>
He
stepped
back
a
pace
or
two
.
<EOS>
Edmunds
advanced
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Let
me
hear
you
speak
,
"
said
the
convict
,
in
a
thick
,
broken
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Stand
off
!
"
cried
the
old
man
,
with
a
dreadful
oath
.
 
<EOS>
The
convict
drew
closer
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Stand
off
!
"
shrieked
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
Furious
with
terror
,
he
raised
his
stick
,
and
struck
Edmunds
a
heavy
blow
across
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Father
---
devil
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
the
convict
between
his
set
teeth
.
 
<EOS>
He
rushed
wildly
forward
,
and
clenched
the
old
man
by
the
throat
---
but
he
was
his
father
;
and
his
arm
fell
powerless
by
his
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
man
uttered
a
loud
yell
which
rang
through
the
lonely
fields
like
the
howl
of
an
evil
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
turned
black
,
the
gore
rushed
from
his
mouth
and
nose
,
and
dyed
the
grass
a
deep
,
dark
red
,
as
he
staggered
and
fell
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
ruptured
a
blood
-
vessel
,
and
he
was
a
dead
man
before
his
son
could
raise
him
.
"
<EOS>
In
that
corner
of
the
churchyard
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
after
a
silence
of
a
few
moments
,
"
in
that
corner
of
the
churchyard
of
which
I
have
before
spoken
,
there
lies
buried
a
man
who
was
in
my
employment
for
three
years
after
this
event
,
and
who
was
truly
contrite
,
penitent
,
and
humbled
,
if
ever
man
was
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
save
myself
knew
in
that
man
's
lifetime
who
he
was
,
or
whence
he
came
<EOS>
---
it
was
John
Edmunds
,
the
returned
convict
.
"
    
Chapter
7
.
<EOS>
How
Mr
Winkle
,
instead
of
shooting
at
the
pigeon
and
killing
the
crow
,
shot
at
the
crow
and
wounded
the
pigeon
;
how
the
Dingley
Dell
Cricket
Club
played
All
-
Muggleton
,
and
how
All
-
Muggleton
dined
at
the
Dingley
Dell
expense
;
with
other
interesting
and
instructive
matters
 
The
fatiguing
adventures
of
the
day
or
the
somniferous
influence
of
the
clergyman
's
tale
operated
so
strongly
on
the
drowsy
tendencies
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
that
in
less
than
five
minutes
after
he
had
been
shown
to
his
comfortable
bedroom
he
fell
into
a
sound
and
dreamless
sleep
,
from
which
he
was
only
awakened
by
the
morning
sun
darting
his
bright
beams
reproachfully
into
the
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
no
sluggard
,
and
he
sprang
like
an
ardent
warrior
from
his
tent
-
bedstead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pleasant
,
pleasant
country
,
"
sighed
the
enthusiastic
gentleman
,
as
he
opened
his
lattice
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
could
live
to
gaze
from
day
to
day
on
bricks
and
slates
who
had
once
felt
the
influence
of
a
scene
like
this
?
<EOS>
Who
could
continue
to
exist
where
there
are
no
cows
but
the
cows
on
the
chimney
-
pots
;
nothing
redolent
of
Pan
but
pan
-
tiles
;
no
crop
but
stone
crop
?
<EOS>
Who
could
bear
to
drag
out
a
life
in
such
a
spot
?
<EOS>
Who
,
I
ask
,
could
endure
it
?
"
<EOS>
and
,
having
cross
-
examined
solitude
after
the
most
approved
precedents
,
at
considerable
length
,
Mr
Pickwick
thrust
his
head
out
of
the
lattice
and
looked
around
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
rich
,
sweet
smell
of
the
hay
-
ricks
rose
to
his
chamber
window
;
the
hundred
perfumes
of
the
little
flower
-
garden
beneath
scented
the
air
around
;
the
deep
-
green
meadows
shone
in
the
morning
dew
that
glistened
on
every
leaf
as
it
trembled
in
the
gentle
air
;
and
the
birds
sang
as
if
every
sparkling
drop
were
to
them
a
fountain
of
inspiration
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
fell
into
an
enchanting
and
delicious
reverie
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
sound
that
roused
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
to
the
right
,
but
he
saw
nobody
;
his
eyes
wandered
to
the
left
,
and
pierced
the
prospect
;
he
stared
into
the
sky
,
but
he
was
n't
wanted
there
;
and
then
he
did
what
a
common
mind
would
have
done
at
once
---
looked
into
the
garden
,
and
there
saw
Mr
Wardle
.
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
?
"
said
the
good
-
humoured
individual
,
out
of
breath
with
his
own
anticipations
of
pleasure
.
"
<EOS>
Beautiful
morning
,
ai
n't
it
?
<EOS>
Glad
to
see
you
up
so
early
.
 
<EOS>
Make
haste
down
,
and
come
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
wait
for
you
here
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
needed
no
second
invitation
.
 
<EOS>
Ten
minutes
sufficed
for
the
completion
of
his
toilet
,
and
at
the
expiration
of
that
time
he
was
by
the
old
gentleman
's
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
in
his
turn
,
seeing
that
his
companion
was
armed
with
a
gun
,
and
that
another
lay
ready
on
the
grass
;
"
what
's
going
forward
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
your
friend
and
I
,
"
replied
the
host
,
"
are
going
out
rook
-
shooting
before
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
very
good
shot
,
ai
n't
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
heard
him
say
he
's
a
capital
one
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
but
I
never
saw
him
aim
at
anything
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
the
host
,
"
I
wish
he
'd
come
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
---
Joe
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
,
who
under
the
exciting
influence
of
the
morning
did
not
appear
to
be
more
than
three
parts
and
a
fraction
asleep
,
emerged
from
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
up
,
and
call
the
gentleman
,
and
tell
him
he
'll
find
me
and
Mr
Pickwick
in
the
rookery
.
 
<EOS>
Show
the
gentleman
the
way
there
;
d'ye
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
boy
departed
to
execute
his
commission
;
and
the
host
,
carrying
both
guns
like
a
second
Robinson
Crusoe
,
led
the
way
from
the
garden
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
place
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
pausing
after
a
few
minutes
walking
,
in
an
avenue
of
trees
.
 
<EOS>
The
information
was
unnecessary
;
for
the
incessant
cawing
of
the
unconscious
rooks
sufficiently
indicated
their
whereabouts
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
laid
one
gun
on
the
ground
,
and
loaded
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
they
are
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
,
as
he
spoke
,
the
forms
of
Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
Mr
Winkle
appeared
in
the
distance
.
 
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
,
not
being
quite
certain
<EOS>
which
gentleman
he
was
directed
to
call
,
had
with
peculiar
sagacity
,
and
to
prevent
the
possibility
of
any
mistake
,
called
them
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
"
shouted
the
old
gentleman
,
addressing
Mr
Winkle
;
"
a
keen
hand
like
you
ought
to
have
been
up
long
ago
,
even
to
such
poor
work
as
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
responded
with
a
forced
smile
,
and
took
up
the
spare
gun
with
an
expression
of
countenance
which
a
metaphysical
rook
,
impressed
with
a
foreboding
of
his
approaching
death
by
violence
,
may
be
supposed
to
assume
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
keenness
,
but
it
looked
remarkably
like
misery
.
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
nodded
;
and
two
ragged
boys
who
had
been
marshalled
to
the
spot
under
the
direction
of
the
infant
Lambert
,
forthwith
commenced
climbing
up
two
of
the
trees
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
these
lads
for
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
abruptly
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
rather
alarmed
;
for
he
was
not
quite
certain
but
that
the
distress
of
the
agricultural
interest
,
about
which
he
had
often
heard
a
great
deal
,
might
have
compelled
the
small
boys
attached
to
the
soil
to
earn
a
precarious
and
hazardous
subsistence
by
making
marks
of
themselves
for
inexperienced
sportsmen
.
<EOS>
"
Only
to
start
the
game
,
"
replied
Mr
Wardle
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
what
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
in
plain
English
,
to
frighten
the
rooks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is
that
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
satisfied
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
begin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
glad
of
any
respite
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
aside
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
Now
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
boy
shouted
,
and
shook
a
branch
with
a
nest
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
Half
a
dozen
young
rooks
in
violent
conversation
,
flew
out
to
ask
what
the
matter
was
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
fired
by
way
of
reply
.
 
<EOS>
Down
fell
one
bird
,
and
off
flew
the
others
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
him
up
,
Joe
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
smile
upon
the
youth
's
face
as
he
advanced
.
<EOS>
Indistinct
visions
of
rook
-
pie
floated
through
his
imagination
.
<EOS>
He
laughed
as
he
retired
with
the
bird
---
it
was
a
plump
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Winkle
,
"
said
the
host
,
reloading
his
own
gun
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fire
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
advanced
,
and
levelled
his
gun
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
cowered
involuntarily
to
escape
damage
from
the
heavy
fall
of
rooks
,
which
they
felt
quite
certain
would
be
occasioned
by
the
devastating
barrel
of
their
friend
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
solemn
pause
---
a
shout
---
a
flapping
of
wings
---
a
faint
click
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
it
go
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Missed
fire
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
who
was
very
pale
---
probably
from
disappointment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Odd
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
taking
the
gun
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
knew
one
of
them
miss
fire
before
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
do
n't
see
anything
of
the
cap
.
"
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
"
I
declare
I
forgot
the
cap
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
slight
omission
was
rectified
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
crouched
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
stepped
forward
with
an
air
of
determination
and
resolution
;
and
Mr
Tupman
looked
out
from
behind
a
tree
.
<EOS>
The
boy
shouted
;
four
birds
flew
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
fired
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
scream
as
of
an
individual
---
not
a
rook
---
in
corporal
anguish
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
had
saved
the
lives
of
innumerable
unoffending
birds
by
receiving
a
portion
of
the
charge
in
his
left
arm
.
   
<EOS>
To
describe
the
confusion
that
ensued
would
be
impossible
.
<EOS>
To
tell
how
Mr
Pickwick
in
the
first
transports
of
emotion
called
Mr
Winkle
"
Wretch
!
"
<EOS>
how
Mr
Tupman
lay
prostrate
on
the
ground
;
and
how
Mr
Winkle
knelt
horror
-
stricken
beside
him
;
how
Mr
Tupman
called
distractedly
upon
some
feminine
Christian
name
,
and
then
opened
first
one
eye
,
and
then
the
other
,
and
then
fell
back
and
shut
them
both
---
all
this
would
be
as
difficult
to
describe
in
detail
,
as
it
would
be
to
depict
the
gradual
recovering
of
the
unfortunate
individual
,
the
binding
up
of
his
arm
with
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
,
and
the
conveying
him
back
by
slow
degrees
supported
by
the
arms
of
his
anxious
friends
.
   
<EOS>
They
drew
near
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
were
at
the
garden
gate
,
waiting
for
their
arrival
and
their
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
The
spinster
aunt
appeared
;
she
smiled
,
and
beckoned
them
to
walk
quicker
.
 
<EOS>
'
Twas
evident
<EOS>
she
knew
not
of
the
disaster
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
thing
!
<EOS>
there
are
times
when
ignorance
is
bliss
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
They
approached
nearer
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
what
is
the
matter
with
the
little
old
gentleman
?
"
said
Isabella
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
The
spinster
aunt
heeded
not
the
remark
;
she
thought
it
applied
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
eyes
Tracy
Tupman
was
a
youth
;
she
viewed
his
years
through
a
diminishing
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
frightened
,
"
called
out
the
old
host
,
fearful
of
alarming
his
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
party
had
crowded
so
completely
round
Mr
Tupman
,
that
they
could
not
yet
clearly
discern
the
nature
of
the
accident
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
frightened
,
"
said
the
host
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
screamed
the
ladies
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tupman
has
met
with
a
little
accident
;
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
spinster
aunt
uttered
a
piercing
scream
,
burst
into
an
hysteric
laugh
,
and
fell
backwards
in
the
arms
of
her
nieces
.
   
<EOS>
"
Throw
some
cold
water
over
her
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
murmured
the
spinster
aunt
;
"
I
am
better
now
.
<EOS>
Bella
,
Emily
---
a
surgeon
!
 
<EOS>
Is
he
wounded
?
<EOS>
---
Is
he
dead
?
<EOS>
---
Is
he
---
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
the
spinster
aunt
burst
into
fit
number
two
,
of
hysteric
laughter
interspersed
with
screams
.
   
<EOS>
"
Calm
yourself
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
affected
almost
to
tears
by
this
expression
of
sympathy
with
his
sufferings
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
madam
,
calm
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
his
voice
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
spinster
aunt
;
and
strong
symptoms
of
fit
number
three
developed
themselves
forthwith
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
agitate
yourself
,
I
entreat
you
,
dearest
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
soothingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
little
hurt
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
not
dead
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
hysterical
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
say
you
are
not
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
a
fool
,
Rachael
,
"
interposed
Mr
Wardle
,
rather
more
roughly
than
was
consistent
with
the
poetic
nature
of
the
scene
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
's
the
use
of
his
saying
he
is
n't
dead
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
I
am
not
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
require
no
assistance
but
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
lean
on
your
arm
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
added
,
in
a
whisper
,
"
Oh
,
Miss
Rachael
!
"
<EOS>
The
agitated
female
advanced
,
and
offered
her
arm
.
 
<EOS>
They
turned
into
the
breakfast
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
gently
pressed
her
hand
to
his
lips
,
and
sank
upon
the
sofa
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
faint
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
anxious
Rachael
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
better
presently
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
closed
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
sleeps
,
"
murmured
the
spinster
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
(
His
organs
of
vision
had
been
closed
nearly
twenty
seconds
.
)
<EOS>
"
Dear
---
dear
---
Mr
Tupman
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
jumped
up
---
"
Oh
,
say
those
words
again
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
started
.
 
<EOS>
"
Surely
you
did
not
hear
them
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
bashfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
,
I
did
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Mr
Tupman
;
"
repeat
them
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
would
have
me
recover
,
repeat
them
.
"
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
said
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
brother
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
resumed
his
former
position
;
and
Mr
Wardle
,
accompanied
by
a
surgeon
,
entered
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
The
arm
was
examined
,
the
wound
dressed
,
and
pronounced
to
be
a
very
slight
one
;
and
the
minds
of
the
company
having
been
thus
satisfied
,
they
proceeded
to
satisfy
their
appetites
with
countenances
to
which
an
expression
of
cheerfulness
was
again
restored
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
alone
was
silent
and
reserved
.
 
<EOS>
Doubt
and
distrust
were
exhibited
in
his
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
His
confidence
in
Mr
Winkle
had
been
shaken
---
greatly
shaken
---
by
the
proceedings
of
the
morning
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
cricketer
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Wardle
of
the
marksman
.
   
<EOS>
At
any
other
time
,
Mr
Winkle
would
have
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
the
delicacy
of
his
situation
,
and
modestly
replied
,
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
once
upon
a
time
,
"
replied
the
host
;
"
but
I
have
given
it
up
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
subscribe
to
the
club
here
,
but
I
do
n't
play
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
grand
match
is
played
to
-
day
,
I
believe
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
the
host
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
would
like
to
see
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
am
delighted
to
view
any
sports
which
may
be
safely
indulged
in
,
and
in
which
the
impotent
effects
of
unskilful
people
do
not
endanger
human
life
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
paused
,
and
looked
steadily
on
Mr
Winkle
,
who
quailed
beneath
his
leader
's
searching
glance
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
man
withdrew
his
eyes
after
a
few
minutes
,
and
added
:
"
Shall
we
be
justified
in
leaving
our
wounded
friend
to
the
care
of
the
ladies
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
leave
me
in
better
hands
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
impossible
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
therefore
settled
that
Mr
Tupman
should
be
left
at
home
in
charge
of
the
females
;
and
that
the
remainder
of
the
guests
,
under
the
guidance
of
Mr
Wardle
,
should
proceed
to
the
spot
where
was
to
be
held
that
trial
of
skill
,
which
had
roused
all
Muggleton
from
its
torpor
,
and
inoculated
Dingley
Dell
with
a
fever
of
excitement
.
   
<EOS>
As
their
walk
,
which
was
not
above
two
miles
long
,
lay
through
shady
lanes
and
sequestered
footpaths
,
and
as
their
conversation
turned
upon
the
delightful
scenery
by
which
they
were
on
every
side
surrounded
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
almost
inclined
to
regret
the
expedition
they
had
used
,
when
he
found
himself
in
the
main
street
of
the
town
of
Muggleton
.
<EOS>
Everybody
whose
genius
has
a
topographical
bent
knows
perfectly
well
that
Muggleton
is
a
corporate
town
,
with
a
mayor
,
burgesses
,
and
freemen
;
and
anybody
who
has
consulted
the
addresses
of
the
mayor
to
the
freemen
,
or
the
freemen
to
the
mayor
,
or
both
to
the
corporation
,
or
all
three
to
Parliament
,
will
learn
from
thence
what
they
ought
to
have
known
before
,
that
Muggleton
is
an
ancient
and
loyal
borough
,
mingling
a
zealous
advocacy
of
Christian
principles
with
a
devoted
attachment
to
commercial
rights
;
in
demonstration
whereof
,
the
mayor
,
corporation
,
and
other
inhabitants
,
have
presented
at
divers
times
,
no
fewer
than
one
thousand
four
hundred
and
twenty
petitions
against
the
continuance
of
negro
slavery
abroad
,
and
an
equal
number
against
any
interference
with
the
factory
system
at
home
;
sixty
-
eight
in
favour
of
the
sale
of
livings
in
the
Church
,
and
eighty
-
six
for
abolishing
Sunday
trading
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
stood
in
the
principal
street
of
this
illustrious
town
,
and
gazed
with
an
air
of
curiosity
,
not
unmixed
with
interest
,
on
the
objects
around
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
open
square
for
the
market
-
place
;
and
in
the
centre
of
it
,
a
large
inn
with
a
sign
-
post
in
front
,
displaying
an
object
very
common
in
art
,
but
rarely
met
with
in
nature
---
to
wit
,
a
blue
lion
,
with
three
bow
legs
in
the
air
,
balancing
himself
on
the
extreme
point
of
the
centre
claw
of
his
fourth
foot
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
,
within
sight
,
an
auctioneer
's
and
fire
-
agency
office
,
a
corn
-
factor
's
,
a
linen
-
draper
's
,
a
saddler
's
,
a
distiller
's
,
a
grocer
's
,
and
a
shoe
-
shop
---
<EOS>
the
last
-
mentioned
warehouse
being
also
appropriated
to
the
diffusion
of
hats
,
bonnets
,
wearing
apparel
,
cotton
umbrellas
,
and
useful
knowledge
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
red
brick
house
with
a
small
paved
courtyard
in
front
,
which
anybody
might
have
known
belonged
to
the
attorney
;
and
there
was
,
moreover
,
another
red
brick
house
with
Venetian
blinds
,
and
a
large
brass
door
-
plate
with
a
very
legible
announcement
that
it
belonged
to
the
surgeon
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
boys
were
making
their
way
to
the
cricket
-
field
;
and
two
or
three
shopkeepers
who
were
standing
at
their
doors
looked
as
if
they
should
like
to
be
making
their
way
to
the
same
spot
,
as
indeed
to
all
appearance
they
might
have
done
,
without
losing
any
great
amount
of
custom
thereby
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
having
paused
to
make
these
observations
,
to
be
noted
down
at
a
more
convenient
period
,
hastened
to
rejoin
his
friends
,
who
had
turned
out
of
the
main
street
,
and
were
already
within
sight
of
the
field
of
battle
.
   
<EOS>
The
wickets
were
pitched
,
and
so
were
a
couple
of
marquees
for
the
rest
and
refreshment
of
the
contending
parties
.
 
<EOS>
The
game
had
not
yet
commenced
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
Dingley
Dellers
,
and
All
-
Muggletonians
,
were
amusing
themselves
with
a
majestic
air
by
throwing
the
ball
carelessly
from
hand
to
hand
;
and
several
other
gentlemen
dressed
like
them
,
in
straw
hats
,
flannel
jackets
,
and
white
trousers
---
a
costume
in
which
they
looked
very
much
like
amateur
stone
-
masons
---
were
sprinkled
about
the
tents
,
towards
one
of
which
Mr
Wardle
conducted
the
party
.
   
<EOS>
Several
dozen
of
"
How
-
are
-
you
's
?
"
hailed
the
old
gentleman
's
arrival
;
and
a
general
raising
of
the
straw
hats
,
and
bending
forward
of
the
flannel
jackets
,
followed
his
introduction
of
his
guests
as
gentlemen
from
London
,
who
were
extremely
anxious
to
witness
the
proceedings
of
the
day
,
with
which
,
he
had
no
doubt
,
they
would
be
greatly
delighted
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
step
into
the
marquee
,
I
think
,
Sir
,
"
said
one
very
stout
gentleman
,
whose
body
and
legs
looked
like
half
a
gigantic
roll
of
flannel
,
elevated
on
a
couple
of
inflated
pillow
-
cases
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
find
it
much
pleasanter
,
Sir
,
"
urged
another
stout
gentleman
,
who
strongly
resembled
the
other
half
of
the
roll
of
flannel
aforesaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
very
good
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
way
,
"
said
the
first
speaker
;
"
they
notch
in
here
---
it
's
the
best
place
in
the
whole
field
;
"
and
the
cricketer
,
panting
on
before
,
preceded
them
to
the
tent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
game
---
smart
sport
---
fine
exercise
---
very
,
"
were
the
words
which
fell
upon
Mr
Pickwick
's
ear
as
he
entered
the
tent
;
and
the
first
object
that
met
his
eyes
was
his
green
-
coated
friend
of
the
Rochester
coach
,
holding
forth
,
to
the
no
small
delight
and
edification
of
a
select
circle
of
the
chosen
of
All
-
Muggleton
.
 
<EOS>
His
dress
was
slightly
improved
,
and
he
wore
boots
;
but
there
was
no
mistaking
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
recognised
his
friends
immediately
;
and
,
darting
forward
and
seizing
Mr
Pickwick
by
the
hand
,
dragged
him
to
a
seat
with
his
usual
impetuosity
,
talking
all
the
while
as
if
the
whole
of
the
arrangements
were
under
his
especial
patronage
and
direction
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
way
---
this
way
---
capital
fun
---
lots
of
beer
---
hogsheads
;
rounds
of
beef
---
bullocks
;
mustard
---
cart
-
loads
;
glorious
day
---
down
with
you
---
make
yourself
at
home
---
glad
to
see
you
---
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
sat
down
as
he
was
bid
,
and
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
also
complied
with
the
directions
of
their
mysterious
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wardle
looked
on
in
silent
wonder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wardle
---
a
friend
of
mine
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Friend
of
yours
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
My
dear
sir
,
how
are
you
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Friend
of
my
friend
's
---
give
me
your
hand
,
sir
"
---
and
the
stranger
grasped
Mr
Wardle
's
hand
with
all
the
fervour
of
a
close
intimacy
of
many
years
,
and
then
stepped
back
a
pace
or
two
as
if
to
take
a
full
survey
of
his
face
and
figure
,
and
then
shook
hands
with
him
again
,
if
possible
,
more
warmly
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
;
and
how
came
you
here
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
smile
in
which
benevolence
struggled
with
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
replied
the
stranger
---
"
stopping
at
Crown
---
<EOS>
Crown
at
Muggleton
---
met
a
party
---
flannel
jackets
---
<EOS>
white
trousers
---
anchovy
sandwiches
---
devilled
kidney
---
splendid
fellows
---
glorious
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
sufficiently
versed
in
the
stranger
's
system
of
stenography
to
infer
from
this
rapid
and
disjointed
communication
that
he
had
,
somehow
or
other
,
contracted
an
acquaintance
with
the
All
-
Muggletons
,
which
he
had
converted
,
by
a
process
peculiar
to
himself
,
into
that
extent
of
good
-
fellowship
on
which
a
general
invitation
may
be
easily
founded
.
 
<EOS>
His
curiosity
was
therefore
satisfied
,
and
putting
on
his
spectacles
he
prepared
himself
to
watch
the
play
which
was
just
commencing
.
   
<EOS>
All
-
Muggleton
had
the
first
innings
;
and
the
interest
became
intense
when
Mr
Dumkins
and
Mr
Podder
,
two
of
the
most
renowned
members
of
that
most
distinguished
club
,
walked
,
bat
in
hand
,
to
their
respective
wickets
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Luffey
,
the
highest
ornament
of
Dingley
Dell
,
was
pitched
to
bowl
against
the
redoubtable
Dumkins
,
and
Mr
Struggles
was
selected
to
do
the
same
kind
office
for
the
hitherto
unconquered
Podder
.
 
<EOS>
Several
players
were
stationed
,
to
"
look
out
,
"
in
different
parts
of
the
field
,
and
each
fixed
himself
into
the
proper
attitude
by
placing
one
hand
on
each
knee
,
and
stooping
very
much
as
if
he
were
"
making
a
back
"
for
some
beginner
at
leap
-
frog
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
regular
players
do
this
sort
of
thing
;
---
indeed
it
is
generally
supposed
that
it
is
quite
impossible
to
look
out
properly
in
any
other
position
.
   
<EOS>
The
umpires
were
stationed
behind
the
wickets
;
the
scorers
were
prepared
to
notch
the
runs
;
a
breathless
silence
ensued
.
<EOS>
Mr
Luffey
retired
a
few
paces
behind
the
wicket
of
the
passive
Podder
,
and
applied
the
ball
to
his
right
eye
for
several
seconds
.
<EOS>
Dumkins
confidently
awaited
its
coming
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
motions
of
Luffey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Play
!
"
<EOS>
suddenly
cried
the
bowler
.
 
<EOS>
The
ball
flew
from
his
hand
straight
and
swift
towards
the
centre
stump
of
the
wicket
.
 
<EOS>
The
wary
Dumkins
was
on
the
alert
:
it
fell
upon
the
tip
of
the
bat
,
and
bounded
far
away
over
the
heads
of
the
scouts
,
who
had
just
stooped
low
enough
to
let
it
fly
over
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Run
---
run
---
another
.
---
<EOS>
Now
,
then
throw
her
up
---
up
with
her
---
stop
there
---
another
---
<EOS>
no
---
yes
---
no
---
throw
her
up
,
throw
her
up
!
"
<EOS>
---
Such
were
the
shouts
which
followed
the
stroke
;
and
at
the
conclusion
of
which
All
-
Muggleton
had
scored
two
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
Podder
behindhand
<EOS>
in
earning
laurels
wherewith
to
garnish
himself
and
Muggleton
.
 
<EOS>
He
blocked
the
doubtful
balls
,
missed
the
bad
ones
,
took
the
good
ones
,
and
sent
them
flying
to
all
parts
of
the
field
.
 
<EOS>
The
scouts
were
hot
and
tired
;
the
bowlers
were
changed
and
bowled
till
their
arms
ached
;
but
Dumkins
and
Podder
remained
unconquered
.
 
<EOS>
Did
an
elderly
gentleman
essay
to
stop
the
progress
of
the
ball
<EOS>
,
it
rolled
between
his
legs
or
slipped
between
his
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
Did
a
slim
gentleman
try
to
catch
it
,
it
struck
him
on
the
nose
,
and
bounded
pleasantly
off
with
redoubled
violence
,
while
the
slim
gentleman
's
eyes
filled
with
water
,
and
his
form
writhed
with
anguish
.
 
<EOS>
Was
it
thrown
straight
up
to
the
wicket
,
Dumkins
had
reached
it
before
the
ball
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
when
Dumkins
was
caught
out
,
and
Podder
stumped
out
,
All
-
Muggleton
had
notched
some
fifty
-
four
,
while
the
score
of
the
Dingley
Dellers
was
as
blank
as
their
faces
.
 
<EOS>
The
advantage
was
too
great
to
be
recovered
.
 
<EOS>
In
vain
did
the
eager
Luffey
,
and
the
enthusiastic
Struggles
,
do
all
that
skill
and
experience
could
suggest
,
to
regain
the
ground
Dingley
Dell
had
lost
in
the
contest
 
<EOS>
---
it
was
of
no
avail
;
and
in
an
early
period
of
the
winning
game
Dingley
Dell
gave
in
,
and
allowed
the
superior
prowess
of
All
-
Muggleton
.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
,
meanwhile
,
had
been
eating
,
drinking
,
and
talking
,
without
cessation
.
 
<EOS>
At
every
good
stroke
he
expressed
his
satisfaction
and
approval
of
the
player
in
a
most
condescending
and
patronising
manner
,
which
could
not
fail
to
have
been
highly
gratifying
to
the
party
concerned
;
while
at
every
bad
attempt
at
a
catch
,
and
every
failure
to
stop
the
ball
,
he
launched
his
personal
displeasure
at
the
head
of
the
devoted
individual
in
such
denunciations
as
---
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
ah
!
---
stupid
"
---
"
Now
,
butter
-
fingers
"
 
---
"
Muff
"
---
"
Humbug
"
---
and
so
forth
---
ejaculations
which
seemed
to
establish
him
in
the
opinion
of
all
around
,
as
a
most
excellent
and
undeniable
judge
of
the
whole
art
and
mystery
of
the
noble
game
of
cricket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
game
---
<EOS>
well
played
---
some
strokes
admirable
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
as
both
sides
crowded
into
the
tent
,
at
the
conclusion
of
the
game
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
played
it
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Wardle
,
who
had
been
much
amused
by
his
loquacity
.
<EOS>
"
Played
it
!
 
<EOS>
Think
I
have
---
thousands
of
times
---
not
here
---
West
Indies
---
exciting
thing
---
hot
work
---
very
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
rather
a
warm
pursuit
in
such
a
climate
,
"
observed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Warm
!
---
<EOS>
red
hot
---
scorching
---
glowing
.
 
<EOS>
Played
a
match
once
---
<EOS>
single
wicket
---
friend
the
colonel
---
<EOS>
Sir
Thomas
Blazo
---
who
should
get
the
greatest
number
of
runs
.
<EOS>
---
Won
the
toss
---
first
innings
---
seven
o'clock
A*M
---
six
natives
to
look
out
---
went
in
;
kept
in
---
heat
intense
---
<EOS>
natives
all
fainted
---
taken
away
---
fresh
half
-
dozen
ordered
---
<EOS>
fainted
also
---
Blazo
bowling
---
supported
by
two
natives
---
could
n't
bowl
me
out
---
<EOS>
fainted
too
---
cleared
away
the
colonel
---
would
n't
give
in
---
faithful
attendant
---
<EOS>
Quanko
Samba
---
last
man
left
---
sun
so
hot
,
bat
in
blisters
,
ball
scorched
brown
---
<EOS>
five
hundred
and
seventy
runs
---
rather
exhausted
---
<EOS>
Quanko
mustered
up
last
remaining
strength
---
bowled
me
out
---
had
a
bath
,
and
went
out
to
dinner
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
became
of
what's
-
his
-
name
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
an
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Blazo
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
---
the
other
gentleman
.
"
<EOS>
"
Quanko
Samba
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
Quanko
---
never
recovered
it
---
<EOS>
bowled
on
,
on
my
account
 
---
bowled
off
,
on
his
own
---
died
,
sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here

stranger
buried
his

in

brown

,
but
whether

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
only

that

,

,

on
,
as
two

,

---
   
<EOS>
"

,

;

<EOS>
"
Of

"

"

Mr
---
;
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Jingle
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Jingle
---
Alfred
Jingle
,
Esq
.
,
of
No

,
Nowhere
.
"
   
"
I

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

,
"

Mr
Alfred
Jingle
,

,

---
   
<EOS>
"
Devilish
good

---
cold
,

---

---
fowls

,

all

---
pleasant

these
---
well

,

---
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
being
no
further

to

,

in

;
and

Blue
Lion
Inn
,
Muggleton
---
<EOS>
Mr
Dumkins
acting
as

,
and
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
There

a
vast

and

of

and

,
and
plates
;
a
great

of
three

-

,
and
a
rapid
disappearance
of
the
substantial
viands
on
the
table
;
to
each
and
every
of
which
item
of
confusion
,
the
facetious
Mr
Jingle
lent
the
aid
of
half
-
a
-
dozen
ordinary
men
at
least
.
 
<EOS>
When
everybody
had

as
much
as

,
the
cloth
was

,

,

,

;
and
the

withdrew
to
"
clear

,
"
or

other

,
to
appropriate

and

whatever

of

.
   
<EOS>
Amidst

,

man

Say
-
nothing
-
to
-
me*-or
-
I'll
-

-
<EOS>
you
sort

,
who

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

---
   
"
Mr

!
"
   
<EOS>
Everybody

,

---
   
"
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
Sir
,

<EOS>
Mr

"

;

;

"
Mr

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

(
four

)
,

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
,

---

(

)
.
 
<EOS>
I

;

,

,

:
<EOS>
and

,
Sir
(

)
;
to
Muggleton
I

all
these
honours

to

fairly
lay
claim
<EOS>
---
they

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
(

.
)
<EOS>
Let

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
,

.
 
<EOS>
(
Cheers
.
)
<EOS>
Every

,

,

---

---
"

"

---
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

"

I

;

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Enthusiasm
.
)
<EOS>
But
,

,

pre
-

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
(

.
)
<EOS>
Have

,

,

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
And

the

;

<EOS>

.
)
<EOS>

"
Dumkins

"
<EOS>
"
   
Here

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Other

were
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Luffey
and
Mr
Struggles
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Jingle
,
were
,
each
in
his

,
the
subject
of
unqualified

;
and

thanks
for

.
   
<EOS>
Enthusiastic
as
we
are
in
the
noble
cause
to
which
we
have
devoted
ourselves
<EOS>
,
we
should
have
felt
a
sensation
of
pride
which
we
can
not
express
,
and
a
consciousness
of
having
done
something
to
merit

of

are
now

,
could

have
laid
the
faintest

on
these

before

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
,
as
usual
,
took
a
great
mass
of
notes
,
which
would
no
doubt
have
afforded
most
useful
and
valuable

,
had
not
the
burning

of

words
or
the

of
the
wine
made
that
gentleman
's
hand
so

unsteady
,
as
to
render

writing
nearly
unintelligible
,
and
<EOS>
his
style
wholly
so
.
 
<EOS>
By
dint
of
patient
investigation
,
we
have
been
enabled
to
trace
some
characters
bearing
a
faint

to
the
names
of
the

;
and
we
can
only

an
entry
of
a

(
supposed

)
,

"
bowl
"
"

"
"
ruby
"
"
bright
"

"
wine
"
are

.
 
<EOS>
We
fancy
,

,

we

discern

the

,

to
"
broiled

"
;
and

the

"
cold
"
"

"
occur
:
but
<EOS>
as

we

found
upon

must
necessarily
rest

,
we
are
not

to

any

to

may

.
   
<EOS>
We
will
therefore
return
to
Mr
Tupman
;
merely

that
within
some

minutes
before
twelve
o'clock
that
night
,
the

of
worthies
of
Dingley
Dell
and
Muggleton
were
heard
to
sing
,
with
great

and

,
the
beautiful
and
pathetic
national
air
of
     
<EOS>
"
We
wo
n't
go
home
till
morning
,
     
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
go
home
till
morning
,
     
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
go
home
till
morning
,
     
<EOS>
Till
daylight
doth
appear
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
8
.
<EOS>
Strongly
illustrative
of
the
position
,
that
the
course
of
true
love
is
not
a
railway
 
<EOS>
The
quiet
seclusion
of
Dingley
Dell
,
the
presence
of
so
many
of
the
gentler
sex
,
and
the
solicitude
and
anxiety
they
evinced
in
his
behalf
,
were
all
favourable
to
the
growth
and
development
of
those
softer
feelings
which
nature
had
implanted
deep
in
the
bosom
of
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
,
and
which
now
appeared
destined
to
centre
in
one
lovely
object
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
were
pretty
,
their
manners
winning
,
their
dispositions
unexceptionable
;
but
there
was
a
dignity
in
the
air
,
a
touch
-
me
-
not
-
ishness
in
the
walk
,
a
majesty
in
the
eye
,
of
the
spinster
aunt
,
to
which
,
at
their
time
of
life
,
they
could
lay
no
claim
,
which
distinguished
her
from
any
female
on
whom
Mr
Tupman
had
ever
gazed
.
 
<EOS>
That
there
was
something
kindred
in
their
nature
,
something
congenial
in
their
souls
,
something
mysteriously
sympathetic
in
their
bosoms
,
was
evident
.
 
<EOS>
Her
name
was
the
first
that
rose
to
Mr
Tupman
's
lips
as
he
lay
wounded
on
the
grass
;
and
her
hysteric
laughter
was
the
first
sound
that
fell
upon
his
ear
when
he
was
supported
to
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
had
her
agitation
arisen
from
an
amiable
and
feminine
sensibility
which
would
have
been
equally
irrepressible
in
any
case
;
or
had
it
been
called
forth
by
a
more
ardent
and
passionate
feeling
,
which
he
,
of
all
men
living
,
could
alone
awaken
?
 
<EOS>
These
were
the
doubts
which
racked
his
brain
as
he
lay
extended
on
the
sofa
;
these
were
the
doubts
which
he
determined
should
be
at
once
and
for
ever
resolved
.
   
<EOS>
it
was
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Isabella
and
Emily
had
strolled
out
with
Mr
Trundle
;
the
deaf
old
lady
had
fallen
asleep
in
her
chair
;
the
snoring
of
the
fat
boy
,
penetrated
in
a
low
and
monotonous
sound
from
the
distant
kitchen
;
the
buxom
servants
were
lounging
at
the
side
door
,
enjoying
the
pleasantness
of
the
hour
,
and
the
delights
of
a
flirtation
,
on
first
principles
,
with
certain
unwieldy
animals
attached
to
the
farm
;
and
there
sat
the
interesting
pair
,
uncared
for
by
all
,
caring
for
none
,
and
dreaming
only
of
themselves
;
there
they
sat
,
in
short
,
like
a
pair
of
carefully
-
folded
kid
gloves
---
bound
up
in
each
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
forgotten
my
flowers
,
"
said
the
spinster
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Water
them
now
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
in
accents
of
persuasion
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
take
cold
in
the
evening
air
,
"
urged
the
spinster
aunt
affectionately
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
rising
;
"
it
will
do
me
good
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
accompany
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
paused
to
adjust
the
sling
in
which
the
left
arm
of
the
youth
was
placed
,
and
taking
his
right
arm
led
him
to
the
garden
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
bower
at
the
farther
end
,
with
honeysuckle
,
jessamine
,
and
creeping
plants
---
one
of
those
sweet
retreats
which
humane
men
erect
for
the
accommodation
of
spiders
.
   
<EOS>
The
spinster
aunt
took
up
a
large
watering
-
pot
which
lay
in
one
corner
,
and
was
about
to
leave
the
arbour
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
detained
her
,
and
drew
her
to
a
seat
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Wardle
!
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
The
spinster
aunt
trembled
,
till
some
pebbles
which
had
accidentally
found
their
way
into
the
large
watering
-
pot
shook
like
an
infant
's
rattle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Wardle
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
"
you
are
an
angel
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tupman
!
"
exclaimed
Rachael
,
blushing
as
red
as
the
watering
-
pot
itself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
"
said
the
eloquent
Pickwickian
---
"
I
know
it
but
too
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
women
are
angels
,
they
say
,
"
murmured
the
lady
playfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
what
can
you
be
;
or
to
what
,
without
presumption
,
can
I
compare
you
?
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
was
the
woman
ever
seen
who
resembled
you
?
 
<EOS>
Where
else
could
I
hope
to
find
so
rare
a
combination
of
excellence
and
beauty
?
 
<EOS>
Where
else
could
I
seek
to
---
 
Oh
!
"
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Tupman
paused
,
and
pressed
the
hand
which
clasped
the
handle
of
the
happy
watering
-
pot
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
turned
aside
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Men
are
such
deceivers
,
"
she
softly
whispered
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
,
they
are
,
"
ejaculated
Mr
Tupman
;
"
but
not
all
men
.
<EOS>
There
lives
at
least
one
being
who
can
never
change
---
one
being
who
would
be
content
to
devote
his
whole
existence
to
your
happiness
---
who
lives
but
in
your
eyes
---
who
breathes
but
in
your
smiles
---
who
bears
the
heavy
burden
of
life
itself
only
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Could
such
an
individual
be
found
---
"
said
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
CAN
be
found
,
"
said
the
ardent
Mr
Tupman
,
interposing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
IS
found
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
here
,
Miss
Wardle
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
ere
<EOS>
the
lady
was
aware
of
his
intention
,
Mr
Tupman
had
sunk
upon
his
knees
at
her
feet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tupman
,
rise
,
"
said
Rachael
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
was
the
valorous
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Rachael
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
seized
her
passive
hand
,
and
the
watering
-
pot
fell
to
the
ground
as
he
pressed
it
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Rachael
!
<EOS>
say
you
love
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tupman
,
"
said
the
spinster
aunt
,
with
averted
head
,
"
I
can
hardly
speak
the
words
;
but
<EOS>
---
but
---
you
are
not
wholly
indifferent
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
no
sooner
heard
this
avowal
,
than
he
proceeded
to
do
what
his
enthusiastic
emotions
prompted
,
and
what
,
for
aught
we
know
(
for
we
are
but
little
acquainted
with
such
matters
)
,
people
so
circumstanced
always
do
.
 
<EOS>
He
jumped
up
,
and
,
throwing
his
arm
round
the
neck
of
the
spinster
aunt
,
imprinted
upon
her
lips
numerous
kisses
,
which
after
a
due
show
of
struggling
and
resistance
,
she
received
so
passively
,
that
there
is
no
telling
how
many
more
Mr
Tupman
might
have
bestowed
,
if
the
lady
had
not
given
a
very
unaffected
start
,
and
exclaimed
in
an
affrighted
tone
---
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
we
are
observed
!
<EOS>
---
we
are
discovered
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
looked
round
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
fat
boy
,
perfectly
motionless
,
with
his
large
circular
eyes
staring
into
the
arbour
,
but
without
the
slightest
expression
on
his
face
that
the
most
expert
physiognomist
could
have
referred
to
astonishment
,
curiosity
,
or
any
other
known
passion
that
agitates
the
human
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
gazed
on
the
fat
boy
,
and
the
fat
boy
stared
at
him
;
and
the
longer
Mr
Tupman
observed
the
utter
vacancy
of
the
fat
boy
's
countenance
,
the
more
convinced
he
became
that
he
either
did
not
know
,
or
did
not
understand
,
anything
that
had
been
going
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Under
this
impression
,
he
said
with
great
firmness
---
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
here
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Supper
's
ready
,
sir
,
"
was
the
prompt
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
just
come
here
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tupman
,
with
a
piercing
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
,
"
replied
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
looked
at
him
very
hard
again
;
but
there
was
not
a
wink
in
his
eye
,
or
a
curve
in
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
took
the
arm
of
the
spinster
aunt
,
and
walked
towards
the
house
;
the
fat
boy
followed
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
knows
nothing
of
what
has
happened
,
"
he
whispered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
said
the
spinster
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
sound
behind
them
,
as
of
an
imperfectly
suppressed
chuckle
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
turned
sharply
round
.
 
<EOS>
No
;
it
could
not
have
been
the
fat
boy
;
there
was
not
a
gleam
of
mirth
,
or
anything
but
feeding
in
his
whole
visage
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
must
have
been
fast
asleep
,
"
whispered
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
the
least
doubt
of
it
,
"
replied
the
spinster
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
They
both
laughed
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
,
Tupman
was
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
,
for
once
,
had
not
been
fast
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
awake
---
wide
awake
---
to
what
had
been
going
forward
.
   
<EOS>
The
supper
passed
off
without
any
attempt
at
a
general
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
had
gone
to
bed
;
Isabella
Wardle
devoted
herself
exclusively
to
Mr
Trundle
;
the
spinster
's
attentions
were
reserved
for
Mr
Tupman
;
and
Emily
's
thoughts
appeared
to
be
engrossed
by
some
distant
object
---
<EOS>
possibly
they
were
with
the
absent
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
Eleven
---
twelve
---
one
o'clock
had
struck
,
and
the
gentlemen
had
not
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
Consternation
sat
on
every
face
.
 
<EOS>
Could
they
have
been
waylaid
and
robbed
?
 
<EOS>
Should
they
send
men
and
lanterns
in
every
direction
by
which
they
could
be
supposed
likely
to
have
travelled
home
?
<EOS>
or
should
they
---
 
Hark
!
<EOS>
there
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
What
could
have
made
them
so
late
?
 
<EOS>
A
strange
voice
,
too
!
 
<EOS>
To
whom
could
it
belong
?
 
<EOS>
They
rushed
into
the
kitchen
,
whither
the
truants
had
repaired
,
and
at
once
obtained
rather
more
than
a
glimmering
of
the
real
state
of
the
case
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
and
his
hat
cocked
completely
over
his
left
eye
,
was
leaning
against
the
dresser
,
shaking
his
head
from
side
to
side
,
and
producing
a
constant
succession
of
the
blandest
and
most
benevolent
smiles
without
being
moved
thereunto
by
any
discernible
cause
or
pretence
whatsoever
;
<EOS>
old
Mr
Wardle
,
with
a
highly
-
inflamed
countenance
,
was
grasping
the
hand
of
a
strange
gentleman
muttering
protestations
of
eternal
friendship
;
Mr
Winkle
,
supporting
himself
by
the
eight
-
day
clock
,
was
feebly
invoking
destruction
upon
the
head
of
any
member
of
the
family
who
should
suggest
the
propriety
of
his
retiring
for
the
night
;
and
Mr
Snodgrass
had
sunk
into
a
chair
,
with
an
expression
of
the
most
abject
and
hopeless
misery
that
the
human
mind
can
imagine
,
portrayed
in
every
lineament
of
his
expressive
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
is
anything
the
matter
?
"
inquired
the
three
ladies
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
the
matter
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
---
we
're
---
all
right
.
<EOS>
---
I
say
,
Wardle
,
we
're
all
right
,
ai
n't
we
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
so
,
"
replied
the
jolly
host
.
<EOS>
---
"
My
dears
,
here
's
my
friend
Mr
Jingle
---
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
friend
,
Mr
Jingle
,
come
"
pon
 
---
<EOS>
little
visit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
anything
the
matter
with
Mr
Snodgrass
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Emily
,
with
great
anxiety
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
the
matter
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cricket
dinner
---
glorious
party
---
capital
songs
---
old
port
---
claret
---
good
 
---
<EOS>
very
good
---
wine
,
ma'am
---
wine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
n't
the
wine
,
"
murmured
Mr
Snodgrass
,
in
a
broken

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
the
salmon
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
Somehow
or
other
,
it
never
is
the
wine
,
in
these
cases
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Had
n't
they
better
go
to
bed
,
ma'am
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
of
the
boys
will
carry
the
gentlemen
upstairs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
go
to
bed
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
firmly
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
living
boy
shall
carry
me
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
stoutly
;
and
he
went
on
smiling
as
before
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
"
<EOS>
gasped
Mr
Winkle
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Mr
Pickwick
,
taking
off
his
hat
and
dashing
it
on
the
floor
,
and
insanely
casting
his
spectacles
into
the
middle
of
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
humorous
feat
he
laughed
outright
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
's
---
have
---
"
nother
---
bottle
,
"
cried
Mr
Winkle
,
commencing
in
a
very
loud
key
,
and
ending
in
a
very
faint
one
.
 
<EOS>
His
head
dropped
upon
his
breast
;
and
,
muttering
his
invincible
determination
not
to
go
to
his
bed
,
and
a
sanguinary
regret
that
he
had
not
"
done
for
old
Tupman
"
in
the
morning
,
he
fell
fast
asleep
;
in
which
condition
he
was
borne
to
his
apartment
by
two
young
giants
under
the
personal
superintendence
of
the
fat
boy
,
to
whose
protecting
care
Mr
Snodgrass
shortly
afterwards
confided
his
own
person
,
Mr
Pickwick
accepted
the
proffered
arm
of
Mr
Tupman
and
quietly
disappeared
,
smiling
more
than
ever
;
and
Mr
Wardle
,
after
taking
as
affectionate
a
leave
of
the
whole
family
as
if
he
were
ordered
for
immediate
execution
,
consigned
to
Mr
Trundle
the
honour
of
conveying
him
upstairs
,
and
retired
,
with
a
very
futile
attempt
to
look
impressively
solemn
and
dignified
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
shocking
scene
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
spinster
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dis
-
gusting
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
both
the
young
ladies
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dreadful
---
dreadful
!
<EOS>
"
said
Jingle
,
looking
very
grave
:
he
was
about
a
bottle
and
a
half
ahead
of
any
of
his
companions
.
"
<EOS>
Horrid
spectacle
---
very
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
nice
man
!
<EOS>
"
whispered
the
spinster
aunt
to
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
looking
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Emily
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
decidedly
,
"
observed
the
spinster
aunt
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
thought
of
the
widow
at
Rochester
,
and
his
mind
was
troubled
.
 
<EOS>
The
succeeding
half
-
hour
's
conversation
was
not
of
a
nature
to
calm
his
perturbed
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
visitor
was
very
talkative
,
and
the
number
of
his
anecdotes
was
only
to
be
exceeded
by
the
extent
of
his
politeness
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
felt
that
as
Jingle
's
popularity
increased
,
he
(
Tupman
)
retired
further
into
the
shade
.
 
<EOS>
His
laughter
was
forced
---
his
merriment
feigned
;
and
when
at
last
he
laid
his
aching
temples
between
the
sheets
,
he
thought
,
with
horrid
delight
,
on
the
satisfaction
it
would
afford
him
to
have
Jingle
's
head
at
that
moment
between
the
feather
bed
and
the
mattress
.
   
<EOS>
The
indefatigable
stranger
rose
betimes
next
morning
,
and
,
although
his
companions
remained
in
bed
overpowered
with
the
dissipation
of
the
previous
night
,
exerted
himself
most
successfully
to
promote
the
hilarity
of
the
breakfast
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
So
successful
were
his
efforts
,
that
even
the
deaf
old
lady
insisted
on
having
one
or
two
of
his
best
jokes
retailed
through
the
trumpet
;
and
even
she
condescended
to
observe
to
the
spinster
aunt
,
that
"
He
"
(
meaning
Jingle
)
"
was
an
impudent
young
fellow
:
"
a
sentiment
in
which
all
her
relations
then
and
there
present
thoroughly
coincided
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
old
lady
's
habit
on
the
fine
summer
mornings
to
repair
to
the
arbour
in
which
Mr
Tupman
had
already
signalised
himself
,
in
form
and
manner
following
:
<EOS>
first
,
the
fat
boy
fetched
from
a
peg
behind
the
old
lady
's
bedroom
door
,
a
close
black
satin
bonnet
,
a
warm
cotton
shawl
,
and
a
thick
stick
with
a
capacious
handle
;
and
the
old
lady
,
having
put
on
the
bonnet
and
shawl
at
her
leisure
,
would
lean
one
hand
on
the
stick
and
the
other
on
the
fat
boy
's
shoulder
,
and
walk
leisurely
to
the
arbour
,
where
the
fat
boy
would
leave
her
to
enjoy
the
fresh
air
for
the
space
of
half
an
hour
;
at
the
expiration
of
which
time
he
would
return
and
reconduct
her
to
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
was
very
precise
and
very
particular
;
and
as
this
ceremony
had
been
observed
for
three
successive
summers
without
the
slightest
deviation
from
the
accustomed
form
,
she
was
not
a
little
surprised
on
this
particular
morning
to
see
the
fat
boy
,
instead
of
leaving
the
arbour
,
walk
a
few
paces
out
of
it
,
look
carefully
round
him
in
every
direction
,
and
return
towards
her
with
great
stealth
and
an
air
of
the
most
profound
mystery
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
was
timorous
---
most
old
ladies
are
---
and
her
first
impression
was
that
the
bloated
lad
was
about
to
do
her
some
grievous
bodily
harm
with
the
view
of
possessing
himself
of
her
loose
coin
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
have
cried
for
assistance
,
but
age
and
infirmity
had
long
ago
deprived
her
of
the
power
of
screaming
;
she
,
therefore
,
watched
his
motions
with
feelings
of
intense
horror
which
were
in
no
degree
diminished
by
his
coming
close
up
to
her
,
and
shouting
in
her
ear
in
an
agitated
,
and
as
it
seemed
to
her
,
a

---
   
"
Missus
!
"
   
<EOS>
Now
it
so
happened
that
Mr
Jingle
was
walking
in
the
garden
close
to
the
arbour
at
that

.
 
<EOS>
He
too
heard
the
shouts
of
"
Missus
,
"
and
stopped
to
hear

.
 
<EOS>
There
were
three

his
doing

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
he
was
idle

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
So

,
and
there

.
   
<EOS>
"
Missus
!
"
shouted
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Joe
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm

been

to

,
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
invariably

treated
very

.
 
<EOS>
You

never

much
to
do
;
and
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

was

to
the
fat
boy
's
most

.
<EOS>
He

,
as

---
<EOS>
"
I
knows
I
has
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

do
now
?
"
said
the

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wants
to
make
your
flesh
creep
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
This
sounded
like

very

mode
of
showing
one
's

;
and
as

old

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do

think
I
see
in
this
very
arbour
last

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless

!
 
<EOS>
What
?
<EOS>
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

---
him
as

---
a
-

'

'
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Who
,

?
 
<EOS>
None

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Who

,

<EOS>
I

.

<EOS>

Miss

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"

<EOS>
"
Speak

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

suffered

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
A

<EOS>
"
I
see
her
a
-

'
of
him
agin
.
"
   
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

"

.
   
<EOS>
It

,

,

Mr
Jingle
within

Manor

on

,

inwardly

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

,
that

off
-

was
by

the
fair

;
and

more

that
she
possessed

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

ousting

rival
by

other
,
flashed

upon
him
,
and
he
immediately

to

certain

tending
to

,
without

's

.
<EOS>
Fielding
tells
us
that
man
is
fire
,
and
woman
tow
,
and
the
Prince
of
Darkness
sets
a

to
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jingle
knew
that
young
men
,
to
spinster
aunts
,
are
as
lighted
gas
to
gunpowder
,
and
he
determined
to
essay

effect
of

without

.
   
<EOS>
Full

upon

,

,
and
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fortune
seemed

to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
and

just

;
and

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

was

.
   
<EOS>
The

-

door
was

.
 
<EOS>
He
peeped
in
.
<EOS>
The

aunt
was

.
 
<EOS>
He
coughed
;
she

.
 
<EOS>
Hesitation
formed
no

Mr
Alfred
Jingle
's

.
 
<EOS>
He
laid
his
finger
on
his
lips

,
walked
in
,
and
closed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Wardle
,
"
said

,

,
"
forgive

---
short

---
<EOS>
no

for

---
all

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

!
"

,

"
Large

---
dumpling

---

---
rascal
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

Joseph
,

?
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
treacherous

,
Joe
---

old

<EOS>
overheard

"

Say

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
Never
!
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
(

.
 
<EOS>
She
HAD
money
.
)

"
More

,

.

<EOS>

Another
!
"

<EOS>

?
"
<EOS>
"
Short

---

---
niece
Emily
.

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Now
,

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
