<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
somebody
else
?
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jingle
fell
on
his
knees
,
remained
thereupon
for
five
minutes
thereafter
;
and
rose
the
accepted
lover
of
the
spinster
aunt
---
conditionally
upon
Mr
Tupman
's
perjury
being
made
clear
and
manifest
.
   
<EOS>
The
burden
of
proof
lay
with
Mr
Alfred
Jingle
;
and
he
produced
his
evidence
that
very
day
at
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
The
spinster
aunt
could
hardly
believe
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
was
established
at
Emily
's
side
,
ogling
,
whispering
,
and
smiling
,
in
opposition
to
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
word
,
not
a
look
,
not
a
glance
,
did
he
bestow
upon
his
heart
's
pride
of
the
evening
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Damn
that
boy
!
"
<EOS>
thought
old
Mr
Wardle
to
himself
.
<EOS>
---
He
had
heard
the
story
from
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Damn
that
boy
!
 
<EOS>
He
must
have
been
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
imagination
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Traitor
!
<EOS>
"
thought
the
spinster
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mr
Jingle
was
not
deceiving
me
.
 
<EOS>
Ugh
!
<EOS>
how
I
hate
the
wretch
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
following
conversation
may
serve
to
explain
to
our
readers
this
apparently
unaccountable
alteration
of
deportment
on
the
part
of
Mr
Tracy
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
was
evening
;
the
scene
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
figures
walking
in
a
side
path
;
one
was
rather
short
and
stout
;
the
other
tall
and
slim
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Jingle
.
<EOS>
The
stout
figure
commenced
the
dialogue
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
did
I
do
it
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
Splendid
---
capital
---
could
n't
act
better
myself
---
you
must
repeat
the
part
to
-
morrow
---
every
evening
till
further
notice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
Rachael
still
wish
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
---
she
do
n't
like
it
---
but
must
be
done
---
avert
suspicion
---
afraid
of
her
brother
---
says
there
's
no
help
for
it
---
only
a
few
days
more
---
when
old
folks
blinded
---
crown
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Any
message
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Love
---
best
love
---
kindest
regards
---
unalterable
affection
.
<EOS>
Can
I
say
anything
for
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
,
"
replied
the
unsuspicious
Mr
Tupman
,
fervently
grasping
his
"
friend
's
"
hand
---
"
carry
my
best
love
---
say
how
hard
I
find
it
to
dissemble
<EOS>
---
say
anything
that
's
kind
:
but
add
how
sensible
I
am
of
the
necessity
of
the
suggestion
she
made
to
me
,
through
you
,
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Say
I
applaud
her
wisdom
and
admire
her
discretion
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
more
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
only
add
how
ardently
I
long
for
the
time
when
I
may
call
her
mine
,
and
all
dissimulation
may
be
unnecessary
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
certainly
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
more
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
friend
!
"
said
poor
Mr
Tupman
,
again
grasping
the
hand
of
his
companion
,
"
receive
my
warmest
thanks
for
your
disinterested
kindness
;
and
forgive
me
if
I
have
ever
,
even
in
thought
,
done
you
the
injustice
of
supposing
that
you
could
stand
in
my
way
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
,
can
I
ever
repay
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
talk
of
it
,
"
replied
Mr
Jingle
.
 
<EOS>
He
stopped
short
,
as
if
suddenly
recollecting
something
,
and
said
---
"
By
the
bye
---
ca
n't
spare
ten
pounds
,
can
you
?
---
<EOS>
very
particular
purpose
---
pay
you
in
three
days
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
I
can
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
,
in
the
fulness
of
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
"
Three
days
,
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
three
days
---
all
over
then
---
no
more
difficulties
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
counted
the
money
into
his
companion
's
hand
,
and
he
dropped
it
piece
by
piece
into
his
pocket
,
as
they
walked
towards
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
careful
,
"
said
Mr
Jingle
---
"
not
a
look
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
wink
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
syllable
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
whisper
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
your
attentions
to
the
niece
---
rather
rude
,
than
otherwise
,
to
the
aunt
---
only
way
of
deceiving
the
old
ones
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
aloud
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I'LL
take
care
,
"
said
Mr
Jingle
internally
;
and
they
entered
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
The
scene
of
that
afternoon
was
repeated
that
evening
,
and
on
the
three
afternoons
and
evenings
next
ensuing
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
fourth
,
the
host
was
in
high
spirits
,
for
he
had
satisfied
himself
that
there
was
no
ground
for
the
charge
against
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
So
was
Mr
Tupman
,
for
Mr
Jingle
had
told
him
that
his
affair
would
soon
be
brought
to
a
crisis
.
 
<EOS>
So
was
Mr
Pickwick
,
for
he
was
seldom
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
So
was
not
Mr
Snodgrass
<EOS>
,
for
he
had
grown
jealous
of
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
So
was
the
old
lady
,
for
she
had
been
winning
at
whist
.
 
<EOS>
So
were
Mr
Jingle
and
Miss
Wardle
,
for
reasons
of
sufficient
importance
in
this
eventful
history
to
be
narrated
in
another
chapter
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
9
.
<EOS>
A
discovery
and
a
chase
 
<EOS>
The
supper
was
ready
laid
,
the
chairs
were
drawn
round
the
table
,
bottles
,
jugs
,
and
glasses
were
arranged
upon
the
sideboard
,
and
everything
betokened
the
approach
of
the
most
convivial
period
in
the
whole
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Rachael
?
"
said
Mr
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
and
Jingle
?
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
the
host
,
"
I
wonder
I
have
n't
missed
him
before
.
<EOS>
Why
,
I
do
n't
think
I
've
heard
his
voice
for
two
hours
at
least
.
<EOS>
Emily
,
my
dear
,
ring
the
bell
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
bell
was
rung
,
and
the
fat
boy
appeared
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
Miss
Rachael
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
say
.
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Mr
Jingle
,
then
?
"
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
know
.
<EOS>
Everybody
looked
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
late
---
past
eleven
o'clock
.
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
laughed
in
his
sleeve
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
loitering
somewhere
,
talking
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
capital
notion
that
---
funny
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
said
Wardle
,
after
a
short
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
'll
turn
up
presently
,
I
dare
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
wait
supper
for
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excellent
rule
,
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
---
"
admirable
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
sit
down
,
"
said
the
host
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
down
they
sat
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
gigantic
round
of
cold
beef
on
the
table
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
was
supplied
with
a
plentiful
portion
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
raised
his
fork
to
his
lips
,
and
was
on
the
very
point
of
opening
his
mouth
for
the
reception
of
a
piece
of
beef
,
when
the
hum
of
many
voices
suddenly
arose
in
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
,
and
laid
down
his
fork
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wardle
paused
too
,
and
insensibly
released
his
hold
of
the
carving
-
knife
,
which
remained
inserted
in
the
beef
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
looked
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
Heavy
footsteps
were
heard
in
the
passage
;
the
parlour
door
was
suddenly
burst
open
;
and
the
man
who
had
cleaned
Mr
Pickwick
's
boots
on
his
first
arrival
,
rushed
into
the
room
,
followed
by
the
fat
boy
and
all
the
domestics
.
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
's
the
meaning
of
this
?
"
exclaimed
the
host
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
kitchen
chimney
ai
n't
a
-
fire
,
is
it
,
Emma
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
old
lady
.
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
grandma
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
"
screamed
both
the
young
ladies
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
roared
the
master
of
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
gasped
for
breath
,
and
faintly
ejaculated
---
   
<EOS>
"
They
ha
'
gone
,
mas'r
!
<EOS>
---
gone
right
clean
off
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
(
At
this
juncture
Mr
Tupman
was
observed
to
lay
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
and
to
turn
very
pale
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
gone
?
"
said
Mr
Wardle
fiercely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mus'r
Jingle
and
Miss
Rachael
,
in
a
po'-chay
,
from
Blue
Lion
,
Muggleton
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
there
;
but
I
could
n't
stop
'em
;
<EOS>
so
I
run
off
to
tell
"
ee
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
paid
his
expenses
!
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
jumping
up
frantically
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
got
ten
pounds
of
mine
!
---
stop
him
!
<EOS>
---
he
's
swindled
me
!
<EOS>
---
I
wo
n't
bear
it
!
<EOS>
---
I
'll
have
justice
,
Pickwick
!
---
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
stand
it
!
"
<EOS>
and
with
sundry
incoherent
exclamations
of
the
like
nature
,
the
unhappy
gentleman
spun
round
and
round
the
apartment
,
in
a
transport
of
frenzy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
preserve
us
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Pickwick
,
eyeing
the
extraordinary
gestures
of
his
friend
with
terrified
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
gone
mad
!
 
<EOS>
What
shall
we
do
?
"
<EOS>
"
Do
!
"
said
the
stout
old
host
,
who
regarded
only
the
last
words
of
the
sentence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
the
horse
in
the
gig
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
get
a
chaise
at
the
Lion
,
and
follow
'em
instantly
.
 
<EOS>
Where
?
<EOS>
"
---
he
exclaimed
,
as
the
man
ran
out
to
execute
the
commission
---
"
where
's
that
villain
,
Joe
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
!
<EOS>
but
I
hain't
a
willin
,
"
replied
a
voice
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
fat
boy
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
get
at
him
,
Pickwick
,
"
cried
Wardle
,
as
he
rushed
at
the
ill
-
starred
youth
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
bribed
by
that
scoundrel
,
Jingle
,
to
put
me
on
a
wrong
scent
,
by
telling
a
cock
-
and
-
bull
story
of
my
sister
and
your
friend
Tupman
!
"
<EOS>
(
Here
Mr
Tupman
sank
into
a
chair
.
)
<EOS>
"
Let
me
get
at
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
let
him
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
all
the
women
,
above
whose
exclamations
the
blubbering
of
the
fat
boy
was
distinctly
audible
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
be
held
!
"
cried
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Winkle
,
take
your
hands
off
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
let
me
go
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautiful
sight
,
in
that
moment
of
turmoil
and
confusion
,
to
behold
the
placid
and
philosophical
expression
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
face
,
albeit
somewhat
flushed
with
exertion
,
as
he
stood
with
his
arms
firmly
clasped
round
the
extensive
waist
of
their
corpulent
host
,
thus
restraining
the
impetuosity
of
his
passion
,
while
the
fat
boy
was
scratched
,
and
pulled
,
and
pushed
from
the
room
by
all
the
females
congregated
therein
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
sooner
released
his
hold
,
than
the
man
entered
to
announce
that
the
gig
was
ready
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
let
him
go
alone
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
the
females
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
kill
somebody
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
with
him
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
good
fellow
,
Pickwick
,
"
said
the
host
,
grasping
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Emma
,
give
Mr
Pickwick
a
shawl
to
tie
round
his
neck
---
make
haste
.
 
<EOS>
Look
after
your
grandmother
,
girls
;
she
has
fainted
away
.
 
<EOS>
Now
then
,
are
you
ready
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
mouth
and
chin
having
been
hastily
enveloped
in
a
large
shawl
,
his
hat
having
been
put
on
his
head
,
and
his
greatcoat
thrown
over
his
arm
,
he
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
They
jumped
into
the
gig
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
her
her
head
,
Tom
,
"
cried
the
host
;
and
away
they
went
,
down
the
narrow
lanes
;
jolting
in
and
out
of
the
cart
-
ruts
,
and
bumping
up
against
the
hedges
on
either
side
,
as
if
they
would
go
to
pieces
every
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
much
are
they
ahead
?
<EOS>
"
shouted
Wardle
,
as
they
drove
up
to
the
door
of
the
Blue
Lion
,
round
which
a
little
crowd
had
collected
,
late
as
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
above
three
-
quarters
of
an
hour
,
"
was
everybody
's
reply
.
<EOS>
"
Chaise
-
and
-
four
directly
!
<EOS>
---
out
with
'em
!
 
<EOS>
Put
up
the
gig
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
boys
!
"
cried
the
landlord
---
"
chaise
-
and
-
four
out
---
make
haste
---
look
alive
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
Away
ran
the
hostlers
and
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
The
lanterns
glimmered
,
as
the
men
ran
to
and
fro
;
the
horses
"
hoofs
clattered
on
the
uneven
paving
of
the
yard
;
the
chaise
rumbled
as
it
was
drawn
out
of
the
coach
-
house
;
and
all
was
noise
and
bustle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
then
!
<EOS>
---
is
that
chaise
coming
out
to
-
night
?
"
cried
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Coming
down
the
yard
now
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
hostler
.
   
<EOS>
Out
came
the
chaise
---
in
went
the
horses
---
on
sprang
the
boys
 
---
in
got
the
travellers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mind
---
the
seven
-
mile
stage
in
less
than
half
an
hour
!
"
shouted
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Off
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
boys
applied
whip
and
spur
,
the
waiters
shouted
,
the
hostlers
cheered
,
and
away
they
went
,
fast
and
furiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
situation
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
when
he
had
had
a
moment
's
time
for
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pretty
situation
for
the
general
chairman
of
the
Pickwick
Club
.
 
<EOS>
Damp
chaise
---
strange
horses
---
fifteen
miles
an
hour
---
and
twelve
o'clock
at
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
For
the
first
three
or
four
miles
,
not
a
word
was
spoken
by
either
of
the
gentlemen
,
each
being
too
much
immersed
in
his
own
reflections
to
address
any
observations
to
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
had
gone
over
that
much
ground
,
however
,
and
the
horses
getting
thoroughly
warmed
began
to
do
their
work
in
really
good
style
,
Mr
Pickwick
became
too
much
exhilarated
with
the
rapidity
of
the
motion
,
to
remain
any
longer
perfectly
mute
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
're
sure
to
catch
them
,
I
think
,
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hope
so
,
"
replied
his
companion
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fine
night
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
up
at
the
moon
,
which
was
shining
brightly
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
worse
,
"
returned
Wardle
;
"
for
they
'll
have
had
all
the
advantage
of
the
moonlight
to
get
the
start
of
us
,
and
we
shall
lose
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
have
gone
down
in
another
hour
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
rather
unpleasant
going
at
this
rate
in
the
dark
,
wo
n't
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
it
will
,
"
replied
his
friend
dryly
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
temporary
excitement
began
to
sober
down
a
little
,
as
he
reflected
upon
the
inconveniences
and
dangers
of
the
expedition
in
which
he
had
so
thoughtlessly
embarked
.
<EOS>
He
was
roused
by
a
loud
shouting
of
the
post
-
boy
on
the
leader
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yo
-
yo
-
yo
-
yo
-
yoe
!
"
went
the
first
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yo
-
yo
-
yo
-
yoe
!
"
went
the
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yo
-
yo
-
yo
-
yoe
!
"
<EOS>
chimed
in
old
Wardle
himself
,
most
lustily
,
with
his
head
and
half
his
body
out
of
the
coach
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yo
-
yo
-
yo
-
yoe
!
"
shouted
Mr
Pickwick
,
taking
up
the
burden
of
the
cry
,
though
he
had
not
the
slightest
notion
of
its
meaning
or
object
.
 
<EOS>
And
amidst
the
yo
-
yoing
of
the
whole
four
,
the
chaise
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
gate
here
,
"
replied
old
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
hear
something
of
the
fugitives
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
lapse
of
five
minutes
,
consumed
in
incessant
knocking
and
shouting
,
an
old
man
in
his
shirt
and
trousers
emerged
from
the
turnpike
-
house
,
and
opened
the
gate
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
is
it
since
a
post
-
chaise
went
through
here
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
?
"
   
"
ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
do
n't
rightly
know
.
 
<EOS>
It
<EOS>
worn't
<EOS>
a
long
time
ago
,
nor
it
worn't
<EOS>
a
short
time
ago
---
just
between
the
two
,
perhaps
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
any
chaise
been
by
at
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
there
's
been
a
Shay
by
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
ago
,
my
friend
,
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
an
hour
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
I
dare
say
it
might
be
,
"
replied
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
two
hours
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
post
---
boy
on
the
wheeler
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
should
n't
wonder
if
it
was
,
"
returned
the
old
man
doubtfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drive
on
,
boys
,
"
cried
the
testy
old
gentleman
;
"
do
n't
waste
any
more
time
with
that
old
idiot
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Idiot
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
old
man
with
a
grin
,
as
he
stood
in
the
middle
of
the
road
with
the
gate
half
-
closed
,
watching
the
chaise
which
rapidly
diminished
in
the
increasing
distance
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
---
not
much
o
'
<EOS>
that
either
;
you
've
lost
ten
minutes
here
,
and
gone
away
as
wise
as
you
came
,
arter
all
.
 
<EOS>
If
every
man
on
the
line
as
has
a
guinea
give
him
,
earns
it
half
as
well
<EOS>
,
you
wo
n't
catch
t'other
shay
this
side
Mich'lmas
,
old
short
-
and
-
fat
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
another
prolonged
grin
,
the
old
man
closed
the
gate
,
re
-
entered
his
house
,
and
bolted
the
door
after
him
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
the
chaise
proceeded
,
without
any
slackening
of
pace
,
towards
the
conclusion
of
the
stage
.
 
<EOS>
The
moon
,
as
Wardle
had
foretold
,
was
rapidly
on
the
wane
;
large
tiers
of
dark
,
heavy
clouds
,
which
had
been
gradually
overspreading
the
sky
for
some
time
past
,
now
formed
one
black
mass
overhead
;
and
large
drops
of
rain
which
pattered
every
now
and
then
against
the
windows
of
the
chaise
,
seemed
to
warn
the
travellers
of
the
rapid
approach
of
a
stormy
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
wind
,
too
,
which
was
directly
against
them
,
swept
in
furious
gusts
down
the
narrow
road
,
and
howled
dismally
through
the
trees
which
skirted
the
pathway
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
drew
his
coat
closer
about
him
,
coiled
himself
more
snugly
up
into
the
corner
of
the
chaise
,
and
fell
into
a
sound
sleep
,
from
which
he
was
only
awakened
by
the
stopping
of
the
vehicle
,
the
sound
of
the
hostler
's
bell
,
and
a
loud
cry
of
"
Horses
on
directly
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
here
another
delay
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
The
boys
were
sleeping
with
such
mysterious
soundness
,
that
it
took
five
minutes
a
-
piece
to
wake
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
hostler
had
somehow
or
other
mislaid
the
key
of
the
stable
,
and
even
when
that
was
found
,
two
sleepy
helpers
put
the
wrong
harness
on
the
wrong
horses
,
and
the
whole
process
of
harnessing
had
to
be
gone
through
afresh
.
 
<EOS>
Had
Mr
Pickwick
been
alone
,
these
multiplied
obstacles
would
have
completely
put
an
end
to
the
pursuit
at
once
,
but
old
Wardle
was
not
to
be
so
easily
daunted
;
and
he
laid
about
him
with
such
hearty
good
-
will
,
cuffing
this
man
,
and
pushing
that
;
strapping
a
buckle
here
,
and
taking
in
a
link
there
,
that
the
chaise
was
ready
in
a
much
shorter
time
than
could
reasonably
have
been
expected
,
under
so
many
difficulties
.
   
<EOS>
They
resumed
their
journey
;
and
certainly
the
prospect
before
them
was
by
no
means
encouraging
.
 
<EOS>
The
stage
was
fifteen
miles
long
,
the
night
was
dark
,
the
wind
high
,
and
the
rain
pouring
in
torrents
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
make
any
great
way
against
such
obstacles
united
;
it
was
hard
upon
one
o'clock
already
;
and
nearly
two
hours
were
consumed
in
getting
to
the
end
of
the
stage
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
however
,
an
object
presented
itself
,
which
rekindled
their
hopes
,
and
reanimated
their
drooping
spirits
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
did
this
chaise
come
in
?
"
cried
old
Wardle
,
leaping
out
of
his
own
vehicle
,
and
pointing
to
one
covered
with
wet
mud
,
which
was
standing
in
the
yard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
quarter
of
an
hour
ago
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
hostler
,
to
whom
the
question
was
addressed
.
<EOS>
"
Lady
and
gentleman
?
"
inquired
Wardle
,
almost
breathless
with
impatience
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tall
gentleman
---
dress
-
coat
---
long
legs
---
thin
body
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Elderly
lady
---
thin
face
---
rather
skinny
---
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
heavens
,
it
's
the
couple
,
Pickwick
,
"
exclaimed
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Would
have
been
here
before
,
"
said
the
hostler
,
"
but
they
broke
a
trace
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
'
Tis
them
!
"
said
Wardle
,
"
it
is
,
by
Jove
!
 
<EOS>
Chaise
-
and
-
four
instantly
!
 
<EOS>
We
shall
catch
them
yet
before
they
reach
the
next
stage
.
 
<EOS>
A
guinea
a
-
piece
<EOS>
,
boys
-
be
alive
there
---
<EOS>
bustle
about
<EOS>
---
there
's
good
fellows
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
with
such
admonitions
as
these
,
the
old
gentleman
ran
up
and
down
the
yard
,
and
bustled
to
and
fro
,
in
a
state
of
excitement
which
communicated
itself
to
Mr
Pickwick
also
;
and
under
the
influence
of
which
,
that
gentleman
got
himself
into
complicated
entanglements
with
harness
,
and
mixed
up
with
horses
and
wheels
of
chaises
,
in
the
most
surprising
manner
,
firmly
believing
that
by
so
doing
he
was
materially
forwarding
the
preparations
for
their
resuming
their
journey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jump
in
---
jump
in
!
"
<EOS>
cried
old
Wardle
,
climbing
into
the
chaise
,
pulling
up
the
steps
,
and
slamming
the
door
after
him
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
!
 
<EOS>
Make
haste
!
"
<EOS>
And
before
Mr
Pickwick
knew
precisely
what
he
was
about
,
he
felt
himself
forced
in
at
the
other
door
,
by
one
pull
from
the
old
gentleman
and
one
push
from
the
hostler
;
and
off
they
were
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
we
are
moving
now
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
exultingly
.
<EOS>
They
were
indeed
,
as
was
sufficiently
testified
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
by
his
constant
collision
either
with
the
hard
wood
-
work
of
the
chaise
,
or
the
body
of
his
companion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
up
!
"
said
the
stout
old
Mr
Wardle
,
as
Mr
Pickwick
dived
head
foremost
into
his
capacious
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
did
feel
such
a
jolting
in
my
life
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
replied
his
companion
,
"
it
will
soon
be
over
.
<EOS>
Steady
,
steady
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
planted
himself
into
his
own
corner
,
as
firmly
as
he
could
;
and
on
whirled
the
chaise
faster
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
travelled
in
this
way
about
three
miles
,
when
Mr
Wardle
,
who
had
been
looking
out
of
the
Window
for
two
or
three
minutes
,
suddenly
drew
in
his
face
,
covered
with
splashes
,
and
exclaimed
in
breathless
eagerness
---
   
<EOS>
"
Here
they
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
thrust
his
head
out
of
his
window
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
:
there
was
a
chaise
-
and
-
four
,
a
short
distance
before
them
,
dashing
along
at
full
gallop
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
go
on
,
"
almost
shrieked
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
guineas
a
-
piece
,
boys
---
do
n't
let
'em
gain
on
us
---
keep
it
up
---
keep
it
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
horses
in
the
first
chaise
started
on
at
their
utmost
speed
;
and
those
in
Mr
Wardle
's
galloped
furiously
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
his
head
,
"
exclaimed
the
choleric
old
man
;
"
damme
,
I
see
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
do
I
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
that
's
he
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
not
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
The
countenance
of
Mr
Jingle
,
completely
coated
with
mud
thrown
up
by
the
wheels
,
was
plainly
discernible
at
the
window
of
his
chaise
;
and
the
motion
of
his
arm
,
which
was
waving
violently
towards
the
postillions
,
denoted
that
he
was
encouraging
them
to
increased
exertion
.
   
<EOS>
The
interest
was
intense
.
 
<EOS>
Fields
,
trees
,
and
hedges
,
seemed
to
rush
past
them
with
the
velocity
of
a
whirlwind
,
so
rapid
was
the
pace
at
which
they
tore
along
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
close
by
the
side
of
the
first
chaise
.
 
<EOS>
Jingle
's
voice
could
be
plainly
heard
,
even
above
the
din
of
the
wheels
,
urging
on
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Mr
Wardle
foamed
with
rage
and
excitement
.
 
<EOS>
He
roared
out
scoundrels
and
villains
by
the
dozen
,
clenched
his
fist
and
shook
it
expressively
at
the
object
of
his
indignation
;
but
Mr
Jingle
only
answered
with
a
contemptuous
smile
,
and
replied
to
his
menaces
by
a
shout
of
triumph
,
as
his
horses
,
answering
the
increased
application
of
whip
and
spur
,
broke
into
a
faster
gallop
,
and
left
the
pursuers
behind
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
just
drawn
in
his
head
,
and
Mr
Wardle
,
exhausted
with
shouting
,
had
done
the
same
,
when
a
tremendous
jolt
threw
them
forward
against
the
front
of
the
vehicle
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sudden
bump
---
a
loud
crash
---
away
rolled
a
wheel
,
and
over
went
the
chaise
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
very
few
seconds
of
bewilderment
and
confusion
,
in
which
nothing
but
the
plunging
of
horses
,
and
breaking
of
glass
could
be
made
out
,
Mr
Pickwick
felt
himself
violently
pulled
out
from
among
the
ruins
of
the
chaise
;
and
as
soon
as
he
had
gained
his
feet
,
extricated
his
head
from
the
skirts
of
his
greatcoat
,
which
materially
impeded
the
usefulness
of
his
spectacles
,
the
full
disaster
of
the
case
met
his
view
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Mr
Wardle
without
a
hat
,
and
his
clothes
torn
in
several
places
,
stood
by
his
side
,
and
the
fragments
of
the
chaise
lay
scattered
at
their
feet
.
 
<EOS>
The
post
-
boys
,
who
had
succeeded
in
cutting
the
traces
,
were
standing
,
disfigured
with
mud
and
disordered
by
hard
riding
,
by
the
horses
"
heads
.
 
<EOS>
About
a
hundred
yards
in
advance
was
the
other
chaise
,
which
had
pulled
up
on
hearing
the
crash
.
 
<EOS>
The
postillions
,
each
with
a
broad
grin
convulsing
his
countenance
,
were
viewing
the
adverse
party
from
their
saddles
,
and
Mr
Jingle
was
contemplating
the
wreck
from
the
coach
window
,
with
evident
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
was
just
breaking
,
and
the
whole
scene
was
rendered
perfectly
visible
by
the
grey
light
of
the
morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"
shouted
the
shameless
Jingle
,
"
anybody
damaged
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
elderly
gentlemen
---
no
light
weights
---
dangerous
work
---
<EOS>
very
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
rascal
,
"
roared
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
"
replied
Jingle
;
and
then
he
added
,
with
a
knowing

,

the

---
"
I
say
---
she
's
very
well
---
<EOS>
desires

---
begs

wo
n't

---
love
to
TUPPY
---
wo

you
get
up
behind
?
<EOS>
---
drive
on
,
boys
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
postillions
resumed
their
proper
attitudes
,
and
away
rattled
the
chaise
,
Mr
Jingle
fluttering
in
derision
a
white
handkerchief
from
the
coach
window
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
in
the
whole
adventure
,
not
even
the
upset
,
had
disturbed
the
calm
and
equable
current
of
Mr
Pickwick
's

.
 
<EOS>
The
villainy
,
however
,
which
could
first
borrow
money
of
his
faithful

,
and
then

his
name
to
"
Tuppy
,
"
<EOS>
was
more
than
he

.
 
<EOS>
He
drew

,
and
coloured

to
the
very

his

,
as

,
slowly

---
   
<EOS>
"
If

,
I
'll
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
"
interrupted

,
"

;
but
while

,
they
'll

,
and
be
married

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
paused
,
bottled

,
and
corked
it
down
.
<EOS>
"
How
far
is
it
to
the
next

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Six
mile
,
ai

,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rayther
better
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rayther
better
nor
six

,
Sir
.
"
   
"
Ca
n't

,
"
said

,
"
we
must

,
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
help
for
it
,
"
replied
that
truly
great
man
.
   
<EOS>
So
sending
forward
one
of
the
boys
on

,
to

a
fresh
chaise
and

,
and

to

,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Wardle
set
manfully

on
the

,
first

shawls
round
their
necks
,
and
slouching
down
their
hats
to
escape
as

from
the
deluge
of
rain
,
which
after
a
slight
cessation
had
again
begun
to
pour
heavily
down
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
Clearing
up
all
doubts
(
if
any
existed
)
of
the
disinterestedness
of
Mr
A
Jingle
's
character
 
<EOS>
There
are
in
London
several
old
inns
,
once
the
headquarters
of
celebrated
coaches
in
the
days
when
coaches
performed
their
journeys
in
a
graver
and
more
solemn
manner
than
they
do
in
these
times
;
but
which
have
now
degenerated
into
little
more
than
the
abiding
and
booking
-
places
of
country
wagons
.
 
<EOS>
The
reader
would
look
in
vain
for
any
of
these
ancient
hostelries
,
among
the
Golden
Crosses
and
Bull
and
Mouths
,
which
rear
their
stately
fronts
in
the
improved
streets
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
would
light
upon
any
of
these
old
places
,
he
must
direct
his
steps
to
the
obscurer
quarters
of
the
town
,
and
there
in
some
secluded
nooks
he
will
find
several
,
still
standing
with
a
kind
of
gloomy
sturdiness
,
amidst
the
modern
innovations
which
surround
them
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
Borough
especially
,
there
still
remain
some
half
-
dozen
old
inns
,
which
have
preserved
their
external
features
unchanged
,
and
which
have
escaped
alike
the
rage
for
public
improvement
and
the
encroachments
of
private
speculation
.
 
<EOS>
Great
,
rambling
queer
old
places
they
are
,
with
galleries
,
and
passages
,
and
staircases
,
wide
enough
and
antiquated
enough
to
furnish
materials
for
a
hundred
ghost
stories
,
supposing
we
should
ever
be
reduced
to
the
lamentable
necessity
of
inventing
any
,
and
that
the
world
should
exist
long
enough
to
exhaust
the
innumerable
veracious
legends
connected
with
old
London
Bridge
,
and
its
adjacent
neighbourhood
on
the
Surrey
side
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
yard
of
one
of
these
inns
---
of
no
less
celebrated
a
one
than
the
White
Hart
---
that
a
man
was
busily
employed
in
brushing
the
dirt
off
a
pair
of
boots
,
early
on
the
morning
succeeding
the
events
narrated
in
the
last
chapter
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
habited
in
a
coarse
,
striped
waistcoat
,
with
black
calico
sleeves
,
and
blue
glass
buttons
;
drab
breeches
and
leggings
.
 
<EOS>
A
bright
red
handkerchief
was
wound
in
a
very
loose
and
unstudied
style
<EOS>
round
his
neck
,
and
an
old
white
hat
was
carelessly
thrown
on
one
side
of
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
rows
of
boots
before
him
,
one
cleaned
and
the
other
dirty
,
and
at
every
addition
he
made
to
the
clean
row
,
he
paused
from
his
work
,
and
contemplated
its
results
with
evident
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
The
yard
presented
none
of
that
bustle
and
activity
which
are
the
usual
characteristics
of
a
large
coach
inn
.
 
<EOS>
Three
or
four
lumbering
wagons
,
each
with
a
pile
of
goods
beneath
its
ample
canopy
,
about
the
height
of
the
second
-
floor
window
of
an
ordinary
house
,
were
stowed
away
beneath
a
lofty
roof
which
extended
over
one
end
of
the
yard
;
and
another
,
which
was
probably
to
commence
its
journey
that
morning
,
was
drawn
out
into
the
open
space
.
 
<EOS>
A
double
tier
of
bedroom
galleries
,
with
old
Clumsy

,
ran
round
two
sides
of
the
straggling
area
,
and

double
row
of
bells
to
correspond
,

from
the
weather
by
a
little

,

the
door

the
bar

.
 
<EOS>
Two

three

were

pent

houses
;
and

,

,

,
that
the
stable
lay
in

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
wool

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

---

.

"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
Sam

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
Here

,
"

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Sam

.
   
<EOS>
Old
Wardle
opened

;

Jingle
,

,

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

---

<EOS>

,

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
(

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

,

---

,

<EOS>
Now
,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

OLD

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

---

the

.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
is
not
seventy
-
three
now
,
my
dear
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
little
man
paused
,
and
took
a

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
cried
Mr
Jingle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
sir
---
you
do
n't
take
snuff
!
<EOS>
---
ah
!
<EOS>
so
much
the
better
---
expensive
habit
---
<EOS>
well
,
my
dear
Sir
,
you
're
a
fine

man
,
man
of
the
world
---
able
to
push
your

,
if

had

,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Jingle
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

think
---
now
,

dear
Sir
,
I
put
it
to
<EOS>
you
do
<EOS>
n't

---
that

Miss

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
do
---
not
half
enough
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Jingle
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
nay
,
my

Sir
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
round
sum
---
a
man

could

in
no

---
great
deal
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
More

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
we
wo

in

,
"
resumed

,
"
say
---
say
---
seventy
.
"
<EOS>
"
Wo

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,
my

<EOS>
---
pray

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Eighty
;

:
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
Sir
,

,
"

,

;
"

WILL

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Expensive

,
"

Mr
Jingle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Money
out
of
pocket
---
posting
,

;

,

---
<EOS>
that

---

---

---
<EOS>
breach

---

<EOS>
---
"
   
"

,

,

,
"

the

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
That

---

---

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,

<EOS>
,

,
"

;

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

;
"

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
---
"
   
"

"

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Off

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Bye

,
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
If
any

could
have
beheld

of
the
illustrious
man
,
whose
name

the
leading

of

of
this
work
,
during
the

this

,
he
would
have

almost
induced
to
wonder
that
the
indignant

which

from

did
not

---
so

.
 
<EOS>
His
nostrils
dilated
,
and
his

clenched

,
as
he
heard

addressed
by
the

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
restrained
himself
again
---
he
did
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
continued

,

's

;
"
get

---
take
home
the
lady
 
---
do
for
Tuppy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
a
philosopher
,
but
philosophers
are
only
men
in
armour
,
after
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
shaft
had
reached
him
,
penetrated
through
his
philosophical

,
to

very

.
 
<EOS>
In
the

of
his
rage
,
he
hurled
the
inkstand
madly
forward
,
and
followed
it
up

.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Jingle
had
disappeared
,
and
he
found
himself
caught
in

arms
of
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,
"
said
that

,
"
furniter
's
cheap
where
you
come
from
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Self
-
acting
ink
,
that
'
ere
;
it
's
wrote
your
mark
upon
the
wall
,
old
gen'l'm'n
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
<EOS>
still
,
Sir
;
wot
's
the
use
o

'
runnin
'
arter
a
man
as
has
made
his
lucky
,
and
got

t'other
end
of
the
Borough
by
this

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
mind
,
like
those
of
all
truly
great
men
,
was
open
to
conviction
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
quick
and
powerful
reasoner
;
and
a
moment
's
reflection
sufficed
to
remind
him
of
the
impotency
of
his
rage
.
 
<EOS>
It
subsided
as
quickly
as
it
had
been
roused
.
<EOS>
He
panted
for
breath
,
and
looked
benignantly
round
upon
his
friends
.
   
<EOS>
Shall
we
tell
the
lamentations
that
ensued
when
Miss
Wardle
found
herself
deserted
by
the
faithless
Jingle
?
 
<EOS>
Shall
we
extract
Mr
Pickwick
's
masterly
description
of
that
heartrending
scene
?
<EOS>
His
note
-
book
,
blotted
with
the
tears
of
sympathising
humanity
,
lies
open
before
us
;
one
word
,
and
it
is
in
the
printer
's
hands
.
<EOS>
But
,
no
!
<EOS>
we
will
be
resolute
!
 
<EOS>
We
will
not
wring
the
public
bosom
,
with
the
delineation
of
such
suffering
!
   
<EOS>
Slowly
and
sadly
did
the
two
friends
and
the
deserted
lady
return
next
day
in
the
Muggleton
heavy

.
 
<EOS>
Dimly
<EOS>
and
darkly
had
the
sombre

of
a
summer
's
night
fallen
upon
all
around
,
when
they
again
reached
Dingley
Dell
,
and
stood
within

to
Manor
Farm
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
Involving
another
journey
,
and
an
antiquarian
discovery
;
recording
Mr
Pickwick
's
determination
to
be
present
at
an
election
;
and
containing
a
manuscript
of
the
old
clergyman
's
 
A
night
of
quiet
and

in
the
profound

of
Dingley

,
and
an

's

of
its

on

morning
,
completely
recovered
Mr
Pickwick
from
the
effects
of
his
late
fatigue
of
body
and
anxiety

mind
.
<EOS>
That
illustrious
man
had
been
separated
from
his
friends
and
fol
lowers
for
two
whole
days
;
and
it
was
with
a

and

,
which
no
common

can
adequately

,
that
he
stepped

to

Mr
Winkle
and
Mr

,
as

on

.
 
<EOS>
The
pleasure
was
mutual
;
for
who
could

's

without
experiencing
the
sensation
?
 
<EOS>
But
still
a
cloud
seemed
to
hang
over
his
companions
which
that
great
man
could
not
but
be
sensible
of
,
and
was
wholly
at
a
loss
to
account
for
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
mysterious
air
about

both
,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
when

had

his

by

,
and
exchanged
warm

of

---
<EOS>
"
how
is
Tupman
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
to
whom
the
question
was
more

,
made
no

.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
away
his

,
and
appeared
absorbed
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Snodgrass
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
earnestly
,
"
how
is
our
friend
---
he
is
not
ill
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
;
and
a

trembled
on
his
sentimental

,
like
a
rain
-
drop
on
a
window
-
frame-'no
;
he
is
not
ill
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
stopped
,
and
gazed
on
each
of
his
friends
in
turn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Winkle
---
Snodgrass
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
what
does
this
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Where
is
our
friend
?
 
<EOS>
What
has
happened
?
 
<EOS>
Speak
---
<EOS>
I
conjure
<EOS>
,
I
entreat
---
<EOS>
nay
,
I
command
you
,
speak
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
solemnity
---
a
dignity
---
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
manner
,
not
to
be
withstood
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
gone
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
,
"
repeated
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
!
"
ejaculated
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
can
only
guess
,
from
that
communication
,
"
replied
Mr
Snodgrass
,
taking
a
letter
from
his
pocket
,
and
placing
it
in
his
friend
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yesterday
morning
,
when
a
letter
was
received
from
Mr
Wardle
,
stating
that
you
would
be
home
with
his
sister
at
night
,
the
melancholy
which
had
hung
over
our
friend
during
the
whole
of
the
previous
day
,
was
observed
to
increase
.
 
<EOS>
He
shortly
afterwards
disappeared
:
he
was
missing
during
the
whole
day
,
and
in
the
evening
this
letter
was
brought
by
the
hostler
from
the
Crown
,
at
Muggleton
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
left
in
his
charge
in
the
morning
,
with
a
strict
injunction
that
it
should
not
be
delivered
until
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
opened
the
epistle
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
his
friend
's
hand
-
writing
,
and
these
were
its
contents
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
MY
DEAR
PICKWICK
,
---
YOU
,
my
dear
friend
,
are
placed
far
beyond
the
reach
of
many
mortal
frailties
and
weaknesses
which
ordinary
people
can
not
overcome
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
not
know
what
it
is
,
at
one
blow
,
to
be
deserted
by
a
lovely
and
fascinating
creature
,
and
to
fall
a
victim
to
the
artifices
of
a
villain
,
who
had
the
grin
of
cunning
beneath
the
mask
of
friendship
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
never
may
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Any
letter
addressed
to
me
at
the
Leather
Bottle
,
Cobham
,
Kent
,
will
be
forwarded
---
supposing
I
still
exist
.
 
<EOS>
I
hasten
from
the
sight
of
that
world
,
which
has
become
odious
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Should
I
hasten
from
it
altogether
,
pity
---
forgive
me
.
 
<EOS>
Life
,
my
dear
Pickwick
,
has
become
insupportable
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
spirit
which
burns
within
us
,
is
a
porter
's
knot
,
on
which
to
rest
the
heavy
load
of
worldly
cares
and
troubles
;
and
when
that
spirit
fails
us
,
the
burden
is
too
heavy
to
be
borne
.
 
<EOS>
We
sink
beneath
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
tell
Rachael
---
Ah
,
that
name
!
<EOS>
---
                      
"
TRACY
TupmAN
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
leave
this
place
directly
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
refolded
the
note
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
not
have
been
decent
for
us
to
remain
here
,
under
any
circumstances
,
after
what
has
happened
;
and
now
we
are
bound
to
follow
in
search
of
our
friend
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
saying
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
His
intention
was
rapidly
communicated
.
 
<EOS>
The
entreaties
to
remain
were
pressing
,
but
Mr
Pickwick
was
inflexible
.
 
<EOS>
Business
,
he
said
,
required
his
immediate
attendance
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
clergyman
was
present
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
really
going
?
"
<EOS>
said
he
,
taking
Mr
Pickwick
aside
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
reiterated
his
former
determination
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
here
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
is
a
little
manuscript
,
which
I
had
hoped
to
have
the
pleasure
of
reading
to
you
myself
.
<EOS>
I
found
it
on
the
death
of
a
friend
of
mine
---
a
medical
man
,
engaged
in
our
county
lunatic
asylum
---
among
a
variety
of
papers
,
which
I
had
the
option
of
destroying
or
preserving
,
as
I
thought
proper
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
hardly
believe
that
the
manuscript
is
genuine
,
though
it
certainly
is
not
in
my
friend
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
whether
it
be
the
genuine
production
of
a
maniac
,
or
founded
upon
the
ravings
of
some
unhappy
being
(
which
I
think
more
probable
)
,
read
it
,
and
judge
for
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
received
the
manuscript
,
and
parted
from
the
benevolent
old
gentleman
with
many
expressions
of
good
-
will
and
esteem
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
more
difficult
task
to
take
leave
of
the
inmates
of
Manor
Farm
,
from
whom
they
had
received
so
much
hospitality
and
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
kissed
the
young
ladies
---
we
were
going
to
say
,
as
if
they
were
his
own
daughters
,
only
,
as
he
might
possibly
have
infused
a
little
more
warmth
into
the
salutation
,
the
comparison
would
not
be
quite
appropriate
---
hugged
the
old
lady
with
filial
cordiality
;
and
patted
the
rosy
cheeks
of
the
female
servants
in
a
most
patriarchal
manner
,
as
he
slipped
into
the
hands
of
each
some
more
substantial
expression
of
his
approval
.
<EOS>
The
exchange
of
cordialities
with
their
fine
old
host
and
Mr
Trundle
was
even
more
hearty
and
prolonged
;
and
it
was
not
until
Mr
Snodgrass
had
been
several
times
called
for
,
and
at
last
emerged
from
a
dark
passage
followed
soon
after
by
Emily
(
whose
bright
eyes
looked
unusually
dim
)
,
that
the
three
friends
were
enabled
to
tear
themselves
from
their
friendly
entertainers
.
<EOS>
Many
a
backward
look
they
gave
at
the
farm
,
as
they
walked
slowly
away
;
and
many
a
kiss
did
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
waft
in
the
air
,
in
acknowledgment
of
something
very
like
a
lady
's
handkerchief
,
which
was
waved
from
one
of
the
upper
windows
,
until
a
turn
of
the
lane
hid
the
old
house
from
their
sight
.
   
<EOS>
At
Muggleton
they
procured
a
conveyance
to
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
they
reached
the
last
-
named
place
,
the
violence
of
their
grief
had
sufficiently
abated
to
admit
of
their
making
a
very
excellent
early
dinner
;
and
having
procured
the
necessary
information
relative
to
the
road
,
the
three
friends
set
forward
again
in
the
afternoon
to
walk
to
Cobham
.
   
<EOS>
A
delightful
walk
it
was
;
for
it
was
a
pleasant
afternoon
in
June
,
and
their
way
lay
through
a
deep
and
shady
wood
,
cooled
by
the
light
wind
which
gently
rustled
the
thick
foliage
,
and
enlivened
by
the
songs
of
the
birds
that
perched
upon
the
boughs
.
<EOS>
The
ivy
and
the
moss
crept
in
thick
clusters
over
the
old
trees
,
and
the
soft
green
turf
overspread
the
ground
like
a
silken
mat
.
 
<EOS>
They
emerged
upon
an
open
park
,
with
an
ancient
hall
,
displaying
the
quaint
and
picturesque
architecture
of
Elizabeth
's
time
.
 
<EOS>
Long
vistas
of
stately
oaks
and
elm
trees
appeared
on
every
side
;
large
herds
of
deer
were
cropping
the
fresh
grass
;
and
occasionally
a
startled
hare
scoured
along
the
ground
,
with
the
speed
of
the
shadows
thrown
by
the
light
clouds
which
swept
across
a
sunny
landscape
like
a
passing
breath
of
summer
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
this
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
about
him
---
"
if
this
were
the
place
to
which
all
who
are
troubled
with
our
friend
's
complaint
<EOS>
came
,
I
fancy
their
old
attachment
to
this
world
would
very
soon
return
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
too
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
really
,
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
half
an
hour
's
walking
had
brought
them
to
the
village
,
"
really
,
for
a
misanthrope
's
choice
<EOS>
,
this
is
one
of
the
prettiest
and
most
desirable
places
of
residence
I
ever
met
with
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
this
opinion
also
,
both
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
expressed
their
concurrence
;
and
having
been
directed
to
the
Leather
Bottle
,
a
clean
and
commodious
village
ale
-
house
,
the
three
travellers
entered
,
and
at
once
inquired
for
a
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Show
the
gentlemen
into
the
parlour
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
landlady
.
   
<EOS>
A
stout
country
lad
opened
a
door
at
the
end
of
the
passage
,
and
the
three
friends
entered
a
long
,
low
-
roofed
room
,
furnished
with
a
large
number
of
high
-
backed
leather
-
cushioned
chairs
,
of
fantastic
shapes
,
and
embellished
with
a
great
variety
of
old
portraits
and
roughly
-
coloured
prints
of
some
antiquity
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
upper
end
of
the
room
was
a
table
,
with
a
white
cloth
upon
it
,
well
covered
with
a
roast
fowl
,
bacon
,
ale
,
and
et
ceteras
;
and
at
the
table
sat
Mr
Tupman
,
looking
as
unlike
a
man
who
had
taken
his
leave
of
the
world
,
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
entrance
of
his
friends
,
that
gentleman
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
and
with
a
mournful
air
advanced
to
meet
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
expect
to
see
you
here
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
grasped
Mr
Pickwick
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
kind
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
sitting
down
,
and
wiping
from
his
forehead
the
perspiration
which
the
walk
had
engendered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Finish
your
dinner
,
and
walk
out
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
speak
to
you
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
did
as
he
was
desired
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
having
refreshed
himself
with
a
copious
draught
of
ale
,
waited
his
friend
's
leisure
.
<EOS>
The
dinner
was
quickly
despatched
,
and
they
walked
out
together
.
   
<EOS>
For
half
an
hour
,
their
forms
might
have
been
seen
pacing
the
churchyard
to
and
fro
,
while
Mr
Pickwick
was
engaged
in
combating
his
companion
's
resolution
.
 
<EOS>
Any
repetition
of
his
arguments
would
be
useless
;
for
what
language
could
convey
to
them
that
energy
and
force
which
their
great
originator
's
manner
communicated
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
Mr
Tupman
was
already
tired
of
retirement
,
or
whether
he
was
wholly
unable
to
resist
the
eloquent
appeal
which
was
made
to
him
,
matters
not
,
he
did
NOT
resist
it
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
mattered
little
to
him
,
"
he
said
,
"
where
he
dragged
out
the
miserable
remainder
of
his
days
;
and
since
his
friend
laid
so
much
stress
upon
his
humble
companionship
,
he
was
willing
to
share
his
adventures
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
smiled
;
they
shook
hands
,
and
walked
back
to
rejoin
their
companions
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
moment
that
Mr
Pickwick
made
that
immortal
discovery
,
which
has
been
the
pride
and
boast
of
his
friends
,
and
the
envy
of
every
antiquarian
in
this
or
any
other
country
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
passed
the
door
of
their
inn
,
and
walked
a
little
way
down
the
village
,
before
they
recollected
the
precise
spot
in
which
it
stood
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
turned
back
,
Mr
Pickwick
's
eye
fell
upon
a
small
broken
stone
,
partially
buried
in
the
ground
,
in
front
of
a
cottage
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
strange
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
strange
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tupman
,
staring
eagerly
at
every
object
near
him
,
but
the
right
one
.
 
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
<EOS>
,
what
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
last
was
an
ejaculation
of
irrepressible
astonishment
,
occasioned
by
seeing
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
his
enthusiasm
for
discovery
,
fall
on
his
knees
before
the
little
stone
,
and
commence
wiping
the
dust
off
it
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
an
inscription
here
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
?
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
discern
,
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
rubbing
away
with
all
his
might
,
and
gazing
intently
through
his
spectacles
---
"
I
can
discern
a
cross
,
and
a
13
,
and
then
a
T^.
 
<EOS>
This
is
important
,
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
starting
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
some
very
old
inscription
,
existing
perhaps
long
before
the
ancient
alms
-
houses
in
this
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
lost
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
tapped
at
the
cottage
door
.
 
<EOS>
A
labouring
man
opened
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
how
this
stone
came
here
,
my
friend
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
benevolent
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
doan't
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
man
civilly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
here
<EOS>
long
afore
<EOS>
I
was
born
,
or
any
on
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
glanced
triumphantly
at
his
companion
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
---
you
---
are
not
particularly
attached
to
it
,
I
dare
say
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
trembling
with
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
mind
selling
it
,
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
but
who
'd
buy
it
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
man
,
with
an
expression
of
face
which
he
probably
meant
to
be
very
cunning
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
give
you
ten
shillings
for
it
,
at
once
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
if
you
would
take
it
up
for
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
astonishment
of
the
village
may
be
easily
imagined
,
when
(
the
little
stone
having
been
raised
with
one
wrench
of
a
spade
)
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
by
dint
of
great
personal
exertion
,
bore
it
with
his
own
hands
to
the
inn
,
and
after
having
carefully
washed
it
,
deposited
it
on
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
The
exultation
and
joy
of
the
Pickwickians
knew
no
bounds
,
when
their
patience
and
assiduity
,
their
washing
and
scraping
,
were
crowned
with
success
.
 
<EOS>
The
stone
was
uneven
and
broken
,
and
the
letters
were
straggling
and
irregular
,
but
the
following
fragment
of
an
inscription
was
clearly
to
be
deciphered
:
---
          
<EOS>
[
cross
]
  
<EOS>
B^
I^
<EOS>
L^
S^
T^
         
u^
m^
          
<EOS>
P^
S^
<EOS>
H^
I^
           
<EOS>
S^
M^
           
<EOS>
ARK
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
eyes
sparkled
with
delight
,
as
he
sat
and
gloated
over
the
treasure
he
had
discovered
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
attained
one
of
the
greatest
objects
of
his
ambition
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
county
known
to
abound
in
the
remains
of
the
early
ages
;
in
a
village
in
which
there
still
existed
some
memorials
of
the
olden
time
,
he
---
he
,
the
chairman
of
the
Pickwick
Club
---
had
discovered
a
strange
and
curious
inscription
of
unquestionable
antiquity
,
which
had
wholly
escaped
the
observation
of
the
many
learned
men
who
had
preceded
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
trust
the
evidence
of
his
senses
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
---
this
,
"
said
he
,
"
determines
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
return
to
town
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
!
"
exclaimed
his
admiring
followers
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
treasure
must
be
at
once
deposited
where
it
can
be
thoroughly
investigated
and
properly
understood
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
another
reason
for
this
step
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
few
days
,
an
election
is
to
take
place
for
the
borough
of
Eatanswill
,
at
which
Mr
Perker
,
a
gentleman
whom
I
lately
met
,
is
the
agent
of
one
of
the
candidates
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
behold
,
and
minutely
examine
,
a
scene
so
interesting
to
every
Englishman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
,
"
was
the
animated
cry
of
three
voices
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
looked
round
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
attachment
and
fervour
of
his
followers
lighted
up
a
glow
of
enthusiasm
within
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
their
leader
,
and
he
felt
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
celebrate
this
happy
meeting
with
a
convivial
glass
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
This
proposition
,
like
the
other
,
was
received
with
unanimous
applause
.
 
<EOS>
Having
himself
deposited
the
important
stone
in
a
small
deal
box
,
purchased
from
the
landlady
for
the
purpose
,
he
placed
himself
in
an
arm
-
chair
,
at
the
head
of
the
table
;
and
the
evening
was
devoted
to
festivity
and
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
past
eleven
o'clock
---
a
late
hour
for
the
little
village
of
Cobham
---
when
Mr
Pickwick
retired
to
the
bedroom
which
had
been
prepared
for
his
reception
.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
open
the
lattice
window
,
and
setting
his
light
upon
the
table
,
fell
into
a
train
of
meditation
on
the
hurried
events
of
the
two
preceding
days
.
   
<EOS>
The
hour
and
the
place
were
both
favourable
to
contemplation
;
Mr
Pickwick
was
roused
by
the
church
clock
striking
twelve
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
stroke
of
the
hour
sounded
solemnly
in
his
ear
,
but
when
the
bell
ceased
the
stillness
seemed
insupportable
---
he
almost
felt
as
if
he
had
lost
a
companion
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
nervous
and
excited
;
and
hastily
undressing
himself
and
placing
his
light
in
the
chimney
,
got
into
bed
.
   
<EOS>
Every
one
has
experienced
that
disagreeable
state
of
mind
,
in
which
a
sensation
of
bodily
weariness
in
vain
contends
against
an
inability
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Pickwick
's
condition
at
this
moment
:
he
tossed
first
on
one
side
and
then
on
the
other
;
and
perseveringly
closed
his
eyes
as
if
to
coax
himself
to
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
the
unwonted
exertion
he
had
undergone
,
or
the
heat
,
or
the
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
or
the
strange
bed
---
whatever
it
was
,
his
thoughts
kept
reverting
very
uncomfortably
to
the
grim
pictures
downstairs
,
and
the
old
stories
to
which
they
had
given
rise
in
the
course
of
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
After
half
an
hour
's
tumbling
about
,
he
came
to
the
unsatisfactory
conclusion
,
that
it
was
of
no
use
trying
to
sleep
;
so
he
got
up
and
partially
dressed
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
,
he
thought
,
was
better
than
lying
there
fancying
all
kinds
of
horrors
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
out
of
the
window
<EOS>
---
it
was
very
dark
.
 
<EOS>
He
walked
about
the
room
<EOS>
---
it
was
very
lonely
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
taken
a
few
turns
from
the
door
to
the
window
,
and
from
the
window
to
the
door
,
when
the
clergyman
's
manuscript
for
the
first
time
entered
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
good
thought
.
 
<EOS>
if
it
failed
to
interest
him
,
it
might
send
him
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
it
from
his
coat
pocket
,
and
drawing
a
small
table
towards
his
bedside
,
trimmed
the
light
,
put
on
his
spectacles
,
and
composed
himself
to
read
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
strange
handwriting
,
and
the
paper
was
much
soiled
and
blotted
.
 
<EOS>
The
title
gave
him
a
sudden
start
,
too
;
and
he
could
not
avoid
casting
a
wistful
glance
round
the
room
.
<EOS>
Reflecting
on
the
absurdity
of
giving
way
to
such
feelings
,
however
,
he
trimmed
the
light
again
,
and
read
as
follows
:
---
     
A
MADMAN
'S
MANUSCRIPT
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
---
<EOS>
a
madman
's
!
 
<EOS>
How
that
word
would
have
struck
to
my
heart
,
many
years
ago
!
 
<EOS>
How
it
would
have
roused
the
terror
that
used
to
come
upon
me
sometimes
,
sending
the
blood
hissing
and
tingling
through
my
veins
,
till
the
cold
dew
of
fear
stood
in
large
drops
upon
my
skin
,
and
my
knees
knocked
together
with
fright
!
 
<EOS>
I
like
it
now
though
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
fine
name
.
 
<EOS>
Show
me
the
monarch
whose
angry
frown
was
ever
feared
like
the
glare
of
a
madman
's
eye
---
whose
cord
and
axe
were
ever
half
so
sure
as
a
madman
's
gripe
.
 
<EOS>
Ho
!
<EOS>
ho
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
grand
thing
to
be
mad
!
<EOS>
to
be
peeped
at
like
a
wild
lion
through
the
iron
bars
---
to
gnash
one
's
teeth
and
howl
,
through
the
long
still
night
,
to
the
merry
ring
of
a
heavy
chain
and
to
roll
and
twine
among
the
straw
,
transported
with
such
brave
music
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
for
the
madhouse
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
's
a
rare
place
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
days
when
I
was
afraid
of
being
mad
;
when
I
used
to
start
from
my
sleep
,
and
fall
upon
my
knees
,
and
pray
to
be
spared
from
the
curse
of
my
race
;
when
I
rushed
from
the
sight
of
merriment
or
happiness
,
to
hide
myself
in
some
lonely
place
,
and
spend
the
weary
hours
in
watching
the
progress
of
the
fever
that
was
to
consume
my
brain
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
madness
was
mixed
up
with
my
very
blood
,
and
the
marrow
of
my
bones
!
<EOS>
that
one
generation
had
passed
away
without
the
pestilence
appearing
among
them
,
and
that
I
was
the
first
in
whom
it
would
revive
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
it
must
be
so
:
<EOS>
that
so
it
always
had
been
,
and
so
it
ever
would
be
:
<EOS>
and
when
I
cowered
in
some
obscure
corner
of
a
crowded
room
,
and
saw
men
whisper
,
and
point
,
and
turn
their
eyes
towards
me
,
I
knew
they
were
telling
each
other
of
the
doomed
madman
;
and
I
slunk
away
again
to
mope
in
solitude
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
this
for
years
;
long
,
long
years
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
The
nights
here
are
long
sometimes
---
very
long
;
but
they
are
nothing
to
the
restless
nights
,
and
dreadful
dreams
I
had
at
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
makes
me
cold
to
remember
them
.
 
<EOS>
Large
dusky
forms
with
sly
and
jeering
faces
crouched
in
the
corners
of
the
room
,
and
bent
over
my
bed
at
night
,
tempting
me
to
madness
.
 
<EOS>
They
told
me
in
low
whispers
,
that
the
floor
of
the
old
house
in
which
my
father
died
,
was
stained
with
his
own
blood
,
shed
by
his
own
hand
in
raging
madness
.
 
<EOS>
I
drove
my
fingers
into
my
ears
,
but
they
screamed
into
my
head
till
the
room
rang
with
it
,
that
in
one
generation
before
him
the
madness
slumbered
,
but
that
his
grandfather
had
lived
for
years
with
his
hands
fettered
to
the
ground
,
to
prevent
his
tearing
himself
to
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
they
told
the
truth
---
I
knew
it
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
found
it
out
years
before
,
though
they
had
tried
to
keep
it
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
too
cunning
for
them
,
madman
as
they
thought
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
last
it
came
upon
me
,
and
I
wondered
how
I
could
ever
have
feared
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
go
into
the
world
now
,
and
laugh
and
shout
with
the
best
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
I
was
mad
,
but
they
did
not
even
suspect
it
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
used
to
hug
myself
with
delight
,
when
I
thought
of
the
fine
trick
I
was
playing
them
after
their
old
pointing
and
leering
,
when
I
was
not
mad
,
but
only
dreading
that
I
might
one
day
become
so
!
 
<EOS>
And
how
I
used
to
laugh
for
joy
,
when
I
was
alone
,
and
thought
how
well
I
kept
my
secret
,
and
how
quickly
my
kind
friends
would
have
fallen
from
me
,
if
they
had
known
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
screamed
with
ecstasy
when
I
dined
alone
with
some
fine
roaring
fellow
,
to
think
how
pale
he
would
have
turned
,
and
how
fast
he
would
have
run
,
if
he
had
known
that
the
dear
friend
who
sat
close
to
him
,
sharpening
a
bright
,
glittering
knife
,
was
a
madman
with
all
the
power
,
and
half
the
will
,
to
plunge
it
in
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
was
a
merry
life
!
   
<EOS>
"
Riches
became
mine
,
wealth
poured
in
upon
me
,
and
I
rioted
in
pleasures
enhanced
a
thousandfold
to
me
by
the
consciousness
of
my
well
-
kept
secret
.
 
<EOS>
I
inherited
an
estate
.
 
<EOS>
The
law
---
the
eagle
-
eyed
law
itself
---
had
been
deceived
,
and
had
handed
over
disputed
thousands
to
a
madman
's
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Where
was
the
wit
of
the
sharp
-
sighted
men
of
sound
mind
?
 
<EOS>
Where
the
dexterity
of
the
lawyers
,
eager
to
discover
a
flaw
?
 
<EOS>
The
madman
's
cunning
had
overreached
them
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
money
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
was
courted
!
 
<EOS>
I
spent
it
profusely
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
was
praised
!
 
<EOS>
How
those
three
proud
,
overbearing
brothers
humbled
themselves
before
me
!
 
<EOS>
The
old
,
white
-
headed
father
,
too
---
such
deference
---
<EOS>
such
respect
---
such
devoted
friendship
<EOS>
---
he
worshipped
me
!
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
had
a
daughter
,
and
the
young
men
a
sister
;
and
all
the
five
were
poor
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
rich
;
and
when
I
married
the
girl
,
I
saw
a
smile
of
triumph
play
upon
the
faces
of
her
needy
relatives
,
as
they
thought
of
their
well
-
planned
scheme
,
and
their
fine
prize
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
for
me
to
smile
.
 
<EOS>
To
smile
!
 
<EOS>
To
laugh
outright
,
and
tear
my
hair
,
and
roll
upon
the
ground
with
shrieks
of
merriment
.
 
<EOS>
They
little
thought
they
had
married
her
to
a
madman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
had
known
it
,
would
they
have
saved
her
?
 
<EOS>
A
sister
's
happiness
against
her
husband
's
gold
.
 
<EOS>
The
lightest
feather
I
blow
into
the
air
,
against
the
gay
chain
that
ornaments
my
body
!
   
<EOS>
"
In
one
thing
I
was
deceived
with
all
my
cunning
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
not
been
mad
---
for
though
we
madmen
are
sharp
-
witted
enough
,
we
get
bewildered
sometimes
---
I
should
have
known
that
the
girl
would
rather
have
been
placed
,
stiff
and
cold
in
a
dull
leaden
coffin
,
than
borne
an
envied
bride
to
my
rich
,
glittering
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
known
that
her
heart
was
with
the
dark
-
eyed
boy
whose
name
I
once
heard
her
breathe
in
her
troubled
sleep
;
and
that
she
had
been
sacrificed
to
me
,
to
relieve
the
poverty
of
the
old
,
white
-
headed
man
and
the
haughty
brothers
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
remember
forms
or
faces
now
,
but
I
know
the
girl
was
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
she
was
;
for
in
the
bright
moonlight
nights
,
when
I
start
up
from
my
sleep
,
and
all
is
quiet
about
me
,
I
see
,
standing
still
and
motionless
in
one
corner
of
this
cell
,
a
slight
and
wasted
figure
with
long
black
hair
,
which
,
streaming
down
her
back
,
stirs
with
no
earthly
wind
,
and
eyes
that
fix
their
gaze
on
me
,
and
never
wink
or
close
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
<EOS>
the
blood
chills
at
my
heart
as
I
write
it
down
<EOS>
---
that
form
is
HERS
;
the
face
is
very
pale
,
and
the
eyes
are
glassy
bright
;
but
I
know
them
well
.
 
<EOS>
That
figure
never
moves
;
it
never
frowns
and
mouths
as
others
do
,
<EOS>
that
fill
this
place
sometimes
;
but
it
is
much
more
dreadful
to
me
,
even
than
the
spirits
that
tempted
me
many
years
ago
<EOS>
---
it
comes
fresh
from
the
grave
;
and
is
so
very
death
-
like
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
nearly
a
year
I
saw
that
face
grow
paler
;
for
nearly
a
year
I
saw
the
tears
steal
down
the
mournful
cheeks
,
and
never
knew
the
cause
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
it
out
at
last
though
.
 
<EOS>
They
could
not
keep
it
from
me
long
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
never
liked
me
;
I
had
never
thought
she
did
:
she
despised
my
wealth
,
and
hated
the
splendour
in
which
she
lived
;
but
I
had
not
expected
that
.
 
<EOS>
She
loved
another
.
 
<EOS>
This
I
had
never
thought
of
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
feelings
came
over
me
,
and
thoughts
,
forced
upon
me
by
some
secret
power
,
whirled
round
and
round
my
brain
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
hate
her
,
though
I
hated
the
boy
she
still
wept
for
.
 
<EOS>
I
pitied
---
<EOS>
yes
,
I
pitied
---
<EOS>
the
wretched
life
to
which
her
cold
and
selfish
relations
had
doomed
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
she
could
not
live
long
;
but
the
thought
that
before
her
death
she
might
give
birth
to
some
ill
-
fated
being
,
destined
to
hand
down
madness
to
its
offspring
,
determined
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
resolved
to
kill
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
many
weeks
I
thought
of
poison
,
and
then
of
drowning
,
and
then
of
fire
.
 
<EOS>
A
fine
sight
,
the
grand
house
in
flames
,
and
the
madman
's
wife
smouldering
away
to
cinders
.
 
<EOS>
Think
of
the
jest
of
a
large
reward
,
too
,
and
of
some
sane
man
swinging
in
the
wind
for
a
deed
he
never
did
,
and
all
through
a
madman
's
cunning
!
<EOS>
I
thought
often
of
this
,
but
I
gave
it
up
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
the
pleasure
of
stropping
the
razor
day
after
day
,
feeling
the
sharp
edge
,
and
thinking
of
the
gash
one
stroke
of
its
thin
,
bright
edge
would
make
!
"
<EOS>
At
last
the
old
spirits
who
had
been
with
me
so
often
before
whispered
in
my
ear
that
the
time
was
come
,
and
thrust
the
open
razor
into
my
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
grasped
it
firmly
,
rose
softly
from
the
bed
,
and
leaned
over
my
sleeping
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
buried
in
her
hands
.
 
<EOS>
I
withdrew
them
softly
,
and
they
fell
listlessly
on
her
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
weeping
;
for
the
traces
of
the
tears
were
still
wet
upon
her
cheek
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
calm
and
placid
;
and
even
as
I
looked
upon
it
,
a
tranquil
smile
lighted
up
her
pale
features
.
<EOS>
I
laid
my
hand
softly
on
her
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
She
started
---
it
was
only
a
passing
dream
.
 
<EOS>
I
leaned
forward
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
screamed
,
and
woke
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
motion
of
my
hand
,
and
she
would
never
again
have
uttered
cry
or
sound
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
startled
,
and
drew
back
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
fixed
on
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
not
how
it
was
,
but
they
cowed
and
frightened
me
;
and
I
quailed
beneath
them
.
 
<EOS>
She
rose
from
the
bed
,
still
gazing
fixedly
and
steadily
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
trembled
;
the
razor
was
in
my
hand
,
but
I
could
not
move
.
 
<EOS>
She
made
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
As
she
neared
it
,
she
turned
,
and
withdrew
her
eyes
from
my
face
.
<EOS>
The
spell
was
broken
.
 
<EOS>
I
bounded
forward
,
and
clutched
her
by
the
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Uttering
shriek
upon
shriek
<EOS>
,
she
sank
upon
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
could
have
killed
her
without
a
struggle
;
but
the
house
was
alarmed
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
the
tread
of
footsteps
on
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
replaced
the
razor
in
its
usual
drawer
,
unfastened
the
door
,
and
called
loudly
for
assistance
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
came
,
and
raised
her
,
and
placed
her
on
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
She
lay
bereft
of
animation
for
hours
;
and
when
life
,
look
,
and
speech
returned
,
her
senses
had
deserted
her
,
and
she
raved
wildly
and
furiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Doctors
were
called
in
---
great
men
who
rolled
up
to
my
door
in
easy
carriages
,
with
fine
horses
and
gaudy
servants
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
at
her
bedside
for
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
a
great
meeting
and
consulted
together
in
low
and
solemn
voices
in
another
room
.
 
<EOS>
One
,
the
cleverest
and
most
celebrated
among
them
,
took
me
aside
,
and
bidding
me
prepare
for
the
worst
,
told
me
---
me
,
the
madman
!
---
that
my
wife
was
mad
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
close
beside
me
at
an
open
window
,
his
eyes
looking
in
my
face
,
and
his
hand
laid
upon
my
arm
.
 
<EOS>
With
one
effort
,
I
could
have
hurled
him
into
the
street
beneath
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
rare
sport
to
have
done
it
;
but
my
secret
was
at
stake
,
and
I
let
him
go
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
days
after
,
they
told
me
I
must
place
her
under
some

:
I
must
provide
a
keeper
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
!
 
<EOS>
I
went
into
the
open
fields
where
none
could
hear
me
,
and
laughed
till
the
air
resounded
with
my
shouts
!
   
<EOS>
"
She
died
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
white

old
man
followed
her
to
the
grave
,
and
the
proud
brothers
dropped
a

the
insensible

of
her
whose

they
had
regarded
in
her
lifetime
with
muscles
of
iron
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
food
for
my
secret
mirth
,
and
I
laughed
behind
the
white
handkerchief
which
I
held
up
to
my
face
,
as
we

,
till
the
tears

into

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
though
I
had
carried
my
object
and
killed
her
,
I
was
restless
and
disturbed
,
and
I
felt
that
before
long
my
secret
must
be
known
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
hide
the
wild

and

which
boiled

,
and
made
me
when
I
was
alone
,
at

,
jump

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

went

,
and
saw

about

;
or
to
the
theatre
,
and

,
and

,
that
I
could
have
rushed

,
and
torn

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
ground

,
and
struck

upon
the

,
and
drove
my
sharp

into

.
 
<EOS>
I
kept

down
;
and
no

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
---
though

's
one

last

:
for
now
I
mix

realities
with
my

,
and

so

,

,

,
from

they

involved
 
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
see

and

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

think

.
 
<EOS>
There
---

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
could

,
only
there

long

here
with
many
doors

---

;

.
 
<EOS>
They

I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Let

:
yes
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
It

late

when
I

,
and

---
urgent
business
<EOS>
he

:
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

's

.
 
<EOS>
Many

.
 
<EOS>
They

he

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
word
to

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
late
,

---
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

little

---
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
My

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Coupling

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
It

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
This

---

,

!
 
<EOS>
This

had

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

man
who
had

his
sister
to
we

;
<EOS>
well

her

that

.
 
<EOS>
Due
to
his
uniform
!
 
<EOS>
The
livery
of

!
 
<EOS>
I
turned

upon

---
<EOS>
I
could

---
but
I
spoke
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
the

that
came

beneath

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
bold

,
but
the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
dragged
mine

to

;
and
I
laughed
<EOS>
---
I
was
very
merry

---
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
afraid
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
were
very
fond
of
your
sister
when
she
was

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
---
"
Very
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,
and
I

;
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You

,
"
said

,
<EOS>
"
I
found

out
:
<EOS>
I

;
I
know
her

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
<EOS>
---
I
know

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
jumped

,
brandished
it

,
and
bid

stand

---
for
I
took

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
for
I

through

,
and

.
   
"
<EOS>
"
Damn

,
"
said

,

,

;
"
I
killed

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

madman
.
 
<EOS>
Down

.
 
<EOS>
Blood
,
blood
!
 
<EOS>
I
will

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
turned

with
one

the
chair
he

me
in

,
and
closed

;
and

.
<EOS>
"
It

a

for
he

,

;
and
I
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
no
strength
could
equal

,
and
I

.
 
<EOS>
Right

,
though

!
 
<EOS>
His

grew

.
<EOS>
I
knelt

,

clasped

.
 
<EOS>
His

;
his
eyes
were
starting

,
and
with

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
I
squeezed
the
tighter
.
<EOS>
"
The
door
was
suddenly
burst
open
with
a

,
and
a

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
secret
was
out
;
and
my
only

now
was

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
gained

feet
before
a

was

,
threw

,
and

with
my
strong

,
as

bore

hatchet
in

,
and
hewed

.
 
<EOS>
I
gained
the
door
,
dropped
over
the
banisters
,
and
in
an
instant
was
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
Straight
and
swift
I
ran
,
and
no
one
dared
to
stop
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
the
noise
of
the
feet
behind
,
and
redoubled
my
speed
.
 
<EOS>
It
grew
fainter
and
fainter
in
the

,
and
at
length
died
away
altogether
;
but
on
I
bounded
,
through
marsh

,
over

and

,
with
a

which
was

that
flocked

on

,
and
swelled

,
till
it
pierced
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
borne
upon
the
arms
of
demons
who
swept
along
upon
the
wind
,
and
bore
down
bank
and
hedge
before
them
,
and
spun
me
round
and
round
with
a

and
a
speed
that
made
my
head
swim
,
until
at
last
they
threw
me
from

with

,
and
I
fell
heavily
upon
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
woke
I
found
myself
here
---
here
in
this
gray
cell
,
where
the
sunlight
seldom
comes
,
and
the
moon
steals
in
,
in
rays
which
only
serve
to
show
the
dark
shadows
about
me
,
and
that
silent
figure
in
its
old
corner
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
lie
awake
,
I
can
sometimes
hear
strange

and
