from
distant
parts
of
this
large
place
.
 
<EOS>
What
they
are
,
I
know
not
;
but
they
neither
come
from
that
pale
form
,
nor
does
it
regard
them
.
 
<EOS>
For
from
the
first
shades
of
dusk
till
the
earliest
light
of
morning
,
it
still
stands
motionless
in
the
same
place
,
listening
to
the
music
of
my
iron
chain
,
and
watching
my
gambols
on
my
straw
bed
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
the
manuscript
was
written
,
in
another
hand
,
this
note
:
---
   
<EOS>
[
The
unhappy
man
whose
ravings
are
recorded
above
,
was
a
melancholy
instance
of
the
baneful
results
of
energies
misdirected
in
early
life
,
and
excesses
prolonged
until
their
consequences
could
never
be
repaired
.
 
<EOS>
The
thoughtless
riot
,
dissipation
,
and
debauchery
of
his
younger
days
produced
fever
and
delirium
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
effects
of
the
latter
was
the
strange
delusion
,
founded
upon
a
well
-
known
medical
theory
,
strongly
contended
for
by
some
,
and
as
strongly
contested
by
others
,
that
an
hereditary
madness
existed
in
his
family
.
 
<EOS>
This
produced
a
settled
gloom
,
which
in
time
developed
a
morbid
insanity
,
and
finally
terminated
in
raving
madness
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
every
reason
to
believe
that
the
events
he
detailed
,
though
distorted
in
the
description
by
his
diseased
imagination
,
really
happened
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
only
matter
of
wonder
to
those
who
were
acquainted
with
the
vices
of
his
early
career
,
that
his
passions
,
when
no
longer
controlled
by
reason
,
did
not
lead
him
to
the
commission
of
still
more
frightful
deeds
.
]
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
candle
was
just
expiring
in
the
socket
,
as
he
concluded
the
perusal
of
the
old
clergyman
's
manuscript
;
and
when
the
light
went
suddenly
out
,
without
any
previous
flicker
by
way
of
warning
,
it
communicated
a
very
considerable
start
to
his
excited
frame
.
 
<EOS>
Hastily
throwing
off
such
articles
of
clothing
as
he
had
put
on
when
he
rose
from
his
uneasy
bed
,
and
casting
a
fearful
glance
around
,
he
once
more
scrambled
hastily
between
the
sheets
,
and
soon
fell
fast
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
The
sun
was
shining
brilliantly
into
his
chamber
,
when
he
awoke
,
and
the
morning
was
far
advanced
.
 
<EOS>
The
gloom
which
had
oppressed
him
on
the
previous
night
had
disappeared
with
the
dark
shadows
which
shrouded
the
landscape
,
and
his
thoughts
and
feelings
were
as
light
and
gay
as
the
morning
itself
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
hearty
breakfast
,
the
four
gentlemen
sallied
forth
to
walk
to
Gravesend
,
followed
by
a
man
bearing
the
stone
in
its
deal
box
.
<EOS>
They
reached
the
town
about
one
o'clock
(
<EOS>
their
luggage
they
had
directed
to
be
forwarded
to
the
city
,
from
Rochester
)
,
and
being
fortunate
enough
to
secure
places
on
the
outside
of
a
coach
,
arrived
in
London
in
sound
health
and
spirits
,
on
that
same
afternoon
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
three
or
four
days
were
occupied
with
the
preparations
which
were
necessary
for
their
journey
to
the
borough
of
Eatanswill
.
 
<EOS>
As
any
references
to
that
most
important
undertaking
demands
a
separate
chapter
,
we
may
devote
the
few
lines
which
remain
at
the
close
of
this
,
to
narrate
,
with
great
brevity
,
the
history
of
the
antiquarian
discovery
.
   
<EOS>
It
appears
from
the
Transactions
of
the
Club
,
then
,
that
Mr
Pickwick
lectured
upon
the
discovery
at
a
General
Club
Meeting
,
convened
on
the
night
succeeding
their
return
,
and
entered
into
a
variety
of
ingenious
and
erudite
speculations
on
the
meaning
of
the
inscription
.
 
<EOS>
It
also
appears
that
a
skilful
artist
executed
a
faithful
delineation
of
the
curiosity
,
which
was
engraven
on
stone
,
and
presented
to
the
Royal
Antiquarian
Society
,
and
other
learned
bodies
:
that
heart
-
burnings
and
jealousies
without
number
were
created
by
rival
controversies
which
were
penned
upon
the
subject
;
and
that
Mr
Pickwick
himself
wrote
a
pamphlet
,
containing
ninety
-
six
pages
of
very
small
print
,
and
twenty
-
seven
different
readings
of
the
inscription
:
that
three
old
gentlemen
cut
off
their
eldest
sons
with
a
shilling
a
-
piece
for
presuming
to
doubt
the
antiquity
of
the
fragment
;
and
that
one
enthusiastic
individual
cut
himself
off
prematurely
,
in
despair
at
being
unable
to
fathom
its
meaning
:
that
Mr
Pickwick
was
elected
an
honorary
member
of
seventeen
native
and
foreign
societies
,
for
making
the
discovery
:
that
none
of
the
seventeen
could
make
anything
of
it
;
but
that
all
the
seventeen
agreed
it
was
very
extraordinary
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blotton
,
indeed
---
and
the
name
will
be
doomed
to
the
undying
contempt
of
those
who
cultivate
the
mysterious
and
the
sublime
---
Mr
Blotton
,
we
say
,
with
the
doubt
and
cavilling
peculiar
to
vulgar
minds
,
presumed
to
state
a
view
of
the
case
,
as
degrading
as
ridiculous
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Blotton
,
with
a
mean
desire
to
tarnish
the
lustre
of
the
immortal
name
of
Pickwick
,
actually
undertook
a
journey
to
Cobham
in
person
,
and
on
his
return
,
sarcastically
observed
in
an
oration
at
the
club
,
that
he
had
seen
the
man
from
whom
the
stone
was
purchased
;
that
the
man
presumed
the
stone
to
be
ancient
,
but
solemnly
denied
the
antiquity
of
the
inscription
---
inasmuch
as
he
represented
it
to
have
been
rudely
carved
by
himself
in
an
idle
mood
,
and
to
display
letters
intended
to
bear
neither
more
or
less
than
the
simple
construction
of
---
"
BILL
STUMPS
,
HIS
MARK
"
;
and
that
Mr
Stumps
,
being
little
in
the
habit
of
original
composition
,
and
more
accustomed
to
be
guided
by
the
sound
of
words
than
by
the
strict
rules
of
orthography
,
had
omitted
the
concluding
"
L
"
of
his
Christian
name
.
   
<EOS>
The
Pickwick
Club
(
as
might
have
been
expected
from
so
enlightened
an
institution
)
received
this
statement
with
the
contempt
it
deserved
,
expelled
the
presumptuous
and
ill
-
conditioned
Blotton
from
the
society
,
and
voted
Mr
Pickwick
a
pair
of
gold
spectacles
,
in
token
of
their
confidence
and
approbation
:
in
return
for
which
,
Mr
Pickwick
caused
a
portrait
of
himself
to
be
painted
,
and
hung
up
in
the
club
room
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blotton
was
ejected
but
not
conquered
.
 
<EOS>
He
also
wrote
a
pamphlet
,
addressed
to
the
seventeen
learned
societies
,
native
and
foreign
,
containing
a
repetition
of
the
statement
he
had
already
made
,
and
rather
more
than
half
intimating
his
opinion
that
the
seventeen
learned
societies
were
so
many
"
humbugs
.
<EOS>
"
Hereupon
,
the
virtuous
indignation
of
the
seventeen
learned
societies
being
roused
,
several
fresh
pamphlets
appeared
;
the
foreign
learned
societies
corresponded
with
the
native
learned
societies
;
the
native
learned
societies
translated
the
pamphlets
of
the
foreign
learned
societies
into
English
;
the
foreign
learned
societies
translated
the
pamphlets
of
the
native
learned
societies
into
all
sorts
of
languages
;
and
thus
commenced
that
celebrated
scientific
discussion
so
well
known
to
all
men
,
as
the
Pickwick
controversy
.
   
<EOS>
But
this
base
attempt
to
injure
Mr
Pickwick
recoiled
upon
the
head
of
its
calumnious
author
.
 
<EOS>
The
seventeen
learned
societies
unanimously
voted
the
presumptuous
Blotton
an
ignorant
meddler
,
and
forthwith
set
to
work
upon
more
treatises
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
And
to
this
day
the
stone
remains
,
an
illegible
monument
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
greatness
,
and
a
lasting
trophy
to
the
littleness
of
his
enemies
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
12
.
<EOS>
Descriptive
of
a
very
important
proceeding
on
the
part
of
Mr
Pickwick
;
no
less
an
epoch
in
his
life
,
than
in
this
history
 
Mr
Pickwick
's
apartments
in
Goswell
Street
,
although
on
a
limited
scale
,
were
not
only
of
a
very
neat
and
comfortable
description
,
but
peculiarly
adapted
for
the
residence
of
a
man
of
his
genius
and
observation
.
 
<EOS>
His
sitting
-
room
was
the
first
-
floor
front
,
his
bedroom
<EOS>
the
second
-
floor
front
;
and
thus
,
whether
he
were
sitting
at
his
desk
in
his
parlour
,
or
standing
before
the
dressing
-
glass
in
his
dormitory
,
he
had
an
equal
opportunity
of
contemplating
human
nature
in
all
the
numerous
phases
it
exhibits
,
in
that
not
more
populous
than
popular
thoroughfare
.
 
<EOS>
His
landlady
,
Mrs
Bardell
---
the
relict
and
sole
executrix
of
a
deceased
custom
-
house
officer
---
was
a
comely
woman
of
bustling
manners
and
agreeable
appearance
,
with
a
natural
genius
for
cooking
,
improved
by
study
and
long
practice
,
into
an
exquisite
talent
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
no
children
,
no
servants
,
no
fowls
.
<EOS>
The
only
other
inmates
of
the
house
were
a
large
man
and
a
small
boy
;
the
first
a
lodger
,
the
second
a
production
of
Mrs
Bardell
's
.
 
<EOS>
The
large
man
was
always
home
precisely
at
ten
o'clock
at
night
,
at
which
hour
he
regularly
condensed
himself
into
the
limits
of
a
dwarfish
French
bedstead
in
the
back
parlour
;
and
the
infantine
sports
and
gymnastic
exercises
of
Master
Bardell
were
exclusively
confined
to
the
neighbouring
pavements
and
gutters
.
 
<EOS>
Cleanliness
and
quiet
reigned
throughout
the
house
;
and
in
it
Mr
Pickwick
's
will
was
law
.
   
<EOS>
To
any
one
acquainted
with
these
points
of
the
domestic
economy
of
the
establishment
,
and
conversant
with
the
admirable
regulation
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
mind
,
his
appearance
and
behaviour
on
the
morning
previous
to
that
which
had
been
fixed
upon
for
the
journey
to
Eatanswill
would
have
been
most
mysterious
and
unaccountable
.
 
<EOS>
He
paced
the
room
to
and
fro
with
hurried
steps
,
popped
his
head
out
of
the
window
at
intervals
of
about
three
minutes
each
,
constantly
referred
to
his
watch
,
and
exhibited
many
other
manifestations
of
impatience
very
unusual
with
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
evident
that
something
of
great
importance
was
in
contemplation
,
but
what
that
something
was
,
not
even
Mrs
Bardell
had
been
enabled
to
discover
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bardell
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
at
last
,
as
that
amiable
female
approached
the
termination
of
a
prolonged
dusting
of
the
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
little
boy
is
a
very
long
time
gone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
it
's
a
good
long
way
to
the
Borough
,
sir
,
"
remonstrated
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
very
true
;
so
it
is
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
relapsed
into
silence
,
and
Mrs
Bardell
resumed
her
dusting
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bardell
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
at
the
expiration
of
a
few
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
again
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
it
a
much
greater
expense
to
keep
two
people
,
than
to
keep
one
?
"
   
"
La
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
colouring
up
to
the
very
border
of
her
cap
,
as
she
fancied
she
observed
a
species
of
matrimonial
twinkle
in
the
eyes
of
her
lodger
;
"
La
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
what
a
question
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
but
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
depends
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
approaching
the
duster
very
near
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
elbow
which
was
planted
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
that
depends
a
good
deal
upon
the
person
,
you
know
,
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
whether
it
's
a
saving
and
careful
person
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
very
true
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
but
the
person
I
have
in
my
eye
(
here
he
looked
very
hard
at
Mrs
Bardell
)
<EOS>
I
think
possesses
these
qualities
;
and
has
,
moreover
,
a
considerable
knowledge
of
the
world
,
and
a
great
deal
of
sharpness
,
Mrs
Bardell
,
which
may
be
of
material
use
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
La
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
the
crimson
rising
to
her
cap
-
border
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
growing
energetic
,
as
was
his
wo
nt
in
speaking
of
a
subject
which
interested
him
---
"
I
do
,
indeed
;
and
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
Mrs
Bardell
,
I
have
made
up
my
mind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
sir
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
think
it
very
strange
now
,
"
said
the
amiable
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
good
-
humoured
glance
at
his
companion
,
"
that
I
never
consulted
you
about
this
matter
,
and
never
even
mentioned
it
,
till
I
sent
your
little
boy
out
this
morning
---
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
could
only
reply
by
a
look
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
long
worshipped
Mr
Pickwick
at
a
distance
,
but
here
she
was
,
all
at
once
,
raised
to
a
pinnacle
to
which
her
wildest
and
most
extravagant
hopes
had
never
dared
to
aspire
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
going
to
propose
---
a
deliberate
plan
,
too
---
sent
her
little
boy
to
the
Borough
,
to
get
him
out
of
the
way
---
how
thoughtful
---
how
considerate
!
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
what
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
trembling
with
agitation
,
"
you
're
very
kind
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
'll
save
you
a
good
deal
of
trouble
,
wo
n't
it
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
never
thought
anything
of
the
trouble
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Bardell
;
"
and
,
of
course
,
I
should
take
more
trouble
to
please
you
then
,
than
ever
;
but
it
is
so
kind
of
you
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
to
have
so
much
consideration
for
my
loneliness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
to
be
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
I
never
thought
of
that
.
<EOS>
When
I
am
in
town
,
you
'll
always
have
somebody
to
sit
with
you
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
so
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
ought
to
be
a
very
happy
woman
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
your
little
boy
---
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
his
heart
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Mrs
Bardell
,
with
a
maternal
sob
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
,
too
,
will
have
a
companion
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
a
lively
one
,
who
'll
teach
him
,
I
'll
be
bound
,
more
tricks
in
a
week
than
he
would
ever
learn
in
a
year
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Pickwick
smiled
placidly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
dear
---
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
started
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
kind
,
good
,
playful
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
;
and
without
more
ado
,
she
rose
from
her
chair
,
and
flung
her
arms
round
Mr
Pickwick
's
neck
,
with
a
cataract
of
tears
and
a
chorus
of
sobs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
,
"
cried
the
astonished
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
Mrs
Bardell
,
my
good
woman
---
<EOS>
dear
me
,
what
a
situation
---
pray
consider
.
<EOS>
---
Mrs
Bardell
,
do
n't
---
if
anybody
should
come
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
let
them
come
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Bardell
frantically
;
"
I
'll
never
leave
you
 
---
dear
,
kind
,
good
soul
;
"
and
,
with
these
words
,
Mrs
Bardell
clung
the
tighter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mercy
upon
me
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
struggling
violently
,
"
I
hear
somebody
coming
up
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
,
do
n't
,
there
's
a
good
creature
,
do
n't
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
entreaty
and
remonstrance
were
alike
unavailing
;
for
Mrs
Bardell
had
fainted
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
arms
;
and
before
he
could
gain
time
to
deposit
her
on
a
chair
,
Master
Bardell
entered
the
room
,
ushering
in
Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
struck
motionless
and
speechless
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
with
his
lovely
burden
in
his
arms
,
gazing
vacantly
on
the
countenances
of
his
friends
,
without
the
slightest
attempt
at
recognition
or
explanation
.
 
<EOS>
They
,
in
their
turn
,
stared
at
him
;
and
Master
Bardell
,
in
his
turn
,
stared
at
everybody
.
   
<EOS>
The
astonishment
of
the
Pickwickians
was
so
absorbing
,
and
the
perplexity
of
Mr
Pickwick
was
so
extreme
,
that
they
might
have
remained
in
exactly
the
same
relative
situations
until
the
suspended
animation
of
the
lady
was
restored
,
had
it
not
been
for
a
most
beautiful
and
touching
expression
of
filial
affection
on
the
part
of
her
youthful
son
.
 
<EOS>
Clad
in
a
tight
suit
of
corduroy
,
spangled
with
brass
buttons
of
a
very
considerable
size
,
he
at
first
stood
at
the
door
astounded
and
uncertain
;
but
by
degrees
,
the
impression
that
his
mother
must
have
suffered
some
personal
damage
pervaded
his
partially
developed
mind
,
and
considering
Mr
Pickwick
as
the
aggressor
,
he
set
up
an
appalling
and
semi
-
earthly
kind
of
howling
,
and
butting
forward
with
his
head
,
commenced
assailing
that
immortal
gentleman
about
the
back
and
legs
,
with
such
blows
and
pinches
as
the
strength
of
his
arm
,
and
the
violence
of
his
excitement
,
allowed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
this
little
villain
away
,
"
said
the
agonised
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
he
's
mad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
said
the
three
tongue
-
tied
Pickwickians
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
pettishly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
away
the
boy
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
Here
Mr
Winkle
carried
the
interesting
boy
,
screaming
and

,
to
the
farther
end
of
the
apartment
.
)
<EOS>
"
Now

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I

,
"

Mrs

.
   
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

---

;
"

.
<EOS>
And
downstairs

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
not

,
"

Pickwick
when

---
"
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Very

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Placed

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>
Queer

'

,

?
 
<EOS>
Up

?

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

an

;

.

<EOS>

.

"
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

"
out

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

.

"

.

.

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To

;

.
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

?

.

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>

this

,
if

,
"
said
Sam
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Call

eight
this

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
and

are

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
the
single
exception
of
one
amiable
indiscretion
,
in
which
an
assistant
housemaid
had
equally
participated
,
the
history
of
Mr
Weller
's
conduct
was
so
very
blameless
,
that
Mr
Pickwick
felt
fully
justified
in
closing
the
engagement
that
very
evening
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
promptness
and
energy
which
characterised
not
only
the
public
proceedings
,
but
all
the
private
actions
of
this
extraordinary
man
,
he
at
once
led
his
new
attendant
to
one
of
those
convenient
emporiums
where
gentlemen
's
new
and
second
-
hand
clothes
are
provided
,
and
the
troublesome
and
inconvenient
formality
of
measurement
dispensed
with
;
and
before
night
had
closed
in
,
Mr
Weller
was
furnished
with
a
grey
coat
with
the
P*C
button
,
a
black
hat
with
a
cockade
to
it
,
a
pink
striped
waistcoat
,
light
breeches
and
gaiters
,
and
a
variety
of
other
necessaries
,
too
numerous
to
recapitulate
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
that
suddenly
-
transformed
individual
,
as
he
took
his
seat
on
the
outside
of
the
Eatanswill
coach
next
morning
;
"
I
wonder
whether
I
'm
meant
to
be
a
footman
,
or
a
groom
,
or
a
gamekeeper
,
or
a
seedsman
.
 
<EOS>
I
looks
like
a
sort
of
compo
of
every
one
on
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
;
there
's
a
change
of
air
,
plenty
to
see
,
and
little
to
do
;
and
all
this
suits
my
complaint
uncommon
;
so
long
life
to
the
Pickvicks
,
says
I
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
Some
account
of
Eatanswill
;
of
the
state
of
parties
therein
;
and
of
the
election
of
a
member
to
serve
in
parliament
for
that
ancient
,
loyal
,
and
patriotic
borough
 
<EOS>
We
will
frankly
acknowledge
that
,
up
to
the
period
of
our
being
first
immersed
in
the
voluminous
papers
of
the
Pickwick
Club
,
we
had
never
heard
of
Eatanswill
;
we
will
with
equal
candour
admit
that
we
have
in
vain
searched
for
proof
of
the
actual
existence
of
such
a
place
at
the
present
day
.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
the
deep
reliance
to
be
placed
on
every
note
and
statement
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
,
and
not
presuming
to
set
up
our
recollection
against
the
recorded
declarations
of
that
great
man
,
we
have
consulted
every
authority
,
bearing
upon
the
subject
,
to
which
we
could
possibly
refer
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
traced
every
name
in
schedules
A
and
B
,
without
meeting
with
that
of
Eatanswill
;
we
have
minutely
examined
every
corner
of
the
pocket
county
maps
issued
for
the
benefit
of
society
by
our
distinguished
publishers
,
and
the
same
result
has
attended
our
investigation
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
therefore
led
to
believe
that
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
that
anxious
desire
to
abstain
from
giving
offence
to
any
,
and
with
those
delicate
feelings
for
which
all
who
knew
him
<EOS>
well
know
<EOS>
he
was
so
eminently
remarkable
,
purposely
substituted
a
fictitious
designation
,
for
the
real
name
of
the
place
in
which
his
observations
were
made
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
confirmed
in
this
belief
by
a
little
circumstance
,
apparently
slight
and
trivial
in
itself
,
but
when
considered
in
this
point
of
view
,
not
undeserving
of
notice
.
 
<EOS>
In
Mr
Pickwick
's
note
-
book
,
we
can
just
trace
an
entry
of
the
fact
,
that
the
places
of
himself
and
followers
were
booked
by
the
Norwich
coach
;
but
this
entry
was
afterwards
lined
through
,
as
if
for
the
purpose
of
concealing
even
the
direction
in
which
the
borough
is
situated
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
not
,
therefore
,
hazard
a
guess
upon
the
subject
,
but
will
at
once
proceed
with
this
history
,
content
with
the
materials
which
its
characters
have
provided
for
us
.
   
<EOS>
It
appears
,
then
,
that
the
Eatanswill
people
,
like
the
people
of
many
other
small
towns
,
considered
themselves
of
the
utmost
and
most
mighty
importance
,
and
that
every
man
in
Eatanswill
,
conscious
of
the
weight
that
attached
to
his
example
,
felt
himself
bound
to
unite
,
heart
and
soul
,
with
one
of
the
two
great
parties
that
divided
the
town
---
the
Blues
and
the
Buffs
.
 
<EOS>
Now
the
Blues
lost
no
opportunity
of
opposing
the
Buffs
,
and
the
Buffs
lost
no
opportunity
of
opposing
the
Blues
;
and
the
consequence
was
,
that
whenever
the
Buffs
and
Blues
met
together
at
public
meeting
,
town
-
hall
,
fair
,
or
market
,
disputes
and
high
words
arose
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
dissensions
it
is
almost
superfluous
to
say
that
everything
in
Eatanswill
was
made
a
party
question
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
Buffs
proposed
to
new
skylight
the
market
-
place
,
the
Blues
got
up
public
meetings
,
and
denounced
the
proceeding
;
if
the
Blues
proposed
the
erection
of
an
additional
pump
in
the
High
Street
,
the
Buffs
rose
as
one
man
and
stood
aghast
at
the
enormity
.
<EOS>
There
were
Blue
shops
and
Buff
shops
,
Blue
inns
and
Buff
inns
---
there
was
a
Blue
aisle
and
a
Buff
aisle
in
the
very
church
itself
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
essentially
and
indispensably
necessary
that
each
of
these
powerful
parties
should
have
its
chosen
organ
and
representative
:
<EOS>
and
,
accordingly
,
there
were
two
newspapers
in
the
town
---
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
and
the
Eatanswill
INDEPENDENT
;
the
former
advocating
Blue
principles
,
and
the
latter
conducted
on
grounds
decidedly
Buff
.
 
<EOS>
Fine
newspapers
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
Such
leading
articles
,
and
such
spirited
attacks
!
---
<EOS>
"
Our
worthless
contemporary
,
the
GAZETTE
"
---
"
<EOS>
That
disgraceful
and
dastardly
journal
,
the
INDEPENDENT
"
---
"
That
false
and
scurrilous
print
,
the
INDEPENDENT
"
---
"
That
vile
and
slanderous
calumniator
,
the
GAZETTE
;
"
these
,
and
other
spirit
-
stirring
denunciations
,
were
strewn
plentifully
over
the
columns
of
each
,
in
every
number
,
and
excited
feelings
of
the
most
intense
delight
and
indignation
in
the
bosoms
of
the
townspeople
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
his
usual
foresight
and
sagacity
,
had
chosen
a
peculiarly
desirable
moment
for
his
visit
to
the
borough
.
 
<EOS>
Never
was
such
a
contest
known
.
 
<EOS>
The
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey
Hall
,
was
the
Blue
candidate
;
and
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esq
.
,
of
Fizkin
Lodge
,
near
Eatanswill
,
had
been
prevailed
upon
by
his
friends
to
stand
forward
on
the
Buff
interest
.
 
<EOS>
The
GAZETTE
warned
the
electors
of
Eatanswill
that
the
eyes
not
only
of
England
,
but
of
the
whole
civilised
world
,
were
upon
them
;
and
the
INDEPENDENT
imperatively
demanded
to
know
,
whether
the
constituency
of
Eatanswill
were
the
grand
fellows
they
had
always
taken
them
for
,
or
base
and
servile
tools
,
undeserving
alike
of
the
name
of
Englishmen
and
the
blessings
of
freedom
.
 
<EOS>
Never
had
such
a
commotion
agitated
the
town
before
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
late
in
the
evening
when
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
companions
,
assisted
by
Sam
,
dismounted
from
the
roof
of
the
Eatanswill
coach
.
 
<EOS>
Large
blue
silk
flags
were
flying
from
the
windows
of
the
Town
Arms
Inn
,
and
bills
were
posted
in
every
sash
,
intimating
,
in
gigantic
letters
,
that
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
's
committee
sat
there
daily
.
 
<EOS>
A
crowd
of
idlers
were
assembled
in
the
road
,
looking
at
a
hoarse
man
in
the
balcony
,
who
was
apparently
talking
himself
very
red
in
the
face
in
Mr
Slumkey
's
behalf
;
but
the
force
and
point
of
whose
arguments
were
somewhat
impaired
by
the
perpetual
beating
of
four
large
drums
which
Mr
Fizkin
's
committee
had
stationed
at
the
street
corner
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
busy
little
man
beside
him
,
though
,
who
took
off
his
hat
at
intervals
and
motioned
to
the
people
to
cheer
,
which
they
regularly
did
,
most
enthusiastically
;
and
as
the
red
-
faced
gentleman
went
on
talking
till
he
was
redder
in
the
face
than
ever
<EOS>
,
it
seemed
to
answer
his
purpose
quite
as
well
as
if
anybody
had
heard
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
Pickwickians
had
no
sooner
dismounted
than
they
were
surrounded
by
a
branch
mob
of
the
honest
and
independent
,
who
forthwith
set
up
three
deafening
cheers
,
which
being
responded
to
by
the
main
body
<EOS>
(
for
it
's
not
at
all
necessary
for
a
crowd
to
know
what
they
are
cheering
about
)
,
swelled
into
a
tremendous
roar
of
triumph
,
which
stopped
even
the
red
-
faced
man
in
the
balcony
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hurrah
!
"
shouted
the
mob
,
in
conclusion
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
cheer
more
,
"
screamed
the
little
fugleman
in
the
balcony
,
and
out
shouted
the
mob
again
,
as
if
lungs
were
cast
-
iron
,
with
steel
works
.
   
<EOS>
"
Slumkey
for
ever
!
"
<EOS>
roared
the
honest
and
independent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Slumkey
for
ever
!
"
echoed
Mr
Pickwick
,
taking
off
his
hat
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
Fizkin
!
"
roared
the
crowd
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
!
"
shouted
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
there
was
another
roaring
,
like
that
of
a
whole
menagerie
when
the
elephant
has
rung
the
bell
for
the
cold
meat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
Slumkey
?
"
whispered
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
the
same
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
ask
any
questions
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
always
best
on
these
occasions
to
do
what
the
mob
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
suppose
there
are
two
mobs
?
"
suggested
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shout
with
the
largest
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Volumes
could
not
have
said
more
.
   
<EOS>
They
entered
the
house
,
the
crowd
opening
right
and
left
to
let
them
pass
,
and
cheering
vociferously
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
object
of
consideration
was
to
secure
quarters
for
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
we
have
beds
here
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
summoning
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
man
;
"
afraid
we
're
full
,
sir
---
I
'll
inquire
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
Away
he
went
for
that
purpose
,
and
presently
returned
,
to
ask
whether
the
gentleman
were
"
Blue
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
neither
Mr
Pickwick
nor
his
companions
took
any
vital
interest
in
the
cause
of
either
candidate
,
the
question
was
rather
a
difficult
one
to
answer
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
dilemma
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
bethought
himself
of
his
new
friend
,
Mr
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
a
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Perker
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
;
Honourable
Mr
Samuel
Slumkey
's
agent
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
Blue
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
WE
are
Blue
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
but
observing
that
the
man
looked
rather
doubtful
at
this
accommodating
announcement
,
he
gave
him
his
card
,
and
desired
him
to
present
it
to
Mr
Perker
forthwith
,
if
he
should
happen
to
be
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
waiter
retired
;
and
reappearing
almost
immediately
with
a
request
that
Mr
Pickwick
would
follow
him
,
led
the
way
to
a
large
room
on
the
first
floor
,
where
,
seated
at
a
long
table
covered
with
books
and
papers
,
was
Mr
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
---
ah
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
said
the
little
man
,
advancing
to
meet
him
;
"
very
happy
to
see
you
,
my
dear
Sir
,
very
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
sit
down
.
<EOS>
So
you
have
carried
your
intention
into
effect
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
come
down
here
to
see
an
election
---
eh
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Spirited
contest
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
said
the
little
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
delighted
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
see
sturdy
patriotism
,
on
whatever
side
it
is
called
forth
---
and
so
it
's
a
spirited
contest
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said
the
little
man
,
"
very
much
so
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
opened
all
the
public
-
houses
in
the
place
,
and
left
our
adversary
nothing
but
the
beer
-
shops
-
masterly
stroke
of
policy
that
,
my
dear
Sir
,
eh
?
"
 
The
little
man
smiled
complacently
,
and
took
a
large
pinch
of
snuff
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
are
the
probabilities
as
to
the
result
of
the
contest
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
doubtful
,
my
dear
Sir
;
rather
doubtful
as
yet
,
"
replied
the
little
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fizkin
's
people
have
got
three
-
and
-
thirty
voters
in
the
lock
-
up
coach
-
house
at
the
White
Hart
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
coach
-
house
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
considerably
astonished
by
this
second
stroke
of
policy
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
keep
'em
locked
up
there
till
they
want
'
em
,
"
resumed
the
little
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
effect
of
that
is
,
you
see
,
to
prevent
our
getting
at
them
;
and
even
if
we
could
,
it
would
be
of
no
use
,
for
they
keep
them
very
drunk
on
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Smart
fellow
Fizkin
's
agent
---
very
smart
fellow
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
stared
,
but
said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
pretty
confident
,
though
,
"
said
Mr
Perker
,
sinking
his
voice
almost
to
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
had
a
little
tea
-
party
here
,
last
night
---
<EOS>
five
-
and
-
forty
women
,
my
dear
sir
---
and
gave
every
one
of
'em
<EOS>
a
green
parasol
<EOS>
when
she
went
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
parasol
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fact
,
my
dear
Sir
,
fact
.
 
Five
-
and
-
forty
green
parasols
,
at
seven
and
sixpence
a
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
All
women
like
finery
---
extraordinary
the
effect
of
those
parasols
.
 
<EOS>
Secured
all
their
husbands
,
and
half
their
brothers
---
beats
stockings
,
and
flannel
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
hollow
.
 
<EOS>
My
idea
,
my
dear
Sir
,
entirely
.
 
<EOS>
Hail
,
rain
,
or
sunshine
<EOS>
,
you
ca
n't
walk
half
a
dozen
yards
up
the
street
,
without
encountering
half
a
dozen
green
parasols
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
little
man
indulged
in
a
convulsion
of
mirth
,
which
was
only
checked
by
the
entrance
of
a
third
party
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
tall
,
thin
man
,
with
a
sandy
-
coloured
head
inclined
to
baldness
,
and
a
face
in
which
solemn
importance
was
blended
with
a
look
of
unfathomable
profundity
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
long
brown
surtout
,
with
a
black
cloth
waistcoat
,
and
drab
trousers
.
 
<EOS>
A
double
eyeglass
dangled
at
his
waistcoat
;
and
on
his
head
he
wore
a
very
low
-
crowned
hat
with
a
broad
brim
.
<EOS>
The
new
-
comer
was
introduced
to
Mr
Pickwick
as
Mr
Pott
,
the
editor
of
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
preliminary
remarks
,
Mr
Pott
turned
round
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
said
with
solemnity
---
   
<EOS>
"
This
contest
excites
great
interest
in
the
metropolis
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
it
does
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
which
I
have
reason
to
know
,
"
said
Pott
,
looking
towards
Mr
Perker
for
corroboration
---
"
<EOS>
to
which
I
have
reason
to
know
that
my
article
of
last
Saturday
in
some
degree
contributed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
doubt
of
it
,
"
said
the
little
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
press
is
a
mighty
engine
,
sir
,
"
said
Pott
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
yielded
his
fullest
assent
to
the
proposition
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
trust
,
sir
,
"
said
Pott
,
"
that
I
have
never
abused
the
enormous
power
I
wield
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
,
sir
,
that
I
have
never
pointed
the
noble
instrument
which
is
placed
in
my
hands
,
against
the
sacred
bosom
of
private
life
,
or
the
tender
breast
of
individual
reputation
;
I
trust
,
sir
,
that
I
have
devoted
my
energies
to
---
to
endeavours
---
<EOS>
humble
they
may
be
,
<EOS>
humble
<EOS>
I
know
they
are
---
to
instil
those
principles
of
---
which
---
are
---
"
   
Here
the
editor
of
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,
appearing
to
ramble
,
Mr
Pickwick
came
to
his
relief
,
and
said
---
   
"
Certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
,
Sir
,
"
said
Pott
---
"
what
,
Sir
,
let
me
ask
you
as
an
impartial
man
,
is
the
state
of
the
public
mind
in
London
,
with
reference
to
my
contest
with
the
INDEPENDENT
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Greatly
excited
,
no
doubt
,
"
interposed
Mr
Perker
,
with
a
look
of
slyness
which
was
very
likely
accidental
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
contest
,
"
said
Pott
,
"
shall
be
prolonged
so
long
as
I
have
health
and
strength
,
and
that
portion
of
talent
with
which
I
am
gifted
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
contest
,
Sir
,
although
it
may
unsettle
men
's
minds
and
excite
their
feelings
,
and
render
them
incapable
for
the
discharge
of
the
everyday
duties
of
ordinary
life
;
from
that
contest
,
sir
,
I
will
never
shrink
,
till
I
have
set
my
heel
upon
the
Eatanswill
INDEPENDENT
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
the
people
of
London
,
and
the
people
of
this
country
to
know
,
sir
,
that
they
may
rely
upon
me
 
---
that
I
will
not
desert
them
,
that
I
am
resolved
to
stand
by
them
,
Sir
,
to
the
last
.
"
<EOS>
"
Your
conduct
is
most
noble
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
he
grasped
the
hand
of
the
magnanimous
Pott
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
sir
,
I
perceive
,
a
man
of
sense
and
talent
,
"
said
Mr
Pott
,
almost
breathless
with
the
vehemence
of
his
patriotic
declaration
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
most
happy
,
sir
,
to
make
the
acquaintance
of
such
a
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
feel
deeply
honoured
by
this
expression
of
your
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
,
sir
,
to
introduce
you
to
my
fellow
-
travellers
,
the
other
corresponding
members
of
the
club
I
am
proud
to
have
founded
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
delighted
,
"
said
Mr
Pott
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
withdrew
,
and
returning
with
his
friends
,
presented
them
in
due
form
to
the
editor
of
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
Pott
,
"
said
little
Mr
Perker
,
"
the
question
is
,
what
are
we
to
do
with
our
friends
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
can
stop
in
this
house
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
spare
bed
in
the
house
,
my
dear
sir
---
not
a
single
bed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Extremely
awkward
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
his
fellow
-
voyagers
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
an
idea
upon
this
subject
,
"
said
Mr
Pott
,
"
which
I
think
may
be
very
successfully
adopted
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
two
beds
at
the
Peacock
,
and
I
can
boldly
say
,
on
behalf
of
Mrs
Pott
,
that
she
will
be
delighted
to
accommodate
Mr
Pickwick
and
any
one
of
his
friends
,
if
the
other
two
gentlemen
and
their
servant
do
not
object
to
shifting
,
as
they
best
can
,
at
the
Peacock
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
repeated
pressings
on
the
part
of
Mr
Pott
,
and
repeated
protestations
on
that
of
Mr
Pickwick
that
he
could
not
think
of
incommoding
or
troubling
his
amiable
wife
,
it
was
decided
that
it
was
the
only
feasible
arrangement
that
could
be
made
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
WAS
made
;
and
after
dinner
together
at
the
Town
Arms
,
the
friends
separated
,
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
repairing
to
the
Peacock
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Winkle
<EOS>
proceeding
to
the
mansion
of
Mr
Pott
;
it
having
been
previously
arranged
that
they
should
all

at
the

in
the
morning
,
and

Samuel

to

of
nomination
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pott
's
domestic
circle
was
limited
to
himself
and
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
All
men
whom
mighty
genius
has
raised
to
a
proud
eminence
in
the
world
,
have
usually
some
little
weakness
which
appears
the
more
conspicuous
from
the
contrast
it
presents
to
their
general
character
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Pott
had
a
weakness
,
it
was
,
perhaps
,
that
he
was
rather
too
submissive
to
the
somewhat
contemptuous
control
and
sway
of
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
not
feel

any

upon

,
because

present

all
Mrs
Pott
's
most
winning

.

"
<EOS>

,
"

,
"
Mr

---
Mr
Pickwick

.
"

<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
We
have

Mr
Pickwick
's
note

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
We

he

the
style
;

Mr
Winkle

closed

Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Pott
was
in

highest

and

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
had

in
her

,

,

Mr
Pickwick
was
"
a

dear
.
<EOS>
"
These

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

,
as

of
the

in

was
held

,
and
the

to

.
   
<EOS>
It

night
---

Mr
Tupman

---

.
 
<EOS>

of
Mr
Winkle
,

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

but

.

like

your
horses
,
we
know
.
<EOS>
We
're
all
wery
fond
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>
you
,
Mr
Weller
,
so
in
case
you
should
have
an
accident
when
you
're
bringing
these
here
<EOS>
woters
down
,
and
should
tip
'em
over
into
the
canal
vithout
hurtin
'
of
'em
<EOS>
,
this
is
for
yourself
,
"
says
he
.
<EOS>
---
"
Gen'l'm'n
,
you
're
wery
kind
,
"
says
my
father
,
"
and
I
'll
drink
your
health
in
another
glass
of
wine
,
"
says
he
;
vich
he
did
,
and
then
buttons
up
the
money
,
and
bows
himself
out
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't
believe
,
sir
,
"
continued
Sam
,
with
a
look
of
inexpressible
impudence
at
his
master
,
"
that
on
the
wery
day
as
he
came
down
with
them
woters
,
his
coach
WAS
upset
on
that
'
ere
wery
spot
,
and
ev'ry
man
on
'em
was
turned
into
the
canal
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
got
out
again
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
replied
Sam
very
slowly
,
"
I
rather
think
one
old
gen'l'm'n
was
missin
'
;
<EOS>
I
know
his
hat
was
found
,
but
I
ai
n't
quite
certain
whether
his
head
was
in
it
or
not
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
I
look
at
is
the
hex
-
traordinary
and
wonderful
coincidence
,
<EOS>
that
arter
what
that
gen'l'm'n
said
,
my
father
's
coach
should
be
upset
in
that
wery
place
,
and
on
that
wery
day
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
it
is
,
no
doubt
,
a
very
extraordinary
circumstance
indeed
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
brush
my
hat
,
Sam
,
for
I
hear
Mr
Winkle
calling
me
to
breakfast
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
Mr
Pickwick
descended
to
the
parlour
,
where
he
found
breakfast
laid
,
and
the
family
already
assembled
.
<EOS>
The
meal
was
hastily
despatched
;
each
of
the
gentlemen
's
hats
was
decorated
with
an
enormous
blue
favour
,
made
up
by
the
fair
hands
of
Mrs
Pott
herself
;
and
as
Mr
Winkle
had
undertaken
to
escort
that
lady
to
a
house
-
top
,
in
the
immediate
vicinity
of
the
hustings
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Pott
repaired
alone
to
the
Town
Arms
,
from
the
back
window
of
which
,
one
of
Mr
Slumkey
's
committee
was
addressing
six
small
boys
and
one
girl
,
whom
he
dignified
,
at
every
second
sentence
,
with
the
imposing
title
of
"
Men
of
Eatanswill
,
"
whereat
<EOS>
the
six
small
boys
aforesaid
cheered
prodigiously
.
   
<EOS>
The
stable
-
yard
exhibited
unequivocal
symptoms
of
the
glory
and
strength
of
the
Eatanswill
Blues
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
regular
army
of
blue
flags
,
some
with
one
handle
,
and
some
with
two
,
exhibiting
appropriate
devices
,
in
golden
characters
four
feet
high
,
and
stout
in
proportion
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
grand
band
of
trumpets
,
bassoons
,
and
drums
,
marshalled
four
abreast
,
and
earning
their
money
,
if
ever
men
did
,
especially
the
drum
-
beaters
,
who
were
very
muscular
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
bodies
of
constables
with
blue
staves
,
twenty
committee
-
men
with
blue
scarfs
,
and
a
mob
of
voters
with
blue
cockades
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
electors
on
horseback
and
electors
afoot
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
open
carriage
-
and
-
four
,
for
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
;
and
there
were
four
carriage
-
and
-
pair
,
for
his
friends
and
supporters
;
and
the
flags
were
rustling
,
and
the
band
was
playing
,
and
the
constables
were
swearing
,
and
the
twenty
committee
-
men
were
squabbling
,
and
the
mob
were
shouting
,
and
the
horses
were
backing
,
and
the
post
-
boys
perspiring
;
and
everybody
,
and
everything
,
then
and
there
assembled
,
was
for
the
special
use
,
behoof
,
honour
,
and
renown
,
of
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey
Hall
,
one
of
the
candidates
for
the
representation
of
the
borough
of
Eatanswill
,
in
the
Commons
House
of
Parliament
of
the
United
Kingdom
.
<EOS>
Loud
and
long
were
the
cheers
,
and
mighty
was
the
rustling
of
one
of
the
blue
flags
,
with
"
Liberty
of
the
Press
"
inscribed
thereon
,
when
the
sandy
head
of
Mr
Pott
was
discerned
in
one
of
the
windows
,
by
the
mob
beneath
;
and
tremendous
was
the
enthusiasm
when
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
himself
,
in
top
-
boots
,
and
a
blue
neckerchief
,
advanced
and
seized
the
hand
of
the
said
Pott
,
and
melodramatically
testified
by
gestures
to
the
crowd
,
his
ineffaceable
obligations
to
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
everything
ready
?
"
said
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
to
Mr
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Everything
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
was
the
little
man
's
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
has
been
omitted
,
I
hope
?
"
said
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
has
been
left
undone
,
my
dear
sir
---
nothing
whatever
.
<EOS>
There
are
twenty
washed
men
at
the
street
door
for
you
to
shake
hands
with
;
and
six
children
in
arms
that
you
're
to
pat
on
the
head
,
and
inquire
the
age
of
;
be
particular
about
the
children
,
my
dear
sir
---
it
has
always
a
great
effect
,
that
sort
of
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
,
"
said
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
perhaps
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
said
the
cautious
little
man
,
"
perhaps
if
you
could
---
I
do
n't
mean
to
say
it
's
indispensable
---
but
if
you
could
manage
to
kiss
one
of
'em
,
it
would
produce
a
very
great
impression
on
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Would
n't
it
have
as
good
an
effect
if
the
proposer
or
seconder
did
that
?
"
said
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
am
afraid
it
would
n't
,
"
replied
the
agent
;
"
if
it
were
done
by
yourself
,
my
dear
Sir
,
I
think
it
would
make
you
very
popular
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
with
a
resigned
air
,
"
then
it
must
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Arrange
the
procession
,
"
cried
the
twenty
committee
-
men
.
   
<EOS>
Amidst
the
cheers
of
the
assembled
throng
,
the
band
,
and
the
constables
,
and
the
committee
-
men
,
and
the
voters
,
and
the
horsemen
,
and
the
carriages
,
took
their
places
---
each
of
the
two
-
horse
vehicles
being
closely
packed
with
as
many
gentlemen
as
could
manage
to
stand
upright
in
it
;
and
that
assigned
to
Mr
Perker
,
containing
Mr
Pickwick
,
Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
about
half
a
dozen
of
the
committee
besides
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
moment
of
awful
suspense
as
the
procession
waited
for
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
to
step
into
his
carriage
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
the
crowd
set
up
a
great
cheering
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
come
out
,
"
said
little
Mr
Perker
,
greatly
excited
;
the
more
so
as
their
position
did
not
enable
them
to
see
what
was
going
forward
.
   
<EOS>
Another
cheer
,
much
louder
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
shaken
hands
with
the
men
,
"
cried
the
little
agent
.
   
<EOS>
Another
cheer
,
far
more
vehement
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
patted
the
babies
on
the
head
,
"
said
Mr
Perker
,
trembling
with
anxiety
.
   
<EOS>
A
roar
of
applause
that
rent
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
kissed
one
of
'
em
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
delighted
little
man
.
   
<EOS>
A
second
roar
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
kissed
another
,
"
gasped
the
excited
manager
.
   
<EOS>
A
third
roar
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
kissing
'em
all
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
the
enthusiastic
little
gentleman
,
and
hailed
by
the
deafening
shouts
of
the
multitude
,
the
procession
moved
on
.
   
<EOS>
How
or
by
what
means
it
became
mixed
up
with
the
other
procession
,
and
how
it
was
ever
extricated
from
the
confusion
consequent
thereupon
,
is
more
than
we
can
undertake
to
describe
,
inasmuch
as
Mr
Pickwick
's
hat
was
knocked
over
his
eyes
,
nose
,
and
mouth
,
by
one
poke
of
a
Buff
flag
-
staff
,
very
early
in
the
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
He
describes
himself
as
being
surrounded
on
every
side
,
when
he
could
catch
a
glimpse
of
the
scene
,
by
angry
and
ferocious
countenances
,
by
a
vast
cloud
of
dust
,
and
by
a
dense
crowd
of
combatants
.
 
<EOS>
He
represents
himself
as
being
forced
from
the
carriage
by
some
unseen
power
,
and
being
personally
engaged
in
a
pugilistic
encounter
;
but
with
whom
,
or
how
,
or
why
,
he
is
wholly
unable
to
state
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
felt
himself
forced
up
some
wooden
steps
by
the
persons
from
behind
;
and
on
removing
his
hat
,
found
himself
surrounded
by
his
friends
,
in
the
very
front
of
the
left
hand
side
of
the
hustings
.
 
<EOS>
The
right
was
reserved
for
the
Buff
party
,
and
the
centre
for
the
mayor
and
his
officers
;
one
of
whom
---
the
fat
crier
of
Eatanswill
---
was
ringing
an
enormous
bell
,
by
way
of
commanding
silence
,
while
Mr
Horatio
Fizkin
,
and
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
with
their
hands
upon
their
hearts
,
were
bowing
with
the
utmost
affability
to
the
troubled
sea
of
heads
that
inundated
the
open
space
in
front
;
and
from
whence
arose
a
storm
of
groans
,
and
shouts
,
and
yells
,
and
hootings
,
that
would
have
done
honour
to
an
earthquake
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
Winkle
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
pulling
his
friend
by
the
sleeve
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
putting
on
his
spectacles
,
which
he
had
fortunately
kept
in
his
pocket
hitherto
.
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
"
on
the
top
of
that
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
there
,
sure
enough
,
in
the
leaden
gutter
of
a
tiled
roof
,
were
Mr
Winkle
and
Mrs
Pott
,
comfortably
seated
in
a
couple
of
chairs
,
waving
their
handkerchiefs
in
token
of
recognition
---
a
compliment
which
Mr
Pickwick
returned
by
kissing
his
hand
to
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
The
proceedings
had
not
yet
commenced
;
and
as
an
inactive
crowd
is
generally
disposed
to
be
jocose
,
this
very
innocent
action
was
sufficient
to
awaken
their
facetiousness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
wicked
old
rascal
,
"
cried
one
voice
,
"
looking
arter
the
girls
,
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
wenerable
sinner
,
"
cried
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
Putting
on
his
spectacles
to
look
at
a
married
"
ooman
!
"
said
a
third
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
him
a
-
winkin
'
at
her
,
with
his
wicked
old
eye
,
"
shouted
a
fourth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
arter
your
wife
,
Pott
,
"
bellowed
a
fifth
---
and
then
there
was
a
roar
of
laughter
.
   
<EOS>
As
these
taunts
were
accompanied
with
invidious
comparisons
between
Mr
Pickwick
and
an
aged
ram
,
and
several
witticisms
of
the
like
nature
;
and
as
they
moreover
rather
tended
to
convey
reflections
upon
the
honour
of
an
innocent
lady
,
Mr
Pickwick
's
indignation
was
excessive
;
but
as
silence
was
proclaimed
at
the
moment
,
he
contented
himself
by
scorching
the
mob
with
a
look
of
pity
for
their
misguided
minds
,
at
which
they
laughed
more
boisterously
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
roared
the
mayor
's
attendants
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whiffin
,
proclaim
silence
,
"
said
the
mayor
,
with
an
air
of
pomp
befitting
his
lofty
station
.
 
<EOS>
In
obedience
to
this
command
the
crier
performed
another
concerto
on
the
bell
,
whereupon
<EOS>
a
gentleman
in
the
crowd
called
out
"
Muffins
"
;
which
occasioned
another
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
said
the
mayor
,
at
as
loud
a
pitch
as
he
could
possibly
force
his
voice
to
---
"
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
Brother
electors
of
the
borough
of
Eatanswill
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
met
here
to
-
day
for
the
purpose
of
choosing
a
representative
in
the
room
of
our
late
---
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
mayor
was
interrupted
by
a
voice
in
the
crowd
.
   
<EOS>
"
Suc
-
cess
to
the
mayor
!
"
cried
the
voice
,
"
and
may
he
never
desert
the
nail
and
sarspan
business
,
as
he
got
his
money
by
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
allusion
to
the
professional
pursuits
of
the
orator
was
received
with
a
storm
of
delight
,
which
,
with
a
bell
-
accompaniment
,
rendered
the
remainder
of
his
speech
inaudible
,
with
the
exception
of
the
concluding
sentence
,
in
which
he
thanked
the
meeting
for
the
patient
attention
with
which
they
heard
him
throughout
---
an
expression
of
gratitude
which
elicited
another
burst
of
mirth
,
of
about
a
quarter
of
an
hour
's
duration
.
   
<EOS>
Next
,
a
tall
,
thin
gentleman
,
in
a
very
stiff
white
neckerchief
,
after
being
repeatedly
desired
by
the
crowd
to
"
send
a
boy
home
,
to
ask
whether
he
had
n't
left
his
voice
under
the
pillow
,
"
begged
to
nominate
a
fit
and
proper
person
to
represent
them
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
And
when
he
said
it
was
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin
Lodge
,
near
Eatanswill
,
the
Fizkinites
applauded
,
and
the
Slumkeyites
groaned
,
so
long
,
and
so
loudly
,
that
both
he
and
the
seconder
might
have
sung
comic
songs
in
lieu
of
speaking
,
without
anybody
's
being
a
bit
the
wiser
.
   
<EOS>
The
friends
of
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
having
had
their
innings
,
a
little
choleric
,
pink
-
faced
man
stood
forward
to
propose
another
fit
and
proper
person
to
represent
the
electors
of
Eatanswill
in
Parliament
;
and
very
swimmingly
the
pink
-
faced
gentleman
would
have
got
on
,
if
he
had
not
been
rather
too
choleric
to
entertain
a
sufficient
perception
of
the
fun
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
But
after
a
very
few
sentences
of
figurative

,
the
pink
-
faced
gentleman
got
from
denouncing
those
who
interrupted
him
in
the
mob
,
to
exchanging
defiances
with
the
gentlemen
on
the
hustings
;
whereupon
arose
an
uproar
which
reduced
him
to
the
necessity
of
expressing
his
feelings
by
serious
pantomime
,
which
he
did
,
and
then
left
the
stage
to
his
seconder
,
who
delivered
a
written
speech
of
half
an
hour
's
length
,
and
would
n't
be
stopped
,
because
he
had
sent
it
all
to
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,
and
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
had
already
printed
it
,
every
word
.
   
<EOS>
Then
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin
Lodge
,
near
Eatanswill
,
presented
himself
for
the
purpose
of
addressing
the
electors
;
which
he
no
sooner

,
than
the
band
employed
by
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
commenced

with

to
which
their
strength
in
the
morning
was
a

;
in

for

,
the
Buff
crowd
belaboured
the

of
the
Blue

;
on
which

Blue

endeavoured
to
dispossess

of
their
very
unpleasant
neighbours
the
Buff
crowd
;
and
a
scene
of
struggling
,
and

,
and
fighting
,
succeeded
,
to
which
we
can
no
more
do
justice
than
the
mayor
<EOS>
could
,
although
he
issued
imperative
orders
to
twelve

to
seize

,
who
might
amount
in
number
to
two
hundred

,
or

.
 
<EOS>
At
all

,
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin
Lodge
,
and
his
friends
,
waxed
fierce

;
until

Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin

,

to

,
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey

,
whether
that
band
played

;
which

the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
declining

,
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin
Lodge
,
shook
his
fist
in
the

of
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey
Hall
;
upon

the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
his
blood
being
up
,
defied
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
to
mortal

.
 
<EOS>
At
this
violation
of
all
known
rules
and

of

,
the
mayor
commanded
another
fantasia
on
the
bell
,
and
declared
that
he
would
bring
before
himself
,
both
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin

,
and
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey
Hall
,
and
bind

over
to

.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
terrific

,
the
supporters
of
the
two
candidates
interfered
,
and
after
the
friends
of
each
party
had

in

,
for
three
-
quarters

an

,
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
touched
his
hat
to
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
;
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
touched
his
to
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
;
the
band
was
stopped
;
the
crowd
were
partially
quieted
;
and
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
was
permitted
to
proceed
.
   
<EOS>
The
speeches
of
the
two
candidates
,
though
differing
in
every
other
respect
,
afforded
a
beautiful
tribute
to
the
merit
and
high
worth
of
the
electors
of
Eatanswill
.
 
<EOS>
Both
expressed
their
opinion
that
a
more
independent
,
a
more
enlightened
,
a
more
public
-
spirited
,
a
more
noble
-
minded
,
a
more
disinterested
set
of
men
than
those
who
had
promised
to
vote
for
him
,
never
existed
on
earth
;
each
darkly
hinted
his
suspicions
that
the
electors
in
the
opposite
interest
had
certain
swinish
and
besotted
infirmities
which
rendered
them
unfit
for
the
exercise
of
the
important
duties
they
were
called
upon
to
discharge
.
 
<EOS>
Fizkin
expressed
his
readiness
to
do
anything
he
was
wanted
:
Slumkey
,
his
determination
to
do
nothing
that
was
asked
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Both
said
that
the
trade
,
the
manufactures
,
the
commerce
,
the
prosperity
of
Eatanswill
,
would
ever
be
dearer
to
their
hearts
than
any
earthly
object
;
and
each
had
it
in
his
power
to
state
,
with
the
utmost
confidence
,
that
he
was
the
man
who
would
eventually
be
returned
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
show
of
hands
;
the
mayor
decided
in
favour
of
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey
Hall
.
 
<EOS>
Horatio
Fizkin
,
Esquire
,
of
Fizkin
Lodge
,
demanded
a
poll
,
and
a
poll
was
fixed
accordingly
.
 
<EOS>
Then
a
vote
of
thanks
was
moved
to
the
mayor
for
his
able
conduct
in
the
chair
;
and
the

,
devoutly

that
he
had
had

chair
to
display
his
able
conduct
in
(
for
he
had
been
standing
during
the
whole

)
,
returned
thanks
.
<EOS>
The
processions
reformed
,
the
carriages
rolled
slowly
through
the
crowd
,
and
its
members
screeched
and
shouted
after
them
as
their
feelings
or
caprice
dictated
.
   
<EOS>
During
the
whole
time
of
the
polling
,
the
town
was
in
a
perpetual
fever
of
excitement
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
was
conducted
on
the
most
liberal
and
delightful
scale
.
 
<EOS>
Excisable
articles
were
remarkably
cheap
at
all
the
public
-
houses
;
and
spring
vans
paraded
the
streets
for
the
accommodation
of
voters
who
were
seized
with
any
temporary
dizziness
in
the
head
---
an
epidemic
which
prevailed
among
the
electors
,
during
the
contest
,
to
a
most
alarming
extent
,
and
under
the
influence
of
which
they
might
frequently
be
seen
lying
on
the
pavements
in
a
state
of
utter
insensibility
.
 
<EOS>
A
small
body
of
electors
remained
unpolled
on
the
very
last
day
.
<EOS>
They
were
calculating
and
reflecting
persons
,
who
had
not
yet
been
convinced
by
the
arguments
of
either
party
,
although
they
had
frequent
conferences
with
each
.
 
<EOS>
One
hour
before
the
close
of
the
poll
,
Mr
Perker
solicited
the
honour
of
a
private
interview
with
these
intelligent
,
these
noble
,
these
patriotic
men
.
 
<EOS>
it
was
granted
.
 
<EOS>
His
arguments
were
brief
but
satisfactory
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
in
a
body
to
the
poll
;
and
when
they
returned
,
the
Honourable
Samuel
Slumkey
,
of
Slumkey
Hall
,
was
returned
also
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
Comprising
a
brief
description
of
the
company
at
the
Peacock
assembled
;
and
a
tale
told
by
a
bagman
 
<EOS>
It
is
pleasant
to
turn
from
contemplating
the
strife
and
turmoil
of
political
existence
,
to
the
peaceful
repose
of
private
life
.
 
<EOS>
Although
in
reality
no
great
partisan
of
either
side
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
sufficiently
fired
with
Mr
Pott
's
enthusiasm
,
to
apply
his
whole
time
and
attention
to
the
proceedings
,
of
which
the
last
chapter
affords
a
description
compiled
from
his
own
memoranda
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
while
he
was
thus
occupied
was
Mr
Winkle
idle
,
his
whole
time
being
devoted
to
pleasant
walks
and
short
country
excursions
with
Mrs
Pott
,
who
never
failed
,
when
such
an
opportunity
presented
itself
,
to
seek
some
relief
from
the
tedious
monotony
she
so
constantly
complained
of
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
gentlemen
being
thus
completely
domesticated
in
the
editor
's
house
,
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
were
in
a
great
measure
cast
upon
their
own
resources
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
but
little
interest
in
public
affairs
,
they
beguiled
their
time
chiefly
with
such
amusements
as
the
Peacock
afforded
,
which
were
limited
to
a
bagatelle
-
board
in
the
first
floor
,
and
a
sequestered
skittle
-
ground
in
the
back
yard
.
<EOS>
In
the
science
and
nicety
of
both
these
recreations
,
which
are
far
more
abstruse
than
ordinary
men
suppose
,
they
were
gradually
initiated
by
Mr
Weller
,
who
possessed
a
perfect
knowledge
of
such
pastimes
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
notwithstanding
that
they
were
in
a
great
measure
deprived
of
the
comfort
and
advantage
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
society
,
they
were
still
enabled
to
beguile
the
time
,
and
to
prevent
its
hanging
heavily
on
their
hands
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
evening
,
however
,
that
the
Peacock
presented
attractions
which
enabled
the
two
friends
to
resist
even
the
invitations
of
the
gifted
,
though
prosy
,
Pott
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
evening
that
the
"
commercial
room
"
was
filled
with
a
social
circle
,
whose
characters
and
manners
it
was
the
delight
of
Mr
Tupman
to
observe
;
whose
sayings
and
doings
it
was
the
habit
of
Mr
Snodgrass
to
note
down
.
   
<EOS>
Most
people
know
what
sort
of
places
commercial
rooms
usually
are
.
 
<EOS>
That
of
the
Peacock
differed
in
no
material
respect
from
the
generality
of
such
apartments
;
that
is
to
say
,
it
was
a
large
,
bare
-

room
,
the
furniture
of
which
had
no
doubt
been
better
when
it
was
newer
,
with
a

in
the
centre
,
and
a
variety
of
smaller
dittos
in

;
an

of
variously

,
and
an
old
Turkey

,
bearing
about
the
same
relative
proportion
to
the
size
of
the
room
,
as
a
lady
's
pocket
-
handkerchief
might
to
the
floor
of
a
watch
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
The
walls
were
garnished
with
one
or
two
large
maps
;
and
several
weather
-
beaten
rough
greatcoats
,
with
complicated

,
dangled
from
a
long
row
of
pegs
in
one
corner
.
 
<EOS>
The
mantel
-
shelf
was
ornamented
with
a
wooden
inkstand
,
containing
one
stump
of
a
pen
and
half
a
wafer
;
a
road
-
book
and
directory
;
a
county
history
minus
the
cover
;
and
the
mortal
remains
of
a
trout
in
a
glass

.
 
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
was
redolent
of
tobacco
-
smoke
,
the
fumes
of
which
had
communicated
a
rather
dingy
hue
to
the
whole
room
,
and
more
especially
to
the
dusty
red
curtains
which
shaded
the
windows
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
sideboard
a
variety
of
miscellaneous
articles
were
huddled
together
,
the
most
conspicuous
of
which
were
some
very
cloudy
fish
-

cruets
,
a
couple

driving
-
boxes
,
two
or
three
whips
,
and
as
many

shawls
,
a

of

and

,
and
the
mustard
.
   
<EOS>
Here

was
that
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
were
seated
on
the
evening
after
the
conclusion
of
the
election
,
with
several
other

of
the
house
,
smoking
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
gents
,
"
said
a

,
hale

of
about

,
with

---

,

,
"
our
noble
selves
,
gents
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
propose
that

to
the
company
,
and
drink
Mary
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
Mary
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Get
along
with
you
,
you
wretch
,
"
said
the
hand
-
maiden
,
obviously
not
ill
-
pleased
with
the

,
however
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
away
,
Mary
,
"
said
the
black
-
eyed
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
alone
,
imperence
,
"
said
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
said
the
one
-
eyed
man
,
calling
after
the
girl
as
she
left

room
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
step
out
by
and
by
,
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
your
spirits
up
,
dear
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
he
went
through
the
not
very
difficult
process
of
winking
upon
the
company
with
his
solitary
eye
,
to
the
enthusiastic
delight
of
an
elderly
personage
with
a
dirty
face
and
a
clay
pipe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rum
creeters
is
women
,
"
said
the
dirty
-
faced
man
,
after
a
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
no
mistake
about
that
<EOS>
,
"
said
a
very
red
-
faced
man
,
behind
a
cigar
.
   
<EOS>
After
this
little
bit
of
philosophy
there
was
another
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
rummer
things
than
women
in
this
world
though
,
mind
you
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
black
eye
,
slowly
filling
a
large
Dutch
pipe
,
with
a
most
capacious
bowl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
married
?
"
inquired
the
dirty
-
faced
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
say
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
the
dirty
-
faced
man
fell
into
ecstasies
of
mirth
at
his
own
retort
,
in
which
he
was
joined
by
a
man
of
bland
voice
and
placid
countenance
,
who
always
made
it
a
point
to
agree
with
everybody
.
   
<EOS>
"
Women
,
after
all
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
enthusiastic
Mr
Snodgrass
,
"
are
the
great
props
and
comforts
of
our
existence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
they
are
,
"
said
the
placid
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
they
're
in
a
good
humour
,
"
interposed
the
dirty
-
faced
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
very
true
,
"
said
the
placid
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
repudiate
that
qualification
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
whose
thoughts
were
fast
reverting
to
Emily
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
repudiate
it
with
disdain
---
with
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
Show
me
the
man
who
says
anything
against
women
,
as
women
,
and
I
boldly
declare
he
is
not
a
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Snodgrass
took
his
cigar
from
his
mouth
,
and
struck
the
table
violently
with
his
clenched
fist
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
good
sound
argument
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
THE
BAGMAN
'S
STORY
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
One

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Marking

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

"
time
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

,

;

,

,

;

,

of

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

comfortable

;
but

---
for
in

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

---

---

,

,

,
for

whole

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tom
Smart
was
by
no
means
of
an
irritable
or
envious

,
but
somehow
or
other
the
tall
man
with
the
brown
coat
and
the
bright
basket
buttons
did
rouse
what
little
gall
he
had
in
his
composition
,
and
did

him
feel
extremely
indignant
,
the
more
especially
as
he
could
now
and
then
observe
,
from
his
seat
before

glass
,
certain
little

passing
between
the
tall
man
and
the
widow
,
which
sufficiently
denoted
that
the
tall
man
was
as
high
in
favour
as
he
was
in
size
.
<EOS>
Tom
was
fond
of
hot
punch
---
I
may
venture
to
say
he
was
VERY
fond
of
hot
punch
---
and
after
he
had
seen
the
vixenish
mare
well
fed
and
well
littered
down
,
and
had
eaten
every
bit
of
the
nice
little

which
the
widow
