up
for
him
with
her
own
hands
,
he
just
ordered
a
tumbler
of
it
by
way
of
experiment
.
<EOS>
Now
,
if
there
was
one
thing
in
the
whole
range
of
domestic
art
,
which
the
widow
could
manufacture
better
than
another
,
it
was
this
identical
article
;
and
the
first
tumbler
was
adapted
to
Tom
Smart
's
taste
with
such
peculiar
nicety
,
that
he
ordered
a
second
with
the
least
possible
delay
.
 
<EOS>
Hot
punch
is
a
pleasant
thing
,
gentlemen
---
an
extremely
pleasant
thing
under
any
circumstances
 
---
but
in
that
snug
old
parlour
,
before
the
roaring
fire
,
with
the
wind
blowing
outside
till
every
timber
in
the
old
house
creaked
again
,
Tom
Smart
found
it
perfectly
delightful
.
 
<EOS>
He
ordered
another
tumbler
,
and
then
another
---
<EOS>
I
am
not
quite
certain
whether
he
did
n't
order
another
after
that
---
but
the
more
he
drank
of
the
hot
punch
,
the
more
he
thought
of
the
tall
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Confound
his
impudence
!
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
to
himself
,
"
what
business
has
he
in
that
snug
bar
?
 
<EOS>
Such
an
ugly
villain
too
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
widow
had
any
taste
,
she
might
surely
pick
up
some
better
fellow
than
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Tom
's
eye
wandered
from
the
glass
on
the
chimney
-
piece
to
the
glass
on
the
table
;
and
as
he
felt
himself
becoming
gradually
sentimental
,
he
emptied
the
fourth
tumbler
of
punch
and
ordered
a
fifth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
Smart
,
gentlemen
,
had
always
been
very
much
attached
to
the
public
line
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
long
his
ambition
to
stand
in
a
bar
of
his
own
,
in
a
green
coat
,
knee
-
cords
,
and
tops
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
great
notion
of
taking
the
chair
at
convivial
dinners
,
and
he
had
often
thought
how
well
he
could
preside
in
a
room
of
his
own
in
the
talking
way
,
and
what
a
capital
example
he
could
set
to
his
customers
in
the
drinking
department
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
things
passed
rapidly
through
Tom
's
mind
as
he
sat
drinking
the
hot
punch
by
the
roaring
fire
,
and
he
felt
very
justly
and
properly
indignant
that
the
tall
man
should
be
in
a
fair
way
of
keeping
such
an
excellent
house
,
while
he
,
Tom
Smart
,
was
as
far
off
from
it
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
after
deliberating
over
the
two
last
tumblers
,
whether
he
had
n't
a
perfect
right
to
pick
a
quarrel
with
the
tall
man
for
having
contrived
to
get
into
the
good
graces
of
the
buxom
widow
,
Tom
Smart
at
last
arrived
at
the
satisfactory
conclusion
that
he
was
a
very
ill
-
used
and
persecuted
individual
,
and
had
better
go
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Up
a
wide
and
ancient
staircase
the
smart
girl
preceded
Tom
,
shading
the
chamber
candle
with
her
hand
,
to
protect
it
from
the
currents
of
air
which
in
such
a
rambling
old
place
might
have
found
plenty
of
room
to
disport
themselves
in
,
without
blowing
the
candle
out
,
but
which
did
blow
it
out
nevertheless
---
thus
affording
Tom
's
enemies
an
opportunity
of
asserting
that
it
was
he
,
and
not
the
wind
,
who
extinguished
the
candle
,
and
that
while
he
pretended
to
be
blowing
it
alight
again
,
he
was
in
fact
kissing
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
another
light
was
obtained
,
and
Tom
was
conducted
through
a
maze
of
rooms
,
and
a
labyrinth
of
passages
,
to
the
apartment
which
had
been
prepared
for
his
reception
,
where
the
girl
bade
him
good
-
night
and
left
him
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
good
large
room
with
big
closets
,
and
a
bed
which
might
have
served
for
a
whole
boarding
-
school
,
to
say
nothing
of
a
couple
of
oaken
presses
that
would
have
held
the
baggage
of
a
small
army
;
but
what
struck
Tom
's
fancy
most
was
a
strange
,
grim
-
looking
,
high
backed
chair
,
carved
in
the
most
fantastic
manner
,
with
a
flowered
damask
cushion
,
and
the
round
knobs
at
the
bottom
of
the
legs
carefully
tied
up
in
red
cloth
,
as
if
it
had
got
the
gout
in
its
toes
.
 
<EOS>
Of
any
other
queer
chair
,
Tom
would
only
have
thought
it
was
a
queer
chair
,
and
there
would
have
been
an
end
of
the
matter
;
but
there
was
something
about
this
particular
chair
,
and
yet
he
could
n't
tell
what
it
was
,
so
odd
and
<EOS>
so
unlike
any
other
piece
of
furniture
he
had
ever
seen
,
that
it
seemed
to
fascinate
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
down
before
the
fire
,
and
stared
at
the
old
chair
for
half
an
hour
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Damn
the
chair
,
it
was
such
a
strange
old
thing
,
he
could
n't
take
his
eyes
off
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Tom
,
slowly
undressing
himself
,
and
staring
at
the
old
chair
all
the
while
,
which
stood
with
a
mysterious
aspect
by
the
bedside
,
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
such
a
rum
concern
as
that
in
my
days
.
 
<EOS>
Very
odd
,
"
said
Tom
,
who
had
got
rather
sage
with
the
hot
punch
---
<EOS>
"
very
odd
.
"
 
<EOS>
Tom
shook
his
head
with
an
air
of
profound
wisdom
,
and
looked
at
the
chair
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
make
anything
of
it
though
,
so
he
got
into
bed
,
covered
himself
up
warm
,
and
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
about
half
an
hour
,
Tom
woke
up
with
a
start
,
from
a
confused
dream
of
tall
men
and
tumblers
of
punch
;
and
the
first
object
that
presented
itself
to
his
waking
imagination
was
the
queer
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
wo
n't
look
at
it
any
more
,
"
said
Tom
to
himself
,
and
he
squeezed
his
eyelids
together
,
and
tried
to
persuade
himself
he
was
going
to
sleep
again
.
 
<EOS>
No
use
;
nothing
but
queer
chairs
danced
before
his
eyes
,
kicking
up
their
legs
,
jumping
over
each
other
's
backs
,
and
playing
all
kinds
of
antics
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
may
as
well
see
one
real
chair
,
as
two
or
three
complete
sets
of
false
ones
,
"
said
Tom
,
bringing
out
his
head
from
under
the
bedclothes
.
 
<EOS>
There
it
was
,
plainly
discernible
by
the
light
of
the
fire
,
looking
as
provoking
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
gazed
at
the
chair
;
and
,
suddenly
as
he
looked
at
it
,
a
most
extraordinary
change
seemed
to
come
over
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
carving
of
the
back
gradually
assumed
the
lineaments
and
expression
of
an
old
,
shrivelled
human
face
;
the
damask
cushion
became
an
antique
,
flapped
waistcoat
;
the
round
knobs
grew
into
a
couple
of
feet
,
encased
in
red
cloth
slippers
;
and
the
whole
chair
looked
like
a
very
ugly
old
man
,
of
the
previous
century
,
with
his
arms
akimbo
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
sat
up
in
bed
,
and
rubbed
his
eyes
to
dispel
the
illusion
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
The
chair
was
an
ugly
old
gentleman
;
and
what
was
more
,
he
was
winking
at
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
was
naturally
a
headlong
,
careless
sort
of
dog
,
and
he
had
had
five
tumblers
of
hot
punch
into
the
bargain
;
so
,
although
he
was
a
little
startled
at
first
,
he
began
to
grow
rather
indignant
when
he
saw
the
old
gentleman
winking
and
leering
at
him
with
such
an
impudent
air
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
resolved
that
he
would
n't
stand
it
;
and
as
the
old
face
still
kept
winking
away
as
fast
as
ever
,
Tom
said
,
in
a
very
angry
tone
---
   
"
"
What
the
devil
are
you
winking
at
me
for
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
Because
I
like
it
,
Tom
Smart
,
"
said
the
chair
;
or
the
old
gentleman
,
whichever
you
like
to
call
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
stopped
winking
though
,
when
Tom
spoke
,
and
began
grinning
like
a
superannuated
monkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
my
name
,
old
nut
-
cracker
face
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tom
Smart
,
rather
staggered
;
though
he
pretended
to
carry
it
off
so
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Come
,
come
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
that
's
not
the
way
to
address
solid
Spanish
mahogany
.
 
<EOS>
Damme
,
you
could
n't
treat
me
with
less
respect
if
I
was
veneered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
When
the
old
gentleman
said
this
,
he
looked
so
fierce
that
Tom
began
to
grow
frightened
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
treat
you
with
any
disrespect
,
Sir
,
"
said
Tom
,
in
a
much
humbler
tone
than
he
had
spoken
in
at
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
the
old
fellow
,
"
perhaps
not
---
perhaps
not
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
---
"
   
"
"
sir
---
"
   
"
"
I
know
everything
about
you
,
Tom
;
everything
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
very
poor
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
certainly
am
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
how
came
you
to
know
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Never
mind
that
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
;
"
you
're
much
too
fond
of
punch
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
Smart
was
just
on
the
point
of
protesting
that
he
had
n't
tasted
a
drop
since
his
last
birthday
,
but
when
his
eye
encountered
that
of
the
old
gentleman
he
looked
so
knowing
that
Tom
blushed
,
and
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
the
widow
's
a
fine
woman
---
remarkably
fine
woman
---
eh
,
Tom
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
the
old
fellow
screwed
up
his
eyes
,
cocked
up
one
of
his
wasted
little
legs
,
and
looked
altogether
so
unpleasantly
amorous
,
that
Tom
was
quite
disgusted
with
the
levity
of
his
behaviour
---
at
his
time
of
life
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
"
I
am
her
guardian
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Are
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
knew
her
mother
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
fellow
:
"
and
her
grandmother
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
very
fond
of
me
---
made
me
this
waistcoat
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Did
she
?
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
And
these
shoes
,
"
said
the
old
fellow
,
lifting
up
one
of
the
red
cloth
mufflers
;
"
but
do
n't
mention
it
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't
like
to
have
it
known
that
she
was
so
much
attached
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
occasion
some
unpleasantness
in
the
family
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
When
the
old
rascal
said
this
,
he
looked
so
extremely
impertinent
,
that
,
as
Tom
Smart
afterwards
declared
,
he
could
have
sat
upon
him
without
remorse
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
have
been
a
great
favourite
among
the
women
in
my
time
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
profligate
old
debauchee
;
"
hundreds
of
fine
women
have
sat
in
my
lap
for
hours
together
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
that
<EOS>
,
you
dog
,
eh
!
"
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
was
proceeding
to
recount
some
other
exploits
of
his
youth
,
when
he
was
seized
with
such
a
violent
fit
of
creaking
that
he
was
unable
to
proceed
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Just
serves
you
right
,
old
boy
,
"
thought
Tom
Smart
;
but
he
did
n't
say
anything
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
fellow
,
"
I
am
a
good
deal
troubled
with
this
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
getting
old
,
Tom
,
and
have
lost
nearly
all
my
rails
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
an
operation
performed
,
too
---
a
small
piece
let
into
my
back
---
and
I
found
it
a
severe
trial
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
dare
say
you
did
,
Sir
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
However
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
that
's
not
the
point
.
<EOS>
Tom
!
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
marry
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Me
,
Sir
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Bless
your
reverend
locks
,
"
said
Tom
(
he
had
a
few
scattered
horse
-
hairs
left
)
<EOS>
---
"
bless
your
reverend
locks
,
she
would
n't
have
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Tom
sighed
involuntarily
,
as
he
thought
of
the
bar
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Would
n't
she
?
"
said
the
old
gentleman
firmly
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
there
's
somebody
else
in
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
A
tall
man
---
a
confoundedly
tall
man
---
with
black
whiskers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
;
"
she
will
never
have
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Wo
n't
she
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
stood
in
the
bar
,
old
gentleman
,
you
'd
tell
another
story
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
Pooh
,
pooh
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
all
about
that
.
 
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
About
what
?
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
The
kissing
behind
the
door
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
he
gave
another
impudent
look
,
which
made
Tom
very
wroth
,
because
as
you
all
know
,
gentlemen
,
to
hear
an
old
fellow
,
who
ought
to
know
better
,
talking
about
these
things
,
is
very
unpleasant
---
nothing
more
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
know
all
about
that
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
it
done
very
often
in
my
time
,
Tom
,
between
more
people
than
I
should
like
to
mention
to
you
;
but
it
never
came
to
anything
after
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
must
have
seen
some
queer
things
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
an
inquisitive
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
may
say
that
,
Tom
,
"
replied
the
old
fellow
,
with
a
very
complicated
wink
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
last
of
my
family
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
with
a
melancholy
sigh
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Was
it
a
large
one
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
There
were
twelve
of
us
,
Tom
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
;
"
fine
,
straight
-
backed
,
handsome
fellows
as
you
'd
wish
to
see
.
<EOS>
None
of
your
modern
abortions
---
all
with
arms
,
and
with
a
degree
of
polish
,
though
I
say
it
that
should
not
,
which
it
would
have
done
your
heart
good
to
behold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
And
what
's
become
of
the
others
,
Sir
?
"
asked
Tom
Smart
---
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
gentleman
applied
his
elbow
to
his
eye
as
he
replied
,
"
Gone
,
Tom
,
gone
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
hard
service
,
Tom
,
and
they
had
n't
all
my
constitution
.
 
<EOS>
They
got
rheumatic
about
the
legs
and
arms
,
and
went
into
kitchens
and
other
hospitals
;
and
one
of
'em
,
with
long
service
and
hard
usage
,
positively
lost
his
senses
<EOS>
---
he
got
so
crazy
that
he
was
obliged
to
be
burnt
.
 
<EOS>
Shocking
thing
that
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Dreadful
!
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
fellow
paused
for
a
few
minutes
,
apparently
struggling
with
his
feelings
of
emotion
,
and
then
said
---
   
"
<EOS>
"
However
,
Tom
,
I
am
wandering
from
the
point
.
 
<EOS>
This
tall
man
,
Tom
,
is
a
rascally
adventurer
.
 
<EOS>
The
moment
he
married
the
widow
,
he
would
sell
off
all
the
furniture
,
and
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
be
the
consequence
?
 
<EOS>
She
would
be
deserted
and
reduced
to
ruin
,
and
I
should
catch
my
death
of
cold
in
some
broker
's
shop
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
---
"
   
"
"
Do
n't
interrupt
me
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
you
,
Tom
,
I
entertain
a
very
different
opinion
;
for
I
well
know
that
if
you
once
settled
yourself
in
a
public
-
house
,
you
would
never
leave
it
,
as
long
as
there
was
anything
to
drink
within
its
walls
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
for
your
good
opinion
,
Sir
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Therefore
,
"
resumed
the
old
gentleman
,
in
a
dictatorial
tone
,
"
you
shall
have
her
,
and
he
shall
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
is
to
prevent
it
?
"
said
Tom
Smart
eagerly
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
This
disclosure
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
;
"
he
is
already
married
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
prove
it
?
"
said
Tom
,
starting
half
out
of
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
gentleman
untucked
his
arm
from
his
side
,
and
having
pointed
to
one
of
the
oaken
presses
,
immediately
replaced
it
,
in
its
old
position
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
He
little
thinks
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
that
in
the
right
-
hand
pocket
of
a
pair
of
trousers
in
that
press
,
he
has
left
a
letter
,
entreating
him
to
return
to
his
disconsolate
wife
,
with
six
<EOS>
---
mark
me
,
<EOS>
Tom
---
six
babes
,
and
all
of
them
small
ones
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
the
old
gentleman
solemnly
uttered
these
words
,
his
features
grew
less
and
less
distinct
,
and
his
figure
more
shadowy
.
<EOS>
A
film
came
over
Tom
Smart
's
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
seemed
gradually
blending
into
the
chair
,
the
damask
waistcoat
to
resolve
into
a
cushion
,
the
red
slippers
to
shrink
into
little
red
cloth
bags
.
 
<EOS>
The
light
faded
gently
away
,
and
Tom
Smart
fell
back
on
his
pillow
,
and
dropped
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
Morning
aroused
Tom
from
the
lethargic
slumber
,
into
which
he
had
fallen
on
the
disappearance
of
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
up
in
bed
,
and
for
some
minutes
vainly
endeavoured
to
recall
the
events
of
the
preceding
night
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
they
rushed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
the
chair
;
it
was
a
fantastic
and
grim
-
looking
piece
of
furniture
,
certainly
,
but
it
must
have
been
a
remarkably
ingenious
and
lively
imagination
,
that
could
have
discovered
any
resemblance
between
it
and
an
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
old
boy
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
bolder
in
the
daylight
---
most
men
are
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
chair
remained
motionless
,
and
spoke
not
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Miserable
morning
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
The
chair
would
not
be
drawn
into
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Which
press
did
you
point
to
?
<EOS>
---
you
can
tell
me
that
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Devil
<EOS>
a
word
,
gentlemen
,
the
chair
would
say
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
's
not
much
trouble
to
open
it
,
anyhow
,
"
said
Tom
,
getting
out
of
bed
very
deliberately
.
 
<EOS>
He
walked
up
to
one
of
the
presses
.
 
<EOS>
The
key
was
in
the
lock
;
he
turned
it
,
and
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
pair
of
trousers
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
his
hand
into
the
pocket
,
and
drew
forth
the
identical
letter
the
old
gentleman
had
described
!
   
"
<EOS>
"
Queer
sort
of
thing
,
this
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
,
looking
first
at
the
chair
and
then
at
the
press
,
and
then
at
the
letter
,
and
then
at
the
chair
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
queer
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
there
was
nothing
in
either
,
to
lessen
the
queerness
,
he
thought
he
might
as
well
dress
himself
,
and
settle
the
tall
man
's
business
at
once
---
just
to
put
him
out
of
his
misery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
surveyed
the
rooms
he
passed
through
,
on
his
way
downstairs
,
with
the
scrutinising
eye
of
a
landlord
;
thinking
it
not
impossible
,
that
before
long
,
they
and
their
contents
would
be
his
property
.
 
<EOS>
The
tall
man
was
standing
in
the
snug
little
bar
,
with
his
hands
behind
him
,
quite
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
grinned
vacantly
at
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
A
casual
observer
might
have
supposed
he
did
it
,
only
to
show
his
white
teeth
;
but
Tom
Smart
thought
that
a
consciousness
of
triumph
was
passing
through
the
place
where
the
tall
man
's
mind
would
have
been
,
if
he
had
had
any
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
laughed
in
his
face
;
and
summoned
the
landlady
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Good
-
morning
ma'am
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
,
closing
the
door
of
the
little
parlour
as
the
widow
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Good
-
morning
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
take
for
breakfast
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
was
thinking
how
he
should
open
the
case
,
so
he
made
no
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
There
's
a
very
nice
ham
,
"
said
the
widow
,
"
and
a
beautiful
cold
larded
fowl
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
send
'em
in
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
These
words
roused
Tom
from
his
reflections
.
 
<EOS>
His
admiration
of
the
widow
increased
as
she
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
Thoughtful
creature
!
<EOS>
Comfortable
provider
!
   
<EOS>
"
"
Who
is
that
gentleman
in
the
bar
,
ma'am
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
His
name
is
Jinkins
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
widow
,
slightly
blushing
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
He
's
a
tall
man
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
He
is
a
very
fine
man
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
"
and
a
very
nice
gentleman
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Is
there
anything
more
you
want
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
the
widow
,
rather
puzzled
by
Tom
's
manner
.
"
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
ma'am
,
will
you
have
the
kindness
to
sit
down
for
one
moment
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
widow
looked
much
amazed
,
but
she
sat
down
,
and
Tom
sat
down
too
,
close

her
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
it
happened
,
gentlemen
---
indeed
my
uncle
used
to
tell
me
that
Tom
Smart
said
he
did

know
how
it
happened
either
---
but
somehow
or
other
the
palm
of
Tom
's
hand
fell
upon
the
back
of
the
widow
's
hand
,
and
remained
there
while
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
My
dear
ma'am
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
---
he
had
always
a
great
notion
of
committing
the
amiable
---
"
my
dear
ma'am
,
you
deserve
a
very
excellent
husband
---
you
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Lor
,
Sir
!
"
said
the
widow
---
<EOS>
as
well
she
might
;
Tom
's
mode
of
commencing
the
conversation
being
rather
unusual
,
not
to
say

;
the

never

set

upon

before
the
previous
night
being
taken
into

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
Sir
!
"
   
"
"
I
scorn
to
flatter
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
deserve
a
very
admirable
husband
,
and
whoever
he
is
,
he
'll
be
a
very
lucky
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
Tom
said
this
,
his

involuntarily
wandered
from
the
widow
's
face
to
the
comfort
around
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
widow
looked
more
puzzled
than
ever
,
and
made
an
effort
to
rise
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
gently
pressed
her
hand
,
as
if
to
detain
her
,
and
she
kept
her

.
 
<EOS>
Widows
,
gentlemen
,
are
not
usually
timorous
,
as
my
uncle
used
to
say
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
am
sure
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
,
Sir
,
for
your
good
opinion
,
"
said
the
buxom
landlady
,
half

;
"
and
if
ever
I
marry
again
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
IF
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
,
looking

of
the
right
-
hand
corner
of

left

.
 
<EOS>
"
IF
---
"
"
"
Well
,
"
said
the
widow
,
laughing
outright
this

,
"
WHEN
I
do
<EOS>
,
I
hope
I
shall
have
as
good

as
you

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Jinkins
,
to
wit
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Lor
,
sir
!
"
exclaimed
the
widow
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
do
n't
tell
me
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
know
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
am
sure
nobody
who
knows
him
,
knows
anything
bad
of
him
,
"
said
the
widow
,
bridling
up

the

air
with
which
Tom
had
spoken
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Hem
!
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
widow
began
to
think
it
was
high
time
to
cry
,
so
she
took
out
her
handkerchief
,
and
inquired

Tom
wished
to
insult
her
,
whether
he
thought
it
like
a
gentleman
to
take
away
the
character
of
another
gentleman
behind
his
back
,
why
,
if
he
had
got
anything

say
,
he
did
n't
say
it
to
the
man
,
like
a
man
,
instead
of
terrifying
a
poor

woman
in
that
way
;
and
so
forth
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
'll
say
it
to
him
fast
enough
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
<EOS>
only
I
want
you
to
hear

first
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
widow
,
looking
intently
in
Tom
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
'll
astonish
you
,
"
said
Tom
,
putting
his
hand
in
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
If
it
is
,
that
he
wants

,
"
said
the
widow
,
"
I

,
and
you
need

trouble

.
"
<EOS>
"
"
Pooh
,
nonsense
,
that
's
nothing
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
,
"
I
want
money
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tain't
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
dear
,
what
can
it
be
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
poor
widow
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Do
n't
be
frightened
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
 
<EOS>
He
slowly
drew
forth
the
letter
,
and
unfolded
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
scream
?
"
said
Tom
doubtfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
the
widow
;
"
let
me
see
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
wo
n't
go
fainting
away
,
or
any
of
that
nonsense
?
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
No
,
no
,
"
returned
the
widow

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
And
do
n't
run
out
,
and
blow
him
up
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
because
I
'll
do
all
that
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
not
exert
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
the
widow
,
"
let
me
see
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
I
will
,
"
replied
Tom
Smart
;
and
,
with
these
words
,
he
placed
the
letter
in
the
widow
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
I
have
heard
my
uncle
say
,
that
Tom
Smart
said
the
widow
's
lamentations
when
she
heard
the
disclosure
would
have
pierced
a
heart
of
stone
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
was
certainly
very
tender
-
hearted
,
but
they
pierced
his
,
to
the
very
core
.
 
<EOS>
The
widow
rocked
herself
to
and
fro
,
and
wrung
her
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
the
deception
and
villainy
of
the
man
!
"
said
the
widow
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Frightful
,
my
dear
ma'am
;
but
compose
yourself
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
I
ca
n't
compose
myself
,
"
shrieked
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
find
anyone
else
I
can
love
so
much
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
yes
you
will
,
my
dear
soul
,
"
said
Tom
Smart
,
letting
fall
a
shower
of
the
largest
-
sized
tears
,
in
pity
for
the
widow
's
misfortunes
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
Smart
,
in
the
energy
of
his
compassion
,
had
put
his
arm
round
the
widow
's
waist
;
and
the
widow
,
in
a
passion
of
grief
,
had
clasped
Tom
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
up
in
Tom
's
face
,
and
smiled
through
her
tears
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
looked
down
in
hers
,
and
smiled
through
his
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
could
find
out
,
gentlemen
,
whether
Tom
did
or
did
not
kiss
the
widow
at
that
particular
moment
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
to
tell
my
uncle
he
did
n't
,
but
I
have
my
doubts
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Between
ourselves
,
gentlemen
,
I
rather
think
he
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
Tom
kicked
the
very
tall
man
out
at
the
front
door
half
an
hour
later
,
and
married
the
widow
a
month
after
.
<EOS>
And
he
used
to
drive
about
the
country
,
with
the
clay
-
coloured
gig
with
the
red
wheels
,
and
the
vixenish
mare
with
the
fast
pace
,
till
he
gave
up
business
many
years
afterwards
,
and
went
to
France
with
his
wife
;
and
then
the
old
house
was
pulled
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
ask
you
,
"
said
the
inquisitive
old
gentleman
,
"
what
became
of
the
chair
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
replied
the
one
-
eyed
bagman
,
"
it
was
observed
to
creak
very
much
on
the
day
of
the
wedding
;
but
Tom
Smart
could
n't
say
for
certain
whether
it
was
with
pleasure
or
bodily
infirmity
.
<EOS>
He
rather
thought
it
was
the
latter
,
though
,
for
it
never
spoke
afterwards
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
believed
the
story
,
did
n't
they
?
"
said
the
dirty
-
faced
man
,
refilling
his
pipe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Except
Tom
's
enemies
,
"
replied
the
bagman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
of
'em
said
Tom
invented
it
altogether
;
and
others
said
he
was
drunk
and
fancied
it
,
and
got
hold
of
the
wrong
trousers
by
mistake
before
he
went
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
But
nobody
ever
minded
what
THEY
said
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
Smart
said
it
was
all
true
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Every
word
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
your
uncle
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Every
letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
must
have
been
very
nice
men
,
both
of
'
em
,
"
said
the
dirty
-
faced
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
they
were
,
"
replied
the
bagman
;
"
very
nice
men
indeed
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
In
which
is
given
a
faithful
portraiture
of
two
distinguished
persons
;
and
an
accurate
description
of
a
public
breakfast
in
their
house
and
grounds
:
which
public
breakfast
leads
to
the
recognition
of
an
old
acquaintance
,
and
the
commencement
of
another
chapter
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
conscience
had
been
somewhat
reproaching
him
for
his
recent
neglect
of
his
friends
at
the
Peacock
;
and
he
was
just
on
the
point
of
walking
forth
in
quest
of
them
,
on
the
third
morning
after
the
election
had
terminated
,
when
his
faithful
valet
put
into
his
hand
a
card
,
on
which
was
engraved
the
following
inscription
:
---
     
<EOS>
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
     
<EOS>
THE
DEN
.
<EOS>
EATANSWILL
.
   
<EOS>
"
Person
's
a
-
waitin
'
,
"
said
Sam
,
epigrammatically
.
   
<EOS>
"
Does
the
person
want
me
,
Sam
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
wants
you
partickler
;
and
no
one
else
"
ll
do
,
as
the
devil
's
private
secretary
said
ven
<EOS>
he
fetched
avay
Doctor
Faustus
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
HE
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
a
gentleman
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
wery
good
imitation
o
<EOS>
'
one
,
if
it
ai
n't
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
a
lady
's
card
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Given
me
by
a
gen'l'm'n
,
howsoever
,
"
replied
Sam
,
"
and
he
's
a
-
waitin
'
in
the
drawing
-
room
---
said
he
'd
rather
wait
all
day
,
than
not
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
on
hearing
this
determination
,
descended
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
where
sat
a
grave
man
,
who
started
up
on
his
entrance
,
and
said
,
with
an
air
of
profound
respect
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
presume
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
same
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
,
Sir
,
the
honour
of
grasping
your
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Permit
me
<EOS>
,
Sir
,
to
shake
it
,
"
said
the
grave
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
shook
the
extended
hand
,
and
then
continued
---
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
heard
of
your
fame
,
sir
.
<EOS>
The
noise
of
your
antiquarian
discussion
has
reached
the
ears
of
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
---
my
wife
,
sir
;
I
am
Mr
Leo
Hunter
"
---
the
stranger
paused
,
as
if
he
expected
that
Mr
Pickwick
would
be
overcome
by
the
disclosure
;
but
seeing
that
he
remained
perfectly
calm
,
proceeded
---
   
<EOS>
"
My
wife
,
sir
---
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
---
is
proud
to
number
among
her
acquaintance
all
those
who
have
rendered
themselves
celebrated
by
their
works
and
talents
.
 
<EOS>
Permit
me
,
sir
,
to
place
in
a
conspicuous
part
of
the
list
the
name
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
his
brother
-
members
of
the
club
that
derives
its
name
from
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
extremely
happy
to
make
the
acquaintance
of
such
a
lady
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
SHALL
make
it
,
sir
,
"
said
the
grave
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
morning
,
sir
,
we
give
a
public
breakfast
---
a
FETE
CHAMPETRE
---
to
a
great
number
of
those
who
have
rendered
themselves
celebrated
by
their
works
and
talents
.
 
<EOS>
Permit
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
Sir
,
to
have
the
gratification
of
seeing
you
at
the
Den
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
great
pleasure
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
has
many
of
these
breakfasts
,
Sir
,
"
resumed
the
new
acquaintance
---
<EOS>
"
"
feasts
of
reason
,
"
sir
,
"
and
flows
of
soul
,
"
as
somebody
who
wrote
a
sonnet
to
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
on
her
breakfasts
,
feelingly
and
originally
observed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
HE
celebrated
for
his
works
and
talents
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
Sir
,
"
replied
the
grave
man
,
"
all
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
's
acquaintances
are
;
it
is
her
ambition
,
sir
,
to
have
no
other
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
very
noble
ambition
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
inform
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
that
that
remark
fell
from
your
lips
,
sir
,
she
will
indeed
be
proud
,
"
said
the
grave
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
gentleman
in
your
train
,
who
has
produced
some
beautiful
little
poems
,
I
think
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
friend
Mr
Snodgrass
has
a
great
taste
for
poetry
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
has
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
She
dotes
on
poetry
,
sir
.
<EOS>
She
adores
it
;
I
may
say
that
her
whole
soul
and
mind
are
wound
up
,
and
entwined
with
it
.
<EOS>
She
has
produced
some
delightful
pieces
,
herself
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
have
met
with
her
"
Ode
to
an
Expiring
Frog
,
"
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
have
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
astonish
me
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Leo
Hunter
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
created
an
immense
sensation
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
signed
with
an
"
L
"
and
eight
stars
,
and
appeared
originally
in
a
lady
's
magazine
.
 
<EOS>
It
commenced
---
     
"
"
Can
I
view
thee
panting
,
lying
     
On
thy
stomach
,
without
sighing
;
     
<EOS>
Can
I
unmoved
see
thee
dying
    
<EOS>
On
a
log
    
Expiring
frog
!
"
<EOS>
"
"
Beautiful
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fine
,
"
said
Mr
Leo
Hunter
;
"
so
simple
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
next
verse
is
still
more
touching
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
repeat
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
runs
thus
,
"
said
the
grave
man
,
still
more
gravely
.
     
<EOS>
"
"
Say
,
have
fiends
in
shape
of
boys
,
     
With
wild
halloo
,
and
brutal
noise
,
     
Hunted
thee
from
marshy
joys
,
    
With
a
dog
,
    
Expiring
frog
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
Finely
expressed
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
All
point
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Leo
Hunter
;
"
but
you
shall
hear
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
repeat
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
can
do
justice
to
it
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
She
will
repeat
it
,
in
character
,
Sir
,
to
-
morrow

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
In
character
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
Minerva
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
forgot
<EOS>
---
it
's
a
fancy
-
dress
DEJEUNE
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
glancing
at
his
own
figure
---
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
possibly
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Ca
n't
,
sir
;
ca
n't
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Leo
Hunter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Solomon
Lucas
,
the
Jew
in
the
High
Street
,
has
thousands
of
fancy
-
dresses
.
<EOS>
Consider
,
Sir
,
how
many
appropriate
characters
are
open
for
your
selection
.
 
<EOS>
Plato
,
Zeno
,
Epicurus
,
Pythagoras
---
all
founders
of
clubs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
but
as
I
can
not

myself
in

with
those
great
men
,
I
can
not
presume
to
wear
their

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
grave
man
considered
deeply
,
for
a
few
seconds
,
and
then
said
---
   
"
<EOS>
On
reflection
,
Sir
,
I
do
n't
know
whether
it
would
not
afford
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
greater
pleasure
,
if
her
guests
saw
a
gentleman
of
your
celebrity
in
his
own

,
rather
than
in
an

.
 
<EOS>
I
may
venture
to
promise

exception
in
your
case
,
sir
---
<EOS>
yes
,
I
am
quite
certain
that
,
on
behalf
of
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
I
may
venture
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
shall
have
great

in
coming
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
waste
your
time
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
grave
man
,
as
if

recollecting
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
its
value
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
detain
you
.
<EOS>
I
may

Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
then
,
that
she
may
confidently
expect
you
and
your
distinguished
friends
?
 
<EOS>
Good
-
morning
,
Sir
,
I
am
proud
to
have
beheld
so
eminent
a
personage
---
not
a
step
sir
;
not
a
word
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
without
giving
Mr
Pickwick
time
to
offer
remonstrance
or
denial
,
Mr
Leo
Hunter
stalked
gravely
away
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
took
up
his
hat
,
and
repaired
to
the
Peacock
,
but
Mr
Winkle
had
conveyed
the
intelligence
of
the
fancy
-
ball
there
,
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Pott
's
going
,
"
were
the
first
words
with
which
he
saluted
his
leader
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
she
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
Apollo
,
"
replied
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
Pott
objects
to
the
tunic
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
right
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
quite
right
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
emphatically
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
so
she
's
going
to
wear
a
white
satin
gown
with
gold
spangles
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
'll
hardly
know
what
she
's
meant
for
;
will
they
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
they
will
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
'll
see
her
lyre
,
wo
n't
they
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
;
I
forgot
that
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
as
a
bandit
,
"
interposed
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
sudden
start
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
a
bandit
,
"
repeated
Mr
Tupman
,
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
say
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
gazing
with
solemn
sternness
at
his
friend
<EOS>
---
"
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
,
Mr
Tupman
,
that
it
is
your
intention
to
put
yourself
into
a
green
velvet
jacket
,
with
a
two
-
inch
tail
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Such
IS
my
intention
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
warmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
considerably
excited
---
"
because
you
are
too
old
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Too
old
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
any
further
ground
of
objection
be
wanting
,
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
you
are
too
fat
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
his
face
suffused
with
a
crimson
glow
,
"
this
is
an
insult
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
the
same
tone
,
"
it
is
not
half
the
insult
to
you
,
that
your
appearance
in
my
presence
in
a
green
velvet
jacket
,
with
a
two
-
inch
tail
,
would
be
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
"
you
're
a
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
you
're
another
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
advanced
a
step
or
two
,
and
glared
at
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
returned
the
glare
,
concentrated
into
a
focus
by
means
of
his
spectacles
,
and
breathed
a
bold
defiance
.
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
looked
on
,
petrified
at
beholding
such
a
scene
between
two
such
men
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
after
a
short
pause
,
speaking
in
a
low
,
deep
voice
,
"
you
have
called
me
old
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
fat
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
reiterate
the
charge
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
a
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
fearful
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
attachment
to
your
person
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
speaking
in
a
voice
tremulous
with
emotion
,
and
tucking
up
his
wristbands
meanwhile
,
"
is
great
---
very
great
---
<EOS>
but
upon
that
person
,
I
must
take
summary
vengeance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
on
,
Sir
!
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Stimulated
by
the
exciting
nature
of
the
dialogue
,
the
heroic
man
actually
threw
himself
into
a
paralytic
attitude
,
confidently
supposed
by
the
two
bystanders
to
have
been
intended
as
a
posture
of
defence
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Snodgrass
,
suddenly
recovering
the
power
of
speech
,
of
which
intense
astonishment
had
previously
bereft
him
,
and
rushing
between
the
two
,
at
the
imminent
hazard
of
receiving
an
application
on
the
temple
from
each
---
<EOS>
"
what
!
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
the
eyes
of
the
world
upon
you
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
!
<EOS>
who
,
in
common
with
us
all
,
derives
a
lustre
from
his
undying
name
!
 
<EOS>
For
shame
,
gentlemen
;
for
shame
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
unwonted
lines
which
momentary
passion
had
ruled
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
clear
and
open
brow
,
gradually
melted
away
,
as
his
young
friend
spoke
,
like
the
marks
of
a
black
-
lead
pencil
beneath
the
softening
influence
of
india
-
rubber
.
 
<EOS>
His
countenance
had
resumed
its
usual
benign
expression
,
ere
he
concluded
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
hasty
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
very
hasty
.
 
<EOS>
Tupman
;
your
hand
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
dark
shadow
passed
from
Mr
Tupman
's
face
,
as
he
warmly
grasped
the
hand
of
his
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
hasty
,
too
,
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
the
fault
was
mine
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
wear
the
green
velvet
jacket
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
oblige
me
,
you
will
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
I
will
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
accordingly
settled
that
Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
should
all
wear
fancy
-
dresses
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
Mr
Pickwick
was
led
by
the
very
warmth
of
his
own
good
feelings
to
give
his
consent
to
a
proceeding
from
which
his
better
judgment
would
have
recoiled
---
a
more
striking
illustration
of
his
amiable
character
could
hardly
have
been
conceived
,
even
if
the
events
recorded
in
these
pages
had
been
wholly
imaginary
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Leo
Hunter
had
not
exaggerated
the
resources
of
Mr
Solomon
Lucas
.
 
<EOS>
His
wardrobe
was
extensive
---
very
extensive
---
not
strictly
classical
perhaps
,
not
quite
new
,
nor
did
it
contain
any
one
garment
made
precisely
after
the
fashion
of
any
age
or
time
,
but
everything
was
more
or
less
spangled
;
and
what
can
be
prettier
than
spangles
!
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
objected
that
they
are
not
adapted
to
the
daylight
,
but
everybody
knows
that
they
would
glitter
if
there
were
lamps
;
and
nothing
can
be
clearer
than
that
if
people
give
fancy
-
balls
in
the
day
-
time
,
and
the
dresses
do
not
show
quite
as
well
as
they
would
by
night
,
the
fault
lies
solely
with
the
people
who
give
the
fancy
-
balls
,
and
is
in
no
wise
chargeable
on
the
spangles
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
the
convincing
reasoning
of
Mr
Solomon
Lucas
;
and
influenced
by
such
arguments
<EOS>
did
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
engage
to
array
themselves
in
costumes
which
his
taste
and
experience
induced
him
to
recommend
as
admirably
suited
to
the
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
A
carriage
was
hired
from
the
Town
Arms
,
for
the
accommodation
of
the
Pickwickians
,
and
a
chariot
was
ordered
from
the
same
repository
,
for
the
purpose
of
conveying
Mr
and
Mrs
Pott
to
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
's
grounds
,
which
Mr
Pott
,
as
a
delicate
acknowledgment
of
having
received
an
invitation
,
had
already
confidently
predicted
in
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
"
would
present
a
scene
of
varied
and
delicious
enchantment
---
a
bewildering
coruscation
of
beauty
and
talent
---
a
lavish
and
prodigal
display
of
hospitality
---
above
all
,
a
degree
of
splendour
softened
by
the
most
exquisite
taste
;
and
adornment
refined
with
perfect
harmony
and
the
chastest
good
keeping
---
compared
with
which
,
the
fabled
gorgeousness
of
Eastern
fairyland
itself
would
appear
to
be
clothed
in
as
many
dark
and
murky
colours
,
as
must
be
the
mind
of
the
splenetic
and
unmanly
being
who
could
presume
to
taint
with
the
venom
of
his
envy
,
the
preparations
made
by
the
virtuous
and
highly
distinguished
lady
at
whose
shrine
this
humble
tribute
of
admiration
was
offered
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
last
was
a
piece
of
biting
sarcasm
against
the
INDEPENDENT
,
who
,
in
consequence
of
not
having
been
invited
at
all
,
had
been
,
through
four
numbers
,
affecting
to
sneer
at
the
whole
affair
,
in
his
very
largest
type
,
with
all
the
adjectives
in
capital
letters
.
   
<EOS>
The
morning
came
:
<EOS>
it
was
a
pleasant
sight
to
behold
Mr
Tupman
in
full
brigand
's
costume
,
with
a
very
tight
jacket
,
sitting
like
a
pincushion
over
his
back
and
shoulders
,
the
upper
portion
of
his
legs
incased
in
the
velvet
shorts
,
and
the
lower
part
thereof
swathed
in
the
complicated
bandages
to
which
all
brigands
are
peculiarly
attached
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
pleasing
to
see
his
open
and
ingenuous
countenance
,
well
mustachioed
and
corked
,
looking
out
from
an
open
shirt
collar
;
and
to
contemplate
the
sugar
-
loaf
hat
,
decorated
with
ribbons
of
all
colours
,
which
he
was
compelled
to
carry
on
his
knee
,
inasmuch
as
no
known
conveyance
with
a
top
to
it
<EOS>
,
would
admit
of
any
man
's
carrying
it
between
his
head
and
the
roof
.
 
<EOS>
Equally
humorous
and
agreeable
was
the
appearance
of
Mr
Snodgrass
in
blue
satin
trunks
and
cloak
,
white
silk
tights
and
shoes
,
and
Grecian
helmet
,
which
everybody
knows
<EOS>
(
and
if
they
do
not
,
Mr
Solomon
Lucas
did
)
to
have
been
the
regular
,
authentic
,
everyday
costume
of
a
troubadour
,
from
the
earliest
ages
down
to
the
time
of
their
final
disappearance
from
the
face
of
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
pleasant
,
but
this
was
as
nothing
compared
with
the
shouting
of
the
populace
when
the
carriage
drew
up
,
behind
Mr
Pott
's
chariot
,
which
chariot
itself
drew
up
at
Mr
Pott
's
door
,
which
door
itself
opened
,
and
displayed
the
great
Pott
accoutred
as
a
Russian
officer
of
justice
,
with
a
tremendous
knout
in
his
hand
---
tastefully
typical
of
the
stern
and
mighty
power
of
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,
and
the
fearful
lashings
it
bestowed
on
public
offenders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"
shouted
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
from
the
passage
,
when
they
beheld
the
walking
allegory
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
heard
to
exclaim
,
from
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hoo
-
roar
Pott
!
"
shouted
the
populace
.
 
<EOS>
Amid
these
salutations
,
Mr
Pott
,
smiling
with
that
kind
of
bland
dignity
which
sufficiently
testified
that
he
felt
his
power
,
and
knew
how
to
exert
it
,
got
into
the
chariot
.
   
<EOS>
Then
there
emerged
from
the
house
,
Mrs
Pott
,
who
would
have
looked
very
like
Apollo
if
she
had
n't
had
a
gown
on
,
conducted
by
Mr
Winkle
,
who
,
in
his
light
-
red
coat
could
not
possibly
have
been
mistaken
for
anything
but
a
sportsman
,
if
he
had
not
borne
an
equal
resemblance
to
a
general
postman
.
 
<EOS>
Last
of
all
came
Mr
Pickwick
,
whom
the
boys
applauded
as
loud
as
anybody
,
probably
under
the
impression
that
his
tights
and
gaiters
were
some
remnants
of
the
dark
ages
;
and
then
the
two
vehicles
proceeded
towards
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
's
;
Mr
Weller
(
who
was
to
assist
in
waiting
)
being
stationed
on
the
box
of
that
in
which
his
master
was
seated
.
   
<EOS>
Every
one
of
the
men
,
women
,
boys
,
girls
,
and
babies
,
who
were
assembled
to
see
the
visitors
in
their
fancy
-
dresses
,
screamed
with
delight
and
ecstasy
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
the
brigand
on
one
arm
,
and
the
troubadour
on
the
other
,
walked
solemnly
up
the
entrance
.
 
<EOS>
Never
were
such
shouts
heard
as
those
which
greeted
Mr
Tupman
's
efforts
to
fix
the
sugar
-
loaf
hat
on
his
head
,
by
way
of
entering
the
garden
in
style
.
   
<EOS>
The
preparations
were
on
the
most
delightful
scale
;
fully
realising
the
prophetic
Pott
's
anticipations
about
the
gorgeousness
of
Eastern
fairyland
,
and
at
once
affording
a
sufficient
contradiction
to
the
malignant
statements
of
the
reptile
INDEPENDENT
.
<EOS>
The
grounds
were
more
than
an
acre
and
a
quarter
in
extent
,
and
they
were
filled
with
people
!
 
<EOS>
Never
was
such
a
blaze
of
beauty
,
and
fashion
,
and
literature
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
young
lady
who
"
did
"
the
poetry
in
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,
in
the
garb
of
a
sultana
,
leaning
upon
the
arm
of
the
young
gentleman
who
"
did
"
the
review
department
,
and
who
was
appropriately
habited
in
a
field
-
marshal
's
uniform
---
the
boots
excepted
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
hosts
of
these
geniuses
,
and
any
reasonable
person
would
have
thought
it
honour
enough
to
meet
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
more
than
these
,
there
were
half
a
dozen
lions
from
London
---
authors
,
real
authors
,
who
had
written
whole
books
,
and
printed
them
afterwards
---
and
here
you
might
see
'em
,
walking
about
,
like
ordinary
men
,
smiling
,
and
talking
---
aye
,
and
talking
pretty
considerable
nonsense
too
,
no
doubt
with
the
benign
intention
of
rendering
themselves
intelligible
to
the
common
people
about
them
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
,
there
was
a
band
of
music
in
pasteboard
caps
;
four
something
-
ean
singers
in
the
costume
of
their
country
,
and
a
dozen
hired
waiters
in
the
costume
of
THEIR
country
---
and
very
dirty
costume
too
.
 
<EOS>
And
above
all
,
there
was
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
in
the
character
of
Minerva
,
receiving
the
company
,
and
overflowing
with
pride
and
gratification
at
the
notion
of
having
called
such
distinguished
individuals
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
,
ma'am
,
"
said
a
servant
,
as
that
gentleman
approached
the
presiding
goddess
,
with
his
hat
in
his
hand
,
and
the
brigand
and
troubadour
on
either
arm
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Where
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
starting
up
,
in
an
affected
rapture
of
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
that
I
have
really
the
gratification
of
beholding
Mr
Pickwick
himself
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
other
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
bowing
very
low
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Permit
me
to
introduce
my
friends
---
Mr
Tupman
---
Mr
Winkle
 
---
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
---
to
the
authoress
of
"
The
Expiring
Frog
.
"
<EOS>
"
Very
few
people
but
those
who
have
tried
it
,
know
what
a
difficult
process
it
is
to
bow
in
green
velvet
smalls
,
and
a
tight
jacket
,
and
high
-
crowned
hat
;
or
in
blue
satin
trunks
and
white
silks
,
or
knee
-
cords
and
top
-
boots
that
were
never
made
for
the
wearer
,
and
have
been
fixed
upon
him
without
the
remotest
reference
to
the
comparative
dimensions
of
himself
and
the
suit
.
 
<EOS>
Never
were
such
distortions
as
Mr
Tupman
's
frame
underwent
in
his
efforts
to
appear
easy
and
graceful
---
never
was
such
ingenious
posturing
,
as
his
fancy
-
dressed
friends
exhibited
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
,
"
I
must
make
you
promise
not
to
stir
from
my
side
the
whole
day
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
hundreds
of
people
here
,
that
I
must

to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
,

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
first

,

my

girls
;
I

,
"
said
Minerva
,
carelessly

towards

full
-

,
of

one
might
be
about

,

a

,
and
who
were
dressed
in
very
juvenile

---
whether
to
make

look
young
,
or
their
mamma
younger
,
Mr
Pickwick
does
not
distinctly

.
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
very

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
They

,
Sir
,
"
said

Pott
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
"

Leo

,

's

with

fan
(
Minerva
with
a
fan
!
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why

,

,
"

,

,
"

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.

Count
,
count
,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Big

.

.

<EOS>

,

,
<EOS>
thoroughly

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wonderful

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sound

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Clear
-

,

-

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
A

Count
Smorltork
's

,
shook

,

,
"
Very
!
"
   
<EOS>
As

enthusiasm
in
Count
Smorltork
's
favour
ran
very
high
,
his
praises
might
have
been
sung
until
the
end
of
the

,
if
the
four
something
-
ean
singers
had
not
ranged

in
front
of
a
small

-
tree
,
to
look
picturesque
,
and
commenced
singing
their
national
songs
,
which
appeared
by
no

difficult
of
execution
,
inasmuch
as
the
grand
secret
seemed
to
be
,
that
three
of
the
something
-
ean
singers
should
grunt
,
while
the
fourth
howled
.
 
<EOS>
This
interesting
performance
having
concluded
amidst
the
loud
plaudits
of
the
whole
company
,
a
boy
forthwith
proceeded
to
entangle
himself
with
the
rails
of
a
chair
,
and
to
jump
over
it
,
and
crawl
under
it
,
and
fall
down
with
it
,
and
do
everything
but
sit
upon
it
,
and
then
to
make
a
cravat
of
his
legs
,
and
tie
them
round
his
neck
,
and
then
to
illustrate
the
ease
with
which
a
human
being
can
be
made
to
look
like
a
magnified
toad
 
---
all
which
feats
yielded
high
delight
and
satisfaction
to
the
assembled
spectators
.
 
<EOS>
After
which
,
the
voice
of
Mrs
Pott
was
heard
to
chirp
faintly
forth
,
something
which
courtesy
interpreted
into
a
song
,
which
was
all
very
classical
,
and
strictly
in
character
,
because
Apollo
was
himself
a
composer
,
and
composers
can
very
seldom
sing
their
own
music
or
anybody
else
's
,
either
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
succeeded
by
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
's
recitation
of
her
far
-
famed
"
Ode
to
an
Expiring
Frog
,
"
which
was
encored
once
,
and
would
have
been
encored
twice
,
if
the
major

of
the
guests
,
who
thought
it
was
high
time

eat
,
had
not
said
that

was
perfectly
shameful
to

Mrs
Hunter
's
good
nature
.
 
<EOS>
So
although
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
professed
her
perfect
willingness
to
recite
the
ode
again
,
her
kind
and
considerate
friends
would
n't
hear
of
it
on
any

;
and
the
refreshment
room
being
thrown
open
,
all
the
people
who
had

there
before
,
scrambled
in
with
all

despatch
---
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
's
usual
course
of
proceedings
being
,
to
issue
cards
for
a
hundred
,
and
breakfast
for
fifty
,
or
in
other
words
to
feed
only
the

particular

,

let

take

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here

,
"

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Alas

the
knout
!
 
<EOS>
The

,
with

on

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Leo
Hunter
looked
round

.
 
<EOS>
Count
Smorltork
was
busily

in
taking

;

no

Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing

,

Mr

Hunter
---
whose

,

---

"

;

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

---
<EOS>
very
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

's

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

,

,

Charles
the
Seconds
,

,
"
regular

---
Baker

---

,

---
might

"
got

"

ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>

---

,

trying

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

postillion
 
---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
---

sha

---

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Will

,
"

,

"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

,
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
The
count

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
His

<EOS>
---
"
   
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
"

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
Where
?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>

To

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Sam
!
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Proud
o
'

<EOS>
Remonstrances
were
useless
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
roused
,
and
his
mind
was
made
up
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
returned
to
his
companions
;
and
in
another
hour
had
drowned
all
present

of
Mr

Jingle
,
or
Mr
Charles
Fitz
-
Marshall
,
in
an

and
a

of

.
 
<EOS>
By
that
time
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Sam
Weller
,
perched
on
the
outside
of
a
stage
-

,
were
every
succeeding
minute
placing
a
less
and
less
distance
between
themselves
and
the
good
old
town
of
Bury
St
Edmunds
.
    
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
Too
full
of
adventure
to
be
briefly
described
 
There
is
no
month
in
the
whole
year
in
which
nature
wears
a
more
beautiful
appearance
than
in
the
month
of
August
.
 
<EOS>
Spring
has
many
beauties
,
and
May
is
a
fresh
and
blooming
month
,
but
the
charms
of
this
time
of
year
are
enhanced
by
their
contrast
with
the
winter
season
.
 
<EOS>
August
has
no
such
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
It
comes
when
we
remember
nothing
but
clear
skies
,
green
fields
,
and
sweet
-
smelling
flowers
---
when
the
recollection
of
snow
,
and
ice
,
and
bleak
winds
,
has
faded
from
our
minds
as
completely
as
they
have
disappeared
from
the
earth
---
and
yet
what
a
pleasant
time
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
Orchards
and
cornfields
ring
with
the
hum
of
labour
;
trees
bend
beneath
the
thick
clusters
of
rich
fruit
which
bow
their
branches
to
the
ground
;
and
the
corn
,
piled
in
graceful
sheaves
,
or
waving
in
every
light
breath
that
sweeps
above
it
,
as
if
it
wooed
the
sickle
,
tinges
the
landscape
with
a
golden
hue
.
 
<EOS>
A
mellow
softness
appears
to
hang
over
the
whole
earth
;
the
influence
of
the
season
seems
to
extend
itself
to
the
very
wagon
,
whose
slow
motion
across
the
well
-
reaped
field
is
perceptible
only
to
the
eye
,
but
strikes
with
no
harsh
sound
upon
the
ear
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
coach
rolls
swiftly
past
the
fields
and
orchards
which
skirt
the
road
,
groups
of
women
and
children
,
piling
the
fruit
in
sieves
,
or
gathering
the
scattered
ears
of
corn
,
pause
for
an
instant
from
their
labour
,
and
shading
the
sun
-
burned
face
with
a
still
browner
hand
,
gaze
upon
the
passengers
with
curious
eyes
,
while
some
stout
urchin
,
too
small
to
work
,
but
too
mischievous
to
be
left
at
home
,
scrambles
over
the
side
of
the
basket
in
which
he
has
been
deposited
for
security
,
and
kicks
and
screams
with
delight
.
 
<EOS>
The
reaper
stops
in
his
work
,
and
stands
with
folded
arms
,
looking
at
the
vehicle
as
it
whirls
past
;
and
the
rough
cart
-
horses
bestow
a
sleepy
glance
upon
the
smart
coach
team
,
which
says
as
plainly
as
a
horse
's
glance
can
,
"
It
's
all
very
fine
to
look
at
,
but
slow
going
,
over
a
heavy
field
,
is
better
than
warm
work
like
that
,
upon
a
dusty
road
,
after
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
You
cast
a
look
behind
you
,
as
you
turn
a
corner
of
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
The
women
and
children
have
resumed
their
labour
;
the
reaper
once
more
stoops
to
his
work
;
the
cart
-
horses
have
moved
on
;
and
all
are
again
in
motion
.
<EOS>
The
influence
of
a
scene
like
this
,
was
not
lost
upon
the
well
-
regulated
mind
of
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Intent
upon
the
resolution
he
had
formed
,
of
exposing
the
real
character
of
the
nefarious
Jingle
,
in
any
quarter
in
which
he
might
be
pursuing
his
fraudulent
designs
,
he
sat
at
first
taciturn
and
contemplative
,
brooding
over
the
means
by
which
his
purpose
could
be
best
attained
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
his
attention
grew
more
and
more
attracted
by
the
objects
around
him
;
and
at
last
he
derived
as
much
enjoyment
from
the
ride
,
as
if
it
had
been
undertaken
for
the
pleasantest
reason
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
"
Delightful
prospect
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beats
the
chimbley
-
pots
,

,
"

Weller
,

.
   
<EOS>

-

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

!

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"

"
Let
me
order
you
a
snug
little
dinner
,
and
make
my
inquiries
below
while
it
's
a
-
getting
ready
;
I
could
worm
ev'ry
secret
out
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>
the
boots
's
heart
,
in
five
minutes
,
Sir
.
"
<EOS>
"
Do
so
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
Mr
Weller
at
once
retired
.
   
<EOS>
In
half
an
hour
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
seated
at
a
very
satisfactory
dinner
;
and
in
three
-
quarters
Mr
Weller
returned
with
the
intelligence
that
Mr
Charles
Fitz
-
Marshall
had
ordered
his
private
room
to
be
retained
for
him
,
until
further
notice
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
spend
the
evening
at
some
private
house
in
the
neighbourhood
,
had
ordered
the
boots
to
sit
up
until
his
return
,
and
had
taken
his
servant
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
argued
Mr
Weller
,
when
he
had
concluded
his
report
,
"
if
I
can
get
a
talk
with
this
here
servant
in
the
mornin
'
,
he
'll
tell
me
all
his
master
's
concerns
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
that
?
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
your
heart
,
sir
,
servants
always
do
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
ah
,
I
forgot
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
can
arrange
what
's
best
to
be
done
,
sir
,
and
we
can
act
accordingly
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
it
appeared
that
this
was
the
best
arrangement
that
could
be
made
,
it
was
finally
agreed
upon
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
,
by
his
master
's
permission
,
retired
to
spend
the
evening
in
his
own
way
;
and
was
shortly
afterwards
elected
,
by
the
unanimous
voice
of
the
assembled
company
,
into
the
taproom
chair
,
in
which
honourable
post
he
acquitted
himself
so
much
to
the
satisfaction
of
the
gentlemen
-
frequenters
,
that
their
roars
of
laughter
and
approbation
penetrated
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
bedroom
,
and
shortened
the
term
of
his
natural
rest
by
at
least
three
hours
.
   
<EOS>
Early
on
the
ensuing
morning
,
Mr
Weller
was
dispelling
all
the
feverish
remains
of
the
previous
evening
's
conviviality
,
through
the
instrumentality
of
a
halfpenny
shower
-
bath
(
having
induced
a
young
gentleman
attached
to
the
stable
department
,
by
the
offer
of
that
coin
,
to
pump
over
his
head
and
face
,
until
he
was
perfectly
restored
)
,
when
he
was
attracted
by
the
appearance
of
a
young
fellow
in
mulberry
-
coloured
livery
,
who
was
sitting
on
a
bench
in
the
yard
,
reading
what
appeared
to
be
a
hymn
-
book
,
with
an
air
of
deep
abstraction
,
but
who
occasionally
stole
a
glance
at
the
individual
under
the
pump
,
as
if
he
took
some
interest
in
his
proceedings
,
nevertheless
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
rum
'
un
to
look
at
,
you
are
!
"
thought
Mr
Weller
,
the
first
time
his
eyes
encountered
the
glance
of
the
stranger
in
the
mulberry
suit
,
who
had
a
large
,
sallow
,
ugly
face
,
very

,
and
a
gigantic
head
,
from
which
depended
a
quantity
of

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
rum
'
un
!
"
thought
Mr
Weller
;
and
thinking
this
,
he
went
on
washing
himself
,
and
thought
no
more
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
Still
the
man
kept
glancing
from
his

-

to
Sam
,
and
from
Sam
to
his

-

,
as
if

wanted
to
open
a

.
<EOS>
So

last
,
Sam
,
by

,
said
with

---
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
governor
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
to
say
,
I
am
pretty
well
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
man
,
speaking
with

,
and
closing

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope

are
the

,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

less

-
bottle
<EOS>
I
should
n't

quite
so
staggery
this
mornin
'
,
"

Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
stoppin
'
in
this
house
,
old
'
un
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
mulberry
man
replied
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
was
it
you
worn't
<EOS>
one
of
us
,
last
night
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
seem
one

sort
 
---
looks

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
<EOS>
inquired

,
colouring

very
red
with

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Fitz
-
Marshall
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Give

,
"
said

,

;
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

<EOS>
"
Did

"
   
"
Upon

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
sing'ler
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

<EOS>
"
Job
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

;

one
I

ai

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
Sam

<EOS>
"
My

;

.
 
<EOS>
Will

drop
<EOS>
o
'

<EOS>

'
,

<EOS>
Mr

;
and

,

,
where

were

in
discussing

,
formed
by

together
,
in

,
certain

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what

?
"
<EOS>

,

's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bad
,
"
said
Job
,

,
"
very

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Worse

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
some

in

,

,
ai

?
"
<EOS>
Now
,

was

in

imaginable
,
Mr
Job
Trotter
plainly
showed

that

's

to

.
<EOS>
He
emptied

,

,

,

,
and

,
as

;
thereby
intimating
that
he
(
Mr
Trotter
)
considered

as

by
Mr
Samuel
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"
said

,
in

,
"
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
That
is

secret
---
a
great

,
Mr
Walker
.
<EOS>
"
As
the
mulberry
man
said

,

,
by

reminding

companion
that

wherewith
to

.
 
<EOS>
Sam
observed
the
hint
;
and
feeling
the

in

was

,
ordered
the
pewter
vessel
to

,
whereat

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so

's

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
i
suppose
your
mas'r
's
wery
rich
?
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Trotter
smiled
,
and
holding

in

,
gave

on

of

with

,
as

that

master
might

much

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said

,
"
that
's

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
do
n't

,
old
feller
,
"

,
"
<EOS>
that

take
in

,

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

Job

,

<EOS>
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

"

Do

"

;
"
di

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who

?

<EOS>
"

's

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
There

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

Job
,

.
<EOS>
"
We

,
Sir
,

,
Sir
;

,
Sir
,

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

"
an

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,

,
"

,
who

's

,
"
blow
this
'
ere
water
-
cart
bis'ness
.
 
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
do
no

,
this
wo

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"

<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
His

,
"

;
"
and

're

wery
fine
,
and
it

he
should
lose
'em
<EOS>
,
I

'd

keep
'em

,

let

ewaporate
in

,
"
specially
as

.
 
<EOS>
Tears
never
yet

up

clock
,
or
worked

steam
ingin
'
.
 
<EOS>
The
next

,

,

that
'
ere

.
 
<EOS>
"
