you
was
a
tight
-
rope
dancer
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
man
is
in
the
right
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
accosting
Job
,
"
although
his
mode
of
expressing
his
opinion
is
somewhat
homely
,
and
occasionally
incomprehensible
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
sir
,
very
right
,
"
said
Mr
Trotter
,
"
and
I
will
give
way
no
longer
.
"
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
where
is
this
boarding
-
school
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
large
,
old
,
red
brick
house
,
just
outside
the
town
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Job
Trotter
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
---
"
<EOS>
when
is
this
villainous
design
to
be
carried
into
execution
---
<EOS>
when
is
this
elopement
to
take
place
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
very
night
,
sir
,
"
replied
Job
Trotter
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
what
alarms
me
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Instant
measures
must
be
taken
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
see
the
lady
who
keeps
the
establishment
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
said
Job
,
"
but
that
course
of
proceeding
will
never
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
master
,
sir
,
is
a
very
artful
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
he
is
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
he
has
so
wound
himself
round
the
old
lady
's
heart
,
Sir
,
"
resumed
Job
,
"
that
she
would
believe
nothing
to
his
prejudice
,
if
you
went
down
on
your
bare
knees
,
and
swore
it
;
especially
as
you
have
no
proof
but
the
word
of
a
servant
,
who
,
for
anything
she
knows
(
and
my
master
would
be
sure
to
say
so
)
,
was
discharged
for
some
fault
,
and
does
this
in
revenge
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
had
better
be
done
,
then
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nothing
but
taking
him
in
the
very
act
of
eloping
,
will
convince
the
old
lady
,
sir
,
"
replied
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
them
old
cats
WILL
run
their
heads
agin
milestones
,
"
observed
Mr
Weller
,
in
a
parenthesis
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
this
taking
him
in
the
very
act
of
elopement
,
would
be
a
very
difficult
thing
to
accomplish
,
I
fear
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Trotter
,
after
a
few
moments
"
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
might
be
very
easily
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
was
Mr
Pickwick
's
inquiry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
replied
Mr
Trotter
,
"
my
master
and
I
,
being
in
the
confidence
of
the
two
servants
,
will
be
secreted
in
the
kitchen
at
ten
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
family
have
retired
to
rest
,
we
shall
come
out
of
the
kitchen
,
and
the
young
lady
out
of
her
bedroom
.
 
<EOS>
A
post
-
chaise
will
be
waiting
,
and
away
we
go
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
I
have
been
thinking
that
if
you
were
in
waiting
in
the
garden
behind
,
alone
---
"
   
"
Alone
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
alone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
very
natural
,
"
replied
Job
,
"
that
the
old
lady
would
n't
like
such
an
unpleasant
discovery
to
be
made
before
more
persons
than
can
possibly
be
helped
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
lady
,
too
,
sir
---
consider
her
feelings
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
right
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
consideration
evinces
your
delicacy
of
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
;
you
are
very
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
I
have
been
thinking
that
if
you
were
waiting
in
the
back
garden
alone
,
and
I
was
to
let
you
in
,
at
the
door
which
opens
into
it
,
from
the
end
of
the
passage
,
at
exactly
half
-
past
eleven
o'clock
,
you
would
be
just
in
the
very
moment
of
time
to
assist
me
in
frustrating
the
designs
of
this
bad
man
,
by
whom
I
have
been
unfortunately
ensnared
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Trotter
sighed
deeply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
distress
yourself
on
that
account
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
if
he
had
one
grain
of
the
delicacy
of
feeling
which
distinguishes
you
,
humble
as
your
station
is
,
I
should
have
some
hopes
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Job
Trotter
bowed
low
;
and
in
spite
of
Mr
Weller
's
previous
remonstrance
,
the
tears
again
rose
to
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
see
such
a
feller
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
<EOS>
Blessed
if
I
do
n't
think
he
's
got
a
main
in
his
head
as
is
always
turned
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
great
severity
,
"
hold
your
tongue
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
<EOS>
well
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
this
plan
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
deep
meditation
.
<EOS>
"
Why
can
not
I
communicate
with
the
young
lady
's
friends
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
they
live
one
hundred
miles
from
here
,
sir
,
"
responded
Job
Trotter
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
clincher
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
aside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
this
garden
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
am
I
to
get
into
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
wall
is
very
low
,
sir
,
and
your
servant
will
give
you
a
leg
up
.
"
<EOS>
"
My
servant
will
give
me
a
leg
up
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pickwick
mechanically
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
sure
to
be
near
this
door
that
you
speak
of
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
mistake
it
,
Sir
;
it
's
the
only
one
that
opens
into
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Tap
at
it
when
you
hear
the
clock
strike
,
and
I
will
open
it
instantly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
the
plan
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
<EOS>
but
as
I
see
no
other
,
and
as
the
happiness
of
this
young
lady
's
whole
life
is
at
stake
,
I
adopt
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
sure
to
be
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
,
for
the
second
time
,
did
Mr
Pickwick
's
innate
good
-
feeling
involve
him
in
an
enterprise
from
which
he
would
most
willingly
have
stood
aloof
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
name
of
the
house
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Westgate
House
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
turn
a
little
to
the
right
when
you
get
to
the
end
of
the
town
;
it
stands
by
itself
,
some
little
distance
off
the
high
road
,
with
the
name
on
a
brass
plate
on
the
gate
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
observed
it
once
before
,
when
I
was
in
this
town
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
depend
upon
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Trotter
made
another
bow
,
and
turned
to
depart
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
thrust
a
guinea
into
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
fine
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
and
I
admire
your
goodness
of
heart
.
 
<EOS>
No
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
---
eleven
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
fear
of
my
forgetting
it
,
sir
,
"
replied
Job
Trotter
.
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
left
the
room
,
followed
by
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
the
latter
,
"
not
a
bad
notion
that
'
ere
crying
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
cry
like
a
rain
-
water
spout
in
a
shower
on
such
good
terms
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
comes
from
the
heart
,
Mr
Walker
,
"
replied
Job
solemnly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
morning
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
soft
customer
<EOS>
,
you
are
;
we
've
got
it
all
out
<EOS>
o
'
you
,
anyhow
,
"
thought
Mr
Weller
,
as
Job
walked
away
.
   
<EOS>
We
can
not
state
the
precise
nature
of
the
thoughts
which
passed
through
Mr
Trotter
's
mind
,
because
we
do
n't
know
what
they
were
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
wore
on
,
evening
came
,
and
at
a
little
before
ten
o'clock
Sam
Weller
reported
that
Mr
Jingle
and
Job
had
gone
out
together
,
that
their
luggage
was
packed
up
,
and
that
they
had
ordered
a
chaise
.
 
<EOS>
The
plot
was
evidently
in
execution
,
as
Mr
Trotter
had
foretold
.
   
<EOS>
Half
-
past
ten
o'clock
arrived
,
and
it
was
time
for
Mr
Pickwick
to
issue
forth
on
his
delicate
errand
.
 
<EOS>
Resisting
Sam
's
tender
of
his
greatcoat
,
in
order
that
he
might
have
no
encumbrance
in
scaling
the
wall
<EOS>
,
he
set
forth
,
followed
by
his
attendant
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
bright
moon
,
but
it
was
behind
the
clouds
.
 
<EOS>
it
was
a
fine
dry
night
,
but
it
was
most
uncommonly
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Paths
,
hedges
,
fields
,
houses
,
and
trees
,
were
enveloped
in
one
deep
shade
.
 
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
was
hot
and
sultry
,
the
summer
lightning
quivered
faintly
on
the
verge
of
the
horizon
,
and
was
the
only
sight
that
varied
the
dull
gloom
in
which
everything
was
wrapped
 
---
sound
there
was
none
,
except
the
distant
barking
of
some
restless
house
-
dog
.
   
<EOS>
They
found
the
house
,
read
the
brass
plate
,
walked
round
the
wall
,
and
stopped
at
that
portion
of
it
which
divided
them
from
the
bottom
of
the
garden
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
return
to
the
inn
,
Sam
,
when
you
have
assisted
me
over
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
well
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
sit
up
,
till
I
return
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cert'nly
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Take
hold
of
my
leg
;
and
,
when
I
say
"
Over
,
"
raise
me
gently
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
settled
these
preliminaries
,
Mr
Pickwick
grasped
the
top
of
the
wall
,
and
gave
the
word
"
Over
,
"
which
was
literally
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
his
body
partook
in
some
degree
of
the
elasticity
of
his
mind
,
or
whether
Mr
Weller
's
notions
of
a
gentle
push
were
of
a
somewhat
rougher
description
than
Mr
Pickwick
's
,
the
immediate
effect
of
his
assistance
was
to
jerk
that
immortal
gentleman
completely
over
the
wall
on
to
the
bed
<EOS>
beneath
,
where
,
after
crushing
three
gooseberry
-
bushes
and
a
rose
-
tree
,
he
finally
alighted
at
full
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ha'n't
hurt
yourself
,
I
hope
,
Sir
?
"
said
Sam
,
in
a
loud
whisper
,
as
soon
as
he
had
recovered
from
the
surprise
consequent
upon
the
mysterious
disappearance
of
his
master
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
hurt
MYSELF
,
Sam
,
certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
from
the
other
side
of
the
wall
,
"
but
I
rather
think
that
YOU
have
hurt
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
rising
,
"
<EOS>
it
's
nothing
but
a
few
scratches
.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
,
or
we
shall
be
overheard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
stealthy
steps
Sam
Weller
departed
,
leaving
Mr
Pickwick
alone
in
the
garden
.
   
<EOS>
Lights
occasionally
appeared
in
the
different
windows
of
the
house
,
or
glanced
from
the
staircases
,
as
if
the
inmates
were
retiring
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Not
caring
to
go
too
near
the
door
,
until
the
appointed
time
,
Mr
Pickwick
crouched
into
an
angle
of
the
wall
,
and
awaited
its
arrival
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
situation
which
might
well
have
depressed
the
spirits
of
many
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
however
,
felt
neither
depression
nor
misgiving
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
that
his
purpose
was
in
the
main
a
good
one
,
and
he
placed
implicit
reliance
on
the
high
-
minded
Job
.
 
<EOS>
it
was
dull
,
certainly
;
not
to
say
dreary
;
but
a
contemplative
man
can
always
employ
himself
in
meditation
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
meditated
himself
into
a
doze
,
when
he
was
roused
by
the
chimes
of
the
neighbouring
church
ringing
out
the
hour
---
half
-
past
eleven
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
time
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
getting
cautiously
on
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
up
at
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
lights
had
disappeared
,
and
the
shutters
were
closed
---
all
in
bed
,
no
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
He
walked
on
tiptoe
to
the
door
,
and
gave
a
gentle
tap
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
minutes
passing
without
any
reply
,
he
gave
another
tap
rather
louder
,
and
then
another
rather
louder
than
that
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
the
sound
of
feet
was
audible
upon
the
stairs
,
and
then
the
light
of
a
candle
shone
through
the
keyhole
of
the
door
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
deal
of
unchaining
and
unbolting
,
and
the
door
was
slowly
opened
.
   
<EOS>
Now
the
door
opened
outwards
;
and
as
the
door
opened
wider
and
wider
,
Mr
Pickwick
receded
behind
it
,
more
and
more
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
his
astonishment
when
he
just
peeped
out
,
by
way
of
caution
,
to
see
that
the
person
who
had
opened
it
was
---
not
Job
Trotter
,
but
a
servant
-
girl
with
a
candle
in
her
hand
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
drew
in
his
head
again
,
with
the
swiftness
displayed
by
that
admirable
melodramatic
performer
,
Punch
,
when
he
lies
in
wait
for
the
flat
-
headed
comedian
with
the
tin
box
of
music
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
must
have
been
the
cat
,
Sarah
,
"
said
the
girl
,
addressing
herself
to
some
one
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
Puss
,
puss
,
puss
,
---
tit
,
tit
,
tit
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
no
animal
being
decoyed
by
these
blandishments
,
the
girl
slowly
closed
the
door
,
and
re
-
fastened
it
;
leaving
Mr
Pickwick
drawn
up
straight
against
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
curious
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
sitting
up
beyond
their
usual
hour
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
Extremely
unfortunate
,
that
they
should
have
chosen
this
night
,
of
all
others
,
for
such
a
purpose
---
exceedingly
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
these
thoughts
,
Mr
Pickwick
cautiously
retired
to
the
angle
of
the
wall
in
which
he
had
been
before
ensconced
;
waiting
until
such
time
as
he
might
deem
it
safe
to
repeat
the
signal
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
here
five
minutes
,
when
a
vivid
flash
of
lightning
was
followed
by
a
loud
peal
of
thunder
that
crashed
and
rolled
away
in
the
distance
with
a
terrific
noise
---
then
came
another
flash
of
lightning
,
brighter
than
the
other
,
and
a
second
peal
of
thunder
louder
than
the
first
;
and
then
down
came
the
rain
,
with
a
force
and
fury
that
swept
everything
before
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
perfectly
aware
that
a
tree
is
a
very
dangerous
neighbour
in
a
thunderstorm
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
tree
on
his
right
,
a
tree
on
his
left
,
a
third
before
him
,
and
a
fourth
behind
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
remained
where
he
was
,
he
might
fall
the
victim
of
an
accident
;
if
he
showed
himself
in
the
centre
of
the
garden
,
he
might
be
consigned
to
a
constable
.
 
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
he
tried
to
scale
the
wall
,
but
having
no
other
legs
this
time
,
than
those
with
which
Nature
had
furnished
him
,
the
only
effect
of
his
struggles
was
to
inflict
a
variety
of
very
unpleasant
gratings
on
his
knees
and
shins
,
and
to
throw
him
into
a
state
of
the
most
profuse
perspiration
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
dreadful
situation
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
pausing
to
wipe
his
brow
after
this
exercise
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
up
at
the
house
---
all
was
dark
.
 
<EOS>
They
must
be
gone
to
bed
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
try
the
signal
again
.
   
<EOS>
He
walked
on
tiptoe
across
the
moist
gravel
,
and
tapped
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
his
breath
,
and
listened
at
the
key
-
hole
.
 
<EOS>
No
reply
:
very
odd
.
 
<EOS>
Another
knock
.
 
<EOS>
He
listened
again
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
low
whispering
inside
,
and
then
a
voice
cried
---
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
Job
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
hastily
drawing
himself
straight
up
against
the
wall
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
woman
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
had
time
to
form
this
conclusion
,
when
a
window
above
stairs
was
thrown
up
,
and
three
or
four
female
voices
repeated
the
query
---
"
Who
's
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
dared
not
move
hand
or
foot
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
clear
that
the
whole
establishment
was
roused
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
up
his
mind
to
remain
where
he
was
,
until
the
alarm
had
subsided
;
and
then
by
a
supernatural
effort
,
to
get
over
the
wall
,
or
perish
in
the
attempt
.
   
<EOS>
Like
all
Mr
Pickwick
's
determinations
,
this
was
the
best
that
could
be
made
under
the
circumstances
;
but
,
unfortunately
,
it
was
founded
upon
the
assumption
that
they
would
not
venture
to
open
the
door
again
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
his
discomfiture
,
when
he
heard
the
chain
and
bolts
withdrawn
,
and
saw
the
door
slowly
opening
,
wider
and
wider
!
 
<EOS>
He
retreated
into
the
corner
,
step
by
step
;
but
do
what
he
would
,
the
interposition
of
his
own
person
,
prevented
its
being
opened
to
its
utmost
width
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
screamed
a
numerous
chorus
of
treble
voices
from
the
staircase
inside
,
consisting
of
the
spinster
lady
of
the
establishment
,
three
teachers
,
five
female
servants
,
and
thirty
boarders
,
all
half
-
dressed
and
in
a
forest
of
curl
-
papers
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
Mr
Pickwick
did
n't
say
who
was
there
:
and
then
the
burden
of
the
chorus
changed
into
<EOS>
---
"
Lor
!
<EOS>
I
am
so
frightened
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cook
,
"
said
the
lady
abbess
,
who
took
care
to
be
on
the
top
stair
,
the
very
last
of
the
group
---
"
cook
,
why
do
n't
you
go
a
little
way
into
the
garden
?
"
<EOS>
"
Please
,
ma'am
,
I
do
n't
like
,
"
responded
the
cook
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
what
a
stupid
thing
that
cook
is
!
"
said
the
thirty
boarders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cook
,
"
said
the
lady
abbess
,
with
great
dignity
;
"
do
n't
answer
me
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
insist
upon
your
looking
into
the
garden
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
cook
began
to
cry
,
and
the
housemaid
said
it
was
"
a
shame
!
"
<EOS>
for
which
partisanship
she
received
a
month
's
warning
on
the
spot
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
,
cook
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
lady
abbess
,
stamping
her
foot
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
hear
your
missis
,
cook
?
"
said
the
three
teachers
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
an
impudent
thing
that
cook
is
!
"
said
the
thirty
boarders
.
   
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
cook
,
thus
strongly
urged
,
advanced
a
step
or
two
,
and
holding
her
candle
just
where
it
prevented
her
from
seeing
at
all
,
declared
there
was
nothing
there
,
and
it
must
have
been
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
just
going
to
be
closed
in
consequence
,
when
an
inquisitive
boarder
,
who
had
been
peeping
between
the
hinges
,
set
up
a
fearful
screaming
,
which
called
back
the
cook
and
housemaid
,
and
all
the
more
adventurous
,
in
no
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
with
Miss
Smithers
?
"
said
the
lady
abbess
,
as
the
aforesaid
Miss
Smithers
proceeded
to
go
into
hysterics
of
four
young
lady
power
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
Miss
Smithers
,
dear
,
"
said
the
other
nine
-
and
-
twenty
boarders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
the
man
---
the
man
---
behind
the
door
!
"
screamed
Miss
Smithers
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
abbess
no
sooner
heard
this
appalling
cry
,
than
she
retreated
to
her
own
bedroom
,
double
-
locked
the
door
,
and
fainted
away
comfortably
.
 
<EOS>
The
boarders
,
and
the
teachers
,
and
the
servants
,
fell
back
upon
the
stairs
,
and
upon
each
other
;
and
never
was
such
a
screaming
,
and
fainting
,
and
struggling
beheld
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
tumult
,
Mr
Pickwick
emerged
from
his
concealment
,
and
presented
himself
amongst
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ladies
---
dear
ladies
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
.
 
<EOS>
he
says
we
're
dear
,
"
cried
the
oldest
and
ugliest
teacher
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
the
wretch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ladies
,
"
roared
Mr
Pickwick
,
rendered
desperate
by
the
danger
of
his
situation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
no
robber
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
the
lady
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
a
ferocious
monster
!
<EOS>
"
screamed
another
teacher
.
"
<EOS>
He
wants
Miss
Tomkins
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
there
was
a
general
scream
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ring
the
alarm
bell
,
somebody
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
dozen
voices
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
---
do
n't
,
"
shouted
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
look
like
a
robber
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
ladies
---
you
may
bind
me
hand
and
leg
,
or
lock
me
up
in
a
closet
,
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
Only
hear
what
I
have
got
to
say
---
only
hear
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
did
you
come
in
our
garden
?
"
<EOS>
faltered
the
housemaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
Call
the
lady
of
the
house
,
and
I
'll
tell
her
everything
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
exerting
his
lungs
to
the
utmost
pitch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Call
her
---
only
be
quiet
,
and
call
her
,
and
you
shall
hear
everything
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
Mr
Pickwick
's
appearance
,
or
it
might
have
been
his
manner
,
or
it
might
have
been
the
temptation
---
irresistible
to
a
female
mind
---
of
hearing
something
at
present
enveloped
in
mystery
,
that
reduced
the
more
reasonable
portion
of
the
establishment
(
some
four
individuals
)
to
a
state
of
comparative
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
By
them
it
was
proposed
,
as
a
test
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
sincerity
,
that
he
should
immediately
submit
to
personal
restraint
;
and
that
gentleman
having
consented
to
hold
a
conference
with
Miss
Tomkins
,
from
the
interior
of
a
closet
in
which
the
day
boarders
hung
their
bonnets
and
sandwich
-
bags
,
he
at
once
stepped
into
it
,
of
his
own
accord
,
and
was
securely
locked
in
.
 
<EOS>
This
revived
the
others
;
and
Miss
Tomkins
having
been
brought
to
,
and
brought
down
,
the
conference
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
do
in
my
garden
,
man
?
"
said
Miss
Tomkins
,
in
a
faint
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
to
warn
you
that
one
of
your
young
ladies
was
going
to
elope
to
-
night
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
from
the
interior
of
the
closet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Elope
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Tomkins
,
the
three
teachers
,
the
thirty
boarders
,
and
the
five
servants
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
with
?
"
<EOS>
"
Your
friend
,
Mr
Charles
Fitz
-
Marshall
.
"
   
"
MY
friend
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
any
such
person
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr
Jingle
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
the
name
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
I
have
been
deceived
,
and
deluded
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
the
victim
of
a
conspiracy
---
a
foul
and
base
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
Send
to
the
Angel
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
if
you
do
n't
believe
me
.
<EOS>
Send
to
the
Angel
for
Mr
Pickwick
's
manservant
,
I
implore
you
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
respectable
---
he
keeps
a
manservant
,
"
said
Miss
Tomkins
to
the
writing
and
ciphering
governess
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
opinion
,
Miss
Tomkins
,
"
said
the
writing
and
ciphering
governess
,
"
that
his
manservant
keeps
him
<EOS>
,
I
think
he
's
a
madman
,
Miss
Tomkins
,
and
the
other
's
his
keeper
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
are
very
right
,
Miss
Gwynn
,
"
responded
Miss
Tomkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
two
of
the
servants
repair
to
the
Angel
,
and
let
the
others
remain
here
,
to
protect
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
two
of
the
servants
were
despatched
to
the
Angel
in
search
of
Mr
Samuel
Weller
;
and
the
remaining
three
stopped
behind
to
protect
Miss
Tomkins
,
and
the
three
teachers
,
and
the
thirty
boarders
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Pickwick
sat
down
in
the
closet
,
beneath
a
grove
of
sandwich
-
bags
,
and
awaited
the
return
of
the
messengers
,
with
all
the
philosophy
and
fortitude
he
could
summon
to
his
aid
.
   
<EOS>
An
hour
and
a
half
elapsed
before
they
came
back
,
and
when
they
did
come
<EOS>
,
Mr
Pickwick
recognised
,
in
addition
to
the
voice
of
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
two
other
voices
,
the
tones
of
which
struck
familiarly
on
his
ear
;
but
whose
they
were
,
he
could
not
for
the
life
of
him
call
to
mind
.
   
<EOS>
A
very
brief
conversation
ensued
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
unlocked
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
stepped
out
of
the
closet
,
and
found
himself
in
the
presence
of
the
whole
establishment
of
Westgate
House
,
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
and
---
old
Wardle
,
and
his
destined
son
-
in
-
law
,
Mr
Trundle
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
running
forward
and
grasping
Wardle
's
hand
,
"
my
dear
friend
,
pray
,
for
Heaven
's
sake
,
explain
to
this
lady
the
unfortunate
and
dreadful
situation
in
which
I
am
placed
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
have
heard
it
from
my
servant
;
say
,
at
all
events
,
<EOS>
my
dear
fellow
,
that
I
am
neither

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have

so
,

friend
.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

,
"
says
that

,

,

,

the

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

Chapter
17
.
<EOS>
Showing
that
an
attack
of
rheumatism
,
in
some
cases
,
acts
as
a
quickener
to
inventive
genius
 
<EOS>
The
constitution
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
though
able
to
sustain
a
very
considerable
amount
of
exertion
and
fatigue
,
was
not
proof
against
such
a
combination
of

as
he
had
undergone
on
the
memorable
night
,
recorded
in
the
last
chapter
.
 
<EOS>
The
process
of
being
washed
in
the
night
air
,
and
rough
-
dried
in
a
closet
,
is
as
dangerous
as
it
is
peculiar
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
laid
up
with
an
attack
of
rheumatism
.
   
<EOS>
But
although
the
bodily
powers
of
the
great
man
were
thus
impaired
,
his
mental
energies
retained
their
pristine
vigour
.
 
<EOS>
His
spirits
were
elastic
;
his
good
-
humour
was
restored
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
vexation
consequent
upon
his
recent
adventure
had
vanished
from
his
mind
;
and
he
could
join
in
the
hearty

,
which
any

to
it
excited
in
Mr
Wardle
,
without
anger
and
without

.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
more
.
 
<EOS>
During

two
days
Mr
Pickwick
was
confined
to
bed
,
Sam
was
his
constant
attendant
.
<EOS>
On
the
first
,
he
endeavoured
to
amuse

master
by
anecdote
and

;
on
the
second
,
Mr
Pickwick
demanded
his
writing
-
desk
,
and
pen
and
ink
,
and
was
deeply
engaged
during
the
whole

.
 
<EOS>
On
the
third
,
being
able
to

in

,

despatched
his
valet
with

to

and

,
intimating
that
if

wine
there
,
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

was
most

;
and

over

,
Mr

,

,
produced
the
following
little

,
as

"
edited
"
by

,
during

,
from
his

of

's

.
  
<EOS>
The
Parish
Clerk
  
<EOS>
A
Tale
of
True
Love
    
"
Once
upon
a
time
,
in
a
very
small
country
town
,
at
a
considerable
distance
from
London
,
there
lived
a
little
man
named
Nathaniel
Pipkin
,
who
was
the
parish
clerk
of
the
little
town
,
and
lived
in
a
little
house
in
the
little
High
Street
,
within
ten
minutes
"
walk
from
the
little
church
;
and
who
was
to
be
found
every
day
,
from
nine
till
four
,
teaching
a
little
learning
to
the
little
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Nathaniel
Pipkin
was
a
harmless
,
inoffensive
,
good
-
natured
being
,
with
a
turned
-
up
nose
,
and
rather
turned
-
in
legs
,
a
cast
in
his
eye
,
and
a
halt
in
his
gait
;
and
he
divided
his
time
between
the
church
and
his
school
,
verily
believing
that
there
existed
not
,
on
the
face
of
the
earth
,
so
clever
a
man
as
the
curate
,
<EOS>
so
imposing
an
apartment
as
the
vestry
-
room
,
or
so
well
-
ordered
a
seminary
as
his
own
.
<EOS>
Once
,
and
only
once
,
in
his
life
,
Nathaniel
Pipkin
had
seen
a
bishop
---
a
real
bishop
,
with
his
arms
in
lawn
sleeves
,
and
his
head
in
a
wig
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
seen
him
walk
,
and
heard
him
talk
,
at
a
confirmation
,
on
which
momentous
occasion
<EOS>
Nathaniel
Pipkin
was
so
overcome
with
reverence
and
awe
,
when
the
aforesaid
bishop
laid
his
hand
on
his
head
,
that
he
fainted
right
clean
away
,
and
was
borne
out
of
church
in
the
arms
of
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
was
a
great
event
,
a
tremendous
era
,
in
Nathaniel
Pipkin
's
life
,
and
it
was
the
only
one
that
had
ever
occurred
to
ruffle
the
smooth
current
of
his
quiet
existence
,
when
happening
one
fine
afternoon
,
in
a
fit
of
mental
abstraction
,
to
raise
his
eyes
from
the
slate
on
which
he
was
devising
some
tremendous
problem
in
compound
addition
for
an
offending
urchin
to
solve
,
they
suddenly
rested
on
the
blooming
countenance
of
Maria
Lobbs
,
the
only
daughter
of
old
Lobbs
,
the
great
saddler
over
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
eyes
of
Mr
Pipkin
had
rested
on
the
pretty
face
of
Maria
Lobbs
many
a
time
and
oft
before
,
at
church
and
elsewhere
;
but
the
eyes
of
Maria
Lobbs
had
never
looked
so
bright
,
the
cheeks
of
Maria
Lobbs
had
never
looked
so
ruddy
,
as
upon
this
particular
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
No
wonder
then
,
that
Nathaniel
Pipkin
was
unable
to
take
his
eyes
from
the
countenance
of
Miss
Lobbs
;
no
wonder
that
Miss
Lobbs
,
finding
herself
stared
at
by
a
young
man
,
withdrew
her
head
from
the
window
out
of
which
she
had
been
peeping
,
and
shut
the
casement
and
pulled
down
the
blind
;
no
wonder
that
Nathaniel
Pipkin
,
immediately
thereafter
,
fell
upon
the
young
urchin
who
had
previously
offended
,
and
cuffed
and
knocked
him
about
to
his
heart
's
content
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
very
natural
,
and
there
's
nothing
at
all
to
wonder
at
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
IS
matter
of
wonder
,
though
,
that
anyone
of
Mr
Nathaniel
Pipkin
's
retiring
disposition
,
nervous
temperament
,
and
most
particularly
diminutive
income
,
should
from
this
day
forth
,
have
dared
to
aspire
to
the
hand
and
heart
of
the
only
daughter
of
the
fiery
old
Lobbs
---
of
old
Lobbs
,
the
great
saddler
,
who
could
have
bought
up
the
whole
village
at
one
stroke
of
his
pen
,
and
never
felt
the
outlay
---
<EOS>
old
Lobbs
,
who
was
well
known
to
have
heaps
of
money
,
invested
in
the
bank
at
the
nearest
market
town
---
who
was
reported
to
have
countless
and
inexhaustible
treasures
hoarded
up
in
the
little
iron
safe
with
the
big
keyhole
,
over
the
chimney
-
piece
in
the
back
parlour
---
and
who
,
it
was
well
known
,
on
festive
occasions
garnished
his
board
with
a
real
silver
teapot
,
cream
-
ewer
,
and
sugar
-
basin
,
which
he
was
wo
nt
,
in
the
pride
of
his
heart
,
to
boast
should
be
his
daughter
's
property
when
she
found
a
man
to
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
repeat
it
,
to
be
matter
of
profound
astonishment
and
intense
wonder
,
that
Nathaniel
Pipkin
should
have
had
the
temerity
to
cast
his
eyes
in
this
direction
.
 
<EOS>
But
love
is
blind
;
and
Nathaniel
had
a
cast
in
his
eye
;
and
perhaps
these
two
circumstances
,
taken
together
,
prevented
his
seeing
the
matter
in
its
proper
light
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
if
old
Lobbs
had
entertained
the
most
remote
or
distant
idea
of
the
state
of
the
affections
of
Nathaniel
Pipkin
,
he
would
just
have
razed
the
school
-
room
to
the
ground
,
or
exterminated
its
master
from
the
surface
of
the
earth
,
or
committed
some
other
outrage
and
atrocity
of
an
equally
ferocious
and
violent
description
;
for
he
was
a
terrible
old
fellow
,
was
Lobbs
,
when
his
pride
was
injured
,
or
his
blood
was
up
.
 
<EOS>
Swear
!
 
<EOS>
Such
trains
of
oaths
would
come
rolling
and
pealing
over
the
way
,
sometimes
,
when
he
was
denouncing
the
idleness
of
the
bony
apprentice
with
the
thin
legs
,
that
Nathaniel
Pipkin
would
shake
in
his
shoes
with
horror
,
and
the
hair
of
the
pupils
"
heads
would
stand
on
end
with
fright
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Day
after
day
,
when
school
was
over
,
and
the
pupils
gone
<EOS>
,
did
Nathaniel
Pipkin
sit
himself
down
at
the
front
window
,
and
,
while
he
feigned
to
be
reading
a
book
,
throw
sidelong

over
the
way
in
search
of
the
bright
eyes
of
Maria
Lobbs
;
and
he
had
n't
sat
there
many
days
,
before
the
bright
eyes
appeared
at
an
upper
window
,
apparently
deeply
engaged
in
reading
too
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
delightful
,
and
gladdening
to
the
heart
of
Nathaniel
Pipkin
.
<EOS>
It
was
something
to
sit
there
for
hours
together
,
and
look
upon
that
pretty
face
when
the
eyes
were
cast
down
;
but
when
Maria
Lobbs
began
to
raise
her
eyes
from
her
book
,
and
dart
their
rays
in
the
direction
of
Nathaniel
Pipkin
,
his
delight
and
admiration
were
perfectly
boundless
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
day
when
he
knew
old
Lobbs
was
out
,
Nathaniel
Pipkin
had
the
temerity
to
kiss
his
hand
to
Maria
Lobbs
;
and
Maria
Lobbs
,
instead
of
shutting
the
window
,
and
pulling
down
the
blind
,
kissed
HERS
to
him
,
and
smiled
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
Nathaniel
Pipkin
determined
,
that
,
come
what
might
,
he
would
develop
the
state
of
his
feelings
,
without
further
delay
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
prettier
foot
,
a
gayer
heart
,
a
more
dimpled
face
,
or
a
smarter
form
,
never
bounded
so
lightly
over
the
earth
they
graced
,
as
did
those
of
Maria
Lobbs
,
the
old
saddler
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
roguish
twinkle
in
her
sparkling
eyes
,
that
would
have
made
its
way
to
far
less
susceptible
bosoms
than
that
of
Nathaniel
Pipkin
;
and
there
was
such
a
joyous
sound
in
her
merry
laugh
,
that
the
sternest
misanthrope
must
have
smiled
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Even
old
Lobbs
himself
,
in
the
very
height
of
his
ferocity
,
could
n't
resist
the
coaxing
of
his
pretty
daughter
;
and
when
she
,
and
her
cousin
Kate
---
an
arch
,
impudent
-
looking
,
bewitching
little
person
---
made
a
dead
set
upon
the
old
man
together
,
as
,
to
say
the
truth
,
they
very
often
did
<EOS>
,
he
could
have
refused
them
nothing
,
even
had
they
asked
for
a
portion
of
the
countless
and
inexhaustible
treasures
,
which
were
hidden
from
the
light
,
in
the
iron
safe
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nathaniel
Pipkin
's
heart
beat
high
within
him
,
when
he
saw
this
enticing
little
couple
<EOS>
some
hundred
yards
before
him
one
summer
's
evening
,
in
the
very
field
in
which
he
had
many
a
time
strolled
about
till
night
-
time
,
and
pondered
on
the
beauty
of
Maria
Lobbs
.
 
<EOS>
But
though
he
had
often
thought
then
,
how
briskly
he
would
walk
up
to
Maria
Lobbs
and
tell
her
of
his
passion
if
he
could
only
meet
her
,
he
felt
,
now
that
she
was
unexpectedly
before
him
,
all
the
blood
in
his
body
mounting
to
his
face
,
manifestly
to
the
great
detriment
of
his
legs
,
which
,
deprived
of
their
usual
portion
,
trembled
beneath
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
stopped
to
gather
a
hedge
flower
,
or
listen
to
a
bird
,
Nathaniel
Pipkin
stopped
too
,
and
pretended
to
be
absorbed
in
meditation
,
as
indeed
he
really
was
;
for
he
was
thinking
what
on
earth
he
should
ever
do
,
when
they
turned
back
,
as
they
inevitably
must
in
time
,
and
meet
him
face
to
face
.
 
<EOS>
But
though
he
was
afraid
to
make
up
to
them
,
he
could
n't
bear
to
lose
sight
of
them
;
so
when
they
walked
faster
he
walked
faster
,
when
they
lingered
he
lingered
,
and
when
they
stopped
he
stopped
;
and
so
they
might
have
gone
on
,
until
the
darkness
prevented
them
,
if
Kate
had
not

,
and

Nathaniel
to
advance
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
Kate
's
manner
that
was
not
to
be
resisted
,
and
so
Nathaniel
Pipkin
complied
with
the

;
and
after

on
his
part
,
and
immoderate
laughter
on
that
of
the
wicked
little
cousin
,
Nathaniel
Pipkin
went
down
on
his

on
the

,
and
declared

to
remain
there
for
ever
,
unless
he
were
permitted
to
rise
the
accepted
lover
of
Maria
Lobbs
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
merry

of
Miss
Lobbs
rang
through
the
calm
evening
air
---
without
seeming
to
disturb
it
,
though
;
it
had
such

pleasant

---
and
the
wicked
little
cousin
laughed
more

than
before
,
and
Nathaniel
Pipkin
blushed

than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
Maria
Lobbs
being
more
strenuously
urged
by
the
love

little
man
,
turned
away
her
head
,
and
whispered
her
cousin
to
say
,
or
at
all
events
Kate
did

,
that

felt
much

Mr

;
that

's

;
but
that
nobody
could

's

.
 
<EOS>
As
all
this
was
said
with
much

and
as

Maria
Lobbs
,

,
he
went
to
bed
a
happy
man
,
and
dreamed
all
night
long
,
of
softening
old
Lobbs
,
opening
the
strong
box
,
and
marrying
Maria
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
day
,
Nathaniel
Pipkin
saw
old
Lobbs
go
out
upon
his
old
gray

,
and
after
a
great
many
signs
at
the
window
from
the
wicked
little
cousin
,
the
object
and
meaning
of
which
he
could
by
no

understand
,
the
bony

with
the

came

that

was
n't
coming
home
all

,
and
that

expected
Mr

to
tea
,
at
six

precisely
.
 
<EOS>
How
the

were
got
through

,
neither
Nathaniel

nor
his
pupils
knew
any
more
than
you
do
;
but

got
through
somehow
,
and
,

,
Nathaniel
Pipkin
took
till
full

to
dress

.
 
<EOS>
Not

,
<EOS>
inasmuch

he
had

;
but

the

,

<EOS>
"
There
was

very

,

and
her

Kate
,

.
 
<EOS>
Nathaniel

had
ocular

of
the

,
that
the

of
old
Lobbs
's

.
 
<EOS>
There

the
real

,

-

,
and

-

,
on

,

to

,

,
and
plates

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
only

-

another

Maria

's
,
and

Kate
,

"
Henry
,
"
and
who
seemed
to

Maria

up

.
<EOS>
It
's

,
but
it
may

carried
rather

,
and
Nathaniel

,

<EOS>
After

,

,

's

,
it
somehow

other

that
Nathaniel
Pipkin
was
nearly

,

male

,

was
sure

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

;

---
Nathaniel

could

.
 
<EOS>
All

---

---

,
in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,

the

no

old
Lobbs
himself
,
who
had
unexpectedly

,
and
was

,
like

;
for
he
wanted
his

.
 
<EOS>
The

was
no

,

,

to

,
who
had

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
it

that
old

being
very
hungry
was

cross
.
 
<EOS>
Nathaniel
Pipkin
could
hear

away
like

old

;
and

,

,

<EOS>
At

,

,

,
and

fell
to
,
in

;
and
having

work
of
it
in
no

,
kissed
his
daughter
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nature
had
placed
Nathaniel
Pipkin
's
knees
in
very
close

,
but
when
he

Lobbs

his
pipe
,

,

,

seen
in

,
regularly
every

,
for

.
 
<EOS>
The
two
girls
went
downstairs
for
the

,
and
upstairs
for
the
pipe
,
and
everywhere
but
where

knew
the
pipe
was
,
and
old
Lobbs
stormed
away

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
thought
of
the
closet
,
and
walked
up
to

.
 
<EOS>
It

of
no
use
a

like
Nathaniel

pulling

,
when

.
 
<EOS>
Old

,

open

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bless
us
!
<EOS>
what
an
appalling
look
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Why
,

do

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nathaniel

could

,

,

<EOS>
"
"
What

?
"
<EOS>
roared

<EOS>
;
"
I

have

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Old

.
 
<EOS>
What

,

---
"
"
Yes
,
I

,

Lobbs
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"

"

?
 
Say

!
 
<EOS>
Damme
,

"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

not

a
hair
of

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
old

,

daughter
.
 
<EOS>
I

once

,
that

very

,
and
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Old
Lobbs
turned

,
as

by

,
when
,
as

,

,

her

,
and
half

at
Nathaniel
Pipkin
,
presented
as
bewitching
an

countenance
,
with

,
too
,
as

old

,
need

.
 
<EOS>
She

's
,

;
and
do
what

would
,
old

could

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Five

;

;

<EOS>
"
Nathaniel

.
 
<EOS>
who

<EOS>

.
"
    
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
Briefly
illustrative
of
two
points
;
first
,
the
power
of

,
and
,

,
the
force
of
circumstances
 
For
two

after
the
DEJEUNE
at
Mrs
Hunter
's
,
the
Pickwickians
remained
at
Eatanswill
,
anxiously

the
arrival
of
some
intelligence
from
their
revered

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
were
once
again
left
to
their
own
means
of

;
for
Mr
Winkle
,
in

most

,
continued
to
reside
at
Mr

's

,
and

to

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

of
Mr

himself
wanting
to

.
<EOS>
Deeply

in

for
the

and
the

of
the
INDEPENDENT
,

not
the

of
that
great
man
to

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

,

,

,

,
and
seeming

,
if

.
   
<EOS>
Such

Mr

,
it
will

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

"
Serpent
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Serpent
,
Sir
,
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
So

,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
bodyguard
.
   
<EOS>
Pott
looked
very
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
time
to
finish
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
sobbed
Mrs
Pott
,
"
now
,
after
all
,
to
be
treated
in
this
way
;
to
be
reproached
and
insulted
in
the
presence
of
a
third
party
,
and
that
party
almost
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
submit
to
it
!
 
<EOS>
Goodwin
,
"
continued
Mrs
Pott
,
raising
herself
in
the
arms
of
her
attendant
,
"
my
brother
,
the
lieutenant
,
shall
interfere
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
be
separated
,
Goodwin
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
certainly
serve
him
right
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Goodwin
.
   
<EOS>
Whatever
thoughts
the
threat
of
a
separation
might
have
awakened
in
Mr
Pott
's
mind
,
he
forbore
to
give
utterance
to
them
,
and
contented
himself
by
saying
,
with
great
humility
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
will
you
hear
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
A
fresh
train
of
sobs
was
the
only
reply
,
as
Mrs
Pott
grew
more
hysterical
,
requested
to
be
informed
why
she
was
ever
born
,
and
required
sundry
other
pieces
of
information
of
a
similar
description
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
remonstrated
Mr
Pott
,
"
do
not
give
way
to
these
sensitive
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
believed
that
the
paragraph
had
any
foundation
,
my
dear
---
impossible
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
only
angry
,
my
dear
---
I
may
say
outrageous
---
with
the
INDEPENDENT
people
for
daring
to
insert
it
;
that
's
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pott
cast
an
imploring
look
at
the
innocent
cause
of
the
mischief
,
as
if
to
entreat
him
to
say
nothing
about
the
serpent
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
steps
,
sir
,
do
you
mean
to
take
to
obtain
redress
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
gaining
courage
as
he
saw
Pott
losing
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Goodwin
<EOS>
,
"
observed
Mrs
Pott
,
"
does
he
mean
to
horsewhip
the
editor
of
the
INDEPENDENT
---
<EOS>
does
he
,
Goodwin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
hush
,
ma'am
;
pray
keep
yourself
quiet
,
"
replied
the
bodyguard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
he
will
,
if
you
wish
it
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Pott
,
as
his
wife
evinced
decided
symptoms
of
going
off
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
shall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
,
Goodwin
---
when
?
"
said
Mrs
Pott
,
still
undecided
about
the
going
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
Immediately
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mr
Pott
;
"
before
the
day
is
out
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Goodwin
,
"
resumed
Mrs
Pott
,
"
it
's
the
only
way
of
meeting
the
slander
,
and
setting
me
right
with
the
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Goodwin
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
man
as
is
a
man
,
ma'am
,
could
refuse
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
,
as
the
hysterics
were
still
hovering
about
,
Mr
Pott
said
once
more
that
he
would
do
it
;
but
Mrs
Pott
was
so
overcome
at
the
bare
idea
of
having
ever
been
suspected
,
that
she
was
half
a
dozen
times
on
the
very
verge
of
a
relapse
,
and
most
unquestionably
would
have
gone
off
,
had
it
not
been
for
the
indefatigable
efforts
of
the
assiduous
Goodwin
,
and
repeated
entreaties
for
pardon
from
the
conquered
Pott
;
and
finally
,
when
that
unhappy
individual
had
been
frightened
and
snubbed
down
to
his
proper
level
,
Mrs
Pott
recovered
,
and
they
went
to
breakfast
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
allow
this
base
newspaper
slander
to
shorten
your
stay
here
,
Mr
Winkle
?
"
said
Mrs
Pott
,
smiling
through
the
traces
of
her
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
Mr
Pott
,
actuated
,
as
he
spoke
,
by
a
wish
that
his
visitor
would
choke
himself
with
the
morsel
of
dry
toast
which
he
was
raising
to
his
lips
at
the
moment
,
and
so
terminate
his
stay
effectually
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
;
"
but
a
letter
has
been
received
from
Mr
Pickwick
---
so
I
learn
by
a
note
from
Mr
Tupman
,
which
was
brought
up
to
my
bedroom
door
,
this
morning
---
in
which
he
requests
us
to
join
him
at
Bury
to
-
day
;
and
we
are
to
leave
by
the
coach
at
noon
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
come
back
?
"
said
Mrs
Pott
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
sure
?
"
said
Mrs
Pott
,
stealing
a
tender
look
at
her
visitor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
,
"
responded
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
The
breakfast
passed
off
in
silence
,
for
each
of
the
party
was
brooding
over
his
,
or
her
,
own
personal
grievances
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Pott
was
regretting
the
loss
of
a
beau
;
Mr
Pott
his
rash
pledge
to
horsewhip
the
INDEPENDENT
;
Mr
Winkle
his
having
innocently
placed
himself
in
so
awkward
a
situation
.
 
<EOS>
Noon
approached
,
and
after
many
adieux
and
promises
to
return
,
he
tore
himself
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
ever
comes
back
,
I
'll
poison
him
,
"
thought
Mr
Pott
,
as
he
turned
into
the
little
back
office
where
he
prepared
his
thunderbolts
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
ever
do
come
back
,
and
mix
myself
up
with
these
people
again
,
"
thought
Mr
Winkle
,
as
he
wended
his
way
to
the
Peacock
,
"
I
shall
deserve
to
be
horsewhipped
myself
---
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
friends
were
ready
,
the
coach
was
nearly
so
,
and
in
half
an
hour
they
were
proceeding
on
their
journey
,
along
the
road
over
which
Mr
Pickwick
and
Sam
had
so
recently
travelled
,
and
of
which
,
as
we
have
already
said
something
,
we
do
not
feel
called
upon
to
extract
Mr
Snodgrass
's
poetical
and
beautiful
description
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
was
standing
at
the
door
of
the
Angel
,
ready
to
receive
them
,
and
by
that
gentleman
they
were
ushered
to
the
apartment
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
where
,
to
the
no
small
surprise
of
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
the
no
small
embarrassment
of
Mr
Tupman
,
they
found
old
Wardle
and
Trundle
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
?
"
said
the
old
man
,
grasping
Mr
Tupman
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
hang
back
,
or
look
sentimental
about
it
;
it
ca
n't
be
helped
,
old
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
For
her
sake
,
I
wish
you
'd
had
her
;
for
your
own
,
I
'm
very
glad
you
have
not
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
fellow
like
you
will
do
better
one
of
these
days
,
eh
?
"
<EOS>
With
this
conclusion
,
Wardle
slapped
Mr
Tupman
on
the
back
,
and
laughed
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
how
are
you
,
my
fine
fellows
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
shaking
hands
with
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
been
telling
Pickwick
that
we
must
have
you
all
down
at
Christmas
.
 
<EOS>
We
're
going
to
have
a
wedding
---
<EOS>
a
real
wedding
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
wedding
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Snodgrass
,
turning
very
pale
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
a
wedding
.
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
be
frightened
,
"
said
the
good
-
humoured
old
man
;
"
it
's
only
Trundle
there
,
and
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is
that
all
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
relieved
from
a
painful
doubt
which
had
fallen
heavily
on
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
you
joy
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
How
is
Joe
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sleepy
as
ever
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
your
mother
,
and
the
clergyman
,
and
all
of
'
em
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
well
.
"
   
"
Where
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
with
an
effort
---
<EOS>
"
where
is
---
SHE
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
and
he
turned
away
his
head
,
and
covered
his
eyes
with
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
SHE
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
with
a
knowing
shake
of
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
my
single
relative
---
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
by
a
nod
,
intimated
that
his
question
applied
to
the
disappointed
Rachael
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
she
's
gone
away
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
living
at
a
relation
's
,
far
enough
off
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
n't
bear
to
see
the
girls
,
so
I
let
her
go
.
 
<EOS>
But
come
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
be
hungry
after
your
ride
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
,
without
any
ride
at
all
;
so
let
us
fall
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ample
justice
was
done
to
the
meal
;
and
when
they
were
seated
round
the
table
,
after
it
had
been
disposed
of
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
to
the
intense
horror
and
indignation
of
his
followers
,
related
the
adventure
he
had
undergone
,
and
the
success
which
had
attended
the
base
artifices
of
the
diabolical
Jingle
.
"
<EOS>
And
the
attack
of
rheumatism
which
I
caught
in
that
garden
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
conclusion
,
"
renders
me
lame
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
too
,
have
had
something
of
an
adventure
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
with
a
smile
;
and
,
at
the
request
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
he
detailed
the
malicious
libel
of
the
Eatanswill
INDEPENDENT
,
and
the
consequent
excitement
of
their
friend
,
the
editor
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
brow
darkened
during
the
recital
.
 
<EOS>
His
friends
observed
it
,
and
,
when
Mr
Winkle
had
concluded
,
maintained
a
profound
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
struck
the
table
emphatically
with
his
clenched
fist
,
and
spoke
as
follows
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
a
wonderful
circumstance
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
we
seem
destined
to
enter
no
man
's
house
without
involving
him
in
some
degree
of
trouble
?
 
<EOS>
Does
it
not
,
I
ask
,
bespeak
the
indiscretion
,
or
,
worse
than
that
,
the
blackness
of
heart
---
that
I
should
say
so
!
<EOS>
---
of
my
followers
,
that
,
beneath
whatever
roof
they
locate
,
they
disturb
the
peace
of
mind
and
happiness
of
some
confiding
female
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
,
I
say
---
"
   
Mr
Pickwick
would
in
all
probability
have
gone
on
for
some
time
,
had
not
the
entrance
of
Sam
,
with
a
letter
,
caused
him
to
break
off
in
his
eloquent
discourse
.
 
<EOS>
He
passed
his
handkerchief
across
his
forehead
,
took
off
his
spectacles
,
wiped
them
,
and
put
them
on
again
;
and
his
voice
had
recovered
its
wonted
softness
of
tone
when
he
said
---
   
"
What
have
you
there
,
Sam
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Called
at
the
post
-
office
just
now
,
and
found
this
here
letter
,
as
has
laid
there
for
two
days
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
sealed
vith
a
vafer
,
and
directed
in
round
hand
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
this
hand
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
opening
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
<EOS>
what
's
this
?
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
a
jest
;
it
---
it
---
ca
n't
be
true
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
was
the
general
inquiry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
dead
,
is
there
?
"
said
Wardle
,
alarmed
at
the
horror
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
made
no
reply
,
but
,
pushing
the
letter
across
the
table
,
and
desiring
Mr
Tupman
to
read
it
aloud
,
fell
back
in
his
chair
with
a
look
of
vacant
astonishment
quite
alarming
to
behold
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
with
a
trembling
voice
,
read
the
letter
,
of
which
the
following
is
a
copy
:
---
   
Freeman
's
Court
,
Cornhill
,
August
28th
,
1827
.
   
<EOS>
Bardell
against
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
,
   
Having
been
instructed
by
Mrs
Martha
Bardell
to
commence
an
action
against
you
for
a
breach
of
promise
of
marriage
,
for
which
the
plaintiff
lays
her
damages
at
fifteen
hundred
pounds
,
we
beg
to
inform
you
that
a
writ
has
been
issued
against
you
in
this
suit
in
the
Court
of
Common
Pleas
;
and
request
to
know
,
by
return
of
post
,
the
name
of
your
attorney
in
London
,
who
will
accept
service
thereof
.
   
<EOS>
We
are
,
Sir
,
Your
obedient
servants
,
Dodson
&
Fogg
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Samuel
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
impressive
in
the
mute
astonishment
with
which
each
man
regarded
his
neighbour
,
and
every
man
regarded
Mr
Pickwick
,
that
all
seemed
afraid
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
The
silence
was
at
length
broken
by
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dodson
and
Fogg
,
"
he
repeated
mechanically
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bardell
and
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
musing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peace
of
mind
and
happiness
of
confiding
females
,
"
murmured
Mr
Winkle
,
with
an
air
of
abstraction
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
conspiracy
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
at
length

the
power
of
speech
;
"
a
base
conspiracy
between
these
two
grasping
attorneys
,
Dodson
and
Fogg
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
would
never
do
it
;
---
she
has
n't
the
heart
to
do
it
;
---
she
has
n't
the
case
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
Ridiculous
---
ridiculous
.
"
<EOS>
"
Of
her
heart
,
"
said
Wardle
,
with
a

,
"
you
should
certainly
be
the
best
judge
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

,
but
I
should
certainly

that
,
of
her
case
,
Dodson

Fogg
are
far

than
any

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

to

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
is
,
"
said
Wardle
,
with
a

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who

in

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
ever
saw

with
her
?
 
<EOS>
Not

my
friends
here
---
"
   
"
Except

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
changed
colour
.
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
that
's
important
.
 
<EOS>
There

nothing

,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

glanced

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
said

,
"
there

;
but
---
I

,
mind
---
she

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gracious

!
"
<EOS>

,

"

!
 
<EOS>

---

.

<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
So

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
<EOS>
"

"

?
 
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Winkle

Tupman
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
With

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Thursday
.
<EOS>
---

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Wery
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Rum

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Think

<EOS>

these

<EOS>

,

---

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Moralising

,
Mr
Samuel
Weller
bent

towards
the
booking
-
office
.
    
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
A
pleasant
day
with
an
unpleasant
termination
 
<EOS>
The
birds
,
who
,
happily
for
their
own
peace
of
mind
and
personal
comfort
,
were
in
blissful
ignorance
of
the
preparations
which
had
been
making
to
astonish
them
,
on
the
first
of
September
,
hailed
it
,
no
doubt
,
as
one
of
the
pleasantest
mornings
they
had
seen
that
season
.
 
<EOS>
Many
a
young
partridge
who
strutted
complacently
among
the
stubble
,
with
all
the
finicking
coxcombry
of
youth
,
and
many
an
older
one
who
watched
his
levity
out
of
his
little
round
eye
,
with
the
contemptuous
air
of
a
bird
of
wisdom
and
experience
<EOS>
,
alike
unconscious
of
their
approaching
doom
,
basked
in
the
fresh
morning
air
with
lively
and
blithesome
feelings
,
and
a
few
hours
afterwards
were
laid
low
upon
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
grow
affecting
:
let
us
proceed
.
   
<EOS>
In
plain
commonplace
matter
-
of
-
fact
,
then
,
it
was
a
fine
morning
---
<EOS>
so
fine
that
you
would
scarcely
have
believed
that
the
few
months
of
an
English
summer
had
yet
flown
by
.
 
<EOS>
Hedges
,
fields
,
and
trees
,
hill
and
moorland
,
presented
to
the
eye
their
ever
-
varying
shades
of
deep
rich
green
;
scarce
a
leaf
had
fallen
,
scarce
a
sprinkle
of
yellow
mingled
with
the
hues
of
summer
,
warned
you
that
autumn
had
begun
.
 
<EOS>
The
sky
was
cloudless
;
the
sun
shone
out
bright
and
warm
;
the
songs
of
birds
,
the
hum
of
myriads
of
summer
insects
,
filled
the
air
;
and
the
cottage
gardens
,
crowded
with
flowers
of
every
rich
and
beautiful
tint
,
sparkled
,
in
the
heavy
dew
,
like
beds
of
glittering
jewels
.
<EOS>
Everything
bore
the
stamp
of
summer
,
and
none
of
its
beautiful
colour
had
yet
faded
from
the
die
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
morning
,
when
an
open
carriage
,
in
which
were
three
Pickwickians
(
Mr
Snodgrass
having
preferred
to
remain
at
home
)
,
Mr
Wardle
,
and
Mr
Trundle
,
with
Sam
Weller
on
the
box
beside
the
driver
,
pulled
up
by
a
gate
at
the
roadside
,
before
which
stood
a
tall
,
raw
-
boned
gamekeeper
,
and
a
half
-
booted
,
leather
-
legginged
boy
,
<EOS>
each
bearing
a
bag
of
capacious
dimensions
,
and
accompanied
by
a
brace
of
pointers
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
whispered
Mr
Winkle
to
Wardle
,
as
the
man
let
down
the
steps
,
"
they
do
n't
suppose
we
're
going
to
kill
game
enough
to
fill
those
bags
,
do
they
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fill
them
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
old
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
yes
!
 
<EOS>
You
shall
fill
one
,
and
I
the
other
;
and
when
we
've
done
with

,
the
pockets
of
our
shooting
-

will
hold
as
much

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
dismounted
without

anything
in
reply
to
this

;
but
he
thought
within
himself
,
that
if

party
remained
in
the
open

,
till
he
had
filled
one
of
the
bags
,
they
stood
a

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hi
,
Juno
,
lass
-
hi
,
old

;
down
,
Daph
,
down
,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Geoffrey
still
in
Scotland
,
of
course
,
Martin
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
tall
gamekeeper
replied
in

,
and
looked
with

from
Mr
Winkle
,
who
was
holding
his

as
if

his
coat
pocket
to

him
the

of

,
to
Mr

,

was

as

---
as
there

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
friends
are
not
much

this

,
Martin
,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Live
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
They
'll

good
shots
one

.
 
<EOS>
I

friend
Winkle
's

,

;
he
has

some
practice
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
smiled

over

blue

in

,
and
got

so

with

,
in

,
that
if

had

loaded
,
he
must
inevitably

shot

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
handle
your
piece
in
that
'
ere
way
,
when
you
come
to

the
charge
in
it
,
Sir
,
"
said

gruffly
;
"
or
I
'm
damned
if
you
wo
n't
make
cold
meat
of
some
   
on
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
thus

,

,
and
in

,
contrived
to
bring
the

into

Mr

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
<EOS>
"
said
Sam
,

,

had

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,

!
<EOS>
if
you
comes
it
this
vay
,
you
'll
fill
one
o
'
them
bags
,
and
something
to
spare
,
at
one

.
"
   
<EOS>
Here

leather
-
legginged
boy
laughed
very

,
and
then
tried
to
look
as

was

,
whereat

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

boy
to

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Side

One
-
tree
Hill
,

,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

's

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

;

's

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
Captain
Boldwig
's

;

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
the

're

.
 
<EOS>
Will

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
particularly

to
view

sport
,
the
more

as

was
rather

in

Mr

's

.
 
<EOS>
On
so

a
morning
,
too
,
it
was
very

to
turn

,
and
leave
his
friends
to

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
,
therefore
,
with
a
very
rueful
air
that
he

---
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
suppose
I
must
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
the
gentleman
a
shot
,
Sir
?
"

long
gamekeeper
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

;
"
and
he
's
lame

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
very

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
---
"
very

.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
barrow
t'other
side
the

,
"
said

boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
If

's

would

,
he

keep
nigh
us
,
and
we

lift

over

,

that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
wery
thing
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
who
was
a
party
interested
,
<EOS>
inasmuch
as
he
ardently
longed
to
see
the
sport
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
wery
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Well
said
,
Smallcheek
;
I
'll
have
it
out
in
a
minute
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
here
a
difficulty
arose
.
 
<EOS>
The
long
gamekeeper
resolutely
protested
against
the
introduction
into
a
shooting
party
,
of
a
gentleman
in
a
barrow
,
as
a
gross
violation
of
all
established
rules
and
precedents
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
objection
,
but
not
an
insurmountable
one
.
 
<EOS>
The
gamekeeper
having
been
coaxed
and
feed
,
and
having
,
moreover
,
eased
his
mind
by
"
punching
"
the
head
of
the
inventive
youth
who
had
first
suggested
the
use
of
the
machine
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
placed
in
it
,
and
off
the
party
set
;
Wardle
and
the
long
gamekeeper
leading
the
way
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
in
the
barrow
,
propelled
by
Sam
,
bringing
up
the
rear
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
when
they
had
got
half
across
the
first
field
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
now
?
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
suffer
this
barrow
to
be
moved
another
step
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
resolutely
,
"
unless
Winkle
carries
that
gun
of
his
in
a
different
manner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
AM
I
to
carry
it
?
"
said
the
wretched
Winkle
.
<EOS>
"
Carry
it
with
the
muzzle
to
the
ground
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
so
unsportsmanlike
,
"
reasoned
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
whether
it
's
unsportsmanlike
or
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
I
am
not
going
to
be
shot
in
a
wheel
-
barrow
,
for
the
sake
of
appearances
,
to
please
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
gentleman'll
put
that
'
ere
charge
into
somebody
<EOS>
afore
he
's
done
,
"
growled
the
long
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
---
I
do
n't
mind
,
"
said
poor
Winkle
,
turning
his
gun
-
stock
uppermost
---
"
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Anythin
'
for
a
quiet
life
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
;
and
on
they
went
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
they
had
gone
a
few
yards
farther
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
now
?
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
gun
of
Tupman
's
is
not
safe
:
<EOS>
I
know
it
is
n't
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
not
safe
?
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
in
a
tone
of
great
alarm
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
as
you
are
carrying
it
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
to
make
any
further
objection
,
but
I
can
not
consent
to
go
on
,
unless
you
carry
it
as
Winkle
does
his
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
had
better
,
sir
,
"
said
the
long
gamekeeper
,
"
or
you
're
quite
as
likely
to
lodge
the
charge
in
yourself
as
in
anything
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
with
the
most
obliging
haste
,
placed
his
piece
in
the
position
required
,
and
the
party
moved
on
again
;
the
two
amateurs
marching
with
reversed
arms
,
like
a
couple
of
privates
at
a
royal
funeral
.
   
<EOS>
The
dogs
suddenly
came
to
a
dead
stop
,
and
the
party
advancing
stealthily
a
single
pace
,
stopped
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
with
the
dogs
"
legs
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
queer
they
're
standing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
ca
n't
you
?
"
replied
Wardle
softly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
see
,
they
're
making
a
point
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Making
a
point
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
staring
about
him
,
as
if
he
expected
to
discover
some
particular
beauty
in
the
landscape
,
which
the
sagacious
animals
were
calling
special
attention
to
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Making
a
point
!
 
<EOS>
What
are
they
pointing
at
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
your
eyes
open
,
"
said
Wardle
,
not
heeding
the
question
in
the
excitement
of
the
moment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
then
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
sharp
whirring
noise
,
that
made
Mr
Winkle
start
back
as
if
he
had
been
shot
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Bang
,
bang
,
went
a
couple
of
guns
---
the
smoke
swept
quickly
away
over
the
field
,
and
curled
into
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
in
a
state
of
the
highest
excitement
,
turning
round
and
round
in
all
directions
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
when
to
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Where
are
they
---
where
are
they
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
!
"
<EOS>
said
Wardle
,
taking
up
a
brace
of
birds
which
the
dogs
had
deposited
at
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
here
they
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
I
mean
the
others
,
"
said
the
bewildered
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Far
enough
off
,
by
this
time
,
"
replied
Wardle
,
coolly
reloading
his
gun
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
very
likely
be
up
with
another
covey
in
five
minutes
,
"
said
the
long
gamekeeper
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
gentleman
begins
to
fire
now
,
perhaps
he
'll
just
get
the
shot
out
of
the
barrel
by
the
time
they
rise
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
"
roared
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
compassionating
his
follower
's
confusion
and
embarrassment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
laugh
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
,
by
way
of
indemnification
,
Mr
Weller
contorted
his
features
from
behind
the
wheel
-
barrow
,
for
the
exclusive
amusement
of
the
boy
with
the
leggings
,
who
thereupon
burst
into
a
boisterous
laugh
,
and
was
summarily
cuffed
by
the
long
gamekeeper
,
who
wanted
a
pretext
for
turning
round
,
to
hide
his
own
merriment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bravo
,
old
fellow
!
"
said
Wardle
to
Mr
Tupman
;
"
you
fired
that
time
,
at
all
events
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
,
with
conscious
pride
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
let
it
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
done
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
hit
something
next
time
,
if
you
look
sharp
.
<EOS>
Very
easy
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
's
very
easy
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
it
hurts
one
's
shoulder
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
It
nearly
knocked
me
backwards
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
idea
these
small
fire
-
arms
kicked
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
smiling
,
"
you
'll
get
used
to
it
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
Now
then
---
all

---
all
right
with
the
barrow
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
hard
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
raising
the
barrow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
on
they
went
,
as
briskly
as
need
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
that
barrow
back
now
,
"
cried
Wardle
,
when
it
had
been
hoisted
over
a
stile
into
another
field
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
deposited
in
it
once
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
,
pausing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Winkle
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
follow
me
softly
,
and
do
n't
be
too
late
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
fear
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
they
pointing
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
not
now
.
 
<EOS>
Quietly
now
,
quietly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
On
they
crept
,
and
very
quietly
they
would
have
advanced
,
if
Mr
Winkle
,
in
the
performance
of
some
very
intricate
evolutions
with
his
gun
,
had
not
accidentally
fired
,
at
the
most
critical
moment
,
over
the
boy
's
head
,
exactly
in
the
very
spot
where
the
tall
man
's
brain
would
have
been
,
had
he
been
there
instead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
on
earth
did
you
do
that
for
?
"
said
old
Wardle
,
as
the
birds
flew
unharmed
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
such
a
gun
in
my
life
,
"
replied
poor
Mr
Winkle
,
looking
at
the
lock
,
as
if
that
would
do
any
good
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
goes
off
of
its
own
accord
.
 
<EOS>
It
WILL
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
do
it
!
"
<EOS>
echoed
Wardle
,
with
something
of
irritation
in
his
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
it
would
kill
something
of
its
own
accord
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
'll
do
that
afore
long
,
Sir
,
"
observed
the
tall
man
,
in
a
low
,
prophetic
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
observation
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
Sir
,
never
mind
,
"
replied
the
long
gamekeeper
;
"
I
've
no
family
myself
,
sir
;
and
this
here
boy
's
mother
will
get
something
handsome
from
Sir
Geoffrey
,
if
he
's
killed
on
his
land
.
<EOS>
Load
again
,
Sir
,
load
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Take
away
his
gun
,
"
cried
Mr
Pickwick
from
the
barrow
,
horror
-
stricken
at
the
long
man
's
dark
insinuations
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
away
his
gun
,
do
you
hear
,
somebody
?
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody
,
however
,
volunteered
to
obey
the
command
;
and
Mr
Winkle
,
after
darting
a
rebellious
glance
at
Mr
Pickwick
,
reloaded
his
gun
,
and
proceeded
onwards
with
the
rest
.
   
<EOS>
We
are
bound
,
on
the
authority
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
to
state
,
that
Mr
Tupman
's
mode
of
proceeding
evinced
far
more
of
prudence
and
deliberation
,
than
that
adopted
by
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
this
by
no
means
detracts
from
the
great
authority
of
the
latter
gentleman
,
on
all
matters
connected
with
the
field
;
because
,
as
Mr
Pickwick
beautifully
observes
,
it
has
somehow
or
other
happened
,
from
time
immemorial
,
that
many
of
the
best
and
ablest
philosophers
,
who
have
been
perfect
lights
of
science
in
matters
of
theory
,
have
been
wholly
unable
to
reduce
them
to
practice
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
's
process
,
like
many
of
our
most
sublime
discoveries
,
was
extremely
simple
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
quickness
and
penetration
of
a
man
of
genius
,
he
had
at
once
observed
that
the
two
great
points
to
be
attained
were
---
first
,
to
discharge
his
piece
without
injury
to
himself
,
and
,
secondly
,
to
do
so
,
without
danger
to
the
bystanders
---
<EOS>
obviously
,
the
best
thing
to
do
,
after
surmounting
the
difficulty
of
firing
at
all
,
was
to
shut
his
eyes
firmly
,
and
fire
into
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
On
one
occasion
,
after
performing
this
feat
,
Mr
Tupman
,
on
opening
his
eyes
,
beheld
a
plump
partridge
in
the
act
of
falling
,
wounded
,
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
on
the
point
of
congratulating
Mr
Wardle
on
his
invariable
success
,
when
that
gentleman
advanced
towards
him
,
and
grasped
him
warmly
by
the
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tupman
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
you
singled
out
that
particular
bird
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Tupman
---
"
no
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
"
said
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
saw
you
do
it
<EOS>
---
I
observed
you
pick
him
out
---
I
noticed
you
,
as
you
raised
your
piece
to
take
aim
;
and
I
will
say
this
,
that
the
best
shot
in
existence
could
not
have
done
it
more
beautifully
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
an
older
hand
at
this
than
I
thought
you
,
Tupman
;
you
have
been
out
before
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
in
vain
for
Mr
Tupman
to
protest
,
with
a
smile
of
self
-
denial
,
that
he
never
had
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
smile
was
taken
as
evidence
to
the
contrary
;
and
from
that
time
forth
his
reputation
was
established
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
only
reputation
that
has
been
acquired
as
easily
,
nor
are
such
fortunate
circumstances
confined
to
partridge
-
shooting
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Mr
Winkle
flashed
,
and
blazed
,
and
smoked
away
,
without
producing
any
material
results
worthy
of
being
noted
down
;
sometimes
expending
his
charge
in
mid
-
air
,
and
at
others
sending
it
skimming
along
so
near
the
surface
of
the
ground
as
to
place
the
lives
of
the
two
dogs
on
a
rather
uncertain
and
precarious
tenure
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
display
of
fancy
-
shooting
,
it
was
extremely
varied
and
curious
;
as
an
exhibition
of
firing
with
any
precise
object
,
it
was
,
upon
the
whole
,
perhaps
a
failure
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
an
established
axiom
,
that
"
every
bullet
has
its
billet
.
<EOS>
"
 
If
it
apply
in
an
equal
degree
to
shot
,
those
of
Mr
Winkle
were
unfortunate
foundlings
,
deprived
of
their
natural
rights
,
cast
loose
upon
the
world
,
and
billeted
nowhere
.
"
Well
,
"
said
Wardle
,
walking
up
to
the
side
of
the
barrow
,
and
wiping
the
streams
of
perspiration
from
his
jolly
red
face
;
"
smoking
day
,
is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
is
tremendously
hot
,
even
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
you
must
feel
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
pretty
hot
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
past
twelve
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
that
green
hill
there
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Certainly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
place
where
we
are
to
lunch
;
and
,
by
Jove
,
there
's
the
boy
with
the
basket
,
punctual
as
clockwork
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
he
is
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
brightening
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
boy
,
that
.
<EOS>
I
'll
give
him
a
shilling
,
presently
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
then
,
Sam
,
wheel
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Hold
on
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
invigorated
with
the
prospect
of
refreshments
.
 
<EOS>
"
Out
of
the
vay
,
young
leathers
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
walley
my
precious
life
do
n't
upset
me
,
as
the
gen'l'm'n
said
to
the
driver
when
they
was
a
-
carryin
'
him
to
Tyburn
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
quickening
his
pace
to
a
sharp
run
,
Mr
Weller
wheeled
his
master
nimbly
to
the
green
hill
,
shot
him
dexterously
out
by
the
very
side
of
the
basket
,
and
proceeded
to
unpack

with
the
utmost

.
   
<EOS>
"
Weal
pie
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
soliloquising
,
as
he

the

on

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wery
good
thing

weal
pie
,
when
you
know

as

,
and
is
quite
sure
it
ai
n't
kittens
;
and
arter
all

,

the
odds
,
when
they
're
so
like
weal

the
wery

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

house
<EOS>
vith

---

---
make

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

,
"

You

<EOS>
"
Other

,
"

a

"

ai

<EOS>

<EOS>
fruits

<EOS>
"

o

<EOS>
"
Mr

"

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
Tongue

,

ai

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"
fall

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

;
and
as

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
An
old

,
and
a

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
This

---

"
said

Pickwick
;
the

was

,

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

---
<EOS>

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
;

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
With

,
"

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Very

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Come
,

<EOS>
,

"

.
 
<EOS>
Our
friends
at
Dingley
Dell
.
"
   
<EOS>
The

was

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll

on

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
understand
it
's
capital

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"
as

,

;

,

.

<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"

.

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cert'nly
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Here

which
was

by
the
beer
-
can
he
was

to

,

,
that
the

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

cold

,
"

,

;
"
and

is

,

---
 
Tupman
,
my

,
a

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
the

,
"
replied
Mr
Tupman
;
and
having

that

,
Mr
Pickwick
took

,
just
to

there
was
any
orange
peel
in
the
punch
,
because
orange
peel
always
disagreed
with
him
;
and
finding
that
there
was
not
,
Mr
Pickwick
took
another
glass
to
the
health
of
their
absent
friend
,
and
then
felt
himself
imperatively
called
upon
to
propose
another
in

of
the

-

,
unknown
.
   
<EOS>
This
constant
succession
of
glasses
produced
considerable
effect
upon
Mr
Pickwick
;
his
countenance
beamed
with
the
most
sunny
smiles
,
laughter
played
around
his
lips
,
and
good
-
humoured

twinkled
in

.
 
<EOS>
Yielding
by
degrees
to
the
influence
of
the
exciting
liquid
,
rendered
more
so
by
the
heat
,
Mr
Pickwick
expressed
a
strong
desire
to
recollect
a
song
which
he
had
heard
in
his
infancy
,
and
the
attempt
proving
abortive
,
sought
to
stimulate
his
memory
with
more
glasses
of
punch
,
which
appeared
to
have
quite
a
contrary
effect
;
for
,
from
forgetting
the
words
of
the
song
,
he
began
to

articulate

;
and

,

rising
to

to

in
an

,
he
fell
into
the
barrow
,
and
fast
asleep
,
simultaneously
.
   
<EOS>
The
basket
having
been
repacked
,
and
it
being
found
perfectly
impossible
to
awaken
Mr
Pickwick
from
his

,
some

whether

Mr

to

back

,
or
to
leave

,

all

.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
course
was
at
length
decided
on
;
and
as
the

was
not
to

an
hour
's

,
and
as
Mr
Weller
begged
very
hard
to
be
one
of

party
,
it
was

to
leave
Mr
Pickwick
asleep
in

,
and
to
call

on

.
 
<EOS>
So

went
,
leaving
Mr
Pickwick
snoring
most

in

.
   
<EOS>
That
Mr
Pickwick
would
have
continued
to
snore
in
the
shade
until
his
friends
came
back
,
or
,
in
default
thereof
,
until
the

of
evening
had
fallen
on
the
landscape
,
there
appears
no
reasonable
cause
to
doubt
;
always
supposing
that
he
had

to
remain
there
in

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
NOT
suffered
to
remain
there
in
peace
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
what
prevented
him
.
   
<EOS>
Captain
Boldwig
was
a
little
fierce
man
in
a
stiff
black
neckerchief
and
blue
surtout
,
who
,
when
he
did
condescend
to
walk
about
his
property
,
did
it
in
company
with
a
thick
rattan
stick
with
a

,
and
a
gardener
and
sub
-
gardener
with
meek
faces
,
to
whom
(
the
gardeners
,
not
the
stick
)
<EOS>
Captain
Boldwig
gave
his
orders
with
all
due
grandeur
and
ferocity
;
for
Captain
Boldwig
's
wife
's
sister
had
married
a
marquis
,
and
the
captain
's
house
was
a
villa
,
and
his
land
"
grounds
,
"
and
it
was
all
very
high
,
and
mighty
,
and
great
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
not
been

when
little
Captain
Boldwig
,
followed
by

,

;

,

,
and

as

thought
the
prospect
ought
to
be

at

to

of

;
and

with

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hunt
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Roll

---
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well

,

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

<EOS>
"
Beg

,

<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
"
Punch
,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

---
that

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's

;

.
<EOS>
Wheel
him
away
,
Wilkins
,
wheel
him
away
directly
.
"
<EOS>
"
Where
shall
I
wheel
him
to
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Wilkins
,
with
great
timidity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wheel
him
to
the
devil
,
"
replied
Captain
Boldwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
sir
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"
said
the
captain
.
   
<EOS>
Wilkins
stopped
accordingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wheel
him
,
"
said
the
captain
---
"
wheel
him
to
the
pound
;
and
let
us
see
whether
he
calls
himself
Punch
when

comes

.
 
<EOS>
He
shall
not
bully
me
<EOS>
---
he
shall
not
bully
me
.
 
<EOS>
Wheel
him
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Away
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
wheeled
in
compliance
with
this
imperious
mandate
;
and
the
great
Captain
Boldwig
,
swelling

,
proceeded
on

.
   
<EOS>
Inexpressible
was
the
astonishment
of
the
little
party
when
they
returned
,
to
find
that
Mr
Pickwick
had
disappeared
,
and
taken
the
wheel
-
barrow
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
most
mysterious
and
unaccountable
thing
that
was
ever
heard
of
For
a
lame
man
to
have
got
upon
his
legs
without
any
previous
notice
,
and
walked
off
,
would
have
been
most
extraordinary
;
but
when
it
came
to
his
wheeling
a
heavy
barrow
before
him
,
by
way
of
amusement
,
it
grew
positively
miraculous
.
 
<EOS>
They
searched
every
nook
and
corner
round
,
together
and
separately
;
they
shouted
,
whistled
,
laughed
,
called
---
and
all
with
the
same
result
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
not
to
be
found
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
hours
of
fruitless
search
,
they
arrived
at
the
unwelcome
conclusion
that
they
must
go
home
without
him
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
wheeled
to
the
pound
,
and
safely

therein
,
fast

the
wheel

,
to
the
immeasurable
delight
and
satisfaction
not
only
of
all

the

,
but
three
-
fourths
of

whole

,
who
had
gathered
round
,
in
expectation
of
his

.
 
<EOS>
If
their
most
intense
gratification
had
been
awakened
by

wheeled
in
,
how
many
hundredfold
was
their
joy
increased
<EOS>
when
,
after
a
few
indistinct

of
"
Sam
!
"
he
sat
up
in
the
barrow
,
and
gazed

on
the
faces
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
A
general
shout
was
of
course
the
signal
of
his
having
woke

;
and
his
involuntary
inquiry
of
<EOS>
"
What
's

matter
?
"
occasioned

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's

game
!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
In

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Captain

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Then

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Do

<EOS>
So

,

for

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Showing
how
Dodson
and
Fogg
were
men
of
business
,
and
their
clerks
men
of
pleasure
;
and
how

affecting

took

and

long

lost

;

what
choice

assembled
at

Magpie

,
and
what
a
capital
chapter
the
next

will
be
 
In
the
ground

,

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
clerks
"

,

,

,

stone

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
ca

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

Mr

ai

<EOS>
