yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Ramsey
tried
to
speak
,
but
Fogg
would
n't
let
him
,
so
he
put
the
money
in
his
pocket
,
and
sneaked
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
scarcely
shut
,
when
old
Fogg
turned
round
to
me
,
with
a
sweet
smile
on
his
face
,
and
drew
the
declaration
out
of
his
coat
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Wicks
,
"
says
Fogg
,
"
take
a
cab
,
and
go
down
to
the
Temple
as
quick
as
you
can
,
and
file
that
.
 
<EOS>
The
costs
are
quite
safe
,
for
he
's
a
steady
man
with
a
large
family
,
at
a
salary
of
five
-
and
-
twenty
shillings
a
week
,
and
if
he
gives
us
a
warrant
of
attorney
,
as
he
must
in
the
end
,
I
know
his
employers
will
see
it
paid
;
so
we
may
as
well
get
all
we
can
get
out
of
him
,
Mr
Wicks
;
it
's
a
Christian
act
to
do
it
,
Mr
Wicks
,
for
with
his
large
family
and
small
income
,
he
'll
be
all
the
better
for
a
good
lesson
against
getting
into
debt
---
wo
n't
he
,
Mr
Wicks
,
wo
n't
he
?
"
<EOS>
---
and
he
smiled
so
good
-
naturedly
as
he
went
away
,
that
it
was
delightful
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
capital
man
of
business
,
"
said
Wicks
,
in
a
tone
of
the
deepest
admiration
,
"
capital
,
is
n't
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
other
three
cordially
subscribed
to
this
opinion
,
and
the
anecdote
afforded
the
most
unlimited
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nice
men
these
here
,
Sir
,
"
whispered
Mr
Weller
to
his
master
;
"
wery
nice
notion
of
fun
<EOS>
they
has
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
nodded
assent
,
and
coughed
to
attract
the
attention
of
the
young
gentlemen
behind
the
partition
,
who
,
having
now
relaxed
their
minds
by
a
little
conversation
among
themselves
,
condescended
to
take
some
notice
of
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
Fogg
's
disengaged
now
?
"
said
Jackson
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
see
,
"
said
Wicks
,
dismounting
leisurely
from
his
stool
.
<EOS>
"
What
name
shall
I
tell
Mr
Fogg
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pickwick
,
"
replied
the
illustrious
subject
of
these
memoirs
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jackson
departed
upstairs
on
his
errand
,
and
immediately
returned
with
a
message
that
Mr
Fogg
would
see
Mr
Pickwick
in
five
minutes
;
and
having
delivered
it
,
returned
again
to
his
desk
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
say
his
name
was
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Wicks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pickwick
,
"
replied
Jackson
;
"
it
's
the
defendant
in
Bardell
and
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
sudden
scraping
of
feet
,
mingled
with
the
sound
of
suppressed
laughter
,
was
heard
from
behind
the
partition
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
're
a
-
twiggin
'
of
you
,
Sir
,
"
whispered
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Twigging
of
me
,
Sam
!
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
what
do
you
mean
by
twigging
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
replied
by
pointing
with
his
thumb
over
his
shoulder
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
,
on
looking
up
,
became
sensible
of
the
pleasing
fact
,
that
all
the
four
clerks
,
with
countenances
expressive
of
the
utmost
amusement
,
and
with
their
heads
thrust
over
the
wooden
screen
,
were
minutely
inspecting
the
figure
and
general
appearance
of
the
supposed
trifler
with
female
hearts
,
and
disturber
of
female
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
looking
up
,
the
row
of
heads
suddenly
disappeared
,
and
the
sound
of
pens
travelling
at
a
furious
rate
over
paper
,
immediately
succeeded
.
   
<EOS>
A
sudden
ring
at
the
bell
which
hung
in
the
office
,
summoned
Mr
Jackson
to
the
apartment
of
Fogg
,
from
whence
he
came
back
to
say
that
he
(
Fogg
)
was
ready
to
see
Mr
Pickwick
if
he
would
step
upstairs
.
<EOS>
Upstairs
Mr
Pickwick
did
step
accordingly
,
leaving
Sam
Weller
below
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
door
of
the
one
-
pair
back
,
bore
inscribed
in
legible
characters
the
imposing
words
,
"
Mr
Fogg
"
;
and
,
having
tapped
thereat
,
and
been
desired
to
come
in
,
Jackson
ushered
Mr
Pickwick
into
the
presence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Dodson
in
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Fogg
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
come
in
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Jackson
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
him
to
step
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
Exit
Jackson
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
a
seat
,
sir
,
"
said
Fogg
;
"
there
is
the
paper
,
sir
;
my
partner
will
be
here
directly
,
and
we
can
converse
about
this
matter
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
took
a
seat
and
the
paper
,
but
,
instead
of
reading
the
latter
,
peeped
over
the
top
of
it
,
and
took
a
survey
of
the
man
of
business
,
who
was
an
elderly
,
pimply
-
faced
,
vegetable
-
diet
sort
of
man
,
in
a
black
coat
,
dark
mixture
trousers
,
and
small
black
gaiters
;
a
kind
of
being
who
seemed
to
be
an
essential
part
of
the
desk
at
which
he
was
writing
,
and
to
have
as
much
thought
or
feeling
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
few
minutes
"
silence
,
Mr
Dodson
,
a
plump
,
portly
,
stern
-
looking
man
,
with
a
loud
voice
,
appeared
;
and
the
conversation
commenced
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Fogg
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
defendant
,
Sir
,
in
Bardell
and
Pickwick
?
"
said
Dodson
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Dodson
,
"
and
what
do
you
propose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Fogg
,
thrusting
his
hands
into
his
trousers
"
pockets
,
and
throwing
himself
back
in
his
chair
,
"
what
do
you
propose
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
Fogg
,
"
said
Dodson
,
"
let
me
hear
what
Mr
Pickwick
has
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
gazing
placidly
on
the
two
partners
,
"
I
came
here
,
gentlemen
,
to
express
the
surprise
with
which
I
received
your
letter
of
the
other
day
,
and
to
inquire
what
grounds
of
action
you
can
have
against
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Grounds
of
---
"
<EOS>
Fogg
had
ejaculated
this
much
,
when
he
was
stopped
by
Dodson
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Fogg
,
"
said
Dodson
,
"
I
am
going
to
speak
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mr
Dodson
,
"
said
Fogg
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
the
grounds
of
action
,
sir
,
"
continued
Dodson
,
with
moral
elevation
in
his
air
,
"
you
will
consult
your
own
conscience
and
your
own
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
We
,
Sir
,
we
,
are
guided
entirely
by
the
statement
of
our
client
.
 
<EOS>
That
statement
,
Sir
,
may
be
true
,
or
it
may
be
false
;
it
may
be
credible
,
or
it
may
be
incredible
;
but
,
if
it
be
true
,
and
if
it
be
credible
,
I
do
not
hesitate
to
say
,
Sir
,
that
our
grounds
of
action
,
Sir
,
are
strong
,
and
not
to

shaken
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
be
an
unfortunate
man
,
Sir
,
or
you
may
be
a
designing
one
;
but
if
I
were
called
upon
,
as
a
juryman
upon
my
oath
,
Sir
,
to
express
an
opinion
of
your
conduct
,
Sir
,
I
do
not
hesitate
to
assert
that
I
should
have
but
one
opinion
about
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Dodson
drew
himself
up
,
with
an
air
of
offended
virtue
,
and
looked
at
Fogg
,
who
thrust
his
hands
farther
in
his
pockets
,
and
nodding
his
head
sagely
,
said
,
in
a
tone
of
the
fullest
concurrence
,
"
Most
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
considerable
pain
depicted
in
his
countenance
,
"
you
will
permit
me
to
assure
you
that
I
am
a
most
unfortunate
man
,
so
far
as
this

is
concerned
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Dodson
;
"
I
trust
you
may
be
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
really
innocent
of
what
is
laid
to
your
charge
,
you
are
more
unfortunate
than
I
had
believed
any
man
could
possibly
be
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
say
,
Mr
Fogg
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say

what
you
say
,
"
replied
Fogg
,
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
writ
,
Sir
,
which
commences
the
action
,
"
continued
Dodson
,
"
was
issued
regularly
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Fogg
,
where
is
the
PRAECIPE
book
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
"
said
Fogg
,
handing
over

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
"
Middlesex
,
Capias
MARTHA
BARDELL
,
WIDOW
,

SAMUEL
PICKWICK
.
 
Damages
#
#
#
#
1500
.
<EOS>
Dodson
&
Fogg
for

plaintiff
,
Aug.
 
28
,
1827
.
"
 
<EOS>
All
regular
,
Sir
;
perfectly
.
"
 
<EOS>
Dodson
coughed
and
looked
at
Fogg
,
who
said
"
Perfectly
,
"
also
.
 
<EOS>
And
then

Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
to

,

,
"

,
"
that

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Understand
,
sir
!
---
<EOS>
that
you
certainly
may
,
"
replied
Dodson
,
with
something

near

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
that
the

are
actually

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
which

you
may
add
my

,
that

could
have
prevailed
upon
our
client
,
they
would
have

at

,

,
"

Dodson
.
<EOS>
"
I

Mrs
Bardell
specially
said
,

,
"
observed
Fogg
,

,
"
that
she
would
not
compromise
for
a
farthing
less
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unquestionably
,
"
replied
Dodson
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
action
was
only
just
begun
;
and
it
would
n't
have
done
to
let
Mr
Pickwick
compromise
it
then
,
even
if

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

offer
no

,

,
"

,

,

of

,
on
Mr

with

,
"
I
had
better

,

.
 
<EOS>
Here

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,

,
"

,

;
"
you

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
Dodson
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
before
I
go
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the

Pickwick
,
turning

,
"
permit

to
say
,
that
of
all
the
disgraceful
and
rascally
proceedings
---
"
   
"
Stay
,
sir
,
stay
,
"
interposed
Dodson
,
with
great
politeness
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Jackson
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Wicks
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
the
two
clerks
,
appearing
at
the

stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
merely

you
to
hear

this

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
,

,

---
disgraceful
and
rascally
proceedings
,
I
think
you
said
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
Sir
,
that

and

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.

<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Go

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
Sir
;

You

like

one
Of
US
.
 
<EOS>
Pray

,
Sir
,

;
we

.
<EOS>
Pray

,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Fogg
put
himself
very

within
the

of
Mr
Pickwick
's
clenched

,
there
is
little
doubt
that
that

would
have

with

,
but
for

Sam
,
who
,

,
emerged

,
mounted

stairs
,
and
seized
his
master

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
just
come

,
"
said
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
"
Battledore
and

's
a
wery
good
game
,
vhen
<EOS>
you
ai
n't
the
shuttlecock
and
two
lawyers
the
battledores
,
in
which
case

too

'

.
 
<EOS>
Come
avay
,

.
 
<EOS>

rayther

"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

walked

,

,
and
bent

up

.
 
<EOS>
Sam

,
when

,
and

---
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

wery
place

vere

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>
Mr

's

was

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

vay

"
cos

ai

'

,

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

;

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
room
was
one
of
a
very
homely
description
,
and
was
apparently
under
the
especial

of
stage
-

;
for
several

,
who
had
all
the

of
belonging
to
that

,
were

and

in

different

.
 
<EOS>
Among

number
was
one
stout
,
red
-

,
elderly
man
,
in
particular
,

in
an

,
who
attracted

Pickwick
's

.
 
<EOS>
The
stout
man
was
smoking
with
great
vehemence
,
but
between
every
half
-
dozen
puffs
,
he
took
his
pipe
from
his
mouth
,
and
looked
first
at
Mr
Weller
and
then
at
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
would
bury
in
a
quart

,
as

as
the

of
the
quart

admitted

its

,
and
take

at
Sam
and
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
would
take
another
half

dozen
puffs
with
an
air

profound
meditation
and
look
at
them
again
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
the
stout
man
,

,
and

,

at
his
pipe
without

off
at

,
and
to

at

new
-

,
as

had

up

to

most

of

.
   
<EOS>
At

of

's

,
but

,

,

,

partially

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

;
for

"

,

!

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

with

gout
,
sir
,
jist
you
marry
a
widder
as
has
got

woice
,
with
a
decent
notion
of
usin
'
it
,
and
you
'll
never

the
gout
agin
.
 
<EOS>
It

a
capital

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
takes
it
reg'lar
,
and
I
can
warrant

to

.
"
 
<EOS>
Having

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
This
favoured

,

of
Mr

and

,
was
what

.
 
<EOS>
That

was

,

,

:

to
a
pieman
,
who
vended

without

,
on

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

,

a

,

,

500,000

,

in
the
bowels
of

,

.
 
<EOS>

intently

,

"

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
hear

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

-

,

"

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
individual
to
whom
Lowten
alluded
,
was
a
little
,
yellow
,
high
-

man
,
whose
countenance
,
from
his
habit
of
stooping
forward
when
silent
,
Mr
Pickwick
had
not
observed
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
wondered
,
though
,
when
the
old
man
raised
his

,
and
bent

gray

,
with
a
keen

,
that
such
remarkable
features
could
have
escaped

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fixed

perpetually
on

;
he

a

,
with

;
and
as

,

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the

that
now
started
forward
,
and
burst

.
 
<EOS>
As
this
chapter
has
been
a
long

,

,
and
as
the
old
man
was
a

,

,

<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
In

,

a

client
 
Aha
!
<EOS>
"

,
"
<EOS>
aha
!
<EOS>
who

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

"
I

what
singular

they
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
!
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
YOU
know
of
the
time
when
young

shut

in
those

rooms
,

read

,
hour

,

till

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

<EOS>
Common

now
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

---

forty

<EOS>

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Well

full
 
---

,

,

<EOS>
"
time
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Who

?
"

,

;

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

a
spirit
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
And

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
In
this

,
"

,
"

was
worked
,

I

.
<EOS>
In
this

,
the

in

,
long

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

,
and
long

,

,
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
and

have

---
the

---
about

my

.
 
<EOS>
This
apartment
is
mine
:
leave
it
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you

upon

,
"

,
who

this

of
the
ghost
's
,
"

;
but
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Say
on
,
"
said
the
apparition

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
the

,
"
I
do

,

most

ghosts
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Egad
,
that
's

;
I
never

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Sir
,
"

,
"
this
is
a

.
 
<EOS>
From

appearance

that

,
I

is

:
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,
Sir
,
"

"
---

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

"

;
"

---
very

,

;
I
ca

"
 
<EOS>

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,

,
"
said

man

,

<EOS>
"
IF
!
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

"

"

about

---

"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

"

<EOS>
"
Ah

"

,
"
nobody
has

it
but

,
and
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
round
the
table
,
and
leered
more

ever
,
as
if

,
at
the

was

.
 
<EOS>
Then

and

to

,
he
began
as

:
---
  
<EOS>
The
Old
Man
's
Tale
about
the
Queer
Client
   
<EOS>
"
It
matters
little
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
where
,
or
how
,
I
picked
up
this
brief

.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
relate

in
the

it
reached

,
I
should
commence
in
the
middle
,
and
when
I
had
arrived

the
conclusion
,
go
back
for
a

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
for
me
to
say
that
some
of
its
circumstances
passed
before
my
own

;
for
the
remainder
I
know
them
to
have
happened
,
and
there

some

,
who
will
remember

but

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
the
Borough
High
Street
,
near
St
George
's
Church
,
and
on
the
same

of

,
stands
,
as

,
the
smallest
of
our
debtors
<EOS>
"
prisons
,
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
Although

later

it
has
been
a
very

from

it

,

holds

to

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
The
condemned
felon
has
as
good

yard
for
air

in
Newgate
,
as
the
insolvent

in

.
 
<EOS>
[
Better
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
past
,
in
a
better
age
,
and
the
prison
exists
no

.
]
   
<EOS>
"
It
may

,
or

that
I

from
the
old

associated
with
it
,
but
this

of
London
I
can
not

.
 
<EOS>
The
street
is
broad
,
the
shops
are
spacious
,
the
noise
of
passing

,
the

of
a

---
all

of

,
resound
in
it
from
morn
to

;
but
the
streets
around
are
mean
and
close
;
poverty
and
debauchery
lie
festering
in
the
crowded

;
<EOS>
want
and
misfortune
are
pent
up
in
the
narrow
prison
;
an
air
of
gloom
and
dreariness
seems
,
in
my

,
to
hang
about
the
scene
,
and
to
impart
to
it
a
squalid

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Many
eyes
,
that
have
long
since
been
closed
in
the
grave
,
have
looked
round
upon
that
scene
lightly
enough
,
when
entering
the
gate
of
the
old
Marshalsea
Prison
for
the
first
time
;
for
despair
seldom
comes
with
the
first
severe
shock
of
misfortune
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
has
confidence
in
untried
friends
,
he
remembers
the
many
offers
of
service
so
freely
made
by

boon

when

not
;
he
has
hope
---
the
hope
of

---
and
however

beneath

,

springs
up
in

,

brief

,
until

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
How
soon
have
those
same
eyes
,
deeply
sunken
in
the
head
,
glared
from
faces
wasted
with

,
and
sallow
from

,
in
days
when
it
was
no
figure

speech
to
say
that
debtors
rotted
in
prison
,
with
no
hope
of
release
,
and
no
prospect
of
liberty
!
<EOS>
The
atrocity
in
its
full
extent
no
longer
exists
,
but
there
is
enough
of
<EOS>
it
left
to
give
rise
to
occurrences
that
make
the
heart
bleed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Twenty
years
ago
,
that
pavement
was
worn
with
the
footsteps
of
a
mother
and
child
,
who
,
day

day
,
so

,

at

;
often
after

of

and

,
were

there
,
a
full
hour

soon
,

,
would

,
and
raising

,

of

morning
's

,
and

the

presented
at

,
endeavour
to

in

before

.
 
<EOS>
But
she
would
quickly
set

down
,
and
hiding

in

,
give
vent

that
blinded

;
for
no

of
interest
or

lighted

thin

.
 
<EOS>
His
recollections
were
few
enough
,
but
they
were
all
of
one
kind
---
all
connected
with
the
poverty
and

of
his
parents
.
 
<EOS>
Hour
after

had
he
sat
on
his
mother
's

,
and
with
childish
sympathy
watched
the
tears
that
stole
down

face
,
and

crept

into

.
 
<EOS>
The
hard

,
with
many

---

,

,

;
and

form

childhood
was
there
,
its
light

,

,

were
wanting
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
father
and
mother
looked
on
upon
this
,
and
upon
each
other
,
with
thoughts
of
agony
they
dared
not

in
words
.
<EOS>
The
healthy
,
strong
-
made
man
,
who
could
have
borne

any

active

,
was
wasting

close

.
 
<EOS>
The
slight
and
delicate
woman
was
sinking
beneath
the
combined
effects
of
bodily
and
mental

.
 
<EOS>
The
child
's
young
heart
was
breaking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Winter
came
,
and
with
it
weeks
of
cold
and

.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
girl
had
removed
to
a
wretched
apartment
close
to
the
spot
of
her
husband
's
imprisonment
;
and
though

had
been
rendered
necessary
by

increasing

,
she
was
happier
now
,
for

was
nearer
him
.
 
<EOS>
For
two
months
,
she
and
her
little

watched
the
opening
of
the
gate
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
One

failed
to
come
,
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
Another
morning
arrived
,
and
she
came
alone
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
was
dead
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
They
little
know
,
who
coldly
talk
of
the
poor
man
's
bereavements
,
as
a
happy
release
from
pain
to

,
and
a

the
survivor
<EOS>
---
they
little

,
I
say
,
what
the
agony
of
those
bereavements
is
.
 
<EOS>
A
silent
look
of
affection
and
regard
when
all
other
eyes
are
turned
coldly
away
 
---
the
consciousness
that
we
possess
the

one

when

---
is

,

,

,
in
the

,
which
no

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

had
sat
at
his
parents
"
feet
for
hours

,
with
his
little

patiently

,
and
his
thin
wan

raised

.
 
<EOS>
They
had
seen

pine
away
,
from
day
to
day
;
and
though

brief
existence
had
been

,
and

that

which
,
child

was
,
he
had
never
known
in
this
world
,
they

his
parents
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
plain

those

's

,
that
death
must
soon
close
the
scene

and

.
 
<EOS>
Her

's
fellow
-
prisoners
shrank
from

on
his
grief
and
misery
,
and
left
to

alone
,
the

room
he
had
previously
occupied
in
common
with
two

.
 
<EOS>
She
shared
it
with
him
;
and
lingering
on
without
pain
,
but
without
hope
,
her
life
ebbed
slowly
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
had
fainted
one
evening
in
her
husband
's
arms
,
and
he
had
borne
her
to
the
open

,
to
revive
her
with
the
air
,
when
the
light
of
the
moon
falling
full

face
,
showed
him
a
change
upon
her

,
which
made

stagger

,
like

helpless

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Set
me
down
,
George
,
"
she
said
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
so
,
and
seating
himself
beside
her
,
covered
his
face
with
his
hands
,
and
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
is
very
hard
to
leave
you
,
George
,
"
she
said
;
"
but
it
is
God
's
will
,
and
you
must
bear
it
for
my

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
how
I
thank
Him
for
having
taken
our
boy
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
happy
,
and
in
heaven
now
.
<EOS>
What
would
he
have
done
here
,
without
his
mother
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
shall
not
die
,
Mary
,
you
shall
not
die
;
"
said
the
husband
,
starting
up
.
 
<EOS>
He
paced
hurriedly
to
and
fro
,
striking
his
head
with
his

;
then
reseating

,
and
supporting

,
added
more

,
"
Rouse

,
my
dear
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray

.
 
<EOS>
You
will
revive
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Never
again
,
George
;
never
again
,
"
said
the

woman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let

lay
me
by
my
poor
boy
now
,

,
that

leave
this

,
and
should

,
you
will
have

,
a
long
,

---
very

---
where
we

.
 
<EOS>
Dear
George
,
promise
me
you
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
do
,
I
do
,
"
said
the
man
,
throwing

.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
to
me
,
Mary
,
another
word
;
one

---
but
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
ceased
to
speak
:
for
the
arm
that
clasped

grew
stiff
and
heavy
.
 
<EOS>
A
deep
sigh
escaped
from
the
wasted
form
before
him
;
the
lips
moved
,
and
a
smile
played
upon
the
face
;
but
the
lips
were
pallid
,
and
the
smile
faded
into
a
rigid
and
ghastly
stare
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
alone
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
night
,
in
the
silence
and
desolation
of
his
miserable
room
,
the
wretched
man
knelt
down
by
the
dead
body
of
his
wife
,
and
called
on
God
to
witness
a
terrible
oath
,
that
from
that
hour
,
he
devoted
himself
to
revenge
her
death
and
that
of
his
child
;
that
thenceforth
to
the
last
moment
of
his
life
,
his
whole
energies
should
be
directed
to
this
one
object
;
that
his
revenge
should
be
protracted
and
terrible
;
that
his
hatred
should
be
undying
and
inextinguishable
;
and
should
hunt
its
object
through
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
deepest
despair
,
and
passion
scarcely
human
,
had
made
such
fierce
ravages
on
his
face
and
form
,
in
that
one
night
,
that
his
companions
in
misfortune
shrank
affrighted
from
him
as
he
passed
by
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
bloodshot
and
heavy
,
his
face
a
deadly
white
,
and
his
body
bent
as
if
with
age
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
bitten
his
under
lip
nearly
through
in
the
violence
of
his
mental
suffering
,
and
the
blood
which
had
flowed
from
the
wound
had
trickled
down
his
chin
,
and
stained
his
shirt
and
neckerchief
.
 
<EOS>
No
tear
,
or
sound
of
complaint
escaped
him
;
but
the
unsettled
look
,
and
disordered
haste
with
which
he
paced
up
and
down
the
yard
,
denoted
the
fever
which
was
burning
within
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
necessary
that
his
wife
's
body
should
be
removed
from
the
prison
,
without
delay
.
 
<EOS>
He
received
the
communication
with
perfect
calmness
,
and
acquiesced
in
its
propriety
.
 
<EOS>
Nearly
all
the
inmates
of
the
prison
had
assembled
to
witness
its
removal
;
they
fell
back
on
either
side
when
the
widower
appeared
;
he
walked
hurriedly
forward
,
and
stationed
himself
,
alone
,
in
a
little
railed
area
close
to
the
lodge
gate
,
from
whence
the
crowd
,
with
an
instinctive
feeling
of
delicacy
,
had
retired
.
 
<EOS>
The
rude
coffin
was
borne
slowly
forward
on
men
's
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
A
dead
silence
pervaded
the
throng
,
broken
only
by
the
audible
lamentations
of
the
women
,
and
the
shuffling
steps
of
the
bearers
on
the
stone
pavement
.
<EOS>
They
reached
the
spot
where
the
bereaved
husband
stood
:
and
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
He
laid
his
hand
upon
the
coffin
,
and
mechanically
adjusting
the
pall
with
which
it
was
covered
,
motioned
them
onward
.
 
<EOS>
The
turnkeys
in
the
prison
lobby
took
off
their
hats
as
it
passed
through
,
and
in
another
moment
the
heavy
gate
closed
behind
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
vacantly
upon
the
crowd
,
and
fell
heavily
to
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Although
for
many
weeks
after
this
,
he
was
watched
,
night
and
day
,
in
the
wildest
ravings
of
fever
,
neither
the
consciousness
of
his
loss
,
nor
the
recollection
of
the
vow
he
had
made
,
ever
left
him
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Scenes
changed
before
his
eyes
,
place
succeeded
place
,
and
event
followed
event
,
in
all
the
hurry
of
delirium
;
but
they
were
all
connected
in
some
way
with
the
great
object
of
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sailing
over
a
boundless
expanse
of
sea
,
with
a
blood
-
red
sky
above
,
and
the
angry
waters
,
lashed
into
fury
beneath
,
boiling
and
eddying
up
,
on
every
side
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
vessel
before
them
,
toiling
and
labouring
in
the
howling
storm
;
her
canvas
fluttering
in
ribbons
from
the
mast
,
and
her
deck
thronged
with
figures
who
were
lashed
to
the
sides
,
over
which
huge
waves
<EOS>
every
instant
burst
,
sweeping
away
some
devoted
creatures
into
the
foaming
sea
.
 
<EOS>
Onward
they
bore
,
amidst
the
roaring
mass
of
water
,
with
a
speed
and
force
which
nothing
could
resist
;
and
striking
the
stem
of
the
foremost
vessel
,
crushed
her
beneath
their
keel
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
huge
whirlpool
which
the
sinking
wreck
occasioned
,
arose
a
shriek
so
loud
and
shrill
---
<EOS>
the
death
-
cry
of
a
hundred
drowning
creatures
,
blended
into
one
fierce
yell
---
that
it
rung
far
above
the
war
-
cry
of
the
elements
,
and
echoed
,
and
re
-
echoed
till
it
seemed
to
pierce
air
,
sky
,
and
ocean
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
was
that
---
that
old
gray
head
that
rose
above
the
water
's
surface
,
and
with
looks
of
agony
,
and
screams
for
aid
,
<EOS>
buffeted
with
the
waves
!
 
<EOS>
One
look
,
and
he
had
sprung
from
the
vessel
's
side
,
and
with
vigorous
strokes
was
swimming
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
reached
it
;
he
was
close
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
HIS
features
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
saw
him
coming
,
and
vainly
strove
to
elude
his
grasp
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
clasped
him
tight
,
and
dragged
him
beneath
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
Down
,
down
with
him
,
fifty
fathoms
down
;
his
struggles
grew
fainter
and
fainter
,
until
they
wholly
ceased
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dead
;
he
had
killed
him
,
and
had
kept
his
oath
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
traversing
the
scorching
sands
of
a
mighty
desert
,
barefoot
and
alone
.
 
<EOS>
The
sand
choked
and
blinded
him
;
its
fine
thin
grains
entered
the
very
pores
of
his
skin
,
and
irritated
him
almost
to
madness
.
 
<EOS>
Gigantic
masses
of
the
same
material
,
carried
forward
by
the
wind
,
and
shone
through
by
the
burning
sun
,
stalked
in
the
distance
like
pillars
of
living
fire
.
 
<EOS>
The
bones
of
men
,
who
had
perished
in
the
dreary
waste
,
lay
scattered
at
his
feet
;
a
fearful
light
fell
on
everything
around
;
so
far
as
the
eye
could
reach
,
nothing
but
objects
of
dread
and
horror
presented
themselves
.
<EOS>
Vainly
striving
to
utter
a
cry
of
terror
,
with
his
tongue
cleaving
to
his
mouth
,
he
rushed
madly
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Armed
with
supernatural
strength
,
he
waded
through
the
sand
,
until
,
exhausted
with
fatigue
and
thirst
,
he
fell
senseless
on
the
earth
.
<EOS>
What
fragrant
coolness
revived
him
;
what
gushing
sound
was
that
?
 
<EOS>
Water
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
a
well
;
and
the
clear
fresh
stream
was
running
at
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
He
drank
deeply
of
it
,
and
throwing
his
aching
limbs
upon
the
bank
,
sank
into
a
delicious
trance
.
 
<EOS>
The
sound
of
approaching
footsteps
roused
him
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
gray
-
headed
man
tottered
forward
to
slake
his
burning
thirst
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
HE
again
!
<EOS>
Fe
wound
his
arms
round
the
old
man
's
body
,
and
held
him
back
.
<EOS>
He
struggled
,
and
shrieked
for
water
---
for
but
one
drop
of
water
to
save
his
life
!
 
<EOS>
But
he
held
the
old
man
firmly
,
and
watched
his
agonies
with
greedy
eyes
;
and
when
his
lifeless
head
fell
forward
on
his
bosom
,
he
rolled
the
corpse
from
him
with
his
feet
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
the
fever
left
him
,
and
consciousness
returned
,
he
awoke
to
find
himself
rich
and
free
,
to
hear
that
the
parent
who
would
have
let
him
die
in
jail
---
WOULD
!
<EOS>
who
HAD
let
those
who
were
far
dearer
to
him
than
his
own
existence
die
of
want
,
and
sickness
of
heart
that
medicine
can
not
cure
---
had
been
found
dead
in
his
bed
of
down
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
had
all
the
heart
to
leave
his
son
a
beggar
,
but
proud
even
of
his
health
and
strength
,
had
put
off
the
act
till
it
was
too
late
,
and
now
might
gnash
his
teeth
in
the
other
world
,
at
the
thought
of
the
wealth
his
remissness
had
left
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
awoke
to
this
,
and
he
awoke
to
more
.
 
<EOS>
To
recollect
the
purpose
for
which
he
lived
,
and
to
remember
that
his
enemy
was
his
wife
's
own
father
---
the
man
who
had
cast
him
into
prison
,
and
who
,
when
his
daughter
and
her
child
sued
at
his
feet
for
mercy
,
had
spurned
them
from
his
door
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
he
cursed
the
weakness
that
prevented
him
from
being
up
,
and
active
,
in
his
scheme
of
vengeance
!
"
<EOS>
He
caused
himself
to
be
carried
from
the
scene
of
his
loss
and
misery
,
and
conveyed
to
a
quiet
residence
on
the
sea
-
coast
;
not
in
the
hope
of
recovering
his
peace
of
mind
or
happiness
,
for
both
were
fled
for
ever
;
but
to
restore
his
prostrate
energies
,
and
meditate
on
his
darling
object
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
,
some
evil
spirit
cast
in
his
way
the
opportunity
for
his
first
,
most
horrible
revenge
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
summer
-
time
;
and
wrapped
in
his
gloomy
thoughts
,
he
would
issue
from
his
solitary
lodgings
early
in
the
evening
,
and
wandering
along
a
narrow
path
beneath
the
cliffs
,
to
a
wild
and
lonely
spot
that
had
struck
his
fancy
in
his
ramblings
,
seat
himself
on
some
fallen
fragment
of
the
rock
,
and
burying
his
face
in
his
hands
,
remain
there
for
hours
---
sometimes
until
night
had
completely
closed
in
,
and
the
long
shadows
of
the
frowning
cliffs
above
his
head
cast
a
thick
,
black
darkness
on
every
object
near
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
seated
here
,
one
calm
evening
,
in
his
old
position
,
now
and
then
raising
his
head
to
watch
the
flight
of
a
sea
-
gull
,
or
carry
his
eye
along
the
glorious
crimson
path
,
which
,
commencing
in
the
middle
of
the
ocean
,
seemed
to
lead
to
its
very
verge
where
the
sun
was
setting
,
when
the
profound
stillness
of
the
spot
was
broken
by
a
loud
cry
for
help
;
he
listened
,
doubtful
of
his
having
heard
aright
,
when
the
cry
was
repeated
with
even
greater
vehemence
than
before
,
and
,
starting
to
his
feet
,
he
hastened
in
the
direction
whence
it
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
tale
told
itself
at
once
:
some
scattered
garments
lay
on
the
beach
;
a
human
head
was
just
visible
above
the
waves
at
a
little
distance
from
the
shore
;
and
an
old
man
,
wringing
his
hands
in
agony
,
was
running
to
and
fro
,
shrieking
for
assistance
.
<EOS>
The
invalid
,
whose
strength
was
now
sufficiently
restored
,
threw
off
his
coat
,
and
rushed
towards
the
sea
,
with
the
intention
of
plunging
in
,
and
dragging
the
drowning
man
ashore
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Hasten
here
,
Sir
,
in
God
's
name
;
help
,
help
,
sir
,
for
the
love
of
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
my
son
,
Sir
,
my
only
son
!
"
said
the
old
man
frantically
,
as
he
advanced
to
meet
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
only
son
,
Sir
,
and
he
is
dying
before
his
father
's
eyes
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
the
first
word
the
old
man
uttered
,
the
stranger
checked
himself
in
his
career
,
and
,
folding
his
arms
,
stood
perfectly
motionless
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Great
God
!
"
exclaimed
the
old
man
,
recoiling
,
"
Heyling
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
stranger
smiled
,
and
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Heyling
!
"
said
the
old
man
wildly
;
"
my
boy
,
Heyling
,
my
dear
boy
,
look
,
look
!
"
<EOS>
Gasping
for
breath
,
the
miserable
father
pointed
to
the
spot
where
the
young
man
was
struggling
for
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Hark
!
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
cries
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
alive
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Heyling
,
save
him
,
save
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
stranger
smiled
again
,
and
remained
immovable
as
a
statue
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
have
wronged
you
,
"
shrieked
the
old
man
,
falling
on
his
knees
,
and
clasping
his
hands
together
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
revenged
;
take
my
all
,
my
life
;
cast
me
into
the
water
at
your
feet
,
and
,
if
human
nature
can
repress
a
struggle
,
I
will
die
,
without
stirring
hand
or
foot
.
<EOS>
Do
it
,
Heyling
,
do
it
,
but
save
my
boy
;
he
is
so
young
,
Heyling
,
so
young
to
die
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Listen
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
grasping
the
old
man
fiercely
by
the
wrist
;
"
I
will
have
life
for
life
,
and
here
is
ONE
.
 
<EOS>
MY
child
died
,
before
his
father
's
eyes
,
a
far
more
agonising
and
painful
death
than
that
young
slanderer
of
his
sister
's
worth
is
meeting
while
I
speak
.
 
<EOS>
You
laughed
---
<EOS>
laughed
in
your
daughter
's
face
,
where
death
had
already
set
his
hand
---
at
our
sufferings
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
What
think
you
of
them
now
!
 
<EOS>
See
there
,
see
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
the
stranger
spoke
,
he
pointed
to
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
A
faint
cry
died
away
upon
its
surface
;
the
last
powerful
struggle
of
the
dying
man
agitated
the
rippling
waves
for
a
few
seconds
;
and
the
spot
where
he
had
gone
down
into
his
early
grave
,
was
undistinguishable
from
the
surrounding
water
.
   
<EOS>
"
Three
years
had
elapsed
,
when
a
gentleman
alighted
from
a
private
carriage
at
the
door
of
a
London
attorney
,
then
well
known
as
a
man
of
no
great
nicety
in
his
professional
dealings
,
and
requested
a
private
interview
on
business
of
importance
.
<EOS>
Although
evidently
not
past
the
prime
of
life
,
his
face
was
pale
,
haggard
,
and
dejected
;
and
it
did
not
require
the
acute
perception
of
the
man
of
business
,
to
discern
at
a
glance
,
that
disease
or
suffering
had
done
more
to
work
a
change
in
his
appearance
,
than
the
mere
hand
of
time
could
have
accomplished
in
twice
the
period
of
his
whole
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
wish
you
to
undertake
some
legal
business
for
me
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
attorney
bowed
obsequiously
,
and
glanced
at
a
large
packet
which
the
gentleman
carried
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
His
visitor
observed
the
look
,
and
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
is
no
common
business
,
"
said
he
;
"
nor
have
these
papers
reached
my
hands
without
long
trouble
and
great
expense
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
attorney
cast
a
still
more
anxious
look
at
the
packet
;
and
his
visitor
,
untying
the
string
that
bound
it
,
disclosed
a
quantity
of
promissory
notes
,
with
copies
of
deeds
,
and
other
documents
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Upon
these
papers
,
"
said
the
client
,
"
the
man
whose
name
they
bear
,
has
raised
,
as
you
will
see
,
large
sums
of
money
,
for
years
past
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
tacit
understanding
between
him
and
the
men
into
whose
hands
they
originally
went
---
and
from
whom
I
have
by
degrees
purchased
the
whole
,
for
treble
and
quadruple
their
nominal
value
---
that
these
loans
should
be
from
time
to
time
renewed
,
until
a
given
period
had
elapsed
.
 
<EOS>
Such
an
understanding
is
nowhere
expressed
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
sustained
many
losses
of
late
;
and
these
obligations
accumulating
upon
him
at
once
,
would
crush
him
to
the
earth
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
The
whole
amount
is
many
thousands
of
pounds
,
"
said
the
attorney
,
looking
over
the
papers
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
is
,
"
said
the
client
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
are
we
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
man
of
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Do
!
"
replied
the
client
,
with
sudden
vehemence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
every
engine
of
the
law
in
force
,
every
trick
that
ingenuity
can
devise
and
rascality
execute
;
fair
means
and
foul
;
the
open
oppression
of
the
law
,
aided
by
all
the
craft
of
its
most
ingenious
practitioners
.
<EOS>
I
would
have
him
die
a
harassing
and
lingering
death
.
 
<EOS>
Ruin
him
,
seize
and
sell
his
lands
and
goods
,
drive
him
from
house
and
home
,
and
drag
him
forth
a
beggar
in
his
old
age
,
to
die
in
a
common
jail
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
But
the
costs
,
my
dear
Sir
,
the
costs
of
all
this
,
"
reasoned
the
attorney
,
when
he
had
recovered
from
his
momentary
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
If
the
defendant
be
a
man
of
straw
,
who
is
to
pay
the
costs
,
Sir
?
"
   
"
"
Name
any
sum
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
his
hand
trembling
so
violently
with
excitement
,
that
he
could
scarcely
hold
the
pen
he
seized
as
he
spoke
---
"
any
sum
,
and
it
is
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
to
name
it
,
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
not
think
it
dear
,
if
you
gain
my
object
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
attorney
named
a
large
sum
,
at
hazard
,
as
the
advance
he
should
require
to
secure
himself
against
the
possibility
of
loss
;
but
more
with
the
view
of
ascertaining
how
far
his
client
was
really
disposed
to
go
,
than
with
any
idea
that
he
would
comply
with
the
demand
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
wrote
a
cheque
upon
his
banker
,
for
the
whole
amount
,
and
left
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
draft
was
duly
honoured
,
and
the
attorney
,
finding
that
his
strange
client
might
be
safely
relied
upon
,
commenced
his
work
in
earnest
.
 
<EOS>
For
more
than
two
years
afterwards
,
Mr
Heyling
would
sit
whole
days
together
,
in
the
office
,
poring
over
the
papers
as
they
accumulated
,
and
reading
again
and
again
,
his
eyes
gleaming
with
joy
,
the
letters
of
remonstrance
,
the
prayers
for
a
little
delay
,
the
representations
of
the
certain
ruin
in
which
the
opposite
party
must
be
involved
,
which
poured
in
,
as
suit
after
suit
,
and
process
after
process
,
was
commenced
.
 
<EOS>
To
all
applications
for
a
brief
indulgence
,
there
was
but
one
reply
---
<EOS>
the
money
must
be
paid
.
 
<EOS>
Land
,
house
,
furniture
,
each
in
its
turn
,
was
taken
under
some
one
of
the
numerous
executions
which
were
issued
;
and
the
old
man
himself
would
have
been
immured
in
prison
<EOS>
had
he
not
escaped
the
vigilance
of
the
officers
,
and
fled
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
implacable
animosity
of
Heyling
,
so
far
from
being
satiated
by
the
success
of
his
persecution
,
increased
a
hundredfold
with
the
ruin
he
inflicted
.
 
<EOS>
On
being
informed
of
the
old
man
's
flight
,
his
fury
was
unbounded
.
 
<EOS>
He
gnashed
his
teeth
with
rage
,
tore
the
hair
from
his
head
,
and
assailed
with
horrid
imprecations
the
men
who
had
been
intrusted
with
the
writ
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
only
restored
to
comparative
calmness
by
repeated
assurances
of
the
certainty
of
discovering
the
fugitive
.
 
<EOS>
Agents
were
sent
in
quest
of
him
,
in
all
directions
;
every
stratagem
that
could
be
invented
was
resorted
to
,
for
the
purpose
of
discovering
his
place
of
retreat
;
but
it
was
all
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
Half
a
year
had
passed
over
,
and
he
was
still
undiscovered
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
length
late
one
night
,
Heyling
,
of
whom
nothing
had
been
seen
for
many
weeks
before
,
appeared
at
his
attorney
's
private
residence
,
and
sent
up
word
that
a
gentleman
wished
to
see
him
instantly
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
attorney
,
who
had
recognised
his
voice
from
above
stairs
,
could
order
the
servant
to
admit
him
,
he
had
rushed
up
the
staircase
,
and
entered
the
drawing
-
room
pale
and
breathless
.
<EOS>
Having
closed
the
door
,
to
prevent
being
overheard
,
he
sank
into
a
chair
,
and
said
,
in
a
low
voice
---
   
"
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
I
have
found
him
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
No
!
"
said
the
attorney
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
done
,
my
dear
sir
,
well
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
He
lies
concealed
in
a
wretched
lodging
in
Camden
Town
,
"
said
Heyling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
is
as
well
we
DID
lose
sight
of
him
,
for
he
has
been
living
alone
there
,
in
the
most
abject
misery
,
all
the
time
,
and
he
is
poor
---
very
poor
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Very
good
,
"
said
the
attorney
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
have
the
caption
made
to
-
morrow
,
of
course
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Heyling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
The
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
surprised
at
my
wishing
to
postpone
it
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
ghastly

;
"
<EOS>
but
I
had
forgotten
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
day
is
an
anniversary
in
his
life
:
let
it
be
done
then
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
the
attorney
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
write
down

for
the
officer
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
No
;
let
him
meet
me
here
,
at
eight
in
the
evening
,
and
I
will
accompany
him

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
met
on
the
appointed
night
,
and
,
hiring
a
hackney
-

,
directed
the
driver
to
stop
at
that
corner
of
the
old
Pancras
Road
,
at
which
stands
the
parish
workhouse
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
they
alighted
there
,
it
was
quite
dark
;
and
,
proceeding
by
the
dead
wall
in
front
of
the
Veterinary
Hospital
,
they
entered
a
small
by
-
street
,
which
is
,
or
was
at
that
time
,
called
Little
College
Street
,
and
which
,
whatever
it
may
be
now
,
was
in
those
days
a
desolate
place
enough
,
surrounded
by
little
else
than
fields
and
ditches
.
   
<EOS>
"
Having
drawn
the
travelling
-
cap
he
had
on
half
over
his
face
,
and
muffled
himself
in
his
cloak
,
Heyling
stopped
before
the
meanest
-
looking
house
in
the
street
,
and
knocked
gently
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
at
once
opened
by
a
woman
,
who
dropped
a
curtsey
of
recognition
,
and
Heyling
,
whispering
the
officer
to
remain
below
,
crept
gently
upstairs
,
and
,
opening
the
door
of
the
front
room
,
entered
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
object
of
his
search
and
his
unrelenting
animosity
,
now
a
decrepit
old
man
,
was
seated
at
a
bare
deal
table
,
on
which
stood
a
miserable
candle
.
 
<EOS>
He
started
on
the
entrance
of
the
stranger
,
and
rose
feebly
to
his
feet
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
What
now
,
what
now
?
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
fresh
misery
is
this
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
A
word
with
YOU
,
"
replied
Heyling
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
seated
himself
at
the
other
end
of
the
table
,
and
,
throwing
off
his
cloak
and
cap
,
disclosed
his
features
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
man
seemed
instantly
deprived
of
speech
.
 
<EOS>
He
fell
backward
in
his
chair
,
and
,
clasping
his
hands
together
,
gazed
on
the
apparition
with
a
mingled
look
of
abhorrence
and
fear
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
This
day
six
years
,
"
said
Heyling
,
"
I
claimed
the
life
you
owed
me
for
my
child
's
.
 
<EOS>
Beside
the
lifeless
form
of
your
daughter
,
old
man
,
I
swore
to
live
a
life
of
revenge
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
swerved
from
my
purpose
for
a
moment
's
space
;
but
if
I
had
,
one
thought
of
her
uncomplaining
,
suffering
look
,
as
she
drooped
away
,
or
of
the
starving
face
of
our
innocent
child
,
would
have
nerved
me
to
my
task
.
 
<EOS>
My
first
act
of
requital
<EOS>
you
well
remember
:
this
is
my
last
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
man
shivered
,
and
his
hands
dropped
powerless
by
his
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
leave
England
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Heyling
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
I
consign
you
to
the
living
death
to
which
you
devoted
her
---
a
hopeless
prison
---
"
   
"
He
raised
his
eyes
to
the
old
man
's
countenance
,
and
paused
.
<EOS>
He
lifted
the
light
to
his
face
,
set
it
gently
down
,
and
left
the
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
had
better
see
to
the
old
man
,
"
he
said
to
the
woman
,
as
he
opened
the
door
,
and
motioned
the
officer
to
follow
him
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
ill
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
woman
closed
the
door
,
ran
hastily
upstairs
,
and
found
him
lifeless
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beneath
a
plain
gravestone
,
in
one
of
the
most
peaceful
and
secluded
churchyards
in
Kent
,
where
wild
flowers
mingle
with
the
grass
,
and
the
soft
landscape
around
forms
the
fairest
spot
in
the
garden
of
England
,
lie
the
bones
of
the
young
mother
and
her
gentle
child
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
ashes
of
the
father
do
not
mingle
with
theirs
;
nor
,
from
that
night
forward
,
did
the
attorney
ever
gain
the
remotest
clue
to
the
subsequent
history
of
his
queer
client
.
<EOS>
"
As
the
old
man
concluded
his
tale
,
he
advanced
to
a
peg
in
one
corner
,
and
taking
down
his
hat
and
coat
,
put
them
on
with
great
deliberation
;
and
,
without
saying
another
word
,
walked
slowly
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
gentleman
with
the
Mosaic
studs
had
fallen
asleep
,
and
the
major
part
of
the
company
were
deeply
occupied
in
the
humorous
process
of
dropping
melted
tallow
-
grease
into
his
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
Mr
Pickwick
departed
unnoticed
,
and
having
settled
his
own
score
,
and
that
of
Mr
Weller
,
issued
forth
,
in
company
with
that
gentleman
,
from
beneath
the
portal
of
the
Magpie
and
Stump
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
journeys
to
Ipswich
and
meets
with
a
romantic
adventure
with
a
middle
-
aged
lady
in
yellow
curl
papers
 
<EOS>
"
That
'
ere
your
governor
's
luggage
,
Sammy
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Weller
of
his
affectionate
son
,
as
he
entered
the
yard
of
the
Bull
Inn
,
Whitechapel
,
with
a

-
bag
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
might
ha
'
made
a
worser
guess
than
that
,
old
feller
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
the
younger
,
setting
down
his
burden
in
the
yard
,
and
sitting
himself
down
upon
it
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
governor
hisself'll
be
down
here
presently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
-
cabbin
'
it
,
I

?
"
said
the
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
's
a
havin'
<EOS>
two
mile
o
'
danger
at
eight
-
pence
,
"
responded

.
 
<EOS>
"
How
's
mother
-
in
-
law
this
mornin
'
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Queer
,
Sammy
,
queer
,
"
replied
the
elder
Mr
Weller
,
with
impressive
gravity
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
been
gettin
'
rayther
in
the
Methodistical
order
lately
,
Sammy
;
and
she

uncommon

<EOS>

<EOS>
care
o
'
<EOS>
the
archvay
,
gen'l'm'n
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heads
,
"
as
the
pieman
says
.
 
<EOS>
That
'll
do
,
Villam
.
 
<EOS>
Let
'em
alone
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
away
went
the
coach
up
Whitechapel
,
to
the
admiration
of
the
whole
population
of
that
pretty
densely
populated
quarter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
wery
nice
neighbourhood
,
this
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
with
a
touch
of
the
hat
,
which
always
preceded
his
entering
into
conversation
with
his
master
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
indeed
,
Sam
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
surveying
the
crowded
and
filthy
street
through
which
they
were
passing
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
wery
remarkable
circumstance
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
that
poverty
and
oysters
always
seem
to
go
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
mean
,
sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
is
,
that
the
poorer
a
place
is
,
the
greater
call
there
seems
to
be
for
oysters
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
,
sir
;
here
's
a
oyster
-
stall
to
every
half
-
dozen
houses
.
 
<EOS>
The
street
's
lined
vith
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Blessed
if
I
do
n't
think
that
ven
a
man
's
wery
poor
,
he
rushes
out
of
his
lodgings
,
and
eats
oysters
in
reg'lar
desperation
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
be
sure
he
does
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
senior
;
"
and
it
's
just
the
same
vith
pickled
salmon
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Those
are
two
very
remarkable
facts
,
which
never
occurred
to
me
before
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
first
place
we
stop
at
,
I
'll
make
a
note
of
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
the
turnpike
at
Mile
End
;
a
profound
silence
prevailed
until
they
had
got
two
or
three
miles
farther
on
,
when
Mr
Weller
,
senior
,
turning
suddenly
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
queer
life
is
a
pike
-
keeper
's
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
what
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
pike
-
keeper
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
a
pike
-
keeper
?
"
inquired
Mr
Peter
Magnus
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
'
un
means
a
turnpike
-
keeper
,
gen'l'm'n
,
"
observed
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
in
explanation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
see
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
;
very
curious
life
.
<EOS>
Very
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
're
all
on
'em
men
as
has
met
vith
some
disappointment
in
life
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
senior
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Consequence
of
vich
<EOS>
,
they
retires
from
the
world
,
and
shuts
themselves
up
in
pikes
;
partly
with
the
view
of
being

,
and
partly
to
rewenge
themselves
on
mankind
by
takin
'

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
never

before
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fact
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
;
"
if
they
was

,
you
'd
call

misanthropes
,
but
as

is
,
they
only
takes
to
pike
-
keepin
'
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
such
conversation
,
possessing
the
inestimable
charm
of
blending
amusement
with
instruction
,
did
Mr
Weller
beguile
the
tediousness
of
the
journey
,
during
the
greater
part
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
Topics
of
conversation
were
never
wanting
,
for
even
when
any
pause
occurred
in
Mr
Weller
's
loquacity
,
it
was
abundantly
supplied
by
the
desire
evinced
by
Mr
Magnus
to
make
himself
acquainted
with
the
whole
of
the
personal
history
of
his
fellow
-
travellers
,
and
his
loudly
-
expressed
anxiety
at
every
stage
,
respecting
the
safety
and
well
-
being
of
the
two
bags
,
the
leather
hat
-
box
,
and
the
brown
-
paper
parcel
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
main
street
of
Ipswich
,
on
the
left
-
hand
side
of
the
way
,
a
short
distance
after
you
have
passed
through
the
open
space
fronting
the
Town
Hall
,
stands
an
inn
known
far
and
wide
by
the
appellation
of
the
Great
White
Horse
,
rendered
the
more
conspicuous
by
a
stone
statue
of
some
rampacious
animal
with
flowing
mane
and
tail
,
distantly
resembling
an
insane
cart
-
horse
,
which
is
elevated
above
the
principal
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
Great
White
Horse
is
famous
in
the
neighbourhood
,
in
the
same
degree
as
a
prize
ox
,
or
a
county
-
paper
-
chronicled
turnip
,
or
unwieldy
pig
---
for
its
enormous
size
.
 
<EOS>
Never
was
such
labyrinths
of
uncarpeted
passages
,
such
clusters
of
mouldy
,
ill
-
lighted
rooms
,
such
huge
numbers
of
small
dens
for
eating
or
sleeping
in
,
beneath
any
one
roof
,
as
are
collected
together
between
the
four
walls
of
the
Great
White
Horse
at
Ipswich
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
the
door
of
this
overgrown
tavern
that
the
London
coach
stopped
,
at
the
same
hour
every
evening
;
and
it
was
from
this
same
London
coach
that
Mr
Pickwick
,
Sam
Weller
,
and
Mr
Peter
Magnus
dismounted
,
on
the
particular
evening
to
which
this
chapter
of
our
history
bears
reference
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
stop
here
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
when
the
striped
bag
,
and
the
red
bag
,
and
the
brown
-
paper
parcel
,
and
the
leather
hat
-
box
,
had
all
been
deposited
in
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
stop
here
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
Mr
Magnus
,
"
<EOS>
I
never
knew
anything
like
these
extraordinary
coincidences
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
stop
here
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
we
dine
together
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
pleasure
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
quite
certain
whether
I
have
any
friends
here
or
not
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
any
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Tupman
here
,
waiter
?
"
   
<EOS>
A
corpulent
man
,
with
a
fortnight
's
napkin
under
his
arm
,
and
coeval
stockings
on
his
legs
,
slowly
desisted
from
his
occupation
of
staring
down
the
street
,
on
this
question
being
put
to
him
by
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
,
after
minutely
inspecting
that
gentleman
's
appearance
,
from
the

of
his
hat
to
the
lowest

of
his

,
replied
emphatically
---
   
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nor
any
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Snodgrass
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nor
Winkle
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
friends
have
not
arrived
to
-
day
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
dine
alone
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
Show
us
a
private
room
,
waiter
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
this
request
being
preferred
,
the
corpulent
man
condescended
to
order
the
boots
to
bring
in
the
gentlemen
's
luggage
;
and
preceding
them
down
a
long
,
dark
passage
,
ushered
them
into
a
large
,
badly
-
furnished
apartment
,
with
a
dirty
grate
,
in
which
a
small
fire
was
making
a
wretched
attempt
to
be
cheerful
,
but
was
fast
sinking
beneath
the
dispiriting
influence
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
After
the
lapse
of
an
hour
,
a
bit
of
fish
and
a
steak
was
served
up
to
the
travellers
,
and
when
the
dinner
was
cleared
away
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Peter
Magnus
drew
their
chairs
up
to
the
fire
,
and
having
ordered
a
bottle
of
the
worst
possible
port
wine
,
at
the
highest
possible
price
,
for
the
good
of
the
house
,
drank
brandy
-
and
-
water
for
their
own
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Peter
Magnus
was
naturally
of
a
very
communicative
disposition
,
and
the
brandy
-
and
-
water
operated
with
wonderful
effect
in
warming
into
life
the
deepest
hidden
secrets
of
his
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
After
sundry
accounts
of
himself
,
his
family
,
his
connections
,
his
friends
,
his
jokes
,
his
business
,
and
his
brothers
(
most
talkative
men
have
a
great
deal
to
say
about
their
brothers
)
,
Mr
Peter
Magnus
took
a
view
of
Mr
Pickwick
through
his
coloured
spectacles
for
several
minutes
,
and
then
said
,
with
an
air
of
modesty
---
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
think
---
what
DO
you
think
,
Mr
Pickwick
---
I
have
come
down
here
for
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
it
is
wholly
impossible
for
me
to
guess
;
on
business
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Partly
right
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
"
but
partly
wrong
at
the
same
time
;
try
again
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
must
throw
myself
on
your
mercy
,
to
tell
me
or
not
,
as
you
may
think
best
;
for
I
should
never
guess
,
if
I
were
to
try
all
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
he
-
he
-
he
!
"
said
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
with

,
"

,
Mr
Pickwick
,

,
Sir
,

?
 
<EOS>
He
,
he
,
he
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
!
 
<EOS>
That
you
are
very
likely

,
"

Mr
Pickwick
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
 
<EOS>
Do

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
;
<EOS>
but

're

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"
said

,
"
to

secret
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
telling
you
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
although
I
'm
dreadful
jealous
by
nature
---
horrid
---
that
the

is
in
this
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Magnus
took
off
his

,
on
purpose
to
wink
,
and
then
put

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
you
were

of
the
room
for
,
before
dinner
,
then
,
so
often
,
"
said
Mr

archly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
you
're
right
,
that
was
it
;
not
such

fool

her
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
would
n't
do
,
you
know
,
after
having
just

off

.
 
<EOS>
Wait
till
to
-
morrow
,
sir
;
double
the

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
Sir
,
there
is
a
suit
of
clothes
in
that
bag
,
and
a
hat
in
that
box
,
which
,
I
expect
,
in
the
effect

will

,
will
be
invaluable
to
me
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
you
must
have
observed
my
anxiety
about
them
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
believe
that
such
another
suit
of
clothes
,
and
such
a
hat
,
could
be
bought
for
money
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
congratulated
the
fortunate
owner
of
the
irresistible
garments
on
their
acquisition
;
and
Mr
Peter
Magnus
remained

apparently

in

.
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
fine
creature
,
"
said
Mr
Magnus
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
she
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
Mr
Magnus
.
 
<EOS>
"
very
.
 
<EOS>
She
lives
about
twenty
miles
from
here
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
she
would
be
here
to
-
night
and
all
to
-
morrow
forenoon
,
and
came
down
to
seize
the
opportunity
.
<EOS>
I
think
an
inn
is
a
good
sort
of
a
place
to
propose
to
a
single
woman
in
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
more
likely
to
feel
the
loneliness
of
her
situation
in
travelling
,
perhaps
,
than
she
would
be
at
home
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
very
probable
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
"
but
I
am
naturally
rather
curious
;
what
may
you
have
come
down
here
for
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
a
far
less

errand
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
the
colour
mounting
to
his
face
at

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
down
here
,
Sir
,
to
expose
the
treachery
and
falsehood
of
an
individual
,
upon
whose
truth
and

I
placed
implicit

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
<EOS>
"
that
's
very
unpleasant
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
lady
,
I
presume
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
ah
!
 
<EOS>
Sly
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
sly
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
sir
,
I
would
n't
probe
your
feelings
for
the
world
.
<EOS>
Painful
subjects
,
these
,
sir
,
very

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
me
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
if
you
wish
to
give
vent
to
your
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
it
is
to
be
jilted
,
Sir
;
I
have
endured
that
sort
of
thing
three
or
four
times
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
,
for
your
condolence
on
what
you
presume
to
be
my
melancholy
case
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
winding
up
his
watch
,
and
laying
it
on
the
table
,
"
<EOS>
but
---
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
"
not
a
word
more
;
it
's
a
painful
subject
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
,
I
see
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
time
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
<EOS>
"
Past
twelve
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
it
's
time
to
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
never
do
,
sitting
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
pale
<EOS>
to
-
morrow
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
bare
notion
of
such
a
calamity
,
Mr
Peter
Magnus
rang
the
bell
for
the
chambermaid
;
and
the
striped
bag
,
the
red
bag
,
the
leathern
hat
-
box
,
and
the
brown
-
paper
parcel
,
having
been
conveyed
to
his
bedroom
,
he
retired
in
company
with
a
japanned
candlestick
,
to
one
side
of
the
house
,
while
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
another
japanned
candlestick
,
were
conducted
through
a
multitude
of
tortuous
windings
,
to
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
your
room
,
sir
,
"
said
the
chambermaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
round
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
tolerably
large
double
-
bedded
room
,
with
a
fire
;
upon
the
whole
,
a
more
comfortable
-
looking
apartment
than
Mr
Pickwick
's
short
experience
of
the
accommodations
of
the
Great
White
Horse
had
led
him
to
expect
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
sleeps
in
the
other
bed
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
my
servant
to
bring
me
up
some
hot
water
at
half
-
past
eight
in
the
morning
,
and
that
I
shall
not
want
him
any
more
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"
and
bidding
Mr
Pickwick
good
-
night
,
the
chambermaid
retired
,
and
left
him
alone
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
sat
himself
down
in
a
chair
before
the
fire
,
and
fell
into
a
train
of
rambling
meditations
.
 
<EOS>
First
he
thought
of
his
friends
,
and
wondered
when
they
would
join
him
;
then
his
mind
reverted
to
Mrs
Martha
Bardell
;
and
from
that
lady
it
wandered
,
by
a
natural
process
,
to
the
dingy
counting
-
house
of
Dodson
&
Fogg
.
 
<EOS>
From
Dodson
&
Fogg
's
it
flew
off
at
a
tangent
,
to
the
very
centre
of
the
history
of
the
queer
client
;
and
then
it
came
back
to
the
Great
White
Horse
at
Ipswich
,
with
sufficient
clearness
to
convince
Mr
Pickwick
that
he
was
falling
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
roused
himself
,
and
began
to
undress
,
when
he
recollected
he
had
left
his
watch
on
the
table
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
Now
this
watch
was
a
special
favourite
with
Mr
Pickwick
,
having
been
carried
about
,
beneath
the
shadow
of
his
waistcoat
,
for
a
greater
number
of
years
than
we
feel
called
upon
to
state
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
The
possibility
of
going
to
sleep
,
unless
it
were
ticking
gently
beneath
his
pillow
,
or
in
the
watch
-
pocket
over
his
head
,
had
never
entered
Mr
Pickwick
's
brain
.
 
<EOS>
So
as
it
was
pretty
late
now
,
and
he
was
unwilling
to
ring
his
bell
at
that
hour
of
the
night
,
he
slipped
on
his
coat
,
of
which
he
had
just
divested
himself
,
and
taking
the
japanned
candlestick
in
his
hand
,
walked
quietly
downstairs
.
<EOS>
The
more
stairs
Mr
Pickwick
went
down
,
the
more
stairs
there
seemed
to
be
to
descend
,
and
again
and
again
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
got
into
some
narrow
passage
,
and
began
to
congratulate
himself
on
having
gained
the
ground
-
floor
,
did
another
flight
of
stairs
appear
before
his
astonished
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
reached
a
stone
hall
,
which
he
remembered
to
have
seen
when
he
entered
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Passage
after
passage
did
he
explore
<EOS>
;
room
after
room
did
he
peep
into
;
at
length
,
as
he
was
on
the
point
of
giving
up
the
search
in
despair
,
he
opened
the
door
of
the
identical
room
in
which
he
had
spent
the
evening
,
and
beheld
his
missing
property
on
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
seized
the
watch
in
triumph
,
and
proceeded
to
retrace
his
steps
to
his
bedchamber
.
 
<EOS>
If
his
progress
downward
had
been
attended
with
difficulties
and
uncertainty
,
his
journey
back
was
infinitely
more
perplexing
.
 
<EOS>
Rows
of
doors
,
garnished
with
boots
of
every
shape
,
make
,
and
size
,
branched
off
in
every
possible
direction
.
 
<EOS>
A
dozen
times
did
he
softly
turn
the
handle
of
some
bedroom
door
which
resembled
his
own
,
when
a
gruff
cry
from
within
of
"
Who
the
devil
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
or
"
What
do
you
want
here
?
<EOS>
"
caused
him
to
steal
away
,
on
tiptoe
,
with
a
perfectly
marvellous
celerity
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
reduced
to
the
verge
of
despair
,
when
an
open
door
attracted
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
He
peeped
in
.
 
<EOS>
Right
at
last
!
<EOS>
There
were
the
two
beds
,
whose
situation
he
perfectly
remembered
,
and
the
fire
still
burning
.
 
<EOS>
His
candle
,
not
a
long
one
when
he
first
received
it
,
had
flickered
away
in
the
drafts
of
air
through
which
he
had
passed
and
sank
into
the
socket
as
he
closed
the
door
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
can
undress
myself
just
as
well
by
the
light
of
the
fire
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
bedsteads
stood
one
on
each
side
of
the
door
;
and
on
the
inner
side
of
each
was
a
little
path
,
terminating
in
a
rush
-
bottomed
chair
,
just
wide
enough
to
admit
of
a
person
's
getting
into
or
out
of
bed
,
on
that
side
,
if
he
or
she
thought
proper
.
<EOS>
Having
carefully
drawn
the
curtains
of
his
bed
on
the
outside
,
Mr
Pickwick
sat
down
on
the
rush
-
bottomed
chair
,
and
leisurely
divested
himself
of
his
shoes
and
gaiters
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
took
off
and
folded
up
his
coat
,
waistcoat
,
and
neckcloth
,
and
slowly
drawing
on
his
tasselled
nightcap
,
secured
it
firmly
on
his
head
,
by
tying
beneath
his
chin
the
strings
which
he
always
had
attached
to
that
article
of
dress
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
moment
that
the
absurdity
of
his
recent
bewilderment
struck
upon
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Throwing
himself
back
in
the
rush
-
bottomed
chair
,
Mr
Pickwick
laughed
to
himself
so
heartily
,
that
it
would
have
been
quite
delightful
to
any
man
of
well
-
constituted
mind
to
have
watched
the
smiles
that
expanded
his
amiable
features
as
they
shone
forth
from
beneath
the
nightcap
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
best
idea
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
to
himself
,
smiling
till
he
almost
cracked
the
nightcap
strings
---
<EOS>
"
it
is
the
best
idea
,
my
losing
myself
in
this
place
,
and
wandering
about
these
staircases
,
that
I
ever
heard
of
.
 
<EOS>
Droll
,
droll
,
very
droll
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Pickwick
smiled
again
,
a
broader
smile
than
before
,
and
was
about
to
continue
the
process
of
undressing
,
in
the
best
possible
humour
,
when
he
was
suddenly
stopped
by
a
most
unexpected
interruption
:
to
wit
,
the
entrance
into
the
room
of
some
person
with
a
candle
,
who
,
after
locking
the
door
,
advanced
to
the
dressing
-
table
,
and
set
down
the
light
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
smile
that
played
on
Mr
Pickwick
's
features
was
instantaneously
lost
in
a
look
of
the
most
unbounded
and
wonder
-
stricken
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
The
person
,
whoever
it
was
,
had
come
in
so
suddenly
and
with
so
little
noise
,
that
Mr
Pickwick
had
had
no
time
to
call
out
,
or
oppose
their
entrance
.
 
<EOS>
Who
could
it
be
?
 
<EOS>
A
robber
?
 
<EOS>
Some
evil
-
minded
person
who
had
seen
him
come
upstairs
with
a
handsome
watch
in
his
hand
,
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
?
   
<EOS>
The
only
way
in
which
Mr
Pickwick
could
catch
a
glimpse
of
his
mysterious
visitor
with
the
least
danger
of
being
seen
himself
,
was
by
creeping
on
to
the
bed
,
and
peeping
out
from
between
the
curtains
on
the
opposite
side
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
manoeuvre
he
accordingly
resorted
.
 
<EOS>
Keeping
the
curtains
carefully
closed
with
his
hand
,
so
that
nothing
more
of
him
could
be
seen
than
his
face
and
nightcap
,
and
putting
on
his
spectacles
,
he
mustered
up
courage
and
looked
out
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
almost
fainted
with
horror
and
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
before
the
dressing
-
glass
was
a
middle
-
aged
lady
,
in
yellow
curl
-
papers
,
busily
engaged
in
brushing
what
ladies
call
their
"
back
-
hair
.
"
<EOS>
However
the
unconscious
middle
-
aged
lady
came
into
that
room
,
it
was
quite
clear
that
she
contemplated
remaining
there
for
the
night
;
for
she
had
brought
a
rushlight
and
shade
with
her
,
which
,
with
praiseworthy
precaution
against
fire
,
she
had
stationed
in
a
basin
on
the
floor
,
where
it
was
glimmering
away
,
like
a
gigantic
lighthouse
in
a
particularly
small
piece
of
water
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
what
a
dreadful
thing
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
lady
;
and
in
went
Mr
Pickwick
's
head
with
automaton
-
like
rapidity
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
met
with
anything
so
awful
as
this
,
"
thought
poor
Mr
Pickwick
,
the
cold
perspiration
starting
in
drops
upon
his
nightcap
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
fearful
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
quite
impossible
to
resist
the
urgent
desire
to
see
what
was
going
forward
.
 
<EOS>
So
out
went
Mr
Pickwick
's
head
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
prospect
was
worse
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
The
middle
-
aged
lady
had
finished
arranging
her
hair
;
had
carefully
enveloped
it
in
a
muslin
nightcap
with
a
small
plaited
border
;
and
was
gazing
pensively
on
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
matter
is
growing
alarming
,
"
reasoned
Mr
Pickwick
with
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
allow
things
to
go
on
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
self
-
possession
of
that
lady
,
it
is
clear
to
me
that
I
must
have
come
into
the
wrong
room
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
call
out
she
'll
alarm
the
house
;
but
if
I
remain
here
the
consequences
will
be
still
more
frightful
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
it
is
quite
unnecessary
to
say
,
was
one
of
the
most
modest
and
delicate
-
minded
of
mortals
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
idea
of
exhibiting
his
nightcap
to
a
lady
overpowered
him
,
but
he
had
tied
those
confounded
strings
in
a
knot
,
and
,
do
what
he
would
,
he
could
n't
get
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
The
disclosure
must
be
made
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
other
way
of
doing
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
shrunk
behind
the
curtains
,
and
called
out
very
loudly
---
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
-
hum
!
"
   
<EOS>
That
the
lady
started
at
this
unexpected
sound
was
evident
,
by
her
falling
up
against
the
rushlight
shade
;
that
she
persuaded
herself
it
must
have
been
the
effect
of
imagination
was
equally
clear
,
for
when
Mr
Pickwick
,
under
the
impression
that
she
had
fainted
away
stone
-
dead
with
fright
,
ventured
to
peep
out
again
,
she
was
gazing
pensively
on
the
fire
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Most
extraordinary
female
this
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
popping
in
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
-
hum
!
"
   
<EOS>
These
last
sounds
,
so
like
those
in
which
,
as
legends
inform
us
,
the
ferocious
giant
Blunderbore
was
in
the
habit
of
expressing
his
opinion
that
it
was
time
to
lay
the
cloth
,
were
too
distinctly
audible
to
be
again
mistaken
for
the
workings
of
fancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gracious
Heaven
!
"
said
the
middle
-
aged
lady
,
"
what
's
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
---
 
<EOS>
it
's
---
only
a
gentleman
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
from
behind
the
curtains
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
lady
,
with
a
terrific
scream
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
over
!
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
strange
man
!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Another
instant
and
the
house
would
be
alarmed
.
 
<EOS>
Her
garments
rustled
as
she
rushed
towards
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
thrusting
out
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
in
the
extremity
of
his
desperation
,
"
ma'am
!
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
although
Mr
Pickwick
was
not
actuated
by
any
definite
object
in
putting
out
his
head
,
it
was
instantaneously
productive
of
a
good
effect
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
,
as
we
have
already
stated
,
was
near
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
She
must
pass
it
,
to
reach
the
staircase
,
and
she
would
most
undoubtedly
have
done
so
by
this
time
,
had
not
the
sudden
apparition
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
nightcap
driven
her
back
into
the
remotest
corner
of
the
apartment
,
where
she
stood
staring
wildly
at
Mr
Pickwick
,
while
Mr
Pickwick
in
his
turn
stared
wildly
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wretch
,
"
said
the
lady
,
covering
her
eyes
with
her
hands
,
"
what
do
you
want
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
ma'am
;
nothing
whatever
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
earnestly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
!
"
said
the
lady
,
looking
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
ma'am
,
upon
my
honour
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
nodding
his
head
so
energetically
,
that
the
tassel
of
his
nightcap
danced
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
almost
ready
to
sink
,
ma'am
,
beneath
the
confusion
of
addressing
a
lady
in
my
nightcap
<EOS>
(
here

lady

)
,
but
I
ca
n't
get
it
off
,
ma'am
<EOS>
(
here
Mr
Pickwick
gave

,
in

)
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
evident

me
,
ma'am
,
now
,
that

have
mistaken

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not

here
five
minutes
,
ma'am
,
when
you
suddenly
entered

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
this

story
be
really

,
Sir
,
"
said
the
lady
,

,
"
you
will

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
ma'am
,
with

,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Instantly
,
sir
,
"
said
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
ma'am
,
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
,
very

.
"
<EOS>
Certainly
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
am
very
sorry
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
making
his
appearance
at
the
bottom
of
the
bed
,
"
to
have
been
the
innocent
occasion
of
this
alarm
and
emotion
;
deeply
sorry
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
pointed
to
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
One
excellent
quality
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
character
was
beautifully
displayed
at
this
moment
,
under
the
most
trying
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
had
hastily
Put
on
his
hat
over
his
nightcap
,
after
the
manner
of
the
old
patrol
;
although
he
carried
his
shoes
and
gaiters
in
his
hand
,
and
his
coat
and
waistcoat
over
his
arm
;
nothing
could
subdue
his
native
politeness
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
exceedingly
sorry
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
bowing
very
low
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
,
Sir
,
you
will
at
once
leave
the
room
,
"
said
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Immediately
,
ma'am
;
this
instant
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
opening
the
door
,
and
dropping
both
his
shoes
with
a

in
so
doing
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
trust
,
ma'am
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pickwick
,
gathering
up

,
and
turning
round
to
bow
again
---
<EOS>
"
I
trust
,
ma'am
,
that
my
unblemished
character
,
and
the
devoted
respect
I
entertain
for
your
sex
,
will
plead
as
some
slight
excuse
for
this
---
"
<EOS>
But
before
Mr
Pickwick
could
conclude
the
sentence
,
the
lady
had
thrust
him
into
the
passage
,
and
locked
and
bolted
the
door
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
Whatever
grounds
of
self
-
congratulation
Mr
Pickwick
might
have
for
having
escaped
so
quietly
from
his
late
awkward
situation
,
his
present
position
was
by
no
means
enviable
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
alone
,
in
an
open
passage
,
in
a
strange
house
in
the
middle
of
the
night
,
half
dressed
;
it
was
not
to
be
supposed
that
he
could
find
his
way
in
perfect
darkness
to
a
room
which
he
had
been
wholly
unable
to
discover
with
a
light
,
and
if
he
made
the
slightest
noise
in
his
fruitless
attempts
to
do
so
,
he
stood
every
chance
of
being
shot
at
,
and
perhaps
killed
,
by
some
wakeful
traveller
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
resource
but
<EOS>
to
remain
where
he
was
until
daylight
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
So
after
groping
his
way
a
few
paces
down
the
passage
,
and
,
to
his
infinite
alarm
,
stumbling
over
several
pairs
of
boots
in
so
doing
,
Mr
Pickwick
crouched
into
a
little
recess
in
the
wall
,
to
wait
for
morning
,
as
philosophically
as
he
might
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
not
destined
,
however
,
to
undergo
this
additional
trial
of
patience
;
for
he
had
not
been
long
ensconced
in
his
present
concealment
when
,
to
his
unspeakable
horror
,
a
man
,
bearing
a
light
,
appeared
at
the
end
of
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
His
horror
was
suddenly
converted
into
joy
,
however
,
when
he
recognised
the
form
of
his
faithful
attendant
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
who
after
sitting
up
thus
late
,
in
conversation
with
the
boots
,
who
was
sitting
up
for
the
mail
,
was
now
about
to
retire
to
rest
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
suddenly
appearing
before
him
,
"
where
's
my
bedroom
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
stared
at
his
master
with
the
most
emphatic
surprise
;
and
it
was
not
until
the
question
had
been
repeated
three
several
times
,
that
he
turned
round
,
and
led
the
way
to
the
long
-
sought
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
got
into
bed
,
"
I
have
made
one
of
the
most
extraordinary
mistakes
to
-
night
,
that
ever
were
heard
of
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Wery
likely
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
drily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
of
this
I
am
determined
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
that
if
I
were
to
stop
in
this
house
for
six
months
,
I
would
never
trust
myself
about
it
,
alone
,
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
wery
prudentest
resolution
as
you
could
come
to
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
rayther

somebody
to
look
arter
you
,
Sir
,
when
your
judgment
goes
out
a
wisitin
'
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean

,
Sam
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
He
raised
himself
in
bed
,
and
extended
his
hand
,
as
if
he
were
about
to
say
something
more
;
but
suddenly
checking
himself
,
turned
round
,
and
bade
his
valet
"
Good
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
when
he
got
outside
the
door
---
shook
his
head
---
walked
on
---
stopped
---
<EOS>
snuffed
the
candle
---
shook
his
head
again
---
and
finally
proceeded
slowly
to
his
chamber
,
apparently
buried
in
the
profoundest
meditation
.
    
Chapter
23
.
<EOS>
In
which
Mr
Samuel
Weller
begins
to
devote
his
energies
to
the
return
match
between
himself
and
Mr
Trotter
 
<EOS>
In
a
small
room
in
the
vicinity
of
the
stableyard
,
betimes
in
the
morning
,
which
was
ushered
in
by
Mr
Pickwick
's
adventure
with
the
middle
---
aged
lady
in
the
yellow
curl
-
papers
,
sat
Mr
Weller
,
senior
,
preparing
himself
for
his
journey
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
in
an
excellent
attitude
for
having
his
portrait
taken
;
and
here
it
is
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
very
possible
that
at
some
earlier
period
of
his
career
,
Mr
Weller
's
profile
might
have
presented
a
bold
and
determined
outline
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
,
however
,
had
expanded
under
the
influence
of
good
living
,
and
a
disposition
remarkable
for
resignation
;
and
its
bold
,
fleshy
curves
had
so
far
extended
beyond
the
limits
originally
assigned
them
,
that
unless
you
took
a
full
view
of
his
countenance
in
front
,
it
was
difficult
to
distinguish
more
than
the
extreme
tip
of
a
very
rubicund
nose
.
 
<EOS>
His
chin
,
from
the
same
cause
,
had
acquired
the
grave
and
imposing
form
which
is
generally
described
by
prefixing
the
word
"
double
"
to
that
expressive
feature
;
and
his
complexion
exhibited
that
peculiarly
mottled
combination
of
colours
which
is
only
to
be
seen
in
gentlemen
of
his
profession
,
and
in
underdone
roast
beef
.
 
<EOS>
Round
his
neck
<EOS>
he
wore
a
crimson
travelling
-
shawl
,
which
merged
into
his
chin
by
such
imperceptible
gradations
,
that
it
was
difficult
to
distinguish
the
folds
of
the
one
,
from
the
folds
of
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Over
this
,
he
mounted
a
long
waistcoat
of
a
broad
pink
-
striped
pattern
,
and
over
that
again
,
a
wide
-
skirted
green
coat
,
ornamented
with
large
brass
buttons
,
whereof
the
two
which
garnished
the
waist
,
were
so
far
apart
,
that
no
man
had
ever
beheld
them
both
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
His
hair
,
which
was
short
,
sleek
,
and
black
,
was
just
visible
beneath
the
capacious
brim
of
a
low
-
crowned
brown
hat
.
 
<EOS>
His
legs
were
encased
in
knee
-
cord
breeches
,
and
painted
top
-
boots
;
and
a
copper
watch
-
chain
,
terminating
in
one
seal
,
and
a
key
of
the
same
material
,
dangled
loosely
from
his
capacious
waistband
.
   
<EOS>
We
have
said
that
Mr
Weller
was
engaged
in
preparing
for
his
journey
to
London
---
he
was
taking
sustenance
,
in
fact
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
table
before
him
,
stood
a
pot
of
ale
,
a
cold
round
of
beef
,
and
a
very
respectable
-
looking
loaf
,
to
each
of
which
he
distributed
his
favours
in
turn
,
with
the
most
rigid
impartiality
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
just
cut
a
mighty
slice
from
the
latter
,
when
the
footsteps
of
somebody
entering
the
room
,
caused
him
to
raise
his
head
;
and
he
beheld
his
son
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mornin
'
,
Sammy
!
"
said
the
father
.
   
<EOS>
The
son
walked
up
to
the
pot
of
ale
,
and
nodding
significantly
to
his
parent
,
took
a
long
draught
by

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
good
power
o
'
suction
,
Sammy
,
"

Mr
Weller
the

,

pot
,
when

first
-
born
had
set

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'd
ha

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

applying

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
wery

,

,
"

Weller
,

by

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
o

,

.

.

"

<EOS>

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
In

Mr
Weller
imbibed
at
a

,
at
least
two
-
thirds
of
a

-

,
and
handed
