over
to
his
son
,
to
dispose
of
the
remainder
,
which
he
instantaneously
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
Sammy
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
consulting
a
large
double
-
faced
silver
watch
that
hung
at
the
end
of
the
copper
chain
.
<EOS>
"
Now
it
's
time
I
was
up
at
the
office
to
get
my
vay
-
bill
and
see
the
coach
loaded
;
for
coaches
,
Sammy
,
is
like
guns
---
they
requires
to
be
loaded
with
wery
great
care
,
afore
they
go
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
parental
and
professional
joke
,
Mr
Weller
,
junior
,
smiled
a
filial
smile
.
 
<EOS>
His
revered
parent
continued
in
a
solemn
tone
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
-
goin
'
to
leave
you
,
Samivel
,
my
boy
,
and
there
's
no
telling
<EOS>
ven
<EOS>
I
shall
see
you
again
.
 
<EOS>
Your
mother
-
in
-
law
may
ha
'
been
too
much
for
me
,
or
a
thousand
things
may
have
happened
by
the
time
you
next
<EOS>
hears
any
news
<EOS>
o
'
the
celebrated
Mr
Veller
o
'
the
Bell
Savage
.
 
<EOS>
The
family
name
depends
wery
much
upon
you
,
Samivel
,
and
I
hope
you
'll
do
wot
's
right
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
all
little
pints
o
'
breedin
'
,
I
know
I
may
trust
you
as
vell
as
if
it
was
my
own
self
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
've
only
this
here
one
little
bit
of
adwice
to
give
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
you
gets
to
up'ards
o
'
fifty
,
and
feels
disposed
to
go
a
-
marryin
'
anybody
---
no
matter
who
---
jist
you
shut
yourself
up
in
your
own
room
,
if
you
've
got
one
,
and
pison
yourself
off
hand
.
<EOS>
Hangin
's
wulgar
,
so
do
n't
you
have
nothin'
to
say
to
that
.
 
<EOS>
Pison
yourself
,
Samivel
,
my
boy
,
pison
yourself
,
and
you
'll
be
glad
on
it
arterwards
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
affecting
words
,
Mr
Weller
looked
steadfastly
on
his
son
,
and
turning
slowly
upon
his
heel
,
disappeared
from
his
sight
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
contemplative
mood
which
these
words
had
awakened
,
Mr
Samuel
Weller
walked
forth
from
the
Great
White
Horse
when
his
father
had
left
him
;
and
bending
his
steps
towards
St
Clement
's
Church
,
endeavoured
to
dissipate
his
melancholy
,
by
strolling
among
its
ancient
precincts
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
loitered
about
,
for
some
time
,
when
he
found
himself
in
a
retired
spot
---
a
kind
of
courtyard
of
venerable
appearance
---
which
he
discovered
had
no
other
outlet
than
the
turning
by
which
he
had
entered
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
about
retracing
his
steps
,
when
he
was
suddenly
transfixed
to
the
spot
by
a
sudden
appearance
;
and
the
mode
and
manner
of
this
appearance
,
we
now
proceed
to
relate
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Samuel
Weller
had
been
staring
up
at
the
old
brick
houses
now
and
<EOS>
then
,
in
his
deep
abstraction
,
bestowing
a
wink
upon
some
healthy
-
looking
servant
girl
as
she
drew
up
a
blind
,
or
threw
open
a
bedroom
window
,
when
the
green
gate
of
a
garden
at
the
bottom
of
the
yard
opened
,
and
a
man
having
emerged
therefrom
,
closed
the
green
gate
very
carefully
after
him
,
and
walked
briskly
towards
the
very
spot
where
Mr
Weller
was
standing
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
taking
this
,
as
an
isolated
fact
,
unaccompanied
by
any
attendant
circumstances
,
there
was
nothing
very
extraordinary
in
it
;
because
in
many
parts
of
the
world
men
do
come
out
of
gardens
,
close
green
gates
after
them
,
and
even
walk
briskly
away
,
without
attracting
any
particular
share
of
public
observation
.
<EOS>
It
is
clear
,
therefore
,
that
there
must
have
been
something
in
the
man
,
or
in
his
manner
,
or
both
,
to
attract
Mr
Weller
's
particular
notice
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
there
was
,
or
not
,
we
must
leave
the
reader
to
determine
,
when
we
have
faithfully
recorded
the
behaviour
of
the
individual
in
question
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
man
had
shut
the
green
gate
after
him
,
he
walked
,
as
we
have
said
twice
already
,
with
a
brisk
pace
up
the
courtyard
;
but
he
no
sooner
caught
sight
of
Mr
Weller
than
he
faltered
,
and
stopped
,
as
if
uncertain
,
for
the
moment
,
what
course
to
adopt
.
<EOS>
As
the
green
gate
was
closed
behind
him
,
and
there
was
no
other
outlet
but
the
one
in
front
,
however
,
he
was
not
long
in
perceiving
that
he
must
pass
Mr
Samuel
Weller
to
get
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
resumed
his
brisk
pace
,
and
advanced
,
staring
straight
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
most
extraordinary
thing
about
the
man
was
,
that
he
was
contorting
his
face
into
the
most
fearful
and
astonishing
grimaces
that
ever
were
beheld
.
 
<EOS>
Nature
's
handiwork
never
was
disguised
with
such
extraordinary
artificial
carving
,
as
the
man
had
overlaid
his
countenance
with
in
one
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Weller
to
himself
,
as
the
man
approached
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
wery
odd
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
ha
'
swore
it
was
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Up
came
the
man
,
and
his
face
became
more
frightfully
distorted
than
ever
,
as
he
drew
nearer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
take
my
oath
to
that
'
ere
black
hair
and
mulberry
suit
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
;
"
only
I
never
see
such
a
face
as
that
afore
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Weller
said
this
,
the
man
's
features
assumed
an
unearthly
twinge
,
perfectly
hideous
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
obliged
to
pass
very
near
Sam
,
however
,
and
the
scrutinising
glance
of
that
gentleman
enabled
him
to
detect
,
under
all
these
appalling
twists
of
feature
,
something
too
like
the
small
eyes
of
Mr
Job
Trotter
to
be
easily
mistaken
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,
you
Sir
!
"
shouted
Sam
fiercely
.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Sam
,
still
more
gruffly
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
with
the
horrible
face
looked
,
with
the
greatest
surprise
,
up
the
court
,
and
down
the
court
,
and
in
at
the
windows
of
the
houses
---
everywhere
but
at
Sam
Weller
---
and
took
another
step
forward
,
when
he
was
brought
to
again
by
another
shout
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,
you
sir
!
"
said
Sam
,
for
the
third
time
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
pretending
to
mistake
where
the
voice
came
from
now
,
so
the
stranger
,
having
no
other
resource
,
at
last
looked
Sam
Weller
full
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
do
,
Job
Trotter
,
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
None
o
'
<EOS>
that
'
ere
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
You
ai
n't
so
wery
"
<EOS>
andsome
that
you
can
afford
to
throw
avay
<EOS>
many
o
'
your
good
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Bring
them
'
ere
<EOS>
eyes
<EOS>
o
'
yourn
back
into

,
or
<EOS>
I
'll
knock
'em
out

.
 
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Weller
appeared
fully
disposed
to
act
up
to
the
spirit
of
this
address
,
Mr
Trotter
gradually
allowed
his
face
to
resume
its
natural
expression
;
and
then
giving
a
start
of
joy
,
exclaimed
,
"
What
do
I
see
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Walker
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
replied
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
wery
glad
to
see
me
,
ai
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Glad
!
"
exclaimed
Job
Trotter
;
"
oh
,
Mr
Walker
,
if
you
had
but
known
how
I
have
looked
forward
to
this
meeting
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
too
much
,
Mr
Walker
;
I
can
not
bear
it
,
indeed
I
can
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
these
words
,
Mr
Trotter
burst
into
a
regular
inundation
of
tears
,
and
,
flinging
his
arms
around
those
of
Mr
Weller
,
embraced
him
closely
,
in
an
ecstasy
of
joy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
off
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sam
,
indignant
at
this
process
,
and
vainly
endeavouring
to
extricate
himself
from
the
grasp
of
his
enthusiastic
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
off
,
I
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
crying
over
me
for
,
you
portable
engine
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
am
so
glad
to
see
you
,
"
replied
Job
Trotter
,
gradually
releasing
Mr
Weller
,
as
the
first
symptoms
of
his
pugnacity
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr
Walker
,
this
is
too
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Too
much
!
"
echoed
Sam
,
"
I
think
it
is
too
much
---
rayther
!
<EOS>
Now
,
what
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Trotter
made
no
reply
;
for
the
little
pink
pocket
-
handkerchief
was
in
full
force
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
,
afore
<EOS>
I
knock
your
head
off
?
"
repeated
Mr
Weller
,
in
a
threatening
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
!
"
said
Mr
Trotter
,
with
a
look
of
virtuous
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
Mr
Walker
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
call
me
Valker
;
my
name
's
Veller
;
you
know
that
vell
enough
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
Mr
Walker
---
<EOS>
Weller
,
I
mean
---
a
great
many
things
,
if
you
will
come
away
somewhere
,
where
we
can
talk
comfortably
.
<EOS>
If
you
knew
how
I
have
looked
for
you
,
Mr
Weller
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Wery
hard
,
indeed
,
I
s'pose
?
<EOS>
"
said
Sam
drily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
very
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Trotter
,
without
moving
a
muscle
of
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
shake
hands
,
Mr
Weller
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
eyed
his
companion
for
a
few
seconds
,
and
then
,
as
if
actuated
by
a
sudden
impulse
,
complied
with
his
request
.
<EOS>
"
How
,
"
said
Job
Trotter
,
as
they
walked
away
,
<EOS>
"
how
is
your
dear
,
good
master
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
he
is
a
worthy
gentleman
,
Mr
Weller
!
<EOS>
I
hope
he
did
n't
catch
cold
,
that
dreadful
night
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
momentary
look
of
deep
slyness
in
Job
Trotter
's
eye
,
as
he
said
this
,
which
ran
a
thrill
through
Mr
Weller
's
clenched
fist
,
as
he
burned
with
a
desire
to
make
a
demonstration
on
his
ribs
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
constrained
himself
,
however
,
and
replied
that
his
master
was
extremely
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
am
so
glad
,
"
replied
Mr
Trotter
;
"
is
he
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
yourn
?
"
asked
Sam
,
by
way
of
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
,
he
is
here
,
and
I
grieve
to
say
,
Mr
Weller
,
he
is
going
on
worse
than
ever
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
ah
!
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
shocking
---
terrible
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
a
boarding
-
school
?
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
at
a
boarding
-

,
"
replied
Job
Trotter
,
with
the
same
sly
look
which
Sam
had
noticed
before
;
"
not
at
a
boarding
-
school
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
the
house
with
the
green
gate
?
"
said
Sam
,
eyeing

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
---
<EOS>
oh
,
not
there
,
"
replied
Job
,
with
a
quickness
very
unusual
to
him
,
"
not
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
was
you
a
-
doin
'
there
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Sam
,
with
a
sharp

.
<EOS>
"
Got
inside
the
gate
by
accident
,
perhaps
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mr
Weller
,
"
replied
Job
,
"
I
do
n't
mind
telling
you
my
little
secrets
,
because
,
you
know
,
we
took
such
a
fancy
for
each
other
when

.
 
<EOS>
You
recollect
how
pleasant

that
morning
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said
Sam
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
remember
.
 
<EOS>
Well
?
"
   
"
Well
,
"
replied
Job
,
speaking
with
great

,
and
in
the
low

of
a
man
who
communicates
an
important

;
"
in
that
house
with
the
green

,
Mr
Weller
,
they
keep

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I

think
,
from

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
continued

,
"

one

is
a

,
who
has
saved

,
Mr

,

,

establish

,
to

in

,
you

.
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

,
I
met

;
a

in

,
Mr

,

four

of

,
which
I

about

me
,
in

,

you

perhaps

---

,

,

,

,

venture

say
,
Mr
Weller
,
that
I
am

the

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,

,
"

Sam
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
great

,
Mr
Weller
,
"

,
<EOS>
his

"
will

,

I

;

<EOS>
"

ha

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

ha
'

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
The

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
24
.
<EOS>
Wherein

,

the

,

Law
 
<EOS>
When

.

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
-

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

,

,

;

)

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had

;

of

clock
following

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

.

"

,

"

.
   
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

's

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

gentlemen
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Hurrying
on
in
this
way
,
Mr
Peter
Magnus
drew
Mr
Pickwick
from
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
paused
at
the
next
door
in
the
passage
,
and
tapped
gently
thereat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
said
a
female
voice
.
 
<EOS>
And
in
they
went
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Witherfield
,
"
said
Mr
Magnus
,
"
allow
me
to
introduce
my
very
particular
friend
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
beg
to
make
you
known
to
Miss
Witherfield
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
was
at
the
upper
end
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
bowed
,
he
took
his
spectacles
from
his
waistcoat
pocket
,
and
put
them
on
;
a
process
which
he
had
no
sooner
gone
through
,
than
,
uttering
an
exclamation
of
surprise
,
Mr
Pickwick
retreated
several
paces
,
and
the
lady
,
with
a
half
-
suppressed
scream
,
hid
her
face
in
her
hands
,
and
dropped
into
a
chair
;
whereupon
Mr
Peter
Magnus
was
stricken
motionless
on
the
spot
,
and
gazed
from
one
to
the
other
,
with
a
countenance
expressive
of
the
extremities
of
horror
and
surprise
.
<EOS>
This
certainly
was
,
to
all
appearance
,
very
unaccountable
behaviour
;
but
the
fact
is
,
that
Mr
Pickwick
no
sooner
put
on
his
spectacles
,
than
he
at
once
recognised
in
the
future
<EOS>
Mrs
Magnus
the
lady
into
whose
room
he
had
so
unwarrantably
intruded
on
the
previous
night
;
and
the
spectacles
had
no
sooner
crossed
Mr
Pickwick
's
nose
,
than
the
lady
at
once
identified
the
countenance
which
she
had
seen
surrounded
by
all
the
horrors
of
a
nightcap
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
lady
screamed
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
started
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Magnus
,
lost
in
astonishment
,
"
what
is
the
meaning
of
this
,
Sir
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
meaning
of
it
,
Sir
?
"
added
Mr
Magnus
,
in
a
threatening
,
and
a
louder
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
somewhat
indignant
at
the
very
sudden
manner
in
which
Mr
Peter
Magnus
had
conjugated
himself
into
the
imperative
mood
,
"
I
decline
answering
that
question
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
decline
it
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Magnus
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
I
object
to
say
anything
which
may
compromise
that
lady
,
or
awaken
unpleasant
recollections
in
her
breast
,
without
her
consent
and
permission
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Witherfield
,
"
said
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
"
do
you
know
this
person
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Know
him
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
the
middle
-
aged
lady
,
hesitating
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
know
him
,
ma'am
;
I
said
know
him
,
"
replied
Mr
Magnus
,
with
ferocity
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
him
,
"
replied
the
middle
-
aged
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
inquired
Mr
Magnus
,
"
<EOS>
where
?
"
   
"
That
,
"
said
the
middle
-
aged
lady
,
rising
from
her
seat
,
and
averting
her
head
---
"
that
I
would
not
reveal
for
worlds
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
understand
you
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
and
respect
your
delicacy
;
it
shall
never
be
revealed
by
ME
depend
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Magnus
,
"
<EOS>
considering
the
situation
in
which
I
am
placed
with
regard
to
yourself
,
you
carry
this
matter
off
with
tolerable
coolness
---
tolerable
coolness
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cruel
Mr
Magnus
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
middle
-
aged
lady
;
here
she
wept
very
copiously
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Address
your
observations
to
me
,
sir
,
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
I
alone
am
to
blame
,
if
anybody
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
alone
are
to
blame
,
are
you
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Magnus
;
"
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
see
through
this
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
repent
of
your
determination
now
,
do
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
determination
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
determination
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
do
n't
stare
at
me
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Magnus
;
<EOS>
"
I
recollect
your
words
last
night
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
came
down
here
,
sir
,
to
expose
the
treachery
and
falsehood
of
an
individual
on
whose
truth
and
honour
you
had
placed
implicit
reliance
---
eh
?
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Peter
Magnus
indulged
in
a
prolonged
sneer
;
and
taking
off
his
green
spectacles
---
which
he
probably
found
superfluous
in
his
fit
of
jealousy
---
rolled
his
little
eyes
about
,
in
a
manner
frightful
to
behold
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
said
Mr
Magnus
;
and
then
he
repeated
the
sneer
with
increased
effect
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
shall
answer
it
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Answer
what
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Magnus
,
striding
up
and
down
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
must
be
something
very
comprehensive
in
this
phrase
of
"
Never
mind
,
"
for
we
do
not
recollect
to
have
ever
witnessed
a
quarrel
in
the
street
,
at
a
theatre
,
public
room
,
or
elsewhere
,
in
which
it
has
not
been
the
standard
reply
to
all
belligerent
inquiries
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
call
yourself
a
gentleman
,
sir
?
"
---
"
Never
mind
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
I
offer
to
say
anything
to
the
young
woman
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
---
"
Never
mind
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
want
your
head
knocked
up
against
that
wall
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
---
"
Never
mind
,
sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
It
is
observable
,
too
,
that
there
would
appear
to
be
some
hidden
taunt
in
this
universal
"
Never
mind
,
"
which
rouses
more
indignation
in
the
bosom
of
the
individual
addressed
,
than
the
most
lavish
abuse
could
possibly
awaken
.
   
<EOS>
We
do
not
mean
to
assert
that
the
application
of
this
brevity
to
himself
,
struck
exactly
that
indignation
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
soul
,
which
it
would
infallibly
have
roused
in
a
vulgar
breast
.
<EOS>
We
merely
record
the
fact
that
Mr
Pickwick
opened
the
room
door
,
and
abruptly
called
out
,
"
Tupman
,
come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
immediately
presented
himself
,
with
a
look
of
very
considerable
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tupman
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
a
secret
of
some
delicacy
,
in
which
that
lady
is
concerned
,
is
the
cause
of
a
difference
which
has
just
arisen
between
this
gentleman
and
myself
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
assure
him
,
in
your
presence
,
that
it
has
no
relation
to
himself
,
and
is
not
in
any
way
connected
with
his
affairs
,
I
need
hardly
beg
you
to
take
notice
that
if
he
continue
to
dispute
it
,
he
expresses
a
doubt
of
my
veracity
,
which
I
shall
consider
extremely
insulting
.
"
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
said
this
,
he
looked
encyclopedias
at
Mr
Peter
Magnus
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
upright
and
honourable
bearing
,
coupled
with
that
force
and
energy
of
speech
which
so
eminently
distinguished
him
,
would
have
carried
conviction
to
any
reasonable
mind
;
but
,
unfortunately
,
at
that
particular
moment
,
the
mind
of
Mr
Peter
Magnus
was
in
anything
but
reasonable
order
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
,
instead
of
receiving
Mr
Pickwick
's
explanation
as
he
ought
to
have
done
,
he
forthwith
proceeded
to
work
himself
into
a
red
-
hot
,
scorching
,
consuming
passion
,
and
to
talk
about
what
was
due
to
his
own
feelings
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
;
adding
force
to
his
declamation
by
striding
to
and
fro
,
and
pulling
his
hair
---
amusements
which
he
would
vary
occasionally
,
by
shaking
his
fist
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
philanthropic
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
his
turn
,
conscious
of
his
own
innocence
and
rectitude
,
and
irritated
by
having
unfortunately
involved
the
middle
-
aged
lady
in
such
an
unpleasant
affair
,
was
not
so
quietly
disposed
as
was
his
wo
nt
.
 
<EOS>
The
consequence
was
,
that
words
ran
high
,
and
voices
higher
;
and
at
length
Mr
Magnus
told
Mr
Pickwick
he
should
hear
from
him
;
to
which
Mr
Pickwick
replied
,
with
laudable
politeness
,
that
the
sooner
he
heard
from
him
the
better
;
whereupon
the
middle
-
aged
lady
rushed
in
terror
from
the
room
,
out
of
which
Mr
Tupman
dragged
Mr
Pickwick
,
leaving
Mr
Peter
Magnus
to
himself
and
meditation
.
   
<EOS>
If
the
middle
-
aged
lady
had
mingled
much
with
the
busy
world
,
or
had
profited
at
all
by
the
manners
and
customs
of
those
who
make
the
laws
and
set
the
fashions
,
she
would
have
known
that
this
sort
of
ferocity
is
the
most
harmless
thing
in
nature
;
but
as
she
had
lived
for
the
most
part
in
the
country
,
and
never
read
the
parliamentary
debates
,
she
was
little
versed
in
these
particular
refinements
of
civilised
life
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
when
she
had
gained
her
bedchamber
,
bolted
herself
in
,
and
began
to
meditate
on
the
scene
she
had
just
witnessed
,
the
most
terrific
pictures
of
slaughter
and
destruction
presented
themselves
to
her
imagination
;
among
which
,
a
full
-
length
portrait
of
Mr
Peter
Magnus
borne
home
by
four
men
,
with
the
embellishment
of
a
whole
barrelful
of
bullets
in
his
left
side
,
was
among
the
very
least
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
the
middle
-
aged
lady
meditated
,
the
more
terrified
she
became
;
and
at
length
she
determined
to
repair
to
the
house
of
the
principal
magistrate
of
the
town
,
and
request
him
to
secure
the
persons
of
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Tupman
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
decision
the
middle
-
aged
lady
was
impelled
by
a
variety
of
considerations
,
the
chief
of
which
was
the
incontestable
proof
it
would
afford
of
her
devotion
to
Mr
Peter
Magnus
,
and
her
anxiety
for
his
safety
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
too
well
acquainted
with
his
jealous
temperament
to
venture
the
slightest
allusion
to
the
real
cause
of
her
agitation
on
beholding
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
she
trusted
to
her
own
influence
and
power
of
persuasion
with
the
little
man
,
to
quell
his
boisterous
jealousy
,
supposing
that
Mr
Pickwick
were
removed
,
and
no
fresh
quarrel
could
arise
.
 
<EOS>
Filled
with
these
reflections
,
the
middle
-
aged
lady
arrayed
herself
in
her
bonnet
and
shawl
,
and
repaired
to
the
mayor
's
dwelling
straightway
.
   
<EOS>
Now
George
Nupkins
,
Esquire
,
the
principal
magistrate
aforesaid
,
was
as
grand
a
personage
as
the
fastest
walker
would
find
out
,
between
sunrise
and
sunset
,
on
the
twenty
-
first
of
June
,
which
being
,
according
to
the
almanacs
,
the
longest
day
in
the
whole
year
,
would
naturally
afford
him
the
longest
period
for
his
search
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
particular
morning
,
Mr
Nupkins
was
in
a
state
of
the
utmost
excitement
and
irritation
,
for
there
had
been
a
rebellion
in
the
town
;
all
the
day
-
scholars
at
the
largest
day
-
school
had
conspired
to
break
the
windows
of
an
obnoxious
apple
-
seller
,
and
had
hooted
the
beadle
and
pelted
the
constabulary
---
an
elderly
gentleman
in
top
-
boots
,
who
had
been
called
out
to
repress
the
tumult
,
and
who
had
been
a
peace
-
officer
,
man
and
boy
,
for
half
a
century
at
least
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Nupkins
was
sitting
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
frowning
with
majesty
,
and
boiling
with
rage
,
when
a
lady
was
announced
on
pressing
,
private
,
and
particular
business
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
looked
calmly
terrible
,
and
commanded
that
the
lady
should
be
shown
in
;
which
command
,
like
all
the
mandates
of
emperors
,
and
magistrates
,
and
other
great
potentates
of
the
earth
,
was
forthwith
obeyed
;
and
Miss
Witherfield
,
interestingly
agitated
,
was
ushered
in
accordingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Muzzle
!
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
Muzzle
was
an
undersized
footman
,
with
a
long
body
and
short
legs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Muzzle
!
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Place
a
chair
,
and
leave
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
ma'am
,
will
you
state
your
business
?
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
of
a
very
painful
kind
,
Sir
,
"
said
Miss
Witherfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Compose
your
feelings
,
ma'am
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Nupkins
looked
benignant
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
then
tell
me
what
legal
business
brings
you
here
,
ma'am
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
the
magistrate
triumphed
over
the
man
;
and
he
looked
stern
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
distressing
to
me
,
Sir
,
to
give
this
information
,
"
said
Miss
Witherfield
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
fear
a
duel
is
going
to
be
fought
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
ma'am
?
"
said
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
Ipswich
.
"
<EOS>
"
In
Ipswich
,
ma'am
!
 
<EOS>
A
duel
in
Ipswich
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
magistrate
,
perfectly
aghast
at
the
notion
.
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,
ma'am
;
nothing
of
the
kind
can
be
contemplated
in
this
town
,
I
am
persuaded
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
<EOS>
my
soul
,
ma'am
,
are
you
aware
of
the
activity
of
our
local
magistracy
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
happen
to
have
heard
,
ma'am
,
that
I
rushed
into
a
prize
-
ring
on
the
fourth
of
May
last
,
attended
by
only
sixty
special
constables
;
and
,
at
the
hazard
of
falling
a
sacrifice
to
the
angry
passions
of
an
infuriated
multitude
,
prohibited
a
pugilistic
contest
between
the
Middlesex
Dumpling
and
the
Suffolk
Bantam
?
 
<EOS>
A
duel
in
Ipswich
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
---
I
do
not
think
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
reasoning
with
himself
,
"
that
any
two
men
can
have
had
the
hardihood
to
plan
such
a
breach
of
the
peace
,
in
this
town
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
information
is
,
unfortunately
,
but
too
correct
,
"
said
the
middle
-
aged
lady
;
"
I
was
present
at
the
quarrel
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
most
extraordinary
thing
,
"
said
the
astounded
magistrate
.
<EOS>
"
Muzzle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Send
Mr
Jinks
here
,
directly
!
 
<EOS>
Instantly
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
Muzzle
retired
;
and
a
pale
,
sharp
-
nosed
,
half
-
fed
,
shabbily
-
clad
clerk
,
of
middle
age
,
entered
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jinks
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jinks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Jinks
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
lady
,
Mr
Jinks
,
has
come
here
,
to
give
information
of
an
intended
duel
in
this
town
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinks
,
not
knowing
exactly
what
to
do
,
smiled
a
dependent
's
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
laughing
at
,
Mr
Jinks
?
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinks
looked
serious
instantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jinks
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
"
you
're
a
fool
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinks
looked
humbly
at
the
great
man
,
and
bit
the
top
of
his
pen
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
see
something
very
comical
in
this
information
,
Sir
---
but
I
can
tell
you
this
,
Mr
Jinks
,
that
you
have
very
little
to
laugh
at
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
The
hungry
-
looking
Jinks
sighed
,
as
if
he
were
quite
aware
of
the
fact
of
his
having
very
little
indeed
to
be
merry
about
;
and
,
being
ordered
to
take
the
lady
's
information
,
shambled
to
a
seat
,
and
proceeded
to
write
it
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
man
,
Pickwick
,
is
the
principal
,
I
understand
?
"
said
the
magistrate
,
when
the
statement
was
finished
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
"
said
the
middle
-
aged
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
other
rioter
---
what
's
his
name
,
Mr
Jinks
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tupman
,
Sir
.
"
<EOS>
"
Tupman
is
the
second
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
other
principal
,
you
say
,
has
absconded
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Miss
Witherfield
,
with
a
short
cough
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
These
are
two
cut
-
throats
from
London
,
who
have
come
down
here
to
destroy
his
Majesty
's
population
,
thinking
that
at
this
distance
from
the
capital
,
the
arm
of
the
law
is
weak
and
paralysed
.
 
<EOS>
They
shall
be
made
an
example
of
.
 
<EOS>
Draw
up
the
warrants
,
Mr
Jinks
.
 
<EOS>
Muzzle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Grummer
downstairs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Send
him
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
obsequious
Muzzle
retired
,
and
presently
returned
,
introducing
the
elderly
gentleman
in
the
top
-
boots
,
who
was
chiefly
remarkable
for
a
bottle
-
nose
,
a
hoarse
voice
,
a
snuff
-
coloured
surtout
,
and
a
wandering
eye
.
   
<EOS>
"
Grummer
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
Wash
-
up
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
the
town
quiet
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
your
Wash
-
up
,
"
replied
Grummer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pop'lar
feeling
has
in
a
measure
subsided
,
consekens
o
'
the
boys
having
dispersed
to
cricket
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
vigorous
measures
will
do
in
these
times
,
Grummer
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
in
a
determined

.
 
<EOS>
"
if
the
authority
of
the
king
's
officers
is
set
at
naught
,
we
must
have
the
riot
act
read
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
civil
power
can
not
protect
these
windows
,
Grummer
,
the
military
must
protect
the
civil
power
,
and

windows

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
that
is
a
maxim
of
the
constitution
,
Mr
Jinks
?
"
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
sir
,
"
said
Jinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
signing

.
<EOS>
"
Grummer
,
you
will
bring
these
persons
before
me
,
this

.
<EOS>
You
will
find
them
at
the
Great
White
Horse
.
 
<EOS>
You
recollect
the
case
of
the
Middlesex
Dumpling
and
the
Suffolk
Bantam
,
Grummer
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
intimated
,
by
a
retrospective
shake
of
the
head
,
that
he
should
never
forget
it
---
<EOS>
as
indeed
it
was
not
likely
he
would
,
so
long
as
it
continued
to
be
cited
daily
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
even
more
unconstitutional
,
"
said
the
magistrate
;
"
this
is
even
a
greater
breach
of
the
peace
,
and
a
grosser
infringement
of
his
Majesty
's
prerogative
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
duelling
is
one
of
his
Majesty
's
most
undoubted
prerogatives
,
Mr
Jinks
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Expressly
stipulated
in
Magna
Charta
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Jinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
brightest
jewels
in
the
British
crown
,
wrung
from
his
Majesty
by
the
barons
,
I
believe
,
Mr
Jinks
?
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just
so
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Jinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
drawing
himself
up
proudly
,
"
it
shall
not
be
violated
in
this
portion
of
his
dominions
.
 
<EOS>
Grummer
,
procure
assistance
,
and
execute
these
warrants
with
as
little
delay
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Muzzle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Show
the
lady
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Witherfield
retired
,
deeply
impressed
with
the
magistrate
's
learning
and
research
;
Mr
Nupkins
retired
to
lunch
;
Mr
Jinks
retired
within
himself
---
that
being
the
only
retirement
he
had
,
except
the
sofa
-
bedstead
in
the
small
parlour
which
was
occupied
by
his
landlady
's
family
in
the
daytime
---
and
Mr
Grummer
retired
,
to
wipe
out
,
by
his
mode
of
discharging
his
present
commission
,
the
insult
which
had
been
fastened
upon
himself
,
and
the
other
representative
of
his
Majesty
---
the
beadle
 
---
in
the
course
of
the
morning
.
   
<EOS>
While
these
resolute
and
determined
preparations
for
the
conservation
of
the
king
's
peace
were
pending
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
,
wholly
unconscious
of
the
mighty
events
in
progress
,
had
sat
quietly
down
to
dinner
;
and
very
talkative
and
companionable
they
all
were
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
in
the
very
act
of
relating
his
adventure
of
the
preceding
night
,
to
the
great
amusement
of
his
followers
,
Mr
Tupman
especially
,
when
the
door
opened
,
and
a
somewhat
forbidding
countenance
peeped
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
eyes
in
the
forbidding
countenance
looked
very
earnestly
at
Mr
Pickwick
,
for
several
seconds
,
and
were
to
all
appearance
satisfied
with
their
investigation
;
for
the
body
to
which
the
forbidding
countenance
belonged
,
slowly
brought
itself
into
the
apartment
,
and
presented
the
form
of
an
elderly
individual
in
top
-
boots
---
not
to
keep
the
reader
any
longer
in
suspense
,
in
short
,
the
eyes
were
the
wandering
eyes
of
Mr
Grummer
,
and
the
body
was
the
body
of
the
same
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
's
mode
of
proceeding
was
professional
,
but
peculiar
.
 
<EOS>
His
first
act
was
to
bolt
the
door
on
the
inside
;
his
second
,
to
polish
his
head
and
countenance
very
carefully
with
a
cotton
handkerchief
;
his
third
,
to
place
his
hat
,
with
the
cotton
handkerchief
in
it
,
on
the
nearest
chair
;
and
his
fourth
,
to
produce
from
the
breast
-
pocket
of
his
coat
a
short
truncheon
,
surmounted
by
a
brazen
crown
,
with
which
he
beckoned
to
Mr
Pickwick
with
a
grave
and
ghost
-
like
air
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
was
the
first
to
break
the
astonished
silence
.
<EOS>
He
looked
steadily
at
Mr
Grummer
for
a
brief
space
,
and
then
said
emphatically
,
"
This
is
a
private
room
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
A
private
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
shook
his
head
,
and
replied
,
"
<EOS>
No
room
's
private
to
his
Majesty
when
the
street
door
's
once
passed
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
law
.
<EOS>
Some
people
maintains
that
an
Englishman
's
house
is
his
castle
.
<EOS>
That
's
gammon
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Pickwickians
gazed
on
each
other
with
wondering
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
is
Mr
Tupman
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Grummer
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
an
intuitive
perception
of
Mr
Pickwick
;
he
knew
him
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
name
's
Tupman
,
"
said
that
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
name
's
Law
,
"
said
Mr
Grummer
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Law
,
"
replied
Mr
Grummer
---
"
Law
,
civil
power
,
and
exekative
;
them
's
my
titles
;
here
's
my
authority
.
 
<EOS>
Blank
Tupman
,
blank
Pickwick
---
against
the
peace
of
our
sufferin
'
lord
the
king
---
stattit
in
the
case
made
and
purwided
---
and
all
regular
.
 
<EOS>
I
apprehend
you
Pickwick
!
 
<EOS>
Tupman
---
the
aforesaid
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
this
insolence
?
"
said
Mr
Tupman
,
starting
up
;
"
leave
the
room
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,
"
said
Mr
Grummer
,
retreating
very
expeditiously
to
the
door
,
and
opening
it
an
inch
or
two
,
"
Dubbley
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
a
deep
voice
from
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
for'ard
,
Dubbley
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
word
of
command
,
a
dirty
-
faced
man
,
something
over
six
feet
high
,
and
stout
in
proportion
,
squeezed
himself
through
the
half
-
open
door
(
making
his
face
very
red
in
the
process
)
,
and
entered
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
the
other
specials
outside
,
Dubbley
?
"
inquired
Mr
Grummer
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dubbley
,
who
was
a
man
of
few
words
,
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Order
in
the
diwision
under
your
charge
,
Dubbley
,
"
said
Mr
Grummer
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dubbley
did
as
he
was
desired
;
and
half
a
dozen
men
,
each
with
a
short
truncheon
and
a
brass
crown
,
flocked
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
pocketed
his
staff
,
and
looked
at
Mr
Dubbley
;
Mr
Dubbley
pocketed
his
staff
and
looked
at
the
division
;
the
division
pocketed
their
staves
and
looked
at
Messrs.
Tupman
and
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
followers
rose
as
one
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
meaning
of
this
atrocious
intrusion
upon
my
privacy
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
dares
apprehend
me
?
"
said
Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
here
,
scoundrels
?
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
said
nothing
,
but
he
fixed
his
eyes
on
Grummer
,
and
bestowed
a
look
upon
him
,
which
,
if
he
had
had
any
feeling
,
must
have
pierced
his
brain
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
however
,
it
had
no
visible
effect
on
him
<EOS>
whatever
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
executive
perceived
that
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
were
disposed
to
resist
the
authority
of
the
law
,
they
very
significantly
turned
up
their
coat
sleeves
,
as
if
knocking
them
down
in
the
first
instance
,
and
taking
them
up
afterwards
,
were
a
mere
professional
act
which
had
only
to
be
thought
of
to
be
done
,
as
a
matter
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
This
demonstration
was
not
lost
upon
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
He
conferred
a
few
moments
with
Mr
Tupman
apart
,
and
then
signified
his
readiness
to
proceed
to
the
mayor
's
residence
,
merely
begging
the
parties
then
and
there
assembled
,
to
take
notice
,
that
it
was
his
firm
intention
to
resent
this
monstrous
invasion
of
his
privileges
as
an
Englishman
,
the
instant
he
was
at
liberty
;
<EOS>
whereat
the
parties
then
and
there
assembled
laughed
very
heartily
,
with
the
single
exception
of
Mr
Grummer
,
who
seemed
to
consider
that
any
slight
cast
upon
the
divine
right
of
magistrates
was
a
species
of
blasphemy
not
to
be
tolerated
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
Mr
Pickwick
had
signified
his
readiness
to
bow
to
the
laws
of
his
country
,
and
just
when
the
waiters
,
and
hostlers
,
and
chambermaids
,
and
post
-
boys
,
who
had
anticipated
a
delightful
commotion
from
his
threatened
obstinacy
,
began
to
turn
away
,
disappointed
and
disgusted
,
a
difficulty
arose
which
had
not
been
foreseen
.
 
<EOS>
With
every
sentiment
of
veneration
for
the
constituted
authorities
,
Mr
Pickwick
resolutely
protested
against
making
his
appearance
in
the
public
streets
,
surrounded
and
guarded
by
the
officers
of
justice
,
like
a
common
criminal
.
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
,
in
the
then
disturbed
state
of
public
feeling
(
for
it
was
half
-
holiday
,
and
the
boys
had
not
yet
gone
home
)
,
as
resolutely
protested
against
walking
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
and
taking
Mr
Pickwick
's
parole
that
he
would
go
straight
to
the
magistrate
's
;
and
both
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Tupman
as
strenuously
objected
to
the
expense
of
a
post
-
coach
,
which
was
the
only
respectable
conveyance
that
could
be
obtained
.
 
<EOS>
The
dispute
ran
high
,
and
the
dilemma
lasted
long
;
and
just
as
the
executive
were
on
the
point
of
overcoming
Mr
Pickwick
's
objection
to
walking
to
the
magistrate
's
,
by
the
trite
expedient
of
carrying
him
thither
,
it
was
recollected
that
there
stood
in
the
inn
yard
,
an
old
sedan
-
chair
,
which
,
having
been
originally
built
for
a
gouty
gentleman
with
funded
property
,
would
hold
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Tupman
,
at
least
as
conveniently
as
a
modern
post
-
chaise
.
<EOS>
The
chair
was
hired
,
and
brought
into
the
hall
;
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Tupman
squeezed
themselves
inside
,
and
pulled
down
the
blinds
;
a
couple
of
chairmen
were
speedily
found
;
and
the
procession
started
in
grand
order
.
 
<EOS>
The
specials
surrounded
the
body
of
the
vehicle
;
Mr
Grummer
and
Mr
Dubbley
marched
triumphantly
in
front
;
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
walked
arm
-
in
-
arm
behind
;
and
the
unsoaped
of
Ipswich
brought
up
the
rear
.
   
<EOS>
The
shopkeepers
of
the
town
,
although
they
had
a
very
indistinct
notion
of
the
nature
of
the
offence
,
could
not
but
be
much
edified
and
gratified
by
this
spectacle
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
the
strong
arm
of
the
law
,
coming
down
with
twenty
gold
-
beater
force
,
upon
two
offenders
from
the
metropolis
itself
;
the
mighty
engine
was
directed
by
their
own
magistrate
,
and
worked
by
their
own
officers
;
and
both
the
criminals
,
by
their
united
efforts
,
were
securely
shut
up
,
in
the
narrow
compass
of
one
sedan
-
chair
.
<EOS>
Many
were
the
expressions
of
approval
and
admiration
which
greeted
Mr
Grummer
,
as
he
headed
the
cavalcade
,
staff
in
hand
;
loud
and
long
were
the
shouts
raised
by
the
unsoaped
;
and
amidst
these
united
testimonials
of
public
approbation
,
the
procession
moved
slowly
and
majestically
along
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
,
habited
in
his
morning
jacket
,
with
the
black
calico
sleeves
,
was
returning
in
a
rather
desponding
state
from
an
unsuccessful
survey
of
the
mysterious
house
with
the
green
gate
,
when
,
raising
his
eyes
,
he
beheld
a
crowd
pouring
down
the
street
,
surrounding
an
object
which
had
very
much
the
appearance
of
a
sedan
-
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Willing
to
divert
his
thoughts
from
the
failure
of
his
enterprise
,
he
stepped
aside
to
see
the
crowd
pass
;
and
finding
that
they
were
cheering
away
,
very
much
to
their
own
satisfaction
,
forthwith
began
(
by
way
of
raising
his
spirits
)
to
cheer
too
,
with
all
his
might
and
main
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
passed
,
and
Mr
Dubbley
passed
,
and
the
sedan
passed
,
and
the
bodyguard
of
specials
passed
,
and
Sam
was
still
responding
to
the
enthusiastic
cheers
of
the
mob
,
and
waving
his
hat
about
as
if
he
were
in
the
very
last
extreme
of
the
wildest
joy
(
though
,
of
course
,
he
had
not
the
faintest
idea
of
the
matter
in
hand
)
,
when
he
was
suddenly
stopped
by
the
unexpected
appearance
of
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
row
,
gen'l'm'n
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
have
they
got
in
this
here
watch
-
box
in
mournin
'
?
"
   
<EOS>
Both
gentlemen
replied
together
,
but
their
words
were
lost
in
the
tumult
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Sam
again
.
   
<EOS>
once
more
was
a
joint
reply
returned
;
and
,
though
the
words
were
inaudible
,
Sam
saw
by
the
motion
of
the
two
pairs
of
lips
that
they
had
uttered
the
magic
word
"
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
enough
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
minute
Mr
Weller
had
made
his
way
through
the
crowd
,
stopped
the
chairmen
,
and
confronted
the
portly
Grummer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,
old
gen'l'm'n
!
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
have
you
got
in
this
here
conweyance
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
back
,
"
said
Mr
Grummer
,
whose
dignity
,
like
the
dignity
of
a
great
many
other
men
,
had
been
wondrously
augmented
by
a
little
popularity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Knock
him
down
,
if
he
do
n't
,
"
said
Mr
Dubbley
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
wery
much
obliged
to
you
,
old
gen'l'm'n
,
"
replied
Sam
,
"
for
consulting
my
conwenience
,
and
I
'm
still
more
obliged
to
the
other
gen'l'm'n
,
who
looks
as
if
he
'd
just
escaped
from
a
giant
's
carrywan
,
for
his
wery
<EOS>
"
andsome
suggestion
;
but
I
should
prefer
your
givin
'
me
a
answer
to
my
question
,
if
it
's
all
the
same
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
---
How
are
you
,
Sir
?
"
 
<EOS>
This
last
observation
was
addressed
with
a
patronising
air
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
was
peeping
through
the
front
window
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Grummer
,
perfectly
speechless
with
indignation
,
dragged
the
truncheon
with
the
brass
crown
from
its
particular
pocket
,
and
flourished
it
before
Sam
's
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
it
's
wery
pretty
,
"
specially
the
crown
,
which
is
uncommon
like
the
real
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
back
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
outraged
Mr
Grummer
.
 
<EOS>
By
way
of
adding
force
to
the
command
,
he
thrust
the
brass
emblem
of
royalty
into
Sam
's
neckcloth
with
one
hand
,
and
seized
Sam
's
collar
with
the
other
---
a
compliment
which
Mr
Weller
returned
by
knocking
him
down
out
of
hand
,
having
previously
with
the
utmost
consideration
,
knocked
down
a
chairman
for
him
to
lie
upon
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
Mr
Winkle
was
seized
with
a
temporary
attack
of
that
species
of
insanity
which
originates
in
a
sense
of
injury
,
or
animated
by
this
display
of
Mr
Weller
's
valour
,
is
uncertain
;
but
certain
it
is
,
that
he
no
sooner
saw
Mr
Grummer
fall
than
he
made
a
terrific
onslaught
on
a
small
boy
who
stood
next
him
;
whereupon
Mr
Snodgrass
,
in
a
truly
Christian
spirit
,
and
in
order
that
he
might
take
no
one
unawares
,
announced
in
a
very
loud
tone
that
he
was
going
to
begin
,
and
proceeded
to
take
off
his
coat
with
the
utmost
deliberation
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
immediately
surrounded
and
secured
;
and
it
is
but
common
justice
both
to
him
and
Mr
Winkle
to
say
,
that
they
did
not
make
the
slightest
attempt
to
rescue
either
themselves
or
Mr
Weller
;
who
,
after
a
most
vigorous
resistance
,
was
overpowered
by
numbers
and
taken
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
The
procession
then
reformed
;
the
chairmen
resumed
their
stations
;
and
the
march
was
re
-
commenced
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
indignation
during
the
whole
of
this
proceeding
was
beyond
all
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
just
see
Sam
upsetting
the
specials
,
and
flying
about
in
every
direction
;
and
that
was
all
he
could
see
,
for
the
sedan
doors
would
n't
open
,
and
the
blinds
would
n't
pull
up
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
with
the
assistance
of
Mr
Tupman
,
he
managed
to
push
open
the
roof
;
and
mounting
on
the
seat
,
and
steadying
himself
as
well
as
he
could
,
by
placing
his
hand
on
that
gentleman
's
shoulder
,
Mr
Pickwick
proceeded
to
address
the
multitude
;
to
dwell
upon
the
unjustifiable
manner
in
which
he
had
been
treated
;
and
to
call
upon
them
to
take
notice
that
his
servant
had
been
first
assaulted
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
order
they
reached
the
magistrate
's
house
;
the
chairmen
trotting
,
the
prisoners
following
,
Mr
Pickwick
oratorising
,
and
the
crowd
shouting
.
    
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
Showing
,
among
a
variety
of
pleasant
matters
,
how
majestic
and
impartial
Mr
Nupkins
was
;
and
how
Mr
Weller
returned
 
<EOS>
Mr
Job
Trotter
's
shuttlecock
as
heavily
as
it
came
---
with
another
matter
,
which
will
be
found
in
its
place
 
<EOS>
Violent
was
Mr
Weller
's
indignation
as
he
was
borne
along
;
numerous
were
the
allusions
to
the
personal
appearance
and
demeanour
of
Mr
Grummer
and
his
companion
;
and
valorous
were
the
defiances
to
any
six
of
the
gentlemen
present
,
in
which
he
vented
his
dissatisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
listened
with
gloomy
respect
to
the
torrent
of
eloquence
which
their
leader
poured
forth
from
the
sedan
-
chair
,
and
the
rapid
course
of
which
not
all
Mr
Tupman
's
earnest
entreaties
to
have
the
lid
of
the
vehicle
closed
,
were
able
to
check
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Weller
's
anger
quickly
gave
way
to
curiosity
when
the
procession
turned
down
the
identical
courtyard
in
which
he
had
met
with
the
runaway
Job
Trotter
;
and
curiosity
was
exchanged
for
a
feeling
of
the
most
gleeful
astonishment
,
when
the
all
-
important
Mr
Grummer
,
commanding
the
sedan
-
bearers
to
halt
,
advanced
with
dignified
and
portentous
steps
to
the
very
green
gate
from
which
Job
Trotter
had
emerged
,
and
gave
a
mighty
pull
at
the
bell
-
handle
which
hung
at
the
side
thereof
.
 
<EOS>
The
ring
was
answered
by
a
very
smart
and
pretty
-
faced
servant
-
girl
,
who
,
after
holding
up
her
hands
in
astonishment
at
the
rebellious
appearance
of
the
prisoners
,
and
the
impassioned
language
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
summoned
Mr
Muzzle
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Muzzle
opened
one
half
of
the
carriage
gate
,
to
admit
the
sedan
,
the
captured
ones
,
and
the
specials
;
and
immediately
slammed
it
in
the
faces
of
the
mob
,
who
,
indignant
at
being
excluded
,
and
anxious
to
see
what
followed
,
relieved
their
feelings
by
kicking
at
the
gate
and
ringing
the
bell
,
for
an
hour
or
two
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
amusement
they
all
took
part
by
turns
,
except
three
or
four
fortunate
individuals
,
who
,
having
discovered
a
grating
in
the
gate
,
which
commanded
a
view
of
nothing
,
stared
through
it
with
the
indefatigable
perseverance
with
which
people
will
flatten
their
noses
against
the
front
windows
of
a
chemist
's
shop
,
when
a
drunken
man
,
who
has
been
run
over
by
a
dog
-
cart
in
the
street
,
is
undergoing
a
surgical
inspection
in
the
back
-
parlour
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
foot
of
a
flight
of
steps
,
leading
to
the
house
door
,
which
was
guarded
on
either
side
by
an
American
aloe
in
a
green
tub
,
the
sedan
-
chair
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
were
conducted
into
the
hall
,
whence
,
having
been
previously
announced
by
Muzzle
,
and
ordered
in
by
Mr
Nupkins
,
they
were
ushered
into
the
worshipful
presence
of
that
public
-
spirited
officer
.
   
<EOS>
The
scene
was
an
impressive
one
,
well
calculated
to
strike
terror
to
the
hearts
of
culprits
,
and
to
impress
them
with
an
adequate
idea
of
the
stern
majesty
of
the
law
.
 
<EOS>
In
front
of
a
big
book
-
case
,
in
a
big
chair
,
behind
a
big
table
,
and
before
a
big
volume
,
sat
Mr
Nupkins
,
looking
a
full
size
larger
than
any
one
of
them
,
big
as
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
The
table
was
adorned
with
piles
of
papers
;
and
above
the
farther
end
of
it
,
appeared
the
head
and
shoulders
of
Mr
Jinks
,
who
was
busily
engaged
in
looking
as
busy
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
The
party
having
all
entered
,
Muzzle
carefully
closed
the
door
,
and
placed
himself
behind
his
master
's
chair
to
await
his
orders
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
threw
himself
back
with
thrilling
solemnity
,
and
scrutinised
the
faces
of
his
unwilling
visitors
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Grummer
,
who
is
that
person
?
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
pointing
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
,
as
the
spokesman
of
his
friends
,
stood
hat
in
hand
,
bowing
with
the
utmost
politeness
and
respect
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
here
's
Pickvick
,
your
Wash
-
up
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
none
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>

'

,

-

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

the

on
;
so
the
sooner
you
commits
these
here
officers
o
'
yourn
to
the
tread
---
mill
for
a
month
or
two
,
the
sooner
we
shall
begin
to
be
on
a

understanding
.
 
<EOS>
Business
first
,
pleasure
arterwards
,
as
King
Richard
<EOS>
the
Third
said
when
he
stabbed
the
t'other
king
in
the
Tower
,
afore
he
smothered
the
babbies
.
"
   
<EOS>
At

of
this
address
,
Mr
Weller
brushed
his
hat
with
his
right

,
and
nodded
benignly
to
Jinks
,
who
had
heard
him
throughout
with
unspeakable

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
this
man
,
Grummer
?
"
said
the
magistrate
,
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wery
desp'rate
ch'racter
,
your
Wash
-
up
,
"

Grummer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
attempted
to

prisoners
,
and
assaulted
the
officers
;
so
we
took
him
into
custody
,
and
brought
him
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
quite
right
,
"
replied
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
evidently
a
desperate
ruffian
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
my
servant
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
he
is
your
servant
,
is
he
?
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
conspiracy
to
defeat
the
ends
of
justice
,
and
murder
its
officers
.
<EOS>
Pickwick
's
servant
.
 
<EOS>
Put
that
down
,
Mr
Jinks
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinks
did
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
name
,
fellow
?
"
thundered
Mr
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Veller
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
very
good
name
for
the
Newgate
Calendar
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
joke
;
so
Jinks
,
Grummer
,
Dubbley
,
all
the
specials
,
and
Muzzle
,
went
into
fits
of
laughter
of
five
minutes
"
duration
.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
down
his
name
,
Mr
Jinks
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Two
L
's
,
old
feller
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
Here
an
unfortunate
special
laughed
again
,
whereupon
the
magistrate
threatened
to
commit
him
instantly
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
dangerous
thing
to
laugh
at
the
wrong
man
,
in
these
cases
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
do
you
live
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Vere
ever
I
can
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
down
that
,
Mr
Jinks
,
"
said

,
who
was
fast

.
   
<EOS>
"
Score
it
under
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is

,
Mr

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

on

,
---
 
<EOS>
is

,
Mr

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

---
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
wery

country
for

,
"
said
Sam
.
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
a
magistrate
goin'
as
do
n't
commit
himself
twice
as
he
commits
other
people
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
sally
another
special
laughed
,
and
then
tried
to
look
so
supernaturally
solemn
,
that
the
magistrate
detected
him
immediately
.
   
<EOS>
"
Grummer
,
"
said

,
reddening

,
<EOS>
"
how

,

?
 
<EOS>
How

,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

very

,
your
Wash
-
up
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
sorry
!
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
repent
of
this

,
Mr

;

.
 
<EOS>
Take
that
fellow
's
staff
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
drunk
,
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not

,

,
"
said

man
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ARE

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
How
dare

say

,
Sir
,

?
 
<EOS>
Does

he
smell

,
Grummer
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Horrid
,
your
Wash
-
up
,
"
replied
Grummer
,
who
had
a

that
there
was
a

of
rum
somewhere
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew
he
did
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

was

,

.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
observe
his

,
Mr
Jinks
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
touched

of

this

,
"
said
the
man
,
who
was
as

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

drunk

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Make

,
Mr

.
"
   
<EOS>
And
committed
the
special
would
have
been
,
only
Jinks
,
who
was
the
magistrate
's
adviser
(
having
had
a
legal
education
of
three
years
in
a
country
attorney
's
office
)
,
whispered
the
magistrate
that
he
thought
it
would
n't
do
;
so
the

made
a
speech
,
and
said
,
that
in
consideration
of
the
special
's
family
,

would

.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
the
special
was
abused
,
vehemently
,
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
and
sent
about
his
business
;
and
Grummer
,
Dubbley
,
Muzzle
,
and
all

other

,
murmured

of

of
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Jinks
,
"
said

,
"
swear
Grummer
.
"
   
<EOS>
Grummer
was
sworn
directly
;
but
as
Grummer
wandered
,
and
Mr
Nupkins
's
dinner
was
nearly
ready
,
Mr
Nupkins
cut
the
matter
short
,
by
putting
leading
questions
to
Grummer
,
which
Grummer
answered
as
nearly
in
the
affirmative
as
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
examination
went
off
,
all
very
smooth
and
comfortable
,
and
two
assaults
were
proved
against
Mr
Weller
,
and
a
threat
against
Mr
Winkle
,
and
a
push
against
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
When
all
this
was
done
to
the
magistrate
's
satisfaction
,
the
magistrate
and
Mr
Jinks
consulted
in
whispers
.
   
<EOS>
The
consultation
having
lasted
about
ten
minutes
,
Mr
Jinks
retired
to
his
end
of
the
table
;
and
the
magistrate
,
with
a
preparatory
cough
,
drew
himself
up
in
his
chair
,
and
was
proceeding
to
commence
his
address
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
interposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
for
interrupting
you
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
but
before
you
proceed
to
express
,
and
act

,
any
opinion
you
may
have
formed
on
the
statements
which
have
been
made
here
,
I
must
claim
my
right
to
be
heard
so
far
as
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your

,
Sir
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must

,
Sir
---
"
said

Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your

,

,
"
interposed

,
"
or

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

;
"
and

I

,

,

,

;

,
Sir
,
of

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Pickvick
and

!
"

,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dumb
as
a
drum
vith
a
hole
in

,
Sir
,
"

Sam
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
looked
at
Mr
Pickwick
with
a

of

,
at
his
displaying
such
unwonted

;
and
was
apparently
about
to

very

,
when
Mr
Jinks
pulled
him
by
the

,
and
whispered
something
in

.
 
<EOS>
To
this
,
the
magistrate
returned
a
half
-
audible
answer
,
and
then
the

was
renewed
.
 
<EOS>
Jinks
was
evidently
remonstrating
.
<EOS>
At
length
the
magistrate
,
gulping
down
,
with
a
very
bad
grace
,
his
disinclination
to
hear
anything
more
,
turned
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
said
sharply
,
"
What
do
you
want
to
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
First
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
sending
a
look

,
under
which
even
Nupkins
quailed
,
<EOS>
"
first
,
I
wish

I
and
my
friend
have

here
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Must
I
tell
him
?
"

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think

had
better
,

,
"
whispered
Jinks
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
An

,
"
said

magistrate
,
"
that

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore
---

,
Mr

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,

,
to
<EOS>
---
I

's

course
,
<EOS>
Mr

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
---
to
---

,
Mr

?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
find

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
call
upon
you
both
---
as
I
was
about

say
when
I

by

---
to
find

.
"
<EOS>
"
Good

,
"

Jinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
require
good

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Town's
-
people
,
"

Jinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
must
be
townspeople
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Fifty
pounds
each
,
"
whispered
Jinks
,
"
and
<EOS>
householders
,
of
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
require
two
sureties
of
fifty
pounds
each
,
"
said
the
magistrate
aloud
,
with
great

,
"
and
they
must
be
householders
,
of
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
bless
my
heart
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
,
together
with
Mr
Tupman
,
was
all
amazement
and

;
"
we
are
perfect
strangers
in
this
town
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
as
little
knowledge
of
any
householders
here
,
as
I
have
intention
of
fighting
a
duel
with
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
,
"
replied
the
magistrate
,
"
I
dare
say
---
do
n't
you
,
Mr
Jinks
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
anything
more
to
say
?
"
inquired
the
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
a
great
deal
more
to
say
,
which
he
would
no
doubt
have
said
,
very
little
to
his
own
advantage
,
or
the
magistrate
's
satisfaction
,
if
he
had
not
,
the
moment
he
ceased
speaking
,
been
pulled
by
the
sleeve
by
Mr
Weller
,
with
whom
he
was
immediately
engaged
in
so
earnest
a
conversation
,
that
he
suffered
the
magistrate
's
inquiry
to
pass
wholly
unnoticed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
was
not
the
man
to
ask
a
question
of
the
kind
twice
over
;
and
<EOS>
so
,
with
another
preparatory
cough
,
he
proceeded
,
amidst
the
reverential
and
admiring
silence
of
the
constables
,
to
pronounce
his
decision
.
<EOS>
He
should
fine
Weller
two
pounds
for
the
first
assault
,
and
three
pounds
for
the
second
.
 
<EOS>
He
should
fine
Winkle
two
pounds
,
and
Snodgrass
one
pound
,
besides
requiring
them
to
enter
into
their
own
recognisances
to
keep
the
peace
towards
all
his
Majesty
's
subjects
,
and
especially
towards
his
liege
servant
,
Daniel
Grummer
.
 
<EOS>
Pickwick
and
Tupman
he
had
already
held
to
bail
.
   
<EOS>
Immediately
on
the
magistrate
ceasing
to
speak
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
smile
mantling
on
his
again
good
-
humoured
countenance
,
stepped
forward
,
and
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
the
magistrate
's
pardon
,
but
may
I
request
a
few
minutes
"
private
conversation
with
him
,
on
a
matter
of
deep
importance
to
himself
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
said
the
magistrate
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
repeated
his
request
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
most
extraordinary
request
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
private
interview
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
private
interview
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
firmly
;
"
<EOS>
only
,
as
a
part
of
the
information
which
I
wish
to
communicate
is
derived
from
my
servant
,
I
should
wish
him
to
be
present
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
magistrate
looked
at
Mr
Jinks
;
Mr
Jinks
looked
at
the
magistrate
;
the
officers
looked
at
each
other
in
amazement
.
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
turned
suddenly
pale
.
 
<EOS>
Could
the
man
Weller
,
in
a
moment
of
remorse
,
have
divulged
some
secret
conspiracy
for
his
assassination
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
dreadful
thought
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
public
man
;
and
he
turned
paler
,
as
he
thought
of
Julius
Caesar
and
Mr
Perceval
.
   
<EOS>
The
magistrate
looked
at
Mr
Pickwick
again
,
and
beckoned
Mr
Jinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
this
request
,
Mr
Jinks
?
<EOS>
"
murmured
Mr
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinks
,
who
did
n't
exactly
know
what
to
think
of
it
,
and
was
afraid
he
might
offend
,
smiled
feebly
,
after
a

,
and
,
screwing
up
the

of

mouth
,
shook

slowly
from
side
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jinks
,
"
said
the
magistrate
gravely
,
"
you
are
an
ass
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
little
expression
of
opinion
,
Mr
Jinks
smiled
again
---
rather
more
feebly
than
before
---
and
edged
himself
,
by
degrees
,
back
into
his
own
corner
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
debated
the
matter
within

for
a

,
and
then
,
rising
from

chair
,
and
requesting
Mr

Sam
to

,
led

into
a
small
room
which
opened
into
the
justice
-

.
 
<EOS>
Desiring
Mr
Pickwick
to
walk
to
the
upper

the
little

,
and
holding

hand
upon
the
half

,
that

effect

,
in

the
least

to

hostilities
<EOS>
,
Mr
Nupkins
expressed

readiness
to

communication
,
whatever

might

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
come
to
the

once
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
it

and

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
Sir
,
that

in

a

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Two
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mulberry
agin
all
natur
,
for
tears
and
willainny
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said

,
"

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wery

,
Sir
,
"

Weller
;
"
but
<EOS>
when
I
think
o
'
that
'
ere
Job
,

ca

"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

Fitz

?
 
<EOS>
Because
,
"

"

,

---
"
   
"
Hush
,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Know

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
An

---

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Dear

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear

,

---
"

Pickvick
,
"

.

<EOS>

!
"

Fitz

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
proceeded
to
pour
into
the

Mr

,
an
abridged

of
all
Mr

's

.
<EOS>
He
related
how
he
had
first
met
him
;
how
he
had
eloped
with
Miss
Wardle
;
how
he
had
cheerfully
resigned
the
lady
for
a
pecuniary

;
how
he
had
entrapped
himself
into
a
lady
's
boarding
-
school
at
midnight
;
and
how
he
(
Mr
Pickwick
)
now
felt
it
his
duty
to
expose
his
assumption
of
his
present
name
and
rank
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
narrative
proceeded
,
all
the
warm
blood
in
the
body
of
Mr
Nupkins
tingled
up
into
the
very
tips
of
his
ears
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
picked
up
the
captain
at
a
neighbouring
race
-
course
.
 
<EOS>
Charmed
with
his
long
list
of
aristocratic
acquaintance
,
<EOS>
his
extensive
travel
,
and
his
fashionable
demeanour
,
Mrs
Nupkins
and
Miss
Nupkins
had
exhibited
Captain
Fitz
-
Marshall
,
and
quoted
Captain
Fitz
-
Marshall
,
and
hurled
Captain
Fitz
-
Marshall
at
the
devoted
heads
of
their
select
circle
of
acquaintance
,
until
their
bosom
friends
,
Mrs
Porkenham
and
the
Misses
Porkenhams
,
and
Mr
Sidney
Porkenham
,
were
ready
to
burst
with
jealousy
and
despair
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
to
hear
,
after
all
,
that
he
was
a
needy
adventurer
,
a
strolling
player
,
and
if
not
a
swindler
,
something
so
very
like
it
,
that
it
was
hard
to
tell
the
difference
!
 
<EOS>
Heavens
!
<EOS>
what
would
the
Porkenhams
say
!
 
<EOS>
What
would
be
the
triumph
of
Mr
Sidney
Porkenham
when
he
found
that
his
addresses
had
been
slighted
for
such
a
rival
!
 
<EOS>
How
should
he
,
Nupkins
,
meet
the
eye
of
old
Porkenham
at
the
next
quarter
-
sessions
!
 
<EOS>
And
what
a
handle
would
it
be
for
the
opposition
magisterial
party
if
the
story
got
abroad
!
   
<EOS>
"
But
after
all
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
brightening
for
a
moment
,
after
a
long

;
"
after
all
,
this
is
a
mere
statement
.
 
<EOS>
Captain
Fitz
-
Marshall
is
a
man
of
very
engaging
manners
,
and
,
I

say
,
has
many

.
 
<EOS>
What
proof
have
you
of
the
truth
of
these
representations
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Confront
me
with
him
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
is
all
I
ask
,
and
all

.
 
<EOS>
Confront
him
with
me
and
my

here
;
you
will

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
"

might
be
very

done
,
for
he
will
be
here
to
-
night
,

,

---
<EOS>
just
---

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
should

Mrs

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pray

.
"
   
<EOS>
Into

they

.
   
<EOS>
"
Grummer
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
in
an

.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
Wash
-
up
,
"

Grummer
,
with
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,

,
Sir
,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Was

?
 
<EOS>
Now

,

!
"
<EOS>
"

-

,
"

"
I-
"

,

"

<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
Grummer
proceeded
to
re
-
state
his
complaint
,
but
<EOS>
,
what
between
Mr
Jinks
's
taking
down
his
words
,
and
the
magistrate
's
taking

up
,
his
natural

to
rambling
,
and
his
extreme

,
he
managed
to
get
involved
,
in
something
under

,
in
such

of

and

,
that
Mr
Nupkins
at
once
declared

did
n't
believe
him
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
fines
were
remitted
,
and
Mr
Jinks
found
a
couple
of
bail
in
no
time
.
 
<EOS>
And
all
these
solemn
proceedings
having
been
satisfactorily
concluded
,
Mr
Grummer
was
ignominiously
ordered
out
---
an
awful
instance
of
the
instability
of
human
greatness
,
and
the
uncertain
tenure
of
great
men
's
favour
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Nupkins
was
a
majestic
female
in
a
pink
gauze
turban
and
a
light
brown
wig
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Nupkins
possessed
all
her
mamma
's
haughtiness
without
the
turban
,
and
all
her
ill
-
nature
without
the
wig
;
and
whenever
the
exercise
of
these
two
amiable
qualities
involved
mother
and
daughter
in
some
unpleasant
dilemma
,
as
they
not
infrequently
did
,
they
both
concurred
in
laying
the
blame
on
the
shoulders
of
Mr
Nupkins
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
when
Mr
Nupkins
sought
Mrs
Nupkins
,
and
detailed
the
communication
which
had
been
made
by
Mr
Pickwick
,
Mrs
Nupkins
suddenly
recollected
that
she
had
always
expected
something
of
the
kind
;
that
she
had
always
said
it
would
be
so
;
that
her
advice
was
never
taken
;
that
she
really
did
not
know
what
Mr
Nupkins
supposed
she
was
;
and
so
forth
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
idea
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Nupkins
,
forcing
a
tear
of
very
scanty
proportions
into
the
corner
of
each
eye
;
"
the
idea
of
my
being
made
such
a
fool
of
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
may
thank
your
papa
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Nupkins
;
"
how
I
have
implored
and
begged
that
man
to
inquire
into
the
captain
's
family
connections
;
how
I
have
urged
and
entreated
him
to
take
some
decisive

!
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
certain
nobody
would
believe
it
---
quite
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
,
<EOS>
you
aggravating
thing
,
do
n't
!
"
said
Mrs
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
love
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
"
you
professed
yourself
very
fond
of
Captain
Fitz
-
Marshall
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
constantly
asked
him
here
,
my
dear
,
and
you
have
lost
no

of
introducing

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
say
so
,
Henrietta
?
"
cried
Mrs
Nupkins
,
appealing
to
her
daughter
with
the
air
of
a
much
-
injured

.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
say
that
your
papa
would
turn
round
and
lay
all
this
at
my

?
<EOS>
Did
n't
I
say
so
?
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mrs
Nupkins
sobbed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
pa
!
"
remonstrated
Miss
Nupkins
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
she
sobbed
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
it
too
much
,
when
he
has
brought
all
this
disgrace
and
ridicule
upon
us
,
to
taunt
me
with
being
the
cause
of
it
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
we
ever
show
ourselves
in
society
!
"
said
Miss
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
we
face
the
Porkenhams
?
"
cried
Mrs
Nupkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
the
Griggs
!
"
cried
Miss
Nupkins
.
<EOS>
"
Or
the
Slummintowkens
!
"
cried
Mrs
Nupkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
does
your
papa
care
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
to
HIM
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
dreadful
reflection
,
Mrs
Nupkins
wept
mental
anguish
,
and
Miss
Nupkins
followed
on
the
same
side
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Nupkins
's
tears
continued
to
gush
forth
,
with
great
velocity
,
until
she
had
gained
a
little
time
to
think
the
matter
over
;
when
she
decided
,
in
her
own
mind
,
that
the
best
thing
to
do
would
be
to
ask
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
to
remain
until
the
captain
's
arrival
,
and
then
to
give
Mr
Pickwick
the
opportunity
he
sought
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
appeared
that
he
had
spoken
truly
,
the
captain
could
be
turned
out
of
the
house
without
noising
the
matter
abroad
,
and
they
could
easily
account
to
the
Porkenhams
for
his
disappearance
,
by
saying
that
he
had
been
appointed
,
through
the
Court
influence
of
his
family
,
to
the
governor
-
generalship
of
Sierra
Leone
,
of
Saugur
Point
,
or
any
other
of
those
salubrious
climates
which
enchant
Europeans
so
much
,
that
when
they
once
get
there
,
they
can
hardly
ever
prevail
upon
themselves
to
come
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
When
Mrs
Nupkins
dried
up
her
tears
,
Miss
Nupkins
dried
up
hers
,
and
Mr
Nupkins
was
very

Mrs

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

,

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Job

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Follow

,
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
As

uttered

,

;
and
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Now
,

no

of

,

about

,

;
and
rushing

Mr
Job
Trotter
,
who
rose
from

chair
on
the
instant
,
tore
and
buffeted
his
large
flat
face
,
with
an
energy
peculiar
to
excited

,
and
twining
her

in

long
black

,
tore
therefrom
about
enough
to
make
five
or
six
dozen
of
the

largest
-

-
rings
.
 
<EOS>
Having

with
all
the

which
her
devoted

for
Mr
Muzzle
inspired
,
she
staggered
back
;
and
being
a
lady
of
very
excitable
and
delicate
feelings
,
she
instantly
fell
under
the
dresser
,
and
fainted
away
.
   
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
the
bell
rang
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
you
,
Job
Trotter
,
"
said
Sam
;
and
before
Mr
Trotter
could
offer

or

---
even
before
he
had
time
to
stanch
the
wounds
inflicted
by
the
insensible
lady
<EOS>
---
Sam
seized
one
arm
and
Mr
Muzzle
the
other
,
and
one
pulling
before
,
and
the
other
pushing
behind
,
they
conveyed
him
upstairs
,
and
into
the
parlour
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
an
impressive
tableau
.
 
<EOS>
Alfred
Jingle
,
Esquire
,
alias
Captain
Fitz
-
Marshall
,
was
standing
near
the
door
with
his
hat
in
his
hand
,
and
a
smile
on
his
face
,
wholly
unmoved
by
his
very
unpleasant
situation
.
 
<EOS>
Confronting
him
,
stood
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
evidently
been
inculcating
some
high
moral
lesson
;
for
his
left
hand
was
beneath
his
coat
tail
,
and
his
right
extended
in
air
,
as
was
his
wo
nt
when
delivering
himself
of
an
impressive
address
.
<EOS>
At
a
little
distance
,
stood
Mr
Tupman
with
indignant
countenance
,
carefully
held
back
by
his
two
younger
friends
;
at
the
farther
end
of
the
room
were
Mr
Nupkins
,
Mrs
Nupkins
,
and
Miss
Nupkins
,
gloomily
grand
and
savagely
vexed
.
<EOS>
"
What
prevents
me
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
with
magisterial
dignity
,
as
Job
was
brought
in
---
"
what
prevents
me
from
detaining
these
men
as
rogues
and
impostors
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
foolish
mercy
.
 
<EOS>
What
prevents
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pride
,
old
fellow
,
pride
,
"
replied
Jingle
,
quite
at
his
ease
.
"
Would
n't
do
---
<EOS>
no
go
---
<EOS>
caught
a
captain
,
eh
?
---
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
very
good
---
husband
for
daughter
---
<EOS>
biter
bit
---
make
it
public
---
not
for
worlds
---
look
stupid
---
very
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wretch
,
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
"
we
scorn
your
base
insinuations
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
always
hated
him
,
"
added
Henrietta
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
of
course
,
"
said
Jingle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tall
young
man
---
old
lover
---
Sidney
Porkenham
---
rich
---
fine
fellow
---
not
so
rich
as
captain
,
though
,
eh
?
---
turn
him
away
---
off
with
him
---
anything
for
captain
---
nothing
like
captain
anywhere
---
all
the
girls
---
raving
mad
---
eh
,
Job
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Jingle
laughed
very
heartily
;
and
Job
,
rubbing
his
hands
with
delight
,
uttered
the
first
sound
he
had
given
vent
to
since
he
entered
the
house
---
a
low
,
noiseless
chuckle
,
which
seemed
to
intimate
that
he
enjoyed
his
laugh
too
much
,
to
let
any
of
it
escape
in
sound
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Nupkins
,
"
said
the
elder
lady
,
"
this
is
not
a
fit
conversation
for
the
servants
to
overhear
.
 
<EOS>
Let
these
wretches
be
removed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
,
"
Said
Mr
,
Nupkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
Muzzle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Open
the
front
door
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
your
Worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Leave
the
house
!
"
said
Mr
Nupkins
,
waving
his
hand
emphatically
.
   
<EOS>
Jingle
smiled
,
and
moved
towards
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
Jingle
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
might
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
have
taken
a
much
greater
revenge
for
the
treatment
I
have
experienced
at
your
hands
,
and
that
of
your
hypocritical
friend
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
Job
Trotter
bowed
with
great
politeness
,
and
laid
his
hand
upon
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
growing
gradually
angry
,
"
that
I
might
have
taken
a
greater
revenge
,
but
I
content
myself
with
exposing
you
,
which
I
consider
a
duty
I
owe
to
society
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
leniency
,
Sir
,
which
I
hope
you
will
remember
.
"
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
Pickwick
arrived
at
this
point
,
Job
Trotter
,
with
facetious
gravity
,
applied
his
hand
to
his
ear
,
as
if
desirous
not
to
lose
a
syllable
he
uttered
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
have
only
to
add
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
now
thoroughly
angry
,
"
that
I
consider
you
a
rascal
,
and
a
---
a
---
ruffian
---
and
---
and
worse
than
any
man
I
ever
saw
,
or
heard
of
,
except
that
pious
and
sanctified
vagabond
in
the
mulberry
livery
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
"
said
Jingle
,
"
good
fellow
,
Pickwick
---
fine
heart
---
stout
old
boy
---
but
must
NOT
be
passionate
---
bad
thing
,
very
<EOS>
---
bye
,
bye
<EOS>
---
see
you
again
some
day
---
keep
up
your
spirits
---
now
,
Job
---
trot
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Mr
Jingle
stuck
on
his
hat
in
his
old
fashion
,
and
strode
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Job
Trotter
paused
,
looked
round
,
smiled
and
then
with
a
bow
of
mock
solemnity
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
a
wink
to
Mr
Weller
,
the
audacious
slyness
of
which
baffles
all
description
,
followed
the
footsteps
of
his
hopeful
master
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
Mr
Weller
was
following
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
"
<EOS>
"
Stay
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
seemed
uncertain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
here
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
n't
I
polish
that
'
ere
Job
off
,
in
the
front

?
"
said
Mr
Weller
.
"
<EOS>
Certainly
not
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
May
n't
I
kick
him
out
o
'
<EOS>
the
gate
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
on
any
account
,
"
replied
his
master
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
since
his
engagement
,
Mr
Weller
looked
,
for
a
moment
,
discontented
and
unhappy
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
countenance
immediately
cleared
up
;
for
the
wily
Mr
Muzzle
,
by
concealing
himself
behind
the
street
door
,
and
rushing
violently
out
,
at
the
right
instant
,
contrived
with
great
dexterity
to
overturn
both
Mr
Jingle
and
his
attendant
,
down
the
flight
of
steps
,
into
the
American
aloe
tubs
that
stood
beneath
.
   
<EOS>
"
Having
discharged
my
duty
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
to
Mr
Nupkins
,
"
I
will
,
with
my
friends
,
bid
you
farewell
.
 
<EOS>
While
we
thank
you
for
such
hospitality
as
we
have
received
,
permit
me
to
assure
you
,
in
our
joint
names
,
that
we
should
not
have
accepted
it
,
or
have
consented
to
extricate
ourselves
in
this
way
,
from
our
previous
dilemma
,
had
we
not
been
impelled
by
a
strong
sense
of
duty
.
 
<EOS>
We
return
to
London
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Your
secret
is
safe
with
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
thus
entered
his
protest
against
their
treatment
of
the
morning
,
Mr
Pickwick
bowed
low
to
the
ladies
,
and
notwithstanding
the
solicitations
of
the
family
,
left
the
room
with
his
friends
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
your
hat
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
below
stairs
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
and
he
ran
down
after
it
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
there
was
nobody
in
the
kitchen
,
but
the
pretty
housemaid
;
and
as
Sam
's
hat
was
mislaid
,
he
had
to
look
for
it
,
and
the
pretty
housemaid
lighted
him
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
to
look
all
over
the
place
for
the
hat
.
 
<EOS>
The
pretty
housemaid
,
in
her
anxiety
to
find
it
,
went
down
on
her
knees
,
and
turned
over
all
the
things
that
were
heaped
together
in
a
little
corner
by
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
awkward
corner
.
 
<EOS>
You
could
n't
get
at
it
without
shutting
the
door
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
"
said
the
pretty
housemaid
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
it
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
The
pretty
housemaid
had
stood
the
candle
on
the
floor
;
and
,
as
it
gave
a
very
dim
light
,
Sam
was
obliged
to
go
down
on
HIS
knees
before
he
could
see
whether
it
really
was
his
own
hat
or
not
.
<EOS>
it
was
a
remarkably
small
corner
,
and
<EOS>
so
---
it
was
nobody
's
fault
but
the
man
's
who
built
the
house
---
Sam
and
the
pretty
housemaid
were
necessarily
very
close
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
this
is
it
,
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
pretty
housemaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Sam
;
and
as
he
said

,
he
dropped
the
hat
that
had
cost
so
much
trouble
in
looking
for
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
awkward
you
are
,
"
said
the
pretty
housemaid
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
lose
it
again
,
if
you
do
n't
take
care
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
just
to
prevent
his
losing
it
again
,
she
put
it
on
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
that
the
pretty
housemaid
's
face
looked
prettier
still
,
when
it
was
raised
towards
Sam
's
,
or
whether

was

of
their
being
so
near
to

other
,
is
matter
of
uncertainty
to
this
day
;
but
Sam
kissed
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean

say
you
did
that
on
purpose
,
"
said
the
pretty
housemaid
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
did
n't
then
,
"
said
Sam
;
"
but
<EOS>
I
will
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
he
kissed
her
again
.
<EOS>
"
Sam
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
calling
over
the
