.
   
<EOS>
"
Coming
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
,
running
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
you
have
been
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
something
behind
the
door
,
Sir
,
which
perwented
our
getting
it
open
,
for
ever
so
long
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
first
passage
of
Mr
Weller
's
first
love
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
Which
contains
a
brief
account
of
the
progress
of
the
action
of
Bardell
against
Pickwick
 
Having
accomplished
the
main
end
and
object
of
his
journey
,
by
the
exposure
of
Jingle
,
Mr
Pickwick
resolved
on
immediately
returning
to
London
,
with
the
view
of
becoming
acquainted
with
the
proceedings
which
had
been
taken
against
him
,
in
the
meantime
,
by
Messrs.
Dodson
and
Fogg
.
 
<EOS>
Acting
upon
this
resolution
with
all
the
energy
and
decision
of
his
character
,
he
mounted
to
the
back
seat
of
the
first
coach
which
left
Ipswich
on
the
morning
after
the
memorable
occurrences
detailed
at
length
in
the
two
preceding
chapters
;
and
accompanied
by
his
three
friends
,
and
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
arrived
in
the
metropolis
,
in
perfect
health
and
safety
,
the
same
evening
.
   
<EOS>
Here
the
friends
,
for
a
short
time
,
separated
.
 
<EOS>
Messrs.
Tupman
,
Winkle
,
and
Snodgrass
repaired
to
their
several
homes
to
make
such
preparations
as
might
be
requisite
for
their
forthcoming
visit
to
Dingley
Dell
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
and
Sam
took
up
their
present
abode
in
very
good
,
old
-
fashioned
,
and
comfortable
quarters
,
to
wit
,
the
George
and
Vulture
Tavern
and
Hotel
,
George
Yard
,
Lombard
Street
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
dined
,
finished
his
second
pint
of
particular
port
,
pulled
his
silk
handkerchief
over
his
head
,
put
his
feet
on
the
fender
,
and
thrown
himself
back
in
an
easy
-
chair
,
when
the
entrance
of
Mr
Weller
with
his
carpet
-
bag
,
aroused
him
from
his
tranquil
meditation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
been
thinking
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
having
left
a
good
many
things
at
Mrs
Bardell
's
,
in
Goswell
Street
,
I
ought
to
arrange
for
taking
them
away
,
before
I
leave
town
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Wery
good
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
send
them
to
Mr
Tupman
's
,
for
the
present
,
Sam
,
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
but
before
we
take
them
away
,
it
is
necessary
that
they
should
be
looked
up
,
and
put
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
would
step
up
to
Goswell
Street
,
Sam
,
and
arrange
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
once
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
once
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
stay
,
Sam
,
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
,
pulling
out
his
purse
,
"
there
is
some
rent
to
pay
.
 
<EOS>
The
quarter
is
not
due
till
Christmas
,
but
you
may
pay
it
,
and
have
done
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
month
's
notice
terminates
my
tenancy
.
 
<EOS>
Here
it
is
,
written
out
.
 
<EOS>
Give
it
,
and
tell
Mrs
Bardell
she
may
put
a
bill
up
,
as
soon
as
she
likes
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Wery
good
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
;
"
anythin
'
more
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
,
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
stepped
slowly
to
the
door
,
as
if
he
expected
something
more
;
slowly
opened
it
,
slowly
stepped
out
,
and
had
slowly
closed
it
within
a
couple
of
inches
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
called
out
---
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
stepping
quickly
back
,
and
closing
the
door
behind
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
objection
,
Sam
,
to
your
endeavouring
to
ascertain
how
Mrs
Bardell
herself
seems
disposed
towards
me
,
and
whether
it
is
really
probable
that
this
vile
and
groundless
action
is
to
be
carried
to
extremity
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
I
do
not
object
to
you
doing
this
,
if
you
wish
it
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
gave
a
short
nod
of
intelligence
,
and
left
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
drew
the
silk
handkerchief
once
more
over
his
head
,
And
composed
himself
for
a
nap
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
promptly
walked
forth
,
to
execute
his
commission
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
nearly
nine
o'clock
when
he
reached
Goswell
Street
.
 
<EOS>
A
couple
of
candles
were
burning
in
the
little
front
parlour
,
and
a
couple
of
caps
were
reflected
on
the
window
-
blind
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
had
got
company
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
knocked
at
the
door
,
and
after
a
pretty
long
interval
---
occupied
by
the
party
without
,
in
whistling
a
tune
,
and
by
the
party
within
,
in
persuading
a
refractory
flat
candle
to
allow
itself
to
be
lighted
---
a
pair
of
small
boots
pattered
over
the
floor
-
cloth
,
and
Master
Bardell
presented
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
young
townskip
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
how
's
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
pretty
well
,
"
replied
Master
Bardell
,
"
so
am
I.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
that
's
a
mercy
,
"
said
Sam
;
"
tell
her
I
want
to
speak
to
her
,
<EOS>
will
you
,
my
hinfant
fernomenon
?
"
   
<EOS>
Master
Bardell
,
thus
adjured
,
placed
the
refractory
flat
candle
on
the
bottom
stair
,
and
vanished
into
the
front
parlour
with
his
message
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
caps
,
reflected
on
the
window
-
blind
,
were
the
respective
head
-
dresses
of
a
couple
of
Mrs
Bardell
's
most
particular
acquaintance
,
who
had
just
stepped
in
,
to
have
a
quiet
cup
of
tea
,
and
a
little
warm
supper
of
a
couple
of
sets
of
pettitoes
and
some
toasted
cheese
.
 
<EOS>
The
cheese
was
simmering
and
browning
away
,
most
delightfully
,
in
a
little
Dutch
oven
before
the
fire
;
the
pettitoes
were
getting
on
deliciously
in
a
little
tin
saucepan
on
the
hob
;
and
Mrs
Bardell
and
her
two
friends
were
getting
on
very
well
,
also
,
in
a
little
quiet
conversation
about
and
concerning
all
their
particular
friends
and
acquaintance
;
when
Master
Bardell
came
back
from
answering
the
door
,
and
delivered
the
message
intrusted
to
him
by
Mr
Samuel
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
's
servant
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
turning
pale
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
raly
would
not
ha
'
believed
it
,
unless
I
had
ha
'
happened
to
ha
'
been
here
!
"
said
Mrs
Sanders
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Cluppins
was
a
little
,
brisk
,
busy
-
looking
woman
;
Mrs
Sanders
was
a
big
,
fat
,
heavy
-
faced
personage
;
and
the
two
were
the
company
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
felt
it
proper
to
be
agitated
;
and
as
none
of
the
three
exactly
knew
whether
under
existing
circumstances
,
any
communication
,
otherwise
than
through
Dodson
&
Fogg
,
ought
to
be
held
with
Mr
Pickwick
's
servant
,
they
were
all
rather
taken
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
state
of
indecision
,
obviously
the
first
thing
to
be
done
,
was
to
thump
the
boy
for
finding
Mr
Weller
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
So
his
mother
thumped
him
,
and
he
cried
melodiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
noise
---
do
---
you
naughty
creetur
!
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
do
n't
worrit
your
poor
mother
,
"
said
Mrs
Sanders
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
quite
enough
to
worrit
her
,
as
it
is
,
without
you
,
Tommy
,
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
,
with
sympathising
resignation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
worse
luck
,
poor
lamb
!
"
said
Mrs
Sanders
.
<EOS>
At
all
which
moral
reflections
,
Master
Bardell
howled
the
louder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
shall
I
do
?
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
to
Mrs
Cluppins
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
ought
to
see
him
,
"
replied

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
on
no
account
without
a

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
two

would
be
more
lawful
,
"
said
Mrs
Sanders
,
who
,
like
the
other
friend
,
was
bursting
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
'd
better
come
in
here
,
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
"
replied
Mrs
Cluppins
,
eagerly

at

idea
;
"
walk
in
,
young
man
;
and
shut
the
street
door
first
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
immediately
took
the
hint
;
and
presenting

in

,
explained
his
business
to
Mrs

thus
---
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
sorry
to
"
casion
any
personal
inconwenience
,
ma'am
,
as
the
housebreaker
said
to
the
old

on

fire
;
but
as
me
and
my

"
s
<EOS>
only
jest
come
to

,
and
is
jest
going
away
agin
,
it
ca
n't
be
helped
,
you
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
the
young
man
ca
n't
help
the
faults
of
his
master
,
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
,
much

by
Mr
Weller
's

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
chimed

Mrs
Sanders
,
who
,
from

at
the
little

,
seemed
to
be
engaged
in
a
mental

of
the
probable

of
the
pettitoes
,
in

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
So
all

've

about
,

jest
this

,
"
said
Sam
,
disregarding

;
"
first
,
to
give
my
governor
's
notice
---
there
it

.
<EOS>
Secondly
,

pay

---

.
 
<EOS>
Thirdly
,

say
as

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fourthly
,

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whatever
has

,
"
said
Mrs

,
"
I
always
have
said
,
and
always

,
that
in
every

but
one
,
Mr
Pickwick
has
always

like

.
<EOS>
His
money
always
as
good
as
the
bank
---
always
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mrs
Bardell
said
this
,
she
applied
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
,
and
went
out
of
the
room
to
get
the
receipt
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
well
knew
that
he
had
only
to
remain
quiet
,
and
the
women
were
sure
to
talk
;
so

looked

the
tin

,
the

,
the

,
and
the

,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
dear
!
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
poor
thing
!
<EOS>
"
replied
Mrs
Sanders
.
<EOS>
Sam
said
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
they
were
coming
to
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
raly
can
not
contain
myself
,
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
,
"
when
I
think
of
such
perjury
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
to
say

to

you
uncomfortable
,
young
man
,
but
your
master
's
an
old
brute
,
and
I
wish

here
to

.
"
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
see

dreadful
she
takes
on
,

,
and

no

in
nothing
,

friends
comes
in
,
out

,
to

,

,
"

,

and

,
"
it
's
shocking
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Barbareous
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
your
master
,
young
man
!
 
<EOS>
A

,
as

never
feel
the

wife
,
no
more

nothing
<EOS>
,
"

,

;
"
why

ai

!
 
<EOS>
Why

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Question
,

,
"

,
"

,

'd

.
 
<EOS>
Hows'ever
,

,
mis'rable

'd

,

;

,

,

,
afore
<EOS>

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
At

,

bridled

,
and
smiled

Sanders
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
action
's
going
on
,

no

,
"

,

re
-

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"

,

"
sake
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
saw
the
advantage
he
should
gain
,
and
at

;
whereupon
Mrs
Bardell
produced
,
from
a

,

-

;
and

,

,

,

's

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Lauk
,
Mrs

,
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
,
"
see
what

've

and

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
that
is
a
good
one
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated

Sanders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
my
poor
head
!
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
Sam

all

,
of

,
so
he
said
at

,
that
he
never
could
drink
before
supper
,
unless
a

with

.
<EOS>
A

laughter

,
and
Mrs

volunteered
to
humour

,
so
she
took

slight

out
of

.
 
<EOS>
Then
Sam
said
it
must
go
all
round
,
so
they
all
took
a
slight
sip
.
 
<EOS>
Then
little
Mrs
Cluppins
proposed
as

,
"
Success
to
Bardell
agin
Pickwick
"
;
and
then
the
ladies
emptied
their

in
honour
of
the
sentiment
,
and
got
very
talkative
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
've
heard
what
's

,
Mr

?
"
said
Mrs

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
heerd

,
"

Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

,
Mr

,
"

;
"
<EOS>
but
I
see

,

I

,

,
Mr

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

's

,

re

;

,

,
that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ven

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Either

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

,
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
But

plaintiff

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

ca

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

Dodson

,

sort
<EOS>
o
'
things

spec
<EOS>
,

,

<EOS>

,

,

---
all

o

,

vish

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Amen

,
"

,
"

liven
"
they
'd
get
out
of
it
!
 
<EOS>
Wish
you
good
-
night
,
ladies
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
the
great
relief
of
Mrs
Sanders
,
Sam
was
allowed
to
depart
without
any
reference
,
on
the
part
of
the
hostess
,
to
the
pettitoes
and
toasted
cheese
;
to
which
the
ladies
,
with
such
juvenile
assistance
as
Master
Bardell
could
afford
,
soon
afterwards
rendered
the
amplest
justice
---
indeed
they
wholly
vanished
before
their
strenuous
exertions
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
wended
his
way
back
to
the
George
and
Vulture
,
and
faithfully
recounted
to
his
master
,
such
indications
of
the
sharp
practice
of
Dodson
&
Fogg
,
as
he
had
contrived
to
pick
up
in
his
visit
to
Mrs
Bardell
's
.
 
<EOS>
An
interview
with
Mr
Perker
,
next
day
,
more
than
confirmed
Mr
Weller
's
statement
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
was
fain
to
prepare
for
his
Christmas
visit
to
Dingley
Dell
,
with
the
pleasant
anticipation
that
some
two
or
three
months
afterwards
,
an
action
brought
against
him
for
damages
sustained
by
reason
of
a
breach
of
promise
of
marriage
,
would
be
publicly
tried
in
the
Court
of
Common
Pleas
;
the
plaintiff
having
all
the
advantages
derivable
,
not
only
from
the
force
of
circumstances
,
but
from
the
sharp
practice
of
Dodson
&
Fogg
to
boot
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
Samuel
Weller
makes
a
pilgrimage
to
Dorking
,
and
beholds
his
mother
-
in
-
law
 
There
still
remaining
an
interval
of
two
days
before
the
time
agreed
upon
for
the
departure
of
the
Pickwickians
to
Dingley
Dell
,
Mr
Weller
sat
himself
down
in
a
back
room
at
the
George
and
Vulture
,
after
eating
an
early
dinner
,
to
muse
on
the
best
way
of
disposing
of
his
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
remarkably
fine
day
;
and
he
had
not
turned
the
matter
over
in
his
mind
ten
minutes
,
when
he
was
suddenly
stricken
filial
and
affectionate
;
and
it
occurred
to
him
so
strongly
that
he
ought
to
go
down
and
see
his
father
,
and
pay
his
duty
to
his
mother
-
in
-
law
,
that
he
was
lost
in
astonishment
at
his
own
remissness
in
never
thinking
of
this
moral
obligation
before
.
 
<EOS>
Anxious
to
atone
for
his
past
neglect
without
another
hour
's
delay
<EOS>
,
he
straightway
walked
upstairs
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
requested
leave
of
absence
for
this
laudable
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sam
,
certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
his
eyes
glistening
with
delight
at
this
manifestation
of
filial
feeling
on
the
part
of
his
attendant
;
"
certainly
,
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
made
a
grateful
bow
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
that
you
have
so
high
a
sense
of
your
duties
as
a
son
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
always
had
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
very
gratifying
reflection
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
approvingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
;
"
if
ever
I
wanted
anythin
'
o
'
my
father
,
I
always
asked
for
it
in
a
wery
"
spectful
and
obligin
'
manner
.
 
<EOS>
If

did

me
,
I
took
it
,
for
fear
I
should
be
led
to
do
anythin
'

,
through
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
saved
him
a
world
o
'

this
vay
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
Sam
,
"
said

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
All
good
feelin
'
,
sir
---
the
wery
best
intentions
,
as
the
gen'l'm'n
said
ven
he
run
away
from
his
wife
"
<EOS>
cos
<EOS>
she
seemed

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may

,
Sam
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
;
and
having

best

,
and

best

,
Sam
planted
himself
on
the
top
of
the
Arundel

,
and
journeyed
on
to
Dorking
.
   
<EOS>
The
Marquis
of
Granby
,
in
Mrs
Weller
's
time
,
was
quite
a
model
of
a
roadside
public
-
house
of
the
better
class
---
just
large
enough
to
be
convenient
,
and
small
enough
to
be
snug
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
opposite
side
of
the
road
was
a
large
sign
-
board
on
a
high
post
,
representing
the
head
and
shoulders
of
a
gentleman
with
an
apoplectic
countenance
,
in
a
red
coat
with
deep
blue
facings
,
and
a
touch
of
the
same
blue
over
his
three
-
cornered
hat
,
for
a
sky
.
<EOS>
Over
that
again
were
a
pair
of
flags
;
beneath
the
last
button
of
his
coat
were
a
couple
of

;
and
the
whole
formed
an
expressive
and
undoubted
likeness
of
the
Marquis
of
Granby
of
glorious
memory
.
   
<EOS>
The
bar
window
displayed
a
choice
collection
of
geranium
plants
,
and
a
well
-
dusted
row
of
spirit
phials
.
 
<EOS>
The
open
shutters
bore
a
variety
of
golden
inscriptions
,
eulogistic
of
good
beds
and
neat
wines
;
and
the
choice
group
of
countrymen
and
hostlers
lounging
about
the
stable
door
and
horse
-
trough
,
afforded
presumptive
proof
of
the
excellent
quality
of
the
ale
and
spirits
which
were
sold
within
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
Weller
paused
,
when
he
dismounted
from
the
coach
,
to
note
all
these
little
indications
of
a
thriving
business
,
with
the
eye
of
an
experienced
traveller
;
and
having
done
so
,
stepped
in
at
once
,
highly
satisfied
with
everything
he
had
observed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
!
"
said
a
shrill
female
voice
the
instant
Sam
thrust
his
head
in
at
the
door
,
"
what
do
you
want
,
young
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
looked
round
in
the
direction
<EOS>
whence
the
voice
proceeded
.
<EOS>
It
came
from
a
rather
stout
lady
of
comfortable
appearance
,
who
was
seated
beside
the
fireplace
in
the
bar
,
blowing
the
fire
to
make
the
kettle
boil
for
tea
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
not
alone
;
for
on
the
other
side
of
the
fireplace
,
sitting
bolt
upright
in
a
high
-
backed
chair
,
was
a
man
in
threadbare
black
clothes
,
with
a
back
almost
as
long
and
stiff
as
that
of
the
chair
itself
,
who
caught
Sam
's
most
particular
and
especial
attention
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
prim
-
faced
,
red
-
nosed
man
,
with
a
long
,
thin
countenance
,
and
a
semi
-
rattlesnake
sort
of
eye
---
rather
sharp
,
but
decidedly
bad
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
very
short
trousers
,
and
black
cotton
stockings
,
which
,
like
the
rest
of
his
apparel
,
were
particularly
rusty
.
 
<EOS>
His
looks
were
starched
,
but
his
white
neckerchief
was
not
,
and
its
long
limp
ends
straggled
over
his
closely
-
buttoned
waistcoat
in
a
very
uncouth
and
unpicturesque
fashion
.
 
<EOS>
A
pair
of
old
,
worn
,
beaver
gloves
,
a
broad
-
brimmed
hat
,
and
a
faded
green
umbrella
,
with
plenty
of
whalebone
sticking
through
the
bottom
,
as
if
to
counterbalance
the
want
of
a
handle
at
the
top
,
lay
on
a
chair
beside
him
;
and
,
being
disposed
in
a
very
tidy
and
careful
manner
,
seemed
to
imply
that
the
red
-
nosed
man
,
whoever
he
was
,
had
no
intention
of
going
away
in
a
hurry
.
   
<EOS>
To
do
the
red
-
nosed
man
justice
,
he
would
have
been
very
far
from
wise
if
he
had
entertained
any
such
intention
;
for
,
to
judge
from
all
appearances
,
he
must
have
been
possessed
of
a
most
desirable
circle
of
acquaintance
,
if
he
could
have
reasonably
expected
to
be
more
comfortable
anywhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
The
fire
was
blazing
brightly
under
the
influence
of
the
bellows
,
and
the
kettle
was
singing
gaily
under
the
influence
of
both
.
 
<EOS>
A
small
tray
of
tea
-
things
was
arranged
on
the
table
;
a
plate
of
hot
buttered

was
gently

before
the
fire
;
and
the
red
-
nosed
man
himself
was
busily
engaged
in
converting
a
large
slice
of
bread
into
the
same
agreeable
edible
,
through
the

of
a
long

-

.
 
<EOS>
Beside

a
glass
of

-

rum
-
and
-
water
,
with

;
and

red

man

,

the

of

how

got

,

-

rum
-
and
-
water
,
and
smiled
upon
the
rather

,
as
she
blew
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
was
so
lost
in
the

of
this
comfortable
scene
,
that
he
suffered
the
first

of
the
rather

to
pass

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not

had

twice

,
each

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
Governor
in
?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
The

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
-
in
-
law
,
"

,
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

do

Weller
!
"
said
Mrs
W
,
raising

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

rayther

;
"

here

THE
Weller

,

.

<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

;

mother
-

.
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

;
"

,

;

ai

sort
<EOS>
o
'

,

"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah

"

,

.
   
<EOS>
Sam

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

-

seemed

;

<EOS>

;

n't

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

's
father
?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
At

,

,

,

<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

'
ere

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Stiggins
took

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a

,
"
said
Mrs
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
man
of

!
"

Stiggins
.
 
<EOS>
He
took

large
semi
-
circular
bite
out
of

,
and
groaned
again
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
felt
very
strongly
disposed
to
give
the
reverend
<EOS>
Mr
Stiggins
something
to
groan
for
,
but
he
repressed

,
and
merely

,
"
What
's
the
old
'
un
up
to
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Up
to
,

!
<EOS>
"
said

Weller
,
"
Oh
,
he
has
a
hard

.
<EOS>
Night
after
night
<EOS>
does

man
---
do

,
Mr
Stiggins
;
I
WILL
say

ARE

---
come

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
Well
,

odd
,
"
said
Sam
;
<EOS>
"
it
'
ud
have
a
wery
considerable
effect
upon
me
,
if
I
wos
in
his
place
;
I
know

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
my
young

,
"
said
Mr
Stiggins

,
"
he
has
an
obderrate

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

young
friend
,

else

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

;
<EOS>
"
I
never
see
one
o
'
<EOS>
them

'

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Those

,

,
"

,
"
blending

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"
said

;
"
them
as

"
shops
,

"
petitions

all
that
'
ere

'

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Stiggins
began

,

.
"
<EOS>
And
he
would
n't

,

?
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sat

,

were
---
what

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Little
humbugs
,
"

Mr
Stiggins
,
deeply

.
   
<EOS>
"
Said
the
infant
negroes
were
little
humbugs
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
both
groaned
at
the
atrocious
conduct
of
the
elder

Weller
.
   
<EOS>
A
great
many
more

of

might
have

,
only
the

being
all

,

tea
having
got
very

,

Sam
holding
out
no

of
meaning

,
Mr

suddenly

that

had
a
most

with

,
and
took

.
   
<EOS>
The
tea
-
things
had

,

,

London

,

,

;

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,

Nobs
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wery

,

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

vish
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"

,
"
she
's

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
She
ai
n't
vithin

'
,
"

;
"

arter

;

.

<EOS>
Saying

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"

,

?
"

<EOS>
"
Red

<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Amiable

'

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Seems

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Borrows

rithmetic

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Ay

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Down

,

,

,
"
ll

rayther

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

<EOS>
And

ai

"
I

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

smoked

,

---
   
"
<EOS>
The
worst
o
'
<EOS>
these
here

is
,

boy
,
that
they
reg'larly
turns
the

,

.
<EOS>
Lord

,

,

<EOS>
,

'

.

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothin'

,
"

,

;
"
and
wot
aggrawates
me
,
Samivel
<EOS>
,
is

'em
a
-
wastin
'
all

as
do

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

'd

,
Samivel
,

just

o
'

,

run

.
 
<EOS>
That
'
ud
shake

,

anythin
'
vould
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
,
having

with

,
eked

of

eye
,
emptied

at

,
and
knocked

ashes

,

.
   
<EOS>
He
was
engaged
in
this

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's

dear

,
Sammy
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
;
and
Mrs
W

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
've

,

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Has

?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
my
dear
,

has

,
"

,
lighting

thereof
,
between

,
a
red
-

from

;
and

,
<EOS>
my

,
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ugh
,

!
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
my
love
,
"
said

Weller
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
father
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
none
<EOS>
o
'
these
little

's
afore

.
 
<EOS>
Here
's

reverend
gen'l'm'n
a
-
comin
'
in

.
<EOS>
"
At

,

just
begun
to
force

;
and
Mr
W
drew

into

-

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Stiggins
was
easily
prevailed
on
to
take
another
glass
of
the
hot
pine
-
apple
rum
-
and
-
water
,
and
a
second
,
and
a
third
,
and
then
to
refresh
himself
with
a
slight
supper
,
previous
to
beginning
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
on
the
same
side
as
Mr
Weller
,
senior
;
and
every
time
he
could
contrive
to
do
so
,
unseen
by
his
wife
,
that
gentleman
indicated
to
his
son
the
hidden
emotions
of
his
bosom
,
by
shaking
his
fist
over
the
deputy
-
shepherd
's
head
;
a
process
which
afforded
his
son
the
most
unmingled
delight
and
satisfaction
,
the
more
especially
as
Mr
Stiggins
went
on
,
quietly
drinking
the
hot
pine
-
apple
rum
-
and
-
water
,
wholly
unconscious
of
what
was
going
forward
.
   
<EOS>
The
major
part
of
the
conversation
was
confined
to
Mrs
Weller
and
the
reverend
Mr
Stiggins
;
and
the
topics
principally
descanted
on
,
were
the
virtues
of
the
shepherd
,
the
worthiness
of
his
flock
,
and
the
high
crimes
and
misdemeanours
of
everybody
beside
---
dissertations
which
the
elder
Mr
Weller
occasionally
interrupted
by
half
-
suppressed
references
to
a
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Walker
,
and
other
running
commentaries
of
the
same
kind
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
Mr
Stiggins
,
with
several
most
indubitable
symptoms
of
having
quite
as
much
pine
-
apple
rum
-
and
-
water
about
him
as
he
could
comfortably
accommodate
,
took
his
hat
,
and
his
leave
;
and
Sam
was
,
immediately
afterwards
,
shown
to
bed
by
his
father
.
 
<EOS>
The
respectable
old
gentleman
wrung
his
hand
fervently
,
and
seemed
disposed
to
address
some
observation
to
his
son
;
but
on
Mrs
Weller
advancing
towards
him
,
he
appeared
to
relinquish
that
intention
,
and
abruptly
bade
him
good
-
night
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
was
up
betimes
next
day
,
and
having
partaken
of
a
hasty
breakfast
,
prepared
to
return
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
set
foot
without
the
house
,
when
his
father
stood
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Goin'
,
Sammy
?
"
inquired
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Off
at
once
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
vish
you
could
muffle
that
'
ere
Stiggins
,
and
take
him
vith
you
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
ashamed
on
you
!
"
said
Sam
reproachfully
;
"
what
do
you
let
him
show
his
red
nose
in
the
Markis
o
'
Granby
at
all
,
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
the
elder
fixed
on
his
son
an
earnest
look
,
and
replied
,
"
<EOS>
'Cause
I
'm
a
married
man
,
Samivel
,
'cause
I
'm
a
married
man
.
 
<EOS>
Ven
<EOS>
you
're
a
married
man
,
Samivel
<EOS>
,
you
'll
understand
a
good
many
things
as
you
do
n't
understand
now
;
but
vether
it
's
worth
while
goin'
through
so
much
,
to
learn
so
little
,
as
the
charity
-
boy
said
ven
<EOS>
he
got
to
the
end
of
the
alphabet
,
is
a
matter
<EOS>
o
'
taste
.
 
<EOS>
I
rayther
think
it
is
n't
.
"
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Tar
,
tar
,
Sammy
,
"
replied
his
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
only
got
to
say
this
here
,
"
said
Sam
,
stopping
short
,
"
that
if
I
was
the
properiator
o
'
the
Markis
o
'
Granby
,
and
that
'
ere
Stiggins
came
and
made
toast
in
my
bar
,
I
'd
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
What
?
<EOS>
"
interposed
Mr
Weller
,
with
great
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pison
his
rum
-
and
-
water
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
shaking
his
son
eagerly
by
the
hand
,
<EOS>
"
would
you
raly
,
Sammy
-
would
you
,
though
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
,
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
be
too
hard
upon
him
at
first
.
<EOS>
I
'd
drop
him
in
the
water
-
butt
,
and
put
the
lid
on
;
and
if
I
found
he
was
insensible
to
kindness
,
I
'd
try
the
other
persvasion
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
elder
Mr
Weller
bestowed
a
look
of
deep
,
unspeakable
admiration
on
his
son
,
and
,
having
once
more
grasped
his
hand
,
walked
slowly
away
,
revolving
in
his
mind
the
numerous
reflections
to
which
his
advice
had
given
rise
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
looked
after
him
,
until
he
turned
a
corner
of
the
road
;
and
then
set
forward
on
his
walk
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
meditated
at
first
,
on
the
probable
consequences
of
his
own
advice
,
and
the
likelihood
of
his
father
's
adopting
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
dismissed
the
subject
from
his
mind
,
however
,
with
the
consolatory
reflection
that
time
alone
would
show
;
and
this
is
the
reflection
we
would
impress
upon
the
reader
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
A
good
-
humoured
Christmas
chapter
,
containing
an
account
of
a
wedding
,
and
some
other
sports
beside
:
which
although
in
their
way
,
even
as
good
customs
as
marriage
itself
,
are
not
quite
so
religiously
kept
up
,
in
these
degenerate
times
 
As
brisk
as
bees
,
if
not
altogether
as
light
as
fairies
,
did
the
four
Pickwickians
assemble
on
the
morning
of
the
twenty
-
second
day
of
December
,
in
the
year
of
grace
in
which
these
,
their
faithfully
-
recorded
adventures
,
were
undertaken
and
accomplished
.
 
<EOS>
Christmas
was
close
at
hand
,
in
all
his
bluff
and
hearty
honesty
;
it
was
the
season
of
hospitality
,
merriment
,
and
open
-
heartedness
;
the
old
year
was
preparing
,
like
an
ancient
philosopher
,
to
call
his
friends
around
him
,
and
amidst
the
sound
of
feasting
and
revelry
to
pass
gently
and
calmly
away
.
 
<EOS>
Gay
and
merry
was
the
time
;
and
right
gay
and
merry
were
at
least
four
of
the
numerous
hearts
that
were
gladdened
by
its
coming
.
   
<EOS>
And
numerous
indeed
are
the
hearts
to
which
Christmas
brings
a
brief
season
of
happiness
and
enjoyment
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
families
,
whose
members
have
been
dispersed
and
scattered
far
and
wide
,
in
the
restless
struggles
of
life
,
are
then
reunited
,
and
meet
once
again
in
that
happy
state
of
companionship
and
mutual
goodwill
,
which
is
a
source
of
such
pure
and
unalloyed
delight
;
and
one
so
incompatible
with
the
cares
and
sorrows
of
the
world
,
that
the
religious
belief
of
the
most
civilised
nations
,
and
the
rude
traditions
of
the
roughest
savages
,
alike
number
it
among
the
first
joys
of
a
future
condition
of
existence
,
provided
for
the
blessed
and
happy
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
old
recollections
,
and
how
many
dormant
sympathies
,
does
Christmas
time
awaken
!
   
<EOS>
We
write
these
words
now
,
many
miles
distant
from
the
spot
at
which
,
year
after
year
,
we
met
on
that
day
,
a
merry
and
joyous
circle
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
the
hearts
that
throbbed
so
gaily
then
,
have
ceased
to
beat
;
<EOS>
many
of
the
looks
that
shone
so
brightly
then
,
have
ceased
to
glow
;
the
hands
we
grasped
,
have
grown
cold
;
the
eyes
we
sought
,
have
hid
their
lustre
in
the
grave
;
and
yet
the
old
house
,
the
room
,
the
merry
voices
and
smiling
faces
,
the
jest
,
the
laugh
,
the
most
minute
and
trivial
circumstances
connected
with
those
happy
meetings
,
crowd
upon
our
mind
at
each
recurrence
of
the
season
,
as
if
the
last
assemblage
had
been
but
yesterday
!
 
<EOS>
Happy
,
happy
Christmas
,
that
can
win
us
back
to
the
delusions
of
our
childish
days
;
that
can
recall
to
the
old
man
the
pleasures
of
his
youth
;
that
can
transport
the
sailor
and
the
traveller
,
thousands
of
miles
away
,
back
to
his
own
fireside
and
his
quiet
home
!
   
<EOS>
But
we
are
so
taken
up
and
occupied
with
the
good
qualities
of
this
saint
Christmas
,
that
we
are
keeping
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
waiting
in
the
cold
on
the
outside
of
the
Muggleton
coach
,
which
they
have
just
attained
,
well
wrapped
up
in
great
-
coats
,
shawls
,
and
comforters
.
 
<EOS>
The
portmanteaus
and
carpet
-
bags
have
been
stowed
away
,
and
Mr
Weller
and
the
guard
are
endeavouring
to
insinuate
into
the
fore
-
boot
a
huge
cod
-
fish
several
sizes
too
large
for
it
---
which
is
snugly
packed
up
,
in
a
long
brown
basket
,
with
a
layer
of
straw
over
the
top
,
and
which
has
been
left
to
the
last
,
in
order
that
he
may
repose
in
safety
on
the
half
-
dozen
barrels
of
real
native
oysters
,
all
the
property
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
which
have
been
arranged
in
regular
order
at
the
bottom
of
the
receptacle
.
 
<EOS>
The
interest
displayed
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
countenance
is
most
intense
,
as
Mr
Weller
and
the
guard
try
to
squeeze
the
cod
-
fish
into
the
boot
,
first
head
first
,
and
then
tail
first
,
and
then
top
upward
,
and
then
bottom
upward
,
and
then
side
-
ways
,
and
then
long
-
ways
,
all
of
which
artifices
the
implacable
cod
-
fish
sturdily
resists
,
until
the
guard
accidentally
hits
him
in
the
very
middle
of
the
basket
,
whereupon
he
suddenly
disappears
into
the
boot
,
and
with
him
,
the
head
and
shoulders
of
the
guard
himself
,
who
,
not
calculating
upon
so
sudden
a
cessation
of
the
passive
resistance
of
the
cod
-
fish
,
experiences
a
very
unexpected
shock
,
to
the
unsmotherable
delight
of
all
the
porters
and
bystanders
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Mr
Pickwick
smiles
with
great
good
-
humour
,
and
drawing
a
shilling
from
his
waistcoat
pocket
,
begs
the
guard
,
as
he
picks
himself
out
of
the
boot
,
to
drink
his
health
in
a
glass
of
hot
brandy
-
and
-
water
;
at
which
the
guard
smiles
too
,
and
Messrs.
Snodgrass
,
Winkle
,
and
Tupman
,
all
smile
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
The
guard
and
Mr
Weller
disappear
for
five
minutes
,
most
probably
to
get
the
hot
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
for
they
smell
very
strongly
of
it
,
when
they
return
,
the
coachman
mounts
to
the
box
,
Mr
Weller
jumps
up
behind
,
the
Pickwickians
pull
their
coats
round
their
legs
and
their
shawls
over
their
noses
,
the
helpers
pull
the
horse
-
cloths
off
,
the
coachman
shouts
out
a
cheery
"
All
right
,
"
and
away
they
go
.
   
<EOS>
They
have
rumbled
through
the
streets
,
and
jolted
over
the
stones
,
and
at
length
reach
the
wide
and
open
country
.
 
<EOS>
The
wheels
skim
over
the
hard
and
frosty
ground
;
and
the
horses
,
bursting
into
a
canter
at
a
smart
crack
of
the
whip
,
step
along
the
road
as
if
the
load
behind
them
---
coach
,
passengers
,
cod
-
fish
,
oyster
-
barrels
,
and
all
---
were
but
a
feather
at
their
heels
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
descended
a
gentle
slope
,
and
enter
upon
a
level
,
as
compact
and
dry
as
a
solid
block
of
marble
,
two
miles
long
.
 
<EOS>
Another
crack
of
the
whip
,
and
on
they
speed
,
at
a
smart
gallop
,
the
horses
tossing
their
heads
and
rattling
the
harness
,
as
if
in
exhilaration
at
the
rapidity
of
the
motion
;
while
the
coachman
,
holding
whip
and
reins
in
one
hand
,
takes
off
his
hat
with
the
other
,
and
resting
it
on
his
knees
,
pulls
out
his
handkerchief
,
and
wipes
his
forehead
,
partly
because
he
has
a
habit
of
doing
it
,
and
partly
because
it
's
as
well
to
show
the
passengers
how
cool
he
is
,
and
what
an
easy
thing
it
is
to
drive
four
-
in
-
hand
,
when
you
have
had
as
much
practice
as
he
has
.
 
<EOS>
Having
done
this
very
leisurely
(
otherwise
the
effect
would
be
materially
impaired
)
,
he
replaces
his
handkerchief
,
pulls
on
his
hat
,
adjusts
his
gloves
,
squares
his
elbows
,
cracks
the
whip
again
,
and
on
they
speed
,
more
merrily
than
before
.
<EOS>
A
few
small
houses
,
scattered
on
either
side
of
the
road
,
betoken
the
entrance
to
some
town
or
village
.
 
<EOS>
The
lively
notes
of
the
guard
's
key
-
bugle
vibrate
in
the
clear
cold
air
,
and
wake
up
the
old
gentleman
inside
,
who
,
carefully
letting
down
the
window
-
sash
half
-
way
,
and
standing
sentry
over
the
air
,
takes
a
short
peep
out
,
and
then
carefully
pulling
it
up
again
,
informs
the
other
inside
that
they
're
going
to
change
directly
;
on
which
the
other
inside
wakes
himself
up
,
and
determines
to
postpone
his
next
nap
until
after
the
stoppage
.
 
<EOS>
Again
the
bugle
sounds
lustily
forth
,
and
rouses
the
cottager
's
wife
and
children
,
who
peep
out
at
the
house
door
,
and
watch
the
coach
till
it
turns
the
corner
,
when
they
once
more
crouch
round
the
blazing
fire
,
and
throw
on
another
log
of
wood
against
father
comes
home
;
while
father
himself
,
a
full
mile
off
,
has
just
exchanged
a
friendly
nod
with
the
coachman
,
and
turned
round
to
take
a
good
long
stare
at
the
vehicle
as
it
whirls
away
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
bugle
plays
a
lively
air
as
the
coach
rattles
through
the
ill
-
paved
streets
of
a
country
town
;
and
<EOS>
the
coachman
,
undoing
the
buckle
which
keeps
his
ribands
together
,
prepares
to
throw
them
off
the
moment
he
stops
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
emerges
from
his
coat
collar
,
and
looks
about
him
with
great
curiosity
;
perceiving
which
,
the
coachman
informs
Mr
Pickwick
of
the
name
of
the
town
,
and
tells
him
it
was
market
-
day
yesterday
,
both
of
which
pieces
of
information
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
retails
to
his
fellow
-
passengers
;
whereupon
they
emerge
from
their
coat
collars
too
,
and
look
about
them
also
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
who
sits
at
the
extreme
edge
,
with
one
leg
dangling
in
the
air
,
is
nearly
precipitated
into
the
street
,
as
the
coach
twists
round
the
sharp
corner
by
the
cheesemonger
's
shop
,
and
turns
into
the
market
-
place
;
and
before
Mr
Snodgrass
,
who
sits
next
to
him
,
has
recovered
from
his
alarm
,
they
pull
up
at
the
inn
yard
where
the
fresh
horses
,
with
cloths
on
,
are
already
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
The
coachman
throws
down
the
reins
and
gets
down
himself
,
and
the
other
outside
passengers
drop
down
also
;
except
those
who
have
no
great
confidence
in
their
ability
to
get
up
again
;
and
they
remain
where
they
are
,
and
stamp
their
feet
against
the
coach
to
warm
them
---
looking
,
with
longing
eyes
and
red
noses
,
at
the
bright
fire
in
the
inn
bar
,
and
the
sprigs
of
holly
with
red
berries
which
ornament
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
guard
has
delivered
at
the
corn
-
dealer
's
shop
,
the
brown
paper
packet
he
took
out
of
the
little
pouch
which
hangs
over
his
shoulder
by
a
leathern
strap
;
and
has
seen
the
horses
carefully
put
to
;
and
has
thrown
on
the
pavement
the
saddle
which
was
brought
from
London
on
the
coach
roof
;
and
has
assisted
in
the
conference
between
the
coachman
and
the
hostler
about
the
gray
mare
that
hurt
her
off
fore
-
leg
last
Tuesday
;
and
he
and
Mr
Weller
are
all
right
behind
,
and
the
coachman
is
all
right
in
front
,
and
the
old
gentleman
inside
,
who
has
kept
the
window
down
full
two
inches
all
this
time
,
has
pulled
it
up
again
,
and
the
cloths
are
off
,
and
they
are
all
ready
for
starting
,
except
the
"
two
stout
gentlemen
,
"
whom
the
coachman
inquires
after
with
some
impatience
.
 
<EOS>
Hereupon
the
coachman
,
and
the
guard
,
and
Sam
Weller
,
and
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
all
the
hostlers
,
and
every
one
of
the
idlers
,
who
are
more
in
number
than
all
the
others
put
together
,
shout
for
the
missing
gentlemen
as
loud
as
they
can
bawl
.
 
<EOS>
A
distant
response
is
heard
from
the
yard
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Tupman
come
running
down
it
,
quite
out
of
breath
,
for
they
have
been
having
a
glass
of
ale
a
-
piece
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
's
fingers
are
so
cold
that
he
has
been
full
five
minutes
before
he
could
find
the
sixpence
to
pay
for
it
.
<EOS>
The
coachman
shouts
an
admonitory
"
Now
then
,
gen'l'm'n
,
"
the
guard
re
-
echoes
it
;
the
old
gentleman
inside
thinks
it
a
very
extraordinary
thing
that
people
WILL
get
down
when
they
know
there
is
n't
time
for
it
;
Mr
Pickwick
struggles
up
on
one
side
,
Mr
Tupman
on
the
other
;
Mr
Winkle
cries
"
All
right
"
;
and
off
they
start
.
 
<EOS>
Shawls
are
pulled
up
,
coat
collars
are
readjusted
,
the
pavement
ceases
,
the
houses
disappear
;
and
they
are
once
again
dashing
along
the
open
road
,
with
the
fresh
clear
air
blowing
in
their
faces
,
and
gladdening
their
very
hearts
within
them
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
progress
of
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
by
the
Muggleton
Telegraph
,
on
their
way
to
Dingley
Dell
;
and
at
three
o'clock
that
afternoon
they
all
stood
high
and
dry
,
safe
and
sound
,
hale
and
hearty
,
upon
the
steps
of
the
Blue
Lion
,
having
taken
on
the
road
quite
enough
of
ale
and
brandy
,
to
enable
them
to
bid
defiance
to
the
frost
that
was
binding
up
the
earth
in
its
iron
fetters
,
and
weaving
its
beautiful
network
upon
the
trees
and
hedges
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
busily
engaged
in
counting
the
barrels
of
oysters
and
superintending
the
disinterment
of
the
cod
-
fish
,
when
he
felt
himself
gently
pulled
by
the
skirts
of
the
coat
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
discovered
that
the
individual
who
resorted
to
this
mode
of
catching
his
attention
was
no
other
than
Mr
Wardle
's
favourite
page
,
better
known
to
the
readers
of
this
unvarnished
history
,
by
the
distinguishing
appellation
of
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
said
it
,
he
glanced
from
the
cod
-
fish
to
the
oyster
-
barrels
,
and
chuckled
joyously
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
fatter
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
you
look
rosy
enough
,
my
young
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
asleep
,
right
in
front
of
the
taproom
fire
,
"
replied
the
fat
boy
,
who
had
heated
himself
to
the
colour
of
a
new
chimney
-
pot
,
in
the
course
of
an
hour
's
nap
.
 
<EOS>
"
Master
sent
me
over
with
the
shay
-
cart
,
to
carry
your
luggage
up
to
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
'd
ha
'
sent
some
saddle
-
horses
,
but
he
thought
you
'd
rather
walk
,
being
a
cold
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
hastily
,
for
he
remembered
how
they
had
travelled
over
nearly
the
same
ground
on
a
previous
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
we
would
rather
walk
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
Sam
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Help
Mr
Wardle
's
servant
to
put
the
packages
into
the
cart
,
and
then
ride
on
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
walk
forward
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
given
this
direction
,
and
settled
with
the
coachman
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
three
friends
struck
into
the
footpath
across
the
fields
,
and
walked
briskly
away
,
leaving
Mr
Weller
and
the
fat
boy
confronted
together
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
looked
at
the
fat
boy
with
great
astonishment
,
but
without
saying
a
word
;
and
began
to
stow
the
luggage
rapidly
away
in
the
cart
,
while
the
fat
boy
stood
quietly
by
,
and
seemed
to
think
it
a
very
interesting
sort
of
thing
to
see
Mr
Weller
working
by
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
Sam
,
throwing
in
the
last
carpet
-
bag
,
"
there
they
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
,
in
a
very
satisfied
tone
,
"
there
they
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
young
twenty
stun
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
you
're
a
nice
specimen
of
a
prize
boy
,
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ai
n't
got
nothin'
on
your
mind
as
makes
you
fret
yourself
,
have
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
as
I
knows
on
,
"
replied
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
rayther
ha
'
thought
,
to
look
at
you
,
that
you
was
a
-
labourin
'
under
an
unrequited
attachment
to
some
young
"
ooman
,
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
drink
anythin
'
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
likes
eating
better
,
"
replied
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
I
should
ha
'
s'posed
that
;
but
what
I
mean
is
,
should
you
like
a
drop
of
anythin
'
as'd
warm
you
?
<EOS>
but
I
s'pose
you
never
was
cold
,
with
all
them
elastic
fixtures
,
was
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
"
replied
the
boy
;
"
and
I
likes
a
drop
of
something
,
when
it
's
good
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
do
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
said
Sam
,
"
come
this
way
,
then
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Blue
Lion
tap
was
soon
gained
,
and
the
fat
boy
swallowed
a
glass
of
liquor
without
so
much
as
winking
---
a
feat
which
considerably
advanced
him
in
Mr
Weller
's
good
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
having
transacted
a
similar
piece
of
business
on
his
own
account
,
they
got
into
the
cart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
drive
?
"
said
the
fat
boy
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
rayther
think
so
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
then
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
,
putting
the
reins
in
his
hand
,
and
pointing
up
a
lane
,
"
it
's
as
straight
as
you
can
go
;
you
ca
n't
miss
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
the
fat
boy
laid
himself
affectionately
down
by
the
side
of
the
cod
-
fish
,
and
,
placing
an
oyster
-
barrel
under
his
head
for
a
pillow
,
fell
asleep
instantaneously
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
of
all
the
cool
boys
<EOS>
ever
I
set
my
eyes
on
,
this
here
young
gen'l'm'n
is
the
coolest
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
wake
up
,
young
dropsy
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
as
young
dropsy
evinced
no
symptoms
of
returning
animation
,
Sam
Weller
sat
himself
down
in
front
of
the
cart
,
and
starting
the
old
horse
with
a
jerk
of
the
rein
,
jogged
steadily
on
,
towards
the
Manor
Farm
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
having
walked
their
blood
into
active
circulation
,
proceeded
cheerfully
on
.
 
<EOS>
The
paths
were
hard
;
the
grass
was
crisp
and
frosty
;
the
air
had
a
fine
,
dry
,
bracing
coldness
;
and
the
rapid
approach
of
the
gray
twilight
<EOS>
(
slate
-
coloured
is
a
better
term
in
frosty
weather
)
made
them
look
forward
with
pleasant
anticipation
to
the
comforts
which
awaited
them
at
their
hospitable
entertainer
's
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
sort
of
afternoon
that
might
induce
a
couple
of
elderly
gentlemen
,
in
a
lonely
field
,
to
take
off
their
greatcoats
and
play
at
leap
-
frog
in
pure
lightness
of
heart
and
gaiety
;
and
we
firmly
believe
that
had
Mr
Tupman
at
that
moment
<EOS>
proffered
"
a
back
,
"
Mr
Pickwick
would
have
accepted
his
offer
with
the
utmost
avidity
.
   
<EOS>
However
,
Mr
Tupman
did
not
volunteer
any
such
accommodation
,
and
the
friends
walked
on
,
conversing
merrily
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
turned
into
a
lane
they
had
to
cross
,
the
sound
of
many
voices
burst
upon
their
ears
;
and
before
they
had
even
had
time
to
form
a
guess
to
whom
they
belonged
,
they
walked
into
the
very
centre
of
the
party
who
were
expecting
their
arrival
---
a
fact
which
was
first
notified
to
the
Pickwickians
,
by
the
loud
"
Hurrah
,
"
which
burst
from
old
Wardle
's
lips
,
when
they
appeared
in
sight
.
   
<EOS>
First
,
there
was
Wardle
himself
,
looking
,
if
that
were
possible
,
more
jolly
than
ever
;
then
there
were
Bella
and
her
faithful
Trundle
;
and
,
lastly
,
there
were
Emily
and
some
eight
or
ten
young
ladies
,
who
had
all
come
down
to
the
wedding
,
which
was
to
take
place
next
day
,
and
who
were
in
as
happy
and
important
a
state
as
young
ladies
usually
are
,
on
such
momentous
occasions
;
and
they
were
,
one
and
all
,
startling
the
fields
and
lanes
,
far
and
wide
,
with
their
frolic
and
laughter
.
   
<EOS>
The
ceremony
of
introduction
,
under
such
circumstances
,
was
very
soon
performed
,
or
we
should
rather
say
that
the
introduction
was
soon
over
,
without
any
ceremony
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
In
two
minutes
thereafter
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
joking
with
the
young
ladies
who
would
n't
come
over
the
stile
while
he
looked
---
or
who
,
having
pretty
feet
and
unexceptionable
ankles
,
preferred
standing
on
the
top
rail
for
five
minutes
or
so
,
declaring
that
they
were
too
frightened
to
move
---
with
as
much
ease
and
absence
of
reserve
or
constraint
,
as
if
he
had
known
them
for
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
worthy
of
remark
,
too
,
that
Mr
Snodgrass
offered
Emily
far
more
assistance
than
the
absolute
terrors
of
the
stile
(
although
it
was
full
three
feet
high
,
and
had
only
a
couple
of
stepping
-
stones
)
<EOS>
would
seem
to
require
;
while
one
black
-
eyed
young
lady
in
a
very
nice
little
pair
of
boots
with
fur
round
the
top
,
was
observed
to
scream
very
loudly
,
when
Mr
Winkle
offered
to
help
her
over
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
was
very
snug
and
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
the
difficulties
of
the
stile
were
at
last
surmounted
,
and
they
once
more
entered
on
the
open
field
,
old
Wardle
informed
Mr
Pickwick
how
they
had
all
been
down
in
a
body
to
inspect
the
furniture
and
fittings
-
up
of
the
house
,
which
the
young
couple
were
to
tenant
,
after
the
Christmas
holidays
;
at
which
communication
Bella
and
Trundle
both
coloured
up
,
as
red
as
the
fat
boy
after
the
taproom
fire
;
and
the
young
lady
with
the
black
eyes
and
the
fur
round
the
boots
,
whispered
something
in
Emily
's
ear
,
and
then
glanced
archly
at
Mr
Snodgrass
;
to
which
Emily
responded
that
she
was
a
foolish
girl
,
but
turned
very
red
,
notwithstanding
;
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
who
was
as
modest
as
all
great
geniuses
usually
are
,
felt
the
crimson
rising
to
the
crown
of
his
head
,
and
devoutly
wished
,
in
the
inmost
recesses
of
his
own
heart
,
that
the
young
lady
aforesaid
,
with
her
black
eyes
,
and
her
archness
,
and
her
boots
with
the
fur
round
the
top
,
were
all
comfortably
deposited
in
the
adjacent
county
.
   
<EOS>
But
if
they
were
social
and
happy
outside
the
house
,
what
was
the
warmth
and
cordiality
of
their
reception
when
they
reached
the
farm
!
 
<EOS>
The
very
servants
grinned
with
pleasure
at
sight
of
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
Emma
bestowed
a
half
-
demure
,
half
-
impudent
,
and
all
-
pretty
look
of
recognition
,
on
Mr
Tupman
,
which
was
enough
to
make
the
statue
of
Bonaparte
in
the
passage
,
unfold
his
arms
,
and
clasp
her
within
them
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
was
seated
with
customary
state
in
the
front
parlour
,
but
she
was
rather
cross
,
and
,
by
consequence
,
most
particularly
deaf
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
went
out
herself
,
and
like
a
great
many
other
old
ladies
of
the
same
stamp
,
she
was
apt
to
consider
it
an
act
of
domestic
treason
,
if
anybody
else
took
the
liberty
of
doing
what
she
could
n't
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
bless
her
old
soul
,
she
sat
as
upright
as
she
could
,
in
her
great
chair
,
and
looked
as
fierce
as
might
be
 
---
and
that
was
benevolent
after
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
said
Wardle
,
"
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
You
recollect
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
replied
the
old
lady
,
with
great
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
trouble
Mr
Pickwick
about
an
old
creetur
like
me
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
cares
about
me
now
,
and
it
's
very
nat'ral
<EOS>
they
should
n't
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
the
old
lady
tossed
her
head
,
and
smoothed
down
her
lavender
-
coloured
silk
dress
with
trembling
hands
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
let
you
cut
an
old
friend
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
down
expressly
to
have
a
long
talk
,
and
another
rubber
with
you
;
and
we
'll
show
these
boys
and
girls
how
to
dance
a
minuet
,
before
they
're
eight
-
and
-
forty
hours
older
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
was
rapidly
giving
way
,
but
she
did
not
like
to
do
it
all
at
once
;
so
she
only
said
,
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
hear
him
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
mother
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
do
n't
be
cross
,
there
's
a
good
soul
.
 
<EOS>
Recollect
Bella
;
come
,
you
must
keep
her
spirits
up
,
poor
girl
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
good
old
lady
heard
this
,
for
her
lip

as
her
son
said

.
 
<EOS>
But
age
has
its
little
infirmities
of
temper
,
and
she
was
not
quite

round
yet
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
she

down

,

"

,
Mr
Pickwick
,

was

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

"

,
"

that

the
old
stock
"
---

,

.
<EOS>
Whether

old

,

,

Mr

,

cause
,
she

melted
;
so

herself
on
her
granddaughter
's
neck
,
and
all
the
little

.
   
<EOS>
A
happy
party
they
were
,
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
Sedate
and
solemn
were
the
score
of

in
which
Mr

and
the
old

together
;
uproarious
was
the
mirth
of
the
round

.
<EOS>
Long
after
the
ladies
had
retired
,
did
the
hot
elder
wine
,
well
qualified
with
brandy
and

,
go
round
,
and
round
,
and
round
again
;
and
sound
was
the
sleep
and
pleasant
<EOS>
were
the
dreams
that
followed
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
remarkable
fact
that
those
of
Mr
Snodgrass
bore
constant
reference
to
Emily
Wardle
;
and
that
the
principal

in
Mr
Winkle
's

was
a
young

with
black
eyes
,
and
arch

,
and
a
pair
of
remarkably
nice
boots
with
fur
round

tops
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
awakened
early
in
the
morning
,
by
a
hum
of
voices
and
a
pattering
of
feet
,
sufficient
to

even
the
fat
boy
from
his

.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
up
in
bed
and
listened
.
 
<EOS>
The
female
servants
and
female
visitors
were
running
constantly
to
and
fro
;
and
there
were
such

demands
for
hot
water
,
such
repeated

for
needles
and

,
and
so

of
"
Oh
,
do

,
there
's
a
dear
!
"
<EOS>
that
Mr
Pickwick
in

that
something
dreadful
must
have
occurred
---
when
he
grew
more
awake
,
and
remembered
the
wedding
.
 
<EOS>
The
occasion
being
an
important
one
,
he
dressed
himself
with
peculiar
care
,
and
descended
to
the

-
room
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
all
the
female
servants
in
a

new

of
pink

with
white
bows
in

,
running

the
house
in
a

and

which
it
would
be
impossible
to

.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
was
dressed
out
in
a
brocaded

,
which
had
not
seen
the
light
for
twenty
years
,
saving
and

such

as
had
stolen

the

in
the
box
in
which

had
been
laid
by
,
during
the
whole

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Trundle
was
in
high
feather
and
spirits
,
but
a
little
nervous
withal
.
 
<EOS>
The
hearty
old
landlord
was
trying
to
look
very
cheerful
and
unconcerned
,
but
failing
signally
in
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
All
the
girls
were
in
tears
and
white

,
except
a
select

three
,
who
were
being
honoured
with
a
private

of
the
bride
and

,
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
Pickwickians
were
in
most
blooming
array
;
and
there
was
a
terrific
roaring
on
the
grass
in
front
of
the
house
,
<EOS>
occasioned
by
all
the
men
,
boys
,
and

to
the
farm
,
each

had

in

button

,
and
all

were

;
being

thereto
,
and

by
the

of
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
who
had
managed
to
become
mighty
popular
already
,
and
was
as
much
at
home
as
if
he
had
been
born
on
the
land
.
   
<EOS>
A
wedding
is
a
licensed
subject
to
joke
upon
,
but
there
really
is
no
great
joke
in
the
matter
after
all
;
---
we
speak
merely
of
the
ceremony
,
and
beg
it
to
be
distinctly
understood
that
we
indulge
in
no
hidden
sarcasm
upon
a
married
life
.
 
<EOS>
Mixed
up
with
the

and
joy
of
the
occasion
,
are
the
many
regrets
at
quitting
home
,
the

of
parting
between
parent
and
child
,
the
consciousness
of
leaving
the
dearest
and

friends
of
the
happiest

of
human
life
,
to
encounter
its

and

with
others
still
untried
and
little

---
natural
feelings
which
we
would
not
render
this
chapter
mournful
by
describing
,
and
which
we
should
be
still
more

.
   
<EOS>
Let

briefly

,

,

was

old

,

's

,

;

;

's

,

,

;

all

;
that

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
To

,

no

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
Mrs

"

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

to

;

,

Tollimglower

;

,

what

<EOS>
grandma
was

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

ten

,
and
said
that
these
always
had
been
considered
capital
stories
,
which
caused

all
to

,
and
put
the
old

into

very

.
 
<EOS>
Then

,

;

<EOS>
"

,
"

"

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

;

.
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

(

.
 
<EOS>
My

,
Trundle
<EOS>
,

;
and

wife
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
(

stentorian
blubberings
,
and
was
led
forth
by
the
coat
collar
,
by
Mr
Weller
.
)
<EOS>
I
wish
,
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
---
"
<EOS>
I
wish
I
was
young
enough
to
be
her
sister
's
husband
(
cheers
)
,
but
,
failing
that
,
I
am
happy
to
be
old
enough
to
be
her
father
;
for
,
being
so
,
I
shall
not
be
suspected
of
any
latent
designs
when
I
say
,
that
I
admire
,
esteem
,
and
love
them
both
(
cheers
and
sobs
)
.
 
<EOS>
The
bride
's
father
,
our
good
friend
there
,
is
a
noble
person
,
and
I
am
proud
to
know
him
(
great
uproar
)
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
kind
,
excellent
,
independent
-
spirited
,
fine
-
hearted
,
hospitable
,
liberal
man
(
enthusiastic
shouts
from
the
poor
relations
,
at
all
the
adjectives
;
and
especially
at
the
two
last
)
.
 
<EOS>
That
his
daughter
may
enjoy
all
the
happiness
,
even
he
can
desire
;
and
that
he
may
derive
from
the
contemplation
of
her
felicity
all
the
gratification
of
heart
and
peace
of
mind
which
he
so
well
deserves
,
is
,
I
am
persuaded
,
our
united
wish
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
let
us
drink
their
healths
,
and
wish
them
prolonged
life
,
and
every
blessing
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
concluded
amidst
a
whirlwind
of
applause
;
and
once
more
were
the
lungs
of
the
supernumeraries
,
under
Mr
Weller
's
command
,
brought
into
active
and
efficient
operation
.
<EOS>
Mr
Wardle
proposed
Mr
Pickwick
;
Mr
Pickwick
proposed
the
old
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
proposed
Mr
Wardle
;
Mr
Wardle
proposed
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
the
poor
relations
proposed
Mr
Tupman
,
and
the
other
poor
relation
proposed
Mr
Winkle
;
all
was
happiness
and
festivity
,
until
the
mysterious
disappearance
of
both
the
poor
relations
beneath
the
table
,
warned
the
party
that
it
was
time
to
adjourn
.
   
<EOS>
At
dinner
they
met
again
,
after
a
five
-
and
-
twenty
mile
walk
,
undertaken
by
the
males
at
Wardle
's
recommendation
,
to
get
rid
of
the
effects
of
the
wine
at
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
relations
had
kept
in
bed
all
day
,
with
the
view
of
attaining
the
same
happy
consummation
,
but
,
as
they
had
been
unsuccessful
,
they
stopped
there
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
kept
the
domestics
in
a
state
of
perpetual
hilarity
;
and
the
fat
boy
divided
his
time
into
small
alternate
allotments
of
eating
and
sleeping
.
   
<EOS>
The
dinner
was
as
hearty
an
affair
as
the
breakfast
,
and
was
quite
as
noisy
,
without
the
tears
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
the
dessert
and
some
more
toasts
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
the
tea
and
coffee
;
and
then
,
the
ball
.
   
<EOS>
The
best
sitting
-
room
at
Manor
Farm
was
a
good
,
long
,
dark
-
panelled
room
with
a
high
chimney
-
piece
,
and
a
capacious
chimney
,
up
which
you
could
have
driven
one
of
the
new
patent
cabs
,
wheels
and
all
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
upper
end
of
the
room
,
seated
in
a
shady
bower
of
holly
and
evergreens
were
the
two
best
fiddlers
,
and
the
only
harp
,
in
all
Muggleton
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
sorts
of
recesses
,
and
on
all
kinds
of
brackets
,
stood
massive
old
silver
candlesticks
with
four
branches
each
.
 
<EOS>
The
carpet
was
up
,
the
candles
burned
bright
,
the
fire
blazed
and
crackled
on
the
hearth
,
and
merry
voices
and
light
-
hearted
laughter
rang
through
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
of
the
old
English
yeomen
had
turned
into
fairies
when
they
died
,
it
was
just
the
place
in
which
they
would
have
held
their
revels
.
   
<EOS>
If
anything
could
have
added
to
the
interest
of
this
agreeable
scene
,
it
would
have
been
the
remarkable
fact
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
appearing
without
his
gaiters
,
for
the
first
time
within
the
memory
of
his
oldest
friends
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
mean
to
dance
?
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
do
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
see
I
am
dressed
for

purpose
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
called
attention
to
his
speckled

,
and
smartly
tied

.
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
in
silk

!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Tupman

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
why
not
,

---
why

?
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

---
I

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
in

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
had

a

,
but
he
found
it

a
serious
matter
;
so
he
looked
grave
,
and
said
they
were
a
pretty
pattern
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
they
are
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
fixing

upon

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
nothing
extraordinary
in
the
stockings
,
AS
stockings
,

,

?
"
   
"
Certainly

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He
walked

;
and
Mr
Pickwick
's

resumed
its

benign
expression
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
ready
,
I
believe
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
was

,

had

four
false

,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
begin
at

,
"
said
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
   
Up
struck
the
two
fiddles
and
the
one
harp
,
and
off
went
Mr
Pickwick
into
hands
across
,
when
there
was
a
general
clapping
of
hands
,
and
a
cry
of
"
Stop
,
stop
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
was
only

to
,
by
the

desisting
,
and
could
have

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
Arabella
Allen
?
<EOS>
"
cried

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Winkle
?
"

Mr
Tupman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
we
are
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
that
gentleman
,
emerging
with
his
pretty
companion
from
the
corner
;
as

,
it
would

hard

the
redder
in

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

,
"

before
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"

,

,

,
<EOS>
"
well
,

WAS

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
However
,

no

to
think

about
the

,
for
the

and

began

.
 
<EOS>
Away

Mr
Pickwick
---
hands
across
---
down
the
middle
to
the
very
end
of
the
room
,
and
half
-
way
up

,
back
again
to
the

---
poussette
everywhere
---
<EOS>
loud

on
the
ground
---
ready
for
the
next
couple
---
off
again
<EOS>
---
all
the
figure
over
once
more
---
another
stamp
to
beat
out
the
time
---
next
couple
,
and
the
next
,
and
the
next
again
---
never
was
such
going
;
at
last
,
after

had

the

of
the

,
and
full
fourteen
couple
after
the
old

had

in

,
and

's
wife
had

,

,
when

no

whatever
on

,
keep

dancing
in
his
place
,
to
keep
time
to

music
,
smiling
on
his
partner
all

with
a

which
baffles

.
   
<EOS>
Long

Mr
Pickwick
was
weary
of

,
the
newly
-
married

had
retired
from

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
glorious

downstairs
,

,
and
a
good

after

;
and

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

has

,

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>

"

;
"

Eve
.
 
<EOS>
Master

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

;

.
"
<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"

,

;
"

!
"
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
All
right
,
Sir
,
"
says
the
pickpocket
,
a
-
wisperin
'
in
his
ear
.
 
<EOS>
And
wen
he
come
straight
agin
,
the
watch

was
gone
,
and
what
's
worse
than
that
<EOS>
,
the
old
gen'l'm'n
's
digestion
was
all
wrong
ever

,
to
the
wery
last

his

;
so
just
you
look
about
you
,
young
feller
,
and
take
care
<EOS>
you
do

too
fat
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Weller
concluded
this
moral
tale
,
with
which
the
fat
boy
appeared
much
affected
,
they
all
three
repaired
to
the
large
kitchen
,
in
which
the
family
were
by
this
time
assembled
,
according
to
annual
custom
on
Christmas
Eve
,
observed
by
old
Wardle
's
forefathers
from
time
immemorial
.
   
<EOS>
From
the
centre
of
the
ceiling
of
this
kitchen
,
old
Wardle
had
just
suspended
,
with
his
own
hands
,
a
huge
branch
of
mistletoe
,
and
this
same
branch
of
mistletoe
instantaneously
gave
rise
to
a
scene
of
general
and
most
delightful
struggling
and

;
in
the

of
which
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a

that
would
have
done
honour
to
a
descendant
of
Lady
Tollimglower
herself
,
took
the
old
lady
by

hand
,
led
her
beneath
the
mystic
branch
,
and
saluted
her
in
all
courtesy
and
decorum
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
submitted
to
this
piece
of
practical
politeness
with
all
the
dignity
which
befitted
so
important
and
serious
a
solemnity
,
but
the
younger
ladies
,
not
being
so
thoroughly
imbued
with
a
superstitious
veneration
for
the
custom
,
or
imagining
that
the
value
of
a
salute
is
very
much
enhanced
if
it
cost
a
little

to
obtain

,
screamed
and
struggled
,
and
ran
into
corners
,
and
threatened
and
remonstrated
,
and
did
everything
but
leave
the
room
,
until
some
of
the
less
adventurous
gentlemen
were
on
the

of
desisting
,
when
they
all
at
once
found
it
useless
to
resist
any

,
and
submitted
to
be
kissed
with
a
good
grace
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
kissed
the
young
lady
with
the
black
eyes
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
kissed
Emily
;
and
Mr
Weller
,
not

about
the
form
of
being
under

,
kissed
Emma
and
the
other
female

,
just
as
he

.
 
<EOS>
As
to

poor
relations
,
they
kissed
everybody
,
not
even

the
plainer

of
the
young
lady
visitors
,
who
,
in

,
ran
right

,
as

was
hung
up
,
without

!
 
<EOS>
Wardle
stood

,

,
with

;
and

,

,
a

,
that
had

,
for

.
   
<EOS>
Now
,

,
and

were
in

,
and

,

,

as

,

,

,

,

,

;
and

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
pleasant

to

Mr
Pickwick
in
the
centre

the
group
,
now
pulled
this
way
,
and

that
,
and
first

,

,
and
then
on
the

,
and
to

were

on

;
but
it
was

more
pleasant
thing
to
see
Mr
Pickwick
,
blinded
shortly
afterwards
with
a
silk
handkerchief
,
falling
up
against
the
wall
,
and
scrambling
into

,
and
going
through
all
the

of
blind
-
man
's
buff
,
with
the
utmost
relish
for
the
game
,
until
at
last
he
caught
one
of
the
poor
relations
,
and
then
had
to
evade
the
blind
-
man
himself
,
which
he
did
with
a

and

that
elicited
the

and

of
all

.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
relations
caught
the
people
who
they
thought
would
like
it
,
and
,
when
the
game
flagged
,
got
caught
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
all
tired
of
blind
-
man
's
buff
,
there
was
a
great
game
at
snap
-
dragon
,
and
when
fingers
enough
were
burned
with
that
,
and
all
the
raisins
were
gone
,

down
by
the
huge
fire
of

logs
to
a

,
and

mighty

of

,
something

,

,

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,

,
"
this
is
,

,
comfort
.
"
<EOS>
"
Our

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Everybody
sits

Christmas
Eve
,

---
servants

,

,

usher

,

.
<EOS>
Trundle
,
my
boy
,
rake

fire
.
"
   
<EOS>
Up

.
<EOS>
The

,
that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said

,
"
a

---
a
Christmas

!
 
<EOS>
I
'll

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"

Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fill
up
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will

two

,

,

through
the
deep

;

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus

,
in
a

,

,
commenced
without
more

---
   
<EOS>
A
CHRISTMAS
CAROL
   
<EOS>
"
I
care
not
for
Spring
;
on
his
fickle
wing
Let
the
blossoms
and
buds
be
borne
;
He
woos
them
amain
with
his
treacherous
rain
,
And
he
scatters
them
ere
the
morn
.
<EOS>
An
inconstant
elf
,
he
knows
not
himself
,
Nor
his
own
changing
mind
an
hour
,
He
'll
smile
in
your
face
,
and
,
with
wry
grimace
,
He
'll
wither
your
youngest
flower
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
the
Summer
sun
to
his
bright
home
run
,
He
shall
never
be
sought
by
me
;
When
he
's
dimmed
by
a
cloud
I
can
laugh
aloud
And
care
not
how
sulky
he
be
!
<EOS>
For
his
darling
child
is
the
madness
wild
That
sports
in
fierce
fever
's
train
;
And
when
love
is
too
strong
,
it
do
n't
last
long
,
As
many
have
found
to
their
pain
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
mild
harvest
night
,
by
the
tranquil
light
Of
the
modest
and
gentle
moon
,
Has
a
far
sweeter
sheen
for
me
,
<EOS>
I
ween
,
Than
the
broad
and
unblushing
noon
.
<EOS>
But
every

awakens
my
grief
,
As
it
lieth
beneath
the
tree
;
So
let
Autumn
air
be
never
so
fair
,
It
by
no
means
agrees
with
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
my
song
I
troll
out
,
for
CHRISTMAS
Stout
,
<EOS>
The
hearty
,
the
true
,
and
the
bold
;
<EOS>
A
bumper
I
drain
,
and
with
might
and
main
Give
three
cheers
for
this
Christmas
old
!
<EOS>
We
'll
usher
him
in
with
a
merry
din
That
shall
gladden
his
joyous
heart
,
And
we
'll
keep
him
up
,
while
there
's
bite
or
sup
,
And
in
fellowship
good
,
we
'll
part
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
his
fine
honest
pride
,
he
scorns
to
hide
One
jot
of
his
hard
-
weather
scars
;
They
're
no
disgrace
,
for
there
's
much
the
same
trace
<EOS>
On
the
cheeks
of
our
bravest
tars
.
<EOS>
Then
again
I
sing
till
the
roof
doth
ring
<EOS>
And
it
echoes
from
wall
to
wall
---
<EOS>
To
the
stout
old
wight
,
fair
welcome
to
-
night
,
As
the
King
of
the
Seasons
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
song
was
tumultuously
applauded
---
for
friends
and
dependents
<EOS>
make
a
capital
audience
---
and
the
poor
relations
,
especially
,
were
in
perfect

of
rapture
.
 
<EOS>
Again
was
the
fire
replenished
,
and
again
went
the
wassail
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
it
snows
!
"
said

men
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Snows
,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Rough
,

,
Sir
,
"

;
"
and

's
a
wind
got
up
,
that
drifts

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
anything
the
matter
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

"

;
"
he

's
a
snowdrift
,

's

.
 
<EOS>
I
should
know

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,
I

---
just

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

;

Gabriel
Grub
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
story

?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nothing
,
nothing
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
About
an
old
sexton
,
that
the
good

down

suppose

carried
away

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

?
 
<EOS>
Suppose
!
 
<EOS>
Have
n't
you
heard
ever
since

were

,
that
he
WAS
carried
away
by
the
goblins
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
WAS

,
Pickwick
;

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

"

Pickwick
,
"
not

end

it
<EOS>
,
I

;
for
I
must
hear
how
,

,

all

.
"
   
<EOS>
Wardle
smiled
,
as
every
head
was
bent
forward
to
hear
,
and
filling

the
wassail
with
no
