,
nodded
a
health
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
began
as
follows
---
   
<EOS>
But
bless
our
editorial
heart
,
what
a
long
chapter
we
have
been
betrayed
into
!
 
<EOS>
We
had
quite
forgotten
all
such
petty
restrictions
as
chapters
,
we
solemnly
declare
.
 
<EOS>
So
here
goes
,
to
give
the
goblin
a
fair
start
in
a
new
one
.
 
<EOS>
A
clear
stage
and
no
favour
for
the
goblins
,
ladies
and
gentlemen
,
if
you
please
.
    
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
The
Story
of
the
Goblins
who
stole
a
Sexton
 
<EOS>
In
an
old
abbey
town
,
<EOS>
down
in
this
part
of
the
country
,
a
long
,
long
while
ago
---
so
long
,
that
the
story
must
be
a
true
one
,
because
our
great
-
grandfathers
implicitly
believed
it
---
there
officiated
as
sexton
and
grave
-
digger
in
the
churchyard
,
one
Gabriel
Grub
.
 
<EOS>
It
by
no
means
follows
that
because
a
man
is
a
sexton
,
and
constantly
surrounded
by
the
emblems
of
mortality
,
therefore
he
should
be
a
morose
and
melancholy
man
;
your
undertakers
are
the
merriest
fellows
in
the
world
;
and
I
once
had
the
honour
of
being
on
intimate
terms
with
a
mute
,
who
in
private
life
,
and
off
duty
,
was
as
comical
and
jocose
a
little
fellow
as
ever
chirped
out
a
devil
-
may
-
care
song
,
without
a
hitch
in
his
memory
,
or
drained
off
a
good
stiff
glass
without
stopping
for
breath
.
 
<EOS>
But
notwithstanding
these
precedents
to
the
contrary
,
Gabriel
Grub
was
an
ill
-
conditioned
,
cross
-
grained
,
surly
fellow
---
a
morose
and
lonely
man
,
who
consorted
with
nobody
but
himself
,
and
an
old
wicker
bottle
which
fitted
into
his
large
deep
waistcoat
pocket
---
and
who
eyed
each
merry
face
,
as
it
passed
him
by
,
with
such
a
deep
scowl
of
malice
and
ill
-
humour
,
as
it
was
difficult
to
meet
without
feeling
something
the
worse
for
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
before
twilight
,
one
Christmas
Eve
,
Gabriel
shouldered
his
spade
,
lighted
his
lantern
,
and
betook
himself
towards
the
old
churchyard
;
for
he
had
got
a
grave
to
finish
by
next
morning
,
and
,
feeling
very
low
,
he
thought
it
might
raise
his
spirits
,
perhaps
,
if
he
went
on
with
his
work
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
went
his
way
,
up
the
ancient
street
,
he
saw
the
cheerful
light
of
the
blazing
fires
gleam
through
the
old
casements
,
and
heard
the
loud
laugh
and
the
cheerful
shouts
of
those
who
were
assembled
around
them
;
he
marked
the
bustling
preparations
for
next
day
's
cheer
,
and
smelled
the
numerous
savoury
odours
consequent
thereupon
,
as
they
steamed
up
from
the
kitchen
windows
in
clouds
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
gall
and
wormwood
to
the
heart
of
Gabriel
Grub
;
and
when
groups
of
children
bounded
out
of
the
houses
,
tripped
across
the
road
,
and
were
met
,
before
they
could
knock
at
the
opposite
door
,
by
half
a
dozen
curly
-
headed
little
rascals
who
crowded
round
them
as
they
flocked
upstairs
to
spend
the
evening
in
their
Christmas
games
,
Gabriel
smiled
grimly
,
and
clutched
the
handle
of
his
spade
with
a
firmer
grasp
,
as
he
thought
of
measles
,
scarlet
fever
,
thrush
,
whooping
-
cough
,
and
a
good
many
other
sources
of
consolation
besides
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
this
happy
frame
of
mind
,
Gabriel
strode
along
,
returning
a
short
,
sullen
growl
to
the
good
-
humoured
greetings
of
such
of
his
neighbours
as
now
and
then
passed
him
,
until
he
turned
into
the
dark
lane
which
led
to
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Gabriel
had
been
looking
forward
to
reaching
the
dark
lane
,
because
it
was
,
generally
speaking
,
a
nice
,
gloomy
,
mournful
place
,
into
which
the
townspeople
did
not
much
care
to
go
,
except
in
broad
daylight
,
and
when
the
sun
was
shining
;
consequently
,
he
was
not
a
little
indignant
to
hear
a
young
urchin
roaring
out
some
jolly
song
about
a
merry
Christmas
,
in
this
very
sanctuary
which
had
been
called
Coffin
Lane
ever
since
the
days
of
the
old
abbey
,
and
the
time
of
the
shaven
-
headed
monks
.
 
<EOS>
As
Gabriel
walked
on
,
and
the
voice
drew
nearer
,
he
found
it
proceeded
from
a
small
boy
,
who
was
hurrying
along
,
to
join
one
of
the
little
parties
in
the
old
street
,
and
who
,
partly
to
keep
himself
company
,
and
partly
to
prepare
himself
for
the
occasion
,
was
shouting
out
the
song
at
the
highest
pitch
of
his
lungs
.
 
<EOS>
So
Gabriel
waited
until
the
boy
came
up
,
and
then
dodged
him
into
a
corner
,
and
rapped
him
over
the
head
with
his
lantern
five
or
six
times
,
just
to
teach
him
to
modulate
his
voice
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
the
boy
hurried
away
with
his
hand
to
his
head
,
singing
quite
a
different
sort
of
tune
,
Gabriel
Grub
chuckled
very
heartily
to
himself
,
and
entered
the
churchyard
,
locking
the
gate
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
took
off
his
coat
,
set
down
his
lantern
,
and
getting
into
the
unfinished
grave
,
worked
at
it
for
an
hour
or
so
with
right
good
-
will
.
<EOS>
But
the
earth
was
hardened
with
the
frost
,
and
it
was
no
very
easy
matter
to
break
it
up
,
and
shovel
it
out
;
and
although
there
was
a
moon
,
it
was
a
very
young
one
,
and
shed
little
light
upon
the
grave
,
which
was
in
the
shadow
of
the
church
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
other
time
,
these
obstacles
would
have
made
Gabriel
Grub
very
moody
and
miserable
,
but
he
was
so
well
pleased
with
having
stopped
the
small
boy
's
singing
,
that
he
took
little
heed
of
the
scanty
progress
he
had
made
,
and
looked
down
into
the
grave
,
when
he
had
finished
work
for
the
night
,
with
grim
satisfaction
,
murmuring
as
he
gathered
up
his
things
---
     
<EOS>
Brave
lodgings
for
one
,
brave
lodgings
for
one
,
     
<EOS>
A
few
feet
of
cold
earth
,
when
life
is
done
;
     
A
stone
at
the
head
,
a
stone
at
the
feet
,
     
<EOS>
A
rich
,
juicy
meal
for
the
worms
to
eat
;
     
Rank
grass
overhead
,
and
damp
clay
around
,
     
Brave
lodgings
for
one
,
these
,
in
holy
ground
!
   
"
<EOS>
"
Ho
!
ho
!
<EOS>
"
laughed
Gabriel
Grub
,
as
he
sat
himself
down
on
a
flat
tombstone
which
was
a
favourite
resting
-
place
of
his
,
and
drew
forth
his
wicker
bottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
coffin
at
Christmas
!
 
<EOS>
A
Christmas
box
!
 
<EOS>
Ho
!
<EOS>
ho
!
<EOS>
ho
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Ho
!
ho
!
ho
!
"
repeated
a
voice
which
sounded
close
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gabriel
paused
,
in
some
alarm
,
in
the
act
of
raising
the
wicker
bottle
to
his
lips
,
and
looked
round
.
 
<EOS>
The
bottom
of
the
oldest
grave
about
him
was
not
more
still
and
quiet
than
the
churchyard
in
the
pale
moonlight
.
 
<EOS>
The
cold
hoar
frost
glistened
on
the
tombstones
,
and
sparkled
like
rows
of
gems
,
among
the
stone
carvings
of
the
old
church
.
 
<EOS>
The
snow
lay
hard
and
crisp
upon
the
ground
;
and
spread
over
the
thickly
-
strewn
mounds
of
earth
,
so
white
and
smooth
a
cover
that
it
seemed
as
if
corpses
lay
there
,
hidden
only
by
their
winding
sheets
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
faintest
rustle
broke
the
profound
tranquillity
of
the
solemn
scene
.
 
<EOS>
Sound
itself
appeared
to
be
frozen
up
,
all
was
so
cold
and
still
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
was
the
echoes
,
"
said
Gabriel
Grub
,
raising
the
bottle
to
his
lips
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
was
NOT
,
"
said
a
deep
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gabriel
started
up
,
and
stood
rooted
to
the
spot
with
astonishment
and
terror
;
for
his
eyes
rested
on
a
form
that
made
his
blood
run
cold
.
   
<EOS>
"
Seated
on
an
upright
tombstone
,
close
to
him
,
was
a
strange
,
unearthly
figure
,
whom
Gabriel
felt
at
once
,
was
no
being
of
this
world
.
 
<EOS>
His
long
,
fantastic
legs
which
might
have
reached
the
ground
,
were
cocked
up
,
and
crossed
after
a
quaint
,
fantastic
fashion
;
his
sinewy
arms
were
bare
;
and
his
hands
rested
on
his
knees
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
short
,
round
body
,
he
wore
a
close
covering
,
ornamented
with
small
slashes
;
a
short
cloak
dangled
at
his
back
;
the
collar
was
cut
into
curious
peaks
,
which
served
the
goblin
in
lieu
of
ruff
or
neckerchief
;
and
his
shoes
curled
up
at
his
toes
into
long
points
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
head
,
he
wore
a
broad
-
brimmed
sugar
-
loaf
hat
,
garnished
with
a
single
feather
.
 
<EOS>
The
hat
was
covered
with
the
white
frost
;
and
the
goblin
looked
as
if
he
had
sat
on
the
same
tombstone
very
comfortably
,
for
two
or
three
hundred
years
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
perfectly
still
;
his
tongue
was
put
out
,
as
if
in
derision
;
and
he
was
grinning
at
Gabriel
Grub
with
such
a
grin
as
only
a
goblin
could
call
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
was
NOT
the
echoes
,
"
said
the
goblin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gabriel
Grub
was
paralysed
,
and
could
make
no
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
do
you
do
here
on
Christmas
Eve
?
"
said
the
goblin
sternly
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
came
to
dig
a
grave
,
Sir
,
"
stammered
Gabriel
Grub
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
man
wanders
among
graves
and
churchyards
on
such
a
night
as
this
?
"
cried
the
goblin
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Gabriel
Grub
!
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
Grub
!
"
screamed
a
wild
chorus
of
voices
that
seemed
to
fill
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
looked
fearfully
round
---
nothing
was
to
be
seen
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
have
you
got
in
that
bottle
?
"
said
the
goblin
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Hollands
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
sexton
,
trembling
more
than
ever
;
for
he
had
bought
it
of
the
smugglers
,
and
he
thought
that
perhaps
his
questioner
might
be
in
the
excise
department
of
the
goblins
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Who
drinks
Hollands
alone
,
and
in
a
churchyard
,
on
such
a
night
as
this
?
"
said
the
goblin
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Gabriel
Grub
!
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
Grub
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
wild
voices
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
goblin
leered
maliciously
at
the
terrified
sexton
,
and
then
raising
his
voice
,
exclaimed
---
   
"
"
And
who
,
then
,
is
our
fair
and
lawful
prize
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
To
this
inquiry
the
invisible
chorus
replied
,
in
a
strain
that
sounded
like
the
voices
of
many
choristers
singing
to
the
mighty
swell
of
the
old
church
organ
---
a
strain
that
seemed
borne
to
the
sexton
's
ears
upon
a
wild
wind
,
and
to
die
away
as
it
passed
onward
;
but
the
burden
of
the
reply
was
still
the
same
,
"
Gabriel
Grub
!
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
Grub
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
goblin
grinned
a
broader
grin
than
before
,
as
he
said
,
"
Well
,
Gabriel
,
what
do
you
say
to
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
sexton
gasped
for
breath
.
"
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
this
,
Gabriel
?
"
said
the
goblin
,
kicking
up
his
feet
in
the
air
on
either
side
of
the
tombstone
,
and
looking
at
the
turned
-
up
points
with
as
much
complacency
as
if
he
had
been
contemplating
the
most
fashionable
pair
of
Wellingtons
in
all
Bond
Street
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
It
's
---
<EOS>
it
's
---
very
curious
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
sexton
,
half
dead
with
fright
;
"
very
curious
,
and
very
pretty
,
<EOS>
but
I
think
I
'll
go
back
and
finish
my
work
,
Sir
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Work
!
"
said
the
goblin
,
"
what
work
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
The
grave
,
Sir
;
making
the
grave
,
"
stammered
the
sexton
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
the
grave
,
eh
?
"
said
the
goblin
;
"
who
makes
graves
at
a
time
when
all
other
men
are
merry
,
and
takes
a
pleasure
in
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Again
the
mysterious
voices
replied
,
"
Gabriel
Grub
!
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
Grub
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
am
afraid
my
friends
want
you
,
Gabriel
,
"
said
the
goblin
,
thrusting
his
tongue
farther
into
his
cheek
than
ever
---
and
a
most
astonishing
tongue
it
was
<EOS>
---
"
I
'm
afraid
my
friends
want
you
,
Gabriel
,
"
said
the
goblin
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Under
favour
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
horror
-
stricken
sexton
,
"
I
do
n't
think
they
can
,
Sir
;
they
do
n't
know
me
,
Sir
;
I
do
n't
think
the
gentlemen
have
ever
seen
me
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
yes
,
they
have
,
"
replied
the
goblin
;
"
we
know
the
man
with
the
sulky
face
and
grim
scowl
,
that
came
down
the
street
to
-
night
,
throwing
his
evil
looks
at
the
children
,
and
grasping
his
burying
-
spade
the
tighter
.
 
<EOS>
We
know
the
man
who
struck
the
boy
in
the
envious
malice
of
his
heart
,
because
the
boy
could
be
merry
,
and
he
could
not
.
 
<EOS>
We
know
him
,
we
know
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
the
goblin
gave
a
loud
,
shrill
laugh
,
which
the
echoes
returned
twentyfold
;
and
throwing
his
legs
up
in
the
air
,
stood
upon
his
head
,
or
rather
upon
the
very
point
of
his
sugar
-
loaf
hat
,
on
the
narrow
edge
of
the
tombstone
,
whence
he
threw
a
Somerset
with
extraordinary
agility
,
right
to
the
sexton
's
feet
,
at
which
he
planted
himself
in
the
attitude
in
which
tailors
generally
sit
upon
the
shop
-
board
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
am
afraid
I
must
leave
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
sexton
,
making
an
effort
to
move
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Leave
us
!
"
said
the
goblin
,
"
Gabriel
Grub
going
to
leave
us
.
<EOS>
Ho
!
<EOS>
ho
!
<EOS>
ho
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
the
goblin
laughed
,
the
sexton
observed
,
for
one
instant
,
a
brilliant
illumination
within
the
windows
of
the
church
,
as
if
the
whole
building
were
lighted
up
;
it
disappeared
,
the
organ
pealed
forth
a
lively
air
,
and
whole
troops
of
goblins
,
the
very
counterpart
of
the
first
one
,
poured
into
the
churchyard
,
and
began
playing
at
leap
-
frog
with
the
tombstones
,
never
stopping
for
an
instant
to
take
breath
,
but
"
overing
"
the
highest
among
them
,
one
after
the
other
,
with
the
most
marvellous
dexterity
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
goblin
was
a
most
astonishing
leaper
,
and
none
of
the
others
could
come
near
him
;
even
in
the
extremity
of
his
terror
the
sexton
could
not
help
observing
,
that
while
his
friends
were
content
to
leap
over
the
common
-
sized
gravestones
,
the
first
one
took
the
family
vaults
,
iron
railings
and
all
,
with
as
much
ease
as
if
they
had
been
so
many
street
-
posts
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
last
the
game
reached
to
a
most
exciting
pitch
;
the
organ
played
quicker
and
quicker
,
and
the
goblins
leaped
faster
and
faster
,
coiling
themselves
up
,
rolling
head
over
heels
upon
the
ground
,
and
bounding
over
the
tombstones
like
footballs
.
 
<EOS>
The
sexton
's
brain
whirled
round
with
the
rapidity
of
the
motion
he
beheld
,
and
his
legs
reeled
beneath
him
,
as
the
spirits
flew
before
his
eyes
;
when
the
goblin
king
,
suddenly
darting
towards
him
,
laid
his
hand
upon
his
collar
,
and
sank
with
him
through
the
earth
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
Gabriel
Grub
had
had
time
to
fetch
his
breath
,
which
the
rapidity
of
his
descent
had
for
the
moment
taken
away
,
he
found
himself
in
what
appeared
to
be
a
large
cavern
,
surrounded
on
all
sides
by
crowds
of
goblins
,
ugly
and
grim
;
in
the
centre
of
the
room
,
on
an
elevated
seat
,
was
stationed
his
friend
of
the
churchyard
;
and
close
behind
him
stood
Gabriel
Grub
himself
,
without
power
of
motion
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Cold
to
-
night
,
"
said
the
king
of
the
goblins
,
"
very
cold
.
 
<EOS>
A
glass
of
something
warm
here
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
this
command
,
half
a
dozen
officious
goblins
,
with
a
perpetual
smile
upon
their
faces
,
whom
Gabriel
Grub
imagined
to
be
courtiers
,
on
that
account
,
hastily
disappeared
,
and
presently
returned
with
a
goblet
of
liquid
fire
,
which
they
presented
to
the
king
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Ah
!
"
cried
the
goblin
,
whose
cheeks
and
throat
were
transparent
,
as
he
tossed
down
the
flame
,
"
this
warms
one
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
Bring
a
bumper
of
the
same
,
for
Mr
Grub
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
in
vain
for
the
unfortunate
sexton
to
protest
that
he
was
not
in
the
habit
of
taking
anything
warm
at
night
;
one
of
the
goblins
held
him
while
another
poured
the
blazing
liquid
down
his
throat
;
the
whole
assembly
screeched
with
laughter
,
as
he
coughed
and
choked
,
and
wiped
away
the
tears
which
gushed
plentifully
from
his
eyes
,
after
swallowing
the
burning
draught
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
the
king
,
fantastically
poking
the
taper
corner
of
his
sugar
-
loaf
hat
into
the
sexton
's
eye
,
and
thereby
occasioning
him
the
most
exquisite
pain
;
"
and
now
,
show
the
man
of
misery
and
gloom
,
a
few
of
the
pictures
from
our
own
great
storehouse
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
the
goblin
said
this
,
a
thick
cloud
which
obscured
the
remoter
end
of
the
cavern
rolled
gradually
away
,
and
disclosed
,
apparently
at
a
great
distance
,
a
small
and
scantily
furnished
,
but
neat
and
clean
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
A
crowd
of
little
children
were
gathered
round
a
bright
fire
,
clinging
to
their
mother
's
gown
,
and
gambolling
around
her
chair
.
 
<EOS>
The
mother
occasionally
rose
,
and
drew
aside
the
window
-
curtain
,
as
if
to
look
for
some
expected
object
;
a
frugal
meal
was
ready
spread
upon
the
table
;
and
an
elbow
chair
was
placed
near
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
A
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
;
the
mother
opened
it
,
and
the
children
crowded
round
her
,
and
clapped
their
hands
for
joy
,
as
their
father
entered
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
wet
and
weary
,
and
shook
the
snow
from
his
garments
,
as
the
children
crowded
round
him
,
and
seizing
his
cloak
,
hat
,
stick
,
and
gloves
,
with
busy
zeal
,
ran
with
them
from
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
as
he
sat
down
to
his
meal
before
the
fire
,
the
children
climbed
about
his
knee
,
and
the
mother
sat
by
his
side
,
and
all
seemed
happiness
and
comfort
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
a
change
came
upon
the
view
,
almost
imperceptibly
.
 
<EOS>
The
scene
was
altered
to
a
small
bedroom
,
where
the
fairest
and
youngest
child
lay
dying
;
the
roses
had
fled
from
his
cheek
,
and
the
light
from
his
eye
;
and
even
as
the
sexton
looked
upon
him
with
an
interest
he
had
never
felt
or
known
before
,
he
died
.
 
<EOS>
His
young
brothers
and
sisters
crowded
round
his
little
bed
,
and
seized
his
tiny
hand
,
so
cold
and
heavy
;
but
they
shrank
back
from
its
touch
,
and
looked
with
awe
on
his
infant
face
;
for
calm
and
tranquil
as
it
was
,
and
sleeping
in
rest
and
peace
as
the
beautiful
child
seemed
to
be
,
they
saw
that
he
was
dead
,
and
they
knew
that
he
was
an
angel
looking
down
upon
,
and
blessing
them
,
from
a
bright
and
happy
Heaven
.
   
<EOS>
"
Again
the
light
cloud
passed
across
the
picture
,
and
again
the
subject
changed
.
 
<EOS>
The
father
and
mother
were
old
and
helpless
now
,
and
the
number
of
those
about
them
was
diminished
more
than
half
;
but
content
and
cheerfulness
sat
on
every
face
,
and
beamed
in
every
eye
,
as
they
crowded
round
the
fireside
,
and
told
and
listened
to
old
stories
of
earlier
and
bygone
days
.
 
<EOS>
Slowly
and
peacefully
,
the
father
sank
into
the
grave
,
and
,
soon
after
,
the
sharer
of
all
his
cares
and
troubles
followed
him
to
a
place
of
rest
.
 
<EOS>
The
few
who
yet
survived
them
,
kneeled
by
their
tomb
,
and
watered
the
green
turf
which
covered
it
with
their
tears
;
then
rose
,
and
turned
away
,
sadly
and
mournfully
,
but
not
with
bitter
cries
,
or
despairing
lamentations
,
for
they
knew
that
they
should
one
day
meet
again
;
and
once
more
they
mixed
with
the
busy
world
,
and
their
content
and
cheerfulness
were
restored
.
 
<EOS>
The
cloud
settled
upon
the
picture
,
and
concealed
it
from
the
sexton
's
view
.
   
"
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
THAT
?
"
said
the
goblin
,
turning
his
large
face
towards
Gabriel
Grub
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Gabriel
murmured
out
something
about
its
being
very
pretty
,
and
looked
somewhat
ashamed
,
as
the
goblin
bent
his
fiery
eyes
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
miserable
man
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
goblin
,
in
a
tone
of
excessive
contempt
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
!
"
<EOS>
He
appeared
disposed
to
add
more
,
but
indignation
choked
his
utterance
,
so
he
lifted
up
one
of
his
very
pliable
legs
,
and
,
flourishing
it
above
his
head
a
little
,
to
insure
his
aim
,
administered
a
good
sound
kick
to
Gabriel
Grub
;
immediately
after
which
,
all
the
goblins
in
waiting
crowded
round
the
wretched
sexton
,
and
kicked
him
without
mercy
,
according
to
the
established
and
invariable
custom
of
courtiers
upon
earth
,
who
kick
whom
royalty
kicks
,
and
hug
whom
royalty
hugs
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Show
him
some
more
!
"
said
the
king
of
the
goblins
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
these
words
,
the
cloud
was
dispelled
,
and
a
rich
and
beautiful
landscape
was
disclosed
to
view
---
there
is
just
such
another
,
to
this
day
,
within
half
a
mile
of
the
old
abbey
town
.
<EOS>
The
sun
shone
from
out
the
clear
blue
sky
,
the
water
sparkled
beneath
his
rays
,
and
the
trees
looked
greener
,
and
the
flowers
more
gay
,
beneath
its
cheering
influence
.
 
<EOS>
The
water
rippled
on
with
a
pleasant
sound
,
the
trees
rustled
in
the
light
wind
that
murmured
among
their
leaves
,
the
birds
sang
upon
the
boughs
,
and
the
lark
carolled
on
high
her
welcome
to
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
it
was
morning
;
the
bright
,
balmy
morning
of
summer
;
the
minutest
leaf
,
the
smallest
blade
of
grass
,
was
instinct
with
life
.
<EOS>
The
ant
crept
forth
to
her
daily
toil
,
the
butterfly
fluttered
and
basked
in
the
warm
rays
of
the
sun
;
myriads
of
insects
spread
their
transparent
wings
,
and
revelled
in
their
brief
but
happy
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Man
walked
forth
,
elated
with
the
scene
;
and
all
was
brightness
and
splendour
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
YOU
a
miserable
man
!
"
said
the
king
of
the
goblins
,
in
a
more
contemptuous
tone
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
And
again
the
king
of
the
goblins
gave
his
leg
a
flourish
;
again
it
descended
on
the
shoulders
of
the
sexton
;
and
again
the
attendant
goblins
imitated
the
example
of
their
chief
.
   
<EOS>
"
Many
a
time
the
cloud
went
and
came
,
and
many
a
lesson
it
taught
to
Gabriel
Grub
,
who
,
although
his
shoulders
smarted
with
pain
from
the
frequent
applications
of
the
goblins
"
feet
thereunto
,
looked
on
with
an
interest
that
nothing
could
diminish
.
<EOS>
He
saw
that
men
who
worked
hard
,
and
earned
their
scanty
bread
with
lives
of
labour
,
were
cheerful
and
happy
;
and
that
to
the
most
ignorant
,
the
sweet
face
of
Nature
was
a
never
-
failing
source
of
cheerfulness
and
joy
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
those
who
had
been
delicately
nurtured
,
and
tenderly
brought
up
,
cheerful
under
privations
,
and
superior
to
suffering
,
that
would
have
crushed
many
of
a
rougher
grain
,
because
they
bore
within
their
own
bosoms
the
materials
of
happiness
,
contentment
,
and
peace
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
that
women
,
the
tenderest
and
most
fragile
of
all
God
's
creatures
,
were
the
oftenest
superior
to
sorrow
,
adversity
,
and
distress
;
and
he
saw
that
it
was
because
they
bore
,
in
their
own
hearts
,
an
inexhaustible
well
-
spring
of
affection
and
devotion
.
<EOS>
Above
all
,
he
saw
that
men
like
himself
,
who
snarled
at
the
mirth
and
cheerfulness
of
others
,
were
the
foulest
weeds
on
the
fair
surface
of
the
earth
;
and
setting
all
the
good
of
the
world
against
the
evil
,
he
came
to
the
conclusion
that
it
was
a
very
decent
and
respectable
sort
of
world
after
all
.
 
<EOS>
No
sooner
had
he
formed
it
,
than
the
cloud
which
had
closed
over
the
last
picture
,
seemed
to
settle
on
his
senses
,
and
lull
him
to
repose
.
 
<EOS>
One
by
one
,
the
goblins
faded
from
his
sight
;
and
,
as
the
last
one
disappeared
,
he
sank
to
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
day
had
broken
when
Gabriel
Grub
awoke
,
and
found
himself
lying
at
full
length
on
the
flat
gravestone
in
the
churchyard
,
with
the
wicker
bottle
lying
empty
by
his
side
,
and
his
coat
,
spade
,
and
lantern
,
all
well
whitened
by
the
last
night
's
frost
,
scattered
on
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
The
stone
on
which
he
had
first
seen
the
goblin
seated
,
stood
bolt
upright
before
him
,
and
the
grave
at
which
he
had
worked
,
the
night
before
,
was
not
far
off
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
he
began
to
doubt
the
reality
of
his
adventures
,
but
the
acute
pain
in
his
shoulders
when
he
attempted
to
rise
,
assured
him
that
the
kicking
of
the
goblins
was
certainly
not
ideal
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
staggered
again
,
by
observing
no
traces
of
footsteps
in
the
snow
on
which
the
goblins
had
played
at
leap
-
frog
with
the
gravestones
,
but
he
speedily
accounted
for
this
circumstance
when
he
remembered
that
,
being
spirits
,
they
would
leave
no
visible
impression
behind
them
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
Gabriel
Grub
got
on
his
feet
as
well
as
he
could
,
for
the
pain
in
his
back
;
and
,
brushing
the
frost
off
his
coat
,
put
it
on
,
and
turned
his
face
towards
the
town
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
was
an
altered
man
,
and
he
could
not
bear
the
thought
of
returning
to
a
place
where
his
repentance
would
be
scoffed
at
,
and
his
reformation
disbelieved
.
 
<EOS>
He
hesitated
for
a
few
moments
;
and
then
turned
away
to
wander
where
he
might
,
and
seek
his
bread
elsewhere
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
lantern
,
the
spade
,
and
the
wicker
bottle
were
found
,
that
day
,
in
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
great
many
speculations
about
the
sexton
's
fate
,
at
first
,
but
it
was
speedily
determined
that
he
had
been
carried
away
by
the
goblins
;
and
there
were
not
wanting
some
very
credible
witnesses
who
had
distinctly
seen
him
whisked
through
the
air
on
the
back
of
a
chestnut
horse
blind
of
one
eye
,
with
the
hind
-
quarters
of
a
lion
,
and
the
tail
of
a
bear
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
all
this
was
devoutly
believed
;
and
the
new
sexton
used
to
exhibit
to
the
curious
,
for
a
trifling
emolument
,
a
good
-
sized
piece
of
the
church
weathercock
which
had
been
accidentally
kicked
off
by
the
aforesaid
horse
in
his
aerial
flight
,
and
picked
up
by
himself
in
the
churchyard
,
a
year
or
two
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
Unfortunately
,
these
stories
were
somewhat
disturbed
by
the
unlooked
-
for
reappearance
of
Gabriel
Grub
himself
,
some
ten
years
afterwards
,
a
ragged
,
contented
,
rheumatic
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
his
story
to
the
clergyman
,
and
also
to
the
mayor
;
and
in
course
of
time
it
began
to
be
received
as
a
matter
of
history
,
in
which
form
it
has
continued
down
to
this
very
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
believers
in
the
weathercock
tale
,
having
misplaced
their
confidence
once
,
were
not
easily
prevailed
upon
to
part
with
it
again
,
so
they
looked
as
wise
as
they
could
,
shrugged
their
shoulders
,
touched
their
foreheads
,
and
murmured
something
about
Gabriel
Grub
having
drunk
all
the
Hollands
,
and
then
fallen
asleep
on
the
flat
tombstone
;
and
they
affected
to
explain
what
he
supposed
he
had
witnessed
in
the
goblin
's
cavern
,
by
saying
that
he
had
seen
the
world
,
and
grown
wiser
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
opinion
,
which
was
by
no
means
a
popular
one
at
any
time
,
gradually
died
off
;
and
be
the
matter
how
it
may
,
as
Gabriel
Grub
was
afflicted
with
rheumatism
to
the
end
of
his
days
,
this
story
has
at
least
one
moral
,
if
it
teach
no
better
one
---
and
that
is
,
that
if
a
man
turn
sulky
and
drink
by
himself
at
Christmas
time
,
he
may
make
up
his
mind
to
be
not
a
bit
the
better
for
it
:
let
the
spirits
be
never
so
good
,
or
let
them
be
even
as
many
degrees
beyond
proof
,
as
those
which
Gabriel
Grub
saw
in
the
goblin
's
cavern
.
"
    
Chapter
30
.
<EOS>
How
the
Pickwickians
made

how

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Wery

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

-

'

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
at
the

of
the
quarter
of
an

,
went
down
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is

!
"
said
old

.
 
<EOS>
"
Pickwick
,

Miss
Allen
's

,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Ben
we

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

,
Mr
---
"
   
"
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
"
interposed
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
;
whereupon
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
and
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
laughed
in
concert
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
bowed
to
Bob
Sawyer
,
and
Bob
Sawyer
bowed
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Bob
and
his
very
particular
friend
then
applied
themselves
most
assiduously
to
the
eatables
before
them
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
had
an
opportunity
of
glancing
at
them
both
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
was
a
coarse
,
stout
,
thick
-
set
young
man
,
with
black
hair
cut
rather
short
,
and
a
white
face
cut
rather
long
.
<EOS>
He
was
embellished
with
spectacles
,
and
wore
a
white
neckerchief
.
<EOS>
Below
his
single
-
breasted
black
surtout
,
which
was
buttoned
up
to
his
chin
,
appeared
the
usual
number
of
pepper
-
and
-
salt
coloured
legs
,
terminating
in
a
pair
of
imperfectly
polished
boots
.
 
<EOS>
Although
his
coat
was
short
in
the
sleeves
,
it
disclosed
no
vestige
of
a
linen
wristband
;
and
although
there
was
quite
enough
of
his
face
to
admit
of
the
encroachment
of
a
shirt
collar
,
it
was
not
graced
by
the
smallest
approach
to
that
appendage
.
<EOS>
He
presented
,
altogether
,
rather
a
mildewy
appearance
,
and
emitted
a
fragrant
odour
of
full
-
flavoured
Cubas
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
who
was
habited
in
a
coarse
,
blue
coat
,
which
,
without
being
either
a
greatcoat
or
a
surtout
,
partook
of
the
nature
and
qualities
of
both
,
had
about
him
that
sort
of
slovenly
smartness
,
and
swaggering
gait
,
which
is
peculiar
to
young
gentlemen
who
smoke
in
the
streets
by
day
,
shout
and
scream
in
the
same
by
night
,
call
waiters
by
their
Christian
names
,
and
do
various
other
acts
and
deeds
of
an
equally
facetious
description
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
a
pair
of
plaid
trousers
,
and
a
large
,
rough
,
double
-
breasted
waistcoat
;
out
of
doors
,
he
carried
a
thick
stick
with
a
big
top
.
 
<EOS>
He
eschewed
gloves
,
and
looked
,
upon
the
whole
,
something
like
a
dissipated
Robinson
Crusoe
.
   
<EOS>
Such
were
the
two
worthies
to
whom
Mr
Pickwick
was
introduced
,
as
he
took
his

at
the

-

on

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Splendid
morning
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
slightly
nodded

assent
to
the
proposition
,
and
asked
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
for
the
mustard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
come
far
this

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Blue

,
"

Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

;
"
ca

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca

,

"

,
"
I

,

.
"
<EOS>
"

,

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As

Pickwick

,

,
gallantly

by

Snodgrass
,
Winkle
,

,

from

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Ben
!
"
said
Arabella
,
in

which
expressed
more

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
to

"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

see
Bob
Sawyer
,
Arabella
?
<EOS>
"

Allen
,

.
 
<EOS>
Arabella

,

Bob

's

.
 
<EOS>
A

to
Mr

's

,
as
Bob

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ben
,

!
"
said

,

;
"

---

---

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
but
I

,
Arabella
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Allen
bowed

to
Mr
Winkle
,
while
Mr
Winkle
and
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
glanced
mutual

out
of
the

of
their

.
   
<EOS>
The
arrival
of
the
two
new
visitors
,
and
the
consequent
check
upon
Mr
Winkle
and
the
young
lady
with
the
fur
round
her
boots
,
would
in
all
probability
have
proved
a
very
unpleasant
interruption
to
the
hilarity
of
the
party
,
had
not
the
cheerfulness
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
the
good
humour
of
the
host
,
been
exerted
to
the
very
utmost
for
the
common
weal
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
gradually
insinuated
himself
into
the
good
graces
of
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
,
and
even
joined
in
a
friendly
conversation
with
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
;
who
,
enlivened
with
the
brandy
,
and
the
breakfast
,
and
the
talking
,
gradually
ripened
into
a
state
of
extreme
facetiousness
,
and
related
with
much
glee
an
agreeable
anecdote
,
about
the
removal
of
a
tumour
on
some
gentleman
's
head
,
which
he
illustrated
by
means
of
an
oyster
-
knife
and
a
half
-
quartern
loaf
,
to
the
great
edification
of
the
assembled
company
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
whole
train
went
to
church
,
where
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
fell
fast
asleep
;
while
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
abstracted
his
thoughts
from
worldly
matters
,
by
the
ingenious
process
of
carving
his
name
on
the
seat
of
the
pew
,
in
corpulent
letters
of
four
inches
long
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Wardle
,
after
a
substantial
lunch
,
with
the
agreeable
items
of
strong
beer
and
cherry
-
brandy
,
had
been
done
ample
justice
to
,
"
what
say
you
to
an
hour
on
the
ice
?
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
plenty
of
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
!
"
said
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Prime
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
skate
,
of
course
,
Winkle
?
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ye
<EOS>
-
yes
;
oh
,
yes
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
am
RATHER
out
of
practice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
DO
skate
,
Mr
Winkle
,
"
said
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
see
it
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
is
SO
graceful
,
"
said
another
young
lady
.
<EOS>
A
third
young
lady
said
it
was
elegant
,
and
a
fourth
expressed
her
opinion
that
it
was
"
swan
-
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
happy
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
reddening
;
"
but
I
have
no
skates
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
objection
was
at
once
overruled
.
 
<EOS>
Trundle
had
a
couple
of
pair
,
and
the
fat
boy
announced
that
there
were
half
a
dozen
more
downstairs
;
whereat
Mr
Winkle
expressed
exquisite
delight
,
and
looked
exquisitely
uncomfortable
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Wardle
led
the
way
to
a
pretty
large
sheet
of
ice
;
and
the
fat
boy
and
Mr
Weller
,
having
shovelled
and
swept
away
the
snow
which
had
fallen
on
it
during
the
night
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
adjusted
his
skates
with
a
dexterity
which
to
Mr
Winkle
was
perfectly
marvellous
,
and
described
circles
with
his
left
leg
,
and
cut
figures
of
eight
,
and
inscribed
upon
the
ice
,
without
once
stopping
for
breath
,
a
great
many
other
pleasant
and
astonishing
devices
,
to
the
excessive
satisfaction
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
Mr
Tupman
,
and
the
ladies
;
which
reached
a
pitch
of
positive
enthusiasm
,
when
old
Wardle
and
Benjamin
Allen
,
assisted
by
the
aforesaid
Bob
Sawyer
,
performed
some
mystic
evolutions
,
which
they
called
a
reel
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Mr
Winkle
,
with
his
face
and
hands
blue
with
the
cold
,
had
been
forcing
a
gimlet
into
the
sole
of
his
feet
,
and
putting
his
skates
on
,
with
the
points
behind
,
and
getting
the
straps
into
a
very
complicated
and
entangled
state
,
with
the
assistance
of
Mr
Snodgrass
,
who
knew
rather
less
about
skates
than
a
Hindoo
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
with
the
assistance
of
Mr
Weller
,
the
unfortunate
skates
were
firmly
screwed
and
buckled
on
,
and
Mr
Winkle
was
raised
to
his
feet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
in
an
encouraging
tone
;
<EOS>
"
off
vith
you
,
and
show
'em
how
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
Sam
,
stop
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
trembling
violently
,
and
clutching
hold
of
Sam
's
arms
with
the
grasp
of
a
drowning
man
.
<EOS>
"
How
slippery
it
is
,
Sam
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
an
uncommon
thing
upon
ice
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
<EOS>
"
Hold
up
,
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
last
observation
of
Mr
Weller
's
bore
reference
to
a
demonstration
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
made
at
the
instant
,
of
a
frantic
desire
to
throw
his
feet
in
the
air
,
and
dash
the
back
of
his
head
on
the
ice
.
   
<EOS>
"
These
---
these
---
are
very
awkward
skates
;
ai
n't
they
,
Sam
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
staggering
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afeerd
there
's
a
orkard
gen'l'm'n
in
'em
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Winkle
,
"
cried
Mr
Pickwick
,
quite
unconscious
that
there
was
anything
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
;
the
ladies
are
all
anxiety
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
with
a
ghastly
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
coming
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
a
-
goin
'
to
begin
,
"
said
Sam
,
endeavouring
to
disengage
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Sir
,
start
off
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
an
instant
,
Sam
,
"
gasped
Mr
Winkle
,
clinging
most
affectionately
to
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
find
I
've
got
a
couple
of
coats
at
home
that
I
do
n't
want
,
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
have
them
,
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
touching
your
hat
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
take
your
hand
away
to
do
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
meant
to
have
given
you
five
shillings
this
morning
for
a
Christmas
box
,
Sam
.
<EOS>
I
'll
give
it
you
this
afternoon
,
Sam
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
wery
good
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
hold
me
at
first
,
Sam
;
will
you
?
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
---
that
's
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
soon
get
in
the
way
of
it
,
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
Not
too
fast
,
Sam
;
not
too
fast
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
stooping
forward
,
with
his
body
half
doubled
up
,
was
being
assisted
over
the
ice
by
Mr
Weller
,
in
a
very
singular
and
un
-
swan
-
like
manner
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
most

shouted
from
the

bank
---
   
"
Sam
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
go
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
hear
the
governor
a
-
callin
'
?
<EOS>
Let
go
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
violent
effort
,
Mr
Weller
disengaged
himself
from
the
grasp
of
the
agonised
Pickwickian
,
and
,
in
so
doing
,
administered
a
considerable
impetus
to
the
unhappy
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
With
an
accuracy
which
no
degree
of
dexterity
or
practice
could
have
insured
,
that
unfortunate
gentleman
bore
swiftly
down
into
the
centre
of
the
reel
,
at
the
very
moment
when
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
was
performing
a
flourish
of
unparalleled
beauty
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
struck
wildly
against
him
,
and
with
a
loud
crash
they
both
fell
heavily
down
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
ran
to
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
Bob
Sawyer
had
risen
to
his
feet
,
but
Mr
Winkle
was
far
too
wise
to
do
anything
of
the
kind
,
in
skates
.
<EOS>
He
was
seated
on
the
ice
,
making
spasmodic
efforts
to
smile
;
but
anguish
was
depicted
on
every
lineament
of
his
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
hurt
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
,
with
great
anxiety
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
rubbing
his
back
very
hard
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
'd
let
me
bleed
you
,
"
said
Mr
Benjamin
,
with
great
eagerness
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
hurriedly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
really
think
you
had
better
,
"
said
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
;
"
I
'd
rather
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
YOU
think
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
inquired
Bob
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
excited
and
indignant
.
 
<EOS>
He
beckoned
to
Mr
Weller
,
and
said
in
a
stern
voice
,
"
Take
his
skates
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
but
really
I
had
scarcely
begun
,
"
remonstrated
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
his
skates
off
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pickwick
firmly
.
   
<EOS>
The
command
was
not
to
be
resisted
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
allowed
Sam
to
obey
it
,
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lift
him
up
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
assisted
him
to
rise
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
retired
a
few
paces
apart
from
the
bystanders
;
and
,
beckoning
his
friend
to
approach
,
fixed
a
searching
look
upon
him
,
and
uttered
in
a
low
,
but
distinct
and
emphatic
tone
,
these
remarkable
words
---
   
"
You
're
a
humbug
,
sir
.
"
<EOS>
"
A
what
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
starting
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
humbug
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
speak
plainer
,
if
you
wish
it
.
 
<EOS>
An
impostor
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
those
words
,
Mr
Pickwick
turned
slowly
on
his
heel
,
and
rejoined
his
friends
.
   
<EOS>
While
Mr
Pickwick
was
delivering
himself
of
the
sentiment
just
recorded
,
Mr
Weller
and
the
fat
boy
,
having
by
their
joint
endeavours
cut
out
a
slide
,
were
exercising
themselves
thereupon
,
in
a
very
masterly
and
brilliant
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
Weller
,
in
particular
,
was
displaying
that
beautiful
feat
of
fancy
-
sliding
which
is
currently
denominated
"
knocking
at
the
cobbler
's
door
,
"
and
which
is
achieved
by
skimming
over
the
ice
on
one
foot
,
and
occasionally
giving
a
postman
's
knock
upon
it
with
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
good
long
slide
,
and
there
was
something
in
the
motion
which
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
was
very
cold
with
standing
still
,
could
not
help
envying
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
looks
a
nice
warm
exercise
that
,
does
n't
it
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
of
Wardle
,
when
that
gentleman
was
thoroughly
out
of
breath
,
by
reason
of
the
indefatigable
manner
in
which
he
had
converted
his
legs
into
a
pair
of
compasses
,
and
drawn
complicated
problems
on
the
ice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
it
does
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
slide
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
used
to
do
so
,
on
the
gutters
,
when
I
was
a
boy
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Try
it
now
,
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
,
please
,
Mr
Pickwick
!
"
cried
all
the
ladies
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
happy
to
afford
you
any
amusement
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
but
I
have
n't
done
such
a
thing
these
thirty
years
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
<EOS>
pooh
!
 
<EOS>
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
"
said
Wardle
,
dragging
off
his
skates
with
the
impetuosity
which
characterised
all
his
proceedings
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
;
I
'll
keep
you
company
;
come
along
!
"
<EOS>
And
away
went
the
good
-
tempered
old
fellow
down
the
slide
,
with
a
rapidity
which
came
very
close
upon
Mr
Weller
,
and
beat
the
fat
boy
all
to
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
paused
,
considered
,
pulled
off
his
gloves
and
put
them
in
his
hat
;
took
two
or
three
short
runs
,
baulked
himself
as
often
,
and
at
last
took
another
run
,
and
went
slowly
and
gravely
down
the
slide
,
with
his
feet
about
a
yard
and
a
quarter
apart
,
amidst
the
gratified
shouts
of
all
the
spectators
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
the
pot
a
-
bilin
'
,
Sir
!
"
said
Sam
;
and
down
went
Wardle
again
,
and
then
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
then
Sam
,
and
then
Mr
Winkle
,
and
then
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
and
then
the
fat
boy
,
and
then
Mr
Snodgrass
,
following
closely
upon
each
other
's
heels
,
and
running
after
each
other
with
as
much
eagerness
as
if
their
future
prospects
in
life
depended
on
their
expedition
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
most
intensely
interesting
thing
,
to
observe
the
manner
in
which
Mr
Pickwick
performed
his
share
in
the
ceremony
;
to
watch
the
torture
of
anxiety
with
which
he
viewed
the
person
behind
,
gaining
upon
him
at
the
imminent
hazard
of
tripping
him
up
;
to
see
him
gradually
expend
the
painful
force
he
had
put
on
at
first
,
and
turn
slowly
round
on
the
slide
,
with
his
face
towards
the
point
from
which
he
had
started
;
to
contemplate
the
playful
smile
which
mantled
on
his
face
when
he
had
accomplished
the
distance
,
and
the
eagerness
with
which
he
turned
round
when
he
had
done
so
,
and
ran
after
his
predecessor
,
his
black
gaiters
tripping
pleasantly
through
the
snow
,
and
his
eyes
beaming
cheerfulness
and
gladness
through
his
spectacles
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
was
knocked
down
(
which
happened
upon
the
average
every
third
round
)
,
it
was
the
most
invigorating
sight
that
can
possibly
be
imagined
,
to
behold
him
gather
up
his
hat
,
gloves
,
and
handkerchief
,
with
a
glowing
countenance
,
and
resume
his
station
in
the
rank
,
with
an
ardour
and
enthusiasm
that
nothing
Could
abate
.
   
<EOS>
The
sport
was
at
its
height
,
the
sliding
was
at
the
quickest
,
the
laughter
was
at
the
loudest
,
when
a
sharp
smart
crack
was
heard
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
quick
rush
towards
the
bank
,
a
wild
scream
from
the
ladies
,
and
a
shout
from
Mr
Tupman
.
 
<EOS>
A
large
mass
of
ice
disappeared
;
the
water
bubbled
up
over
it
;
Mr
Pickwick
's
hat
,
gloves
,
and
handkerchief
were
floating
on
the
surface
;
and
this
was
all
of
Mr
Pickwick
that
anybody
could
see
.
   
<EOS>
Dismay
and
anguish
were
depicted
on
every
countenance
;
the
males
turned
pale
,
and
the
females
fainted
;
Mr
Snodgrass
and
Mr
Winkle
grasped
each
other
by
the
hand
,
and
gazed
at
the
spot
where
their
leader
had
gone
down
,
with
frenzied
eagerness
;
while
Mr
Tupman
,
by
way
of
rendering
the
promptest
assistance
,
and
at
the
same
time
conveying
to
any
persons
who
might
be
within
hearing
,
the
clearest
possible
notion
of
the
catastrophe
,
ran
off
across
the
country
at
his
utmost
speed
,
screaming
"
Fire
!
"
<EOS>
with
all
his
might
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
moment
,
when
old
Wardle
and
Sam
Weller
were
approaching
the
hole
with
cautious
steps
,
and
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
was
holding
a
hurried
consultation
with
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
on
the
advisability
of
bleeding
the
company
generally
,
as
an
improving
little
bit
of
professional
practice
<EOS>
---
it
was
at
this
very
moment
,
that
a
face
,
head
,
and
shoulders
,
emerged
from
beneath
the
water
,
and
disclosed
the
features
and
spectacles
of
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
yourself
up
for
an
instant
---
for
only
one
instant
!
"
<EOS>
bawled
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
do
;
let
me
implore
you
---
for
my
sake
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Mr
Winkle
,
deeply
affected
.
 
<EOS>
The
adjuration
was
rather
unnecessary
;
the
probability
being
,
that
if
Mr
Pickwick
had
declined
to
keep
himself
up
for
anybody
else
's
sake
,
it
would
have
occurred
to
him
that
he
might
as
well
do
so
,
for
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
feel
the
bottom
there
,
old
fellow
?
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
certainly
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
wringing
the
water
from
his
head
and
face
,
and
gasping
for
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fell
upon
my
back
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
get
on
my
feet
at
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
clay
upon
so
much
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
coat
as
was
yet
visible
,
bore
testimony
to
the
accuracy
of
this
statement
;
and
as
the
fears
of
the
spectators
were
still
further
relieved
by
the
fat
boy
's
suddenly
recollecting
that
the
water
was
nowhere
more
than
five
feet
deep
,
prodigies
of
valour
were
performed
to
get
him
out
.
<EOS>
After
a
vast
quantity
of
splashing
,
and
cracking
,
and
struggling
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
at
length
fairly
extricated
from
his
unpleasant
position
,
and
once
more
stood
on
dry
land
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
he
'll
catch
his
death
of
cold
,
"
said
Emily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
old
thing
!
"
said
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
wrap
this
shawl
round
you
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
's
the
best
thing
you
can
do
,
"
said
Wardle
;
"
<EOS>
and
when
you
've
got
it
on
,
run
home
as
fast
as
your
legs
can
carry
you
,
and
jump
into
bed
directly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
dozen
shawls
were
offered
on
the
instant
.
 
<EOS>
Three
or
four
of
the
thickest
having
been
selected
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
wrapped
up
,
and
started
off
,
under
the

Mr
Weller
;
presenting
the
singular
phenomenon
of
an
elderly
gentleman
,
dripping
wet
,
and
without

hat
,
with
his

bound

,
skimming

the
ground
,
without
any
clearly
-

purpose
,
at
the
rate
of
six
good
English
miles
an
hour
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pickwick
cared
not
for
appearances
in
such
an
extreme
case
,
and
urged
on
by
Sam
Weller
,
he
kept
at
the
very
top
of
his
speed
until
he
reached
the
door
of
Manor
Farm
,
where
Mr
Tupman
had
arrived
some
five
minutes
before
,
and
had
frightened
the
old
lady
into
palpitations
of
the
heart
by
impressing
her
with
the
unalterable
conviction
that
the
kitchen
chimney
was
on
fire
---
a
calamity
which
always
presented
itself
in
glowing
colours
to
the
old
lady
's
mind
,
when
anybody
about
her
evinced
the
smallest

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
paused
not
an
instant
until
he
was
snug
in
bed
.
<EOS>
Sam
Weller
lighted
a
blazing
fire
in
the
room
,
and
took
up
his
dinner
;
a

of
punch
was
carried
up

,
and
a
grand
carouse
held
in

of
his

.
 
<EOS>
Old
Wardle
would
not
hear
of
his
rising
,
so
they
made
the
bed
the
chair
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
presided
.
 
<EOS>
A
second
and
a
third
bowl
were
ordered
in
;
and
when
Mr
Pickwick
awoke
next
morning
,
there
was
not
a

of
rheumatism
about

;
which
proves
,
as
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
very
justly
observed
,
that
there
is
nothing
like
hot
punch
in
such
cases
;
and
that
if
ever

punch
did
fail
to
act
as
a
preventive
,
it
was
merely
because
the
patient
fell
into
the
vulgar

of
not
taking
enough
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
jovial
party
broke
up
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Breakings
-
up
are
capital
things
in
our
school
-
days
,
but
in
after
life
they
are
painful
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Death
,
self
-
interest
,
and
fortune
's
changes
,
are
every
day
breaking
up
many
a
happy
group
,
and
scattering
them
far
and

;
and
the
boys
and
girls
never

again
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
not

;

;

;

that

,

been

---

Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
Which
is
all
about
the
law
,
and
Sundry
Great
Authorities
learned
therein
 
Scattered
about
,
in
various
holes
and
corners
of
the
Temple
,
are
certain
dark
and
dirty
chambers
,
in
and
out
of
which
,
all
the
morning
in
vacation
,
and
half
the
evening
too
in
term
time
,
there
may
be
seen
constantly
hurrying
with
bundles
of
papers
under
their
arms
,
and
protruding
from
their
pockets
,
an
almost
uninterrupted
succession
of
lawyers
"
clerks
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
several
grades
of
lawyers
"
clerks
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
articled
clerk
,
who
has
paid
a
premium
,
and
is
an
attorney
in
perspective
,
who
runs
a
tailor
's
bill
,
receives
invitations
to
parties
,
knows
a
family
in
Gower
Street
,
and
another
in
Tavistock
Square
;
who
goes
out
of
town
every
long
vacation
to
see
his
father
,
who
keeps
live
horses
innumerable
;
and
who
is
,
in
short
,
the
very
aristocrat
of
clerks
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
salaried
clerk
---
out
of
door
,
or
in
door
,
as
the
case
may
be
---
who
devotes
the
major
part
of
his
thirty
shillings
a
week
to
his
Personal
pleasure
and
adornments
,
repairs
half
-
price
to
the
Adelphi
Theatre
at
least
three
times
a
week
,
dissipates
majestically
at
the
cider
cellars
afterwards
,
and
is
a
dirty
caricature
of
the
fashion
which
expired
six
months
ago
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
middle
-
aged
copying
clerk
,
with
a
large
family
,
who
is
always
shabby
,
and
often
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
are
the
office
lads
in
their
first
surtouts
,
who
feel
a
befitting
contempt
for
boys
at
day
-
schools
,
club
as
they
go
home
at
night
,
for
saveloys
and
porter
,
and
think
there
's
nothing
like
"
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
are
varieties
of
the
genus
,
too
numerous
to
recapitulate
,
but
however
numerous
they
may
be
,
they
are
all
to
be
seen
,
at
certain
regulated
business
hours
,
hurrying
to
and
from
the
places
we
have
just
mentioned
.
   
<EOS>
These
sequestered
nooks
are
the
public
offices
of
the
legal
profession
,
where
writs
are
issued
,
judgments
signed
,
declarations
filed
,
and
numerous
other
ingenious
machines
put
in
motion
for
the
torture
and
torment
of
His
Majesty
's
liege
subjects
,
and
the
comfort
and
emolument
of
the
practitioners
of
the
law
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
,
for
the
most
part
,
low
-
roofed
,
mouldy
rooms
,
where
innumerable
rolls
of
parchment
,
which
have
been
perspiring
in
secret
for
the
last
century
,
send
forth
an
agreeable
odour
,
which
is
mingled
by
day
with
the
scent
of
the
dry
-
rot
,
and
by
night
with
the
various
exhalations
which
arise
from
damp
cloaks
,
festering
umbrellas
,
and
the
coarsest
tallow
candles
.
   
<EOS>
About
half
-
past
seven
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
some
ten
days
or
a
fortnight
after
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
returned
to
London
,
there
hurried
into
one

these
offices
,
an
individual
in
a
brown
coat

brass

,
whose
long

was
<EOS>
scrupulously
twisted
round
the
rim
of
his
napless
hat
,
and
<EOS>
whose
soiled

were
so

over
his
Blucher

,
that
his

threatened
every

to
start

.
<EOS>
He
produced
from

coat

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
He
then

paper
,

,

of

strip

with
blanks
for

name
;
and
having

,
put
all

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

brown

,

,
was
no

our

Mr
Jackson

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

:

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
had
witnessed
this
process
in

,
when
Jackson
,

,

---
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
ai

when
I
say
your
name
's
Tupman
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

;
but
,

<EOS>
"

,

,

"
   
<EOS>
"

's

Winkle
,

?
"
said

.
<EOS>
Mr

out

in
the

;
and
both

were
forthwith

with

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

,

ai

.
<EOS>

Samuel
Weller
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Send
my

"

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
considerably

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

"
<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>

"
Not

'
,
ca

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

ca

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

seemed

's

;

,

,

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
slept

that

;
his

had

on

's

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

?
"

<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The
relation
of
this
affecting
incident
of
private
life
brought
master
and
man
to
Mr
Perker
's
chambers
.
 
<EOS>
Lowten
,
holding
the
door
half
open
,
was
in
conversation
with
a
rustily
-
clad
,
miserable
-
looking
man
,
in
boots
without
toes
and
gloves
without
fingers
.
<EOS>
There
were
traces
of
privation
and
suffering
---
almost
of
despair
 
---
in
his
lank
and
care
-
worn
countenance
;
he
felt
his
poverty
,
for
he
shrank
to
the
dark
side
of
the
staircase
as
Mr
Pickwick
approached
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
unfortunate
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
Lowten
,
scribbling
his
name
on
the

with
his

,
and
rubbing

again
with
the

.

.

Snubbin
.

<EOS>

's

,

,

had

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbins
was
a
lantern
-
faced
,
sallow
-
complexioned
man
,
of
about
five
-
and
-
forty
,
or
---
as

say
---
he
might

fifty
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
that
dull
-
looking
,
boiled
eye
which
is
often
to
be
seen
in
the
heads
of
people
who
have
applied
themselves
during
many
years
to
a
weary
and
laborious
course
of
study
;
and
which
would
have
been
sufficient
,
without
the
additional
eyeglass
which
dangled
from
a
broad
black
riband
round
his
neck
,
to
warn
a
stranger
that
he
was
very
near
-
sighted
.
 
<EOS>
His
hair
was
thin
and
weak
,
which
was
partly
attributable
to
his
having
never
devoted
much
time
to
its
arrangement
,
and
partly
to
his
having
worn
for
five
-
and
-
twenty
years
<EOS>
the
forensic
wig
which
hung
on
a
block
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
marks
of
hairpowder
on
his
coat
-
collar
,
and
the
ill
-
washed
and
worse
tied
white
neckerchief
round
his
throat
,
showed
that
he
had
not
found
leisure
since
he
left
the
court
to
make
any
alteration
in
his
dress
;
while
the
slovenly
style
of
the
remainder
of
his
costume
warranted
the
inference
that
his
personal
appearance
would
not
have
been
very
much
improved
if
he
had
.
 
<EOS>
Books
of
practice
,
heaps
of
papers
,
and
opened
letters
,
were
scattered
over
the
table
,
without
any
attempt
at
order
or
arrangement
;
the
furniture
of
the
room
was
old
and
rickety
;
the
doors
of
the
book
-
case
were
rotting
in
their
hinges
;
the
dust
flew
out
from
the
carpet
in
little
clouds
at
every
step
;
the
blinds
were
yellow
with
age
and
dirt
;
the
state
of
everything
in
the
room
showed
,
with
a
clearness
not
to
be
mistaken
,
that
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
was
far
too
much
occupied
with
his
professional
pursuits
to
take
any
great
heed
or
regard
of
his
personal
comforts
.
   
<EOS>
The
Serjeant
was
writing
when
his
clients
entered
;
he
bowed
abstractedly
when
Mr
Pickwick
was
introduced
by
his
solicitor
;
and
then
,
motioning
them
to
a
seat
,
put
his
pen
carefully
in
the
inkstand
,
nursed
his
left
leg
,
and
waited
to
be
spoken
to
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
is
the
defendant
in
Bardell
and
Pickwick
,
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
"
said
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
retained
in
that
,
am
I
?
"
said
the
Serjeant
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
The
Serjeant
nodded
his
head
,
and
waited
for
something
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
anxious
to
call
upon
you
,
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
"
said
Perker
,
"
to
state
to
you
,
before
you
entered
upon
the
case
,
that
he
denies
there
being
any
ground
or
pretence
<EOS>
whatever
for
the
action
against
him
;
and
that
unless
he
came
into
court
with
clean
hands
,
and
without
the
most
conscientious
conviction
that
he
was
right
in
resisting
the
plaintiff
's
demand
,
he
would
not
be
there
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
state
your
views
correctly
;
do
I
not
,
my
dear
Sir
?
"
said
the
little
man
,
turning
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
so
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
unfolded
his
glasses
,
raised
them
to
his
eyes
;
and
,
after
looking
at
Mr
Pickwick
for
a
few
seconds
with
great
curiosity
,
turned
to
Mr
Perker
,
and
said
,
smiling
slightly
as
he
spoke
---
"
<EOS>
Has
Mr
Pickwick
a
strong
case
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
attorney
shrugged
his
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
propose
calling
witnesses
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
smile
on
the
Serjeant
's
countenance
became
more
defined
;
he
rocked
his
leg
with
increased
violence
;
and
,
throwing
himself
back
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
coughed
dubiously
.
   
<EOS>
These
tokens
of
the
Serjeant
's
presentiments
on
the
subject
,
slight
as
they
were
,
were
not
lost
on
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
He
settled
the
spectacles
,
through
which
he
had
attentively
regarded
such
demonstrations
of
the
barrister
's
feelings
as
he
had
permitted
himself
to
exhibit
,
more
firmly
on
his
nose
;
and
said
with
great
energy
,
and
in
utter
disregard
of
all
Mr
Perker
's
admonitory
winkings
and
frownings
---
   
<EOS>
"
My
wishing
to
wait
upon
you
,
for
such
a
purpose
as
this
,
Sir
,
appears
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
to
a
gentleman
who
sees
so
much
of
these
matters
as
you
must
necessarily
do
,
a
very
extraordinary
circumstance
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Serjeant
tried
to
look
gravely
at
the
fire
,
but
the
smile
came
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
of
your
profession
,
Sir
,
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
see
the
worst
side
of
human
nature
.
 
<EOS>
All
its
disputes
,
all
its
ill
-
will
and
bad
blood
,
rise
up
before
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
from
your
experience
of
juries
(
I
mean
no
disparagement
to
you
,
or
them
)
<EOS>
how
much
depends
upon
effect
;
and
you
are
apt
to
attribute
to
others
,
a
desire
to
use
,
for
purposes
of
deception
and
Self
-
interest
,
the
very
instruments
which
you
,
in
pure
honesty
and
honour
of
purpose
,
and
with
a
laudable
desire
to
do
your
utmost
for
your
client
,
know
the
temper
and
worth
of
<EOS>
so
well
,
from
constantly
employing
them
yourselves
.
 
<EOS>
I
really
believe
that
to
this
circumstance
may
be
attributed
the
vulgar
but
very
general
notion
of
your
being
,
as
a
body
,
suspicious
,
distrustful
,
and
over
-

.
<EOS>
Conscious
as
I
am
,
sir
,
of
the
disadvantage
of
making
such
a
declaration
to
you
,
under
such
circumstances
,
I
have
come
here
,
because
I
wish
you
distinctly
to
understand
,
as
my
friend
Mr
Perker
has
said
,
that
I
am
innocent
of
the
falsehood
laid
to
my
charge
;
and
although
I
am
very
well

of
the
inestimable
value
of
your

,
Sir
,
I
must

,
that
unless

this
,
I
would
rather
be
deprived
of
the
aid
of
your
talents
than
have
the
advantage
of
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Long
before
the
close
of
this
address
,
which
we
are
bound
to
say
was
of
a
very
prosy
character
for
Mr
Pickwick
,
the
Serjeant
had
relapsed
into
a
state
of

.
 
<EOS>
After
some
minutes
,
however
,
during
which
he
had
reassumed
his

,
he
appeared
to
be
again

of
the
presence
of
his

;
raising
his

from
the
paper
,
he
said
,
rather

---
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
with
me
in
this

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Phunky
,
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Phunky
---
Phunky
,
"
said

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he

young

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

only

.
 
<EOS>
Let

see
<EOS>
---
he

Bar
eight

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr

,

---

---
"
"

's
---

,

.
 
<EOS>
(
Holborn

,

,

.
)
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Phunky
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Mallard
departed
to
execute
his
commission
;
and
Serjeant
Snubbin
relapsed
into
abstraction
until
Mr
Phunky
himself
was
introduced
.
   
<EOS>
Although
an
infant
barrister
,
he
was
a
full
-
grown
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
very
nervous
manner
,
and
a
painful
hesitation
in
his
speech
;
it
did
not
appear
to
be
a
natural
defect
,
but
seemed
rather
the
result
of
timidity
,
arising
from
the
consciousness
of
being
"
kept
down
"
by
want
of
means
,
or
interest
,
or
connection
,
or
impudence
,
as
the
case
might
be
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
overawed
by
the
Serjeant
,
and
profoundly
courteous
to
the
attorney
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
before
,
Mr
Phunky
,
"
said
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
with
haughty
condescension
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Phunky
bowed
.
 
<EOS>
He
HAD
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
the
Serjeant
,
and
of
envying
him
too
,
with
all
a
poor
man
's
envy
,
for
eight
years
and
a
quarter
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
with
me
in
this
case
,
I
understand
?
"
said
the
Serjeant
.
   
<EOS>
If
Mr
Phunky
had
been
a
rich
man
,
he
would
have
instantly
sent
for
his
clerk
to
remind
him
;
if
he
had
been
a
wise
one
,
he
would
have
applied
his
forefinger
to
his
forehead
,
and
endeavoured
to
recollect
,
whether
,
in
the
multiplicity
of
his
engagements
,
he
had
undertaken
this
one
or
not
;
but
as
he
was
neither
rich
nor
wise
(
in
this
sense
,
at
all
events
)
<EOS>
he
turned
red
,
and
bowed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
read
the
papers
,
Mr
Phunky
?
"
inquired
the
Serjeant
.
   
<EOS>
Here
again
,
Mr
Phunky
should
have
professed
to
have
forgotten
all
about
the
merits
of
the
case
;
but
as
he
had
read
such
papers
as
had
been
laid
before
him
in
the
course
of
the
action
,
and
had
thought
of
nothing
else
,
waking
or
sleeping
,
throughout
the
two
months
during
which
he
had
been
retained
as
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
's
junior
,
he
turned
a
deeper
red
and
bowed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
the
Serjeant
,
waving
his
pen
in
the
direction
in
which
that
gentleman
was
standing
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Phunky
bowed
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
reverence
which
a
first
client
must
ever
awaken
;
and
again
inclined
his
head
towards
his
leader
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
will
take
Mr
Pickwick
away
,
"
said
the
Serjeant
,
"
and
---
<EOS>
and
---
and
---
hear
anything
Mr
Pickwick
may
wish
to
communicate
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
a
consultation
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
hint
that
he
had
been
interrupted
quite
long
enough
,
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
who
had
been
gradually
growing
more
and
more
abstracted
,
applied
his
glass
to
his
eyes
for
an
instant
,
bowed
slightly
round
,
and
was
once
more
deeply
immersed
in
the
case
before
him
,
which
arose
out
of
an
interminable
lawsuit
,
originating
in
the
act
of
an
individual
,
deceased
a
century
or
so
ago
,
who
had
stopped
up
a
pathway
leading
from
some
place
which
nobody
ever
came
from
,
to
some
other
place
which
nobody
ever
went
to
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Phunky
would
not
hear
of
passing
through
any
door
until
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
solicitor
had
passed
through
before
him
,
so
it
was
some
time
before
they
got
into
the
Square
;
and
when
they
did
reach
it
,
they
walked
up
and
down
,
and
held
a
long
conference
,
<EOS>
the
result
of
which
was
,
that
it
was
a
very
difficult
matter
to
say
how
the
verdict
would
go
;
that
nobody
could
presume
to
calculate
on
the
issue
of
an
action
;
that
it
was
very
lucky
they
had
prevented
the
other
party
from
getting
Serjeant
Snubbin
;
and
other
topics
of
doubt
and
consolation
,
common
in
such
a
position
of
affairs
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
was
then
roused
by
his
master
from
a
sweet
sleep
of
an
hour
's
duration
;
and
,
bidding
adieu
to
Lowten
,
they
returned
to
the
city
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
Describes
,
far
more
fully
than
the
Court
Newsman
ever
did
,
a
Bachelor
's
party
,
given
by
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
at
his
lodgings
in
the
Borough
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
repose
about
Lant
Street
,
in
the
Borough
,
which
sheds
a
gentle
melancholy
upon
the
soul
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
always
a
good
many
houses
to
let
in
the
street
:
it
is
a
by
-
street
too
,
and
its
dulness
is
soothing
.
 
<EOS>
A
house
in
Lant
Street
would
not
come
within
the
denomination
of
a
first
-
rate
residence
,
in
the
strict
acceptation
of
the
term
;
but
it
is
a
most
desirable
spot
nevertheless
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
man
wished
to
abstract
himself
from
the
world
---
to
remove
himself
from
within
the
reach
of
temptation
---
to
place
himself
beyond
the
possibility
of
any
inducement
to
look
out
of
the
window
---
we
should
recommend
him
by
all
means
go
to
Lant
Street
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
happy
retreat
are
colonised
a
few
clear
-
starchers
,
a
sprinkling
of
journeymen
bookbinders
,
one
or
two
prison
agents
for
the
Insolvent
Court
,
several
small
housekeepers
who
are
employed
in
the
Docks
,
a
handful
of
mantua
-
makers
,
and
a
seasoning
of
jobbing
tailors
.
 
<EOS>
The
majority
of
the
inhabitants
either
direct
their
energies
to
the
letting
of
furnished
apartments
,
or
devote
themselves
to
the
healthful
and
invigorating
pursuit
of
mangling
.
 
<EOS>
The
chief
features
in
the
still
life
of
the
street
are
green
shutters
,
lodging
-
bills
,
brass
door
-
plates
,
and
bell
-
handles
;
the
principal
specimens
of
animated
nature
,
the
pot
-
boy
,
the
muffin
youth
,
and
the
baked
-
potato
man
.
 
<EOS>
The
population
is
migratory
,
usually
disappearing
on
the
verge
of
quarter
-
day
,
and
generally
by
night
.
 
<EOS>
His
Majesty
's
revenues
are
seldom
collected
in
this
happy
valley
;
the
rents
are
dubious
;
and
the
water
communication
is
very
frequently
cut
off
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
embellished
one
side
of
the
fire
,
in
his
first
-
floor
front
,
early
on
the
evening
for
which
he
had
invited
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
Mr
Ben
Allen
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
The
preparations
for
the
reception
of
visitors
appeared
to
be
completed
.
 
<EOS>
The
umbrellas
in
the
passage
had
been
heaped
into
the
little
corner
outside
the
back
-
parlour
door
;
the
bonnet
and
shawl
of
the
landlady
's
servant
had
been
removed
from
the
bannisters
;
there
were
not
more
than
two
pairs
of
pattens
on
the
street
-
door
mat
;
and
a
kitchen
candle
,
with
a
very
long
snuff
,
burned
cheerfully
on
the
ledge
of
the
staircase
window
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
had
himself
purchased
the
spirits
at
a
wine
vaults
in
High
Street
,
and
had
returned
home
preceding
the
bearer
thereof
,
to
preclude
the
possibility
of
their
delivery
at
the
wrong
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
punch
was
ready
-
made
in
a
red
pan
in
the
bedroom
;
a
little
table
,
covered
with
a
green
baize
cloth
,
had
been
borrowed
from
the
parlour
,
to
play
at
cards
on
;
and
the
glasses
of
the
establishment
,
together
with
those
which
had
been
borrowed
for
the
occasion
from
the
public
-
house
,
were
all
drawn
up
in
a
tray
,
which
was
deposited
on
the
landing
outside
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
highly
satisfactory
nature
of
all
these
arrangements
,
there
was
a
cloud
on
the
countenance
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
as
he
sat
by
the
fireside
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sympathising

,
too
,
in

features
of
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
as

gazed

on
the
coals
,
and
a
tone

in
his
voice
,
as
he
said
,
after
a
long

---
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

.

"
   
<EOS>
"
That

her
malevolence

---

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

:
<EOS>

It

.

<EOS>

;
"
Missis
Raddle
raked
out
the
kitchen
fire
<EOS>
afore
<EOS>
she
went
to
bed
,
and
locked
up
the
kittle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
never
mind
;
never
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
disturb
yourself
about
such

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
observing
the
conflict
of
Bob
Sawyer
's
passions
,
as
depicted
in
his
countenance
,
"
cold
water
will
do
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
admirably
,
"
said
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
landlady
is
subject
to
some
slight

of
mental

,
"
remarked
Bob
Sawyer
,
with
a

;
"
I
fear
I
must
give
her
warning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
do
n't
,
"
said
Ben
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
must
,
"
said
Bob
,
with
heroic
firmness
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
pay
her
what
I
owe
her
,
and
give
her
warning
to
-
morrow
morning
.
"
 
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
how
devoutly
he
wished
he
could
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
's
heart
-
sickening
attempts
to
rally
under
this
last
blow
,
communicated
a
dispiriting
influence
to
the
company
,
the
greater
part
of
whom
,
with
the
view
of
raising
their
spirits
,
attached
themselves
with
extra
cordiality
to
the
cold
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
the
first
perceptible
effects
of
which
were
displayed
in
a
renewal
of
hostilities
between
the
scorbutic
youth
and
the
gentleman
in
the
shirt
.
 
<EOS>
The
belligerents
vented
their
feelings
of
mutual
contempt
,
for
some
time
,
in
a
variety
of
frownings
and
snortings
,
until
at
last
the
scorbutic
youth
felt
it
necessary
to
come
to
a
more
explicit
understanding
on
the
matter
;
when
the
following
clear
understanding
took
place
.
<EOS>
"
Sawyer
,
"
said
the
scorbutic
youth
,
in
a
loud
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Noddy
,
"
replied
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should

,
Sawyer
,
"
said

Noddy
,
"
to

at
any

,

,
Sawyer
---
very
;
but
I

Mr
Gunter

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

,
"

,

o
'

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

FEEL

<EOS>

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
At

the

of

guests
interposed
,
and
remonstrated
with
both

on
the

of

;
on
which
Mr
Noddy
begged
to
state
that
his
father
was
quite
as

Mr
Gunter
's
father
;
to
which
Mr
Gunter
replied
that
his
father
was
to
the
full
as
respectable
as
Mr
Noddy
's
father
,
and
that
his
father
's
son
was
as
good
a
man
as
Mr
Noddy
,
any
day
in
the
week
.
 
<EOS>
As
this
announcement
seemed
the
prelude
to
a
recommencement
of
the
dispute
,
there
was
another
interference
on
the
part
of
the
company
;
and
a
vast
quantity
of
talking
and
clamouring
ensued
,
in
the
course
of
which
Mr
Noddy
gradually
allowed
his
feelings
to
overpower
him
,
and
professed
that
he
had
ever
entertained
a
devoted
personal
attachment
towards
Mr
Gunter
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
Mr
Gunter
replied
that
,
upon
the
whole
,
he
rather
preferred
Mr
Noddy
to
his
own
brother
;
on
hearing
which
admission
,
Mr
Noddy
magnanimously
rose
from
his
seat
,
and
proffered
his
hand
to
Mr
Gunter
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gunter
grasped
it
with
affecting
fervour
;
and
everybody
said
that
the
whole
dispute
had
been
conducted
in
a
manner
which
was
highly
honourable
to
both

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Jack
Hopkins
,
"
just
to
set

going
again
,
Bob
,
I
do
n't
mind
singing
a
song
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Hopkins
,
incited
thereto
by

,

"
The
King
,
God

,
"
which
he

as

,
to

,
compounded
of
the
"
Bay
of

,
"

"
A
Frog
he
would
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
chorus
was
the

of
the
song
;
and
,
as
each

sang
it
to
the
tune
he
knew
best
,
the
effect
was
very
striking
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
It
was

the
end

to
the
first

,
that
Mr
Pickwick
held

,

,

---
   
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
I
beg

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought

from

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
A
profound

;
and
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
hear

now
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Have

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

was
no

than
all

on
the
subject
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Sawyer
!
<EOS>
Mr
Sawyer
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mrs
Raddle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

this
,
Mr
Sawyer
?
"

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
it
enough
to

's

,

money
lent
out

pocket

,

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
---
Turn

.

<EOS>
"
You

,
"

Raddle
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ashamed

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ugh
,

.
<EOS>
"
DO

<EOS>

,
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Just
as

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
prim
man
was

had

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Hardly

,

?
"
   
<EOS>

Not

,
"

;
"
let

,
Bob
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall

,

?
"
<EOS>

,
"

,

?
 
<EOS>
You

,
Bob
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
Hopkins
,
"

,
"

is

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Sawyer
,
"

,
"
are

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
're

,
Mrs
Raddle
,
"
said

;
"
they

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
!
"
said
Mrs
Raddle
,
thrusting
her

over
the
banisters
just
as
Mr
Pickwick
,
followed

Mr

,

from

-

.
 
<EOS>
"
Going
!
<EOS>
what
did
they
ever
come
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
ma'am
,
"
remonstrated
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
along
with
you
,
old
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Mrs
Raddle
,
hastily
withdrawing
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Old
enough
to
be
his
grandfather
,
you
willin
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
worse
than
any
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
found
it
in
vain
to
protest
his
innocence
,
so
hurried
downstairs
into
the
street
,
whither
he
was
closely
followed
by
Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
.
<EOS>
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
who
was
dismally
depressed
with
spirits
and
agitation
,
accompanied
them
as
far
as
London
Bridge
,
and
in
the
course
of
the
walk
confided
to
Mr
Winkle
,
as
an
especially
eligible
person
to
intrust
the
secret
to
,
that
he
was
resolved
to
cut
the
throat
of
any
gentleman
,
except
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
who
should
aspire
to
the
affections
of
his
sister
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
Having
expressed
his
determination
to
perform
this
painful
duty
of
a
brother
with
proper
firmness
,
he
burst
into
tears
,
knocked
his
hat
over
his
eyes
,
and
,
making
the
best
of
his
way
back
,
knocked
double
knocks
at
the
door
of
the
Borough
Market
office
,
and
took
short
naps
on
the
steps
alternately
,
until
daybreak
,
under
the
firm
impression
that
he
lived
there
,
and
had
forgotten
the
key
.
   
<EOS>
The
visitors
having
all
departed
,
in
compliance
with
the
rather
pressing
request
of
Mrs
Raddle
,
the
luckless
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
was
left
alone
,
to
meditate
on
the
probable
events
of
to
-
morrow
,
and
the
pleasures
of
the
evening
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
the
elder
delivers
some
critical
sentiments
respecting
literary
composition
;
and
,
assisted
by
his
son
Samuel
,
pays
a
small
instalment
of
retaliation
to
the
account
of
the
reverend
gentleman
with
the
red
nose
 
<EOS>
The
morning
of
the
thirteenth
of
February
,
which
the
readers
of
this
authentic
narrative
know
,
as
well
as
we
do
,
to
have
been
the
day
immediately
preceding
that
which
was
appointed
for
the
trial
of
Mrs
Bardell
's
action
,
was
a
busy
time
for
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
who
was
perpetually
engaged
in
travelling
from
the
George
and
Vulture
to
Mr
Perker
's
chambers
and
back
again
,
from
and
between
the
hours
of
nine
o'clock
in
the
morning
and
two
in
the
afternoon
,
both
inclusive
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
there
was
anything
whatever
to
be
done
,
for
the
consultation
had
taken
place
,
and
the
course
of
proceeding
to
be
adopted
,
had
been
finally
determined
on
;
but
Mr
Pickwick
being
in
a
most
extreme
state
of
excitement
,
persevered
in
constantly
sending
small
notes
to
his
attorney
,
merely
containing
the
inquiry
,
"
Dear
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
Is
all
going
on
well
?
"
<EOS>
to
which
Mr
Perker
invariably
forwarded
the
reply
,
"
Dear
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
As
well
as
possible
"
;
the
fact
being
,
as
we
have
already
hinted
,
that
there
was
nothing
whatever
to
go
on
,
<EOS>
either
well
or
ill
,
until
the
sitting
of
the
court
on
the
following
morning
.
   
<EOS>
But
people
who
go
voluntarily
to
law
,
or
are
taken
forcibly
there
,
for
the
first
time
,
may
be
allowed
to
labour
under
some
temporary
irritation
and
anxiety
;
and
Sam
,
with
a
due
allowance
for
the
frailties
of
human
nature
,
obeyed
all
his
master
's
behests
with
that
imperturbable
good
-
humour
and
unruffable
composure
which
formed
one
of
his
most
striking
and
amiable
characteristics
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
had
solaced
himself
with
a
most
agreeable
little
dinner
,
and
was
waiting
at
the
bar
for
the
glass
of
warm
mixture
in
which
Mr
Pickwick
had
requested
him
to
drown
the
fatigues
of
his
morning
's

,
when
a

of
about

,

,

to

in

of
an

,
entered
the

of
the
George
and
Vulture
,
and
looked
first
up

stairs
,
and
then
along

passage
,
and
then
into
the
bar
,
as

of

a

;
whereupon
the

,
conceiving

not

that
the
said

might
be
directed

the
tea

table

of
the

,
accosted

boy
with
---
   
"
<EOS>
Now
,

,
what
do

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there

here
,
named
Sam
?
"
inquired

,
in
a
loud

of
treble

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
t'other
name
?
"
said
Sam
Weller
,

round
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
should
I
know
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
briskly

young

below

.
<EOS>
"
You
're

sharp

,
you

,
"
said

Weller
;
"
<EOS>
only

would

wery

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

young

,
awakening

as

with

of
a

's

,
delivered
in

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
having
obtained
leave
of

from
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
,
in
his
then
state
of

,

at

,
set
forth
,
long
before
the

,
and
having

,

,
where
he
paused
and

,

,
the
numerous
cads
and
drivers
of
short

who
assemble
near
that
famous
place
of
resort
,
to
the
great
terror
and
confusion
of
the
old

of
these

.
 
<EOS>
Having
loitered
here
,
for
half
an
hour
or
so
,
Mr
Weller
turned
,
and
began
wending
his
way
towards
Leadenhall
Market
,
through
a
variety
of
by
-

and

.
 
<EOS>
As
he
was
sauntering
away
his
spare
time
,
and
stopped
to
look
at
almost
every
object
that
met
his
gaze
,
it
is
by
no
means
surprising
that
Mr
Weller
should
have
paused
before
a
small
stationer
's
and
print
-
seller
's
window
;
but
without
further
explanation
it
does
appear
surprising
that
his
eyes
should
have
no
sooner

on
certain
pictures
which
were
exposed
for
sale
therein
,
than
he
gave
a
sudden
start
,
smote
his
right
leg
with
great
vehemence
,
and
exclaimed
,
with
energy
,
"
if
it
had
n't
been
for
this
,
I
should
ha
'
forgot
all
about
it
,
till
it
was
too
late
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
particular
picture
on
which
Sam
Weller
's
eyes
were
fixed
,
as
he
said
this
,
was
a
highly

representation
of
a
couple
of
human
hearts
skewered
together
with
an
arrow
,
cooking
before
a
cheerful
fire
,
while
a

in
modern
attire
,
the
gentleman
being
clad
in
a
blue
coat
and
white

,

in

deep
red

of
the

,
were
approaching
the
meal
with
hungry

,
up
a
serpentine

path
leading
thereunto
.
 
<EOS>
A
decidedly
indelicate
young
gentleman
,
in
a
pair

wings
and
nothing
else
,
was
depicted
as
superintending
the

;
a

of
the
spire
of
the
church
in
Langham
Place
,
London
,
appeared
in
the
distance
;
and
the
whole
formed
a
"
valentine
,
"
of
which
,
as
a
written
inscription
in
the
window
testified
,
there
was
a
large

within
,
which
the
shopkeeper
pledged
himself
to
dispose
of
,
to
his
countrymen
generally
,
at
the
reduced
rate
of
one
-
and
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
ha
'
forgot
it
;
I
should
certainly
ha
'
forgot
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
Sam
;
<EOS>
so
saying
,
he
at
once
stepped
into
the
stationer
's
shop
,
and
requested
to
be
served
with
a
sheet
of
the
best

-
edged
letter
-
paper
,
and
a
hard
-
nibbed
pen
which
could
be
warranted
not
to
splutter
.
 
<EOS>
These
articles
having
been
promptly
supplied
,
he
walked
on
direct
towards
Leadenhall
Market
at
a
good
round
pace
,
very
different
from
his
recent
lingering
one
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
round
him
,
he
there
beheld
a
signboard
on
which
the
painter
's
art
had
delineated
something
remotely
resembling
a
cerulean
elephant
with
an

in

.
 
<EOS>
Rightly
conjecturing
that
this
was
the
Blue
Boar
himself
,
he
stepped
into
the
house
,
and
inquired
concerning
his
parent
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
be
here
this
three
-

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wery
good
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let

nine
-

o
'

,

inkstand
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then

to

,

,
Sam

,
squared

,

to
write
.
   
<EOS>
To
ladies
and
gentlemen
who
are
not
in
the
habit
of
devoting
themselves
practically
to
the
science
of
penmanship
,
writing
a
letter
is
no
very
easy
task
;
it
being
always
considered
necessary
in
such
cases
for
the
writer
to
recline
his
head
on

left
arm
,
so
as

,

,

form
with

imaginary

to
correspond
.
 
<EOS>
These
motions
,
although
unquestionably
of
the
greatest
assistance
to
original
composition
,
retard
in
some
degree
the

;
and
Sam
had
unconsciously

a

,

,

the
old

,
when

Vell

<EOS>

<EOS>

a

<EOS>
He

;
and

,

"
fire

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sam

the
ink
to

,

---
   
"
<EOS>
"
Lovely
---
"
"
   
"
Stop
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
A

round
him
very
cautiously
,
"
you
and
I
'll
go
,
punctiwal
to
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
deputy
-
shepherd
wo
n't
,
Sammy
;
the
deputy
-
shepherd
wo
n't
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Weller
was
seized
with
a

of
chuckles
,
which
gradually
terminated
in
as
near
an

to
a

as
an

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
never
see
sitch
an
old

in
all

days
,
"

,
rubbing

old

's

,
hard

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
a
-
laughin
'
at
,
corpilence
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
Sammy
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
looking
round

with
increased

,
and
speaking
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
friends
o
'
mine
,
as
works
the
Oxford

,
and
is
up
to
all
kinds
o
'
games
,
has

in
tow
,
Sammy
;
and
ven
he

Ebenezer

<EOS>
(
vich

:
for

,

<EOS>
,

wos
at

Markis
o
'
Granby
,
Dorkin
'
,

that

not

neither
.
"
 
<EOS>
And

,
Mr
Weller
once

,

into

,

.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
could
have
been
more
in

with
Sam
Weller
's

than
the
projected
exposure
of
the
real

and

of
the
red
-
nosed
man
;
and
it
being
very
near
the
appointed

of

,
the
father
and

took
their
way
at
once
to
Brick
Lane
<EOS>
,
Sam
not
forgetting
to
drop
his
letter
into
a
general

office
as

along
.
   
<EOS>
The
monthly
meetings
of
the
Brick
Lane
Branch
of
the
United
Grand
Junction
Ebenezer
Temperance
Association
were
held
in
a
large
room
,
pleasantly
and
airily
situated
at
the
top
of
a
safe
and
commodious
ladder
.
 
<EOS>
The
president
was
the
straight
-
walking
Mr
Anthony
Humm
,
a
converted
fireman
,
now
a
schoolmaster
,
and
occasionally
an
itinerant
preacher
;
and
the
secretary
was
Mr
Jonas
Mudge
,
chandler
's
shopkeeper
,
an
enthusiastic
and
disinterested
vessel
,
who
sold
tea
to
the
members
.
 
<EOS>
Previous
to
the
commencement
of
business
,
the
ladies
sat
upon
forms
,
and
drank
tea
,
till
such
time
as
they
considered
it
expedient
to
leave
off
;
and
a
large
wooden
money
-
box
was
conspicuously
placed
upon
the
green
baize
cloth
of
the
business
-
table
,
behind
which
the
secretary
stood
,
and
acknowledged
,
with
a
gracious
smile
,
every
addition
to
the
rich
vein
of
copper
which
lay
concealed
within
.
   
<EOS>
On
this
particular
occasion
the
women
drank
tea
to
a
most
alarming
extent
;
greatly
to
the

of
Mr
Weller
,
senior
,
who
,
utterly
regardless
of
all
Sam
's

,
stared
about

in
every

with
the
most
undisguised

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sammy
,
"

Weller
,
"
if
some
o
'
<EOS>
these
here

,

,

wot

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
"
Be

,
ca

?
"

<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>

'

"
   
<EOS>

"
it
ai

"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
young
"
ooman
on

form
but

,
as
has

and

;
and
she
's
a
-
swellin
'

my

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There

,

,

<EOS>
The

,

was

,

,

"
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
The

at

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

;

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

in
the

,
and
Mr
Humm
rose
and
said
---
<EOS>
That
,

his
Brick

Branch
brothers

then

,

Brick
Lane
Branch
committee
;
a

which
was
again

with
a

of
pocket
-

.
   
<EOS>
The
secretary
having
sneezed
in
a
very
impressive

,
and
the
cough
which
always
seizes
an

,
when

is

,

,

"
REPORT
OF

OF
THE
BRICK
LANE

OF
THE

EBENEZER
TEMPERANCE

<EOS>
"
Your
committee
have

during
the
past

,
and
