Temperance
.
   
<EOS>
"
H
Walker
,
tailor
,
wife
,
and
two
children
.
 
<EOS>
When
in
better
circumstances
,
owns
to
having
been
in
the
constant
habit
of
drinking
ale
and
beer
;
says
he
is
not
certain
whether
he
did
not
twice

week
,
for
twenty
years
,
taste
"
dog
's
nose
,
"
which
your
committee
find

,

of
warm

,

,
gin
,

(
a

,
and
"
So
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
from
an

female
)
.
 
<EOS>
Is
now
out
of
work
and
penniless
;
thinks
it
must
be
the
porter
(
cheers
)
or
the
loss
of
the
use
of

right

;
is
not

,
but
thinks
it
very
likely
that
,
if
he
had
drunk
nothing
but
water
all

life
,
his
fellow
-

would
never
have
stuck
a
rusty

in
him
,
and
thereby

his

(
tremendous

)
.
 
<EOS>
Has
nothing
but
cold
water
to

,

never

(
great

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Betsy
Martin
,
widow
,
one
child
,
and
one
eye
.
 
Goes
out
charing
and
washing
,
by
the
day
;
never
had
more
than
one
eye
,
but
knows
her
mother
drank
bottled
stout
,
and
should
n't
wonder
if
that
caused
it
(
immense
cheering
)
.
 
<EOS>
Thinks
it
not
impossible
that
if
she
had
always
abstained
from
spirits
she
might
have
had
two
eyes
by
this
time
(

)
.
 
<EOS>
Used
,

every

she
went
to
,

eighteen

,

,

;

,

-
and
-
sixpence
(
the

of
this
most
interesting
fact
was
received
with
deafening

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Henry
Beller
was
for
many
years
toast
-
master
at
various
corporation
dinners
,
during
which
time
he
drank
a
great
deal
of
foreign
wine
;
may
sometimes
have
carried
a

or

home
with

;
is
not
quite
certain
of
that
,
but
is
sure
if
he
did
,
that
he
drank
the
contents
.
 
<EOS>
Feels
very
low
and
melancholy
,
is
very
feverish
,
and
has
a
constant
thirst
upon
him
;
thinks
it
must
be
the
wine
he
used
to
drink
(
cheers
)
.
 
<EOS>
Is
out
of
employ
now
;
and
never
touches
a
drop
of
foreign
wine
by
any
chance
(
tremendous
plaudits
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thomas
Burton
is
purveyor
of
cat
's
meat
to
the
Lord
Mayor
and
Sheriffs
,
and
several
members
of
the
Common
Council
(
the

of
this
gentleman
's
name
was
received
with

)
.
 
<EOS>
Has
a
wooden
leg
;
finds
a
wooden
leg
expensive
,
going
over
the
stones
;
used
to
wear
second
-
hand
wooden
legs
,
and
drink
a

of
hot
gin

-

regularly
every

---
sometimes
two
(
deep

)
.
 
<EOS>
Found
the
second
-
hand
wooden
legs
split
and
rot
very
quickly
;
is
firmly
persuaded
that
their
constitution
was
undermined
by
the
gin
-
and
-
water
(

)
.
 
<EOS>
Buys
new
wooden
legs
now
,
and
drinks
nothing
but
water
and
weak
tea
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
legs
last
twice
as
long
as
the
others
used
to
do
,
and
he
attributes
this
solely
to
his
temperate
habits
(
triumphant

)
.
"
   
<EOS>
Anthony
Humm
now
moved
that
the
assembly
do
regale
itself
with
a
song
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
view
to
their
rational
and

,
Brother
Mordlin
had

of
"
Who

n't

Waterman
?
"
to

,

(

)
.
 
<EOS>
He

his

that
the
late
Mr
Dibdin
,
seeing
the
errors
of

former

,
had

to
show

of

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
temperance
song
(

of
cheers
)
.
 
<EOS>
The
neatness
of
the
young
man
's

,

,
the
enviable

which

him
in

,
to
     
"
Row
along
,

nothing

,
"
   
all

to
prove
that
he
must
have

a
water
-

(
cheers
)
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
state
of
virtuous

!
 
<EOS>
(
rapturous
cheering
)
.
<EOS>
And
what
was
the

man
's

?
 
<EOS>
Let
all
young
men
present
mark

:
     
<EOS>
"
The
maidens
all
flocked
to
his
boat
so
readily
.
"
   
<EOS>
(
Loud

,

.
)
<EOS>
What
a
bright
example
!
<EOS>
The
sisterhood
,
the
maidens
,
flocking
round
the
young

,
and

along
the

duty

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

?
 
<EOS>
No
!
     
<EOS>
"
He
was
always
first
oars
with
the
fine

ladies
.
"
   
<EOS>
(
Immense

.
)
<EOS>
The
soft
sex
to
a
man
<EOS>
---
he
begged

,
to

female
---
rallied

,

(

)
.
 
<EOS>
The

(

)
.
 
<EOS>
That

was

;
that

were

;

(
Mr
Anthony
Humm
)
,

,

"
first

"
(

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wot

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
womin
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
ai

,
Sammy
,
"

;
"
they
MUST

---

,

---
if

.
"
   
<EOS>
Any

from

of

,
which
Mr
Anthony
Humm
gave

at

,
for

.
<EOS>
While

,

man

;

,
and

Mr
Anthony
Humm
,
with
a

the

importance
.
<EOS>
"
My
friends
,
"
said
Mr
Humm
,
holding

in

,
to

of
such
of
the
stout
old
ladies
as
were
yet
a
line
or
two
behind
;
"
my
friends
,
a
delegate
from
the
Dorking
Branch
of
our
society
,
Brother
Stiggins
,
attends
below
.
"
   
<EOS>
Out
came
the
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
again
,
in
greater
force
than
ever
;
for
Mr
Stiggins
was
excessively
popular
among
the
female
constituency
of
Brick
Lane
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
may
approach
,
I
think
,
"
said
Mr
Humm
,
looking
round
him
,
with
a
fat
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Brother
Tadger
,
let
him
come
forth
and
greet
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
in
the
drab
shorts
who
answered
to
the
name
of
Brother
Tadger
,
bustled
down
the
ladder
with
great
speed
,
and
was
immediately
afterwards
heard
tumbling
up
with
the
Reverend
Mr
Stiggins
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
-
comin
'
,
Sammy
,
"
whispered
Mr
Weller
,
purple
in
the
countenance
with
suppressed
laughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
nothin'
to
me
,
"
replied
Sam
,
"
for
I
ca
n't
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
close
to
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
him
a
-
knockin
'
his
head
again
the
lath
and
plaster
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
Sam
Weller
spoke
,
the
little
door
flew
open
,
and
Brother
Tadger
appeared
,
closely
followed
by
the
Reverend
Mr
Stiggins
,
who
no
sooner
entered
,
than
there
was
a
great
clapping
of
hands
,
and
stamping
of
feet
,
and
flourishing
of
handkerchiefs
;
to
all
of
which
manifestations
of
delight
<EOS>
,
Brother
Stiggins
returned
no
other
acknowledgment
than
staring
with
a
wild
eye
,
and
a
fixed
smile
,
at
the
extreme
top
of
the
wick
of
the
candle
on
the
table
,
swaying
his
body
to
and
fro
,
meanwhile
,
in
a
very
unsteady
and
uncertain
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
unwell
,
Brother
Stiggins
?
<EOS>
"
whispered
Mr
Anthony
Humm
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
all
right
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Stiggins
,
in
a
tone
in
which
ferocity
was
blended
with
an
extreme
thickness
of
utterance
;
"
I
am
all
right
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
very
well
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Anthony
Humm
,
retreating
a
few
paces
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
no
man
here
has
ventured
to
say
that
I
am
not
all
right
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Stiggins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
not
,
"
said
Mr
Humm
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
advise
him
not
to
,
Sir
;
I
should
advise
him
not
,
"
said
Mr
Stiggins
.
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
audience
were
perfectly
silent
,
and
waited
with
some
anxiety
for
the
resumption
of
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
address
the
meeting
,
brother
?
"
said
Mr
Humm
,
with
a
smile
of
invitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Stiggins
;
"
No
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
meeting
looked
at
each
other
with
raised
eyelids
;
and
a
murmur
of
astonishment
ran
through
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
opinion
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Stiggins
,
unbuttoning
his
coat
,
and
speaking
very
loudly
---
<EOS>
"
it
's
my
opinion
,
sir
,
that
this
meeting
is
drunk
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Brother
Tadger
,
sir
!
"
said
Mr
Stiggins
,
suddenly
increasing
in
ferocity
,
and
turning
sharp
round
on
the
little
man
in
the
drab
shorts
,
"
YOU
are
drunk
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
this
,
Mr
Stiggins
,
entertaining
a
praiseworthy
desire
to
promote
the
sobriety
of
the
meeting
,
and
to
exclude
therefrom
all
improper
characters
,
hit
Brother
Tadger
on
the
summit
of
the
nose
with
such
unerring
aim
,
that
the
drab
shorts
disappeared
like
a
flash
of
lightning
.
<EOS>
Brother
Tadger
had
been
knocked
,
head
first
,
down
the
ladder
.
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
women
set
up
a
loud
and
dismal
screaming
;
and
rushing
in
small
parties
before
their
favourite
brothers
,
flung
their
arms
around
them
to
preserve
them
from
danger
.
 
<EOS>
An
instance
of
affection
,
which
had
nearly
proved
fatal
to
Humm
,
who
,
being
extremely
popular
,
was
all
but
suffocated
,
by
the
crowd
of
female
devotees
that
hung
about
his
neck
,
and
heaped
caresses
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
greater
part
of
the
lights
were
quickly
put
out
,
and
nothing
but
noise
and
confusion
resounded
on
all
sides
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Sammy
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
taking
off
his
greatcoat
with
much
deliberation
,
"
just
you
step
out
,
and
fetch
in
a
watchman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
wot
are
you
a
-
goin
'
to
do
,
the
while
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
me
,
Sammy
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
;
"
I
shall
ockipy
myself
in
<EOS>
havin'
a
small
settlement
with
that
'
ere
Stiggins
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Before
Sam
could
interfere
to
prevent
it
,
his
heroic
parent
had
penetrated
into
a
remote
corner
of
the
room
,
and
attacked
the
Reverend
Mr
Stiggins
with
manual
dexterity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
off
!
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
on
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Weller
;
and
without
further
invitation
he
gave
the
Reverend
Mr
Stiggins
a
preliminary
tap
on
the
head
,
and
began
dancing
round
him
in
a
buoyant
and
cork
-
like
manner
,
which
in
a
gentleman
at
his
time
of
life
was
a
perfect
marvel
to
behold
.
   
<EOS>
Finding
all
remonstrances
unavailing
,
Sam
pulled
his
hat
firmly
on
,
threw
his
father
's
coat
over
his
arm
,
and
taking
the
old
man
round
the
waist
,
forcibly
dragged
him
down
the
ladder
,
and
into
the
street
;
never
releasing
his
hold
,
or
permitting
him
to
stop
,
until
they
reached
the
corner
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
gained
it
,
they
could
hear
the
shouts
of
the
populace
,
who
were
witnessing
the
removal
of
the
Reverend
Mr
Stiggins
to
strong
lodgings
for
the
night
,
and
could
hear
the
noise
occasioned
by
the
dispersion
in
various
directions
of
the
members
of
the
Brick
Lane
Branch
of
the
United
Grand
Junction
Ebenezer
Temperance
Association
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
Is
wholly
devoted
to
a
full
and
faithful
report
of
the
memorable
trial
of
Bardell
against
Pickwick
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
what
the
foreman
of
the
jury
,
whoever
he
'll
be
,
has
got
for
breakfast
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
by
way

keeping

on
the

morning
of
the
fourteenth
of
February
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Perker
,
"
I
hope
he
's
got
a
good
one
.
"
<EOS>
"
Why
so
?
<EOS>
"
inquired

Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Highly
important
---
very

,
my
dear
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
good
,
contented
,
well
-
breakfasted
juryman
is

.
 
<EOS>
Discontented
or

,
my

,
always
find
for
the
plaintiff
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Bless

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,

,
"
what
do

do
that
for
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
the
little
man
coolly
;
"
saves
time
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
's
near
dinner
-
time
,
the
foreman
takes

watch
when
the
jury
has

,

,
"

,

,

,

<EOS>
I

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
So

,
"
says

else
,

who

three
and

.
<EOS>
The

,
and

watch
:
---
"
Well
,

,
what

say
,
plaintiff

,

?
 
<EOS>
I
rather
think
,
so
far

I

,

,
---
I

,

---
but

---
<EOS>
I
RATHER
think
the
plaintiff
's
the

.
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
two

three
other

they

---
as

;

.
 
<EOS>
Ten
minutes
past
nine
!
"
said

man
,

.
<EOS>
"
Time

off
,
my
dear
sir
;
breach
of
promise
trial
-
court
is
generally
full
in

.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
ring
for
a
coach
,
my
dear

,
or
we
shall

rather
late
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
immediately
rang
the
bell
,
and
a
coach
having
been
procured
,
the
four
Pickwickians
and
Mr
Perker
ensconced
themselves
therein
,
and
drove
to
Guildhall
;
Sam
Weller
,
Mr
Lowten
,
and
the
blue
bag
,
following
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Lowten
,
"
said
Perker
,
when

outer

of

court
,
"
put
Mr
Pickwick
's
friends
in
the
students
"
box
;
Mr
Pickwick
himself
had
better
sit
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
This
way
,
my

sir
,
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Taking
Mr
Pickwick
by
the
coat
sleeve
,
the
little
man
led
him
to
the
low
seat
just
beneath
the
desks
of
the
King
's
Counsel
,
which
is
constructed
for
the
convenience
of
attorneys
,
who
from
that
spot
can
whisper
into
the
ear
of
the
leading
counsel
in
the
case
,
any
instructions
that
may
be
necessary
during
the
progress
of
the
trial
.
 
<EOS>
The
occupants
of
this
seat
are
invisible
to
the
great
body
of
spectators
,
inasmuch
as
they
sit
on
a
much
lower
level
than
either
the
barristers
or
the
audience
,
whose
seats
are
raised
above
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
they
have
their
backs
to
both
,
and
their
faces
towards
the
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
witness
-
box
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
pointing
to
a
kind
of
pulpit
,
with

,
on
his
left

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
witness
-
box
,
my

,
"
replied
Perker
,
disinterring
a
quantity
of
papers
from
the
blue
bag
,
which
Lowten
had
just
deposited
at

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,

,
"
that

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
identical
place
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
replied
Perker
,
tapping
the
lid
of
his
snuff
-
box
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
stood
up
in
a
state
of
great
agitation
,
and
took
a
glance
at
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
already
a
pretty
large
sprinkling
of
spectators
in
the
gallery
,
and
a
numerous
muster
of
gentlemen
in
wigs
,
in
the
barristers
<EOS>
"
seats
,
who
presented
,
as
a
body
,
all
that
pleasing
and
extensive
variety
of
nose
and
whisker
for
which
the
Bar
of
England
is
so
justly
celebrated
.
 
<EOS>
Such
of
the
gentlemen
as
had
a
brief
to
carry
,
carried
it
in
as
conspicuous
a
manner
as
possible
,
and
occasionally
scratched
their
noses
therewith
,
to
impress
the
fact
more
strongly
on
the
observation
of
the
spectators
.
<EOS>
Other
gentlemen
,
who
had
no
briefs
to
show
,
carried
under
their
arms
goodly
octavos
,
with
a
red
label
behind
,
and
that
under
-
done
-
pie
-
crust
-
coloured
cover
,
which
is
technically
known
as
"
law
calf
.
"
 
Others
,
who
had
neither
briefs
nor
books
,
thrust
their
hands
into
their
pockets
,
and
looked
as
wise
as
they
conveniently
could
;
others
,
again
,
moved
here
and
there
with
great
restlessness
and
earnestness
of
manner
,
content
to
awaken
thereby
the
admiration
and
astonishment
of
the
uninitiated
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
,
to
the
great
wonderment
of
Mr
,
Pickwick
,
were
divided
into
little
groups
,
who
were
chatting
and
discussing
the
news
of
the
day
in
the
most
unfeeling
manner
possible
---
just
as
if
no
trial
at
all
were
coming
on
.
   
<EOS>
A
bow
from
Mr
Phunky
,
as
he
entered
,
and
took
his
seat
behind
the
row
appropriated
to
the
King
's
Counsel
,
attracted
Mr
Pickwick
's
attention
;
and
he
had
scarcely

,
when
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
appeared
,
followed
by
Mr
Mallard
,
who
half
hid
the
Serjeant
behind

large
crimson
bag
,
which
he
placed
on
his
table
,
and
,
after

hands
with
Perker
,
withdrew
.
<EOS>
Then
there
entered
two
or
three
more
Serjeants
;
and
among
them
,
one
with
a
fat
body
and
a
red
face
,
who
nodded
in
a
friendly
manner
to
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
and
said
it
was
a
fine
morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
's
that
red
-
faced
man
,
who
said
it
was
a
fine
morning
,
and
nodded
to
our
counsel
?
"
<EOS>

Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
"

Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
opposed
to
us
;
he
leads
on
the
other

.
 
<EOS>
That
gentleman
behind
him
is
Mr
Skimpin
,
his
junior
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
on
the
point
of
inquiring
,
with
great
abhorrence
of
the
man
's
cold
-
blooded
villainy
,
how
Mr
,
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
who
was
counsel
for
the
opposite

,
dared
to
presume
to
tell
Mr
Serjeant
Snubbin
,
who

,
that

morning
,
when
he
was
interrupted
by
a
general
rising
of
the
barristers
,
and
a
loud
cry
of
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
from
the
officers
of
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
found
that
this
was
caused
by
the
entrance
of
the
judge
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
(
who
sat
in
the
absence
of
the
Chief
Justice
,
occasioned
by
indisposition
)
was
a
most
particularly
short
man
,
and
so
fat
,
that
he
seemed
all
face
and
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
He
rolled
in
,
upon
two
little
turned
legs
,
and
having
bobbed
gravely
to
the
Bar
,
who
bobbed
gravely
to
him
,
put
his
little
legs
underneath
his
table
,
and
his
little
three
-
cornered
hat
upon
it
;
and
when
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
had
done
this
,
all
you
could
see
of
him
was
two
queer
little
eyes
,
one
broad
pink
face
,
and
somewhere
about
half
of
a
big
and
very
comical
-
looking
wig
.
   
<EOS>
The
judge
had
no
sooner
taken
his
seat
,
than
the
officer
on
the
floor
of
the
court
called
out
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
commanding
tone
,
upon
which
another
officer
in
the
gallery
cried
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
in
an
angry
manner
,
whereupon
three
or
four
more
ushers
shouted
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
voice
of
indignant
remonstrance
.
 
<EOS>
This
being
done
,
a
gentleman
in
black
,
who
sat
below
the
judge
,
proceeded
to
call
over
the
names
of
the
jury
;
and
after
a
great
deal
of
bawling
,
it
was
discovered
that
only
ten
special
jurymen
were
present
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
prayed
a
TALES
;
the
gentleman
in
black
then
proceeded
to
press
into
the
special
jury
,
two
of
the
common
jurymen
;
and
a
greengrocer
and
a
chemist
were
caught
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Answer
to
your
names
,
gentlemen
,
that
you
may
be
sworn
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
black
.
 
<EOS>
"
Richard
Upwitch
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
said
the
greengrocer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thomas
Groffin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
said
the
chemist
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
the
book
,
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
well
and
truly
try
---
"
   
"
I
beg
this
court
's
pardon
,
"
said
the
chemist
,
who
was
a
tall
,
thin
,
yellow
-
visaged
man
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
hope
this
court
will
excuse
my
attendance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
what
grounds
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
assistant
,
my
Lord
,
"
said
the
chemist
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
that
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
should
hire
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
afford
it
,
my
Lord
,
"
rejoined
the
chemist
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
ought
to
be
able
to
afford
it
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
judge
,
reddening
;
for
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
's
temper
bordered
on
the
irritable
,
and
brooked
not
contradiction
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
OUGHT
to
do
,
if
I
got
on
as
well
as
I
deserved
;
but
I
do
n't
,
my
Lord
,
"
answered
the
chemist
.
   
<EOS>
"
Swear
the
gentleman
,
"
said
the
judge
peremptorily
.
   
<EOS>
The
officer
had
got
no
further
than
the
"
You
shall
well
and
truly
try
,
"
when
he
was
again
interrupted
by
the
chemist
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
to
be
sworn
,
my
Lord
,
am
I
?
"
said
the
chemist
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
testy
little
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
my
Lord
,
"
replied
the
chemist
,
in
a
resigned
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
there
'll
be
murder
before
this
trial
's
over
;
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
Swear
me
,
if
you
please
,
Sir
;
"
and
sworn
the
chemist
was
,
before
the
judge
could
find
words
to
utter
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
merely
wanted
to
observe
,
my
Lord
,
"
said
the
chemist
,
taking
his
seat
with
great
deliberation
,
"
that
I
've
left
nobody
but
an
errand
-
boy
in
my
shop
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
very
nice
boy
,
my
Lord
,
but
he
is
not
acquainted
with
drugs
;
and
I
know
that
the
prevailing
impression
on
his
mind
is
,
that
Epsom
salts
means
oxalic
acid
;
and
syrup
of
senna
,
laudanum
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
,
my
Lord
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
the
tall
chemist
composed
himself
into
a
comfortable
attitude
,
and
,
assuming
a
pleasant
expression
of
countenance
,
appeared
to
have
prepared
himself
for
the
worst
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
regarding
the
chemist
with
feelings
of
the
deepest
horror
,
when
a
slight
sensation
was
perceptible
in
the
body
of
the
court
;
and
immediately
afterwards
Mrs
Bardell
,
supported
by
Mrs
Cluppins
,
was
led
in
,
and
placed
,
in
a
drooping
state
,
at
the
other
end
of
the
seat
on
which
Mr
Pickwick
sat
.
<EOS>
An
extra
-
sized
umbrella
was
then
handed
in
by
Mr
Dodson
,
and
a
pair
of
pattens
by
Mr
Fogg
,
each
of
whom
had
prepared
a
most
sympathising
and
melancholy
face
for
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sanders
then
appeared
,
leading
in
Master
Bardell
.
 
<EOS>
At
sight
of
her
child
,
Mrs
Bardell
started
;
suddenly
recollecting
herself
,
she
kissed
him
in
a
frantic
manner
;
then
relapsing
into
a
state
of
hysterical
imbecility
,
the
good
lady
requested
to
be
informed
where
she
was
.
 
<EOS>
In
reply
to
this
,
Mrs
Cluppins
and
Mrs
Sanders
turned
their
heads
away
and
wept
,
while
Messrs.
Dodson
and
Fogg
entreated
the
plaintiff
to
compose
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Serjeant
Buzfuz
rubbed
his
eyes
very
hard
with
a
large
white
handkerchief
,
and
gave
an
appealing
look
towards
the
jury
,
while
the
judge
was
visibly
affected
,
and
several
of
the
beholders
tried
to
cough
down
their
emotion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
notion
that
indeed
,
"
whispered
Perker
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Capital
fellows
those
Dodson
and
Fogg
;
excellent
ideas
of
effect
,
my
dear
Sir
,
excellent
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Perker
spoke
,
Mrs
Bardell
began
to
recover
by
slow
degrees
,
while
Mrs
Cluppins
,
after
a
careful
survey
of
Master
Bardell
's
buttons
and
the
button
-
holes
to
which
they
severally
belonged
,
placed
him
on
the
floor
of
the
court
in
front
of
his
mother
---
a
commanding
position
in
which
he
could
not
fail
to
awaken
the
full
commiseration
and
sympathy
of
both
judge
and
jury
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
not
done
without
considerable
opposition
,
and
many
tears
,
on
the
part
of
the
young
gentleman
himself
,
who
had
certain
inward
misgivings
that
the
placing
him
within
the
full
glare
of
the
judge
's
eye
was
only
a
formal
prelude
to
his
being
immediately
ordered
away
for
instant
execution
,
or
for
transportation
beyond
the
seas
,
during
the
whole
term
of
his
natural
life
,
at
the
very
least
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bardell
and
Pickwick
,
"
cried
the
gentleman
in
black
,
calling
on
the
case
,
which
stood
first
on
the
list
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
for
the
plaintiff
,
my
Lord
,
"
said
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is

you
,
Brother
Buzfuz
?
"
said
the
judge
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpin
bowed
,
to
intimate
that
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
appear
for
the
defendant
,

Lord
,
"
said

Serjeant
Snubbin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anybody

,
Brother

?
"
inquired

court
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Phunky
,
my
Lord
,
"

Serjeant
Snubbin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Serjeant
Buzfuz
and
Mr
Skimpin
for
the
plaintiff
,
"
said
the
judge
,
writing

names
in

-

,
and
reading
as

;
"
for
the
defendant
,
Serjeant
Snubbin
and
Mr
Monkey
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
Lordship
's
pardon
,
Phunky
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
very
good
,
"
said
the
judge
;
"
I
never
had
the
pleasure
of
hearing
the
gentleman
's
name
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Phunky
bowed
and
smiled
,
and
the
judge
bowed
and
smiled
too
,
and
then
Mr
Phunky
,
blushing
into
the
very
whites
of
his
eyes
,
tried
to
look
as
if
he
did
n't
know
that
everybody
was
gazing
at
him
,
a
thing
which
no
man
ever
succeeded
in
doing
yet
,
or
in
all
reasonable
probability
,
ever
will
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
"
said
the
judge
.
   
<EOS>
The
ushers
again
called
silence
,
and
Mr
Skimpin
proceeded
to
"
open
the
case
"
;
and
the
case
appeared
to
have
very
little
inside
it
when
he
had
opened
it
,
for
he
kept
such
particulars
as
he
knew
,
completely
to
himself
,
and
sat
down
,
after
a
lapse
of
three
minutes
,
leaving
the
jury
in
precisely
the
same
advanced
stage
of
wisdom
as
they
were
in
before
.
   
<EOS>
Serjeant
Buzfuz
then
rose
with
all
the
majesty
and
dignity
which
the
grave
nature
of
the
proceedings
demanded
,
and
having
whispered
to
Dodson
,
and
conferred
briefly
with
Fogg
,
pulled
his
gown
over
his
shoulders
,
settled
his
wig
,
and
addressed
the
jury
.
   
<EOS>
Serjeant
Buzfuz
began
by
saying
,
that
never
,
in
the
whole
course
of
his
professional
experience
---
never
,
from
the
very
first
moment
of
his
applying
himself
to
the
study
and
practice
of
the
law
---
had
he
approached
a
case
with
feelings
of
such
deep
emotion
,
or
with
such
a
heavy
sense
of
the
responsibility
imposed
upon
him
---
a
responsibility
,
he
would
say
,
which
he
could
never
have
supported
,
were
he
not
buoyed
up
and
sustained
by
a
conviction
so
strong
,
that
it
amounted
to
positive
certainty
that
the
cause
of
truth
and
justice
,
or
,
in
other
words
,
the
cause
of
his
much
-
injured
and
most
oppressed
client
,
must
prevail
with
the
high
-
minded
and
intelligent
dozen
of
men
whom
he
now
saw
in
that
box
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
Counsel
usually
begin
in
this
way
,
because
it
puts
the
jury
on
the
very
best
terms
with
themselves
,
and
makes
them
think
what
sharp
fellows
they
must
be
.
 
<EOS>
A
visible
effect
was
produced
immediately
,
several
jurymen
beginning
to
take
voluminous
notes
with
the
utmost
eagerness
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
from
my
learned
friend
,
gentlemen
,
"
continued
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
well
knowing
that
,
from
the
learned
friend
alluded
to
,
the
gentlemen
of
the
jury
had
heard
just
nothing
at
all
---
"
you
have
heard
from
my
learned
friend
,
gentlemen
,
that
this
is
an
action
for
a
breach
of
promise
of
marriage
,
in
which
the

are
laid
at
#
#
#
#
1,500
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
have
not
heard
from
my
learned
friend
,
inasmuch
as
it
did
not
come
within
my
learned
friend
's
province
to
tell
you
,
what
are
the
facts
and
circumstances
of
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
Those
facts
and
circumstances
,
gentlemen
<EOS>
,
you
shall
hear
detailed
by
me
,
and
proved
by
the
unimpeachable
female
whom
I
will
place
in
that
box
before
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
,
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
with
a
tremendous
emphasis
on
the
word
"
box
,
"
smote
his
table
with
a
mighty
sound
,
and
glanced
at
Dodson
and
Fogg
,
who
nodded
admiration
of
the
Serjeant
,
and
indignant
defiance
of
the
defendant
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
plaintiff
,
gentlemen
,
"
continued
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
in
a
soft
and
melancholy
voice
,
"
the
plaintiff
is
a
widow
;
yes
,
gentlemen
,
a
widow
.
 
<EOS>
The
late
Mr
Bardell
,
after
enjoying
,
for
many
years
,
the
esteem
and
confidence
of
his
sovereign
,
as
one
of
the
guardians
of
his
royal
revenues
,
glided
almost
imperceptibly
from
the
world
,
to
seek
elsewhere
for
that
repose
and
peace
which
a
custom
-
house
can
never
afford
.
"
<EOS>
At
this
pathetic
description
of
the
decease
of
Mr
Bardell
,
who
had
been
knocked
on
the
head
with
a
quart
-
pot
in
a
public
-
house
cellar
,
the
learned
serjeant
's
voice
faltered
,
and
he
proceeded
,
with
emotion
---
   
<EOS>
"
Some
time
before
his
death
,
he
had
stamped
his
likeness
upon
a
little
boy
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
little
boy
,
the
only
pledge
of
her
departed
exciseman
,
Mrs
Bardell
shrank
from
the
world
,
and
courted
the
retirement
and
tranquillity
of
Goswell
Street
;
and
here
she
placed
in
her
front
parlour
window
a
written
placard
,
bearing
this
inscription
---
"
Apartments
furnished
for
a
single
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Inquire
within
.
"
<EOS>
"
Here
Serjeant
Buzfuz
paused
,
while
several
gentlemen
of
the
jury
took
a
note
of
the
document
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
date
to
that
,
is
there
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
a
juror
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
date
,
gentlemen
,
"
replied
Serjeant
Buzfuz
;
"
but
I
am
instructed
to
say
that
it
was
put
in
the
plaintiff
's
parlour
window
just
this
time
three
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
entreat
the
attention
of
the
jury
to
the
wording
of
this
document
---
"
Apartments
furnished
for
a
single
gentleman
"
!
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
's
opinions
of
the
opposite
sex
,
gentlemen
,
were
derived
from
a
long
contemplation
of
the
inestimable
qualities
of
her
lost
husband
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
no
fear
<EOS>
,
she
had
no
distrust
,
she
had
no
suspicion
;
all
was
confidence
and
reliance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Bardell
,
"
said
the
widow
---
"
<EOS>
Mr
Bardell
was
a
man
of
honour
,
Mr
Bardell
was
a
man
of
his
word
,
Mr
Bardell
was
no
deceiver
,
Mr
Bardell
was
once
a
single
gentleman
himself
;
to
single
gentlemen
I
look
for
protection
,
for
assistance
,
for
comfort
,
and
for
consolation
;
in
single
gentlemen
I
shall
perpetually
see
something
to
remind
me
of
what
Mr
Bardell
was
when
he
first
won
my
young
and
untried
affections
;
to
a
single
gentleman
,
then
,
shall
my
lodgings
be
let
.
<EOS>
"
Actuated
by
this
beautiful
and
touching
impulse
(
among
the
best
impulses
of
our
imperfect
nature
,
gentlemen
)
,
the
lonely
and
desolate
widow
dried
her
tears
,
furnished
her
first
floor
,
caught
her
innocent
boy
to
her
maternal
bosom
,
and
put
the
bill
up
in
her
parlour
window
.
<EOS>
Did
it
remain
there
long
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
The
serpent
was
on
the
watch
,
the
train
was
laid
,
the
mine
was
preparing
,
the
sapper
and
miner
was
at
work
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
bill
had
been
in
the
parlour
window
three
days
---
three
days
,
gentlemen
---
a
being
,
erect
upon
two
legs
,
and
bearing
all
the
outward
semblance
of
a
man
,
and
not
of
a
monster
,
knocked
at
the
door
of
Mrs
Bardell
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
inquired
within
---
he
took
the
lodgings
;
and
on
the
very
next
day
he
entered
into
possession
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
man
was
Pickwick
---
Pickwick
,
the
defendant
.
"
   
<EOS>
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
who
had
proceeded
with
such
volubility
that
his
face
was
perfectly
crimson
,
here
paused
for
breath
.
 
<EOS>
The
silence
awoke
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
,
who
immediately
wrote
down
something
with
a
pen
without
any
ink
in
it
,
and
looked
unusually
profound
,
to
impress
the
jury
with
the
belief
that
he
always
thought
most
deeply
with
his
eyes
shut
.
 
<EOS>
Serjeant
Buzfuz
proceeded
---
   
<EOS>
"
Of
this
man
Pickwick
I
will
say
little
;
the
subject
presents
but
few
attractions
;
and
I
,
gentlemen
,
am
not
the
man
,
nor
are
you
,
gentlemen
,
the
men
,
to
delight
in
the
contemplation
of
revolting
heartlessness
,
and
of
systematic
villainy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
been
writhing
in
silence
for
some
time
,
gave
a
violent
start
,
as
if
some
vague
idea
of
assaulting
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
in
the
august
presence
of
justice
and
law
,
suggested
itself
to
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
An
admonitory
gesture
from
Perker
restrained
him
,
and
he
listened
to
the
learned
gentleman
's
continuation
with
a
look
of
indignation
,
which
contrasted
forcibly
with
the
admiring
faces
of
Mrs
Cluppins
and
Mrs
Sanders
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
systematic
villainy
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
looking
through
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
talking
AT
him
;
"
and
when
I
say
systematic
villainy
,
let
me
tell
the
defendant
Pickwick
,
if
he
be
in
court
,
as
I
am
informed
he
is
,
that
it
would
have
been
more
decent
in
him
,
more
becoming
,
in
better
judgment
,
and
in
better
taste
,
if
he
had
stopped
away
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
tell
him
,
gentlemen
,
that
any
gestures
of
dissent
or
disapprobation
in
which
he
may
indulge
in
this
court
will
not
go
down
with
you
;
that
you
will
know
how
to
value
and
how
to
appreciate
them
;
and
let
me
tell
him
further
,
as
my
Lord
will
tell
you
,
gentlemen
,
that
a
counsel
,
in
the
discharge
of
his
duty
to
his
client
,
is
neither
to
be
intimidated
nor
bullied
,
nor
put
down
;
and
that
any
attempt
to
do
either
the
one
or
the
other
,
or
the
first
,
or
the
last
,
will
recoil
on
the
head
of
the
attempter
,
be
he
plaintiff
or
be
he
defendant
,
be
his
name
Pickwick
,
or
Noakes
,
or
Stoakes
,
or
Stiles
,
or
Brown
,
or
Thompson
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
little
divergence
from
the
subject
in
hand
,
had
,
of
course
,
the
intended
effect
of
turning
all
eyes
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
having
partially
recovered
from
the
state
of
moral
elevation
into
which
he
had
lashed
himself
,
resumed
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
show
you
,
gentlemen
,
that
for
two
years
,
Pickwick
continued
to
reside
constantly
,
and
without
interruption
or
intermission
,
at
Mrs
Bardell
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
show
you
that
Mrs
Bardell
,
during
the
whole
of
that
time
,
waited
on
him
,
attended
to
his
comforts
,
cooked
his
meals
,
looked
out
his
linen
for
the
washerwoman
when
it
went
abroad
,
darned
,
aired
,
and
prepared
it
for
wear
,
when
it
came
home
,
and
,
in
short
,
enjoyed
his
fullest
trust
and
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
show
you
that
,
on
many
occasions
,
he
gave
halfpence
,
and
on
some
occasions
even
sixpences
,
to
her
little
boy
;
and
I
shall
prove
to
you
,
by
a
witness
whose
testimony
it
will
be
impossible
for
my
learned
friend
to
weaken
or
controvert
,
that
on
one
occasion
he
patted
the
boy
on
the
head
,
and
,
after
inquiring
whether
he
had
won
any
"
ALLEY
TORS
"
or
"
COMMONEYS
"
lately
(
both
of
which
I
understand
to
be
a
particular
species
of
marbles
much
prized
by
the
youth
of
this
town
)
,
made
use
of
this
remarkable
expression
,
"
How
should
you
like
to
have
another
father
?
<EOS>
"
I
shall
prove
to
you
,
gentlemen
,
that
about
a
year
ago
,
Pickwick
suddenly
began
to
absent
himself
from
home
,
during
long
intervals
,
as
if
with
the
intention
of
gradually
breaking
off
from
my
client
;
but
I
shall
show
you
also
,
that
his
resolution
was
not
at
that
time
sufficiently
strong
,
or
that
his
better
feelings
conquered
,
if
better
feelings
he
has
,
or
that
the
charms
and
accomplishments
of
my
client
prevailed
against
his
unmanly
intentions
,
by
proving
to
you
,
that
on
one
occasion
,
when
he
returned
from
the
country
,
he
distinctly
and
in
terms
,
offered
her
marriage
:
previously
,
however
,
taking
special
care
that
there
would
be
no
witness
to
their
solemn
contract
;
and
I
am
in
a
situation
to
prove
to
you
,
on
the
testimony
of
three
of
his
own
friends
---
most
unwilling
witnesses
,
gentlemen
---
most
unwilling
witnesses
---
that
on
that
morning
he
was
discovered
by
them
holding
the
plaintiff
in
his
arms
,
and
soothing
her
agitation
by
his
caresses
and
endearments
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
visible
impression
was
produced
upon
the
auditors
by
this
part
of
the
learned
Serjeant
's
address
.
 
<EOS>
Drawing
forth
two
very
small
scraps
of
paper
,
he
proceeded
---
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
gentlemen
,
but
one
word
more
.
 
<EOS>
Two
letters
have
passed
between
these
parties
,
letters
which
are
admitted
to
be
in
the
handwriting
of
the
defendant
,
and
which
speak
volumes
,
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
The
letters
,
too
,
bespeak
the
character
of
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
open
,
fervent
,
eloquent
epistles
,
breathing
nothing
but
the
language
of
affectionate
attachment
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
covert
,
sly
,
underhanded
communications
,
but
,
fortunately
,
far
more
conclusive
than
if
couched
in
the
most
glowing
language
and
the
most
poetic
imagery
---
letters
that
must
be
viewed
with
a
cautious
and
suspicious
eye
---
letters
that
were
evidently
intended
at
the
time
,
by
Pickwick
,
to
mislead
and
delude
any
third
parties
into
whose
hands
they
might
fall
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
read
the
first
:
"
Garraways
,
twelve
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mrs
B.
---
Chops
and
tomato
sauce
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
,
PICKWICK
.
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
what
does
this
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Chops
and
tomato
sauce
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
,
Pickwick
!
 
<EOS>
Chops
!
 
<EOS>
Gracious
heavens
!
<EOS>
and
tomato
sauce
!
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
is
the
happiness
of
a
sensitive
and
confiding
female
to
be
trifled
away
,
by
such
shallow
artifices
as
these
?
 
<EOS>
The
next
has
no
date
whatever
,
which
is
in
itself
suspicious
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mrs
B.
,
I
shall
not
be
at
home
till
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Slow
coach
.
<EOS>
"
And
then
follows
this
very
remarkable
expression
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
trouble
yourself
about
the
warming
-
pan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
warming
-
pan
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
gentlemen
,
who
DOES
trouble
himself
about
a
warming
-
pan
?
<EOS>
When
was
the
peace
of
mind
of
man
or
woman
broken
or
disturbed
by
a
warming
-
pan
,
which
is
in
itself
a
harmless
,
a
useful
,
and
I
will
add
,
gentlemen
,
a
comforting
article
of
domestic
furniture
?
 
<EOS>
Why
is
Mrs
Bardell
so
earnestly
entreated
not
to
agitate
herself
about
this
warming
-
pan
,
unless
(
as
is
no
doubt
the
case
)
<EOS>
it
is
a
mere
cover
for
hidden
fire
---
a
mere
substitute
for
some
endearing
word
or
promise
,
agreeably
to
a
preconcerted
system
of
correspondence
,
artfully
contrived
by
Pickwick
with
a
view
to
his
contemplated
desertion
,
and
which
I
am
not
in
a
condition
to
explain
?
 
<EOS>
And
what
does
this
allusion
to
the
slow
coach
mean
?
 
<EOS>
For
aught
<EOS>
I
know
,
it
may
be
a
reference
to
Pickwick
himself
,
who
has
most
unquestionably
been
a
criminally
slow
coach
during
the
whole
of
this
transaction
,
but
whose
speed
will
now
be
very
unexpectedly
accelerated
,
and
whose
wheels
,
gentlemen
,
as
he
will
find
to
his
cost
,
will
very
soon
be
greased
by
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
paused
in
this
place
,
to
see
whether
the
jury
smiled
at
his
joke
;
but
as
nobody
took
it
but
the
greengrocer
,
whose
sensitiveness
on
the
subject
was
very
probably
occasioned
by
his
having
subjected
a
chaise
-
cart
to
the
process
in
question
on
that
identical
morning
,
the
learned
Serjeant
considered
it
advisable
to
undergo
a
slight
relapse
into
the
dismals
before
he
concluded
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
enough
of
this
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
"
it
is
difficult
to
smile
with
an
aching
heart
;
it
is
ill
jesting
when
our
deepest
sympathies
are
awakened
.
 
<EOS>
My
client
's
hopes
and
prospects
are
ruined
,
and
it
is
no
figure
of
speech
to
say
that
her
occupation
is
gone
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
The
bill
is
down
---
but
there
is
no
tenant
.
 
<EOS>
Eligible
single
gentlemen
pass
and
repass
-
<EOS>
but
there
is
no
invitation
for
to
inquire
within
or
without
.
 
<EOS>
All
is
gloom
and
silence
in
the
house
;
even
the
voice
of
the
child
is
hushed
;
his
infant
sports
are
disregarded
when
his
mother
weeps
;
his
"
alley
tors
"
and
his
"
commoneys
"
are
alike
neglected
;
he
forgets
the
long
familiar
cry
of
"
knuckle
down
,
"
and
at
tip
-
cheese
,
or
odd
and
even
,
his
hand
is
out
.
 
<EOS>
But
Pickwick
,
gentlemen
,
Pickwick
,
the
ruthless
destroyer
of
this
domestic
oasis
in
the
desert
of
Goswell
Street
---
Pickwick
who
has
choked
up
the
well
,
and
thrown
ashes
on
the
sward
---
Pickwick
,
who
comes
before
you
to
-
day
with
his
heartless
tomato
sauce
and
warming
-
pans
---
Pickwick
still
rears
his
head
with
unblushing
effrontery
,
and
gazes
without
a
sigh
on
the
ruin
he
has
made
.
 
<EOS>
Damages
,
gentlemen
---
<EOS>
heavy
damages
is
the
only
punishment
with
which
you
can
visit
him
;
the
only
recompense
you
can
award
to
my
client
.
 
<EOS>
And
for
those
damages
she
now
appeals
to
an
enlightened
,
a
high
-
minded
,
a
right
-
feeling
,
a
conscientious
,
a
dispassionate
,
a
sympathising
,
a
contemplative
jury
of
her
civilised
countrymen
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
beautiful
peroration
,
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
sat
down
,
and
Mr
Justice
Stareleigh
woke
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Call
Elizabeth
Cluppins
,
"
said
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
rising
a
minute
afterwards
,
with
renewed
vigour
.
   
<EOS>
The
nearest
usher
called
for
Elizabeth
Tuppins
;
another
one
,
at
a
little
distance
off
,
demanded
Elizabeth
Jupkins
;
and
a
third
rushed
in
a
breathless
state
into
King
Street
,
and
screamed
for
Elizabeth
Muffins
till
he
was
hoarse
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Mrs
Cluppins
,
with
the
combined
assistance
of
Mrs
Bardell
,
Mrs
Sanders
,
Mr
Dodson
,
and
Mr
Fogg
,
was
hoisted
into
the
witness
-
box
;
and
when
she
was
safely
perched
on
the
top
step
,
Mrs
Bardell
stood
on
the
bottom
one
,
with
the
pocket
-
handkerchief
and
pattens
in
one
hand
,
and
a
glass
bottle
that
might
hold
about
a
quarter
of
a
pint
of
smelling
-
salts
in
the
other
,
ready
for
any
emergency
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sanders
,
whose
eyes
were
intently
fixed
on
the
judge
's
face
,
planted
herself
close
by
,
with
the
large
umbrella
,
keeping
her
right
thumb
pressed
on
the
spring
with
an
earnest
countenance
,
as
if
she
were
fully
prepared
to
put
it
up
at
a
moment
's
notice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Cluppins
,
"
said
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
"
pray
compose
yourself
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Of
course
,
directly
Mrs
Cluppins
was
desired
to
compose
herself
,
she
sobbed
with
increased
vehemence
,
and
gave
divers
alarming
manifestations
of
an
approaching
fainting
fit
,
or
,
as
she
afterwards
said
,
of
her
feelings
being
too
many
for
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
recollect
,
Mrs
Cluppins
,
"
said
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
after
a
few
unimportant
questions
---
"
do
you
recollect
being
in
Mrs
Bardell
's
back
one
pair
of
stairs
,
on
one
particular
morning
in
July
last
,
when
she
was
dusting
Pickwick
's
apartment
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
Lord
and
jury
,
I
do
,
"
replied
Mrs
Cluppins
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
sitting
-
room
was
the
first
-
floor
front
,
I
believe
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
were
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Cluppins
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
were
you
doing
in
the
back
room
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
little
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
Lord
and
jury
,
"
said
Mrs
Cluppins
,
with
interesting
agitation
,
"
I
will
not
deceive
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
not
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
little
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
there
,
"
resumed
Mrs
Cluppins
,
"
unbeknown
to
Mrs
Bardell
;
I
had
been
out
with
a
little
basket
,
gentlemen
,
to
buy
three
pound
of
red
kidney
pertaties
,
which
was
three
pound
tuppence
ha'penny
,
when
I
see
Mrs
Bardell
's
street
door
on
the
jar
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
the
what
?
"
exclaimed
the
little
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Partly
open
,
my
Lord
,
"
said
Serjeant
Snubbin
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
said
on
the
jar
,
"
said
the
little
judge
,
with
a
cunning
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
the
same
,
my
Lord
,
"
said
Serjeant
Snubbin
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
judge
looked
doubtful
,
and
said
he
'd
make
a
note
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Cluppins
then
resumed
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
walked
in
,
gentlemen
,
just
to
say
good
-
mornin
'
,
and
went
,
in
a
permiscuous
manner
,
upstairs
,
and
into
the
back
room
.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
there
was
the
sound
of
voices
in
the
front
room
,
and
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
you
listened
,
I
believe
,
Mrs
Cluppins
?
"
said
Serjeant
Buzfuz
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beggin
'
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Cluppins
,
in
a
majestic
manner
,
"
I
would
scorn
the
haction
.
 
<EOS>
The
voices
was
very
loud
,
Sir
,
and
forced
themselves
upon
my
ear
,
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mrs
Cluppins
,
you
were
not
listening
,
but
you
heard
the
voices
.
 
<EOS>
Was
one
of
those
voices
Pickwick
's
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
were
,
Sir
.
"
<EOS>
And
Mrs
Cluppins
,
after
distinctly
stating
that
Mr
Pickwick
addressed
himself
to
Mrs
Bardell
,
repeated
by
slow
degrees
,
and
by
dint
of
many
questions
,
the
conversation
with
which
our
readers
are
already
acquainted
.
   
<EOS>
The
jury
looked
suspicious
,
and
Mr
Serjeant
Buzfuz
smiled
as
he
sat
down
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
positively
awful
when
Serjeant
Snubbin
intimated
that
he
should
not
cross
-
examine
the
witness
,
for
Mr
Pickwick
wished
it
to
be
distinctly
stated
that
it
was
due
to
her
to
say
,
that
her
account
was
in
substance
correct
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Cluppins
having
once
broken
the
ice
,
thought
it
a
favourable
opportunity
for
entering
into
a
short
dissertation
on
her
own
domestic
affairs
;
so
she
straightway
proceeded
to
inform
the
court
that
she
was
the
mother
of
eight
children
at
that
present
speaking
,
and
that
she
entertained
confident
expectations
of
presenting
Mr
Cluppins
with
a
ninth
,
somewhere
about
that
day
six
months
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
interesting
point
,
the
little
judge
interposed
most
irascibly
;
and
the
effect
of
the
interposition
was
,
that
both
the
worthy
lady
and
Mrs
Sanders
were
politely
taken
out
of
court
,
under
the
escort
of
Mr
Jackson
,
without
further
parley
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nathaniel
Winkle
!
"
said
Mr
Skimpin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
!
"
replied
a
feeble
voice
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
entered
the
witness
-
box
,
and
having
been
duly
sworn
,
bowed
to
the
judge
with
considerable
deference
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
look
at
me
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
judge
sharply
,
in
acknowledgment
of
the
salute
;
"
look
at
the
jury
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
obeyed
the
mandate
,
and
looked
at
the
place
where
he
thought
it
most
probable
the
jury
might
be
;
for
seeing
anything
in
his
then
state
of
intellectual
complication
was
wholly
out
of
the
question
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
was
then
examined
by
Mr
Skimpin
,
who
,
being
a
promising
young
man
of
two
or
three
-
and
-
forty
,
was
of
course
anxious
to
confuse
a
witness
who
was
notoriously
predisposed
in
favour
of
the
other
side
,
as
much
as
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpin
,
"
have
the
goodness
to
let
his
Lordship
know
what
your
name
is
,
will
you
?
"
<EOS>
and
Mr
Skimpin
inclined
his
head
on
one
side
to
listen
with
great
sharpness
to
the
answer
,
and
glanced
at
the
jury
meanwhile
,
as
if
to
imply
that
he
rather
expected
Mr
Winkle
's
natural
taste
for
perjury
would
induce
him
to
give
some
name
which
did
not
belong
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Winkle
,
"
replied
the
witness
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
Christian
name
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
angrily
inquired
the
little
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nathaniel
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Daniel
---
any
other
name
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nathaniel
,
sir
---
my
Lord
,
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nathaniel
Daniel
,
or
Daniel
Nathaniel
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
Lord
,
only
Nathaniel
---
not
Daniel
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
tell
me
it
was
Daniel
for
,
then
,
sir
?
"
inquired
the
judge
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
,
my
Lord
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
judge
,
with
a
severe
frown
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
could
I
have
got
Daniel
on
my
notes
,
unless
you
told
me
so
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
argument
was
,
of
course
,
unanswerable
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Winkle
has
rather
a
short
memory
,
my
Lord
,
"
interposed
Mr
Skimpin
,
with
another
glance
at
the
jury
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
find
means
to
refresh
it
before
we
have
quite
done
with
him
,
I
dare
say
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
be
careful
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
little
judge
,
with
a
sinister
look
at
the
witness
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Winkle
bowed
,
and
endeavoured
to
feign
an
easiness
of
manner
,
which
,
in
his
then
state
of
confusion
,
gave
him
rather
the
air
of
a
disconcerted
pickpocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Winkle
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpin
,
"
attend
to
me
,
if
you
please
,
Sir
;
and
let
me
recommend
you
,
for
your
own
sake
,
to
bear
in
mind
his
Lordship
's
injunctions
to
be
careful
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
you
are
a
particular
friend
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
the
defendant
,
are
you
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
known
Mr
Pickwick
now
,
as
well
as
I
recollect
at
this
moment
,
nearly
---
"
   
"
Pray
,
Mr
Winkle
,
do
not
evade
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
,
or
are
you
not
,
a
particular
friend
of
the
defendant
's
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
just
about
to
say
,
that
---
"
   
"
Will
you
,
or
will
you
not
,
answer
my
question
,
Sir
?
"
"
If
you
do
n't
answer
the
question
,
you
'll
be
committed
,
Sir
,
"
interposed
the
little
judge
,
looking
over
his
note
-
book
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpin
,
"
yes
<EOS>
or
no
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
And
why
could
n't
you
say
that
at
once
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
know
the
plaintiff
too
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
Mr
Winkle
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
her
;
I
've
seen
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
do
n't
know
her
,
but
you
've
seen
her
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
have
the
goodness
to
tell
the
gentlemen
of
the
jury
what
you
mean
by
that
,
Mr
Winkle
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
I
am
not
intimate
with
her
,
but
I
have
seen
her
when
I
went
to
call
on
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
Goswell
Street
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
often
have
you
seen
her
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
often
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Yes
,
Mr
Winkle
,
how
often
?
 
<EOS>
I
'll
repeat
the
question
for
you
a
dozen
times
,
if
you
require
it
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
learned
gentleman
,
with
a
firm
and
steady
frown
,
placed
his
hands
on
his
hips
,
and
smiled
suspiciously
to
the
jury
.
   
<EOS>
On
this
question
there
arose
the
edifying
brow
-
beating
,
customary
on
such
points
.
 
<EOS>
First
of
all
,
Mr
Winkle
said
it
was
quite
impossible
for
him
to
say
how
many
times
he
had
seen
Mrs
Bardell
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
was
asked
if
he
had
seen
her
twenty
times
,
to
which
he
replied
,
"
Certainly
---
more
than
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
he
was
asked
whether
he
had
n't
seen
her
a
hundred
times
---
whether
he
could
n't
swear
that
he
had
seen
her
more
than
fifty
times
---
whether
he
did
n't
know
that
he
had
seen
her
at
least
seventy
-
five
times
,
and
so
forth
;
the
satisfactory
conclusion
which
was
arrived
at
,
at
last
,
being
,
that
he
had
better
take
care
of
himself
,
and
mind
what
he
was
about
.
 
<EOS>
The
witness
having
been
by
these
means
reduced
to
the
requisite
ebb
of
nervous
perplexity
,
the
examination
was
continued
as
follows
---
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
Mr
Winkle
,
do
you
remember
calling
on
the
defendant
Pickwick
at
these
apartments
in
the
plaintiff
's
house
in
Goswell
Street
,
on
one
particular
morning
,
in
the
month
of
July
last
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Were
you
accompanied
on
that
occasion
by
a
friend
of
the
name
of
Tupman
,
and
another
by
the
name
of
Snodgrass
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
here
?
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
they
are
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
looking
very
earnestly
towards
the
spot
where
his
friends
were
stationed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
attend
to
me
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
never
mind
your
friends
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpin
,
with
another
expressive
look
at
the
jury
.
<EOS>
"
They
must
tell
their
stories
without
any
previous
consultation
with
you
,
if
none
has
yet
taken
place
(
another
look
at
the
jury
)
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Sir
,
tell
the
gentlemen
of
the
jury
what
you
saw
on
entering
the
defendant
's
room
,
on
this
particular
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Come
;
out
with
it
,
Sir
;
we
must
have
it
,
sooner
or
later
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
defendant
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
was
holding
the
plaintiff
in
his
arms
,
with
his
hands
clasping
her
waist
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
with
natural
hesitation
,
"
and
the
plaintiff
appeared
to
have
fainted
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
hear
the
defendant
say
anything
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
heard
him
call
Mrs
Bardell
a
good
creature
,
and
I
heard
him
ask
her
to
compose
herself
,
for
what
a
situation
it
was
,
if
anybody
should
come
,
or
words
to
that
effect
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Winkle
,
I
have
only
one
more
question
to
ask
you
,
and
I
beg
you
to
bear
in
mind
his
Lordship
's
caution
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
undertake
to
swear
that
Pickwick
,
the
defendant
,
did
not
say
on
the
occasion
in
question
---
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mrs
Bardell
,
you
're
a
good
creature
;
compose
yourself
to
this
situation
,
for
to
this
situation
you
must
come
,
"
or
words
to
that
effect
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
did
n't
understand
him
so
,
certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
astounded
on
this
ingenious
dove
-
tailing
of
the
few
words
he
had
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
on
the
staircase
,
and
could
n't
hear
distinctly
;
the
impression
on
my
mind
is
---
"
   
"
The
gentlemen
of
the
jury
want
none
of
the
impressions
on
your
mind
,
Mr
Winkle
,
which
I
fear
would
be
of
little
service
to
honest
,
straightforward
men
,
"
interposed
Mr
Skimpin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
on
the
staircase
,
and
did
n't
distinctly
hear
;
but
you
will
not
swear
that
Pickwick
did
not
make
use
of
the
expressions
I
have
quoted
?
 
<EOS>
Do
I
understand
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
will
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
;
and
down
sat
Mr
Skimpin
with
a
triumphant
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
case
had
not
gone
off
in
so
particularly
happy
a
manner
,
up
to
this
point
,
that
it
could
very
well
afford
to
have
any
additional
suspicion
cast
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
it
could
afford
to
be
placed
in
a
rather
better
light
,
if
possible
,
Mr
Phunky
rose
for
the
purpose
of
getting
something
important
out
of
Mr
Winkle
in
cross
-
examination
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
did
get
anything
important
out
of
him
,
will
immediately
appear
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
,
Mr
Winkle
,
"
said
Mr
Phunky
,
"
that
Mr
Pickwick
is
not
a
young
man
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
;
"
old
enough
to
be
my
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
told
my
learned
friend
that
you
have
known
Mr
Pickwick
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
Had
you
ever
any
reason
to
suppose
or
believe
that
he
was
about
to
be
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
;
certainly
not
;
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
with
so
much
eagerness
,
that
Mr
Phunky
ought
to
have
got
him
out
of
the
box
with
all
possible
dispatch
.
 
<EOS>
Lawyers
hold
that
there
are
two
kinds
of
particularly
bad
witnesses
---
a
reluctant
witness
,
and
a
too
-
willing
witness
;
it
was
Mr
Winkle
's
fate
to
figure
in
both
characters
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
even
go
further
than
this
,
Mr
Winkle
,
"
continued
Mr
Phunky
,
in
a
most
smooth
and
complacent

.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
see
anything
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
manner

towards
the
opposite
sex
,
to
induce
you
to
believe
that
he
ever
contemplated
matrimony
of
late
years
,
in
any
case
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
;
certainly
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Has
his
behaviour
,
when
females
have
been
in
the
case
,
always
been
that
of
a
man
,
who
,

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
---
yes
---
<EOS>
oh
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
"

,

;
for

was

.
   
<EOS>
"
N
-
n
-
no
,
"

,
"
except

one

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,

Mr

,

(

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,
"

;
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
Amid

,
Mr

out
,
that

of

was
Mr

's

a

's

-

at

;

had

,

,

!
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
did

,
and

with

to
the
George
and
Vulture
,
where
he

some

,

,

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
Tracy
Tupman
,
and
Augustus
Snodgrass
,
were
severally

into
the
box
;
both

the

of
their
unhappy
friend
;
and
each
was
driven
to
the
verge
of
desperation
by
excessive
badgering
.
<EOS>
Susannah
Sanders
was
then
called
,
and
examined
by
Serjeant
Buzfuz
,
and
cross
-
examined
by
Serjeant
Snubbin
.
 
<EOS>
Had
always
said
and
believed
that
Pickwick
would
marry
Mrs
Bardell
;
knew
that
Mrs
Bardell
's
being
engaged
to
Pickwick
was
the
current
topic
of
conversation
in
the
neighbourhood
,
after
the
fainting
in
July
;
had
been
told
it
herself
by
Mrs
Mudberry
which
kept
a
mangle
,
and
Mrs
Bunkin
which
clear
-
starched
,
but
did
not
see
either
Mrs
Mudberry
or
Mrs
Bunkin
in
court
.
 
<EOS>
Had
heard
Pickwick
ask
the
little
boy
how
he
should
like
to
have
another
father
.
 
<EOS>
Did
not
know
that
Mrs
Bardell
was
at
that
time
keeping
company
with
the
baker
,
but
did
know
that
the
baker
was
then
a
single
man
and
is
now
married
.
 
<EOS>
Could
n't
swear
that
Mrs
Bardell
was
not
very
fond
of
the
baker
,
but
should
think
that
the
baker
was
not

of
Mrs
Bardell
,
or
he
would
n't
have
married
somebody
else
.
 
<EOS>
Thought
Mrs
Bardell
fainted
away
on
the
morning
in
July
,
because
Pickwick
asked
her
to
name

day
:
knew
that
she
(
witness
)
fainted
away
stone
dead
when
Mr
Sanders
asked

to
name
the
day
,
and
believed
that
everybody
as
called
herself
a

,

.
<EOS>
Heard

ask

boy
the
question
about
the

,
but
upon
her
oath
did
not
know

difference
between
an
"
alley
tor
"
and

"
commoney
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
the
COURT
.
<EOS>
---
During
the
period
of
her
keeping
company
with
Mr
Sanders
,
had
received
love
letters
,
like
other
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
course

their
correspondence
<EOS>
Mr
Sanders
had
often
called
her
a
"
duck
,
"
but
never
"
chops
,
"
nor
yet
"
tomato

.
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
particularly

of

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps

as

and

,

called

<EOS>
that
,
as

.
   
<EOS>
Serjeant

now
rose
with

,
if

,

;
"
Call
Samuel
Weller
.
"
   
<EOS>
It

;
for
Samuel
Weller
stepped

;

,

.

"

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
Weller
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Usher

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

,

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

,

.

"

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

?

,

.
 
<EOS>

wos

.

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
Sir
,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Mr

-

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

and
Mr

were
too
much

by

's

to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
had
not

of

at

,
to

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said

,
"

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
think
none
of
us
have

there
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody
had
;
and
as
the
proposition
was
warmly
seconded
by
Perker
,
who
considered
it
extremely
probable
that
if
Mr
Pickwick
saw
a
little

and

he
would
be
inclined
to
think
better
of
his
determination
,
and
worse
of
a
debtor
's
prison
,
it
was
carried
unanimously
;
and
Sam
was
at
once
despatched
to
the
White
Horse
Cellar
,
to
take
five
places
by
the
half
-
past
seven
o'clock
coach
,
next
morning
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
just
two
places
to
be
had
inside
,
and
just
three
to
be
had
out
;
so
Sam
Weller
booked
for
them
all
,
and
having
exchanged
a
few
compliments
with
the
booking
-
office
clerk
on
the
subject
of
a
pewter
half
-
crown
which
was
tendered
him
as
a
portion
of
his
"
change
,
"
walked
back
to
the
George
and
Vulture
,
where
he
was
pretty
busily
employed
until
bed
-
time
in
reducing
clothes
and
linen
into
the
smallest
possible
compass
,
and
exerting
his
mechanical
genius
in
constructing
a
variety
of
ingenious
devices
for
keeping
the
lids
on
boxes
which
had
neither
locks
nor
hinges
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
was
a
very
unpropitious
morning
for
a
journey
---
muggy
,
damp
,
and
drizzly
.
 
<EOS>
The
horses
in
the
stages
that
were
going
out
,
and
had
come
through
the
city
,
were
smoking
so
,
that
the
outside
passengers
were
invisible
.
 
<EOS>
The
newspaper
-
sellers
looked
moist
,
and
smelled
mouldy
;
the
wet
ran
off
the
hats
of
the
orange
-
vendors
as
they
thrust
their
heads
into
the
coach
windows
,
and
diluted
the
insides
in
a
refreshing
manner
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jews
with
the
fifty
-
bladed
penknives
shut
them
up
in
despair
;
the
men
with
the
pocket
-
books
made
pocket
-
books
of
them
.
<EOS>
Watch
-
guards
and
toasting
-
forks
were
alike
at
a
discount
,
and
pencil
-
cases
and
sponges
were
a
drug
in
the
market
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving
Sam
Weller
to
rescue
the
luggage
from
the
seven
or
eight
porters
who
flung
themselves
savagely
upon
it
,
the
moment
the
coach
stopped
,
and
finding
that
they
were
about
twenty
minutes
too
early
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
went
for
shelter
into
the
travellers
"
room
---
the
last
resource
of
human
dejection
.
   
<EOS>
The
travellers
"
room
at
the
White
Horse
Cellar
is
of
course
uncomfortable
;
it
would
be
no
travellers
"
room
if
it
were
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
right
-
hand
parlour
,
into
which
an
aspiring
kitchen
fireplace
appears
to
have
walked
,
accompanied
by
a
rebellious
poker
,
tongs
,
and
shovel
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
divided
into
boxes
,
for
the
solitary
confinement
of
travellers
,
and
is
furnished
with
a
clock
,
a
looking
-
glass
,
and
a
live
waiter
,
which
latter
article
is
kept
in
a
small
kennel
for
washing
glasses
,
in
a
corner
of
the
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
One
of
these
boxes
was
occupied
,
on
this
particular
occasion
,
by
a
stern
-
eyed
man
of
about
five
-
and
-
forty
,
who
had
a
bald
and
glossy
forehead
,
with
a
good
deal
of
black
hair
at
the
sides
and
back
of
his
head
,
and
large
black
whiskers
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
buttoned
up
to
the
chin
in
a
brown
coat
;
and
had
a
large
sealskin
travelling
-
cap
,
and
a
greatcoat
and
cloak
,
lying
on
the
seat
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
up
from
his
breakfast
as
Mr
Pickwick
entered
,
with
a
fierce
and
peremptory
air
,
which
was
very
dignified
;
and
,
having
scrutinised
that
gentleman
and
his
companions
to
his
entire
satisfaction
,
hummed
a
tune
,
in
a
manner
which
seemed
to
say
that
he
rather
suspected
somebody
wanted
to
take
advantage
of
him
,
but
it
would
n't
do
.
   
<EOS>
"
Waiter
,
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
whiskers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
?
"
replied
a
man
with
a
dirty
complexion
,
and
a
towel
of
the
same
,
emerging
from
the
kennel
before
mentioned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Some
more
toast
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Buttered
toast
,
mind
,
"
said
the
gentleman
fiercely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Directly
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
with
the
whiskers
hummed
a
tune
in
the
same
manner
as
before
,
and
pending
the
arrival
of
the
toast
,
advanced
to
the
front
of
the
fire
,
and
,
taking
his
coat
tails
under
his
arms
,
looked
at
his
boots
and
ruminated
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whereabouts
in
Bath
this
coach
puts
up
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
mildly
addressing
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
---
<EOS>
eh
---
what
's
that
?
"
said
the
strange
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
made
an
observation
to
my
friend
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
always
ready
to
enter
into
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wondered
at
what
house
the
Bath
coach
put
up
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
can
inform
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
Bath
?
"
said
the
strange
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
those
other
gentlemen
?
"
   
"
They
are
going
also
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
inside
---
I
'll
be
damned
if
you
're
going
inside
,
"
said
the
strange
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
all
of
us
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
all
of
you
,
"
said
the
strange
man
emphatically
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
taken
two
places
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
try
to
squeeze
six
people
into
an
infernal
box
that
only
holds
four
,
I
'll
take
a
post
-
chaise
and
bring
an
action
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
paid
my
fare
.
 
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
do
;
I
told
the
clerk
when
I
took
my
places
that
it
would
n't
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
these
things
have
been
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
they
are
done
every
day
;
but
I
never
was
done
,
and
I
never
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
know
me
best
,
best
know
it
;
crush
me
!
"
<EOS>
Here
the
fierce
gentleman
rang
the
bell
with
great
violence
,
and
told
the
waiter
he
'd
better
bring
the
toast
in
five
seconds
,
or
he
'd
know
the
reason
why
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
good
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
you
will
allow
me
to
observe
that
this
is
a
very
unnecessary
display
of
excitement
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
only
taken
places
inside
for
two
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
said
the
fierce
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
withdraw
my
expressions
.
 
<EOS>
I
tender
an
apology
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
my
card
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
your
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
great
pleasure
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
to
be
fellow
-
travellers
,
and
I
hope
we
shall
find
each
other
's
society
mutually
agreeable
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
we
shall
,
"
said
the
fierce
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
we
shall
.
<EOS>
I
like
your
looks
;
they
please
me
.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
your
hands
and
names
.
 
<EOS>
Know
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Of
course
,
an
interchange
of
friendly
salutations
followed
this
gracious
speech
;
and
the
fierce
gentleman
immediately
proceeded
to
inform
the
friends
,
in
the
same
short
,
abrupt
,
jerking
sentences
,
that
his
name
was
Dowler
;
that
he
was
going
to
Bath
on
pleasure
;
that
he
was
formerly
in
the
army
;
that
he
had
now
set
up
in
business
as
a
gentleman
;
that
he
lived
upon
the
profits
;
and
that
the
individual
for
whom
the
second
place
was
taken
,
was
a
personage
no
less
illustrious
than
Mrs
Dowler
,
his
lady
wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
fine
woman
,
"
said
Mr
Dowler
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
proud
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
reason
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
have
the
pleasure
of
judging
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
,
"
replied
Dowler
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
shall
know
you
.
 
<EOS>
She
shall
esteem
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
courted
her
under
singular
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
I
won
her
through
a
rash
vow
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
her
;
I
loved
her
;
I
proposed
;
she
refused
me
.
<EOS>
---
"
You
love
another
?
"
<EOS>
---
"
Spare
my
blushes
.
"
<EOS>
---
"
I
know
him
.
"
<EOS>
---
"
You
do
.
"
<EOS>
---
"
Very
good
;
if
he
remains
here
,
I
'll
skin
him
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lord
bless
me
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
involuntarily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
skin
the
gentleman
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
with
a
very
pale
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wrote
him
a
note
,
I
said
it
was
a
painful
thing
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
interposed
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
said
I
had
pledged
my
word
as
a
gentleman
to
skin
him
.
 
<EOS>
My
character
was
at
stake
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
alternative
.
 
<EOS>
As
an
officer
in
His
Majesty
's
service
,
I
was
bound
to
skin
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
regretted
the
necessity
,
but
it
must
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
open
to
conviction
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
that
the
rules
of
the
service
were
imperative
.
 
<EOS>
He
fled
.
 
<EOS>
I
married
her
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
her
head
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Dowler
concluded
,
he
pointed
to
a
stage
which
had
just
driven
up
,
from
the
open
window
of
which
a
rather
pretty
face
in
a
bright
blue
bonnet
was
looking
among
the
crowd
on
the
pavement
,
most
probably
for
the
rash
man
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dowler
paid
his
bill
,
and
hurried
out
with
his
travelling
cap
,
coat
,
and
cloak
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
followed
to
secure
their
places
.
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr
Snodgrass
had
seated

at
the
back

of
the
coach
;
Mr
Winkle
had
got
inside
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
was
preparing
to
follow
him
,
when
Sam
Weller
came
up
to
his
master
,
and
whispering
in
his
ear
,
begged
to
speak
to
him
,
with
an
air
of
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
<EOS>
what
's
the
matter
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
rayther
a
rum
go
,

,
"

Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"

Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
This

,
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
wery

afeerd
,

,
that
the
properiator
o
'
<EOS>
this
here
coach
is
a

'
some

vith

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
Sam
?
"

;
"
are

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,

,
"

,
"
but

'em
up
,

o
'

.
"
<EOS>
As

,

that

on
which
the

usually

and

,

,

,

of
PICKWICK
!
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,

;
"
what

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
that
ai
n't
all
,
"
said
Sam
,

's

;
"
not

vith
writin
'
up
<EOS>
"
Pickwick
,
"
they
puts
"
Moses
"
afore

,
vich
I
call
addin

,
as

ven
they
not

took
him
from

,
but
made

talk
the
English
langwidge
arterwards
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
odd
enough
,
certainly
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
but
if
we
stand

here
,
we
shall
lose

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
,
ai
n't
nothin'
to
be
done
in

,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Sam
,
perfectly
aghast
at
the
coolness
with
which
Mr
Pickwick
prepared
to
ensconce

inside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Done
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
should
be
done
?
"
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
nobody
to
be
whopped
for
takin
'
this
here

,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
who

least

would

been

to

guard
and

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
eagerly
;
"
not
on
any
account
.
 
<EOS>
Jump
up
to
your
seat
directly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
wery
much
afeered
,
"
muttered
Sam
to
himself
,
as
he
turned
away
,
"
that
somethin'
queer
's
come
over
the
governor
,
or
he
'd
never
ha
'
stood
this
so
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
that
'
ere
trial
has
n't
broke
his
spirit
,
but
it
looks
bad
,
wery
bad
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
shook
his
head
gravely
;
and
it
is
worthy
of
remark
,
as
an
illustration
of
the
manner
in
which
he
took
this
circumstance
to
heart
,
that
he
did
not
speak
another
word
until
the
coach
reached
the
Kensington
turnpike
.
 
<EOS>
Which
was
so
long
a
time
for
him
to
remain
taciturn
,
that
the
fact
may
be
considered
wholly
unprecedented
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
worthy
of
special
mention
occurred
during
the
journey
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dowler
related
a
variety
of
anecdotes
,
all
illustrative
of
his
own
personal
prowess
and
desperation
,
and
appealed
to
Mrs
Dowler
in
corroboration
thereof
;
when
Mrs
Dowler
invariably
brought
in
,
in
the
form
of
an
appendix
,
some
remarkable
fact
or
circumstance
which
Mr
Dowler
had
forgotten
,
or
had
perhaps
through
modesty
,
omitted
;
for
the
addenda
in
every
instance
went
to
show
that
Mr
Dowler
was
even
a
more
wonderful
fellow
than
he
made
himself
out
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Winkle
listened
with
great
admiration
,
and
at
intervals
conversed
with
Mrs
Dowler
,
who
was
a
very
agreeable
and
fascinating
person
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
what
between
Mr
Dowler
's
stories
,
and
Mrs
Dowler
's
charms
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
's
good
-
humour
,
and
Mr
Winkle
's
good
listening
,
the
insides
contrived
to
be
very
companionable
all
the
way
.
<EOS>
The
outsides
did
as
outsides
always
do
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
very
cheerful
and
talkative
at
the
beginning
of
every
stage
,
and
very
dismal
and
sleepy
in
the
middle
,
and
very
bright
and
wakeful
again
towards
the
end
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
young
gentleman
in
an
India
-
rubber
cloak
,
who
smoked
cigars
all
day
;
and
there
was
another
young
gentleman
in
a
parody
upon
a
greatcoat
,
who
lighted
a
good
many
,
and
feeling
obviously
unsettled
after
the
second
whiff
,
threw
them
away
when
he
thought
nobody
was
looking
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
third
young
man
on
the
box
who
wished
to
be
learned
in
cattle
;
and
an
old
one
behind
,
who
was
familiar
with
farming
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
constant
succession
of
Christian
names
in
smock
-
frocks
and
white
coats
,
who
were
invited
to
have
a
"
lift
"
by
the
guard
,
and
who
knew
every
horse
and
hostler
on
the
road
and
off

;
and
there
was
a
dinner
which
would
have
been
cheap
at
half
-
a
-
crown
a
mouth
,
if
any
moderate
number
of
mouths
could
have
eaten
it
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
And
at
seven
o'clock
PM
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
,
and
Mr
Dowler
and

wife
,

at

White
Hart

,

Great
Pump
Room
,
Bath
,
where

,
from

,
might

Westminster

,
only

destroy

by

.
<EOS>
Breakfast

on

,
when
a

in

's

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

of

,

in

,

,
and
the
thinnest

.
 
<EOS>
A
gold
eye
-
glass
was
suspended
from
his

by
a
short
,
broad
,
black
ribbon
;
a
gold
snuff
-
box
was
lightly

in
his
left

;
gold
rings
innumerable
glittered
on
his
fingers
;
and
a
large
diamond

in

glistened
in

shirt

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
gold
watch
,
and
a
gold
curb
chain
with
large
gold
seals
;
and
he
carried
a
pliant
ebony

with
a
gold
top
.
 
<EOS>
His
linen
was
of
the
very
whitest
,
finest
,
and
stiffest
;
his
wig
of
the
glossiest
,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
His

was
princes
"
mixture
;
his
scent
BOUQUET
DU
ROI
.
 
<EOS>
His

were
contracted

;
and

were
in

that

.

.

,

"
<EOS>

a

<EOS>
Sam

<EOS>

winked
,
shook
his
head
,
smiled
,
winked
again
;
<EOS>
and
,
with
an
expression
of
countenance
which
seemed
to
denote
that
he
was
greatly
amused
with
something
or
other
,
walked
merrily
away
.
   
<EOS>
At
precisely
twenty
minutes
before
eight
o'clock
that
night
,
Angelo
Cyrus
Bantam
,
Esq
.
,
the
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
,
emerged
from
his
chariot
at
the
door
of
the
Assembly
Rooms
in
the
same
wig
,
the
same
teeth
,
the
same
eye
-
glass
,
the
same
watch
and
seals
,
the
same
rings
,
the
same
shirt
-
pin
,
and
the
same
cane
.
<EOS>
The
only
observable
alterations
in
his
appearance
were
,
that
he
wore
a
brighter
blue
coat
,
with
a
white
silk
lining
,
black
tights
,
black
silk
stockings
,
and
pumps
,
and
a
white
waistcoat
,
and
was
,
if
possible
,
just
a
thought
more
scented
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
attired
,
the
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
,
in
strict
discharge
of
the
important
duties
of
his
all
-
important
office
,
planted
himself
in
the
room
to
receive
the
company
.
   
<EOS>
Bath
being
full
,
the
company
,
and
the
sixpences
for
tea
,
poured
in
,
in
shoals
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
ballroom
,
the
long
card
-
room
,
the
octagonal
card
-
room
,
the
staircases
,
and
the
passages
,
the
hum
of
many
voices
,
and
the
sound
of
many
feet
,
were
perfectly
bewildering
.
 
<EOS>
Dresses
rustled
,
feathers
waved
,
lights
shone
,
and
jewels
sparkled
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
music
---
not
of
the
quadrille
band
,
for
it
had
not
yet
commenced
;
but
the
music
of
soft
,
tiny
footsteps
,
with
now
and
then
a
clear
,
merry
laugh
---
low
and
gentle
,
but
very
pleasant
to
hear
in
a
female
voice
,
whether
in
Bath
or
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
Brilliant
eyes
,
lighted
up
with
pleasurable
expectation
,
gleamed
from
every
side
;
and
,
look
where
you
would
,
some
exquisite
form
glided
gracefully
through
the
throng
,
and
was
no
sooner
lost
,
than
it
was
replaced
by
another
as
dainty
and
bewitching
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
tea
-
room
,
and
hovering
round
the
card
-
tables
,
were
a
vast
number
of
queer
old
ladies
,
and
decrepit
old
gentlemen
,
discussing
all
the
small
talk
and
scandal
of
the
day
,
with
a
relish
and
gusto
which
sufficiently
bespoke
the
intensity
of
the
pleasure
they
derived
from
the
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
Mingled
with
these
groups
,
were
three
or
four
match
-
making
mammas
,
appearing
to
be
wholly
absorbed
by
the
conversation
in
which
they
were
taking
part
,
but
failing
not
from
time
to
time
to
cast
an
anxious
sidelong
glance
upon
their
daughters
,
who
,
remembering
the
maternal
injunction
to
make
the
best
use
of
their
youth
,
had
already
commenced
incipient
flirtations
in
the
mislaying
scarves
,
putting
on
gloves
,
setting
down
cups
,
and
so
forth
;
slight
matters
apparently
,
but
which
may
be
turned
to
surprisingly
good
account
by
expert
practitioners
.
   
<EOS>
Lounging
near
the
doors
,
and
in
remote
corners
,
were
various
knots
of
silly
young
men
,
displaying
various
varieties
of
puppyism
and
stupidity
;
amusing
all
sensible
people
near
them
with
their
folly
and
conceit
;
and
happily
thinking
themselves
the
objects
of
general
admiration
---
a
wise
and
merciful
dispensation
which
no
good
man
will
quarrel
with
.
   
<EOS>
And
lastly
,
seated
on
some
of
the
back
benches
,
where
they
had
already
taken
up
their
positions
for
the
evening
,
were
divers
unmarried
ladies
past
their
grand
climacteric
,
who
,
not
dancing
because
there
were
no
partners
for
them
,
and
not
playing
cards
lest
they
should
be
set
down
as
irretrievably
single
,
were
in
the
favourable
situation
of
being
able
to
abuse
everybody
without
reflecting
on
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
they
could
abuse
everybody
,
because
everybody
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
scene
of
gaiety
,
glitter
,
and
show
;
of
richly
-
dressed
people
,
handsome
mirrors
,
chalked
floors
,
girandoles
and
wax
-
candles
;
and
in
all
parts
of
the
scene
,
gliding
from
spot
to
spot
in
silent
softness
,
bowing
obsequiously
to
this
party
,
nodding
familiarly
to
that
,
and
smiling
complacently
on
all
,
was
the
sprucely
-
attired
person
of
Angelo
Cyrus
Bantam
,
Esquire
,
the
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
in
the
tea
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
sixpenn'orth
.
 
<EOS>
Then
lay
on
hot
water
,
and
call
it
tea
.
 
<EOS>
Drink
it
,
"
said
Mr
Dowler
,
in
a
loud
voice
,
directing
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
advanced
at
the
head
of
the
little
party
,
with
Mrs
Dowler
on
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Into
the
tea
-
room
Mr
Pickwick
turned
;
and
catching
sight
of
him
,
Mr
Bantam
corkscrewed
his
way
through
the
crowd
and
welcomed
him
with
ecstasy
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Sir
,
I
am
highly
honoured
.
 
<EOS>
Ba
-
ath
is
favoured
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Dowler
,
you
embellish
the
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
I
congratulate
you
on
your
feathers
.
 
<EOS>
Re
-
markable
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Anybody
here
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Dowler
suspiciously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anybody
!
 
<EOS>
The
ELITE
of
Ba
-
ath
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
do
you
see
the
old
lady
in
the
gauze
turban
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
fat
old
lady
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
innocently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
my
dear
sir
---
<EOS>
nobody
's
fat
or
old
in
Ba
-
ath
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
Dowager
Lady
Snuphanuph
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
indeed
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
less
a
person
,
I
assure

,
"
said
the
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
.
<EOS>
"
Hush
.
 
<EOS>
Draw
a
little
nearer
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
the
splendidly
-
dressed
young
man
coming
this

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
one
with
the
long
hair
,
and
the
particularly
small
forehead
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
same
.
 
<EOS>
The
richest
young
man
in
Ba
-
ath
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
Young
Lord
Mutanhed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say

?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
hear
his
voice
in
a

,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
speak
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
gentleman
with
him
,
in
the
red
under
-
waistcoat
and
dark

,
is
the
Honourable
Mr
Crushton
,
his
bosom
friend
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
my
Lord
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Veway
hot
,
Bantam
,
"
said
his
Lordship
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
IS
very
warm
,
my
Lord
,
"
replied
the
M*C.
   
"
Confounded
,
"
assented
the
Honourable
Mr
Crushton
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
his
Lordship
's
mail
-
cart
,
Bantam
?
<EOS>
"
inquired

Honourable
Mr
Crushton
,
after

,
during

young
Lord
Mutanhed
had

Mr
Pickwick
out
of

,
and
Mr
Crushton
had
been
reflecting
what
subject
his
Lordship
could
talk
about
best
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
no
,
"
replied
the
M*C.
"
A
mail
-
cart
!
 
<EOS>
What
an
excellent
idea
.
 
<EOS>
Re
-
markable
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gwacious
heavens
!
<EOS>
"
said
his
Lordship
,
"
I
thought
evewebody
had
seen
the
new
mail
-
cart
;
it
's
the
neatest
,
pwettiest
,
gwacefullest
thing
that
ever
wan
upon

.
 
<EOS>
Painted
we
d
,
with
a
cweam
piebald
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
a
real
box
for
the

,
and
all

,
"
said

Mr
Crushton
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
a
little
seat
in
fwont
,
with
an
iwon
wail
,
for
the
dwiver
,
"
added
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dwove
it
over
to
Bwistol
the
other
morning
,
in
a
cwimson
coat
,
with
two
servants
widing
a
quarter
of
a
mile
behind
;
and
confound
me
if
the
people
did
n't
wush
out
of
their
