,
and
awest
my
pwogwess
,
to
know
if
I
was
n't
the
post
.
 
<EOS>
Glorwious
---
glorwious
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
anecdote
his
Lordship
laughed
very
heartily
,
as
did
the
listeners
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
drawing
his
arm
through
that
of
the
obsequious
Mr
Crushton
,
Lord
Mutanhed
walked
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Delightful
young
man
,
his
Lordship
,
"
said
the
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
should
think
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
drily
.
   
<EOS>
The
dancing
having
commenced
,
the
necessary
introductions
having
been
made
,
and
all
preliminaries
arranged
,
Angelo
Bantam
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
led
him
into
the
card
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
Just
at
the
very
moment
of
their
entrance
,
the
Dowager
Lady
Snuphanuph
and
two
other
ladies
of
an
ancient
and
whist
-
like
appearance
,
were
hovering
over
an
unoccupied
card
-
table
;
and
they
no
sooner
set
eyes
upon
Mr
Pickwick
under
the
convoy
of
Angelo
Bantam
,
than
they
exchanged
glances
with
each
other
,
seeing
that
he
was
precisely
the
very
person
they
wanted
,
to
make
up
the
rubber
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Bantam
,
"
said
the
Dowager
Lady
Snuphanuph
coaxingly
,
"
find
us
some
nice
creature
to
make
up
this
table
;
there
's
a
good
soul
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
happened
to
be
looking
another
way
at
the
moment
,
so
her
Ladyship
nodded
her
head
towards
him
,
and
frowned
expressively
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
friend
Mr
Pickwick
,
my
Lady
,
will
be
most
happy
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
remarkably
so
,
"
said
the
M*C
,
taking
the
hint
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
,
Lady
Snuphanuph
---
<EOS>
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
---
Miss
Bolo
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
bowed
to
each
of
the
ladies
,
and
,
finding
escape
impossible
,
cut
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
Miss
Bolo
against
Lady
Snuphanuph
and
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
.
<EOS>
As
the
trump
card
was
turned
up
,
at
the
commencement
of
the
second
deal
,
two
young
ladies
hurried
into
the
room
,
and
took
their
stations
on
either
side
of
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
's
chair
,
where
they
waited
patiently
until
the
hand
was
over
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Jane
,
"
said
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
,
turning
to
one
of
the
girls
,
"
what
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
came
to
ask
,
ma
,
whether
I
might
dance
with
the
youngest
Mr
Crawley
,
"
whispered
the
prettier
and
younger
of
the
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
God
,
Jane
,
how
can
you
think
of
such
things
?
"
replied
the
mamma
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
n't
you
repeatedly
heard
that
his
father
has
eight
hundred
a
year
,
which
dies
with
him
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
Not
on
any
account
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ma
,
"
whispered
the
other
,
who
was
much
older
than
her
sister
,
and
very
insipid
and
artificial
,
"
Lord
Mutanhed
has
been
introduced
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
I
thought
I
was
n't
engaged
,
ma
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
sweet
pet
,
my
love
,
"
replied
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
,
tapping
her
daughter
's
cheek
with
her
fan
,
"
and
are
always
to
be
trusted
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
immensely
rich
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
With
these
words
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
kissed
her
eldest
daughter
most
affectionately
,
and
frowning
in
a
warning
manner
upon
the
other
,
sorted
her
cards
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Pickwick
!
<EOS>
he
had
never
played
with
three
thorough
-
paced
female
card
-
players
before
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
so
desperately
sharp
,
that
they
quite
frightened
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
played
a
wrong
card
,
Miss
Bolo
looked
a
small
armoury
of
daggers
;
if
he
stopped
to
consider
which
was
the
right
one
,
Lady
Snuphanuph
would
throw
herself
back
in
her
chair
,
and
smile
with
a
mingled
glance
of
impatience
and
pity
to
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
,
at
which
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
would
shrug
up
her
shoulders
,
and
cough
,
as
much
as
to
say
she
wondered
whether
he
ever
would
begin
.
<EOS>
Then
,
at
the
end
of
every
hand
,
Miss
Bolo
would
inquire
with
a
dismal
countenance
and
reproachful
sigh
,
why
Mr
Pickwick
had
not
returned
that
diamond
,
or
led
the
club
,
or
roughed
the
spade
,
or
finessed
the
heart
,
or
led
through
the
honour
,
or
brought
out
the
ace
,
or
played
up
to
the
king
,
or
some
such
thing
;
and
in
reply
to
all
these
grave
charges
,
Mr
Pickwick
would
be
wholly
unable
to
plead
any
justification
whatever
,
having
by
this
time
forgotten
all
about
the
game
.
 
<EOS>
People
came
and
looked
on
,
too
,
which
made
Mr
Pickwick
nervous
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
all
this
,
there
was
a
great
deal
of
distracting
conversation
near
the
table
,
between
Angelo
Bantam
and
the
two
Misses
Matinter
,
who
,
being
single
and
singular
,
paid
great
court
to
the
Master
of
the
Ceremonies
,
in
the
hope
of
getting
a
stray
partner
now
and
then
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
things
,
combined
with
the
noises
and
interruptions
of
constant
comings
in
and
goings
out
,
made
Mr
Pickwick
play
rather
badly
;
the
cards
were
against
him
,
also
;
and
when
they
left
off
at
ten
minutes
past
eleven
,
Miss
Bolo
rose
from
the
table
considerably
agitated
,
and
went
straight
home
,
in
a
flood
of
tears
and
a
sedan
-
chair
.
   
<EOS>
Being
joined
by
his
friends
,
who
one
and
all
protested
that
they
had
scarcely
ever
spent
a
more
pleasant
evening
,
Mr
Pickwick
accompanied
them
to
the
White
Hart
,
and
having
soothed
his
feelings
with
something
hot
,
went
to
bed
,
and
to
sleep
,
almost
simultaneously
.
    
Chapter
36
.
<EOS>
The
chief
features
of
which
will
be
found
to
be
an
authentic
version
of
the
Legend
of
Prince
Bladud
,
and
a
most
extraordinary
calamity
that
befell
Mr
Winkle
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
contemplated
a
stay
of
at
least
two
months
in
Bath
,
he
deemed
it
advisable
to
take
private
lodgings
for
himself
and
friends
for
that
period
;
and
as
a
favourable
opportunity
offered
for
their
securing
,
on
moderate
terms
,
the
upper
portion
of
a
house
in
the
Royal
Crescent
,
which
was
larger
than
they
required
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Dowler
offered
to
relieve
them
of
a
bedroom
and
sitting
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
This
proposition
was
at
once
accepted
,
and
in
three
days
"
time
they
were
all
located
in
their
new
abode
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
began
to
drink
the
waters
with
the
utmost
assiduity
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
took
them
systematically
.
 
<EOS>
He
drank
a
quarter
of
a
pint
before
breakfast
,
and
then
walked
up
a
hill
;
and
another
quarter
of
a
pint
after
breakfast
,
and
then
walked
down
a
hill
;
and
,
after
every
fresh
quarter
of
a
pint
,
Mr
Pickwick
declared
,
in
the
most
solemn
and
emphatic
terms
,
that
he
felt
a
great
deal
better
;
whereat
his
friends
were
very
much
delighted
,
though
they
had
not
been
previously
aware
that
there
was
anything
the
matter
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
Great
Pump
Room
is
a
spacious
saloon
,
ornamented
with
Corinthian
pillars
,
and
a
music
-
gallery
,
and
a
Tompion
clock
,
and
a
statue
of
Nash
,
and
a
golden
inscription
,
to
which
all
the
water
-
drinkers
should
attend
,
for
it
appeals
to
them
in
the
cause
of
a
deserving
charity
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
large
bar
with
a
marble
vase
,
out
of
which
the
pumper
gets
the
water
;
and
there
are
a
number
of
yellow
-
looking
tumblers
,
out
of
which
the
company
get
it
;
and
it
is
a
most
edifying
and
satisfactory
sight
to
behold
the
perseverance
and
gravity
with
which
they
swallow
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
baths
near
at
hand
,
in
which
a
part
of
the
company
wash
themselves
;
and
a
band
plays
afterwards
,
to
congratulate
the
remainder
on
their
having
done
so
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
another
pump
room
,
into
which
infirm
ladies
and
gentlemen
are
wheeled
,
in
such
an
astonishing
variety
of
chairs
and
chaises
,
that
any
adventurous
individual
who
goes
in
with
the
regular
number
of
toes
,
is
in
imminent
danger
of
coming
out
without
them
;
and
there
is
a
third
,
into
which
the
quiet
people
go
,
<EOS>
for
it
is
less
noisy
than
either
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
immensity
of
promenading
,
on
crutches
and
off
,
with
sticks
and
without
,
and
a
great
deal
of
conversation
,
and
liveliness
,
and
pleasantry
.
   
<EOS>
Every
morning
,
the
regular
water
-
drinkers
,
Mr
Pickwick
among
the
number
,
met
each
other
in
the
pump
room
,
took
their
quarter
of
a
pint
,
and
walked
constitutionally
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
afternoon
's
promenade
,
Lord
Mutanhed
,
and
the
Honourable
Mr
Crushton
,
the
Dowager
Lady
Snuphanuph
,
Mrs
Colonel
Wugsby
,
and
all
the
great
people
,
and
all
the
morning
water
-
drinkers
,
met
in
grand
assemblage
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
,
they
walked
out
,
or
drove
out
,
or
were
pushed
out
in
bath
-
chairs
,
and
met
one
another
again
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
,
the
gentlemen
went
to
the
reading
-
rooms
,
and
met
divisions
of
the
mass
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
,
they
went
home
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
were
theatre
-
night
,
perhaps
they
met
at
the
theatre
;
if
it
were
assembly
-
night
,
they
met
at
the
rooms
;
and
if
it
were
neither
,
they
met
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
A
very
pleasant
routine
,
with
perhaps
a
slight
tinge
of
sameness
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
sitting
up
by
himself
,
after
a
day
spent
in
this
manner
,
making
entries
in
his
journal
,
his
friends
having
retired
to
bed
,
when
he
was
roused
by
a
gentle
tap
at
the
room
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Craddock
,
the
landlady
,
peeping
in
;
"
but
did
you
want
anything
more
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
young
girl
is
gone
to
bed
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Craddock
;
"
and
Mr
Dowler
is
good
enough
to
say
that
he
'll
sit
up
for
Mrs
Dowler
,
as
the
party
is
n't
expected
to
be
over
till
late
<EOS>
;
so
I
was
thinking
that
if
you
wanted
nothing
more
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
would
go
to
bed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
<EOS>
Wish
you
good
-
night
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Craddock
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
,
ma'am
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Craddock
closed
the
door
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
resumed
his
writing
.
   
<EOS>
In
half
an
hour
's
time
the
entries
were
concluded
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
carefully
rubbed
the
last
page
on
the
blotting
-
paper
,
shut
up
the
book
,
wiped
his
pen
on
the
bottom
of
the
inside
of
his
coat
tail
,
and
opened
the
drawer
of
the
inkstand
to
put
it
carefully
away
.
<EOS>
There
were
a
couple
of
sheets
of
writing
-
paper
,
pretty
closely
written
over
,
in
the
inkstand
drawer
,
and
they
were
folded
so
,
that
the
title
,
which
was
in
a
good
round
hand
,
was
fully
disclosed
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
from
this
,
that
it
was
no
private
document
;
and
as
it
seemed
to
relate
to
Bath
,
and
was
very
short
:
Mr
Pickwick
unfolded
it
,
lighted
his
bedroom
candle
that
it
might
burn
up
well
by
the
time
he
finished
;
and
drawing
his
chair
nearer
the
fire
,
read
as
follows
---
     
<EOS>
THE
TRUE
LEGEND
OF
PRINCE
BLADUD
   
<EOS>
"
Less
than
two
hundred
years
ago
,
on
one
of
the
public
baths
in
this
city
,
there
appeared
an
inscription
in
honour
of
its
mighty
founder
,
the
renowned
Prince
Bladud
.
 
<EOS>
That
inscription
is
now
erased
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
many
hundred
years
before
that
time
,
there
had
been
handed
down
,
from
age
to
age
,
an
old
legend
,
that
the
illustrious
prince
being
afflicted
with
leprosy
,
on
his
return
from
reaping
a
rich
harvest
of
knowledge
in
Athens
,
shunned
the
court
of
his
royal
father
,
and
consorted
moodily
with
husbandman
and
pigs
.
<EOS>
Among
the
herd
(
so
said
the
legend
)
was
a
pig
of
grave
and
solemn
countenance
,
with
whom
the
prince
had
a
fellow
-
feeling
 
---
for
he
too
was
wise
---
a
pig
of
thoughtful
and
reserved
demeanour
;
an
animal
superior
to
his
fellows
,
whose
grunt
was
terrible
,
and
whose
bite
was
sharp
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
prince
sighed
deeply
as
he
looked
upon
the
countenance
of
the
majestic
swine
;
he
thought
of
his
royal
father
,
and
his
eyes
were
bedewed
with
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
sagacious
pig
was
fond
of
bathing
in
rich
,
moist
mud
.
<EOS>
Not
in
summer
,
as
common
pigs
do
now
,
to
cool
themselves
,
and
did
even
in
those
distant
ages
(
which
is
a
proof
that
the
light
of
civilisation
had
already
begun
to
dawn
,
though
feebly
)
,
but
in
the
cold
,
sharp
days
of
winter
.
 
<EOS>
His
coat
was
ever
so
sleek
,
and
his
complexion
so
clear
,
that
the
prince
resolved
to
essay
the
purifying
qualities
of
the
same
water
that
his
friend
resorted
to
.
<EOS>
He
made
the
trial
.
 
<EOS>
Beneath
that
black
mud
,
bubbled
the
hot
springs
of
Bath
.
 
<EOS>
He
washed
,
and
was
cured
.
 
<EOS>
Hastening
to
his
father
's
court
,
he
paid
his
best
respects
,
and
returning
quickly
hither
,
founded
this
city
and
its
famous
baths
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
sought
the
pig
with
all
the
ardour
of
their
early
friendship
 
---
but
,
alas
!
<EOS>
the
waters
had
been
his
death
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
imprudently
taken
a
bath
at
too
high
a
temperature
,
and
the
natural
philosopher
was
no
more
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
succeeded
by
Pliny
,
who
also
fell
a
victim
to
his
thirst
for
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
was
the
legend
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
to
the
true
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
great
many
centuries
since
,
there
flourished
,
in
great
state
,
the
famous
and
renowned
Lud
Hudibras
,
king
of
Britain
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
mighty
monarch
.
 
<EOS>
The
earth
shook
when
he
walked
---
he
was
so
very
stout
.
 
<EOS>
His
people
basked
in
the
light
of
his
countenance
---
it
was
so
red
and
glowing
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
indeed
,
every
inch
a
king
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
were
a
good
many
inches
of
him
,
too
,
for
although
he
was
not
very
tall
,
he
was
a
remarkable
size
round
,
and
the
inches
that
he
wanted
in
height
,
he
made
up
in
circumference
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
degenerate
monarch
of
modern
times
could
be
in
any
way
compared
with
him
,
I
should
say
the
venerable
King
Cole
would
be
that
illustrious
potentate
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
good
king
had
a
queen
,
who
eighteen
years
before
,
had
had
a
son
,
who
was
called
Bladud
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sent
to
a
preparatory
seminary
in
his
father
's
dominions
until
he
was
ten
years
old
,
and
was
then
despatched
,
in
charge
of
a
trusty
messenger
,
to
a
finishing
school
at
Athens
;
and
as
there
was
no
extra
charge
for
remaining
during
the
holidays
,
and
<EOS>
no
notice
required
previous
to
the
removal
of
a
pupil
,
there
he
remained
for
eight
long
years
,
at
the
expiration
of
which
time
,
the
king
his
father
sent
the
lord
chamberlain
over
,
to
settle
the
bill
,
and
to
bring
him
home
;
which
,
the
lord
chamberlain
doing
,
was
received
with
shouts
,
and
pensioned
immediately
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
King
Lud
saw
the
prince
his
son
,
and
found
he
had
grown
up
such
a
fine
young
man
,
he
perceived
what
a
grand
thing
it
would
be
to
have
him
married
without
delay
,
so
that
his
children
might
be
the
means
of
perpetuating
the
glorious
race
of
Lud
,
down
to
the
very
latest
ages
of
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
sent
a
special
embassy
,
composed
of
great
noblemen
who
had
nothing
particular
to
do
,
and
wanted
lucrative
employment
,
to
a
neighbouring
king
,
and
demanded
his
fair
daughter
in
marriage
for
his
son
;
stating
at
the
same
time
that
he
was
anxious
to
be
on
the
most
affectionate
terms
with
his
brother
and
friend
,
but
that
if
they
could
n't
agree
in
arranging
this
marriage
,
he
should
be
under
the
unpleasant
necessity
of
invading
his
kingdom
and
putting
his
eyes
out
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
,
the
other
king
(
who
was
the
weaker
of
the
two
)
replied
that
he
was
very
much
obliged
to
his
friend
and
brother
for
all
his
goodness
and
magnanimity
,
and
that
his
daughter
was
quite
ready
to
be
married
,
whenever
Prince
Bladud
liked
to
come
and
fetch
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
answer
no
sooner
reached
Britain
,
than
the
whole
nation
was
transported
with
joy
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
was
heard
,
on
all
sides
,
but
the
sounds
of
feasting
and
revelry
---
except
the
chinking
of
money
as
it
was
paid
in
by
the
people
to
the
collector
of
the
royal
treasures
,
to
defray
the
expenses
of
the
happy
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
upon
this
occasion
that
King
Lud
,
seated
on
the
top
of
his
throne
in
full
council
,
rose
,
in
the
exuberance
of
his
feelings
,
and
commanded
the
lord
chief
justice
to
order
in
the
richest
wines
and
the
court
minstrels
---
an
act
of
graciousness
which
has
been
,
through
the
ignorance
of
traditionary
historians
,
attributed
to
King
Cole
,
in
those
celebrated
lines
in
which
his
Majesty
is
represented
as
     
Calling
for
his
pipe
,
and
calling
for
his
pot
,
     
And
calling
for
his
fiddlers
three
.
   
<EOS>
Which
is
an
obvious
injustice
to
the
memory
of
King
Lud
,
and
a
dishonest
exaltation
of
the
virtues
of
King
Cole
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
in
the
midst
of
all
this
festivity
and
rejoicing
,
there
was
one
individual
present
,
who
tasted
not
when
the
sparkling
wines
were
poured
forth
,
and
who
danced
not
,
when
the
minstrels
played
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
no
other
than
Prince
Bladud
himself
,
in
honour
of
whose
happiness
a
whole
people
were
,
at
that
very
moment
,
straining
alike
their
throats
and
purse
-
strings
.
 
<EOS>
The
truth
was
,
that
the
prince
,
forgetting
the
undoubted
right
of
the
minister
for
foreign
affairs
to
fall
in
love
on
his
behalf
,
had
,
contrary
to
every
precedent
of
policy
and
diplomacy
,
already
fallen
in
love
on
his
own
account
,
and
privately
contracted
himself
unto
the
fair
daughter
of
a
noble
Athenian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
we
have
a
striking
example
of
one
of
the
manifold
advantages
of
civilisation
and
refinement
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
prince
had
lived
in
later
days
,
he
might
at
once
have
married
the
object
of
his
father
's
choice
,
and
then
set
himself
seriously
to
work
,
to
relieve
himself
of
the
burden
which
rested
heavily
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
have
endeavoured
to
break
her
heart
by
a
systematic
course
of
insult
and
neglect
;
or
,
if
the
spirit
of
her
sex
,
and
a
proud
consciousness
of
her
many
wrongs
had
upheld
her
under
this
ill
-
treatment
,
he
might
have
sought
to
take
her
life
,
and
so
get
rid
of
her
effectually
.
<EOS>
But
neither
mode
of
relief
suggested
itself
to
Prince
Bladud
;
so
he
solicited
a
private
audience
,
and
told
his
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
it
is
an
old
prerogative
of
kings
to
govern
everything
but
their
passions
.
 
<EOS>
King
Lud
flew
into
a
frightful
rage
,
tossed
his
crown
up
to
the
ceiling
,
and
caught
it
again
---
for
in
those
days
kings
kept
their
crowns
on
their
heads
,
and
not
in
the
Tower
---
stamped
the
ground
,
rapped
his
forehead
,
wondered
why
his
own
flesh
and
blood
rebelled
against
him
,
and
,
finally
,
calling
in
his
guards
,
ordered
the
prince
away
to
instant
Confinement
in
a
lofty
turret
;
a
course
of
treatment
which
the
kings
of
old
very
generally
pursued
towards
their
sons
,
when
their
matrimonial
inclinations
did
not
happen
to
point
to
the
same
quarter
as
their
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
Prince
Bladud
had
been
shut
up
in
the
lofty
turret
for
the
greater
part
of
a
year
,
with
no
better
prospect
before
his
bodily
eyes
than
a
stone
wall
,
or
before
his
mental
vision
than
prolonged
imprisonment
,
he
naturally
began
to
ruminate
on
a
plan
of
escape
,
which
,
after
months
of
preparation
,
he
managed
to
accomplish
;
considerately
leaving
his
dinner
-
knife
in
the
heart
of
his
jailer
,
lest
the
poor
fellow
(
who
had
a
family
)
should
be
considered
privy
to
his
flight
,
and
punished
accordingly
by
the
infuriated
king
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
monarch
was
frantic
at
the
loss
of
his
son
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
not
on
whom
to
vent
his
grief
and
wrath
,
until
fortunately
bethinking
himself
of
the
lord
chamberlain
who
had
brought
him
home
,
he
struck
off
his
pension
and
his
head
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Meanwhile
,
the
young
prince
,
effectually
disguised
,
wandered
on
foot
through
his
father
's
dominions
,
cheered
and
supported
in
all
his
hardships
by
sweet
thoughts
of
the
Athenian
maid
,
who
was
the
innocent
cause
of
his
weary
trials
.
 
<EOS>
One
day
he
stopped
to
rest
in
a
country
village
;
and
seeing
that
there
were
gay
dances
going
forward
on
the
green
,
and
gay
faces
passing
to
and
fro
,
ventured
to
inquire
of
a
reveller
who
stood
near
him
,
the
reason
for
this
rejoicing
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Know
you
not
,
O
stranger
,
"
was
the
reply
,
"
of
the
recent
proclamation
of
our
gracious
king
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Proclamation
!
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
What
proclamation
?
<EOS>
"
rejoined
the
prince
---
for
he
had
travelled
along
the
by
and
little
-
frequented
ways
,
and
knew
nothing
of
what
had
passed
upon
the
public
roads
,
such
as
they
were
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Why
,
"
replied
the
peasant
,
"
the
foreign
lady
that
our
prince
wished
to
we
d
,
is
married
to
a
foreign
noble
of
her
own
country
,
and
the
king
proclaims
the
fact
,
and
a
great
public
festival
besides
;
for
now
,
of
course
,
Prince
Bladud
will
come
back
and
marry
the
lady
his
father
chose
,
who
they
say
is
as
beautiful
as
the
noonday
sun
.
 
<EOS>
Your
health
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
God
save
the
king
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
prince
remained
to
hear
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
fled
from
the
spot
,
and
plunged
into
the
thickest
recesses
of
a
neighbouring
wood
.
<EOS>
On
,
on
,
he
wandered
,
night
and
day
;
beneath
the
blazing
sun
,
and
the
cold
pale
moon
;
through
the
dry
heat
of
noon
,
and
the
damp
cold
of
night
;
in
the
gray
light
of
morn
,
and
the
red
glare
of
eve
.
 
<EOS>
So
heedless
was
he
of
time
or
object
,
that
being
bound
for
Athens
,
he
wandered
as
far
out
of
his
way
as
Bath
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
city
where
Bath
stands
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
vestige
of
human
habitation
,
or
sign
of
man
's
resort
,
to
bear
the
name
;
but
there
was
the
same
noble
country
,
the
same
broad
expanse
of
hill
and
dale
,
the
same
beautiful
channel
stealing
on
,
far
away
,
the
same
lofty
mountains
which
,
like
the
troubles
of
life
,
viewed
at
a
distance
,
and
partially
obscured
by
the
bright
mist
of
its
morning
,
lose
their
ruggedness
and
asperity
,
and
seem
all
ease
and
softness
.
 
<EOS>
Moved
by
the
gentle
beauty
of
the
scene
,
the
prince
sank
upon
the
green
turf
,
and
bathed
his
swollen
feet
in
his
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
the
unhappy
Bladud
,
clasping
his
hands
,
and
mournfully
raising
his
eyes
towards
the
sky
,
"
would
that
my
wanderings
might
end
here
!
 
<EOS>
Would
that
these
grateful
tears
with
which
I
now
mourn
hope
misplaced
,
and
love
despised
,
might
flow
in
peace
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
wish
was
heard
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
time
of
the
heathen
deities
,
who
used
occasionally
to
take
people
at
their
words
,
with
a
promptness
,
in
some
cases
,
extremely
awkward
.
 
<EOS>
The
ground
opened
beneath
the
prince
's
feet
;
he
sank
into
the
chasm
;
and
instantaneously
it
closed
upon
his
head
for
ever
,
save
where
his
hot
tears
welled
up
through
the
earth
,
and
where
they
have
continued
to
gush
forth
ever
since
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
observable
that
,
to
this
day
,
large
numbers
of
elderly
ladies
and
gentlemen
who
have
been
disappointed
in
procuring
partners
,
and
almost
as
many
young
ones
who
are
anxious
to
obtain
them
,
repair
annually
to
Bath
to
drink
the
waters
,
from
which
they
derive
much
strength
and
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
most
complimentary
to
the
virtue
of
Prince
Bladud
's
tears
,
and
strongly
corroborative
of
the
veracity
of
this
legend
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
yawned
several
times
when
he
had
arrived
at
the
end
of
this
little
manuscript
,
carefully
refolded
,
and
replaced
it
in
the
inkstand
drawer
,
and
then
,
with
a
countenance
expressive
of
the
utmost
weariness
,
lighted
his
chamber
candle
,
and
went
upstairs
to
bed
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
at
Mr
Dowler
's
door
,
according
to
custom
,
and
knocked
to
say
good
-
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Dowler
,
"
going
to
bed
?
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
Dismal
night
.
<EOS>
Windy
;
is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
went
to
his
bedchamber
,
and
Mr
Dowler
resumed
his
seat
before
the
fire
,
in
fulfilment
of
his
rash
promise
to
sit
up
till
his
wife
came
home
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
few
things
more
worrying
than
sitting
up
for
somebody
,
especially
if
that
somebody
be
at
a
party
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
not
help
thinking
how
quickly
the
time
passes
with
them
,
which
drags
so
heavily
with
you
;
and
the
more
you
think
of
this
,
the
more
your
hopes
of
their
speedy
arrival
decline
.
 
<EOS>
Clocks
tick
so
loud
,
too
,
when
you
are
sitting
up
alone
,
and
you
seem
as
if
you
had
an
under
-
garment
of
cobwebs
on
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
something
tickles
your
right
knee
,
and
then
the
same
sensation
irritates
your
left
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
no
sooner
changed
your
position
,
than
it
comes
again
in
the
arms
;
when
you
have
fidgeted
your
limbs
into
all
sorts
of
queer
shapes
,
you
have
a
sudden
relapse
in
the
nose
,
which
you
rub
as
if
to
rub
it
off
---
as
there
is
no
doubt
you
would
,
if
you
could
.
<EOS>
Eyes
,
too
,
are
mere
personal
inconveniences
;
and
the
wick
of
one
candle
gets
an
inch
and
a
half
long
,
while
you
are
snuffing
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
and
various
other
little
nervous
annoyances
<EOS>
,
render
sitting
up
for
a
length
of
time
after
everybody
else
has
gone
to
bed
,
anything
but
a
cheerful
amusement
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
just
Mr
Dowler
's
opinion
,
as
he
sat
before
the
fire
,
and
felt
honestly
indignant
with
all
the
inhuman
people
at
the
party
who
were
keeping
him
up
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
put
into
better
humour
either
,
by
the
reflection
that
he
had
taken
it
into
his
head
,
<EOS>
early
in
the
evening
,
to
think
he
had
got
an
ache
there
,
and
so
stopped
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
several
droppings
asleep
,
and
fallings
forward
towards
the
bars
,
and
catchings
backward
soon
enough
to
prevent
being
branded
in
the
face
,
Mr
Dowler
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
throw
himself
on
the
bed
in
the
back
room
and
think
---
not
sleep
,
of
course
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
heavy
sleeper
,
"
said
Mr
Dowler
,
as
he
flung
himself
on
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
keep
awake
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
shall
hear
a
knock
here
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
hear
the
watchman
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
goes
.
<EOS>
Fainter
now
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
fainter
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
turning
the
corner
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
When
Mr
Dowler
arrived
at
this
point
,
he
turned
the
corner
at
which
he
had
been
long
hesitating
,
and
fell
fast
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
Just
as
the
clock
struck
three
,
there
was
blown
into
the
crescent
a
sedan
-
chair
with
Mrs
Dowler
inside
,
borne
by
one
short
,
fat
chairman
,
and
one
long
,
thin
one
,
who
had
had
much
ado
to
keep
their
bodies
perpendicular
:
to
say
nothing
of
the
chair
.
<EOS>
But
on
that
high
ground
,
and
in
the
crescent
,
which
the
wind
swept
round
and
round
as
if
it
were
going
to
tear
the
paving
stones
up
,
its
fury
was
tremendous
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
very
glad
to
set
the
chair
down
,
and
give
a
good
round
loud
double
-
knock
at
the
street
door
.
   
<EOS>
They
waited
some
time
,
but
nobody
came
.
   
<EOS>
"
Servants
is
in
the
arms
o
'
Porpus
,
I
think
,
"
said
the
short
chairman
,
warming
his
hands
at
the
attendant
link
-
boy
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
he
'd
give
'em
a
squeeze
and
wake
'
em
,
"
observed
the
long
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Knock
again
,
<EOS>
will
you
,
if
you
please
,
"
cried
Mrs
Dowler
from
the
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Knock
two
or
three
times
,
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
short
man
was
quite
willing
to
get
the
job
over
,
as
soon
as
possible
;
so
he
stood
on
the
step
,
and
gave
four
or
five
most
startling

-

,
of
eight
or
ten
knocks
a
-
piece
,
while
the
long
man
went
into
the
road
,
and
looked
up
at
the
windows
for
a
light
.
   
<EOS>
Nobody
came
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
as
silent
and
dark
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Mrs
Dowler
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
knock
again
,
if
you
please
.
"
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
a
bell
,
is
there
,
ma'am
?
"
said
the
short
chairman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
there
is
,
"
interposed

link
-
boy
,
"
I
've
been
a
-
ringing
at
it
ever

long
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
a
handle
,
"
said
Mrs
Dowler
,
"
the
wire
's
broken
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
the
servants
"
heads
wos
,
"
growled
the
long
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
trouble
you
to
knock
again
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
Mrs
Dowler
,
with
the
utmost

.
   
<EOS>
The
short
man
did
knock
again
several
times
,
without
producing
the
smallest
effect
.
 
<EOS>
The
tall
man
,
growing
very
impatient
,
then
relieved
him
,
and
kept
on
perpetually
knocking
double
-
knocks
of
two
loud
knocks
each
,
like
an
insane
postman
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
Mr
Winkle
began
to
dream
that
he
was
at
a
club
,
and
that
the
members
being
very
refractory
,
the
chairman
was
obliged
to
hammer
the
table
a
good
deal
to
preserve
order
;
then
he
had
a
confused
notion
of
an
auction
room
where
there
were
no
bidders
,
and
the
auctioneer
was
buying
everything
in
;
and
ultimately
he
began
to
think
it
just
within
the
bounds
of
possibility
that
somebody
might
be
knocking
at
the
street
door
.
 
<EOS>
To
make
quite
certain
,
however
,
he
remained
quiet
in
bed
for
ten
minutes
or
so
,
and
listened
;
and
when
he
had
counted
two
or
three
-
and
-
thirty
knocks
,
he
felt
quite
satisfied
,
and
gave
himself
a
great
deal
of
credit
for
being
so
wakeful
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rap
rap
-
rap
rap
-
rap
rap
-
ra
,
ra
,
ra
,
ra
,
ra
,
rap
!
<EOS>
"
went
the
knocker
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
jumped
out
of
bed
,
wondering
very
much
what
could
possibly
be
the
matter
,
and
hastily
putting
on
his
stockings
and
slippers
,
folded
his
dressing
-
gown
round
him
,
lighted
a
flat
candle
from
the
rush
-
light
that
was
burning
in
the
fireplace
,
and
hurried
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
somebody
comin
'
<EOS>
at
last
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
short
chairman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
wos
behind
him
vith
a
bradawl
,
"
muttered
the
long
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Winkle
,
undoing
the
chain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stop
to
ask
questions
,
cast
-
iron
head
,
"
replied
the
long
man
,
with
great
disgust
,
taking
it
for
granted
that
the
inquirer
was
a
footman
;
"
but
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
look
sharp
,
timber
eyelids
,
"
added
the
other
encouragingly
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
being
half
asleep
,
obeyed
the
command
mechanically
,
opened
the
door
a
little
,
and
peeped
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
thing
he
saw
,
was
the
red
glare
of
the
link
-
boy
's
torch
.
 
<EOS>
Startled
by
the
sudden
fear
that
the
house
might
be
on
fire
,
he
hastily
threw
the
door
wide
open
,
and
holding
the
candle
above
his
head
,
stared
eagerly
before
him
,
not
quite
certain
whether
what
he
saw
was
a
sedan
-
chair
or
a
fire
-
engine
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
instant
there
came
a
violent
gust
of
wind
;
the
light
was
blown
out
;
Mr
Winkle
felt
himself
irresistibly
impelled
on
to
the
steps
;
and
the
door
blew
to
,
with
a
loud
crash
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
young
man
,
now
you
HAVE
done
it
!
"
said
the
short
chairman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
catching
sight
of
a
lady
's
face
at
the
window
of
the
sedan
,
turned
hastily
round
,
plied
the
knocker
with
all
his
might
and
main
,
and
called
frantically
upon
the
chairman
to
take
the
chair
away
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
it
away
,
take
it
away
,
"
cried
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
somebody
coming
out
of
another
house
;
put
me
into
the
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Hide
me
!
 
<EOS>
Do
something
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
he
was
shivering
with
cold
;
and
every
time
he
raised
his
hand
to
the
knocker
<EOS>
,
the
wind
took
the
dressing
-
gown
in
a
most
unpleasant
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
people
are
coming
down
the
crescent
now
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
ladies
with
'em
;
cover
me
up
with
something
.
 
<EOS>
Stand
before
me
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
chairmen
were
too
much
exhausted
with
laughing
to
afford
him
the
slightest
assistance
,
and
the
ladies
were
every
moment
approaching
nearer
and
nearer
.
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
gave
a
last
hopeless
knock
;
the
ladies
were
only
a
few
doors
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
away
the
extinguished
candle
,
which
,
all

time
he
had
held
above
his
head
,
and
fairly
bolted
into
the
sedan
-
chair
where
Mrs
Dowler
was
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mrs
Craddock
had
heard
the
knocking
and
the
voices
at
last
;
and
,
only
waiting
to
put
something
smarter
on
her
head
than
her
nightcap
,
ran
down
into
the
front
drawing
-
room
to
make
sure
that
it
was
the
right
party
.
 
<EOS>
Throwing
up
the
window
-
sash
as
Mr
Winkle
was
rushing
into
the
chair
,
she
no
sooner
caught
sight
of
what
was
going
forward
below
,
than
she
raised
a
vehement
and

,
and
implored
Mr
Dowler
to
get
up
directly
,
for
his
wife
was
running
away
with
another
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Mr
Dowler
bounced
off
the
bed
as

as
an
India

ball
,
and
rushing
into
the
front
room
,
arrived
at
one

just

Mr
Pickwick

up
the

,
when
the
first

that

,
was
Mr
Winkle
bolting
into

.
   
<EOS>
"
Watchman
,
"

Dowler

,
"
stop
him
---
hold
him
 
---
keep
him
tight
---
shut

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
cut
his
throat
---
give
me
a

---
from
ear
<EOS>
to

,
Mrs
Craddock
---

!
"
<EOS>
And

from

Mr

,

seized
a

,

.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Winkle
did
n't

.
 
<EOS>
He
no

the
horrible
threat
of
the
valorous
Dowler
,
than

,

,
and

,
took

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
kept
ahead
;
the
door
was
open
as

came
round

;
he
rushed
in
,
slammed
it
in
Dowler
's

,

,

,

,

,

,

with

.
   
<EOS>
Dowler
came
up
to

;
avowed
,

,
his

cutting

's

next

;

endeavouring

,

to

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
37
.
<EOS>
Honourably
accounts

Mr
Weller
's

,

to

;

with

"

,
"

<EOS>

Wery

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

,

I
ai

much
in

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

wo

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

rayther

o
'

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
By

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Plates
for

;

:
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
The
man
in

being

,

,

,

Mr
Weller
's

,
but

,

;

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your

,
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

much
.
<EOS>
I

's
wery
pretty
.
"
   
<EOS>

,
<EOS>
for

,

<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
'
ere

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
She

's
wot
,

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr

a

<EOS>

<EOS>

The

.

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

,

-

,
<EOS>
whereupon

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
Universal

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
The

,
Mr
Whiffers
explained
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
certainly
could
have
wished
to
have
continued

he
had
just
resigned
.
 
<EOS>
The
uniform
was

and

,
the
females
of
the
family
was
most

,
and
the

of

was
not
,

bound

,
too

;

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
could

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

Shame
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Whiffers

that

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
and

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

on

,
to

,
would

in

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

's

<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tuckle
was
not
proof
against
this

.
 
<EOS>
He

cocked
hat
and
stick
which

had
just

,
and
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
As

went

Tuckle
,

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
Sam
ordered

from
the
green
-
grocer
's

;
and

was
so

,
that
Mr

,

,

,
while
the

in
blue
played

upon
an

upon

curl

.
<EOS>
At

,

was

,

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tuckle
no
sooner

into

,
than
he

to
lie
on
the

;
Sam
thought
it
would
be
a
pity
to

,
and
so
let
him
have
his
own

.
 
<EOS>
As
the

hat
would
have
been

there
,
Sam
very

down
on
the

of
the
gentleman
in
blue
,
and
putting
the
big
stick
in

,
propped
him
up
against

own
street
-
door
,
rang
the
bell
,
and
walked
quietly
home
.
   
<EOS>
At
a
much
earlier
hour
next
morning
than
his
usual
time
of
rising
,
Mr
Pickwick
walked
downstairs
completely
dressed
,
and
rang
the
bell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
when
Mr
Weller
appeared
in

to

summons
,
"
shut
the

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
did

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

here
,
last
night
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
which

Winkle
some

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
've
heerd

,
Sir
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

,
"
continued

,

,
"
that

,

has

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gone

!
"

Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Left
the
house
early
this
morning
,
without
the
slightest
previous
communication
with
me
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
is
gone
,
I
know
not
where
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
should
ha
'
stopped
and
fought
it
out
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
n't
take
much
to
settle
that
'
ere
Dowler
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
may
have
my

of
his
great

and

.
 
<EOS>
But

may

,
Mr
Winkle
is

.
 
<EOS>
He
must
be
found
,
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
Found
and
brought
back
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
And
s'pose
he
wo
n't
come

,
Sir
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
to

,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sam
,
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
good
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these

Mr
Weller
left
the
room
,
and
immediately
afterwards
was
heard
to
shut
the

.
 
<EOS>
In
two
hours
"
time
he
returned
with
so

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"

,

,
"
you

;

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
Sam
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cert'nly
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

'

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
Sam
?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

'll

if

's
anyvere
,
"

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then

.
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

,
and

,
in
pursuit
of
the
fugitive
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
put
a
few
necessaries
in
a
carpet
-
bag
,
and
was
ready
for

.
 
<EOS>
He
stopped
when

to
the
end
of
the

,
and

,

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

'

,

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thoroughly
.
 
<EOS>
Do
what

.
 
<EOS>
You
have
my

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
gave
a
nod
of
intelligence
,
and
withdrawing
his
head
from
the
door
,
set
forth
on
his
pilgrimage
with
a
light
heart
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
38
.
<EOS>
How
Mr
Winkle
,
when
he
stepped
out
of
the
Frying
-
pan
,
walked
gently
and
comfortably
into
the
fire
 
<EOS>
The
ill
-
starred
gentleman
who
had
been
the
unfortunate
cause
of
the
unusual
noise
and
disturbance
which
alarmed
the
inhabitants
of
the
Royal
Crescent
in
manner
and
form
already
described
,
after
passing
a
night
of
great
confusion
and
anxiety
,
left
the
roof
beneath
which
his
friends
still
slumbered
,
bound
he
knew
not
whither
.
<EOS>
The
excellent
and
considerate
feelings
which
prompted
Mr
Winkle
to
take
this
step
can
never
be
too
highly
appreciated
or
too
warmly
extolled
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
,
"
reasoned
Mr
Winkle
with
himself
---
"
if
this
Dowler
attempts
(
as
I
have
no
doubt
he
will
)
to
carry
into
execution
his
threat
of
personal
violence
against
myself
,
it
will
be
incumbent
on
me
to
call
him
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
wife
;
that
wife
is
attached
to
,
and
dependent
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
Heavens
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
should
kill
him
in
the
blindness
of
my
wrath
,
what
would
be
my
feelings
ever
afterwards
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
painful
consideration
operated
so
powerfully
on
the
feelings
of
the
humane
young
man
,
as
to
cause
his
knees
to
knock
together
,
and
his
countenance
to
exhibit
alarming
manifestations
of
inward
emotion
.
 
<EOS>
Impelled
by
such
reflections
,
he
grasped
his
carpet
-
bag
,
and
creeping
stealthily
downstairs
,
shut
the
detestable
street
door
with
as
little
noise
as
possible
,
and
walked
off
.
 
<EOS>
Bending
his
steps
towards
the
Royal
Hotel
,
he
found
a
coach
on
the
point
of
starting
for
Bristol
,
and
,
thinking
Bristol
as
good
a
place
for
his
purpose
as
any
other
he
could
go
to
<EOS>
,
he
mounted
the
box
,
and
reached
his
place
of
destination
in
such
time
as
the
pair
of
horses
,
who
went
the
whole
stage
and
back
again
,
twice
a
day
or
more
,
could
be
reasonably
supposed
to
arrive
there
.
<EOS>
He
took
up
his
quarters
at
the
Bush
,
and
designing
to
postpone
any
communication
by
letter
with
Mr
Pickwick
until
it
was
probable
that
Mr
Dowler
's
wrath
might
have
in
some
degree
evaporated
,
walked
forth
to
view
the
city
,
which
struck
him
as
being
a
shade
more
dirty
than
any
place
he
had
ever
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Having
inspected
the
docks
and
shipping
,
and
viewed
the
cathedral
,
he
inquired
his
way
to
Clifton
,
and
being
directed
thither
,
took
the
route
which
was
pointed
out
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
the
pavements
of
Bristol
are
not
the
widest
or
cleanest
upon
earth
,
so
its
streets
are
not
altogether
the
straightest
or
least
intricate
;
and
Mr
Winkle
,
being
greatly
puzzled
by
their
manifold
windings
and
twistings
,
looked
about
him
for
a
decent
shop
in
which
he
could
apply
afresh
for
counsel
and
instruction
.
   
<EOS>
His
eye
fell
upon
a
newly
-
painted
tenement
which
had
been
recently
converted
into
something
between
a
shop
and
a
private
house
,
and
which
a
red
lamp
,
projecting
over
the
fanlight
of
the
street
door
,
would
have
sufficiently
announced
as
the
residence
of
a
medical
practitioner
,
even
if
the
word
"
Surgery
"
had
not
been
inscribed
in
golden
characters
on
a
wainscot
ground
,
above
the
window
of
what
,
in
times
bygone
,
had
been
the
front
parlour
.
<EOS>
Thinking
this
an
eligible
place
wherein
to
make
his
inquiries
,
Mr
Winkle
stepped
into
the
little
shop
where
the
gilt
-
labelled
drawers
and
bottles
were
;
and
finding
nobody
there
,
knocked
with
a
half
-
crown
on
the
counter
,
to
attract
the
attention
of
anybody
who
might
happen
to
be
in
the
back
parlour
,
which
he
judged
to
be
the
innermost
and
peculiar
sanctum
of
the
establishment
,
from
the
repetition
of
the
word
surgery
on
the
door
---
painted
in
white
letters
this
time
,
by
way
of
taking
off
the
monotony
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
first
knock
,
a
sound
,
as
of
persons
fencing
with
fire
-
irons
,
which
had
until
now
been
very
audible
,
suddenly
ceased
;
at
the
second
,
a
studious
-
looking
young
gentleman
in
green
spectacles
,
with
a
very
large
book
in
his
hand
,
glided
quietly
into
the
shop
,
and
stepping
behind
the
counter
,
requested
to
know
the
visitor
's
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
trouble
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
"
but
will
you
have
the
goodness
to
direct
me
to
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
"
roared
the
studious
young
gentleman
,
throwing
the
large
book
up
into
the
air
,
and
catching
it
with
great
dexterity
at
the
very
moment
when
it
threatened
to
smash
to
atoms
all
the
bottles
on
the
counter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
start
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
,
without
doubt
;
for
Mr
Winkle
was
so
very
much
astonished
at
the
extraordinary
behaviour
of
the
medical
gentleman
,
that
he
involuntarily
retreated
towards
the
door
,
and
looked
very
much
disturbed
at
his
strange
reception
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
do
n't
you
know
me
?
"
said
the
medical
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
murmured
,
in
reply
,
that
he
had
not
that
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
"
said
the
medical
gentleman
,
"
there
are
hopes
for
me
yet
;
I
may
attend
half
the
old
women
in
Bristol
,
if
I
've
decent
luck
.
 
<EOS>
Get
out
,
you
mouldy
old
villain
,
get
out
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
adjuration
,
which
was
addressed
to
the
large
book
,
the
medical
gentleman
kicked
the
volume
with
remarkable
agility
to
the
farther
end
of
the
shop
,
and
,
pulling
off
his
green
spectacles
,
grinned
the
identical
grin
of
Robert
Sawyer
,
Esquire
,
formerly
of
Guy
's
Hospital
in
the
Borough
,
with
a
private
residence
in
Lant
Street
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
say
you
were
n't
down
upon
me
?
"
said
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
shaking
Mr
Winkle
's
hand
with
friendly
warmth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
I
was
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
returning
his
pressure
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
you
did
n't
see
the
name
,
"
said
Bob
Sawyer
,
calling

's

,

,

"
Sawyer
,
late
Nockemorf
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
never
caught
my
eye
,
"
returned
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lord
,
if
I
had

you
were
,
I
should

,

,
"
said
Bob
Sawyer
;
"
but

,
I

the
King's
-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"

Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
,

,
"
responded
Bob
Sawyer
,
"
and
I
was
just

that
I
was
n't
at
home
,
but
if
you
'd

message
I
'd

;
for
he
do
n't

me
;
no

the
Lighting

.
 
<EOS>
I

Church
-
rates
guesses
who
I

,

Water
-
works
does
,
because
I

of
his
when

.
 
<EOS>
But
come
in
,
come
in
!
"
 
<EOS>
Chattering
in
this

,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
pushed
Mr
Winkle
into
the
back

,
where
,
amusing

by
boring
little
circular

in

chimney
-
piece
with
a
red
-
hot
poker
,
sat
no
less
a
person
than
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
indeed
a
pleasure
I
did
not
expect
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
very
nice
place
you
have
here
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
pretty
well
,
"

Bob
Sawyer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
PASSED
,
soon
after
that
precious
party
,
and
my
friends
came
down
with
the
needful
for
this
business
;
so
I
put
on
a
black
suit
of
clothes
,
and
a
pair

,
and
came
here
to
look

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
a
very
snug

business
you
have
,
no

?
"
said
Mr
Winkle
knowingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
replied
Bob
Sawyer
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
snug
,
that
at
the
end

a
few

you
might
put
all
the

in

-

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
You
can
not

?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
stock
itself
---
"
"
Dummies
,
my

,
"
said

;
"
half
the
drawers
have
nothing

,

n't

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fact
---
honour
!
<EOS>
"
returned
Bob
Sawyer
,
stepping
out
into
the
shop
,
and
demonstrating
the

of
the
assertion
by
divers
hard
pulls
at
the
little

on
the
counterfeit

.
"
<EOS>
Hardly
anything
real
in
the
shop
but
the
leeches
,
and
THEY
are
second
-
hand
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Sawyer

<EOS>

<EOS>

to

in

Mr
Winkle

.
   
<EOS>
We

hinted

,
that
Mr
Benjamin
Allen

after

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
as
we
ourself

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
At
this

of
his
existence
,
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
had
perhaps

to

than

;
the
cause
of
which

was

this
.
 
<EOS>
He

with
Mr
Bob

;
Mr

was
not

,

Allen
for

;

,

,

had

between

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

<EOS>
,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
All

,

,

<EOS>
"
No

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Not

,

<EOS>
Short

,

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Could

?
<EOS>

,

?
 
<EOS>
He

,

the
explanatory
"
over

"

"

,

.
   
<EOS>
But

's

,

<EOS>
The

,

's

;

)

;

"
in

.
"
   
<EOS>
After

,
Mr

Sawyer

in
the
largest

in

shop
,

jorum

-

therein
,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sawyer
,
being

,
had
only

house
,
which

Mr
Winkle
as

the
visitor
,
Mr
Ben
Allen
being

with
a

with
a
cork
in
the
narrow
end
,
and
Bob
Sawyer
contented
himself
with
one
of
those
wide
-

inscribed
with

variety

,
in
which
chemists
are
wo
nt
to
measure
out
their
liquid
drugs
in

.
 
<EOS>
These
preliminaries
adjusted
,
the
punch
was
tasted
,
and
pronounced
excellent
;
and
it
having
been
arranged
that
Bob
Sawyer
and
Ben
Allen
should
be
considered
at
liberty
to
fill
twice
to
Mr
Winkle
's
once
<EOS>
,
they
started
fair
,
with
great
satisfaction
and
good
-
fellowship
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
singing
,
because
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
said
it
would
n't
look
professional
;
but
to
make
amends
for
this
deprivation
there
was
so
much
talking
and
laughing
that
it
might
have
been
heard
,
and
very
likely
was
,
at
the
end
of
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
Which
conversation
materially
lightened
the
hours
and
improved
the
mind
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
's
boy
,
who
,
instead
of
devoting
the
evening
to
his
ordinary
occupation
of
writing
his
name
on
the
counter
,
and
rubbing
it
out
again
,
peeped
through
the
glass
door
,
and
thus
listened
and
looked
on
at
the
same
time
.
   
<EOS>
The
mirth
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
was
rapidly
ripening
into
the
furious
,
Mr
Ben
Allen
was
fast
relapsing
into
the
sentimental
,
and
the
punch
had
well
-
nigh
disappeared
altogether
,
when
the
boy
hastily
running
in
,
announced
that
a
young
woman
had
just
come
over
,
to
say
that
Sawyer
late
Nockemorf
was
wanted
directly
,
a
couple
of
streets
off
.
 
<EOS>
This
broke
up
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
understanding
the
message
,
after
some
twenty
repetitions
,
tied
a
wet
cloth
round
his
head
to
sober
himself
,
and
,
having
partially
succeeded
,
put
on
his
green
spectacles
and
issued
forth
.
<EOS>
Resisting
all
entreaties
to
stay
till
he
came
back
,
and
finding
it
quite
impossible
to
engage
Mr
Ben
Allen
in
any
intelligible

on
the
subject
nearest
his
heart
,
or
indeed
on
any
other
,
Mr
Winkle
took
his
departure
,
and
returned
to
the
Bush
.
   
<EOS>
The
anxiety
of
his
mind
,
and
the
numerous
meditations
which
Arabella
had
awakened
,
prevented
his
share
of
the
mortar
of
punch
producing
that
effect
upon
him
which
it
would
have
had
under
other

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
after
taking
a
glass
of

water
and

at
the

,
he
turned
into
the
coffee
-
room
,
dispirited
rather
than
elevated
by
the
occurrences
of
the
evening
.
<EOS>
Sitting
in
front
of
the
fire
,
with
his
back

,
was
a
tallish
gentleman
in
a
greatcoat
:
the
only
other
occupant
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
rather
a
cool
evening
for
the
season
of
the
year
,
and
the
gentleman
drew
his
chair
aside
to
afford
the
new
-

a
sight
of
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
What
were
Mr
Winkle
's

when
,

so
,

disclosed
to
view

face
and
figure
of
the

Dowler
!
   
<EOS>
Mr

's

was
to

pull
at
the
nearest
bell
-
handle
,
but
that
unfortunately
happened
to

behind

Dowler
's

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo

.
 
<EOS>
A

!
 
<EOS>
Never
!
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Pickwick

<EOS>
As

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

of

commencement
of
their
conversation
was
explained
;
Mr
Dowler
had
as
great

duelling
as

;
in

,
this

awful
personage
was
one
of
the
most
egregious
cowards
in
existence
,
and
interpreting
Mr
Winkle
's
absence
through
the

of
his
own
fears
,
had
taken
the
same
step
as
himself
,
and
prudently
retired
until
all
excitement
of
feeling
should
have
subsided
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
real
state
of
the
case
dawned
upon
Mr
Winkle
's

,
he
looked
very
terrible
,
and
said
he
was
perfectly
satisfied
;
but
at
the

,

with

Mr

no

but
to

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

and

;
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
About

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>

what

.
   
<EOS>
Into

were

concealed
from
view
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
was
sitting
with
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
dust
-
heap
outside
the
next
gate
to
that
by
which
the
groom
had
disappeared
,
profoundly
turning
over
in
his
mind
the
difficulties
of
his
present
undertaking
,
when
the
gate
opened
,
and
a
female
servant
came
out
into
the
lane
to
shake
some
bedside
carpets
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
was
so
very
busy
with
his
own
thoughts
,
that
it
is
probable
he
would
have
taken
no
more
notice
of
the
young
woman
than
just
raising
his
head
and
remarking
that
she
had
a
very
neat
and
pretty
figure
,
if
his
feelings
of
gallantry
had
not
been
most
strongly
roused
by
observing
that
she
had
no
one
to
help
her
,
and
that
the
carpets
seemed
too
heavy
for
her
single
strength
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
was
a
gentleman
of
great
gallantry
in
his
own
way
,
and
he
no
sooner
remarked
this
circumstance
than
he
hastily
rose
from
the
large
stone
,
and
advanced
towards
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Sam
,
sliding
up
with
an
air
of
great
respect
,
"
you
'll
spile
that
wery
pretty
figure
out
<EOS>
o
'
all
perportion
<EOS>
if
you
shake
them
carpets
by
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
help
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
lady
,
who
had
been

affecting
not

know
that

was
so

,

as
Sam

---
no

(

)
to

---
when

.
 
<EOS>
Sam
was
scarcely
less

,
for
in
the
countenance
of
the
well
-
shaped
female
servant
,
he
beheld
the
very
features
of
his
valentine
,
the
pretty

from
Mr
Nupkins
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wy
,
Mary
,
my
dear
!
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lauk
,
Mr
Weller
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
how
you
do

one
!
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
made
no

to

,
nor

.
 
<EOS>
We

,
"
Lor
,
do

,
Mr

!
"

---

tokens
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>

O

,
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
was
so

on

that
he
found

to
cling

fair

for

;
and
divers
little
love

had

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
"

,
"

do

beat
cock
-

'

never
vill
,

,
<EOS>
ven
<EOS>

'

's

arter

.
 
<EOS>
That
wery

!
 
<EOS>
Wy
,
I
've

a
message
to
her
as

've

a
-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"

,
"

<EOS>
you
ca

,

,

;
she

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
ruminated
for
a

,
and
finally
hit
upon
the
following
plan
of
operations
;
that
he
should
return
just
at
dusk
 
---
the
time
at
which
Arabella
invariably
took
her
walk
---
and
,
being
admitted
by
Mary
into
the
garden
of
the
house
to
which
she
belonged
,
would
contrive
to
scramble
up
the
wall
,
beneath
the

of
a

-

,
which
would

screen

from

;
would
there

,

,

,

Mr
Winkle
for

at

.
 
<EOS>
Having
made
this
arrangement
with
great
despatch
,
he
assisted
Mary
in
the
long
-
deferred
occupation
of
shaking
the
carpets
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
half
as
innocent
a
thing
as
it
looks
,
that
shaking
little
pieces
of
carpet
---
<EOS>
at
least
,
there
may
be
no
great
harm
in
the
shaking
,
but
the
folding
is
a
very
insidious
process
.
 
<EOS>
So
long
as
the
shaking
lasts
,
and
the
two
parties
are
kept
the
carpet
's
length
apart
,
it
is
as
innocent
an
amusement
as
can
well
be
devised
;
but
when
the
folding
begins
,
and
the
distance
between
them
gets
gradually
lessened
from
one
half
its
former
length
to
a
quarter
,
and
then
to
an
eighth
,
and
then
to
a
sixteenth
,
and
then
to
a
thirty
-
second
,
if
the
carpet
be
long
enough
,
it
becomes
dangerous
.
<EOS>
We
do
not
know
,
to
a
nicety
,
how
many
pieces
of
carpet
were
folded
in
this

,
but
we
can
venture
to
state
that
as
many

,
so
many
times
did
Sam
kiss
the
pretty
housemaid
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
regaled
himself
with
moderation
at
the
nearest
tavern
until
it
was
nearly
dusk
,
and
then
returned
to
the
lane
without

.
 
<EOS>
Having
been
admitted
into
the

by
Mary
,
and

that
lady
sundry

concerning
the

and

,
Sam
mounted
into
the
pear
-

,
to
wait
until
Arabella
should
come

.
   
<EOS>
He
waited
so
long
without
this
anxiously
-
expected
event
occurring
,
that
he
began
to
think
it

not

take

at

,
when

heard

upon
the

,
and

beheld
Arabella
walking
pensively
down

.
 
<EOS>
As

as
she
came
nearly
below

,
Sam
began
,
by

gently

,
to
make
sundry

noises
similar
to
those
which
would
probably
be
natural
to
a
person
of
middle
age
who
had
been

with
a
combination
of
inflammatory

,

,
and

,
from
his

.
   
<EOS>
Upon

,

cast

the
spot
whence
the
dreadful

proceeded
;
and
her
previous

being
not
at
all

when
she
saw
a
man
among

,
she
would
most

have
decamped
,
and
alarmed

house
,
had
not

fortunately

of

,

,

<EOS>
"
She
's

-

'
off
,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

miss
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
how
?
---
<EOS>
where
?
"
cried
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
leave
the
house
alone
.
 
<EOS>
My
brother
is
so
unkind
,
so
unreasonable
!
 
<EOS>
I
know
how
strange
my
talking
thus
to
you
may
appear
,
Mr
Weller
,
but
I
am
very
,
very
unhappy
---
"
and
here
poor
Arabella
wept
so
bitterly
that
Sam
grew
chivalrous
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
seem
wery
strange
talkin
'
to
me
about
these
here
affairs
,
miss
,
"
said
Sam
,
with
great
vehemence
;
"
but
all
I
can
say
is
,
that
I
'm
not
only
ready
but
villin
'
to
do
<EOS>
anythin
'
as'll
make
matters
agreeable
;
and
<EOS>
if
chuckin
'
either
o
'
them
sawboneses
out
<EOS>
o
'
winder
"
ull
do
it
,
I
'm
the
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
Sam
Weller
said
this
,
he
tucked
up
his
wristbands
,
at
the
imminent
hazard
of
falling
off
the
wall
in
so
doing
,
to
intimate
his
readiness
to
set
to
work
immediately
.
   
<EOS>
Flattering
as
these
professions
of
good
feeling
were
,
Arabella
resolutely
declined
(
most
unaccountably
,
as
Sam
thought
)
to
avail
herself
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
time
she
strenuously
refused
to
grant
Mr
Winkle
<EOS>
the
interview
Sam
had
so
pathetically
requested
;
but
at
length
,
when
the
conversation
threatened
to
be
interrupted
by
the
unwelcome
arrival
of
a
third
party
,
she
hurriedly
gave
him
to
understand
,
with
many
professions
of
gratitude
,
that
it
was
barely
possible
she
might
be
in
the
garden
an
hour
later
,
next
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
understood
this
perfectly
well
;
and
Arabella
,
bestowing
upon
him
one
of
her
sweetest
smiles
,
tripped
gracefully
away
,
leaving
Mr
Weller
in
a
state
of
very
great
admiration
of
her
charms
,
both
personal
and
mental
.
   
<EOS>
Having
descended
in
safety
from
the
wall
,
and
not
forgotten
to
devote
a
few
moments
to
his
own
particular
business
in
the
same
department
,
Mr
Weller
then
made
the
best
of
his
way
back
to
the
Bush
,
where
his
prolonged
absence
had
occasioned
much
speculation
and
some
alarm
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
be
careful
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
listening
attentively
to
Sam
's
tale
,
"
not
for
our
sakes
,
but
for
that
of
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
be
very
cautious
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
WE
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Winkle
,
with
marked
emphasis
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
momentary
look
of
indignation
at
the
tone
of
this
remark
,
subsided
into
his
characteristic
expression
of
benevolence
,
as
he
replied
---
   
<EOS>
"
WE
,
Sir
!
 
<EOS>
I
shall
accompany
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
!
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
mildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
affording
you
this
interview
,
the
young
lady
has
taken
a
natural
,
perhaps
,
but
still
a
very
imprudent
step
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
am
present
at
the
meeting
---
a
mutual
friend
,
who
is
old
enough
to
be
the
father
of
both
parties
---
the
voice
of
calumny
can
never
be
raised
against
her
hereafter
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
eyes
lightened
with
honest
exultation
at
his
own
foresight
,
as
he
spoke
thus
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
was
touched
by
this
little
trait
of
his
delicate
respect
for
the
young
PROTEGEE
of
his
friend
,
and
took
his
hand
with
a
feeling
of
regard
,
akin
to
veneration
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
SHALL
go
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
have
my
greatcoat
and
shawl
ready
,
and
order
a
conveyance
to
be
at
the
door
to
-
morrow
evening
,
rather
earlier
than
is
absolutely
necessary
,
in
order
that
we
may
be
in
good
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
touched
his
hat
,
as
an
earnest
of
his
obedience
,
and
withdrew
to
make
all
needful
preparations
for
the
expedition
.
   
<EOS>
The
coach
was
punctual
to
the
time
appointed
;
and
Mr
Weller
,
after
duly
installing
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Winkle
inside
,
took
his
seat
on
the
box
by
the
driver
.
 
<EOS>
They
alighted
,
as
had
been
agreed
on
,
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
from
the
place
of
rendezvous
,
and
desiring
the
coachman
to
await
their
return
,
proceeded
the
remaining
distance
on
foot
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
stage
of
the
undertaking
that
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
many
smiles
and
various
other
indications
of
great
self
-
satisfaction
,
produced
from
one
of
his
coat
pockets
a
dark
lantern
,
with
which
he
had
specially
provided
himself
for
the
occasion
,
and
the
great
mechanical
beauty
of
which
he
proceeded
to
explain
to
Mr
Winkle
,
as
they
walked
along
,
to
the
no
small
surprise
of
the
few
stragglers
they
met
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
been
the
better
for
something
of
this
kind
,
in
my
last
garden
expedition
,
at
night
;
eh
,
Sam
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
good
-
humouredly
round
at
his
follower
,
who
was
trudging
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
nice
things
<EOS>
,
if
they
're
managed
properly
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
;
"
but
wen
you
do
n't
want
to
be
seen
,
I
think
they
're
more
useful
arter
<EOS>
the
candle
's
gone
out
,
than
wen
<EOS>
it
's
alight
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
appeared
struck
by
Sam
's
remarks
,
for
he
put
the
lantern
into
his
pocket
again
,
and
they
walked
on
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Down
here
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
lead
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
lane
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Down
the
lane
they
went
,
and
dark
enough
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
brought
out
the
lantern
,
once
or
twice
,
as
they
groped
their
way
along
,
and
threw
a
very
brilliant
little
tunnel
of
light
before
them
,
about
a
foot
in
diameter
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
pretty
to
look
at
,
but
seemed
to
have
the
effect
of
rendering
surrounding
objects
rather
darker
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
they
arrived
at
the
large
stone
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Sam
recommended
his
master
and
Mr
Winkle
to
seat
themselves
,
while
he
reconnoitred
,
and
ascertained
whether
Mary
was
yet
in
waiting
.
   
<EOS>
After
an
absence
of
five
or
ten
minutes
,
Sam
returned
to
say
that
the
gate
was
opened
,
and
all
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
Following
him
with
stealthy
tread
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Winkle
soon
found
themselves
in
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Here
everybody
said
,
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
a
good
many
times
;
and
that
being
done
,
no
one
seemed
to
have
any
very

of
what
was
to
be
done
next
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Miss
Allen
in
the
garden
yet
,
Mary
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
much
agitated
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
pretty
housemaid
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
best
thing
to
be
done
,

,
will

Mr
Weller

give

a

,

Pickwick

see

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
Goodness
gracious
<EOS>
,
what
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
'
ere
blessed
lantern
"
ull

,
"

Sam

.
 
<EOS>
"
Take

<EOS>
wot
<EOS>
you
're
a
-

'

,

;
you
're
a
-
sendin
'

o
'
<EOS>
light
,
right

winder
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
"
said

Pickwick
,
turning

,
"
I
did

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

's

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless

!
"
<EOS>

Pickwick
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
it
's
in
the
stable
,
and
they
'll

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Shut

,
sir
,
ca
n't

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
most
extraordinary
lantern
I
ever
met
with
,

all

!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
'll

vun

,
if

keep
blazin
'
avay

,

,
"

Sam
,

Mr

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
the

's

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

Winkle
,

,
up
vith

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,

!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
must
speak
to
her

.
<EOS>
Help

,
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gently
,
Sir
,
"

Sam
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Step
atop
o
'
that
'
ere
flower
-

,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Now

,
up
vith

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

I

,
Sam
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never

,
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lend

,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Steady
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
time
o
'
day
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Sam
spoke
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
by

almost
supernatural
in
a
gentleman
of
his
years
and
weight
,
contrived
to
get
upon
Sam
's
back
;
and
Sam
gently
raising
himself
up
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
holding
on
fast
by
the
top
of
the
wall
,
while
Mr
Winkle
clasped
him
tight
by
the
legs
,
they
contrived
by
these
means
to
bring
his
spectacles
just
above
the
level
of
the
coping
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
over
the
wall
,
and
catching
sight
of
Arabella
,
on
the
other
side
,
"
do
n't
be
frightened
,
my
dear
,
it
's
only
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
pray
go
away
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
them
all
to
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so
dreadfully
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
Mr
Pickwick
,
do
n't
stop
there
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
fall
down
and
kill
yourself
,
I
know
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
pray
do
n't
alarm
yourself
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
soothingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
not
the
least
cause
for
fear
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
Stand
firm
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
longer
than
you
can
conweniently
help
,

.
 
<EOS>
You
're
rayther
heavy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
another
moment
,
Sam
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
merely
wished
you
to
know
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
that
I
should
not
have
allowed
my
young
friend
to
see
you
in
this
clandestine
way
,
if
the
situation
in
which
you
are
placed
had
left

;
and
,

of
this
step
should
cause
you
any

,
my
love
,
it
may
be
a

to
you
,
to
know
that
I
am
present
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
am

to
you
for
your
kindness
and
consideration
,
"
replied
Arabella
,
drying
her

with
her
