.
 
<EOS>
She
would
probably
have
said
much
more
,
had
not
Mr
Pickwick
's
head
disappeared
with
great
swiftness
,
in
consequence
of
a
false
step
on
Sam
's
shoulder
which
brought
him
suddenly
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
up
again
in
an
instant
however
;
and
bidding
Mr
Winkle
make
haste
and
get
the
interview
over
,
ran
out
into
the
lane
to
keep
watch
,
with
all
the
courage
and
ardour
of
youth
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
himself
,
inspired
by
the
occasion
,
was
on
the
wall
in
a
moment
,
merely
pausing
to
request
Sam
to
be
careful
of
his
master
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
on
him
,
sir
,
"
replied
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
him
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
What
's
he
doing
,
Sam
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Winkle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
his
old
gaiters
,
"
rejoined
Sam
,
looking
out
at
the
garden
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
-
keepin
'
guard
in
the
lane
vith
that
'
ere
dark
lantern
,
like
a
amiable
Guy
Fawkes
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
see
such
a
fine
creetur
in
my
days
.
 
<EOS>
Blessed
if
I
do
n't
think
his
heart
must
ha
'
been
born
five
-
and
-
twenty
year
arter
his
body
,
at
least
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
stayed
not
to
hear
the
encomium
upon
his
friend
.
<EOS>
He
had
dropped
from
the
wall
;
thrown
himself
at
Arabella
's
feet
;
and
by
this
time
was
pleading
the
sincerity
of
his
passion
with
an
eloquence
worthy
even
of
Mr
Pickwick
himself
.
   
<EOS>
While
these
things
were
going
on
in
the
open
air
,
an
elderly
gentleman
of
scientific
attainments
was
seated
in
his
library
,
two
or
three
houses
off
,
writing
a
philosophical
treatise
,
and
ever
and
anon
moistening
his
clay
and
his
labours
with
a
glass
of
claret
from
a
venerable
-
looking
bottle
which
stood
by
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
agonies
of
composition
,
the
elderly
gentleman
looked
sometimes
at
the
carpet
,
sometimes
at
the
ceiling
,
and
sometimes
at
the
wall
;
and
when
neither
carpet
,
ceiling
,
nor
wall
afforded
the
requisite
degree
of
inspiration
,
he
looked
out
of
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
In
one
of
these
pauses
of
invention
,
the
scientific
gentleman
was
gazing
abstractedly
on
the
thick
darkness
outside
,
when
he
was
very
much
surprised
by
observing
a
most
brilliant
light
glide
through
the
air
,
at
a
short
distance
above
the
ground
,
and
almost
instantaneously
vanish
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
time
the
phenomenon
was
repeated
,
not
once
or
twice
,
but
<EOS>
several
times
;
at
last
the
scientific
gentleman
,
laying
down
his
pen
,
began
to
consider
to
what
natural
causes
these
appearances
were
to
be
assigned
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
not
meteors
;
they
were
too
low
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
glow
-
worms
;
they
were
too
high
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
will
-
o'-the
-
wisps
;
they
were
not
fireflies
;
they
were
not
fireworks
.
 
<EOS>
What
could
they
be
?
 
<EOS>
Some
extraordinary
and
wonderful
phenomenon
of
nature
,
which
no
philosopher
had
ever
seen
before
;
<EOS>
something
which
it
had
been
reserved
for
him
alone
to
discover
,
and
which
he
should
immortalise
his
name
by
chronicling
for
the
benefit
of
posterity
.
 
<EOS>
Full
of
this
idea
,
the
scientific
gentleman
seized
his
pen
again
,
and
committed
to
paper
sundry
notes
of
these
unparalleled
appearances
,
with
the
date
,
day
,
hour
,
minute
,
and
precise
second
at
which
they
were
visible
:
all
of
which
were
to
form
the
data
of
a
voluminous
treatise
of
great
research
and
deep
learning
,
which
should
astonish
all
the
atmospherical
wiseacres
that
ever
drew
breath
in
any
part
of
the
civilised
globe
.
   
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
back
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
wrapped
in
contemplations
of
his
future
greatness
.
 
<EOS>
The
mysterious
light
appeared
more
brilliantly
than
before
,
dancing
,
to
all
appearance
,
up
and
down
the
lane
,
crossing
from
side
to
side
,
and
moving
in
an
orbit
as
eccentric
as
comets
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
The
scientific
gentleman
was
a
bachelor
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
wife
to
call
in
and
astonish
,
so
he
rang
the
bell
for
his
servant
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pruffle
,
"
said
the
scientific
gentleman
,
"
there
is
something
very
extraordinary
in
the
air
to
-
night
?
 
<EOS>
Did
you
see
that
?
"
said
the
scientific
gentleman
,
pointing
out
of
the
window
,
as
the
light
again
became
visible
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
did
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
it
,
Pruffle
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
of
it
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
bred
up
in
this
country
.
 
<EOS>
What
should
you
say
was
the
cause
for
those
lights
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
scientific
gentleman
smilingly
anticipated
Pruffle
's
reply
that
he
could
assign
no
cause
for
them
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Pruffle
meditated
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
it
was
thieves
,
Sir
,
"
said
Pruffle
at
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
fool
,
and
may
go
downstairs
,
"
said
the
scientific
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Pruffle
.
 
<EOS>
And
down
he
went
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
scientific
gentleman
could
not
rest
under
the
idea
of
the
ingenious
treatise
he
had
projected
being
lost
to
the
world
,
which
must
inevitably
be
the
case
if
the
speculation
of
the
ingenious
Mr
Pruffle
were
not
stifled
in
its
birth
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
on
his
hat
and
walked
quickly
down
the
garden
,
determined
to
investigate
the
matter
to
the
very
bottom
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
shortly
before
the
scientific
gentleman
walked
out
into
the
garden
,
Mr
Pickwick
had
run
down
the
lane
as
fast
as
he
could
,
to
convey
a
false
alarm
that
somebody
was
coming
that
way
;
occasionally
drawing
back
the
slide
of
the
dark
lantern
to
keep
himself
from
the
ditch
.
 
<EOS>
The
alarm
was
no
sooner
given
,
than
Mr
Winkle
scrambled
back
over
the
wall
,
and
Arabella
ran
into
the
house
;
the
garden
gate
was
shut
,
and
the
three
adventurers
were
making
the
best
of
their
way
down
the
lane
,
when
they
were
startled
by
the
scientific
gentleman
unlocking
his
garden
gate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
hard
,
"
whispered
Sam
,
who
was
,
of
course
,
the
first
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
"
Show
a
light
for
just
vun
second
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
did
as
he
was
desired
,
and
Sam
,
seeing
a
man
's
head
peeping
out
very
cautiously
within
half
a
yard
of
his
own
,
gave
it
a
gentle
tap
with
his
clenched
fist
,
which
knocked
it
,
with
a
hollow
sound
,
against
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
Having
performed
this
feat
with
great
suddenness
and
dexterity
,
Mr
Weller
caught
Mr
Pickwick
up
on
his
back
,
and
followed
Mr
Winkle
down
the
lane
at
a
pace
which
,
considering
the
burden
he
carried
,
was
perfectly
astonishing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
your
vind
back
agin
,
Sir
,
"
inquired
Sam
,
when
they
had
reached
the
end
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
,
now
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
come
along
,
Sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
setting
his
master
on
his
feet
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
betveen
us
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Not
half
a
mile
to
run
.
 
<EOS>
Think
you
're
vinnin
'
a
cup
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Now
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
encouraged
,
Mr
Pickwick
made
the
very
best
use
of
his
legs
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
confidently
stated
that
a
pair
of
black
gaiters
never
got
over
the
ground
in
better
style
than
did
those
of
Mr
Pickwick
on
this
memorable
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
The
coach
was
waiting
,
the
horses
were
fresh
,
the
roads
were
good
,
and
the
driver
was
willing
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
party
arrived
in
safety
at
the
Bush
before
Mr
Pickwick
had
recovered
his
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
in
with
you
at
once
,
sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
as
he
helped
his
master
out
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stop
a
second
in
the
street
,
arter
that
'
ere
exercise
.
 
<EOS>
Beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
continued
Sam
,
touching
his
hat
as
Mr
Winkle
descended
,
"
hope
there
warn't
<EOS>
a
priory
"
tachment
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
grasped
his
humble
friend
by
the
hand
,
and
whispered
in
his
ear
,
"
It
's
all
right
,
Sam
;
quite
right
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
Mr
Weller
struck
three
distinct
blows
upon
his
nose
in
token
of
intelligence
,
smiled
,
winked
,
and
proceeded
to
put
the
steps
up
,
with
a
countenance
expressive
of
lively
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
the
scientific
gentleman
,
he
demonstrated
,
in
a
masterly
treatise
,
that
these
wonderful
lights
were
the
effect
of
electricity
;
and
clearly
proved
the
same
by
detailing
how
a
flash
of
fire
danced
before
his
eyes
when
he
put
his
head
out
of
the
gate
,
and
how
he
received
a
shock
which
stunned
him
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
afterwards
;
which
demonstration
delighted
all
the
scientific
associations
beyond
measure
,
and
caused
him
to
be
considered
a
light
of
science
ever
afterwards
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
40
.
<EOS>
Introduces
Mr
Pickwick
to
a
new
and
not
uninteresting
scene
in
the
great
drama
of
life
 
<EOS>
The
remainder
of
the
period
which
Mr
Pickwick
had
assigned
as
the
duration
of
the
stay
at
Bath
passed
over
without
the
occurrence
of
anything
material
.
 
<EOS>
Trinity
term
commenced
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
expiration
of
its
first
week
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
friends
returned
to
London
;
and
the
former
gentleman
,
attended
of
course
by
Sam
,
straightway
repaired
to
his
old
quarters
at
the
George
and
Vulture
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
third
morning
after
their
arrival
,
just
as
all
the
clocks
in
the
city
were
striking
nine
individually
,
and
somewhere
about
nine
hundred
and
ninety
-
nine
collectively
,
Sam
was
taking
the
air
in
George
Yard
,
when
a
queer
sort
of
fresh
-
painted
vehicle
drove
up
,
out
of
which
there
jumped
with
great
agility
,
throwing
the
reins
to
a
stout
man
who
sat
beside
him
,
a
queer
sort
of
gentleman
,
who
seemed
made
for
the
vehicle
,
and
the
vehicle
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
vehicle
was
not
exactly
a
gig
,
neither
was
it
a
stanhope
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
what
is
currently
denominated
a
dog
-
cart
,
neither
was
it
a
taxed
cart
,
nor
a
chaise
-
cart
,
nor
a
guillotined
cabriolet
;
and
yet
it
had
something
of
the
character
of
each
and
every
of
these
machines
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
painted
a
bright
yellow
,
with
the
shafts
and
wheels
picked
out
in
black
;
and
the
driver
sat
in
the
orthodox
sporting
style
,
on
cushions
piled
about
two
feet
above
the
rail
.
<EOS>
The
horse
was
a
bay
,
a
well
-
looking
animal
enough
;
but
with
something
of
a
flash
and
dog
-
fighting
air
about
him
,
nevertheless
,
which
accorded
both
with
the
vehicle
and
his
master
.
   
<EOS>
The
master
himself
was
a
man
of
about
forty
,
with
black
hair
,
and
carefully
combed
whiskers
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
particularly
gorgeous
manner
,
with
plenty
of
articles
of
jewellery
about
him
---
all
about
three
sizes
larger
than
those
which
are
usually
worn
by
gentlemen
---
and
a
rough
greatcoat
to
crown
the
whole
.
 
<EOS>
Into
one
pocket
of
this
greatcoat
,
he
thrust
his
left
hand
the
moment
he
dismounted
,
while
from
the
other
he
drew
forth
,
with
his
right
,
a
very
bright
and
glaring
silk
handkerchief
,
with
which
he
whisked
a
speck
or
two
of
dust
from
his
boots
,
and
then
,
crumpling
it
in
his
hand
,
swaggered
up
the
court
.
   
<EOS>
It
had
not
escaped
Sam
's
attention
that
,
when
this
person
dismounted
,
a
shabby
-
looking
man
in
a
brown
greatcoat
shorn
of
divers
buttons
,
who
had
been
previously
slinking
about
,
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
crossed
over
,
and
remained
stationary
close
by
.
 
<EOS>
Having
something
more
than
a
suspicion
of
the
object
of
the
gentleman
's
visit
,
Sam
preceded
him
to
the
George
and
Vulture
,
and
,
turning
sharp
round
,
planted
himself
in
the
Centre
of
the
doorway
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
fine
fellow
!
"
said
the
man
in
the
rough
coat
,
in
an
imperious
tone
,
attempting
at
the
same
time
to
push
his
way
past
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Sir
,
wot
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Sam
,
returning
the
push
with
compound
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
none
of
this
,
my
man
;
this
wo
n't
do
with
me
,
"
said
the
owner
of
the
rough
coat
,
raising
his
voice
,
and
turning
white
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Smouch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
wot
's
amiss
here
?
<EOS>
"
growled
the
man
in
the
brown
coat
,
who
had
been
gradually
sneaking
up
the
court
during
this
short
dialogue
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
some
insolence
of
this
young
man
's
,
"
said
the
principal
,
giving
Sam
another
push
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
none
o
'
this
gammon
,
"
growled
Smouch
,
giving
him
another
,
and
a
harder
one
.
   
<EOS>
This
last
push
had
the
effect
which
it
was
intended
by
the
experienced
Mr
Smouch
to
produce
;
for
while
Sam
,
anxious
to
return
the
compliment
,
was
grinding
that
gentleman
's
body
against
the
door
-
post
,
the
principal
crept
past
,
and
made
his
way
to
the
bar
,
whither
Sam
,
after
bandying
a
few
epithetical
remarks
with
Mr
Smouch
,
followed
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
morning
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
principal
,
addressing
the
young
lady
at
the
bar
,
with
Botany
Bay
ease
,
and
New
South
Wales
gentility
;
"
which
is
Mr
Pickwick
's
room
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Show
him
up
,
"
said
the
barmaid
to
a
waiter
,
without
deigning
another
look
at
the
exquisite
,
in
reply
to
his
inquiry
.
   
<EOS>
The
waiter
led
the
way
upstairs
as
he
was
desired
,
and
the
man
in
the
rough
coat
followed
,
with
Sam
behind
him
,
who
,
in
his
progress
up
the
staircase
,
indulged
in
sundry
gestures
indicative
of
supreme
contempt
and
defiance
,
to
the
unspeakable
gratification
of
the
servants
and
other
lookers
-
on
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smouch
,
who
was
troubled
with
a
hoarse
cough
,
remained
below
,
and
expectorated
in
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
fast
asleep
in
bed
,
when
his
early
visitor
,
followed
by
Sam
,
entered
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
they
made
,
in
so
doing
,
awoke
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shaving
-
water
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
from
within
the
curtains
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shave
you
directly
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
the
visitor
,
drawing
one
of
them
back
from
the
bed
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
an
execution
against
you
,
at
the
suit
of
Bardell
.
<EOS>
---
Here
's
the
warrant
.
<EOS>
---
Common
Pleas
.
<EOS>
---
Here
's
my
card
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
'll
come
over
to
my
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
Giving
Mr
Pickwick
a
friendly
tap
on
the
shoulder
,
the
sheriff
's
officer
(
for
such
he
was
)
threw
his
card
on
the
counterpane
,
and
pulled
a
gold
toothpick
from
his
waistcoat
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Namby
's
the
name
,
"
said
the
sheriff
's
deputy
,
as
Mr
Pickwick
took
his
spectacles
from
under
the
pillow
,
and
put
them
on
,
to
read
the
card
.
 
<EOS>
"
Namby
,
Bell
Alley
,
Coleman
Street
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
point
,
Sam
Weller
,
who
had
had
his
eyes
fixed
hitherto
on
Mr
Namby
's
shining
beaver
,
interfered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
Quaker
?
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
let
you
know
I
am
,
before
I
've
done
with
you
,
"
replied
the
indignant
officer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
teach
you
manners
,
my
fine
fellow
,
one
of
these
fine
mornings
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
do
the
same
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
hat
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
Mr
Weller
,
in
the
most
dexterous
manner
,
knocked
Mr
Namby
's
hat
to
the
other
side
of
the
room
,
with
such
violence
,
that
he
had
very
nearly
caused
him
to
swallow
the
gold
toothpick
into
the
bargain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Observe
this
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
the
disconcerted
officer
,
gasping
for
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
assaulted
in
the
execution
of
my
dooty
by
your
servant
in
your
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
in
bodily
fear
.
 
<EOS>
I
call
you
to
witness
this
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
witness
nothin'
,
Sir
,
"
interposed
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shut
your
eyes
up
tight
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
pitch
him
out
o
'
winder
,
only
he
could
n't
fall
far
enough
,
"
cause
o
'
the
leads
outside
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
an
angry
voice
,
as
his
attendant
made
various
demonstrations
of
hostilities
,
"
if
you
say
another
word
,
or
offer
the
slightest
interference
with
this
person
,
I
discharge
you
that
instant
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
Sir
!
"
said
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
that
hat
up
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
this
Sam
flatly
and
positively
refused
to
do
;
and
,
after
he
had
been
severely
reprimanded
by
his
master
,
the
officer
,
being
in
a
hurry
,
condescended
to
pick
it
up
himself
,
venting
a
great
variety
of
threats
against
Sam
meanwhile
,
which
that
gentleman
received
with
perfect
composure
,
merely
observing
that
if
Mr
Namby
would
have
the
goodness
to
put
his
hat
on
again
,
he
would
knock
it
into
the
latter
end
of
next
week
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Namby
,
perhaps
thinking
that
such
a
process
might
be
productive
of
inconvenience
to
himself
,
declined
to
offer
the
temptation
,
and
,
soon
after
,
called
up
Smouch
.
 
<EOS>
Having
informed
him
that
the
capture
was
made
,
and
that
he
was
to
wait
for
the
prisoner
until
he
should
have
finished
dressing
,
Namby
then
swaggered
out
,
and
drove
away
.
 
<EOS>
Smouch
,
requesting
Mr
Pickwick
in
a
surly
manner
"
to
be
as
alive
as
he
could
<EOS>
,
for
it
was
a
busy
time
,
"
drew
up
a
chair
by
the
door
and
sat
there
,
until
he
had
finished
dressing
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
was
then
despatched
for
a
hackney
-
coach
,
and
in
it
the
triumvirate
proceeded
to
Coleman
Street
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
fortunate
the
distance
was
short
;
for
Mr
Smouch
,
besides
possessing
no
very
enchanting
conversational
powers
,
was
rendered
a
decidedly
unpleasant
companion
in
a
limited
space
,
by
the
physical
weakness
to
which
we
have
elsewhere
adverted
.
   
<EOS>
The
coach
having
turned
into
a
very
narrow
and
dark
street
,
stopped
before
a
house
with
iron
bars
to
all
the
windows
;
the
door
-
posts
of
which
were
graced
by
the
name
and
title
of
"
Namby
,
Officer
to
the
Sheriffs
of
London
"
;
the
inner
gate
having
been
opened
by
a
gentleman
who
might
have
passed
for
a
neglected
twin
-
brother
of
Mr
Smouch
,
and
who
was
endowed
with
a
large
key
for
the
purpose
,
Mr
Pickwick
was
shown
into
the
"
coffee
-
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
coffee
-
room
was
a
front
parlour
,
the
principal
features
of
which
were
fresh
sand
and
stale
tobacco
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
bowed
to
the
three
persons
who
were
seated
in
it
when
he
entered
;
and
having
despatched
Sam
for
Perker
,
withdrew
into
an
obscure
corner
,
and
looked
thence
with
some
curiosity
upon
his
new
companions
.
   
<EOS>
One
of
these
was
a
mere
boy
of
nineteen
or
twenty
,
who
,
though
it
was
yet
barely
ten
o'clock
,
was
drinking
gin
-
and
-
water
,
and
smoking
a
cigar
---
amusements
to
which
,
judging
from
his
inflamed
countenance
,
he
had
devoted
himself
pretty
constantly
for
the
last
year
or
two
of
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
Opposite
him
,
engaged
in
stirring
the
fire
with
the
toe
of
his
right
boot
,
was
a
coarse
,
vulgar
young
man
of
about
thirty
,
with
a
sallow
face
and
harsh
voice
;
evidently
possessed
of
that
knowledge
of
the
world
,
and
captivating
freedom
of
manner
,
which
is
to
be
acquired
in
public
-
house
parlours
,
and
at
low
billiard
tables
.
 
<EOS>
The
third
tenant
of
the
apartment
was
a
middle
-
aged
man
in
a
very
old
suit
of
black
,
who
looked
pale
and
haggard
,
and
paced
up
and
down
the
room
incessantly
;
stopping
,
now
and
then
,
to
look
with
great
anxiety
out
of
the
window
as
if
he
expected
somebody
,
and
then
resuming
his
walk
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'd
better
have
the
loan
of
my
razor
this
morning
,
Mr
Ayresleigh
,
"
said
the
man
who
was
stirring
the
fire
,
tipping
the
wink
to
his
friend
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
no
,
<EOS>
I
sha
n't
want
it
;
I
expect
I
shall
be
out
,
in
the
course
of
an
hour
or
so
,
"
replied
the
other
in
a
hurried
manner
.
<EOS>
Then
,
walking
again
up
to
the
window
,
and
once
more
returning
disappointed
,
he
sighed
deeply
,
and
left
the
room
;
upon
which
the
other
two
burst
into
a
loud
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
never
saw
such
a
game
as
that
,
"
said
the
gentleman
who
had
offered
the
razor
,
whose
name
appeared
to
be
Price
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Never
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Price
confirmed
the
assertion
with
an
oath
,
and
then
laughed
again
,
when
of
course
the
boy
(
who
thought
his
companion
one
of
the
most
dashing
fellows
alive
)
laughed
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'd
hardly
think
,
would
you
now
,
"
said
Price
,
<EOS>
turning
towards
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
that
chap
's
been
here
a
week
yesterday
,
and
never
once
shaved
himself
yet
,
because
he
feels
so
certain
he
's
going
out
in
half
an
hour
's
time
,
thinks
he
may
as
well
put
it
off
till
he
gets
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
man
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
his
chances
of
getting
out
of
his
difficulties
really
so
great
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Chances
be
d####d
,
"
replied
Price
;
"
he
has
n't
half
the
ghost
of
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
give
THAT
for
his
chance
of
walking
about
the
streets
this
time
ten
years
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
Mr
Price
snapped
his
fingers
contemptuously
,
and
rang
the
bell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Give
me
a
sheet
of
paper
,
Crookey
,
"
said
Mr
Price
to
the
attendant
,
who
in
dress
and
general
appearance
looked
something
between
a
bankrupt
glazier
,
and
a
drover
in
a
state
of
insolvency
;
"
and
a
glass
of
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
Crookey
,
d'ye
hear
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
going
to
write
to
my
father
,
and
I
must
have
a
stimulant
,
or
I
sha
n't
be
able
to
pitch
it
strong
enough
into
the
old
boy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
facetious
speech
,
the
young
boy
,
it
is
almost
needless
to
say
,
was
fairly
convulsed
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
said
Mr
Price
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
say
die
.
 
<EOS>
All
fun
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Prime
!
"
said
the
young
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
've
got
some
spirit
about
you
,
you
have
,
"
said
Price
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
seen
something
of
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
rather
think
I
have
!
"
replied
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
looked
at
it
through
the
dirty
panes
of
glass
in
a
bar
door
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
feeling
not
a
little
disgusted
with
this
dialogue
,
as
well
as
with
the
air
and
manner
of
the
two
beings
by
whom
it
had
been
carried
on
,
was
about
to
inquire
whether
he
could
not
be
accommodated
with
a
private
sitting
-
room
,
when
two
or
three
strangers
of
genteel
appearance
entered
,
at
sight
of
whom
the
boy
threw
his
cigar
into
the
fire
,
and
whispering
to
Mr
Price
that
they
had
come
to
"
make
it
all
right
"
for
him
,
joined
them
at
a
table
in
the
farther
end
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
It
would
appear
,
however
,
that
matters
were
not
going
to
be
made
all
right
quite
so
speedily
as
the
young
gentleman
anticipated
;
for
a
very
long
conversation
ensued
,
of
which
Mr
Pickwick
could
not
avoid
hearing
certain
angry
fragments
regarding
dissolute
conduct
,
and
repeated
forgiveness
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
there
were
very
distinct
allusions
made
by
the
oldest
gentleman
of
the
party
to
one
Whitecross
Street
,
at
which
the
young
gentleman
,
notwithstanding
his
primeness
and
his
spirit
,
and
his
knowledge
of
life
into
the
bargain
,
reclined
his
head
upon
the
table
,
and
howled
dismally
.
   
<EOS>
Very
much
satisfied
with
this
sudden
bringing
down
of
the
youth
's
valour
,
and
this
effectual
lowering
of
his
tone
,
Mr
Pickwick
rang
the
bell
,
and
was
shown
,
at
his
own
request
,
into
a
private
room
furnished
with
a
carpet
,
table
,
chairs
,
sideboard
and
sofa
,
and
ornamented
with
a
looking
-
glass
,
and
various
old
prints
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
had
the
advantage
of
hearing
Mrs
Namby
's
performance
on
a
square
piano
overhead
,
while
the
breakfast
was
getting
ready
;
when
it
came
,
Mr
Perker
came
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
said
the
little
man
,
"
nailed
at
last
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Come
,
come
,
I
'm
not
sorry
for
it
either
,
because
now
you
'll
see
the
absurdity
of
this
conduct
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
noted
down
the
amount
of
the
taxed
costs
and
damages
for
which
the
ca
-
sa
was
issued
,
and
we
had
better
settle
at
once
and
lose
no
time
.
 
<EOS>
Namby
is
come
home
by
this
time
,
I
dare
say
.
 
<EOS>
What
say
you
,
my
dear
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
draw
a
cheque
,
or
will
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
little
man
rubbed
his
hands
with
affected
cheerfulness
as
he
said
this
,
but
glancing
at
Mr
Pickwick
's
countenance
,
could
not
forbear
at
the
same
time
casting
a
desponding
look
towards
Sam
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perker
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
let
me
hear
no
more
of
this
,
I
beg
.
<EOS>
I
see
no
advantage
in
staying
here
,
so
I
Shall
go
to
prison
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
go
to
Whitecross
Street
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
said
Perker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Impossible
!
 
<EOS>
There
are
sixty
beds
in
a
ward
;
and
the
bolt
's
on
,
sixteen
hours
out
of
the
four
-
and
-
twenty
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
go
to
some
other
place
of
confinement
if
I
can
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
not
,
I
must
make
the
best
I
can
of
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
go
to
the
Fleet
,
my
dear
Sir
,
if
you
're
determined
to
go
somewhere
,
"
said
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
'll
do
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
there
directly
<EOS>
I
have
finished
my
breakfast
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
stop
,
my
dear
Sir
;
not
the
least
occasion
for
being
in
such
a
violent
hurry
to
get
into
a
place
that
most
other
men
are
as
eager
to
get
out
of
,
"
said
the
good
-
natured
little
attorney
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
have
a
habeas
-
corpus
.
 
<EOS>
There
'll
be
no
judge
at
chambers
till
four
o'clock
this
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
wait
till
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
unmoved
patience
.
<EOS>
"
Then
we
will
have
a
chop
here
,
at
two
.
 
<EOS>
See
about
it
,
Sam
,
and
tell
them
to
be
punctual
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
remaining
firm
,
despite
all
the
remonstrances
and
arguments
of
Perker
,
the
chops
appeared
and
disappeared
in
due
course
;
he
was
then
put
into
another
hackney
coach
,
and
carried
off
to
Chancery
Lane
,
after
waiting
half
an
hour
or
so
for
Mr
Namby
,
who
had
a
select
dinner
-
party
and
could
on
no
account
be
disturbed
before
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
two
judges
in
attendance
at
Serjeant
's
Inn
---
one
King
's
Bench
,
and
one
Common
Pleas
---
and
a
great
deal
of
business
appeared
to
be
transacting
before
them
,
if
the
number
of
lawyer
's
clerks
who
were
hurrying
in
and
out
with
bundles
of
papers
,
afforded
any
test
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
reached
the
low
archway
which
forms
the
entrance
to
the
inn
,
Perker
was
detained
a
few
moments
parlaying
with
the
coachman
about
the
fare
and
the
change
;
and
Mr
Pickwick
,
stepping
to
one
side
to
be
out
of
the
way
of
the
stream
of
people
that
were
pouring
in
and
out
,
looked
about
him
with
some
curiosity
.
   
<EOS>
The
people
that
attracted
his
attention
most
,
were
three
or
four
men
of
shabby
-
genteel
appearance
,
who
touched
their
hats
to
many
of
the
attorneys
who
passed
,
and
seemed
to
have
some
business
there
,
the
nature
of
which
Mr
Pickwick
could
not
divine
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
curious
-
looking
fellows
.
 
<EOS>
One
was
a
slim
and
rather
lame
man
in
rusty
black
,
and
a
white
neckerchief
;
another
was
a
stout
,
burly
person
,
dressed
in
the
same
apparel
,
with
a
great
reddish
-
black
cloth
round
his
neck
;
a
third
was
a
little
weazen
,
drunken
-
looking
body
,
with
a
pimply
face
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
loitering
about
,
with
their
hands
behind
them
,
and
now
and
then
with
an
anxious
countenance
whispered
something
in
the
ear
of
some
of
the
gentlemen
with
papers
,
as
they
hurried
by
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
remembered
to
have
very
often
observed
them
lounging
under
the
archway
when
he
had
been
walking
past
;
and
his
curiosity
was
quite
excited
to
know
to
what
branch
of
the
profession
these
dingy
-
looking
loungers
could
possibly
belong
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
propound
the
question
to
Namby
,
who
kept
close
beside
him
,
sucking
a
large
gold
ring
on
his
little
finger
,
when
Perker
bustled
up
,
and
observing
that
there
was
no
time
to
lose
,
led
the
way
into
the
inn
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
followed
,
the
lame
man
stepped
up
to
him
,
and
civilly
touching
his
hat
,
held
out
a
written
card
,
which
Mr
Pickwick
,
not
wishing
to
hurt
the
man
's
feelings
by
refusing
,
courteously
accepted
and
deposited
in
his
waistcoat
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Perker
,
turning
round
before
he
entered
one
of
the
offices
,
to
see
that
his
companions
were
close
behind
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
here
,
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Hallo
,
what
do
you
want
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
last
question
was
addressed
to
the
lame
man
,
who
,
unobserved
by
Mr
Pickwick
,
made
one
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
In
reply
to
it
,
the
lame
man
touched
his
hat
again
,
with
all
imaginable
politeness
,
and
motioned
towards
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Perker
,
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
want
you
,
my
dear
friend
,
we
do
n't
want
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
the
lame
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
took
my
card
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
employ
me
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
nodded
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
be
judged
by
the
gentleman
himself
.
 
<EOS>
You
nodded
to
me
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
,
pooh
,
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
You
did
n't
nod
to
anybody
,
Pickwick
?
<EOS>
A
mistake
,
a
mistake
,
"
said
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
gentleman
handed
me
his
card
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
producing
it
from
his
waistcoat
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
accepted
it
,
as
the
gentleman
seemed
to
wish
it
---
in
fact
I
had
some
curiosity
to
look
at
it
when
I
should
be
at
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
"
   
The
little
attorney
burst
into
a
loud
laugh
,
and
returning
the
card
to
the
lame
man
,
informing
him
it
was
all
a
mistake
,
<EOS>
whispered
to
Mr
Pickwick
as
the
man
turned
away
in
dudgeon
,
that
he
was
only
a
bail
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
what
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
bail
,
"
replied
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
bail
!
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
sir
---
half
a
dozen
of
'em
here
.
 
Bail
you
to
any
amount
,
and
only
charge
half
a
crown
.
 
<EOS>
Curious
trade
,
is
n't
it
?
"
said
Perker
,
regaling
himself
with
a
pinch
of
snuff
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Am
I
to
understand
that
these
men
earn
a
livelihood
by
waiting
about
here
,
to
perjure
themselves
before
the
judges
of
the
land
,
at
the
rate
of
half
a
crown
a
crime
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,
quite
aghast
at
the
disclosure
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
do
n't
exactly
know
about
perjury
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
replied
the
little
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Harsh
word
,
my
dear
sir
,
very
harsh
word
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
legal
fiction
,
my
dear
sir
,
nothing
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
Saying
which
,
the
attorney
shrugged
his
shoulders
,
smiled
,
took
a
second
pinch
of
snuff
,
and
led
the
way
into
the
office
of
the
judge
's
clerk
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
room
of
specially
dirty
appearance
,
with
a
very
low
ceiling
and
old
panelled
walls
;
and
so
badly
lighted
,
that
although
it
was
broad
day
outside
,
great
tallow
candles
were
burning
on
the
desks
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
end
,
was
a
door
leading
to
the
judge
's
private
apartment
,
round
which
were
congregated
a
crowd
of
attorneys
and
managing
clerks
,
who
were
called
in
,
in
the
order
in
which
their
respective
appointments
stood
upon
the
file
.
 
<EOS>
Every
time
this
door
was
opened
to
let
a
party
out
,
the
next
party
made
a
violent
rush
to
get
in
;
and
,
as
in
addition
to
the
numerous
dialogues
which
passed
between
the
gentlemen
who
were
waiting
to
see
the
judge
,
a
variety
of
personal
squabbles
ensued
between
the
greater
part
of
those
who
had
seen
him
,
there
was
as
much
noise
as
could
well
be
raised
in
an
apartment
of
such
confined
dimensions
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
were
the
conversations
of
these
gentlemen
<EOS>
the
only
sounds
that
broke
upon
the
ear
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
on
a
box
behind
a
wooden
bar
at
another
end
of
the
room
was
a
clerk
in
spectacles
who
was
"
taking
the
affidavits
"
;
large
batches
of
which
were
,
from
time
to
time
,
carried
into
the
private
room
by
another
clerk
for
the
judge
's
signature
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
large
number
of
attorneys
"
clerks
to
be
sworn
,
and
it
being
a
moral
impossibility
to
swear
them
all
at
once
,
the
struggles
of
these
gentlemen
to
reach
the
clerk
in
spectacles
,
were
like
those
of
a
crowd
to
get
in
at
the
pit
door
of
a
theatre
when
Gracious
Majesty
honours
it
with
its
presence
.
<EOS>
Another
functionary
,
from
time
to
time
,
exercised
his
lungs
in
calling
over
the
names
of
those
who
had
been
sworn
,
for
the
purpose
of
restoring
to
them
their
affidavits
after
they
had
been
signed
by
the
judge
,
which
gave
rise
to
a
few
more
scuffles
;
and
all
these
things
going
on
at
the
same
time
,
occasioned
as
much
bustle
as
the
most
active
and
excitable
person
could
desire
to
behold
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
yet
another
class
of
persons
---
those
who
were
waiting
to
attend
summonses
their
employers
had
taken
out
,
which
it
was
optional
to
the
attorney
on
the
opposite
side
to
attend
or
not
---
and
whose
business
it
was
,
from
time
to
time
,
to
cry
out
the
opposite
attorney
's
name
;
to
make
certain
that
he
was
not
in
attendance
without
their
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
For
example
.
 
<EOS>
Leaning
against
the
wall
,
close
beside
the
seat
Mr
Pickwick
had
taken
,
was
an
office
-
lad
of
fourteen
,
with
a
tenor
voice
;
near
him
a
common
-
law
clerk
with
a
bass
one
.
   
<EOS>
A
clerk
hurried
in
with
a
bundle
of
papers
,
and
stared
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sniggle
and
Blink
,
"
cried
the
tenor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Porkin
and
Snob
,
"
growled
the
bass
.
<EOS>
"
Stumpy
and
Deacon
,
"
said
the
new
-
comer
.
   
<EOS>
Nobody
answered
;
the
next
man
who
came
in
,
was
bailed
by
the
whole
three
;
and
he
in
his
turn
shouted
for
another
firm
;
and
then
somebody
else
roared
in
a
loud
voice
for
another
;
and
so
forth
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
the
man
in
the
spectacles
was
hard
at
work
,
swearing
the
clerks
;
the
oath
being
invariably
administered
,
without
any
effort
at
punctuation
,
and
usually
in
the
following
terms
<EOS>
:
---
   
"
Take
the
book
in
your
right
hand
this
is
your
name
and
hand
-
writing
<EOS>
you
swear
that
the
contents
of
this
your
affidavit
are
true
<EOS>
so
help
you
God
a
shilling
<EOS>
you
must
get
change
<EOS>
I
have
n't
got
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
suppose
they
are
getting
the
HABEAS
-
CORPUS
ready
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
vish
<EOS>
they
'd
bring
out
the
have
-
his
-
carcase
.
<EOS>
It
's
wery
unpleasant
keepin
'
us
vaitin
'
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
ha
'
got
half
a
dozen
have
-
his
-
carcases
ready
,
<EOS>
pack'd
up
and
all
,
by
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
What
sort
of
cumbrous
and
unmanageable
machine
,
Sam
Weller
imagined
a
habeas
-
corpus
to
be
,
does
not
appear
;
for
Perker
,
at
that
moment
,
walked
up
and
took
Mr
Pickwick
away
.
   
<EOS>
The
usual
forms
having
been
gone
through
,
the
body
of
Samuel
Pickwick
was
soon
afterwards
confided
to
the
custody
of
the
tipstaff
,
to
be
by
him
taken
to
the
warden
of
the
Fleet
Prison
,
and
there
detained
until
the
amount
of
the
damages
and
costs
in
the
action
of
Bardell
against
Pickwick
was
fully
paid
and
satisfied
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
laughing
,
"
will
be
a
very
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
,
call
another
hackney
-
coach
.
 
<EOS>
Perker
,
my
dear
friend
,
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
with
you
,
and
see
you
safe
there
,
"
said
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
would
rather
go
without
any
other
attendant
than
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
get
settled
,
I
will
write
and
let
you
know
,
and
I
shall
expect
you
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
Until
then
,
good
-
bye
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
said
this
,
he
got
into
the
coach
which
had
by
this
time
arrived
,
followed
by
the
tipstaff
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
having
stationed
himself
on
the
box
,
it
rolled
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
most
extraordinary
man
that
!
<EOS>
"
said
Perker
,
as
he
stopped
to
pull
on
his
gloves
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
bankrupt
he
'd
make
,
Sir
,
"
observed
Mr
Lowten
,
who
was
standing
near
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
he
would
bother
the
commissioners
!
<EOS>
He
'd
set
'em
at
defiance
if
they
talked
of
committing
him
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
attorney
did
not
appear
very
much
delighted
with
his
clerk
's
professional
estimate
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
character
,
for
he
walked
away
without
deigning
any
reply
.
   
<EOS>
The
hackney
-
coach
jolted
along
Fleet
Street
,
as
hackney
-
coaches
usually
do
.
 
<EOS>
The
horses
"
went
better
"
,
the
driver
said
,
when
they
had
anything
before
them
(
they
must
have
gone
at
a
most
extraordinary
pace
when
there
was
nothing
)
,
and
so
the
vehicle
kept
behind
a
cart
;
when
the
cart
stopped
,
it
stopped
;
and
when
the
cart
went
on
again
,
it
did
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
sat
opposite
the
tipstaff
;
and
the
tipstaff
sat
with
his
hat
between
his
knees
,
whistling
a
tune
,
and
looking
out
of
the
coach
window
.
   
<EOS>
Time
performs
wonders
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
powerful
old
gentleman
's
aid
,
even
a
hackney
-
coach
gets
over
half
a
mile
of
ground
.
 
<EOS>
They
stopped
at
length
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
alighted
at
the
gate
of
the
Fleet
.
   
<EOS>
The
tipstaff
,
just
looking
over
his
shoulder
to
see
that
his
charge
was
following
close
at
his
heels
,
preceded
Mr
Pickwick
into
the
prison
;
turning
to
the
left
,
<EOS>
after
they
had
entered
,
they
passed
through
an
open
door
into
a
lobby
,
from
which
a
heavy
gate
,
opposite
to
that
by
which
they
had
entered
,
and
which
was
guarded
by
a
stout
turnkey
with
the
key
in
his
hand
,
led
at
once
into
the
interior
of
the
prison
.
   
<EOS>
Here
they
stopped
,
while
the
tipstaff
delivered
his
papers
;
and
here
Mr
Pickwick
was
apprised
that
he
would
remain
,
until
he
had
undergone
the
ceremony
,
known
to
the
initiated
as
"
sitting
for
your
portrait
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sitting
for
my
portrait
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Having
your
likeness
taken
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
stout
turnkey
.
<EOS>
"
We
're
capital
hands
at
likenesses
here
.
 
<EOS>
Take
'em
in
no
time
,
and
always
exact
.
 
<EOS>
Walk
in
,
sir

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

;
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Here
,

,

,

over

-

of

,
or
playing
at
all
-
fours
with

very

of

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
some

might

seen

,
by

light
of
a

,
over

,

to

from

,

,
for

,
some

of
his

,
for
the
perusal
of
some
great
man
whose
eyes
it
would
never

,
or
whose
heart
it
would
never
touch
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
third
,
a
man
,
with

wife
and
a

,
might

making

,

,
for
the

.
 
<EOS>
And
in
a

,

,
and
a

,
and
a

,
the

,

,
and
the

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
In

themselves
,
and
more

-
cases
,
there

a
great
number
of

,
who
came

,
some
because

were
empty
and

,
others
because

were
full

hot
;
the

were

and

,
and
not
possessed
of
the
secret
of

what
to
do
with

.
 
<EOS>
There
were
many
classes
of
people
here
,
from
the
labouring
man
in
his
fustian
jacket
,
to
the
broken
-
down
spendthrift
in

shawl
dressing
-
gown
,
most
appropriately
out
at
elbows
;
but

about

all
---
a

,
jail
-
bird
,

,
a

who's
-
afraid

of
bearing
,
which
is
wholly

in
words
,
but
which
any
man
can
understand
in
one
moment
if
he
wish
,
by
setting
foot
in
the
nearest
debtors

<EOS>
As

.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few

in
the
Painted

,
which
,
as
it
was
now

,

,
he
intimated
to
Mr
Weller
that
he
thought

high
time
for
him
to
withdraw
for
the
night
;
requesting
him
to
seek
a
bed
in
some
adjacent
public
-
house
,
and
return
early
in
the
morning
,
to
make
arrangements
for
the
removal
of
his
master
's
wardrobe
from
the
George
and
Vulture
.
 
<EOS>
This
request
<EOS>
Mr
Samuel
Weller
prepared
to
obey
,
with
as
good
a
grace
as
he
could
assume
,
but
with
a
very
considerable
show
of
reluctance
nevertheless
.
 
<EOS>
He
even
went
so
far
as
to
essay
sundry
ineffectual
hints
regarding
the
expediency
of
stretching
himself
on
the
gravel
for
that
night
;
but
finding
Mr
Pickwick
obstinately
deaf
to
any
such
suggestions
,
finally
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
no
disguising
the
fact
that
Mr
Pickwick
felt
very
low
-
spirited
and
uncomfortable
---
not
for
lack
of
society
,
for
the
prison
was
very
full
,
and
a
bottle
of
wine
would
at
once
have
purchased
the
utmost
good
-
fellowship
of
a
few
choice
spirits
,
without
any
more
formal
ceremony
of
introduction
;
but
he
was
alone
in
the
coarse
,
vulgar
crowd
,
and
felt
the
depression
of
spirits
and
sinking
of
heart
,
naturally
consequent
on
the
reflection
that
he
was
cooped
and
caged
up
,
without
a
prospect
of
liberation
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
idea
of
releasing
himself
by
ministering
to
the
sharpness
of
Dodson
&
Fogg
,
it
never
for
an
instant
entered
his
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
frame
of
mind
he
turned
again
into
the
coffee
-
room
gallery
,
and
walked
slowly
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
was
intolerably
dirty
,
and
the
smell
of
tobacco
smoke
perfectly
suffocating
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
perpetual
slamming
and
banging
of
doors
as
the
people
went
in
and
out
;
and
the
noise
of
their
voices
and
footsteps
echoed
and
re
-
echoed
through
the
passages
constantly
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
woman
,
with
a
child
in
her
arms
,
who
seemed
scarcely
able
to
crawl
,
from
emaciation
and
misery
,
was
walking
up
and
down
the
passage
in
conversation
with
her
husband
,
who
had
no
other
place
to
see
her
in
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
passed
Mr
Pickwick
,
he
could
hear
the
female
sob
bitterly
;
and
once
she
burst
into
such
a
passion
of
grief
,
that
she
was
compelled
to
lean
against
the
wall
for
support
,
while
the
man
took
the
child
in
his
arms
,
and
tried
to
soothe
her
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
heart
was
really
too
full
to
bear
it
,
and
he
went
upstairs
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
although
the
warder
's
room
was
a
very
uncomfortable
one
(
being
,
in
every
point
of
decoration
and
convenience
,
several
hundred
degrees
inferior
to
the
common
infirmary
of
a
county
jail
)
,
it
had
at
present
the
merit
of
being
wholly
deserted
save
by
Mr
Pickwick
himself
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
he
sat
down
at
the
foot
of
his
little
iron
bedstead
,
and
began
to
wonder
how
much
a
year
the
warder
made
out
of
the
dirty
room
.
 
<EOS>
Having
satisfied
himself
,
by
mathematical
calculation
,
that
the
apartment
was
about
equal
in
annual
value
to
the
freehold
of
a
small
street
in
the
suburbs
of
London
,
he
took
to
wondering
what
possible
temptation
could
have
induced
a
dingy
-
looking
fly
that
was
crawling
over
his
pantaloons
,
to
come
into
a
close
prison
,
when
he
had
the
choice
of
so
many
airy
situations
---
a
course
of
meditation
which
led
him
to
the
irresistible
conclusion
that
the
insect
was
insane
.
 
<EOS>
After
settling
this
point
,
he
began
to
be
conscious
that
he
was
getting
sleepy
;
whereupon
he
took
his
nightcap
out
of
the
pocket
in
which
he
had
had
the
precaution
to
stow
it
in
the
morning
,
and
,
leisurely
undressing
himself
,
got
into
bed
and
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
 
<EOS>
Heel
over
toe
---
<EOS>
cut
and
shuffle
---
pay
away
at
it
,
Zephyr
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
smothered
if
the
opera
house
is
n't
your
proper
hemisphere
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
it
up
!
 
<EOS>
Hooray
!
"
 
<EOS>
These
expressions
,
delivered
in
a
most
boisterous
tone
,
and
accompanied
with
loud
peals
of
laughter
,
roused
Mr
Pickwick
from
one
of
those
sound
slumbers
which
,
lasting
in
reality
some
half
-
hour
,
seem
to
the
sleeper
to
have
been
protracted
for
three
weeks
or
a
month
.
   
<EOS>
The
voice
had
no
sooner
ceased
than
the
room
was
shaken
with
such
violence
that
the
windows
rattled
in
their
frames
,
and
the
bedsteads
trembled
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
started
up
,
and
remained
for
some
minutes
fixed
in
mute
astonishment
at
the
scene
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
floor
of
the
room
,
a
man
in
a
broad
-
skirted
green
coat
,
with
corduroy
knee
-
smalls
and
gray
cotton
stockings
,
was
performing
the
most
popular
steps
of
a
hornpipe
,
with
a
slang
and
burlesque
caricature
of
grace
and
lightness
,
which
,
combined
with
the
very
appropriate
character
of
his
costume
,
was
inexpressibly
absurd
.
 
<EOS>
Another
man
,
evidently
very
drunk
,
who
had
probably
been
tumbled
into
bed
by
his
companions
,
was
sitting
up
between
the
sheets
,
warbling
as
much
as
he
could
recollect
of
a
comic
song
,
with
the
most
intensely
sentimental
feeling
and
expression
;
while
a
third
,
seated
on
one
of
the
bedsteads
,
was
applauding
both
performers
with
the
air
of
a
profound
connoisseur
,
and
encouraging
them
by
such
ebullitions
of
feeling
as
had
already
roused
Mr
Pickwick
from
his
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
This
last
man
was
an
admirable
specimen
of
a
class
of
gentry
which
never
can
be
seen
in
full
perfection
but
in
such
places
---
they
may
be
met
with
,
in
an
imperfect
state
,
occasionally
about
stable
-
yards
and
Public
-
houses
;
but
they
never
attain
their
full
bloom
except
in
these
hot
-
beds
,
which
would
almost
seem
to
be
considerately
provided
by
the
legislature
for
the
sole
purpose
of
rearing
them
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
fellow
,
with
an
olive
complexion
,
long
dark
hair
,
and
very
thick
bushy
whiskers
meeting
under
his
chin
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
no
neckerchief
,
as
he
had
been
playing
rackets
all
day
,
and
his
Open
shirt
collar
displayed
their
full
luxuriance
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
head
he
wore
one
of
the
common
eighteenpenny
French
skull
-
caps
,
with
a
gaudy
tassel
<EOS>
dangling
therefrom
,
very
happily
in
keeping
with
a
common
fustian
coat
.
 
<EOS>
His
legs
,
which
,
being
long
,
were
afflicted
with
weakness
,
graced
a
pair
of
Oxford
-
mixture
trousers
,
made
to
show
the
full
symmetry
of
those
limbs
.
 
<EOS>
Being
somewhat
negligently
braced
,
however
,
and
,
moreover
,
but
imperfectly
buttoned
,
they
fell
in
a
series
of
not
the
most
graceful
folds
over
a
pair
of
shoes
sufficiently
down
at
heel
to
display
a
pair
of
very
soiled
white
stockings
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
rakish
,
vagabond
smartness
,
and
a
kind
of
boastful
rascality
,
about
the
whole
man
,
that
was
worth
a
mine
of
gold
.
   
<EOS>
This
figure
was
the
first
to
perceive
that
Mr
Pickwick
was
looking
on
;
upon
which
he
winked
to
the
Zephyr
,
and
entreated
him
,
with
mock
gravity
,
not
to
wake
the
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
bless
the
gentleman
's
honest
heart
and
soul
!
"
said
the
Zephyr
,
turning
round
and
affecting
the
extremity
of
surprise
;
"
the
gentleman
is
awake
.
 
<EOS>
Hem
,
Shakespeare
!
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
Sir
?
 
<EOS>
How
is
Mary
and
Sarah
,
sir
?
<EOS>
and
the
dear
old
lady
at
home
,
Sir
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
have
the
kindness
to
put
my
compliments
into
the
first
little
parcel
you
're
sending
that
way
,
sir
,
and
say
that
I
would
have
sent
'em
before
,
only
I
was
afraid
they
might
be
broken
in
the
wagon
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
overwhelm
the
gentlemen
with
ordinary
civilities
when
you
see
he
's
anxious
to
have
something
to
drink
,
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
whiskers
,
with
a
jocose
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
ask
the
gentleman
what
he
'll
take
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
I
quite
forgot
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
take
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
take
port
wine
,
sir
,
or
sherry
wine
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
I
can
recommend
the
ale
,
sir
;
or
perhaps
you
'd
like
to
taste
the
porter
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
have
the
felicity
of
hanging
up
your
nightcap
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
,
the
speaker
snatched
that
article
of
dress
from
Mr
Pickwick
's
head
,
and
fixed
it
in
a
twinkling
on
that
of
the
drunken
man
,
who
,
firmly
impressed
with
the
belief
that
he
was
delighting
a
numerous
assembly
,
continued
to
hammer
away
at
the
comic
song
in
the
most
melancholy
strains
imaginable
.
   
<EOS>
Taking
a
man
's
nightcap
from
his
brow
by
violent
means
,
and
adjusting
it
on
the
head
of
an
unknown
gentleman
,
of
dirty
exterior
,
however
ingenious
a
witticism
in
itself
,
is
unquestionably
one
of
those
which
come
under
the
denomination
of
practical
jokes
.
 
<EOS>
Viewing
the
matter
precisely
in
this
light
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
without
the
slightest
intimation
of
his
purpose
,
sprang
vigorously
out
of
bed
,
struck
the
Zephyr
<EOS>
so
smart
a
blow
in
the
chest
as
to
deprive
him
of
a
considerable
portion
of
the
commodity
which
sometimes
bears
his
name
,
and
then
,
recapturing
his
nightcap
,
boldly
placed
himself
in
an
attitude
of
defence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
gasping
no
less
from
excitement
than
from
the
expenditure
of
so
much
energy
,
"
come
on
---
both
of
you
---
both
of
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
liberal
invitation
the
worthy
gentleman
communicated
a
revolving
motion
to
his
clenched
fists
,
by
way
of
appalling
his
antagonists
with
a
display
of
science
.
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
Mr
Pickwick
's
very
unexpected
gallantry
,
or
it
might
have
been
the
complicated
manner
in
which
he
had
got
himself
out
of
bed
,
and
fallen
all
in
a
mass
upon
the
hornpipe
man
,
that
touched
his
adversaries
.
 
<EOS>
Touched
they
were
;
for
,
instead
of
then
and
there
making
an
attempt
to
commit
man
-
slaughter
,
<EOS>
as
Mr
Pickwick
implicitly
believed
they
would
have
done
,
they
paused
,
stared
at
each
other
a
short
time
,
and
finally
laughed
outright
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
you
're
a
trump
,
and
I
like
you
all
the
better
for
it
,
"
said
the
Zephyr
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
jump
into
bed
again
,
or
you
'll
catch
the
rheumatics
.
 
<EOS>
No
malice
,
I
hope
?
"
said
the
man
,
extending
a
hand
the
size
of
the
yellow
clump
of
fingers
which
sometimes
swings
over
a
glover
's
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
great
alacrity
;
for
,
<EOS>
now
that
the
excitement
was
over
,
he
began
to
feel
rather
cool
about
the
legs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
the
H
-
onour
,
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
whiskers
,
presenting
his
dexter
hand
,
and
aspirating
the
h.
   
<EOS>
"
With
much
pleasure
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
and
having
executed
a
very
long
and
solemn
shake
,
he
got
into
bed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Smangle
,
sir
,
"
said
the
man
with
the
whiskers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mine
is
Mivins
,
"
said
the
man
in
the
stockings
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
delighted
to
hear
it
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
,
"
coughed
Mr
Smangle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
speak
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
did
not
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Smangle
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
was
very
genteel
and
pleasant
;
and
,
to
make
matters
still
more
comfortable
,
Mr
Smangle
assured
Mr
Pickwick
a
great
many
more
times
that
he
entertained
a
very
high
respect
for
the
feelings
of
a
gentleman
;
which
sentiment
,
indeed
,
did
him
infinite
credit
,
as
he
could
be
in
no
wise
supposed
to
understand
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
through
the
court
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Smangle
.
<EOS>
"
Through
the
what
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Through
the
court
---
Portugal
Street
---
the
Court
for
Relief
of
---
 
You
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
out
,
perhaps
?
"
suggested
Mr
Mivins
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
refuse
to
pay
some
damages
,
and
am
here
in
consequence
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
"
said
Mr
Smangle
,
<EOS>
"
paper
has
been
my
ruin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
stationer
,
I
presume
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
innocently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stationer
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
confound
and
curse
me
!
 
<EOS>
Not
so
low
as
that
.
<EOS>
No
trade
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
say
paper
,
I
mean
bills
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
use
the
word
in
that
sense
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Damme
!
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
must
expect
reverses
,
"
said
Smangle
.
<EOS>
"
What
of
that
?
 
<EOS>
Here
am
I
in
the
Fleet
Prison
.
 
<EOS>
Well
;
good
.
 
<EOS>
What
then
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
none
the
worse
for
that
,
am
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
,
"
replied
Mr
Mivins
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
was
quite
right
;
for
,
so
far
from
Mr
Smangle
being
any
the
worse
for
it
,
he
was
something
the
better
,
inasmuch
as
to
qualify
himself
for
the
place
,
he
had
attained
gratuitous
possession
of
certain
articles
of
jewellery
,
which
,
long
before
that
,
had
found
their
way
to
the
pawnbroker
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
;
but
come
,
"
said
Mr
Smangle
;
"
this
is
dry
work
.
 
<EOS>
Let
's
rinse
our
mouths
with
a
drop
of
burnt
sherry
;
the
last
-
comer
shall
stand
it
,
Mivins
shall
fetch

,
and
I
'll
help
to
drink
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
fair
and
gentlemanlike
division
of
labour
,
anyhow
.
 
<EOS>
Curse
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Unwilling
to
hazard
another
quarrel
,
Mr
Pickwick
gladly
assented
to
the
proposition
,
and
consigned
the
money
to
Mr
Mivins
,
who
,
as
it
was
nearly
eleven
o'clock
,
lost
no
time
in
repairing
to
the
coffee
-
room
on
his
errand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
whispered
Smangle
,
the
moment
his
friend
had
left
the
room
;
"
what
did
you
give
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Half
a
sovereign
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
a
devilish
pleasant
gentlemanly
dog
,
"
said
Mr
Smangle
;
---
"
infernal
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
anybody
more
so
;
<EOS>
but
---
"
Here
Mr
Smangle
stopped
short
,
and
shook
his
head
dubiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
think
there
is
any
probability
of
his
appropriating
the
money
to
his
own
use
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Mind
,
I
do
n't
say
that
;
I
expressly
say
that
he
's
a
devilish
gentlemanly
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Smangle
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
think
,
perhaps
,
if
somebody
went
down
,
just
to
see
that
he
did
n't
dip
his
beak
into
the
jug
by
accident
,
or
make
some
confounded
mistake
in
losing
the
money
as
he
came
upstairs
,
it
would
be
as
well
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
you
sir
,
just
run
downstairs
,
and
look
after
that
gentleman
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
request
was
addressed
to
a
little
timid
-
looking
,
nervous
man
,
whose
appearance
bespoke
great
poverty
,
and
who
had
been
crouching
on
his
bedstead
all
this
while
,
apparently
stupefied
by
the
novelty
of
his
situation
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
where
the
coffee
-
room
is
,
"
said
Smangle
;
"
just
run
down
,
and
tell
that
gentleman
you
've
come
to
help
him
up
with
the
jug
.
 
<EOS>
Or
---
stop
<EOS>
---
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
---
I
'll
tell
you
how
we
'll
do
him
,
"
said
Smangle
,
with
a
cunning
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Send
down
word
that
he
's
to
spend
the
change
in
cigars
.
<EOS>
Capital
thought
.
 
<EOS>
Run
and
tell
him
that
<EOS>
;
d'ye
hear
?
 
<EOS>
They
sha
n't
be
wasted
,
"
continued
Smangle
,
turning
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I'LL
smoke
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
manoeuvring
was
so
exceedingly
ingenious
and
,
withal
,
performed
with
such
immovable
composure
and
coolness
,
that
Mr
Pickwick
would
have
had
no
wish
to
disturb
it
,
even
if
he
had
had
the
power
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
Mr
Mivins
returned
,
bearing
the
sherry
,
which
Mr
Smangle
dispensed
in
two
little
cracked
mugs
;
considerately
remarking
,
with
reference
to
himself
,
that
a
gentleman
must
not
be
particular
under
such
circumstances
,
and
that
,
for
his
part
,
he
was
not
too
proud
to
drink
out
of
the
jug
.
<EOS>
In
which
,
to
show
his
sincerity
,
he
forthwith
pledged
the
company
in
a
draught
which
half
emptied
it
.
   
<EOS>
An
excellent
understanding
having
been
by
these
means
promoted
,
Mr
Smangle
proceeded
to
entertain
his
hearers
with
a
relation
of
divers
romantic
adventures
in
which
he
had
been
from
time
to
time
engaged
,
involving
various
interesting
anecdotes
of
a
thoroughbred
horse
,
and
a
magnificent
Jewess
,
both
of
surpassing
beauty
,
and
much
coveted
by
the
nobility
and
gentry
of
these
kingdoms
.
   
<EOS>
Long
before
these
elegant
extracts
from
the
biography
of
a
gentleman
were
concluded
,
Mr
Mivins
had
betaken
himself
to
bed
,
and
had
set
in
snoring
for
the
night
,
leaving
the
timid
stranger
and
Mr
Pickwick
to
the
full
benefit
of
Mr
Smangle
's
experiences
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
were
the
two
last
-
named
gentlemen
as
much
edified
as
they
might
have
been
by
the
moving
passages
narrated
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
in
a
state
of
slumber
for
some
time
,
when
he
had
a
faint
perception
of
the
drunken
man
bursting
out
afresh
with
the
comic
song
,
and
receiving
from
Mr
Smangle
a
gentle
intimation
,
through
the
medium
of
the
water
-
jug
,
that
his
audience
was
not
musically
disposed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
then
once
again
dropped
off
to
sleep
,
with
a
confused
consciousness
that
Mr
Smangle
was
still
engaged
in
relating
a
long
story
,
the
chief
point
of
which
appeared
to
be
that
,
on
some
occasion
particularly
stated
and
set
forth
,
he
had
"
done
"
a
bill
and
a
gentleman
at
the
same
time
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
42
.
<EOS>
Illustrative
,
like
the
preceding
one
,
of
the
old
proverb
,
that
adversity
brings
a
man
acquainted
with
strange
bedfellows
---
likewise
containing
Mr
Pickwick
's
extraordinary
and
startling
announcement
to
Mr
Samuel
Weller
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Pickwick
opened
his
eyes
next
morning
,
the
first
object
upon
which
they
rested
was
Samuel
Weller
,
seated
upon
a
small

,
intently
regarding
,
apparently
in
a
condition
of
profound

,
the
stately
figure
of
the
dashing
Mr
Smangle
;
while
Mr
Smangle
himself
,
who
was
already
partially
dressed
,
was
seated
on
his
bedstead
,
occupied
in
the
desperately
hopeless
attempt
of
staring
Mr
Weller
out
of
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
We
say
desperately
hopeless
,
because
Sam
,
with
a
comprehensive

which
took
in
Mr
Smangle
's
cap
,

,

,

,

,

,
all

,

to

steadily
on
,
with
every

of
lively

,
but
with

to
Mr

's

than

had

a

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
;

?
"
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'd
svear

anyveres
,
Sir
,
"

Sam

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

wen

,
I

upon

wery
best
extra
-
super
behaviour
!
"
 
<EOS>

,

imply
that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mivins
!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
"
<EOS>
'

"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
Has

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

ud

<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.

<EOS>
Guided
