gallery
until
he
encountered
the
"
portrait
of
a
gentleman
,
"
above
described
,
upon
whose
countenance
he
tapped
,
with
the
knuckle
of
his
forefinger
---
gently
at
first
,
and
then
audibly
.
 
<EOS>
After
repeating
this
process
several
times
without
effect
,
he
ventured
to
open
the
door
and
peep
in
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
man
in
the
room
,
and
he
was
leaning
out
of
window
as
far
as
he
could
without
overbalancing
himself
,
endeavouring
,
with
great
perseverance
,
to
spit
upon
the
crown
of
the
hat
of
a
personal
friend
on
the
parade
below
.
 
<EOS>
As
neither
speaking
,
coughing
,
sneezing
,
knocking
,
nor
any
other
ordinary
mode
of
attracting
attention
,
made
this
person
aware
of
the
presence
of
a
visitor
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
some
delay
,
stepped
up
to
the
window
,
and
pulled
him
gently
by
the
coat
tail
.
 
<EOS>
The
individual
brought
in
his
head
and
shoulders
with
great
swiftness
,
and
surveying
Mr
Pickwick
from
head
to
foot
,
demanded
in
a
surly
tone
what
the
---
something
beginning
with
a
capital
H
---
he
wanted
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
consulting
his
ticket
---
"
<EOS>
I
believe
this
is
twenty
-
seven
in
the
third
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
replied
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
here
in
consequence
of
receiving
this
bit
of
paper
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hand
it
over
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
complied
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
Roker
might
have
chummed
you
somewhere
else
,
"
said
Mr
Simpson
(
for
it
was
the
leg
)
<EOS>
,
after
a
very
discontented
sort
of
a
pause
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
thought
so
also
;
but
,
under
all
the
circumstances
,
he
considered
it
a
matter
of
sound
policy
to
be
silent
.
<EOS>
Mr
Simpson
mused
for
a
few
moments
after
this
,
and
then
,
thrusting
his
head
out
of
the
window
,
gave
a
shrill
whistle
,
and
pronounced
some
word
aloud
,
several
times
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
word
was
,
Mr
Pickwick
could
not
distinguish
;
but
he
rather
inferred
that
it
must
be
some
nickname
which
distinguished
Mr
Martin
,
from
the
fact
of
a
great
number
of
gentlemen
on
the
ground
below
,
immediately
proceeding
to
cry
"
Butcher
!
"
<EOS>
in
imitation
of
the
tone
in
which
that
useful
class
of
society
are
wo
nt
,
diurnally
,
to
make
their
presence
known
at
area
railings
.
   
<EOS>
Subsequent
occurrences
confirmed
the
accuracy
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
impression
;
for
,
in
a
few
seconds
,
a
gentleman
,
prematurely
broad
for
his
years
,
clothed
in
a
professional
blue
jean
frock
and
top
-
boots
with
circular
toes
,
entered
the
room
nearly
out
of
breath
,
closely
followed
by
another
gentleman
in
very
shabby
black
,
and
a
sealskin
cap
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
gentleman
,
who
fastened
his
coat
all
the
way
up
to
his
chin
by
means
of
a
pin
and
a
button
alternately
,
had
a
very
coarse
red
face
,
and
looked
like
a
drunken
chaplain
;
which
,
indeed
,
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
These
two
gentlemen
having
by
turns
perused
Mr
Pickwick
's
billet
,
the
one
expressed
his
opinion
that
it
was
"
a
rig
,
"
and
the
other
his
conviction
that
it
was
"
a
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
recorded
their
feelings
in
these
very
intelligible
terms
,
they
looked
at
Mr
Pickwick
and
each
other
in
awkward
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
aggravating
thing
,
just
as
we
got
the
beds
so
snug
,
"
said
the
chaplain
,
looking
at
three
dirty
mattresses
,
each
rolled
up
in
a
blanket
;
which
occupied
one
corner
of
the
room
during
the
day
,
and
formed
a
kind
of
slab
,
on
which
were
placed
an
old
cracked
basin
,
ewer
,
and
soap
-
dish
,
of
common
yellow
earthenware
,
with
a
blue
flower
---
"
very
aggravating
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Martin
expressed
the
same
opinion
in
rather
stronger
terms
;
Mr
Simpson
,
after
having
let
a
variety
of
expletive
adjectives
loose
upon
society
without
any
substantive
to
accompany
them
,
tucked
up
his
sleeves
,
and
began
to
wash
the
greens
for
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
While
this
was
going
on
,
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
eyeing
the
room
,
which
was
filthily
dirty
,
and
smelt
intolerably
close
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
vestige
of
either
carpet
,
curtain
,
or
blind
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
even
a
closet
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Unquestionably
there
were
but
few
things
to
put
away
,
if
there
had
been
one
;
but
,
<EOS>
however
few
in
number
,
or
small
in
individual
amount
,
still
,
remnants
of
loaves
and
pieces
of
cheese
,
and
damp
towels
,
and
scrags
of
meat
,
and
articles
of
wearing
apparel
,
and
mutilated
crockery
,
and
bellows
without
nozzles
,
and
toasting
-
forks
without
prongs
,
do
present
somewhat
of
an
uncomfortable
appearance
when
they
are
scattered
about
the
floor
of
a
small
apartment
,
which
is
the
common
sitting
and
sleeping
room
of
three
idle
men
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
this
can
be
managed
somehow
,
"
said
the
butcher
,
after
a
pretty
long
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
take
to
go
out
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
say
?
<EOS>
I
hardly
understand
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
take
to
be
paid
out
?
"
said
the
butcher
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
regular
chummage
is
two
-
and
-
six
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
take
three
bob
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
a
bender
,
"
suggested
the
clerical
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
do
n't
mind
that
;
it
's
only
twopence
<EOS>
a
piece
more
,
"
said
Mr
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
,
now
?
 
<EOS>
We
'll
pay
you
out
for
three
-
and
-
sixpence
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
stand
a
gallon
of
beer
down
,
"
chimed
in
Mr
Simpson
.
"
There
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
drink
it
on
the
spot
,
"
said
the
chaplain
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
   
"
I
really
am
so
wholly
ignorant
of
the
rules
of
this
place
,
"
returned
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
I
do
not
yet
comprehend
you
.
 
<EOS>
Can
I
live
anywhere
else
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
could
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
inquiry
Mr
Martin
looked
,
with
a
countenance
of
excessive
surprise
,
at
his
two
friends
,
and
then
each
gentleman
pointed
with
his
right
thumb
over
his
left
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
This
action
imperfectly
described
in
words
by
the
very
feeble
term
of
"
over
the
left
,
"
when
performed
by
any
number
of
ladies
or
gentlemen
who
are
accustomed
to
act
in
unison
,
has
a
very
graceful
and
airy
effect
;
its
expression
is
one
of
light
and
playful
sarcasm
.
   
<EOS>
"
CAN
you
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Martin
,
with
a
smile
of
pity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
if
I
knew
as
little
of
life
as
that
,
I
'd
eat
my
hat
and
swallow
the
buckle
whole
,
"
said
the
clerical
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
would
I
,
"
added
the
sporting
one
solemnly
.
   
<EOS>
After
this
introductory
preface
,
the
three
chums
informed
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
a
breath
,
that
money
was
,
in
the
Fleet
,
<EOS>
just
what
money
was
out
of
it
;
that
it
would
instantly
procure
him
almost
anything
he
desired
;
and
that
,
supposing
he
had
it
,
and
had
no
objection
to
spend
it
,
if
he
only
signified
his
wish
to
have
a
room
to
himself
,
he
might
take
possession
of
one
,
furnished
and
fitted
to
boot
,
in
half
an
hour
's
time
.
   
<EOS>
With
this
the
parties
separated
,
very
much
to
their
common
satisfaction
;
Mr
Pickwick
once
more
retracing
his
steps
to
the
lodge
,
and
the
three
companions
adjourning
to
the
coffee
-
room
,
there
to
spend
the
five
shillings
which
the
clerical
gentleman
had
,
with
admirable
prudence
and
foresight
,
borrowed
of
him
for
the
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
knowed
it
!
"
said
Mr
Roker
,
with
a
chuckle
,
when
Mr
Pickwick
stated
the
object
with
which
he
had
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
say
so
,
Neddy
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
philosophical
owner
of
the
universal
penknife
growled
an
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
knowed
you
'd
want
a
room
for
yourself
,
bless
you
!
"
said
Mr
Roker
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
want
some
furniture
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
hire
that
of
me
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
reg'lar
thing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
great
pleasure
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
capital
room
up
in
the
coffee
-
room
flight
,
that
belongs
to
a
Chancery
prisoner
,
"
said
Mr
Roker
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
'll
stand
you
in
a
pound
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
do
n't
mind
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
step
there
with
me
,
"
said
Roker
,
taking
up
his
hat
with
great
alacrity
;
"
the
matter
's
settled
in
five
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
!
<EOS>
why
did
n't
you
say
at
first
that
you
was
willing
to
come
down
handsome
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
matter
was
soon
arranged
,
as
the
turnkey
had
foretold
.
<EOS>
The
Chancery
prisoner
had
been
there
long
enough
to
have
lost
his
friends
,
fortune
,
home
,
and
happiness
,
and
to
have
acquired
the
right
of
having
a
room
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
laboured
,
however
,
under
the
inconvenience
of
often
wanting
a
morsel
of
bread
,
he
eagerly
listened
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
proposal
to
rent
the
apartment
,
and
readily
covenanted
and
agreed
to
yield
him
up
the
sole
and
undisturbed
possession
thereof
,
in
consideration
of
the
weekly
payment
of
twenty
shillings
;
from
which
fund
he
furthermore
contracted
to
pay
out
any
person
or
persons
that
might
be
chummed
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
struck
the
bargain
,
Mr
Pickwick
surveyed
him
with
a
painful
interest
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
,
gaunt
,
cadaverous
man
,
in
an
old
greatcoat
and
slippers
,
with
sunken
cheeks
,
and
a
restless
,
eager
eye
.
 
<EOS>
His
lips
were
bloodless
,
and
his
bones
sharp
and
thin
.
 
<EOS>
God
help
him
!
<EOS>
the
iron
teeth
of
confinement
and
privation
had
been
slowly
filing
him
down
for
twenty
years
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
where
will
you
live
meanwhile
,
Sir
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
laid
the
amount
of
the
first
week
's
rent
,
in
advance
,
on
the
tottering
table
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
gathered
up
the
money
with
a
trembling
hand
,
and
replied
that
he
did
n't
know
yet
;
he
must
go
and
see
where
he
could
move
his
bed
to
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
laying
his
hand
gently
and
compassionately
on
his
arm
---
"
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
you
will
have
to
live
in
some
noisy
,
crowded
place
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
pray
,
consider
this
room
your
own
when
you
want
quiet
,
or
when
any
of
your
friends
come
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Friends
!
"
interposed
the
man
,
in
a
voice
which
rattled
in
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
"
if
I
lay
dead
at
the
bottom
of
the
deepest
mine
in
the
world
;
tight
screwed
down
and
soldered
in
my
coffin
;
rotting
in
the
dark
and
filthy
ditch
that
drags
its
slime
along
,
beneath
the
foundations
of
this
prison
;
I
could
not
be
more
forgotten
or
unheeded
than
I
am
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
dead
man
;
dead
to
society
,
without
the
pity
they
bestow
on
those
whose
souls
have
passed
to
judgment
.
 
<EOS>
Friends
to
see
me
!
 
<EOS>
My
God
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
sunk
,
from
the
prime
of
life
into
old
age
,
in
this
place
,
and
there
is
not
one
to
raise
his
hand
above
my
bed
when
I
lie
dead
upon
it
,
and
say
,
"
It
is
a
blessing
he
is
gone
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
The
excitement
,
which
had
cast
an
unwonted
light
over
the
man
's
face
,
while
he
spoke
,
subsided
as
he
concluded
;
and
pressing
his
withered
hands
together
in
a
hasty
and
disordered
manner
,
he
shuffled
from
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rides
rather
rusty
,
"
said
Mr
Roker
,
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
they
're
like
the
elephants
.
 
<EOS>
They
feel
it
now
and
then
,
and
it
makes
'em
wild
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
made
this
deeply
-
sympathising
remark
,
Mr
Roker
entered
upon
his
arrangements
with
such
expedition
,
that
in
a
short
time
the
room
was
furnished
with
a
carpet
,
six
chairs
,
a
table
,
a
sofa
bedstead
,
a
tea
-
kettle
,
and
various
small
articles
,
on
hire
,
at
the
very
reasonable
rate
of
seven
-
and
-
twenty
shillings
and
sixpence
per
week
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
is
there
anything
more
we
can
do
for
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Roker
,
looking
round
with
great
satisfaction
,
and
gaily
chinking
the
first
week
's
hire
in
his
closed
fist
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
been
musing
deeply
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
there
any
people
here
who
run
on
errands
,
and
so
forth
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Outside
,
do
you
mean
?
"
inquired
Mr
Roker
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
who
are
able
to
go
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Not
prisoners
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
there
is
,
"
said
Roker
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
an
unfortunate
devil
,
who
has
got
a
friend
on
the
poor
side
,
that
's
glad
to
do
anything
of
that
sort
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
been
running
odd
jobs
,
and
that
,
for
the
last
two
months
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
send
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
;
no
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
side
,
you
say
?
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
to
him
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
poor
side
of
a
debtor
's
prison
is
,
as
its
name
imports
,
that
in
which
the
most
miserable
and
abject
class
of
debtors
are
confined
.
 
<EOS>
A
prisoner
having
declared
upon
the
poor
side
,
pays
neither
rent
nor
chummage
.
 
<EOS>
His
fees
,
upon
entering
and
leaving
the
jail
,
are
reduced
in
amount
,
and
he
becomes
entitled
to
a
share
of
some
small
quantities
of
food
:
to
provide
which
,
a
few
charitable
persons
have
,
from
time
to
time
,
left
trifling
legacies
in
their
wills
.
 
<EOS>
Most
of
our
readers
will
remember
,
that
,
until
within
a
very
few
years
past
,
there
was
a
kind
of
iron
cage
in
the
wall
of
the
Fleet
Prison
,
within
which
was
posted
some
man
of
hungry
looks
,
who
,
from
time
to
time
,
rattled
a
money
-
box
,
and
exclaimed
in
a
mournful
voice
,
"
Pray
,
remember
the
poor
debtors
;
pray
remember
the
poor
debtors
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
receipts
of
this
box
,
when
there
were
any
,
were
divided
among
the
poor
prisoners
;
and
the
men
on
the
poor
side
relieved
each
other
in
this
degrading
office
.
   
<EOS>
Although
this
custom
has
been
abolished
,
and
the
cage
is
now
boarded
up
,
the
miserable
and
destitute
condition
of
these
unhappy
persons
remains
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
We
no
longer
suffer
them
to
appeal
at
the
prison
gates
to
the
charity
and
compassion
of
the
passersby
;
but
we
still
leave
unblotted
the
leaves
of
our
statute
book
,
for
the
reverence
and
admiration
of
succeeding
ages
,
the
just
and
wholesome
law
which
declares
that
the
sturdy
felon
shall
be
fed
and
clothed
,
and
that
the
penniless
debtor
shall
be
left
to
die
of
starvation
and
nakedness
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
no
fiction
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
week
passes
over
our
head
,
but
,
in
every
one
of
our
prisons
for
debt
,
some
of
these
men
must
inevitably
expire
in
the
slow
agonies
of
want
,
if
they
were
not
relieved
by
their
fellow
-
prisoners
.
   
<EOS>
Turning
these
things
in
his
mind
,
as
he
mounted
the
narrow
staircase
at
the
foot
of
which
Roker
had
left
him
,
Mr
Pickwick
gradually
worked
himself
to
the
boiling
-
over
point
;
and
so
excited
was
he
with
his
reflections
on
this
subject
,
that
he
had
burst
into
the
room
to
which
he
had
been
directed
,
before
he
had
any
distinct
recollection
,
either
of
the
place
in
which
he
was
,
or
of
the
object
of
his
visit
.
   
<EOS>
The
general
aspect
of
the
room
recalled
him
to
himself
at
once
;
but
he
had
no
sooner
cast
his
eye
on
the
figure
of
a
man
who
was
brooding
over
the
dusty
fire
,
than
,
letting
his
hat
fall
on
the
floor
,
he
stood
perfectly
fixed
and
immovable
with
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
Yes
;
in
tattered
garments
,
and
without
a
coat
;
his
common
calico
shirt
,
yellow
and
in
rags
;
his
hair
hanging
over
his
face
;
his
features
changed
with
suffering
,
and
pinched
with
famine
---
there
sat
Mr
Alfred
Jingle
;
his
head
resting
on
his
hands
,
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
fire
,
and
his
whole
appearance
denoting
misery
and
dejection
!
   
<EOS>
Near
him
,
leaning
listlessly
against
the
wall
,
stood
a
strong
-
built
countryman
,
flicking
with
a
worn
-
out
hunting
-
whip
the
top
-
boot
that
adorned
his
right
foot
;
his
left
being
thrust
into
an
old
slipper
.
 
<EOS>
Horses
,
dogs
,
and
drink
had
brought
him
there
,
pell
-
mell
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
rusty
spur
on
the
solitary
boot
,
which
he
occasionally
jerked
into
the
empty
air
,
at
the
same
time
giving
the
boot
a
smart
blow
,
and
muttering
some
of
the
sounds
by
which
a
sportsman
encourages
his
horse
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
riding
,
in
imagination
,
some
desperate
steeplechase
at
that
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
wretch
!
 
<EOS>
He
never
rode
a
match
on
the
swiftest
animal
in
his
costly
stud
,
with
half
the
speed
at
which
he
had
torn
along
the
course
that
ended
in
the
Fleet
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
opposite
side
of
the
room
an
old
man
was
seated
on
a
small
wooden
box
,
with
his
eyes
riveted
on
the
floor
,
and
his
face
settled
into
an
expression
of
the
deepest
and
most
hopeless
despair
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
girl
---
his
little
grand
-
daughter
---
was
hanging
about
him
,
endeavouring
,
with
a
thousand
childish
devices
,
to
engage
his
attention
;
but
the
old
man
neither
saw
nor
heard
her
.
<EOS>
The
voice
that
had
been
music
to
him
,
and
the
eyes
that
had
been
light
,
fell
coldly
on
his
senses
.
 
<EOS>
His
limbs
were
shaking
with
disease
,
and
the
palsy
had
fastened
on
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
two
or
three
other
men
in
the
room
,
congregated
in
a
little
knot
,
and
noiselessly
talking
among
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
lean
and
haggard
woman
,
too
---
<EOS>
a
prisoner
's
wife
---
who
was
watering
,
with
great
solicitude
,
the
wretched
stump
of
a
dried
-
up
,
withered
plant
,
which
,
it
was
plain
to
see
,
could
never
send
forth
a
green
leaf
again
---
too
true
an
emblem
,
perhaps
,
of
the
office
she
had
come
there
to
discharge
.
   
<EOS>
Such
were
the
objects
which
presented
themselves
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
view
,
as
he
looked
round
him
in
amazement
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
of
some
one
stumbling
hastily
into
the
room
,
roused
him
.
<EOS>
Turning
his
eyes
towards
the
door
,
they
encountered
the
new
-
comer
;
and
in
him
,
through
his
rags
and
dirt
,
he
recognised
the
familiar
features
of
Mr
Job
Trotter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
!
"
exclaimed
Job
aloud
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
said
Jingle
,
starting
from
his
seat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
 
---
!
 
<EOS>
So
it
is
---
<EOS>
queer
place
---
strange
things
---
serves
me
right
---
very
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jingle
thrust
his
hands
into
the
place
where
his
trousers
pockets
used
to
be
,
and
,
dropping
his
chin
upon
his
breast
,
sank
back
into
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
was
affected
;
the
two
men
looked
so
very
miserable
.
<EOS>
The
sharp
,
involuntary
glance
Jingle
had
cast
at
a
small
piece
of
raw
loin
of
mutton
,
which
Job
had
brought
in
with
him
,
said
more
of
their
reduced
state
than
two
hours
"
explanation
could
have
done
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
looked
mildly
at
Jingle
,
and
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
speak
to
you
in
private
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
step
out
for
an
instant
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Jingle
,
rising
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
step
far
---
no
danger
of
overwalking
yourself
here
---
<EOS>
spike
park
---
<EOS>
grounds
pretty
---
romantic
,
but
not
extensive
---
open
for
public
inspection
 
---
family
always
in
town
---
housekeeper
desperately
careful
---
very
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
forgotten
your
coat
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
they
walked
out
to
the
staircase
,
and
closed
the
door
after
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
said
Jingle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Spout
---
dear
relation
---
uncle
Tom
---
could
n't
help
it
---
must
eat
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Wants
of
nature
---
and
all
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
,
my
dear
sir
---
last
coat
---
ca
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
Lived
on
a
pair
of
boots
---
whole
fortnight
.
 
<EOS>
Silk
umbrella
---
<EOS>
ivory
handle
---
<EOS>
week
---
fact
---
honour
<EOS>
---
ask
Job
---
knows
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lived
for
three
weeks
upon
a
pair
of
boots
,
and
a
silk
umbrella
with
an
ivory
handle
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
only
heard
of
such
things
in
shipwrecks
or
read
of
them
in
Constable
's
Miscellany
.
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
said
Jingle
,
nodding
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pawnbroker
's
shop
---
duplicates
here
---
<EOS>
small
sums
---
<EOS>
mere
nothing
---
all
rascals
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
much
relieved
by
this
explanation
;
"
I
understand
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
pawned
your
wardrobe
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everything
---
<EOS>
Job
's
too
---
all
shirts
gone
---
never
mind
---
<EOS>
saves
washing
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
soon
---
lie
in
bed
---
starve
---
die
---
inquest
---
little
bone
-
house
---
poor
prisoner
---
common
necessaries
---
<EOS>
hush
it
up
---
gentlemen
of
the
jury
---
warden
's
tradesmen
---
keep
it
snug
---
natural
death
---
coroner
's
order
---
workhouse
funeral
---
serve
him
right
---
all
over
---
drop
the
curtain
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jingle
delivered
this
singular
summary
of
his
prospects
in
life
,
with
his
accustomed
volubility
,
and
with
various
twitches
of
the
countenance
to
counterfeit
smiles
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
easily
perceived
that
his
recklessness
was
assumed
,
and
looking
him
full
,
but
not
unkindly
,
in
the
face
,
saw
that
his
eyes
were
moist
with
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
fellow
,
"
said
Jingle
,
pressing
his
hand
,
and
turning
his
head
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ungrateful
dog
---
boyish
to
cry
---
ca
n't
help
it
---
bad
fever
---
weak
---
ill
---
hungry
.
 
<EOS>
Deserved
it
all
---
but
suffered
much
---
very
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wholly
unable
to
keep
up
appearances
any
longer
,
and
perhaps
rendered
worse
by
the
effort
he
had
made
,
the
dejected
stroller
sat
down
on
the
stairs
,
and
,
covering
his
face
with
his
hands
,
sobbed
like
a
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
considerable
emotion
,
"
we
will
see
what
can
be
done
,
when
I
know
all
about
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Here
,
Job
;
where
is
that
fellow
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
sir
,
"
replied
Job
,
presenting
himself
on
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
described
him
,
by
the
bye
,
as
having
deeply
-
sunken
eyes
,
in
the
best
of
times
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
present
state
of
want
and
distress
,
he
looked
as
if
those
features
had
gone
out
of
town
altogether
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
sir
,
"
cried
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
trying
to
look
stern
,
with
four
large
tears
running
down
his
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
that
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Take
what
?
 
<EOS>
In
the
ordinary
acceptation
of
such
language
,
it
should
have
been
a
blow
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
world
runs
,
it
ought
to
have
been
a
sound
,
hearty
cuff
;
for
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
duped
,
deceived
,
and
wronged
by
the
destitute
outcast
who
was
now
wholly
in
his
power
.
 
<EOS>
Must
we
tell
the
truth
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
something
from
Mr
Pickwick
's
waistcoat
pocket
,
which
chinked
as
it
was
given
into
Job
's
hand
,
and
the
giving
of
which
,
somehow
or
other
imparted
a
sparkle
to
the
eye
,
and
a
swelling
to
the
heart
,
of
our
excellent
old
friend
,
as
he
hurried
away
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
had
returned
when
Mr
Pickwick
reached
his
own
room
,
and
was
inspecting
the
arrangements
that
had
been
made
for
his
comfort
,
with
a
kind
of
grim
satisfaction
which
was
very
pleasant
to
look
upon
.
 
<EOS>
Having
a
decided
objection
to
his
master
's
being
there
at
all
,
Mr
Weller
appeared
to
consider
it
a
high
moral
duty
not
to
appear
too
much
pleased
with
anything
that
was
done
,
said
,
suggested
,
or
proposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
comfortable
now
,
eh
,
Sam
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
vell
,
sir
,
"
responded
Sam
,
looking
round
him
in
a
disparaging
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
Mr
Tupman
and
our
other
friends
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
HAVE
seen
'em
,
sir
,
and
they
're
a
-
comin
'
to
-
morrow
,
and
wos
wery
much
surprised
to
hear
they
warn't
<EOS>
to
come
to
-
day
,
"
replied
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
brought
the
things
I
wanted
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
in
reply
pointed
to
various
packages
which
he
had
arranged
,
as
neatly
as
he
could
,
in
a
corner
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
a
little
hesitation
;
"
listen
to
what
I
am
going
to
say
,
Sam
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cert'nly
,

,
"

;
"
fire

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

re

.
<EOS>

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
43
.
<EOS>
Showing
how
Mr
Samuel
Weller
got
into
difficulties
 
<EOS>
In
a
lofty
room
,
ill
-
lighted
and
worse
ventilated
,
situated
in
Portugal
Street
,
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
,
there
sit
<EOS>
nearly
the
whole
year
round
,
one
,
two
,
three
,
or
four
gentlemen
in
wigs
,
as
the
case
may
be
,
with
little
writing
-
desks
before
them
,
constructed
after
the
fashion
of
those
used
by
the
judges
of
the
land
,
barring
the
French
polish
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
box
of
barristers
on
their
right
hand
;
there
is
an
enclosure
of
insolvent
debtors
on
their
left
;
and
there
is
an
inclined
plane
of
most
especially
dirty
faces
in
their
front
.
 
<EOS>
These
gentlemen
are
the
Commissioners
of
the
Insolvent
Court
,
and
the
place
in
which
they
sit
,
is
the
Insolvent
Court
itself
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
,
and
has
been
,
time
out
of
mind
,
the
remarkable
fate
of
this
court
to
be
,
somehow
or
other
,
held
and
understood
,
by
the
general
consent
of
all
the
destitute
shabby
-
genteel
people
in
London
,
as
their
common
resort
,
and
place
of
daily
refuge
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
always
full
.
 
<EOS>
The
steams
of
beer
and
spirits
perpetually
ascend
to
the
ceiling
,
and
,
being
condensed
by
the
heat
,
roll
down
the
walls
like
rain
;
there
are
more
old
suits
of
clothes
in
it
at
one
time
,
than
will
be
offered
for
sale
in
all
Houndsditch
in
a
twelvemonth
;
more
unwashed
skins
and
grizzly
beards
than
all
the
pumps
and
shaving
-
shops
between
Tyburn
and
Whitechapel
could
render
decent
,
between
sunrise
and
sunset
.
   
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
supposed
that
any
of
these
people
have
the
least
shadow
of
business
in
,
or
the
remotest
connection
with
,
the
place
they
so
indefatigably
attend
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
had
,
it
would
be
no
matter
of
surprise
,
and
the
singularity
of
the
thing
would
cease
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
sleep
during
the
greater
part
of
the
sitting
;
others
carry
small
portable
dinners
wrapped
in
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
or
sticking
out
of
their
worn
-
out
pockets
,
and
munch
and
listen
with
equal
relish
;
but
no
one
among
them
was
ever
known
to
have
the
slightest
personal
interest
in
any
case
that
was
ever
brought
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
they
do
,
there
they
sit
from
the
first
moment
to
the
last
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
is
heavy
,
rainy
weather
,
they
all
come
in
,
wet
through
;
and
at
such
times
the
vapours
of
the
court
are
like
those
of
a
fungus
-
pit
.
   
<EOS>
A
casual
visitor
might
suppose
this
place
to
be
a
temple
dedicated
to
the
Genius
of
Seediness
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
not
a
messenger
or
process
-
server
attached
to
it
,
who
wears
a
coat
that
was
made
for
him
;
not
a
tolerably
fresh
,
or
wholesome
-
looking
man
in
the
whole
establishment
,
except
a
little
white
-
headed
apple
-
faced
tipstaff
,
and
even
he
,
like
an
ill
-
conditioned
cherry
preserved
in
brandy
,
seems
to
have
artificially
dried
and
withered
up
into
a
state
of
preservation
to
which
he
can
lay
no
natural
claim
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
barristers
"
<EOS>
wigs
are
ill
-
powdered
,
and
their
curls
lack
crispness
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
attorneys
,
who
sit
at
a
large
bare
table
below
the
commissioners
,
are
,
after
all
,
the
greatest
curiosities
.
 
<EOS>
The
professional
establishment
of
the
more
opulent
of
these
gentlemen
,
consists
of
a
blue
bag
and
a
boy
;
generally
a
youth
of
the
Jewish
persuasion
.
<EOS>
They
have
no
fixed
offices
,
their
legal
business
being
transacted
in
the
parlours
of
public
-
houses
,
or
the
yards
of
prisons
,
whither
they
repair
in
crowds
,
and
canvass
for
customers
after
the
manner
of
omnibus
cads
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
of
a
greasy
and
mildewed
appearance
;
and
if
they
can
be
said
to
have
any
vices
at
all
,
perhaps
drinking
and
cheating
are
the
most
conspicuous
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
Their
residences
are
usually
on
the
outskirts
of
"
the
Rules
,
"
chiefly
lying
within
a
circle
of
one
mile
from
the
obelisk
in
St
George
's
Fields
.
 
<EOS>
Their
looks
are
not
prepossessing
,
and
their
manners
are
peculiar
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Solomon
Pell
,
one
of
this
learned
body
,
was
a
fat
,
flabby
,
pale
man
,
in
a
surtout
which
looked
green
one

,
and
brown

,
with
a

of
the
same

.
<EOS>
His

was
narrow
,
his
face
wide
,
his
head
large
,
and
his
nose
all
on
one
side
,
<EOS>
as
if
Nature
,
indignant
with
the
propensities
she
observed
in
him
in
his
birth
,
had
given
it
an
angry

which
it
had
never

.
 
<EOS>
Being
short
-

and

,
however
,
he
respired
principally
through
this
feature
;
so
,
perhaps
,
what
it
wanted
in

,
it
made
up
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Certain

"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

No

,
"

;

.
   
<EOS>
Now
,

;

Mr

,

,

<EOS>

vere

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

back

,

Mr

at

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
insolvent
gentleman
,
who
had
contracted
a
speculative
but
imprudent

for
horsing
long

,
which
had
led
to
his
present
embarrassments
,
looked
extremely
well
,
and
was
soothing
the
excitement
of
his

with
shrimps
and
porter
.
   
<EOS>
The
salutation
between
Mr
Weller
and
his
friends
was
strictly
confined
to
the
freemasonry
of
the
craft
;
consisting
of
a
jerking
round
of
the
right
wrist
,
and
a
tossing
of
the
little
finger
into
the
air
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
We
once
knew
two
famous
coachmen
(
they
are
dead
now
,
poor
fellows
)
who
were
twins
,
and
between
whom
an
unaffected
and
devoted
attachment
existed
.
 
<EOS>
They
passed
each
other
on
the
Dover
road
,
every
day
,
for
twenty
-
four
years
,
never
exchanging
any
other
greeting
than
this
;
and
yet
,
when
one
died
,
the
other
pined
away
,
and
soon
afterwards
followed
him
!
   
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
George
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
senior
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
How

?
<EOS>
All

,

?
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
George

Vell
,

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Con

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery

,
wery

<EOS>
"

ven

.

<EOS>

;

Ven

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Mr

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

---
 
<EOS>

---
 
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>
"

,
"

"

!
 
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

service

you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

I
a
-

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think

was
remarkin
'
as

would
n't

another
o
'
<EOS>
the

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

---
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Hem

"
   
<EOS>
This

<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
Why
should

?
"
   
A

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,
"

;

,

;

"
Pell
,
"

,
"
no

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

,
Pell
;

.
"
 
<EOS>
Those

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>

Pell

.

.

wery

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Observations

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Thank

,

;

.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus

,

thrust

,

,

,
rattled
three

with
terrible

.
   
<EOS>
This
virtuous
resolution
had
scarcely

formed
,
when
the
boy
and

blue

,

,

(
at

,

took

in

)
that
the
case
was

.
 
<EOS>
The

was
no
sooner
received
than
the
whole
party
hurried
across
the
street
,
and
began
to
fight
their
way
into
court
---
a
preparatory
ceremony
,
which
has
been
calculated
to
occupy
,
in
ordinary
cases
,
from
twenty
-
five
minutes
to
thirty
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
,
being
stout
,
cast
himself
at
once
into
the
crowd
,
with
the
desperate
hope
of
ultimately
turning
up
in
some
place
which
would
suit

.
 
<EOS>
His

was
not
quite
equal
to
his

;
for
having
neglected
to
take
his
hat
off
,
it
was
knocked
over
his
eyes
by
some
unseen
person
,
upon
whose
toes
he
had
alighted
with
considerable
force
.
 
<EOS>
Apparently
this
individual
regretted
his
impetuosity
immediately
afterwards
,
for
,
muttering

indistinct

of

,
he
dragged
the
old
man
out
into
the

,
and
,
after

,
released
his
head
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Samivel
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Weller
,
when
he
was
thus
enabled
to
behold

.
   
<EOS>
Sam
nodded
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
dutiful

boy
,
you
are
,
ai
n't

,
"

Weller
,
"
to
come
a
-
bonnetin
'
your
father

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

cept

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

Some

wo

.

.
 
<EOS>

o

,

.

<EOS>

---

ooman

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

old

;
"
if

von't

there
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
Sammy
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

;
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
At

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
a
old
image

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

-

,

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
From

,

,
a

,

,

,

,

.

"

,

,
"

<EOS>

,

,

;

upon

one
Samuel
Weller
;

incurred
,

Solomon
Pell
.
   
<EOS>
The
attorney
was
in
high
glee
,
for
the
embarrassed
coach
-
horser
was
ordered
to
be
discharged
forthwith
.
 
<EOS>
He
highly
approved
of
Sam
's
attachment
to
his
master
;
declared
that
it
strongly
reminded
him
of
his
own
feelings
of
devotion
to
his
friend
,
the
Chancellor
;
and
at
once
led
the
elder
Mr
Weller
down
to
the
Temple
,
to
swear
the
affidavit
of
debt
,
which
the
boy
,
with
the
assistance
of
the
blue
bag
,
had
drawn
up
on
the
spot
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Sam
,
having
been
formally
introduced
to
the
whitewashed
gentleman
and
his
friends
,
as
the
offspring
of
Mr
Weller
,
of
the
Belle
Savage
,
was
treated
with
marked
distinction
,
and
invited
to
regale
himself
with
them
in
honour
of
the
occasion
 
---
an
invitation
which
he
was
by
no
means
backward
in
accepting
.
   
<EOS>
The
mirth
of
gentlemen
of
this
class
is
of
a
grave
and
quiet
character
,
usually
;
but
the
present
instance
was
one
of
peculiar
festivity
,
and
they
relaxed
in
proportion
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
rather
tumultuous
toasting
of
the
Chief
Commissioner
and
Mr
Solomon
Pell
,
who
had
that
day
displayed
such
transcendent
abilities
,
a
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
in
a
blue
shawl
proposed
that
somebody
should
sing
a
song
.
 
<EOS>
The
obvious
suggestion
was
,
that
the
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
,
being
anxious
for
a
song
,
should
sing

himself
;
but
this
the
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
sturdily
,
and
somewhat

,
declined
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
as
is
not
unusual
in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
said

-

,
"
rather
than

of
this

,
perhaps
Mr
Samuel
Weller
will
oblige

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Raly
,

,
"

Sam
,
"
I
'm
not
wery
much
in
the
habit
o
'
singin
'
without

;
but
anythin
'
for
a

life
,

the
man
said
wen

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

burst

following

,
which
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
would

,

,

.
          
<EOS>
ROMANCE
     
<EOS>
I^
   
<EOS>
Bold
Turpin
vunce
,

,

.

,

"

"
Sure

)

<EOS>
As

.

"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;
"

<EOS>
Benjamin
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
And

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Three
ten
and

.
 
<EOS>
Much

,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Your

,

,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
"
added

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
a
game

is
!
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
reg'lar

son
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Prodigal
---
prodigal
son
,
Sir
,
"
suggested
Mr
Pell
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
wot
's
o'clock
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Wen
<EOS>
I
do
n't
<EOS>
,
I
'll
ask
you
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
the
time
the
officer
arrived
,
Sam
had
made
himself
so
extremely
popular
,
that
the
congregated
gentlemen
determined
to
see
him
to
prison
in
a
body
.
 
<EOS>
So
off
they
set
;
the
plaintiff
and
defendant
walking
arm
in
arm
,
the
officer
in
front
,
and
eight
stout
coachmen
bringing
up
the
rear
.
 
<EOS>
At
Serjeant
's
Inn
Coffee
-
house
the
whole
party
halted
to
refresh
,
and
,
the
legal
arrangements
being
completed
,
the
procession
moved
on
again
.
   
<EOS>
Some
little
commotion
was
occasioned
in
Fleet
Street
,
by
the
pleasantry
of
the
eight
gentlemen
in
the
flank
,
who
persevered
in
walking
four
abreast
;
it
was
also
found
necessary
to
leave
the
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
behind
,
to
fight
a
ticket
-
porter
,
it
being
arranged
that
his
friends
should
call
for
him
as
they
came
back
.
<EOS>
Nothing
but
these
little
incidents
occurred
on
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
reached
the
gate
of
the
Fleet
,
the
cavalcade
,
taking
the
time
from
the
plaintiff
,
gave
three
tremendous
cheers
for
the
defendant
,
and
,
after
having
shaken
hands
all
round
,
left
him
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
,
having
been
formally
delivered
into
the
warder
's
custody
,
to
the
intense
astonishment
of
Roker
,
and
to
the
evident
emotion
of
even
the
phlegmatic
Neddy
,
passed
at
once
into
the
prison
,
walked
straight
to
his
master
's
room
,
and
knocked
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
appeared
,
pulled
off
his
hat
,
and
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Sam
,
my
good
lad
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
evidently
delighted
to
see
his
humble
friend
again
;
"
I
had
no
intention
of
hurting
your
feelings
yesterday
,
<EOS>
my
faithful
fellow
,
by
what
I
said
.
 
<EOS>
Put
down
your
hat
,
Sam
,
and
let
me
explain
my
meaning
,
a
little
more
at

to
his
taking
lodgings
by
the
week
,
of
a
bald
-
headed
cobbler
,
who
rented
a
small
slip
room
in
one
of
the
upper
galleries
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
humble
apartment
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
moved
a
mattress
and
bedding
,
which
he
hired
of
Mr
Roker
;
and
,
by
the
time

lay
down
upon

at

,
was
as

he
had
been
bred
in
the

,
and
his

therein

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

always

arter
you
goes
to
bed
,
old
cock
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

of

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I

,
young

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Will

to
in
-
quire
<EOS>
wy
<EOS>
you

bed

that
'
ere

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
'Cause

afore
<EOS>
I

here
,

legs

the

answer

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

Mr

's

;
and
,

<EOS>
He
was
a
sallow

---
all

are
;
and

all

.
 
<EOS>
His

was
a

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

was
sixty
,

,
and
Heaven

,
so
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

"

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Contempt
?
"
<EOS>

.
     
<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,

"
wot

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

<EOS>
Some

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
echoed
Mr
Smangle
,
with
a
long

drawn

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
delightful
company
,
that
man
is
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
better
company
anywhere
;
but
he
has
that
one
drawback
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
ghost
of
his
grandfather
,
Sir
,
was
to

him
this
minute
,
he
'd
ask
him
for
the
loan
of
his
acceptance
on
an

.
<EOS>
"
     
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
added
Mr
Smangle
;
"
and
if
he
'd
the
power

again
,
he
would
,
in
two

three

this

,
to
renew

bill
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Those

,
"
said

;
"
but
I
'm

here
,

be

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
show
'em
the
way
,
"
said
Smangle
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
disturb
you
while
they
're
here
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
bye
---
"
   
As
Smangle

,
he

,

door
which
he

opened
,

,

,
stepped
close
up
to

on

,
and
said
,
in
a
very
soft

---
   
<EOS>
"
You
could
n't
make
it
convenient
to
lend
me
half
-
a
-
crown
till
the
latter
end
of
next
week
,
could
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
could
scarcely
forbear

,
but

,
he
drew
forth
the
coin
,
and
placed
it
in
Mr
Smangle
's

;
upon
which
,
that

,
with

,

,

in
quest

,
with

he
presently

;
and
having

thrice
,
and

as

,
as

Mr
Pickwick
that

pay
,
he
shook

all

,
in

,
and
at
length

off
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
friends
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,

Mr
Tupman
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
who
were
the
three
visitors
in
question
,
"
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
triumvirate
were
much
affected
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
shook
his
head
deploringly
,
Mr
Snodgrass
drew
forth

,
with
undisguised

;
and
Mr
Winkle
retired
to

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mornin
'
,
gen'l'm'n
,
"
said
Sam
,
entering
at
the
moment
with

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Avay
vith
melincholly
,
as
the
little
boy
said
ven
his
schoolmissus
died
.
 
<EOS>
Velcome
to
the
college
,
gen'l'm'n
.
<EOS>
"
     
<EOS>
"
This
foolish

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
tapping
Sam

<EOS>
---
"
this

has

,

.
"
     
<EOS>
"
What
!
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

I

---

,
<EOS>
sir

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Con

fined
,

.
<EOS>
"
     
"
A

!
"

,

<EOS>
"
Hollo
,

!
"

Sam
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wot

<EOS>
"
I

,

,

---
 
Nothing
,

"

<EOS>
There

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has

,

very

.
 
<EOS>
We

be
something
the
matter
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
and

Sam

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"
faltered

,
"

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
So
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Winkle

,
Mr
Pickwick
felt
,

,
that
Sam
's

were

at
the
gaiters
,
as
if

.
 
<EOS>
Sam

up

,

,

;
and

,

seemed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

of

,
Sam
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
do
n't
,

,
"
replied
Mr
Weller
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,
Sam
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wy
,

,
"

I

I

heerd

'

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

"

what
"
It
is
<EOS>
,
fear

a
wrong
'
un
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
There
.
 
<EOS>
We

.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus

,
Mr
Pickwick
led
the

to
different

,
and
Mr
Winkle
gradually
appeared
more
at

,
though
still

.
 
<EOS>
They
had
all
so
much
to
converse
about
,
that
the
morning
very
quickly

away
;
and
when
,

,

Weller
produced
upon

little

,

roast
leg
of

and

,
with

of

,
and

porter
,
which
stood
upon

or
the
sofa
bedstead
,
or
where
they
could
,
everybody
felt
disposed
to
do
justice
to
the
meal
,
notwithstanding
that
the
meat
had
been
purchased
,
and
dressed
,
and
the
pie
made
,
and
baked
,
at
the
prison
cookery
hard
by
.
   
<EOS>
To
these
succeeded
a
bottle
or
two
of
very
good
wine
,
for
which
a

was
despatched
by
Mr
Pickwick
to
the
Horn
Coffee
-
house
,
in
Doctors
"
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
The

or
two
,
indeed
,
might
be
more
properly
described
as
a
bottle

six
,
for

was
drunk
,
and
tea
over
,

bell

to
ring
for

to

.
   
<EOS>
But
,
if
Mr
Winkle
's

had

unaccountable
in

,
it
became

when
,

,
and
his
share
of
the

,

prepared

of

.
 
<EOS>
He

behind
,

Mr

and
Mr

had

,
and
then

Mr

's

,

face
in
which

was

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,

Sir
!
"

between

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless

,

!
"
replied
the
warm
-
hearted
Mr
Pickwick
,
as

the

young

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
then
!
"
cried
Mr
Tupman
from

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well

,

-

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

,

,

"

<EOS>

;

,

,

,
I
---

,

<EOS>
"
Are

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

wo

.

<EOS>
,

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
You

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yours
,

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

-

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
The
Chancery

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
wo

Chancery

wery

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
"

;
"

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

Roker
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

'd

<EOS>
He

,

;

<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"

<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
however
,
"
said
Roker
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
that
it
's
all
up
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
offered
Neddy
two
six
-
penn'orths
to
one
upon
it
just
now
,
but
he
would
n't
take
it
,
and
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
Thank'ee
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
this
infirmary
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
over
where
you
slept
,
sir
,
"
replied
Roker
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
show
you
,
if
you
like
to
come
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
snatched
up
his
hat
without
speaking
,
and
followed
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
led
the
way
in
silence
;
and
gently
raising
the
latch
of
the
room
door
,
motioned
Mr
Pickwick
to
enter
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
,
bare
,
desolate
room
,
with
a
number
of
stump
bedsteads
made
of
iron
,
on
one
of
which
lay
<EOS>
stretched
the
shadow
of
a
man
 
---
wan
,
pale
,
and
ghastly
.
 
<EOS>
His
breathing
was
hard
and
thick
,
and
he
moaned
painfully
as
it
came
and
went
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
bedside
sat
a
short
old
man
in
a
cobbler
's
apron
,
who
,
by
the
aid
of
a
pair
of
horn
spectacles
,
was
reading
from
the
Bible
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
fortunate
legatee
.
   
<EOS>
The
sick
man
laid
his
hand
upon
his
attendant
's
arm
,
and
motioned
him
to
stop
.
 
<EOS>
He
closed
the
book
,
and
laid
it
on
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Open
the
window
,
"
said
the
sick
man
.
   
<EOS>
He
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
of
carriages
and
carts
,
the
rattle
of
wheels
,
the
cries
of
men
and
boys
,
all
the
busy
sounds
of
a
mighty
multitude
instinct
with
life
and
occupation
,
blended
into
one
deep
murmur
,
floated
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Above
the
hoarse
loud
hum
,
arose
,
from
time
to
time
,
a
boisterous
laugh
;
or
a
scrap
of
some
jingling
song
,
shouted
forth
,
by
one
of
the
giddy
crowd
,
would
strike
upon
the
ear
,
for
an
instant
,
and
then
be
lost
amidst
the
roar
of
voices
and
the
tramp
of
footsteps
;
the
breaking
of
the
billows
of
the
restless
sea
of
life
,
that
rolled
heavily
on
,
without
.
<EOS>
These
are
melancholy
sounds
to
a
quiet
listener
at
any
time
;
but
how
melancholy
to
the
watcher
by
the
bed
of
death
!
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
air
here
,
"
said
the
man
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
place
pollutes
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
fresh
round
about
,
when
I
walked
there
,
years
ago
;
but
it
grows
hot
and
heavy
in
passing
these
walls
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
breathe
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
breathed
it
together
,
for
a
long
time
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
short
silence
,
during
which
the
two
spectators
approached
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
The
sick
man
drew
a
hand
of
his
old
fellow
-
prisoner
towards
him
,
and
pressing
it
affectionately
between
both
his
own
,
retained
it
in
his
grasp
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
he
gasped
after
a
while
,
so
faintly
that
they
bent
their
ears
close
over
the
bed
to
catch
the
half
-
formed
sounds
his
pale
lips
gave
vent
to
---
"
I
hope
my
merciful
Judge
will
bear
in
mind
my
heavy
punishment
on
earth
.
 
<EOS>
Twenty
years
,
my
friend
,
twenty
years
in
this
hideous
grave
!
 
<EOS>
My
heart
broke
when
my
child
died
,
and
I
could
not
even
kiss
him
in
his
little
coffin
.
 
<EOS>
My
loneliness
since
then
,
in
all
this
noise
and
riot
,
has
been
very
dreadful
.
 
<EOS>
May
God
forgive
me
!
 
<EOS>
He
has
seen
my
solitary
,
lingering
death
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
folded
his
hands
,
and
murmuring
something
more
they
could
not
hear
,
fell
into
a
sleep
---
only
a
sleep
at
first
,
for
they
saw
him
smile
.
   
<EOS>
They
whispered
together
for
a
little
time
,
and
the
turnkey
,
stooping
over
the
pillow
,
drew
hastily
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
got
his
discharge
,
by
G
---
!
"
said
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
grown
so
like
death
in
life
,
that
they
knew
not
when
he
died
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
45
.
<EOS>
Descriptive
of
an
affecting
interview
between
Mr
Samuel
Weller
and
a
family
party
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
makes
a
tour
of
the
diminutive
world
he
inhabits
,
and
resolves
to
mix
with
it
,
in
future
,
as
little
as
possible
 
A
few
mornings
after
his
incarceration
,
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
having
arranged
his
master
's
room
with
all
possible
care
,
and
seen
him
comfortably
seated
over
his
books
and
papers
,
withdrew
to
employ
himself
for
an
hour
or
two
to
come
,
as
he
best
could
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
morning
,
and
it
occurred
to
Sam
that
a
pint
of
porter
in
the
open
air
would
lighten
his
next
quarter
of
an
hour
or
so
,
as
well
as
any
little
amusement
in
which
he
could
indulge
.
   
<EOS>
Having
arrived
at
this
conclusion
,
he
betook
himself
to
the
tap
.
 
<EOS>
Having
purchased
the
beer
,
and
obtained
,
moreover
,
the
day
-
but
-
one
-
before
-
yesterday
's
paper
,
he
repaired
to
the
skittle
-
ground
,
and
seating
himself
on
a
bench
,
proceeded
to
enjoy
himself
in
a
very
sedate
and
methodical
manner
.
   
<EOS>
First
of
all
,
he
took
a
refreshing
draught
of
the
beer
,
and
then
he
looked
up
at
a
window
,
and
bestowed
a
platonic
wink
on
a
young
lady
who
was
peeling
potatoes
thereat
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
opened
the
paper
,
and
folded
it
so
as
to
get
the
police
reports
outwards
;
and
this
being
a
vexatious
and
difficult
thing
to
do
,
when
there
is
any
wind
stirring
,
he
took
another
draught
of
the
beer
when
he
had
accomplished
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
read
two
lines
of
the
paper
,
and
stopped
short
to
look
at
a
couple
of
men
who
were
finishing
a
game
at
rackets
,
which
,
being
concluded
,
he
cried
out
"
wery
good
,
"
in
an
approving
manner
,
and
looked
round
upon
the
spectators
,
to
ascertain
whether
their
sentiments
coincided
with
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
This
involved
the
necessity
of
looking
up
at
the
windows
also
;
and
as
the
young
lady
was
still
there
,
it
was
an
act
of
common
politeness
to
wink
again
,
and
to
drink
to
her
good
health
in
dumb
show
,
in
another
draught
of
the
beer
,
which
Sam
did
;
and
having
frowned
hideously
upon
a
small
boy
who
had
noted
this
latter
proceeding
with
open
eyes
,
he
threw
one
leg
over
the
other
,
and
,
holding
the
newspaper
in
both
hands
,
began
to
read
in
real
earnest
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
composed
himself
into
the
needful
state
of
abstraction
,
when
he
thought
he
heard
his
own
name
proclaimed
in
some
distant
passage
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
mistaken
,
for
it
quickly
passed
from
mouth
to
mouth
,
and
in
a
few
seconds
the
air
teemed
with
shouts
of
"
Weller
!
"
<EOS>
"
Here
!
"
roared
Sam
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wot
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
Who
wants
him
?
 
<EOS>
Has
an
express
come
to

his

afire
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Somebody

hall
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just

that
'
ere
paper

,

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
-

'
.
 
<EOS>
Blessed
,

was
a
-

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Accompanying

noticed
,

"
Weller
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

Weller
!
"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

'

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

;

,

for

.
   
<EOS>
Nor

Mrs
Weller
behind
-
hand
in

.
 
<EOS>
The
good

began
by
protesting
that
she
could
n't
touch
a
drop
---
then
took
a

---
then
a

---
then
a
great
many
drops
;
and
her

being
of
the

of
those
substances
which
are

,
she
dropped

with

of
negus
,
and

,
melting

feelings
down
,
<EOS>
until
at
length

had

of

.
   
<EOS>
The
elder
Mr
Weller
observed
these

with
many

of

,
and
when
,
after

jug
of

,
Mr

began
to
sigh

a

,
he

,
by

,
among

gammon
"
were
alone

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll

wot

,

,
my
boy
,
"

;
"
I
think

somethin'

-

law

inside
,
as
vell
as
in
that
o
'

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

"
that
wot

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
delivered
this
scientific
opinion
with
many
confirmatory
frowns
and
nods
;
which
,
Mrs
Weller
remarking
,
and
concluding
that
they
bore
some
disparaging
reference
either
to
herself
or
to
Mr
Stiggins
,
or
to
both
,
was
on
the
point
of
becoming
infinitely
worse
,
when
Mr
Stiggins
,
getting
on
his
legs
as
well
as
he
could
,
proceeded
to
deliver
an
edifying
discourse
for
the
benefit
of
the
company
,
but
more
especially
of
Mr
Samuel
,
whom
he
adjured
in
moving
terms
to
be
upon
his
guard
in
that
sink
of
iniquity
into
which
he
was
cast
;
to
abstain
from
all
hypocrisy
and
pride
of
heart
;
and
to
take
in
all
things
exact
pattern
and
copy
by
him
(
Stiggins
)
,
in
which
case
he
might
calculate
on
arriving
,
sooner
or
later
at
the
comfortable

,
that
,
like
him
,
he
was
a
most
estimable
and
blameless
character
,
and
that
all
his
acquaintances
and
friends
were
hopelessly
abandoned
and
profligate
wretches
.
 
<EOS>
Which
consideration
,
he
said
,
could
not
but
afford
him
the
liveliest
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
He
furthermore
conjured
him
to
avoid
,
above
all
things
,
the
vice
of
intoxication
,
which
he
likened
unto
the
filthy
habits
of
swine
,
and
to
those
poisonous
and
baleful
drugs
which
being
chewed
in
the
mouth
,
are
said
to
filch
away
the
memory
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
his

,
the
reverend
and
red
-
nosed
gentleman
became
singularly
incoherent
,
and

to

in
the

of
his
eloquence
,
was
fain
to
catch
at
the
back
of
a
chair
to
preserve
his
perpendicular
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Stiggins
did
not
desire
his
hearers
to
be
upon
their
guard
against
those
false
prophets
and
wretched
mockers
of
religion
,
who
,
without
sense
to
expound
its
first
doctrines
,
or
hearts
to
feel
its
first
principles
,
are
more
dangerous
members
of
society
than
the
common
criminal
;
imposing
,
as
they
necessarily
do
,
upon
the
weakest
and
worst
informed
,
casting
scorn
and
contempt
on
what
should
be
held
most
sacred
,
and
bringing
into
partial
disrepute
large
bodies
of
virtuous
and
well
-

persons
of
many
excellent
sects
and

.
 
<EOS>
But
as
he
leaned
over
the
back
of
the
chair
for
a

,
and
closing
one
eye
,
winked
a
good
deal
with
the
other
,
it
is
presumed
that
he
thought
all
this
,
but
kept
it
to
himself
.
   
<EOS>
During
the

oration
,
Mrs
Weller
sobbed

at
the
end

paragraphs
;

Sam
,

,

,

"
Brayvo
;
wery

!
"

<EOS>
Sam

,

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Here

.
"
   
<EOS>
As

,
Jingle
walked
up
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
less
miserable
than
before
,
being
clad

-
worn

,

,

's

,
had

's
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
clean

too
,
and
had

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very

,

;
and

,

on

easy
to
see
that
he
had
suffered
severely
from
illness
and

,
and
was
still
very

.
 
<EOS>
He
took
off
his
hat
as
Mr
Pickwick
saluted
him
,
and
seemed
much
humbled
and
abashed
at
the
sight
of
Sam
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
Following
close
at
his
heels
,
came
Mr
Job
Trotter
,
in
the
catalogue
of
whose
vices
,
want
of
faith
and
attachment
to
his
companion
could
at
all
events
find
no
place
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
ragged
and

,
but

was

as
on

Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

about

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

,

AM

!
"
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
Now
,

!
"

,

<EOS>
"
I

-

,

"

,

Mr
Job

,

at

.
<EOS>
Job

<EOS>
Sam
,

,

,

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

"

,

"

,
nor
the
best
ones
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
they
ai
n't
,
"
replied
Sam
expressively
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
may
be
put
on
,
Mr
Weller
,
"
said
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
they
may
,
"
said
Sam
;
"
some
people
,
indeed
,
has
'em
always
ready
laid
on
,
and
can
pull
out
the
plug
wenever
they
likes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Job
;
"
but
these
sort
of
things
are
not
so
easily
counterfeited
,
Mr
Weller
,
and
it
is
a
more
painful
process
to
get
them
up
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
pointed
to
his
sallow
,
sunken
cheeks
,
and
,
drawing
up
his
coat
sleeve
,
disclosed
an
arm
which
looked
as
if
the
bone
could
be
broken
at
a
touch
,
so
sharp
and
brittle
<EOS>
did
it
appear
,
beneath
its
thin
covering
of
flesh
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
have
you
been
a
-
doin
'
to
yourself
?
"
said
Sam
,
recoiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothin'
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Sam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
doin'
nothing
for
many
weeks
past
,
"
said
Job
;
and
eating
and
drinking
almost
as
little
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
took
one
comprehensive
glance
at
Mr
Trotter
's
thin
face
and
wretched
apparel
;
and
then
,
seizing
him
by
the
arm
,
commenced
dragging
him
away
with
great
violence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
,
Mr
Weller
?
"
<EOS>
said
Job
,
vainly
struggling
in
the
powerful
grasp
of
his
old
enemy
.
<EOS>
"
Come
on
,
"
said
Sam
;
"
come
on
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
deigned
no
further
explanation
till
they
reached
the
tap
,
and
then
called
for
a
pot
of
porter
,
which
was
speedily
produced
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
drink
that
up
,
ev'ry
drop
on
it
,
and
then
turn
the
pot
upside
down
,
to
let
me
see
as
you
've
took
the
medicine
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
Mr
Weller
,
"
remonstrated
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
Down
vith
it
!
"
said
Sam
peremptorily
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
admonished
,
Mr
Trotter
raised
the
pot
to
his
lips
,
and
,
by
gentle
and
almost
imperceptible

,
tilted
it
into
the
air
.
<EOS>
He
paused
once
,
and
only
once
,
to
draw
a
long
breath
,
but
without
raising
his
face
from
the
vessel
,
which
,
in
a

,
he
held
out
at
arm
's

,
bottom
upward
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
fell
upon
the
ground
but
a
few
particles
of
froth
,
which
slowly
detached
themselves
from
the
rim
,
and
trickled
lazily
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
done
!
"
said
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
find
yourself
arter
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Better
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
am
better
,
"
responded
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
O
'
course
you
air
,
"
said
Sam
argumentatively
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
like
puttin
'
gas
in
a
balloon
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
see
with
the
naked

that
you
gets
stouter
under

.
 
<EOS>
Wot
<EOS>
do
you
say
to
another
o
'
the
same

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
I

you
,
Sir
,
"

Job
---
"
much

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
then
,
wot
do
you
say

some
wittles
?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thanks

worthy

,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Trotter
,
"
we

,
baked
,
at
a
quarter
before
three
,
with
the

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
!
 
<EOS>
Has
HE
been
a
-
purwidin
'
for

?
"

Sam

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

,
Sir
,
"

Job
.
 
<EOS>
"
More
than
that
,
Mr
Weller
;
my

,
he

a
room
<EOS>
---
we

---
and

,

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
,
"
said
Job
,
with

,

,
"
I
could
serve
that

till

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
said
Sam
,
"
I

,

!
 
<EOS>
None
<EOS>
o
'
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
Job

looked

.
   
<EOS>
"
None
o
'
that
,
I
say
,
young
feller
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
man

him
but

.
 
<EOS>
And

're
upon
it
,
I
'll
let

,
"
said
Sam
,
as

.
<EOS>
"
I
never
heerd
,
mind
you
,
or
read
of
in

-

,
nor
see

,
any

---
not
even

,
as
I
remember
,
though
that
may
ha
'
been
done
for
anythin
'
<EOS>
I

the
contrairey
---
but
mark

vords
,
<EOS>
Job
Trotter
,
he
's

reg'lar
thoroughbred
angel
for
all
that
;
and
let
me
see
the
man
as
wenturs
to
tell
me
he
knows
a
better
vun
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
defiance
,
Mr
Weller
buttoned
up
his
change
in
a
side
pocket
,
and
,
with
many
confirmatory
nods
and
gestures
by
the
way
,
proceeded
in
search
of
the
subject
of
discourse
.
   
<EOS>
They
found
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
company
with
Jingle
,
talking
very
earnestly
,
and
not
bestowing
a
look
on
the
groups
who
were
congregated
on
the
racket
-
ground
;
they
were
very
motley
groups
too
,
and
worth
the
looking
at
,
if
it
were
only
in
idle
curiosity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
Sam
and
his
companion
drew
nigh
,
"
you
will
see
how
your
health
becomes
,
and
think
about
it
meanwhile
.
 
<EOS>
Make
the
statement
out
for
me
when
you
feel
yourself
equal
to
the
task
,
and
I
will
discuss
the
subject
with
you
when
I
have
considered
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
go
to
your
room
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
tired
,
and
not
strong
enough
to
be
out
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Alfred
Jingle
,
without
one
spark
of
his
old
animation
---
with
nothing
even
of
the
dismal
gaiety
which
he
had
assumed
when
Mr
Pickwick
first
stumbled
on
him
in
his

---
bowed
low
without
speaking
,
and
,
motioning
to
Job
not
to
follow
him
just
yet
,
crept
slowly
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Curious
scene
this
,
is
it
not
,
Sam
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
good
-
humouredly
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
<EOS>
much
so
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wonders
"
ull
never
cease
,
"
added
Sam
,
speaking
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
wery
much
mistaken
if
that
,
ere
Jingle
<EOS>
worn't
a
-
doin
somethin'
in
the
water
-
cart
way
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
area
formed
by
the
wall
in
that
part
of
the
Fleet
in
which
Mr
Pickwick
stood
was
just
wide
enough
to
make
a
good
racket
-
court
;
one
side
being
formed
,
of
course
,
by
the
wall
itself
,
and
the
other
by
that
portion
of
the
prison
which
looked
(
or
rather
would
have
looked
,
but
for
the
wall
)
towards
St
Paul
's
Cathedral
.
 
<EOS>
Sauntering
or
sitting
about
,
in
every
possible
attitude
of
listless
idleness
,
were
a
great
number
of
debtors
,
the
major
part
of
whom
were
waiting
in
prison
until
their
day
of
"
going
up
"
before
the
Insolvent
Court
should
arrive
;
while
others
had
been
remanded
for
various
terms
,
which
they
were
idling
away
as
they
best
could
.
 
<EOS>
Some
were
shabby
,
some
were
smart
,
many
dirty
,
a
few
clean
;
but
there
they
all
lounged
,
and
loitered
,
and
slunk
about
with
as
little
spirit
or
purpose
as
the
beasts
in
a
menagerie
.
   
<EOS>
Lolling
from
the
windows
which
commanded
a
view
of
this
promenade
were
a
number
of
persons
,
some
in
noisy
conversation
with
their
acquaintance
below
,
others
playing
at
ball
with
some
adventurous
throwers
outside
,
others
looking
on
at
the
racket
-
players
,
or
watching
the
boys
as
they
cried
the
game
.
 
<EOS>
Dirty
,
slipshod
women
passed
and
repassed
,
on
their
way
to
the
cooking
-
house
in
one
corner
of
the
yard
;
children
screamed
,
and
fought
,
and
played
together
,
in
another
;
the
tumbling
of
the
skittles
,
and
the
shouts
of
the
players
,
mingled
perpetually
with
these
and
a
hundred
other
sounds
;
and
all
was
noise
and
tumult
---
save
in
a
little
miserable
shed
a
few
yards
off
,
<EOS>
where
lay
,
all
quiet
and
ghastly
,
the
body
of
the
Chancery
prisoner
who
had
died
the
night
before
,
awaiting
the
mockery
of
an
inquest
.
 
<EOS>
The
body
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
lawyer
's
term
for
the
restless
,
whirling
mass
of
cares
and
anxieties
,
affections
,
hopes
,
and
griefs
<EOS>
,
that
make
up
the
living
man
.
 
<EOS>
The
law
had
his
body
;
and
there
it
lay
,
clothed
in
grave
-
clothes
,
an
awful
witness
to
its
tender
mercy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
like
to
see
a
whistling
-
shop
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Job
Trotter
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
was
Mr
Pickwick
's
counter
inquiry
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
vistlin
'
shop
,
Sir
,
"
interposed
Mr
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
,
Sam
?
---
<EOS>
A
bird
-
fancier
's
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
your
heart
,
no
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Job
;
"
a
whistling
-
shop
,
Sir
,
is
where
they
sell
spirits
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Job
Trotter
briefly
explained
here
,
that
all
persons
,
being
prohibited
under
heavy
penalties
from
conveying
spirits
into
debtors
"
prisons
,
and
such
commodities
being
highly
prized
by
the
ladies
and
gentlemen
confined
therein
,
it
had
occurred
to
some
speculative
turnkey
to
connive
,
for
certain
lucrative
considerations
,
at
two
or
three
prisoners
retailing
the
favourite
article
of
gin
,
for
their
own
profit
and
advantage
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
plan
,
you
see
,
Sir
,
has
been
gradually
introduced
into
all
the
prisons
for
debt
,
"
said
Mr
Trotter
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
it
has
this
wery
great
advantage
,
"
said
Sam
,
"
that
the
turnkeys
takes
wery
good
care
to
seize
hold
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>
ev'rybody
<EOS>
but
them
as
pays
'em
,
that
attempts
the
willainy
,
and
wen
it
gets
in
the
papers
they
're
applauded
for
their
wigilance
;
so
it
cuts
two
ways
---
frightens
other
people
from
the
trade
,
and
elewates
their
own
characters
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
so
,
Mr
Weller
,
"
observed
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
but
are
these
rooms
never
searched
to
ascertain
whether
any
spirits
are
concealed
in
them
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cert'nly
<EOS>
they
are
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
;
"
but
the
turnkeys
knows
beforehand
,
and
gives
the
word
to
the
wistlers
,
and
you
may
wistle
for
it
wen
you
go
to
look
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Job
had
tapped
at
a
door
,
which
was
opened
by
a
gentleman
with
an
uncombed
head
,
who
bolted
it
after
them
when
they
had
walked
in
,
and
grinned
;
upon
which
Job
grinned
,
and
Sam
also
;
whereupon
Mr
Pickwick
,
thinking
it
might
be
expected
of
him
,
kept
on
smiling
to
the
end
of
the
interview
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
with
the
uncombed
head
appeared
quite
satisfied
with
this
mute
announcement
of
their
business
,
and
,
producing
a
flat
stone
bottle
,
which
might
hold
about
a
couple
of
quarts
,
from
beneath
his
bedstead
,
filled
out
three
glasses
of
gin
,
<EOS>
which
Job
Trotter
and
Sam
disposed
of
in
a
most
workmanlike
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Any
more
?
"
said
the
whistling
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
more
,
"
replied
Job
Trotter
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
paid
,
the
door
was
unbolted
,
and
out
they
came
;
the
uncombed
gentleman
bestowing
a
friendly
nod
upon
Mr
Roker
,
who
happened
to
be
passing
at
the
moment
.
   
<EOS>
From
this
spot
,
Mr
Pickwick
wandered
along
all
the
galleries
,
up
and
down
all
the
staircases
,
and
once
again
round
the
whole
area
of
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
body
of
the
prison
population
appeared
to
be
Mivins
,
and
Smangle
,
and
the
parson
,
and
the
butcher
,
and
the
leg
,
over
and
over
,
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
same
squalor
,
the
same
turmoil
and
noise
,
the
same
general
characteristics
,
in
every
corner
;
in
the
best
and
the
worst
alike
.
<EOS>
The
whole
place
seemed
restless
and
troubled
;
and
the
people
were
crowding
and
flitting
to
and
fro
,
like
the
shadows
in
an
uneasy
dream
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
enough
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
threw
himself
into
a
chair
in
his
little
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
head
aches
with
these
scenes
,
and
my
heart
too
.
 
<EOS>
Henceforth
I
will
be
a
prisoner
in
my
own
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
Mr
Pickwick
steadfastly
adhered
to
this
determination
.
<EOS>
For
three
long
months
he
remained
shut
up
,
all
day
;
only
stealing
out
at
night
to
breathe
the
air
,
when
the
greater
part
of
his
fellow
-
prisoners
were
in
bed
or
carousing
in
their
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
His
health
was
beginning
to
suffer
from
the
closeness
of
the
confinement
,
but
neither
the
often
-
repeated
entreaties
of
Perker
and
his
friends
,
nor
the
still
more
frequently
-
repeated
warnings
and
admonitions
of
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
could
induce
him
to
alter
one
jot
of
his
inflexible
resolution
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
46
.
<EOS>
Records
a
touching
act
of
delicate
feeling
,
not
unmixed
with
pleasantry
,
achieved
and
performed
by
Messrs
Dodson
and
<EOS>
Fogg
 
It
was
within
a
week
of
the
close
of
the
month
of
July
,
that
a
hackney
cabriolet
,
number
unrecorded
,
was
seen
to
proceed
at
a
rapid
pace
up
Goswell
Street
;
three
people
were
squeezed
into
it
besides
the
driver
,
who
sat
in
his
own
particular
little
dickey
at
the
side
;
over
the
apron
were
hung
two
shawls
,
belonging
to
two
small
vixenish
-
looking
ladies
under
the
apron
;
between
whom
,
compressed
into
a
very
small
compass
,
was
stowed
away
,
a
gentleman
of
heavy
and
subdued
demeanour
,
who
,
whenever
he
ventured
to
make
an
observation
,
was
snapped
up
short
by
one
of
the
vixenish
ladies
before
-
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
Lastly
,
the
two
vixenish
ladies
and
the
heavy
gentleman
were
giving
the
driver
contradictory
directions
,
all
tending
to
the
one
point
,
that
he
should
stop
at
Mrs
Bardell
's
door
;
which
the
heavy
gentleman
,
in
direct
opposition
to
,
and
defiance
of
,
the
vixenish
ladies
,
contended
was
a
green
door
and
not
a
yellow
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
at
the
house
with
a
green
door
,
driver
,
"
said
the
heavy
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
perwerse
creetur
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
one
of
the
vixenish

.
 
<EOS>
"
Drive
to
the
'
ouse
with
the
yellow
door
,
cabmin
.
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
the
cabman
,
who
in
a

to
pull
up
at
the
house
with
the
green
door
,
had
pulled
the
horse
up
so
high
that
he
nearly
pulled
him
backward
into
the
cabriolet
,
let
the
animal
's
fore

down

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
vere
am
I
to
pull

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Settle

among

.
 
<EOS>
All
I
ask
is
,
vere
?
"
   
<EOS>
Here

contest
was
renewed
with

;
and
the
horse
being
troubled
with
a
fly
on

nose
,
the
cabman
humanely
employed
his
leisure
in
lashing
him
about
on
the
head
,
on
the
counter
-
irritation
principle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Most
wotes
carries
the
day
!
"
said
one
of
the
vixenish
ladies
at
length
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
'
ouse
with
the
yellow
door
,
cabman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
after

had
dashed
up
,
in

,
to
the
house
with
the
yellow
door
,
"
making
,
"
as
one

,
"
acterrally
more

's

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Aggrawatin
'

!
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>

My

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

fear

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
While

was
going

,

driver
was
most

the
horse
,
by

,
up

house

red

,
which
Master

had
already

.
<EOS>
Here
was
a
mean
and
low
way
of
arriving
at
a
friend
's
house
!
<EOS>
No
dashing
up
,
with
all

fire

of

;
no

;
no

;
no

,
for
fear
of

ladies

in

;
and
then
the
man
handing
the
shawls
out
,
afterwards
,
as
if

were

!
<EOS>
The
whole
edge
of
the
thing
had
been
taken
off
---
it
was
flatter
than
walking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Tommy
,
"
said

,
"
<EOS>
how
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Here

.
   
<EOS>
"

-

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Cheered

this

,
the
precocious
boy
applied

to
his

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
The
above
examination
of
a
child
of
tender
years
took
place
while
Mr
and
Mrs
Raddle

,

,

"
Lauk

<EOS>
"
Raddle
ai

;

<EOS>
This

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

;

,

,

,

,

,
all

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Being

into
the
front

,
she
was
there

on
a

;
and
the
lady
from
the
first

running
up
to
the
first
floor
,

with

sal
-
volatile
,
which
,

Mrs
Raddle
tight

,
she
applied
in
all

and

to
her
nose
,
until
that
lady
with
many

was
fain
to

better
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

!
<EOS>
"

,
"
I

's

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

!
<EOS>

,
"

;

they

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Even

's

,

<EOS>
"
But

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Thereupon

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

"

---
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She

.
"
   
<EOS>
All

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Which

for
about

,

Mrs

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
She
knew

did
n't
mean

unkind
;
but
Mary
Ann
was
very
far
from
strong
,
and
,

he
did
n't

,
he

when

,

;
and
so
on
.
 
<EOS>
All

,
Mr
Raddle
heard

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,
"

,

!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Raddle
,

;
Mrs

,

;
Mrs
Raddle
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
"

,

,
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

little
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
I
said
,
as
we
was
a
-
coming
along
in
the
cabrioily
---
"
   
At

of

word
which
awakened

,
Mrs
Raddle
applied

,

;
so
that
Mrs

frowned

Mr
Raddle
,
to

,
and

's

,

"
put

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

of

closet
,
which

,

old

port
---
<EOS>
that
at
one
-
and

nine
---

of

East

at
fourteen

,
which
were

produced
in

of

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
After

Mrs

,
by

(

old

"
the

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
This

,

,
where

;

less

to

,

(

one

,

!
   
<EOS>
However
,

,

.
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

:

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"
What
