?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mrs
Bardell
,
pausing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
one
of
our
public
offices
,
"
replied
Jackson
,
hurrying
her
through
a
door
,
and
looking
round
to
see
that
the
other
women
were
following
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
sharp
,
Isaac
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Safe
and
sound
,
"
replied
the
man
with
the
ash
stick
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
swung
heavily
after
them
,
and
they
descended
a
small
flight
of
steps
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
we
are
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
All
right
and
tight
<EOS>
,
Mrs
Bardell
!
"
said
Jackson
,
looking
exultingly
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
said
Mrs
Bardell
,
with
a
palpitating
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
this
,
"
replied
Jackson
,
drawing
her
a
little
on
one
side
;
"
do
n't
be
frightened
,
Mrs
Bardell
.
 
<EOS>
There
never
was
a
more
delicate
man
than
Dodson
,
ma'am
,
or
a
more
humane
man
than
Fogg
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
their
duty
in
the
way
of
business
,
to
take
you
in
execution
for
them
costs
;
but
they
were
anxious
to
spare
your
feelings
as
much
as
they
could
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
comfort
it
must
be
,
to
you
,
to
think
how
it
's
been
done
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
Fleet
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
Wish
you
good
-
night
,
Mrs
Bardell
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
Tommy
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Jackson
hurried
away
in
company
with
the
man
with
the
ash
stick
another
man
,
with
a
key
in
his
hand
,
who
had
been
looking
on
,
led
the
bewildered
female
to
a
second
short
flight
of
steps
leading
to
a
doorway
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
screamed
violently
;
Tommy
roared
;
Mrs
Cluppins
shrunk
within
herself
;
and
Mrs
Sanders
made
off
,
without
more
ado
.
 
<EOS>
For
there
stood
the
injured
Mr
Pickwick
,
taking
his
nightly
allowance
of
air
;
and
beside
him
leant
Samuel
Weller
,
who
,
seeing
Mrs
Bardell
,
took
his
hat
off
with
mock
reverence
,
while
his
master
turned
indignantly
on
his
heel
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
bother
the
woman
,
"
said
the
turnkey
to
Weller
;
"
she
's
just
come
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
prisoner
!
<EOS>
"
said
Sam
,
quickly
replacing
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
the
plaintives
?
 
<EOS>
What
for
?
 
<EOS>
Speak
up
,
old
feller
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dodson
and
Fogg
,
"
replied
the
man
;
"
execution
on
COGNOVIT
for
costs
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Job
,
Job
!
"
shouted
Sam
,
dashing
into
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Run
to
Mr
Perker
's
,
Job
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
him
directly
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
some
good
in
this
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
game
.
 
<EOS>
Hooray
!
<EOS>
vere
's
the
gov'nor
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
reply
to
these
inquiries
,
for
Job
had
started
furiously
off
,
the
instant
he
received
his
commission
,
and
Mrs
Bardell
had
fainted
in
real
downright
earnest
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
47
.
<EOS>
Is
chiefly
devoted
to
matters
of
business
,
and
the
temporal
advantage
of
Dodson
and
Fogg
---
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
reappears
under
extraordinary
circumstances
---
Mr
Pickwick
's
benevolence
proves
stronger
than
his
obstinacy
 
Job
Trotter
,
abating
nothing
of
his
speed
,
ran
up
Holborn
,
sometimes
in
the
middle
of
the
road
,
sometimes
on
the
pavement
,
sometimes
in
the
gutter
,
as
the
chances
of
getting
along
varied
with
the
press
of
men
,
women
,
children
,
and
coaches
,
in
each
division
of
the
thoroughfare
,
and
,
regardless
of
all
obstacles
stopped
not
for
an
instant
until
he
reached
the
gate
of
Gray
's
Inn
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
all
the
expedition
he
had
used
,
however
,
the
gate
had
been
closed
a
good
half
-
hour
when
he
reached
it
,
and
by
the
time
he
had
discovered
Mr
Perker
's
laundress
,
who
lived
with
a
married
daughter
,
who
had
bestowed
her
hand
upon
a
non
-
resident
waiter
,
who
occupied
the
one
-
pair
of
some
number
in
some
street
closely
adjoining
to
some
brewery
somewhere
behind
Gray
's
Inn
Lane
,
it
was
within
fifteen
minutes
of
closing
the
prison
for
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
had
still
to
be
ferreted
out
from
the
back
parlour
of
the
Magpie
and
Stump
;
and
Job
had
scarcely
accomplished
this
object
,
and
communicated
Sam
Weller
's
message
,
when
the
clock
struck
ten
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
Lowten
,
"
it
's
too
late
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
get
in
to
-
night
;
you
've
got
the
key
of
the
street
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
me
,
"
replied
Job
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
sleep
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
But
wo
n't
it
be
better
to
see
Mr
Perker
to
-
night
,
so
that
we
may
be
there
,
the
first
thing
in
the
morning
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
responded
Lowten
,
after
a
little
consideration
,
"
if
it
was
in
anybody
else
's
case
,
Perker
would
n't
be
best
pleased
at
my
going
up
to
his
house
;
but
<EOS>
as
it
's
Mr
Pickwick
's
,
I
think
I
may
venture
to
take
a
cab
and
charge
it
to
the
office
.
"
 
<EOS>
Deciding
on
this
line
of
conduct
,
Mr
Lowten
took
up
his
hat
,
and
begging
the
assembled
company
to
appoint
a
deputy
-
chairman
during
his
temporary
absence
,
led
the
way
to
the
nearest
coach
-
stand
.
<EOS>
Summoning
the
cab
of
most
promising
appearance
,
he
directed
the
driver
to
repair
to
Montague
Place
,
Russell
Square
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Perker
had
had
a
dinner
-
party
that
day
,
as
was
testified
by
the
appearance
of
lights
in
the
drawing
-
room
windows
,
the
sound
of
an
improved
grand
piano
,
and
an
improvable
cabinet
voice
issuing
therefrom
,
and
a
rather
overpowering
smell
of
meat
which
pervaded
the
steps
and
entry
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
a
couple
of
very
good
country
agencies
happening
to
come
up
to
town
,
at
the
same
time
,
an
agreeable
little
party
had
been
got
together
to
meet
them
,
comprising
Mr
Snicks
,
the
Life
Office
Secretary
,
Mr
Prosee
,
the
eminent
counsel
,
three
solicitors
,
one
commissioner
of
bankrupts
,
a
special
pleader
from
the
Temple
,
a
small
-
eyed
peremptory
young
gentleman
,
his
pupil
,
who
had
written
a
lively
book
about
the
law
of
demises
,
with
a
vast
quantity
of
marginal
notes
and
references
;
and
several
other
eminent
and
distinguished
personages
.
<EOS>
From
this
society
,
little
Mr
Perker
detached
himself
,
on
his
clerk
being
announced
in
a
whisper
;
and
repairing
to
the
dining
-
room
,
there
found
Mr
Lowten
and
Job
Trotter
looking
very
dim
and
shadowy
by
the
light
of
a
kitchen
candle
,
which
the
gentleman
who
condescended
to
appear
in
plush
shorts
and
cottons
for
a
quarterly
stipend
,
had
,
with
a
becoming
contempt
for
the
clerk
and
all
things
appertaining
to
"
the
office
,
"
placed
upon
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Lowten
,
"
said
little
Mr
Perker
,
shutting
the
door
,
"
what
's
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
No
important
letter
come
in
a
parcel
,
is
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Lowten
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
messenger
from
Mr
Pickwick
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
From
Pickwick
,
eh
?
"
said
the
little
man
,
turning
quickly
to
Job
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
what
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dodson
and
Fogg
have
taken
Mrs
Bardell
in
execution
for
her
costs
,
Sir
,
"
said
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
exclaimed
Perker
,
putting
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
reclining
against
the
sideboard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Job
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seems
they
got
a
cognovit
out
of
her
,
for
the
amount
of
'em
,
directly
after
the
trial
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
By
Jove
!
<EOS>
"
said
Perker
,
taking
both
hands
out
of
his
pockets
,
and
striking
the
knuckles
of
his
right
against
the
palm
of
his
left
,
emphatically
,
"
those
are
the
cleverest
scamps
I
ever
had
anything
to
do
with
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sharpest
practitioners
I
ever
knew
,
Sir
,
"
observed
Lowten
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sharp
!
"
echoed
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
knowing
where
to
have
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
Sir
,
there
is
not
,
"
replied
Lowten
;
and
then
,
both
master
and
man
pondered
for
a
few
seconds
,
with
animated
countenances
,
as
if
they
were
reflecting
upon
one
of
the
most
beautiful
and
ingenious
discoveries
that
the
intellect
of
man
had
ever
made
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
had
in
some
measure
recovered
from
their
trance
of
admiration
,
Job
Trotter
discharged
himself
of
the
rest
of
his
commission
.
 
<EOS>
Perker
nodded
his
head
thoughtfully
,
and
pulled
out
his
watch
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
ten
precisely
,
I
will
be
there
,
"
said
the
little
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sam
is
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
so
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
take
a
glass
of
wine
,
Lowten
?
"
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
mean
yes
,
I
think
,
"
said
the
little
man
,
turning
to
the
sideboard
for
a
decanter
and
glasses
.
   
<EOS>
As
Lowten
DID
mean
yes
,
he
said
no
more
on
the
subject
,
but
inquired
of
Job
,
in
an
audible
whisper
,
whether
the
portrait
of
Perker
,
which
hung
opposite
the
fireplace
,
was
n't
a
wonderful
likeness
,
to
which
Job
of
course
replied
that
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
The
wine
being
by
this
time
poured
out
,
Lowten
drank
to
Mrs
Perker
and
the
children
,
and
Job
to
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
in
the
plush
shorts
and
cottons
considering
it
no
part
of
his
duty
to
show
the
people
from
the
office
out
,
consistently
declined
to
answer
the
bell
,
and
they
showed
themselves
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
attorney
betook
himself
to
his
drawing
-
room
,
the
clerk
to
the
Magpie
and
Stump
,
and
Job
to
Covent
Garden
Market
to
spend
the
night
in
a
vegetable
basket
.
   
<EOS>
Punctually
at
the
appointed
hour
next
morning
,
the
good
-
humoured
little
attorney
tapped
at
Mr
Pickwick
's
door
,
which
was
opened
with
great
alacrity
by
Sam
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Perker
,
sir
,
"
said
Sam
,
announcing
the
visitor
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
was
sitting
at
the
window
in
a
thoughtful
attitude
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wery
glad
you
've
looked
in
accidentally
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
rather
think
the
gov'nor
wants
to
have
a
word
and
a
half
with
you
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Perker
bestowed
a
look
of
intelligence
on
Sam
,
intimating
that
he
understood
he
was
not
to
say
he
had
been
sent
for
;
and
beckoning
him
to
approach
,
whispered
briefly
in
his
ear
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
that
'
ere
,
Sir
?
"
said
Sam
,
starting
back
in
excessive
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
Perker
nodded
and
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Samuel
Weller
looked
at
the
little
lawyer
,
then
at
Mr
Pickwick
,
then
at
the
ceiling
,
then
at
Perker
again
;
grinned
,
laughed
outright
,
and
finally
,
catching
up
his
hat
from
the
carpet
,
without
further
explanation
,
disappeared
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
mean
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
at
Perker
with
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
put
Sam
into
this
extraordinary
state
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nothing
,
nothing
,
"
replied
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
my
dear
Sir
,
draw
up
your
chair
to
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
good
deal
to
say
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
papers
are
those
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
the
little
man
deposited
on
the
table
a
small
bundle
of
documents
tied
with
red
tape
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
papers
in
Bardell
and
Pickwick
,
"
replied
Perker
,
undoing
the
knot
with
his
teeth
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
grated
the
legs
of
his
chair
against
the
ground
;
and
throwing
himself
into
it
,
folded
his
hands
and
looked
sternly
 
---
if
Mr
Pickwick
ever
could
look
sternly
---
at
his
legal
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
like
to
hear
the
name
of
the
cause
?
"
said
the
little
man
,
still
busying
himself
with
the
knot
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
do
not
indeed
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sorry
for
that
,
"
resumed
Perker
,
"
because
it
will
form
the
subject
of
our
conversation
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
that
the
subject
should
be
never
mentioned
between
us
,
Perker
,
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
,
pooh
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
said
the
little
man
,
untying
the
bundle
,
and
glancing
eagerly
at
Mr
Pickwick
out
of
the
corners
of
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
here
on
purpose
.
<EOS>
Now
,
are
you
ready
to
hear
what
I
have
to
say
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Sir
?
 
<EOS>
No
hurry
;
if
you
are
not
,
I
can
wait
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
this
morning
's
paper
here
.
 
<EOS>
Your
time
shall
be
mine
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
"
 
<EOS>
Hereupon
,
the
little
man
threw
one
leg
over
the
other
,
and
made
a
show
of
beginning
to
read
with
great
composure
and
application
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a
sigh
,
but
softening
into
a
smile
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
what
you
have
to
say
;
it
's
the
old
story
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
a
difference
,
my
dear
Sir
;
with
a
difference
,
"
rejoined
Perker
,
deliberately
folding
up
the
paper
and
putting
it
into
his
pocket
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bardell
,
the
plaintiff
in
the
action
,
is
within
these
walls
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
was
Mr
Pickwick
's
reply
,
   
"
Very
good
,
"
retorted
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
know
how
she
comes
here
,
I
suppose
;
I
mean
on
what
grounds
,
and
at
whose
suit
?
"
   
"
Yes
;
at
least
I
have
heard
Sam
's
account
of
the
matter
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
affected
carelessness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
's
account
of
the
matter
,
"
replied
Perker
,
"
is
,
I
will
venture
to
say
,
a
perfectly
correct
one
.
 
<EOS>
Well
now
,
my
dear
Sir
,
the
first
question
I
have
to
ask
,
is
,
whether
this
woman
is
to
remain
here
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
To
remain
here
!
"
echoed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
remain
here
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
rejoined
Perker
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
and
looking
steadily
at
his
client
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
ask
me
?
"
said
that
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
rests
with
Dodson
and
Fogg
;
you
know
that
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
of
the
kind
,
"
retorted
Perker
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
NOT
rest
with
Dodson
and
Fogg
;
you
know
the
men
,
my
dear
Sir
,
as
well
as
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
It
rests
solely
,
wholly
,
and
entirely
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
me
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Pickwick
,
rising
nervously
from
his
chair
,
and
reseating
himself
directly
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
gave
a
double
-
knock
on
the
lid
of
his
snuff
-
box
,
opened
it
,
took
a
great
pinch
,
shut
it
up
again
,
and
repeated
the
words
,
"
With
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
resumed
the
little
man
,
who
seemed
to
gather
confidence
from
the
snuff
---
"
I
say
,
that
her
speedy
liberation
or
perpetual
imprisonment
rests
with
you
,
and
with
you
alone
.
<EOS>
Hear
me
out
,
my
dear
Sir
,
if
you
please
,
and
do
not
be
so
very
energetic
,
<EOS>
for
it
will
only
put
you
into
a
perspiration
and
do
no
good
<EOS>
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
,
"
continued
Perker
,
checking
off
each
position
on
a
different
finger
,
as
he
laid
it
down
---
"
I
say
that
nobody
but
you
can
rescue
her
from
this
den
of
wretchedness
;
and
that
you
can
only
do
that
,
by
paying
the
costs
of
this
suit
---
both
of
plaintive
and
defendant
---
into
the
hands
of
these
Freeman
Court
sharks
.
 
<EOS>
Now
pray
be
quiet
,
my
dear
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
whose
face
had
been
undergoing
most
surprising
changes
during
this
speech
,
and
was
evidently
on
the
verge
of
a
strong
burst
of
indignation
,
calmed
his
wrath
as
well
as
he
could
.
<EOS>
Perker
,
strengthening
his
argumentative
powers
with
another
pinch
of
snuff
,
proceeded
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
the
woman
,
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
By
paying
the
costs
,
you
can
obtain
a
full
release
and
discharge
from
the
damages
;
and
further
---
this
I
know
is
a
far
greater
object
of
consideration
with
you
,
my
dear
sir
---
a
voluntary
statement
,
under
her
hand
,
in
the
form
of
a
letter
to
me
,
that
this
business
was
,
from
the
very
first
,
fomented
,
and
encouraged
,
and
brought
about
,
by
these
men
,
Dodson
and
Fogg
;
that
she
deeply
regrets
ever
having
been
the
instrument
of
annoyance
or
injury
to
you
;
and
that
she
entreats
me
to
intercede
with
you
,
and
implore
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
pay
her
costs
for
her
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
valuable
document
,
indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
"
if
"
in
the
case
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
said
Perker
triumphantly
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
the
very
letter
I
speak
of
.
 
<EOS>
Brought
to
my
office
by
another
woman
at
nine
o'clock
this
morning
,
before
I
had
set
foot
in
this
place
,
or
held
any
communication
with
Mrs
Bardell
,
upon
my
honour
.
"
 
<EOS>
Selecting
the
letter
from
the
bundle
,
the
little
lawyer
laid
it
at
Mr
Pickwick
's
elbow
,
and
took
snuff
for
two
consecutive
minutes
,
without
winking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
this
all
you
have
to
say
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
,
"
replied
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
undertake
to
say
,
at
this
moment
,
whether
the
wording
of
the
cognovit
,
the
nature
of
the
ostensible
consideration
,
and
the
proof
we
can
get
together
about
the
whole
conduct
of
the
suit
,
will
be
sufficient
to
justify
an
indictment
for
conspiracy
.
 
<EOS>
I
fear
not
,
my
dear
Sir
;
they
are
too
clever
for
that
<EOS>
,
I
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
mean
to
say
,
however
,
that
the
whole
facts
,
taken
together
,
will
be
sufficient
to
justify
you
,
in
the
minds
of
all
reasonable
men
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
my
dear
Sir
,
I
put
it
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
This
one
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
,
or
whatever
it
may
be
 
<EOS>
---
take
it
in
round
numbers
---
is
nothing
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
A
jury
had
decided
against
you
;
well
,
their
verdict
is
wrong
,
but
still
they
decided
as
they
thought
right
,
and
it
IS
against
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
now
an
opportunity
,
on
easy
terms
,
of
placing
yourself
in
a
much
higher
position
than
you
ever
could
,
by
remaining
here
;
which
would
only
be
imputed
,
by
people
who
did
n't
know
you
,
to
sheer
dogged
,
wrongheaded
,
brutal
obstinacy
;
nothing
else
,
my
dear
Sir
,
believe
me
.
 
<EOS>
Can
you
hesitate
to
avail
yourself
of
it
,
when
it
restores
you
to
your
friends
,
your
old
pursuits
,
your
health
and
amusements
;
when
it
liberates
your
faithful
and
attached
servant
,
whom
you
otherwise
doom
to
imprisonment
for
the
whole
of
your
life
;
and
above
all
,
when
it
enables
you
to
take
the
very
magnanimous
revenge
---
which
I
know
,
my
dear
sir
,
is
one
after
your
own
heart
---
of
releasing
this
woman
from
a
scene
of
misery
and
debauchery
,
to
which
no
man
should
ever
be
consigned
,
if
I
had
my
will
,
but
the
infliction
of
which
on
any
woman
,
is
even
more
frightful
and
barbarous
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
ask
you
,
my
dear
sir
,
not
only
as
your
legal
adviser
,
but
as
your
very
true
friend
,
will
you
let
slip
the
occasion
of
attaining
all
these
objects
,
and
doing
all
this
good
,
for
the
paltry
consideration
of
a
few
pounds
finding
their
way
into
the
pockets
of
a
couple
of
rascals
,
to
whom
it
makes
no
manner
of
difference
,
except
that
the
more
they
gain
,
the
more
they
'll
seek
,
and
so
the
sooner
be
led
into
some
piece
of
knavery
that
must
end
in
a
crash
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
put
these
considerations
to
you
,
my
dear
Sir
,
very
feebly
and
imperfectly
,
but
I
ask
you
to
think
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
Turn
them
over
in
your
mind
as
long
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
I
wait
here
most
patiently
for
your
answer
.
"
   
<EOS>
Before
Mr
Pickwick
could
reply
,
before
Mr
Perker
had
taken
one
twentieth
part
of
the
snuff
with
which
so
unusually
long
an
address
imperatively
required
to
be
followed
up
,
there
was
a
low
murmuring
of
voices
outside
,
and
then
a
hesitating
knock
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
been
evidently
roused
by
his
friend
's
appeal
;
"
what
an
annoyance
that
door
is
!
<EOS>
Who
is
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sam
Weller
,
putting
in
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
speak
to
you
just
now
,
Sam
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
engaged
at
this
moment
,
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Weller
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
here
's
a
lady
here
,
Sir
,
as
says
she
's
somethin'
wery
partickler
to
disclose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
see
any
lady
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
whose
mind
was
filled
with
visions
of
Mrs
Bardell
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
make
too
sure
o
'
that
,
Sir
,
"
urged
Mr
Weller
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
know'd
who
was
near
,
sir
<EOS>
,
I
rayther
think
you
'd
change
your
note
;
as
the
hawk
remarked
to
himself
vith
a
cheerful
laugh
,
<EOS>
ven
<EOS>
he
heerd
the
robin
-
redbreast
a
-
singin
'
round
the
corner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
see
her
,
Sir
?
"
asked
Mr
Weller
,
holding
the
door
in
his
hand
as
if
he
had
some
curious
live
animal
on
the
other
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
must
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
at
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
all
in
to
begin
!
"
cried
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sound
the
gong
,
draw
up
the
curtain
,
and
enter
the
two
conspiraytors
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Sam
Weller
spoke
,
he
threw
the
door
open
,
and
there
rushed
tumultuously
into
the
room
,
Mr
Nathaniel
Winkle
,
leading
after
him
by
the
hand
,
the
identical
young
lady
who
at
Dingley
Dell
had
worn
the
boots
with
the
fur
round
the
tops
,
and
who
,
now
a
very
pleasing
compound
of
blushes
and
confusion
,
and
lilac
silk
,
and
a
smart
bonnet
,
and
a
rich
lace
veil
,
looked
prettier
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Arabella
Allen
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,
rising
from
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
dropping
on
his
knees
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Winkle
.
<EOS>
Pardon
,
my
dear
friend
,
pardon
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
could
scarcely
believe
the
evidence
of
his
senses
,
and
perhaps
would
not
have
done
so
,
but
for
the
corroborative
testimony
afforded
by
the
smiling
countenance
of
Perker
,
and
the
bodily
presence
,
in
the
background
,
of
Sam
and
the
pretty
housemaid
;
who
appeared
to
contemplate
the
proceedings
with
the
liveliest
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr
Pickwick
!
"
said
Arabella
,
in
a
low
voice
,
as
if
alarmed
at
the
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
forgive
my
imprudence
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
returned
no
verbal
response
to
this
appeal
;
but
he
took
off
his
spectacles
in
great
haste
,
and
seizing
both
the
young
lady
's
hands
in
his
,
kissed
her
a
great
number
of
times
---
perhaps
a
greater
number
than
was
absolutely
necessary
---
and
then
,
still
retaining
one
of
her
hands
,
told
Mr
Winkle
he
was
an
audacious
young
dog
,
and
bade
him
get
up
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
Mr
Winkle
,
who
had
been
for
some
seconds
scratching
his
nose
with
the
brim
of
his
hat
,
in
a
penitent
manner
,
did
;
whereupon
Mr
Pickwick
slapped
him
on
the
back
several
times
,
and
then
shook
hands
heartily
with
Perker
,
who
,
not
to
be
behind
-
hand
in
the
compliments
of
the
occasion
,
saluted
both
the
bride
and
the
pretty
housemaid
with
right
good
-
will
,
and
,
having
wrung
Mr
,
Winkle
's
hand
most
cordially
,
wound
up
his
demonstrations
of
joy
by
taking
snuff
enough
to
set
any
half
-
dozen
men
with
ordinarily
-
constructed
noses
,
a
-
sneezing
for
life
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
girl
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
how
has
all
this
come
about
?
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
and
let
me
hear
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
How
well
she
looks
,
does
n't
she
,
Perker
?
<EOS>
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
,
surveying
Arabella
's
face
with
a
look
of
as
much
pride
and
exultation
,
as
if
she
had
been
his
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Delightful
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
replied
the
little
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
not
a
married
man
myself
,
I
should
be
disposed
to
envy
you
,
you
dog
.
"
<EOS>
Thus
expressing
himself
,
the
little
lawyer
gave
Mr
Winkle
a
poke
in
the
chest
,
which
that
gentleman
reciprocated
;
after
which
they
both
laughed
very
loudly
,
but
not
so
loudly
as
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
who
had
just
relieved
his
feelings
by
kissing
the
pretty
housemaid
under
cover
of
the
cupboard
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
never
be
grateful
enough
to
you
,
Sam
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Arabella
,
with
the
sweetest
smile
imaginable
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
forget
your
exertions
in
the
garden
at
Clifton
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
say
nothin'
wotever
about
it
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Sam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
assisted
natur
,
ma'am
;
as
the
doctor
said
to
the
boy
's
mother
,
after
he
'd
bled
him
to
death
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mary
,
my
dear
,
sit
down
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
cutting
short
these
compliments
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
then
;
how
long
have
you
been
married
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Arabella
looked
bashfully
at
her
lord
and

,
who

,
"
Only
three
days
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
three
days
,
eh
?
"
said
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
have
you
been
doing
these
three

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

be

!
"
<EOS>
interposed

;
"
come
,

.
 
<EOS>
You

Mr
Pickwick
's
only

,
that
it
was
n't
all
over
,
months
ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why

,
"

,

,
"
that
I

not

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
Mary

,

,

<EOS>

,
"

,

"
upon

!
<EOS>
you

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
Ah
,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hot
blood
,
hot
blood
.
"
 
<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

"

"

"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Here
poor
Arabella
hid
her

in
her

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
's
nature
was
a
good
deal
worked
upon
,
by
these
same
tears
;
but
when
Mrs
Winkle
,
drying
her

,
took
to
coaxing
and

in
the
sweetest

of
a
very
sweet

,
he
became

,
and

how

,
as

by
sundry
nervous

of
his
spectacle
-
glasses
,
nose
,

,

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Taking
advantage

these

of

,
Mr

(
to
whom
,
it

,
the
young

)

with
legal

that
Mr
Winkle
,

,
was

with
the

's
flight

which
his

;

said

upon

said
Winkle
,
senior
,
continuing
to
regard

with

,

it

,

;
that

,
might

,

to

Mr

,

;
lastly
,
that
Mr

,

,

to

Mr

as

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
and
Mr

arrived
,
most

,
in
this

,
and

,

pro
and

,
the

were

,
after
which
everybody
urged
every

in

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
And
,
at
last
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
fairly

and
remonstrated
out
of
all

,
and

of
being

,
caught
Arabella
in

arms
,
and
declaring
that
she
was
a
very

,
and
that
he
did
n't

how
it
was
,
but
he
had
always

very

of
her
from
the
first
,
said

could
never

to
stand
in
the
way
of
young
people
's
happiness
,
and
they

do
with

as

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
's
first

,
on

,

Job

to

,

,

;

,

hurra'd
<EOS>
in

until

,

.
   
<EOS>
At
three

,

took

,

,
as

,
through

debtors
who

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
here
,
to

,
and
his

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

,

<EOS>
"
Perker
,
"

"
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
Job

,

"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr

uttered

,

raised

.
 
<EOS>
Many

were

forward

shake

by

hand

,
when
he
drew

arm
through
Perker
's
,
and

from
the
prison
,
far

,
for

,
than
when

.
 
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
how
many
sad
and
unhappy
beings
had
he
left
behind
!
   
<EOS>
A
happy
evening
was
that
for
at
least
one
party
in
the
George
and
Vulture
;
and
light
and
cheerful
were
two
of
the
hearts
that
emerged
from
its
hospitable
door
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
owners
thereof
were
Mr
Pickwick
and
Sam
Weller
,
the
former
of
whom
was
speedily
deposited
inside
a
comfortable
post
-

,
with

little

behind
,
in
which
the
latter
mounted
with
great

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
called

Mr
Weller
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sam
,
"

Mr
Pickwick
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
them
horses
had
been
three
months
and
better
in
the
Fleet
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Sam
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wy
,
Sir
,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Weller
,

,
"
how
they
would
go
if

!
"
    
Chapter
48
.
<EOS>
Relates
how
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
the
assistance
of
Samuel
Weller
,
essayed
to
soften
the
heart
of
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
,
and
to
mollify
the
wrath
of
Mr
Robert
Sawyer
 
Mr
Ben
Allen
and
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
<EOS>
sat
together
in
the
little
surgery
behind
the
shop
,
discussing
minced
veal
and
future
prospects
,
when
the
discourse
,
not
unnaturally
,
turned
upon
the
practice
acquired
by
Bob
the
aforesaid
,
and
his
present
chances
of
deriving
a
competent
independence
from
the
honourable
profession
to
which
he
had
devoted
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
,
I
think
,
"
observed
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
pursuing
the
thread
of
the
subject
---
"
which
,
I
think
,
Ben
,
are
rather
dubious
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
rather
dubious
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
at
the
same
time
sharpening
his
intellect
with
a
draught
of
beer
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
dubious
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
chances
,
"
responded
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
forgot
,
"
said
Mr
Ben
Allen
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
beer
has
reminded
me
that
I
forgot
,
Bob
---
<EOS>
yes
;
they
ARE
dubious
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
wonderful
how
the
poor
people
patronise
me
,
"
said
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
reflectively
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
knock
me
up
,
at
all
hours
of
the
night
;
they
take
medicine
to
an
extent
which
I
should
have
conceived
impossible
;
they
put
on
blisters
and
leeches
with
a
perseverance
worthy
of
a
better
cause
;
they
make
additions
to
their
families
,
in
a
manner
which
is
quite
awful
.
 
<EOS>
Six
of
those
last
-
named
little
promissory
notes
,
all
due
on
the
same
day
,
Ben
,
and
all
intrusted
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
gratifying
,
is
n't
it
?
"
said
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
holding
his
plate
for
some
more
minced
veal
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
very
,
"
replied
Bob
;
"
only
not
quite
so
much
so
as
the
confidence
of
patients
with
a
shilling
or
two
to
spare
would
be
.
<EOS>
This
business
was
capitally
described
in
the
advertisement
,
Ben
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
practice
,
a
very
extensive
practice
---
and
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bob
,
"
said
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
laying
down

and

,
and
fixing

on
the
visage
of
his
friend
,
"
Bob
,
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
make
yourself
,
with
as

delay
as
possible
,
master
of
Arabella
's
one
thousand
pounds
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Three
per
cent
.
<EOS>
consolidated
bank
annuities
,
now
standing
in
her
name
in
the
book
or

of
the

and

Bank
of
England
,
"
added
Bob
Sawyer
,
in
legal

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
,
"
said
Ben
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
it
when
she
comes
of
age
,
or

.
 
<EOS>
She
wants
a
year

,
and

she
need

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

,

"

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
Mr

Allen

,

---
   
<EOS>
"

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Because

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

's

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
who
had
been
slumbering
behind
the
counter
,
with
his
head
half
a
foot
or
so
below
his
knees
,
no
sooner
heard
this
appalling
communication
,
than
he
made
a
precipitate
rush
at
Mr
Martin
,
and
,
twisting
his
hand
in
the
neck
-
cloth
of
that
taciturn
servitor
,
expressed
an
obliging
intention
of
choking
him
where
he
stood
.
 
<EOS>
This
intention
,
with
a
promptitude
often
the
effect
of
desperation
,
he
at
once
commenced
carrying
into
execution
,
with
much
vigour
and
surgical
skill
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Martin
,
who
was
a
man
of
few
words
and
possessed
but
little
power
of
eloquence
or
persuasion
,
submitted
to
this
operation
with
a
very
calm
and
agreeable
expression
of
countenance
,
for
some
seconds
;
finding
,
however
,
that
it
threatened
speedily
to
lead
to
a
result
which
would
place
it
beyond
his
power
to
claim
any
wages
,
board
or
otherwise
,
in
all
time
to
come
,
he
muttered
an
inarticulate
remonstrance
and
felled
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
As
that
gentleman
had
his
hands
entangled
in
his
cravat
,
he
had
no
alternative
but
to
follow
him
to
the
floor
.
<EOS>
There
they
both
lay
struggling
,
when
the
shop
door
opened
,
and
the
party
was
increased
by
the
arrival
of
two
most
unexpected
visitors
,
to
wit
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Samuel
Weller
.
   
<EOS>
The
impression
at
once
produced
on
Mr
Weller
's
mind
by
what
he
saw
,
was
,
that
Mr
Martin
was
hired
by
the
establishment
of
Sawyer
,
late
Nockemorf
,
to
take
strong
medicine
,
or
to
go
into
fits
and
be
experimentalised
upon
,
or
to
swallow
poison
now
and
then
with
the
view
of
testing
the
efficacy
of
some
new
antidotes
,
or
to
do
something
or
other
to
promote
the
great
science
of
medicine
,
and
gratify
the
ardent
spirit
of
inquiry
burning
in
the
bosoms
of
its
two
young

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
without
presuming
to
interfere
,
Sam
stood
perfectly
still
,
and
looked
on
,
as
if
he
were
mightily
interested
in
the
result
of
the
then
pending

.
<EOS>
Not
so
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
He
at
once
threw
himself
on
the
astonished
combatants
,
with
his
accustomed
energy
,
and
loudly

upon

to

.
   
<EOS>
This

Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
who

.
 
<EOS>
With

's

,
Mr
Pickwick

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

;

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
At

,

,

,

know
what
she
had
done
that
no
respect
was
to
be
paid
to
her
years
or
station
,
and
that
she
should
be
obliged
to
beg
and
pray
,
in
that
way
,
of
her
own
nephew
,
whom
she
remembered
about
five
-
and
-
twenty
years
before
he
was
born
,
and
whom
she
had
known
,
personally
,
when
he
had
n't
a
tooth
in
his
head
;
to
say
nothing
of
her
presence
on
the
first
occasion
of
his
having
his
hair
cut
,
and
assistance
at
numerous
other
times
and
ceremonies
during
his
babyhood
,
of
sufficient
importance
to
found
a
claim
upon
his
affection
,
obedience
,
and
sympathies
,
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
While
the
good
lady
was
bestowing
this
objurgation
on
Mr
Ben
Allen
,
Bob
Sawyer
and
Mr
Pickwick
had
retired
in
close
conversation
to
the
inner
room
,
where
Mr
Sawyer
was
observed
to
apply
himself
several
times
to
the
mouth
of
a
black
bottle
,
under
the
influence
of
which
,
his
features
gradually
assumed
a
cheerful
and
even
jovial
expression
.
 
<EOS>
And
at
last
he
emerged
from
the
room
,
bottle
in
hand
,
and
,
remarking
that
he
was
very
sorry
to
say
he
had
been
making
a
fool
of
himself
,
begged
to
propose
the
health
and
happiness
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Winkle
,
whose
felicity
,
so
far
from
envying
,
he
would
be
the
first
to
congratulate
them
upon
.
 
<EOS>
Hearing
this
,
Mr
Ben
Allen
suddenly
arose
from
his
chair
,
and
,
seizing
the
black
bottle
,
drank
the
toast
so
heartily
,
<EOS>
that
,
the
liquor
being
strong
,
he
became
nearly
as
black
in
the
face
as
the
bottle
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
the
black
bottle
went
round
till
it
was
empty
,
and
there
was
so
much
shaking
of
hands
and
interchanging
of
compliments
,
that
even
the
metal
-
visaged
Mr
Martin
condescended
to
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Bob
Sawyer
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
"
we
'll
have
a
jolly
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
I
must
return
to
my
inn
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
accustomed
to
fatigue
lately
,
and
my
journey
has
tired
me
exceedingly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
some
tea
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
said
the
old
lady
,
with
irresistible
sweetness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
I
would
rather
not
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
that
the
old
lady
's
evidently
increasing
admiration
was
Mr
Pickwick
's
principal
inducement
for
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
Mrs
Bardell
;
and
every
glance
of
the
old
lady
's
eyes
threw
him
into
a
cold
perspiration
.
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
could
by
no
means
be
prevailed
upon
to
stay
,
it
was
arranged
at
once
,
on
his
own
proposition
,
that
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
should
accompany
him
on
his
journey
to
the
elder
Mr
Winkle
's
,
and
that
the
coach
should
be
at
the
door
,
at
nine
o'clock
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
took
his
leave
,
and
,
followed
by
Samuel
Weller
,
repaired
to
the
Bush
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
worthy
of
remark
,
that
Mr
Martin
's
face
was
horribly
convulsed
as
he
shook
hands
with
Sam
at
parting
,
and
that
he
gave
vent
to
a
smile
and
an
oath
simultaneously
;
from
which
tokens
it
has
been
inferred
by
those
who
were
best
acquainted
with
that
gentleman
's
peculiarities
,
that
he
expressed
himself
much
pleased
with
Mr
Weller
's
society
,
and
requested
the
honour
of
his
further
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
order
a
private
room
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
Sam
,
when
they
reached
the
Bush
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,
Sam
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
as
I
dined
in
the
coffee
-
room
,
and
shall
go
to
bed
soon
,
it
is
hardly
worth
while
.
<EOS>
See
who
there
is
in
the
travellers
"
room
,
Sam
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
departed
on
his
errand
,
and
presently
returned
to
say
that
there
was
only
a
gentleman
with
one
eye
;
and
that
he
and
the
landlord
were
drinking
a
bowl
of
bishop
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
join
them
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
queer
customer
,
the
vun
-
eyed
vun
,
sir
,
"
observed
Mr
Weller
,
as
he
led
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
-
gammonin
'
that
'
ere
landlord
,
he
is
,
sir
,
till
he
do
n't
rightly
know
wether
he
's
a
-
standing
on
the
soles
of
his
boots
or
the
crown
of
his
hat
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
individual
to
whom
this
observation
referred
,
was
sitting
at
the
upper
end
of
the
room
when
Mr
Pickwick
entered
,
and
was
smoking
a
large
Dutch
pipe
,
with
his
eye
intently
fixed
on
the
round
face
of
the
landlord
;
a
jolly
-
looking
old
personage
,
to
whom
he
had
recently
been
relating
some
tale
of
wonder
,
as
was
testified
by
sundry
disjointed
exclamations
of
,
"
Well
,
I
would
n't
have
believed
it
!
 
<EOS>
The
strangest
thing
I
ever
heard
!
 
<EOS>
Could
n't
have
supposed
it
possible
!
"
<EOS>
and
other
expressions
of
astonishment
which
burst
spontaneously
from
his
lips
,
as
he
returned
the
fixed
gaze
of
the
one
-
eyed
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Servant
,
sir
,
"
said
the
one
-
eyed
man
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fine
night
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
so
indeed
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
the
waiter
placed
a
small
decanter
of
brandy
,
and
some
hot
water
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
While
Mr
Pickwick
was
mixing
his
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
the
one
-
eyed
man
looked
round
at
him
earnestly
,
from
time
to
time
,
and
at
length
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
've
seen
you
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
recollect
you
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
not
,
"
said
the
one
-
eyed
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
know
me
,
but
I
knew
two
friends
of
yours
that
were
stopping
at
the
Peacock
at
Eatanswill
,
at
the
time
of
the
election
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
rejoined
the
one
-
eyed
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mentioned
a
little
circumstance
to
them
about
a
friend
of
mine
of
the
name
of
Tom
Smart
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
've
heard
them
speak
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Often
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
,
smiling
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
your
uncle
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
only
a
friend
of
my
uncle
's
,
"
replied
the
one
-
eyed
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
wonderful
man
,
that
uncle
of
yours
,
though
,
"
remarked
the
landlord
shaking
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
think
he
was
;
I
think
I
may
say
he
was
,
"
answered
the
one
-
eyed
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
tell
you
a
story
about
that
same
uncle
,
gentlemen
,
that
would
rather
surprise
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Could
you
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hear
it
,
by
all
means
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
one
-
eyed
bagman
ladled
out
a
glass
of
negus
from
the
bowl
,
and
drank
it
;
smoked
a
long
whiff
out
of
the
Dutch
pipe
;
and
then
,
calling
to
Sam
Weller
who
was
lingering
near
the
door
,
that
he
need
n't
go
away
unless
he
wanted
to
,
because
the
story
was
no
secret
,
fixed
his
eye
upon
the
landlord
's
,
and
proceeded
,
in
the
words
of
the
next
chapter
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
49
.
<EOS>
Containing
the
story
of
the
bagman
's
uncle
 
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
bagman
,
"
was
one
of
the
merriest
,
pleasantest
,
cleverest
fellows
,
that
ever
lived
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
had
known
him
,
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
On
second
thoughts
,
gentlemen
,
I
do
n't
wish
you
had
known
him
,
for
if
you
had
,
you
would
have
been
all
,
by
this
time
,
in
the
ordinary
course
of
nature
,
if
not
dead
,
at
all
events
so
near
it
,
as
to
have
taken
to
stopping
at
home
and
giving
up
company
,
which
would
have
deprived
me
of
the
inestimable
pleasure
of
addressing
you
at
this
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
I
wish
your
fathers
and
mothers
had
known
my
uncle
.
<EOS>
They
would
have
been
amazingly
fond
of
him
,
especially
your
respectable
mothers
;
I
know
they
would
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
two
of
his
numerous
virtues
predominated
over
the
many
that
adorned
his
character
,
I
should
say
they
were
his
mixed
punch
and
his
after
-
supper
song
.
 
<EOS>
Excuse
my
dwelling
on
these
melancholy
recollections
of
departed
worth
<EOS>
;
you
wo
n't
see
a
man
like
my
uncle
every
day
in
the
week
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
considered
it
a
great
point
in
my
uncle
's
character
,
gentlemen
,
that
he
was
the
intimate
friend
and
companion
of
Tom
Smart
,
of
the
great
house
of
Bilson
and
Slum
,
Cateaton
Street
,
City
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
collected
for
Tiggin
and
Welps
,
but
for
a
long
time
he
went
pretty
near
the
same
journey
as
Tom
;
and
the
very
first
night
they
met
,
my
uncle
took
a
fancy
for
Tom
,
and
Tom
took
a
fancy
for
my
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
They
made
a
bet
of
a
new
hat
before
they
had
known
each
other
half
an
hour
,
who
should
brew
the
best
quart
of
punch
and
drink
it
the
quickest
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
was
judged
to
have
won
the
making
,
but
Tom
Smart
beat
him
in
the
drinking
by
about
half
a
salt
-
spoonful
.
 
<EOS>
They
took
another
quart
apiece
to
drink
each
other
's
health
in
,
and
were
staunch
friends
ever
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
destiny
in
these
things
,
gentlemen
;
we
ca
n't
help
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
personal
appearance
,
my
uncle
was
a
trifle
shorter
than
the
middle
size
;
he
was
a
thought
stouter
too
,
than
the
ordinary
run
of
people
,
and
perhaps
his
face
might
be
a
shade
redder
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
the
jolliest
face
you
ever
saw
,
gentleman
:
something
like
Punch
,
with
a
handsome
nose
and
chin
;
his
eyes
were
always
twinkling
and
sparkling
with
good
-
humour
;
and
a
smile
---
not
one
of
your
unmeaning
wooden
grins
,
but
a
real
,
merry
,
hearty
,
good
-
tempered
smile
---
was
perpetually
on
his
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
pitched
out
of
his
gig
once
,
and
knocked
,
head
first
,
against
a
milestone
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
lay
,
stunned
,
and
so
cut
about
the
face
with
some
gravel
which
had
been
heaped
up
alongside
it
,
that
,
to
use
my
uncle
's
own
strong
expression
,
if
his
mother
could
have
revisited
the
earth
,
she
would
n't
have
known
him
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
when
I
come
to
think
of
the
matter
,
gentlemen
,
I
feel
pretty
sure
she
would
n't
.
 
<EOS>
for
she
died
when
my
uncle
was
two
years
and
seven
months
old
,
and
I
think
it
's
very
likely
that
,
even
without
the
gravel
,
his
top
-
boots
would
have
puzzled
the
good
lady
not
a
little
;
to
say
nothing
of
his
jolly
red
face
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
there
he
lay
,
and
I
have
heard
my
uncle
say
,
many
a
time
,
that
the
man
said
who
picked
him
up
that
he
was
smiling
as
merrily
as
if
he
had
tumbled
out
for
a
treat
,
and
that
after
they
had
bled
him
,
the
first
faint
glimmerings
of
returning
animation
,
were
his
jumping
up
in
bed
,
bursting
out
into
a
loud
laugh
,
kissing
the
young
woman
who
held
the
basin
,
and
demanding
a
mutton
chop
and
a
pickled
walnut
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
fond
of
pickled
walnuts
,
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
He
said
he
always
found
that
,
taken
without
vinegar
,
they
relished
the
beer
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
's
great
journey
was
in
the
fall
of
the
leaf
,
at
which
time
he
collected
debts
,
and
took
orders
,
in
the
north
;
going
from
London
to
Edinburgh
,
from
Edinburgh
to
Glasgow
,
from
Glasgow
back
to
Edinburgh
,
and
thence
to
London
by
the
smack
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
to
understand
that
his
second
visit
to
Edinburgh
was
for
his
own
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
to
go
back
for
a
week
,
just
to
look
up
his
old
friends
;
and
what
with
breakfasting
with
this
one
,
lunching
with
that
,
dining
with
the
third
,
and
supping
with
another
,
a
pretty
tight
week
he
used
to
make
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
any
of
you
,
gentlemen
,
ever
partook
of
a
real
substantial
hospitable
Scotch
breakfast
,
and
then
went
out
to
a
slight
lunch
of
a
bushel
of
oysters
,
a
dozen
or
so
of
bottled
ale
,
and
a
noggin
or
two
of
whiskey
to
close
up
with
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ever
did
,
you
will
agree
with
me
that
it
requires
a
pretty
strong
head
to
go
out
to
dinner
and
supper
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
bless
your
hearts
and
eyebrows
,
all
this
sort
of
thing
was
nothing
to
my
uncle
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
well
seasoned
,
that
it
was
mere
child
's
play
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
him
say
that
he
could
see
the
Dundee
people
out
,
any
day
,
and
walk
home
afterwards
without
staggering
;
and
yet
the
Dundee
people
have
as
strong
heads
and
as
strong
punch
,
gentlemen
,
as
you
are
likely
to
meet
with
,
between
the
poles
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
of
a
Glasgow
man
and
a
Dundee
man
drinking
against
each
other
for
fifteen
hours
at
a
sitting
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
both
suffocated
,
as
nearly
as
could
be
ascertained
,
at
the
same
moment
,
but
with
this
trifling
exception
,
gentlemen
,
they
were
not
a
bit
the
worse
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
night
,
within
four
-
and

twenty
hours
of
the
time
when
he
had
settled
to
take
shipping
for
London
,
my
uncle
supped
at
the
house
of
a
very
old

,
a
Bailie
Mac
something
and
four

after
it
,
who
lived
in
the
old

of
Edinburgh
.
<EOS>
There
were
the
bailie
's
wife
,
and
the
bailie
's
three

,
and
the
bailie
's
grown

,
and
three

,
that
the
bailie
had
got
together
to
do

to
my
uncle
,
and
help
to
make

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
glorious
supper
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
kippered
salmon
,
and
Finnan
haddocks
,
and
a
lamb
's
head
,
and
a
haggis
---
a

Scotch
dish
,
gentlemen
,
which
my
uncle
used
to
say
always
looked
to
him
,
when
it
came
to

,
very

like
a
Cupid
's

---
and
a

many

,
that
I

but
very

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

were
pretty

;
the
bailie
's
wife
was
one
of
the
best
creatures
that
ever
lived
;
and
my
uncle
was
in
thoroughly
good

.
 
<EOS>
The
consequence
of
which
was
,
that
the
young

tittered
and
giggled
,
and
the
old

out

,
and
the
bailie
and
the
other
old
fellows
roared
till
they
were
red

the
face
,
the
whole
mortal
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
do

quite
recollect
how
many
tumblers
of
whiskey
-
toddy
each
man
drank
after

;
but
this
I
know
,
that
about
one

morning
,
the

's
grown

became

of
"
Willie
brewed

o

"
;
and

,
for

the
only

visible
above
the
mahogany
<EOS>
,

it

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
Still

;

---
<EOS>
neat

,

---
and
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
it
was
a
wild

when
my
uncle

the
bailie
's

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

were

;
at

anon

.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
this
wo

"

<EOS>
"
This

.
 
<EOS>
It
will

any

,
"

my
uncle
,

.
 
<EOS>
Having

,

for

was

with
looking

.
   
<EOS>
"
The

,

other

<EOS>
On

<EOS>
Six
,
seven
,
eight
Storey
high
,
were

;

,
as
children
build
with

---
throwing

over
the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
A

,
but

to

.
 
<EOS>
Glancing

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
particular
in

my

the

the
street
,
with
his
thumbs
in

,
gentlemen
,
because
,
as

say
(

that

<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,

,
taking

,

now

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Here

,

,

its

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
my

stopped
here
,
for
a

,

;
and

,

,

,

,

,
as

;

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

and

,

,

<EOS>
"
When

,

<EOS>
Now
,

,

,

,

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
My

a

,

;
so

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
might

a
dozen

,

---
my

was
never

,

,

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

had

;

off
,
only

here

;

,

long

,

,

;

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

the

of

mails
,
and
in
that

,
at
that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
uncle

,
and

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
my
uncle
used
to
SAY

thought

,

,
<EOS>
for

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
my

,

<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Be

,

.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
woke
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
In

,

,

most

.
 
<EOS>
The
mail
coach
doors
were
on
their

,
the
lining
was
replaced
,
the
ironwork
was
as
good

,
the

was

,
the

were
alight
;
cushions

were
on
every

box
,

were

,

were

away

,

;

were
pushing

,
fixing

every
coach
<EOS>
;

,

,

;

clear
that

there
,

.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,

that
,

,

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Now

!
"

,

,
"
you
're

inside
.
 
<EOS>
You
'd

get

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
booked
!
"
<EOS>
said

uncle
,
turning
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Yes
,
certainly
.
"
   
"
My
uncle
,
gentlemen
,
could
say
nothing
,
he
was
so

.
 
<EOS>
The
queerest

of
all
was
that
although

was
such

crowd

,
and
although

were
pouring
in
,
every
moment
,
there
was
no
telling
where
they
came
from
.
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
start
up
,
in
some
strange
manner
,
from
the
ground
,
or
the
air
,
and
disappear
in
the
same
way
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
porter
had
put
his
luggage
in
the
coach
,
and
received
his
fare
,
he
turned
round
and
was
gone
;
and
before
my
uncle
had
well
begun
to
wonder
what
had
become
of
him
,
half
a
dozen
fresh
ones
started
up
,
and
staggered
along
under
the
weight
of
parcels
,
which
seemed
big
enough
to
crush
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
passengers
were
all
dressed
so
oddly
too
!
 
<EOS>
Large
,
broad
-
skirted
laced
coats
,
with
great
cuffs
and
no
collars
;
and
wigs
,
gentlemen
---
great
formal
wigs
with
a
tie
behind
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
could
make
nothing
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Now
,
are
you
going
to
get
in
?
"
said
the
person
who
had
addressed
my
uncle
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
as
a
mail
guard
,
with
a
wig
on
his
head
and
most
enormous
cuffs
to
his
coat
,
and
had
a
lantern
in
one
hand
,
and
a
huge
blunderbuss
in
the
other
,
which
he
was
going
to
stow
away
in
his
little
arm
-
chest
.
 
<EOS>
"
ARE
you
going
to
get
in
,
Jack
Martin
?
"
said
the
guard
,
holding
the
lantern
to
my
uncle
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Hollo
!
"
said
my
uncle
,
falling
back
a
step
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
familiar
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
It
's
so
on
the
way
-
bill
,
"
said
the
guard
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Is
n't
there
a
"
Mister
"
before
it
?
"
said
my
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
felt
,
gentlemen
,
that
for
a
guard
he
did
n't
know
,
to
call
him
Jack
Martin
,
was
a
liberty
which
the
Post
Office
would
n't
have
sanctioned
if
they
had
known
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
No
,
there
is
not
,
"
rejoined
the
guard
coolly
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Is
the
fare
paid
?
"
inquired
my
uncle
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Of
course
it
is
,
"
rejoined
the
guard
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
it
is
,
is
it
?
"
said
my
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
here
goes
!
 
<EOS>
Which
coach
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
This
,
"
said
the
guard
,
pointing
to
an
old
-
fashioned
Edinburgh
and
London
mail
,
which
had
the
steps
down
and
the
door
open
.
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
 
<EOS>
Here
are
the
other
passengers
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
get
in
first
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
the
guard
spoke
,
there
all
at
once
appeared
,
right
in
front
of
my
uncle
,
a
young
gentleman
in
a
powdered
wig
,
and
a
sky
-
blue
coat
trimmed
with
silver
,
made
very
full
and
broad
in
the
skirts
,
which
were
lined
with
buckram
.
 
<EOS>
Tiggin
and
Welps
were
in
the
printed
calico
and
waistcoat
piece
line
,
gentlemen
,
so
my
uncle
knew
all
the
materials
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
knee
breeches
,
and
a
kind
of
leggings
rolled
up
over
his
silk
stockings
,
and
shoes
with
buckles
;
he
had
ruffles
at
his
wrists
,
a
three
-
cornered
hat
on
his
head
,
and
a
long
taper
sword
by
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
The
flaps
of
his
waist
-
coat
came
half
-
way
down
his
thighs
,
and
the
ends
of
his
cravat
reached
to
his
waist
.
 
<EOS>
He
stalked
gravely
to
the
coach
door
,
pulled
off
his
hat
,
and
held
it
above
his
head
at
arm
's
length
,
cocking
his
little
finger
in
the
air
at
the
same
time
,
as
some
affected
people
do
,
when
they
take
a
cup
of
tea
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
drew
his
feet
together
,
and
made
a
low
,
grave
bow
,
and
then
put
out
his
left
hand
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
was
just
going
to
step
forward
,
and
shake
it
heartily
,
when
he
perceived
that
these
attentions
were
directed
,
not
towards
him
,
but
to
a
young
lady
who
just
then
appeared
at
the
foot
of
the
steps
,
attired
in
an
old
-
fashioned
green
velvet
dress
with
a
long
waist
and
stomacher
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
no
bonnet
on
her
head
,
gentlemen
,
which
was
muffled
in
a
black
silk
hood
,
but
she
looked
round
for
an
instant
as
she
prepared
to
get
into
the
coach
,
and
such
a
beautiful
face
as
she
disclosed
,
my
uncle
had
never
seen
---
not
even
in
a
picture
.
 
<EOS>
She
got
into
the
coach
,
holding
up
her
dress
with
one
hand
;
and
as
my
uncle
always
said
with
a
round
oath
,
when
he
told
the
story
,
he
would
n't
have
believed
it
possible
that
legs
and
feet
could
have
been
brought
to
such
a
state
of
perfection
unless
he
had
seen
them
with
his
own
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
in
this
one
glimpse
of
the
beautiful
face
,
my
uncle
saw
that
the
young
lady
cast
an
imploring
look
upon
him
,
and
that
she
appeared
terrified
and
distressed
.
 
<EOS>
He
noticed
,
too
,
that
the
young
fellow
in
the
powdered
wig
,
notwithstanding
his
show
of
gallantry
,
which
was
all
very
fine
and
grand
,
clasped
her
tight
by
the
wrist
when
she
got
in
,
and
followed
himself
immediately
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
An
uncommonly
ill
-
looking
fellow
,
in
a
close
brown
wig
,
and
a
plum
-
coloured
suit
,
wearing
a
very
large
sword
,
and
boots
up
to
his
hips
,
belonged
to
the
party
;
and
when
he
sat
himself
down
next
to
the
young
lady
,
who
shrank
into
a
corner
at
his
approach
,
my
uncle
was
confirmed
in
his
original
impression
that
something
dark
and
mysterious
was
going
forward
,
or
,
as
he
always
said
himself
,
that
"
there
was
a
screw
loose
somewhere
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It
's
quite
surprising
how
quickly
he
made
up
his
mind
to
help
the
lady
at
any
peril
,
if
she
needed
any
help
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Death
and
lightning
!
"
exclaimed
the
young
gentleman
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
sword
as
my
uncle
entered
the
coach
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Blood
and
thunder
!
"
roared
the
other
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
whipped
his
sword
out
,
and
made
a
lunge
at
my
uncle
without
further
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
had
no
weapon
about
him
,
but
with
great
dexterity
he
snatched
the
ill
-
looking
gentleman
's
three
-
cornered
hat
from
his
head
,
and
,
receiving
the
point
of
his
sword
right
through
the
crown
,
squeezed
the
sides
together
,
and
held
it
tight
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Pink
him
behind
!
"
cried
the
ill
-
looking
gentleman
to
his
companion
,
as
he
struggled
to
regain
his
sword
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
He
had
better
not
,
"
cried
my
uncle
,
displaying
the
heel
of
one
of
his
shoes
,
in
a
threatening
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
kick
his
brains
out
,
if
he
has
any
---
,
or
fracture
his
skull
if
he
has
n't
.
"
 
<EOS>
Exerting
all
his
strength
,
at
this
moment
,
my
uncle
wrenched
the
ill
-
looking
man
's
sword
from
his
grasp
,
and
flung
it
clean
out
of
the
coach
window
,
upon
which
the
younger
gentleman
vociferated
,
"
Death
and
lightning
!
"
<EOS>
again
,
and
laid
his
hand
upon
the
hilt
of
his
sword
,
in
a
very
fierce
manner
,
but
did
n't
draw
it
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
gentlemen
,
as
my
uncle
used
to
say
with
a
smile
,
perhaps
he
was
afraid
of
alarming
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Now
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
my
uncle
,
taking
his
seat
deliberately
,
"
I
do
n't
want
to
have
any
death
,
with
or
without
lightning
,
in
a
lady
's
presence
,
and
we
have
had
quite
blood
and
thundering
enough
for
one
journey
;
so
,
if
you
please
,
we
'll
sit
in
our
places
like
quiet
insides
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
guard
,
pick
up
that
gentleman
's
carving
-
knife
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
quickly
as
my
uncle
said
the
words
,
the
guard
appeared
at
the
coach
window
,
with
the
gentleman
's
sword
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
up
his
lantern
,
and
looked
earnestly
in
my
uncle
's
face
,
as
he
handed
it
in
,
when
,
by
its
light
,
my
uncle
saw
,
to
his
great
surprise
,
that
an
immense
crowd
of
mail
-
coach
guards
swarmed
round
the
window
,
every
one
of
whom
had
his
eyes
earnestly
fixed
upon
him
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
seen
such
a
sea
of
white
faces
,
red
bodies
,
and
earnest
eyes
,
in
all
his
born
days
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
This
is
the
strangest
sort
of
thing
I
ever
had
anything
to
do
with
,
"
thought
my
uncle
;
"
allow
me
to
return
you
your
hat
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
ill
-
looking
gentleman
received
his
three
-
cornered
hat
in
silence
,
looked
at
the
hole
in
the
middle
with
an
inquiring
air
,
and
finally
stuck
it
on
the
top
of
his
wig
with
a
solemnity
the
effect
of
which
was
a
trifle
impaired
by
his
sneezing
violently
at
the
moment
,
and
jerking
it
off
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
All
right
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
guard
with
the
lantern
,
mounting
into
his
little
seat
behind
.
 
<EOS>
Away
they
went
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
peeped
out
of
the
coach
window
as
they
emerged
from
the
yard
,
and
observed
that
the
other
mails
,
with
coachmen
,
guards
,
horses
,
and
passengers
,
complete
,
were
driving
round
and
round
in
circles
,
at
a
slow
trot
of
about
five
miles
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
burned
with
indignation
,
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
commercial
man
,
he
felt
that
the
mail
-
bags
were
not
to
be
trifled
with
,
and
he
resolved
to
memorialise
the
Post
Office
on
the
subject
,
the
very
instant
he
reached
London
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
present
,
however
,
his
thoughts
were
occupied
with
the
young
lady
who
sat
in
the
farthest
corner
of
the
coach
,
with
her
face
muffled
closely
in
her
hood
;
the
gentleman
with
the
sky
-
blue
coat
sitting
opposite
to
her
;
the
other
man
in
the
plum
-
coloured
suit
,
by
her
side
;
and
both
watching
her
intently
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
so
much
as
rustled
the
folds
of
her
hood
,
he
could
hear
the
ill
-
looking
man
clap
his
hand
upon
his
sword
,
and
could
tell
by
the
other
's
breathing
(
it
was
so
dark
he
could
n't
see
his
face
)
that
he
was
looking
as
big
as
if
he
were
going
to
devour
her
at
a
mouthful
.
<EOS>
This
roused
my
uncle
more
and
more
,
and
he
resolved
,
come
what
might
,
to
see
the
end
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
great
admiration
for
bright
eyes
,
and
sweet
faces
,
and
pretty
legs
and
feet
;
in
short
,
he
was
fond
of
the
whole
sex
.
 
<EOS>
It
runs
in
our
family
,
gentleman
---
so
am
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Many
were
the
devices
which
my
uncle
practised
,
to
attract
the
lady
's
attention
,
or
at
all
events
,
to
engage
the
mysterious
gentlemen
in
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
all
in
vain
;
the
gentlemen
would
n't
talk
,
and
the
lady
did
n't
dare
.
 
<EOS>
He
thrust
his
head
out
of
the
coach
window
at
intervals
,
and
bawled
out
to
know
why
they
did
n't
go
faster
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
called
till
he
was
hoarse
;
nobody
paid
the
least
attention
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
leaned
back
in
the
coach
,
and
thought
of
the
beautiful
face
,
and
the
feet
and
legs
.
 
<EOS>
This
answered
better
;
it
whiled
away
the
time
,
and
kept
him
from
wondering
where
he
was
going
,
and
how
it
was
that
he
found
himself
in
such
an
odd
situation
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
this
would
have
worried
him
much
,
anyway
 
---
he
was
a
mighty
free
and
easy
,
roving
,
devil
-
may
-
care
sort
of
person
,
was
my
uncle
,
gentlemen
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
of
a
sudden
the
coach
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"
said
my
uncle
,
"
what
's
in
the
wind
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Alight
here
,
"
said
the
guard
,
letting
down
the
steps
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Here
!
"
cried
my
uncle
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Here
,
"
rejoined
the
guard
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
'll
do
nothing
of
the
sort
,
"
said
my
uncle
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Very
well
,
then
stop
where
you
are
,
"
said
the
guard
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
will
,
"
said
my
uncle
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Do
,
"
said
the
guard
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
passengers
had
regarded
this
colloquy
with
great
attention
,
and
,
finding
that
my
uncle
was
determined
not
to
alight
,
the
younger
man
squeezed
past
him
,
to
hand
the
lady
out
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
the
ill
-
looking
man
was
inspecting
the
hole
in
the
crown
of
his
three
-
cornered
hat
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
young
lady
brushed
past
,
she
dropped
one
of
her
gloves
into
my
uncle
's
hand
,
and
softly
whispered
,
with
her
lips
so
close
to
his
face
that
he
felt
her
warm
breath
on
his
nose
,
the
single
word
"
Help
!
"
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
my
uncle
leaped
out
of
the
coach
at
once
,
with
such
violence
that
it
rocked
on
the
springs
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
!
you
've
thought
better
of
it
,
have
you
?
"
said
the
guard
,
when
he
saw
my
uncle
standing
on
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
looked
at
the
guard
for
a
few
seconds
,
in
some
doubt
whether
it
would
n't
be
better
to
wrench
his
blunderbuss
from
him
,
fire
it
in
the
face
of
the
man
with
the
big
sword
,
knock
the
rest
of
the
company
over
the
head
with
the
stock
,
snatch
up
the
young
lady
,
and
go
off
in
the
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
On
second
thoughts
,
however
,
he
abandoned
this
plan
,
as
being
a
shade
too
melodramatic
in
the
execution
,
and
followed
the
two
mysterious
men
,
who
,
keeping
the
lady
between
them
,
were
now
entering
an
old
house
in
front
of
which
the
coach
had
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
They
turned
into
the
passage
,
and
my
uncle
followed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
ruinous
and
desolate
places
my
uncle
had
ever
beheld
,
this
was
the
most
so
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
as
if
it
had
once
been
a
large
house
of
entertainment
;
but
the
roof
had
fallen
in
,
in
many
places
,
and
the
stairs
were
steep
,
rugged
,
and
broken
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
huge
fireplace
in
the
room
into
which
they
walked
,
and
the
chimney
was
blackened
with
smoke
;
but
no
warm
blaze
lighted
it
up
now
.
 
<EOS>
The
white
feathery
dust
of
burned
wood
was
still
strewed
over
the
hearth
,
but
the
stove
was
cold
,
and
all
was
dark
and
gloomy
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Well
,
"
said
my
uncle
,
as
he
looked
about
him
,
"
a
mail
travelling
at
the
rate
of
six
miles
and
a
half
an
hour
,
and
stopping
for
an
indefinite
time
at
such
a
hole
as
this
,
is
rather
an
irregular
sort
of
proceeding
,
I
fancy
.
 
<EOS>
This
shall
be
made
known
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
write
to
the
papers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
said
this
in
a
pretty
loud
voice
,
and
in
an
open
,
unreserved
sort
of
manner
,
with
the
view
of
engaging
the
two
strangers
in
conversation
if
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
neither
of
them
took
any
more
notice
of
him
than
whispering
to
each
other
,
and
scowling
at
him
as
they
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
was
at
the
farther
end
of
the
room
,
and
once
she
ventured
to
wave
her
hand
,
as
if
beseeching
my
uncle
's
assistance
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
length
the
two
strangers
advanced
a
little
,
and
the
conversation
began
in
earnest
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
do
n't
know
this
is
a
private
room
,
I
suppose
,
fellow
?
"
said
the
gentleman
in
sky
-
blue
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
No
,
I
do
not
,
fellow
,
"
rejoined
my
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
,
if
this
is
a
private
room
specially
ordered
for
the
occasion
,
I
should
think
the
public
room
must
be
a
VERY
comfortable
one
;
"
with
this
,
my
uncle
sat
himself
down
in
a
high
-
backed
chair
,
and
took
such
an
accurate
measure
of
the
gentleman
,
with
his
eyes
,
that
Tiggin
and
Welps
could
have
supplied
him
with
printed
calico
for
a
suit
,
and
not
an
inch
too
much
or
too
little
,
from
that
estimate
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Quit
this
room
,
"
said
both
men
together
,
grasping
their
swords
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Eh
?
"
said
my
uncle
,
not
at
all
appearing
to
comprehend
their
meaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Quit
the
room
,
or
you
are
a
dead
man
,
"
said
the
ill
-
looking
fellow
with
the
large
sword
,
drawing
it
at
the
same
time
and
flourishing
it
in
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Down
with
him
!
"
cried
the
gentleman
in
sky
-
blue
,
drawing
his
sword
also
,
and
falling
back
two
or
three
yards
.
 
<EOS>
"
Down
with
him
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
lady
gave
a
loud
scream
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
uncle
was
always
remarkable
for
great
boldness
,
and
great
presence
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
time
that
he
had
appeared
so
indifferent
to
what
was
going
on
,
he
had
been
looking
slily
about
for
some
missile
or
weapon
of
defence
,
and
at
the
very
instant
when
the
swords
were
drawn
,
he
espied
,
standing
in
the
chimneycorner
,
an
old
basket
-
hilted
rapier
in
a
rusty
scabbard
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
bound
,
my
uncle
caught
it
in
his
hand
,
drew
it
,
flourished
it
gallantly
above
his
head
,
called
aloud
to
the
lady
to
keep
out
of
the
way
,
hurled
the
chair
at
the
man
in
sky
-
blue
,
and
the
scabbard
at
the
man
in
plum
-
colour
,
and
taking
advantage
of
the
confusion
,
fell
upon
them
both
,
pell
-
mell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
there
is
an
old
story
---
none
the
worse
for
being
true
---
regarding
a
fine
young
Irish
gentleman
,
who
being
asked
if
he
could
play
the
fiddle
,
<EOS>
replied
he
had
no
doubt
he
could
,
but
he
could
n't
exactly
say
,
for
certain
,
because
he
had
never
tried
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
not
inapplicable
to
my
uncle
and
his
fencing
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
had
a
sword
in
his
hand
before
,
except
once
when
he
played
Richard
the
Third
at
a
private
theatre
,
upon
which
occasion
it
was
arranged
with
Richmond
that
he
was
to
be
run
through
,
from
behind
,
without
showing
fight
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
here
he
was
,
cutting
and
slashing
with
two
experienced
swordsman
,
thrusting
,
and
guarding
,
and
poking
,
and
slicing
,
and
acquitting
himself
in
the
most
manful
and
dexterous
manner
possible
,
although
up
to
that
time
he
had
never
been
aware
that
he
had
the
least
notion
of
the
science
.
 
<EOS>
It
only
shows
how
true
the
old
saying
is
,
that
a
man
never
knows
what
he
can
do
till
he
tries
,
gentlemen
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
noise
of
the
combat
was
terrific
;
each
of
the
three
combatants
swearing
like
troopers
,
and
their
swords
clashing
with
as
much
noise
as
if
all
the
knives
and
steels
in
Newport
market
were
rattling
together
,
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
at
its
very
height
,
the
lady
(
to
encourage
my
uncle
most
probably
)
withdrew
her
hood
entirely
from
her
face
,
and
disclosed
a
countenance
of
such
dazzling
beauty
,
that
he
would
have
fought
against
fifty
men
,
to
win
one
smile
from
it
and
die
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
done
wonders
before
,
but
now
he
began
to
powder
away
like
a
raving
mad
giant
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
this
very
moment
,
the
gentleman
in
sky
-
blue
turning
round
,
and
seeing
the
young
lady
with
her
face
uncovered
,
vented
an
exclamation
of
rage
and
jealousy
,
and
,
turning
his
weapon
against
her
beautiful
bosom
,
pointed
a
thrust
at
her
heart
,
which
caused
my
uncle
to
utter
a
cry
of
apprehension
that
made
the
building
ring
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
stepped
lightly
aside
,
and
snatching
the
young
man
's
sword
from
his
hand
,
before
he
had
recovered
his
balance
,
drove
him
to
the
wall
,
and
running
it
through
him
,
and
the
panelling
,
up
to
the
very
hilt
,
pinned
him
there
,
hard
and
fast
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
splendid
example
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
,
with
a
loud
shout
of
triumph
,
and
a
strength
that
was
irresistible
,
made
his
adversary
retreat
in
the
same
direction
,
and
plunging
the
old
rapier
into
the
very
centre
of
a
large
red
flower
in
the
pattern
of
his
waistcoat
,
nailed
him
beside
his
friend
;
there
they
both
stood
,
gentlemen
,
jerking
their
arms
and
legs
about
in
agony
,
like
the
toy
-
shop
figures
that
are
moved
by
a
piece
of
pack
-
thread
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
always
said
,
afterwards
,
that
this
was
one
of
the
surest
means
he
knew
of
,
for
disposing
of
an
enemy
;
but
it
was
liable
to
one
objection
on
the
ground
of
expense
,
inasmuch
as
it
involved
the
loss
of
a
sword
for
every
man
disabled
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
The
mail
,
the
mail
!
"
cried
the
lady
,
running
up
to
my
uncle
and
throwing
her
beautiful
arms
round
his
neck
;
"
we
may
yet
escape
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
May
!
"
cried
my
uncle
;
"
why
,
my
dear
,
there
's
nobody
else
to
kill
,
is
there
?
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
was
rather
disappointed
,
gentlemen
,
for
he
thought
a
little
quiet
bit
of
love
-
making
would
be
agreeable
after
the
slaughtering
,
if
it
were
only
to
change
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
We
have
not
an
instant
to
lose
here
,
"
said
the
young
lady
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
(
pointing
to
the
young
gentleman
in
sky
-
blue
)
is
the
only
son
of
the
powerful
Marquess
of
Filletoville
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
Well
then
,
my
dear
,
I
'm
afraid
he
'll
never
come
to
the
title
,
"
said
my
uncle
,
looking
coolly
at
the
young
gentleman
as
he
stood
fixed
up
against
the
wall
,
in
the
cockchafer
fashion
that
I
have
described
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
cut
off
the
entail
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
have
been
torn
from
my
home
and
my
friends
by
these
villains
,
"
said
the
young
lady
,
her
features
glowing
with
indignation
.
<EOS>
"
That
wretch
would
have
married
me
by
violence
in
another
hour
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Confound
his
impudence
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
uncle
,
bestowing
a
very
contemptuous
look
on
the
dying
heir
of
Filletoville
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
As
you
may
guess
from
what
you
have
seen
,
"
said
the
young
lady
,
"
the
party
were
prepared
to
murder
me
if
I
appealed
to
any
one
for
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
If
their
accomplices
find
us
here
,
we
are
lost
.
 
<EOS>
Two
minutes
hence
may
be
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
The
mail
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
overpowered
by
her
feelings
,
and
the
exertion
of
sticking
the
young
Marquess
of
Filletoville
,
she
sank
into
my
uncle
's
arms
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
caught
her
up
,
and
bore
her
to
the
house
door
.
<EOS>
There
stood
the
mail
,
with
four
long
-
tailed
,
flowing
-
maned
,
black
horses
,
ready
harnessed
;
but
no
coachman
,
no
guard
,
no
hostler
even
,
at
the
horses
"
heads
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
I
hope
I
do
no
injustice
to
my
uncle
's
memory
,
when
I
express
my
opinion
,
that
although
he
was
a
bachelor
,
he
had
held
some
ladies
in
his
arms
before
this
time
;
I
believe
,
indeed
,
that
he
had
rather
a
habit
of
kissing
barmaids
;
and
I
know
,
that
in
one
or
two
instances
,
he
had
been
seen
by
credible
witnesses
,
to
hug
a
landlady
in
a
very
perceptible
manner
.
 
<EOS>
I
mention
the
circumstance
,
to
show
what
a
very
uncommon
sort
of
person
<EOS>
this
beautiful
young
lady
must
have
been
,
to
have
affected
my
uncle
in
the
way
she
did
;
he
used
to
say
,
that
as
her
long
dark
hair
trailed
over
his
arm
,
and
her
beautiful
dark
eyes
fixed
themselves
upon
his
face
when
she
recovered
,
he
felt
so
strange
and
nervous
that
his
legs
trembled
beneath
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
who
can
look
in
a
sweet
,
soft
pair
of
dark
eyes
,
without
feeling
queer
?
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
,
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
to
look
at
some
eyes
I
know
,
and
that
's
the
truth
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
You
will
never
leave
me
,
"
murmured
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Never
,
"
said
my
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
meant
it
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
My
dear
preserver
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
kind
,
brave
preserver
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Do
n't
,
"
said
my
uncle
,
interrupting
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
"
Why
?
"
inquired
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Because
your
mouth
looks
so
beautiful
when
you
speak
,
"
rejoined
my
uncle
,
"
that
I
'm
afraid
I
shall
be
rude
enough
to
kiss
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
young
lady
put
up
her
hand
as
if
to
caution
my
uncle
not
to
do
so
,
and
said
---
 
No
,
she
did
n't
say
anything
---
she
smiled
.
<EOS>
When
you
are
looking
at
a
pair
of
the
most
delicious
lips
in
the
world
,
and
see
them
gently
break
into
a
roguish
smile
---
if
you
are
very
near
them
,
and
nobody
else
by
---
you
can
not
better
testify
your
admiration
of
their
beautiful
form
and
colour
than
by
kissing
them
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
did
so
,
and
I
honour
him
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Hark
!
"
cried
the
young
lady
,
starting
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
noise
of
wheels
,
and
horses
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
So
it
is
,
"
said
my
uncle
,
listening
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
good
ear
for
wheels
,
and
the
trampling
of
hoofs
;
but
there
appeared
to
be
so
many
horses
and
carriages
rattling
towards
them
,
from
a
distance
,
that
it
was
impossible
to
form
a
guess
at
their
number
.
 
<EOS>
The
sound
was
like
that
of
fifty
brakes
,
with
six
blood
cattle
in
each
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
We
are
pursued
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
young
lady
,
clasping
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
pursued
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
hope
<EOS>
but
in
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
such
an
expression
of
terror
in
her
beautiful
face
,
that
my
uncle
made
up
his
mind
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
He
lifted
her
into
the
coach
,
told
her
not
to
be
frightened
,
pressed
his
lips
to
hers
once
more
,
and
then
advising
her
to
draw
up
the
window
to
keep
the
cold
air
out
,
mounted
to
the
box
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Stay
,
love
,
"
cried
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
said
my
uncle
,
from
the
coach
-
box
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
I
want
to
speak
to
you
,
"
said
the
young
lady
;
"
only
a
word
.
<EOS>
Only
one
word
,
dearest
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
Must
I
get
down
?
"
inquired
my
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
made
no
answer
,
but
she
smiled
again
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
smile
,
gentlemen
!
 
<EOS>
It
beat
the
other
one
,
all
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
My
uncle
descended
from
his
perch
in
a
twinkling
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
is
it
,
my
dear
?
"
said
my
uncle
,
looking
in
at
the
coach
window
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
happened
to
bend
forward
at
the
same
time
,
and
my
uncle
thought
she
looked
more
beautiful
than
she
had
done
yet
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
close
to
her
just
then
,
gentlemen
,
so
he
really
ought
to
know
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
What
is
it
,
my
dear
?
"
said
my
uncle
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Will
you
never
love
any
one
<EOS>
but
me
---
never
marry
any
one
beside
?
"
said
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
swore
a
great
oath
that
he
never
would
marry
anybody
else
,
and
the
young
lady
drew
in
her
head
,
and
pulled
up
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
He
jumped
upon
the
box
,
squared
his
elbows
,
adjusted
the
ribands
,
seized
the
whip
which
lay
on
the
roof
,
gave
one
flick
to
the
off
leader
,
and
away
went
the
four
long
-
tailed
,
flowing
-
maned
black
horses
,
at
fifteen
good
English
miles
an
hour
,
with
the
old
mail
-
coach
behind
them
.
 
<EOS>
Whew
!
 
<EOS>
How
they
tore
along
!
   
<EOS>
"
The
noise
behind
grew
louder
.
 
<EOS>
The
faster
the
old
mail
went
,
the
faster
came
the
pursuers
---
men
,
horses
,
dogs
,
were
leagued
in
the
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
was
frightful
,
but
,
above
all
,
rose
the
voice
of
the
young
lady
,
urging
my
uncle
on
,
and
shrieking
,
"
Faster
!
 
<EOS>
Faster
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
whirled
past
the
dark
trees
,
as
feathers
would
be
swept
before
a
hurricane
.
 
<EOS>
Houses
,
gates
,
churches
,
haystacks
,
objects
of
every
kind
they
shot
by
,
with
a
velocity
and
noise
like
roaring
waters
suddenly
let
loose
.
 
<EOS>
But
still
the
noise
of
pursuit
grew
louder
,
and
still
my
uncle
could
hear
the
young
lady
wildly
screaming
,
"
<EOS>
Faster
!
 
<EOS>
Faster
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
plied
whip
and
rein
,
and
the
horses
flew
onward
till
they
were
white
with
foam
;
and
yet
the
noise
behind
increased
;
and
yet
the
young
lady
cried
,
"
Faster
!
 
<EOS>
Faster
!
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
gave
a
loud
stamp
on
the
boot
in
the
energy
of
the
moment
,
and
---
found
that
it
was
gray
morning
,
and
he
was
sitting
in
the
wheelwright
's
yard
,
on
the
box
of
an
old
Edinburgh
mail
,
shivering
with
the
cold
and
wet
and
stamping
his
feet
to
warm
them
!
 
<EOS>
He
got
down
,
and
looked
eagerly
inside
for
the
beautiful
young
lady
.
<EOS>
Alas
!
 
<EOS>
There
was
neither
door
nor
seat
to
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
mere
shell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
my
uncle
knew
very
well
that
there
was
some
mystery
in
the
matter
,
and
that
everything
had
passed
exactly
as
he
used
to
relate
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
remained
staunch
to
the
great
oath
he
had
sworn
to
the
beautiful
young
lady
,
refusing
several
eligible
landladies
on
her
account
,
and
dying
a
bachelor
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
He
always
said
what
a
curious
thing
it
was
that
he
should
have
found
out
,
by
such
a
mere
accident
as
his
clambering
over
the
palings
,
that
the
ghosts
of
mail
-
coaches
and
horses
,
guards
,
coachmen
,
and
passengers
,
were
in
the
habit
of
making
journeys
regularly
every
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
to
add
,
that
he
believed
he
was
the
only
living
person
who
had
ever
been
taken
as
a
passenger
on
one
of
these
excursions
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
think
he
was
right
,
gentlemen
---
at
least
I
never
heard
of
any
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
what
these
ghosts
of
mail
-
coaches
carry
in
their
bags
,
"
said
the
landlord
,
who
had
listened
to
the
whole
story
with
profound
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
dead
letters
,
of
course
,
"
said
the
bagman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
ah
!
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
"
rejoined
the
landlord
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
thought
of
that
.
"
    
Chapter
50
.
<EOS>
How
Mr
Pickwick
sped
upon
his
mission
,
and
how
he
was
reinforced
in
the
outset
by
a
most
unexpected
auxiliary
 
<EOS>
The
horses
were
put
to
,
punctually
at
a
quarter
before
nine
next
morning
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
and
Sam
Weller
<EOS>
having
each
taken
his
seat
,
the
one
inside
and
the
other
out
,
the
postillion
was
duly
directed
to
repair
in
the
first
instance
to
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
's
house
,
for
the
purpose
of
taking
up
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
with
feelings
of
no
small
astonishment
,
when
the
carriage
drew
up
before
the
door
with
the
red
lamp
,
and
the
very
legible
inscription
of
"
Sawyer
,
late
Nockemorf
,
"
that
Mr
Pickwick
saw
,
on
popping
his
head
out
of
the
coach
window
,
the
boy
in
the
gray
livery
very
busily
employed
in
putting
up
the
shutters
 
---
the
which
,
being
an
unusual
and
an
unbusinesslike
proceeding
at
that
hour
of
the
morning
,
at
once
suggested
to
his
mind
two
inferences
:
the
one
,
that
some
good
friend
and
patient
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
's
was
dead
;
the
other
,
that
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
himself
was
bankrupt
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
to
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
's
the
matter
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
boy
,
expanding
his
mouth
to
the
whole
breadth
of
his
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
all
right
!
"
cried
Bob
Sawyer
,
suddenly
appearing
at
the
door
,
with
a
small
leathern
knapsack
,
limp
and
dirty
,
in
one
hand
,
and
a
rough
coat
and
shawl
thrown
over
the
other
arm
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
going
,
old
fellow
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Bob
Sawyer
,
"
and
a
regular
expedition
we
'll
make
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
Sam
!
 
<EOS>
Look
out
!
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
briefly
bespeaking
Mr
Weller
's
attention
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
jerked
the
leathern
knapsack
into
the
dickey
,
where
it
was
immediately
stowed
away
,
under
the
seat
,
by
Sam
,
who
regarded
the
proceeding
with
great
admiration
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
with
the
assistance
of
the
boy
,
forcibly
worked
himself
into
the
rough
coat
,
which
was
a
few
sizes
too
small
for
him
,
and
then
advancing
to
the
coach
window
,
thrust
in
his
head
,
and
laughed
boisterously
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
start
it
is
,
is
n't
it
?
"
cried
Bob
,
wiping
the
tears
out
of
his
eyes
,
with
one
of
the
cuffs
of
the
rough
coat
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
some

,
"
I
had
no
idea
of
your
accompanying
us
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
that
's
just
the
very
thing
,
"
replied
Bob
,
seizing
Mr
Pickwick
by
the

of
his
coat
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
joke
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
that
's
the
joke
,
is
it
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
replied
Bob
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
whole
point
of
the
thing
,
you
know
---
that
,
and
leaving
the
business
to
take
care
of
itself
,
as
it
seems
to
have
made

not
to
take

of
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this

of
the
phenomenon
of
the
shutters
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
pointed
to
the
shop
,
and
relapsed
into
an
ecstasy
of
mirth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
me
,
you
are
surely
not
mad
enough
to
think
of
leaving
your
patients
without
anybody
to
attend
them
!
"
<EOS>
remonstrated
Mr
Pickwick
in
a
very
serious
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
asked
Bob
,
in
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
save
by
it
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
None
of
them
ever
pay
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
"
said
Bob
,
lowering
his
voice
to
a
confidential

,
"
they
will
be
all
the
better
for
it
;
for
,
being
nearly
out
of
drugs
,
and
not
able
to
increase
my
account
just
now
,
I
should
have
been
obliged
to
give
them
calomel
all
round
,
and
it
would
have
been
certain
to
have
disagreed
with
some
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
's
all
for
the
best
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
philosophy
and
a
strength
of
reasoning
about
this
reply
,
which
Mr
Pickwick
was
not
prepared
for
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
a
few
moments
,
and
added
,
less
firmly
than
before
---
   
"
<EOS>
But
this
chaise
,
my
young
friend
,
will
only
hold
two
;
and
I
am
pledged
to
Mr
Allen
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
think
of
me
for
a
minute
,
"
replied
Bob
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
arranged
it
all
;
Sam
and
I
will
share
the
dickey
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
.
<EOS>
This
little
bill
is
to
be
wafered
on
the
shop
door
:
"
Sawyer
,
late
Nockemorf
.
 
<EOS>
Inquire
of
Mrs
Cripps
over
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Cripps
is
my
boy
's
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Sawyer
's
very
sorry
,
"
says
Mrs
Cripps
,
"
could
n't
help
it
---
fetched
away
early
this
morning
to
a
consultation
of
the
very
first
surgeons
in
the
country
---
could
n't
do
without
him
---
would
have
him
at
any
price
---
tremendous
operation
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
"
said
Bob
,
in

,
"
it
'll
do
me
more
good
than
otherwise
,
I
