.
 
<EOS>
If
it
gets
into
one
of
the
local
papers
,
it
will
be
the
making
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
Ben
;
now
then
,
jump
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
hurried
words
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
pushed
the
postboy
on
one
side
,
jerked
his
friend
into
the
vehicle
,
slammed
the
door
,
put
up
the
steps
,
wafered
the
bill
on
the
street
door
,
locked
it
,
put
the
key
in
his
pocket
,
jumped
into
the
dickey
,
gave
the
word
for
starting
,
and
did
the
whole
with
such
extraordinary
precipitation
,
that
before
Mr
Pickwick
had
well
begun
to
consider
whether
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
ought
to
go
or
not
,
they
were
rolling
away
,
with
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
thoroughly
established
as
part
and
parcel
of
the
equipage
.
   
<EOS>
So
long
as
their
progress
was
confined
to
the
streets
of
Bristol
,
the
facetious
Bob
kept
his
professional
green
spectacles
on
,
and
conducted
himself
with
becoming
steadiness
and
gravity
of
demeanour
;
merely
giving
utterance
to
divers
verbal
witticisms
for
the
exclusive
behoof
and
entertainment
of
Mr
Samuel
Weller
.
<EOS>
But
when
they
emerged
on
the
open
road
,
he
threw
off
his
green
spectacles
and
his
gravity
together
,
and
performed
a
great
variety
of
practical
jokes
,
which
were
calculated
to
attract
the
attention
of
the
passersby
,
and
to
render
the
carriage
and
those
it
contained
objects
of
more
than
ordinary
curiosity
;
the
least
conspicuous
among
these
feats
being
a
most
vociferous
imitation
of
a
key
-
bugle
,
and
the
ostentatious
display
of
a
crimson
silk
pocket
-
handkerchief
attached
to
a
walking
-
stick
,
which
was
occasionally
waved
in
the
air
with
various
gestures
indicative
of
supremacy
and
defiance
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
stopping
in
the
midst
of
a
most
sedate
conversation
with
Ben
Allen
,
bearing
reference
to
the
numerous
good
qualities
of
Mr
Winkle
and
his
sister
---
"
I
wonder
what
all
the
people
we
pass
,
can
see
in
us
to
make
them
stare
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
neat
turn
-
out
,
"
replied
Ben
Allen
,
with
something
of
pride
in
his
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
're
not
used
to
see
this
sort
of
thing
,
every
day
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Possibly
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
might
very
probably
have
reasoned
himself
into
the
belief
that
it
really
was
,
had
he
not
,
just
then
happening
to
look
out
of
the
coach
window
,
observed
that
the
looks
of
the
passengers
betokened
anything
but
respectful
astonishment
,
and
that
various
telegraphic
communications
appeared
to
be
passing
between
them
and
some
persons
outside
the
vehicle
,
whereupon
it
occurred
to
him
that
these
demonstrations
might
be
,
in
some
remote
degree
,
referable
to
the
humorous
deportment
of
Mr
Robert
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
that
our
volatile
friend
is
committing
no
absurdities
in
that
dickey
behind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
,
"
replied
Ben
Allen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Except
when
he
's
elevated
,
Bob
's
the
quietest
creature
breathing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
a
prolonged
imitation
of
a
key
-
bugle
broke
upon
the
ear
,
succeeded
by
cheers
and
screams
,
all
of
which
evidently
proceeded
from
the
throat
and
lungs
of
the
quietest
creature
breathing
,
or
in
plainer
designation
,
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
himself
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Ben
Allen
looked
expressively
at
each
other
,
and
the
former
gentleman
taking
off
his
hat
,
and
leaning
out
of
the
coach
window
until
nearly
the
whole
of
his
waistcoat
was
outside
it
,
was
at
length
enabled
to
catch
a
glimpse
of
his
facetious
friend
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
was
seated
,
not
in
the
dickey
,
but
on
the
roof
of
the
chaise
,
with
his
legs
as
far
asunder
as
they
would
conveniently
go
,
wearing
Mr
Samuel
Weller
's
hat
on
one
side
of
his
head
,
and
bearing
,
in
one
hand
,
a
most
enormous
sandwich
,
while
,
in
the
other
,
he
supported
a
goodly
-
sized
case
-
bottle
,
to
both
of
which
he
applied
himself
with
intense
relish
,
varying
the
monotony
of
the
occupation
by
an
occasional
howl
,
or
the
interchange
of
some
lively
badinage
with
any
passing
stranger
.
<EOS>
The
crimson
flag
was
carefully
tied
in
an
erect
position
to
the
rail
of
the
dickey
;
and
Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
decorated
with
Bob
Sawyer
's
hat
,
was
seated
in
the
centre
thereof
,
discussing
a
twin
sandwich
,
with
an
animated
countenance
,
the
expression
of
which
betokened
his
entire
and
perfect
approval
of
the
whole
arrangement
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
enough
to
irritate
a
gentleman
with
Mr
Pickwick
's
sense
of
propriety
,
but
it
was
not
the
whole
extent
of
the
aggravation
,
for
a
stage
-
coach
full
,
inside
and
out
,
was
meeting
them
at
the
moment
,
and
the
astonishment
of
the
passengers
was
very
palpably
evinced
.
 
<EOS>
The
congratulations
of
an
Irish
family
,
too
,
who
were
keeping
up
with
the
chaise
,
and
begging
all
the
time
,
were
of
rather
a
boisterous
description
,
especially
those
of
its
male
head
,
who
appeared
to
consider
the
display
as
part
and
parcel
of
some
political
or
other
procession
of
triumph
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Sawyer
!
"
cried
Mr
Pickwick
,
in
a
state
of
great
excitement
,
"
Mr
Sawyer
,
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"
responded
that
gentleman
,
looking
over
the
side
of
the
chaise
with
all
the
coolness
in
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
mad
,
sir
?
"
demanded
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
replied
Bob
;
"
only
cheerful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cheerful
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
down
that
scandalous
red
handkerchief
,
I
beg
.
 
<EOS>
I
insist
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
,
take
it
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Before
Sam
could
interpose
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
gracefully
struck
his
colours
,
and
having
put
them
in
his
pocket
,
nodded
in
a
courteous
manner
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
wiped
the
mouth
of
the
case
-
bottle
,
and
applied
it
to
his
own
,
thereby
informing
him
,
without
any
unnecessary
waste
of
words
,
that
he
devoted
that
draught
to
wishing
him
all
manner
of
happiness
and
prosperity
.
 
<EOS>
Having
done
this
,
Bob
replaced
the
cork
with
great
care
,
and
looking
benignantly
down
on
Mr
Pickwick
,
took
a
large
bite
out
of
the
sandwich
,
and
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
whose
momentary
anger
was
not
quite
proof
against
Bob
's
immovable
self
-
possession
,
"
pray
let
us
have
no
more
of
this
absurdity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
Bob
,
once
more
exchanging
hats
with
Mr
Weller
;
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
do
it
,
only
I
got
so
enlivened
with
the
ride
that
I
could
n't
help
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
of
the
look
of
the
thing
,
"
expostulated
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
have
some
regard
to
appearances
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
,
"
said
Bob
,
"
it
's
not
the
sort
of
thing
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
All
over
,
governor
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Satisfied
with
this
assurance
,
Mr
Pickwick
once
more
drew
his
head
into
the
chaise
and
pulled
up
the
glass
;
but
he
had
scarcely
resumed
the
conversation
which
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
had
interrupted
,
when
he
was
somewhat
startled
by
the
apparition
of
a
small
dark
body
,
of
an
oblong
form
,
on
the
outside
of
the
window
,
which
gave
sundry
taps
against
it
,
as
if
impatient
of
admission
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
this
?
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
looks
like
a
case
-
bottle
;
"
remarked
Ben
Allen
,
eyeing
the
object
in
question
through
his
spectacles
with
some
interest
;
"
I
rather
think
it
belongs
to
Bob
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
impression
was
perfectly
accurate
;
for
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
having
attached
the
case
-
bottle
to
the
end
of
the
walking
-
stick
,
was
battering
the
window
with
it
,
in
token
of
his
wish
,
that
his
friends
inside
would
partake
of
its
contents
,
in
all
good
-
fellowship
and
harmony
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
to
be
done
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
at
the
bottle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
proceeding
is
more
absurd
than
the
other
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
would
be
best
to
take
it
in
,
"
replied
Mr
Ben
Allen
;
"
it
would
serve
him
right
to
take
it
in
and
keep
it
,
would
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
shall
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
the
most
proper
course
<EOS>
we
could
possibly
adopt
,
"
replied
Ben
.
   
<EOS>
This
advice
quite
coinciding
with
his
own
opinion
,
Mr
Pickwick
gently
let
down
the
window
and
disengaged
the
bottle
from
the
stick
;
upon
which
the
latter
was
drawn
up
,
and
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
was
heard
to
laugh
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
merry
dog
it
is
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
round
at
his
companion
,
with
the
bottle
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
"
said
Mr
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
possibly
be
angry
with
him
,
"
remarked
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
out
of
the
question
,
"
observed
Benjamin
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
During
this
short
interchange
of
sentiments
,
Mr
Pickwick
had
,
in
an
abstracted
mood
,
uncorked
the
bottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Ben
Allen
carelessly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
equal
carelessness
.
<EOS>
"
It
smells
,
I
think
,
like
milk
-
punch
.
"
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
indeed
?
"
said
Ben
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
THINK
so
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
,
very
properly
guarding
himself
against
the
possibility
of
stating
an
untruth
;
"
mind
,
I
could
not
undertake
to
say
certainly
,
without
tasting
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
do
so
,
"
said
Ben
;
"
we
may
as
well
know
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
so
?
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
;
if
you
are
curious
to
know
,
of
course
I
have
no
objection
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ever
willing
to
sacrifice
his
own
feelings
to
the
wishes
of
his
friend
,
Mr
Pickwick
at
once
took
a
pretty
long
taste
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Ben
Allen
,
interrupting
him
with
some
impatience
.
   
<EOS>
"
Curious
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
smacking
his
lips
,
"
I
hardly
know
,
now
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
after
a
second
taste
.
<EOS>
"
It
IS
punch
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Ben
Allen
looked
at
Mr
Pickwick
;
Mr
Pickwick
looked
at
Mr
Ben
Allen
;
Mr
Ben
Allen
smiled
;
Mr
Pickwick
did
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
serve
him
right
,
"
said
the
last
-
named
gentleman
,
with
some
severity
---
"
it
would
serve
him
right
to
drink
it
every
drop
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
very
thing
that
occurred
to
me
,
"
said
Ben
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
indeed
?
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
here
's
his
health
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
that
excellent
person
took
a
most
energetic
pull
at
the
bottle
,
and
handed
it
to
Ben
Allen
,
who
was
not
slow
to
imitate
his
example
.
 
<EOS>
The
smiles
became
mutual
,
and
the
milk
-
punch
was
gradually
and
cheerfully
disposed
of
.
   
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
drained
the
last
drop
,
"
his
pranks
are
really
very
amusing
;
very
entertaining
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
say
that
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Ben
Allen
.
 
<EOS>
In
proof
of
Bob
Sawyer
's
being
<EOS>
one
of
the
funniest
fellows
alive
,
he
proceeded
to
entertain
Mr
Pickwick
with
a
long
and
circumstantial
account
how
that
gentleman
once
drank
himself
into
a
fever
and
got
his
head
shaved
;
the
relation
of
which
pleasant
and
agreeable
history
was
only
stopped
by
the
stoppage
of
the
chaise
at
the
Bell
at
Berkeley
Heath
,
to
change
horses
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
We
're
going
to
dine
here
,
are
n't
we
?
"
<EOS>
said
Bob
,
looking
in
at
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dine
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
we
have
only
come
nineteen
miles
,
and
have
eighty
-
seven
and
a
half
to
go
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
the
reason
why
we
should
take
something
to
enable
us
to
bear
up
against
the
fatigue
,
"
remonstrated
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
quite
impossible
to
dine
at
half
-
past
eleven
o'clock
in
the
day
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
at
his
watch
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
it
is
,
"
rejoined
Bob
,
"
lunch
is
the
very
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Hollo
,
you
sir
!
<EOS>
Lunch
for
three
,
directly
;
and
keep
the
horses
back
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
them
to
put
everything
they
have
cold
,
on
the
table
,
and
some
bottled
ale
,
and
let
us
taste
your
very
best
Madeira
.
"
 
<EOS>
Issuing
these
orders
with
monstrous
importance
and
bustle
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
at
once
hurried
into
the
house
to
superintend
the
arrangements
;
in
less
than
five
minutes
he
returned
and
declared
them
to
be
excellent
.
   
<EOS>
The
quality
of
the
lunch
fully
justified
the
eulogium
which
Bob
had
pronounced
,
and
very
great
justice
was
done
to
it
,
not
only
by
that
gentleman
,
but
Mr
Ben
Allen
and
Mr
Pickwick
also
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
auspices
of
the
three
,
the
bottled
ale
and
the
Madeira
were
promptly
disposed
of
;
and
when
(
the
horses
being
once
more
put
to
)
<EOS>
they
resumed
their
seats
,
with
the
case
-
bottle
full
of
the
best
substitute
for
milk
-
punch
that
could
be
procured
on
so
short
a
notice
,
the
key
-
bugle
sounded
,
and
the
red
flag
waved
,
without
the
slightest
opposition
on
Mr
Pickwick
's
part
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
Hop
Pole
at
Tewkesbury
,
they
stopped
to
dine
;
upon
which
occasion
there
was
more
bottled
ale
,
with
some
more
Madeira
,
and
some
port
besides
;
and
here
the
case
-
bottle
was
replenished
for
the
fourth
time
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
influence
of
these
combined
stimulants
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Mr
Ben
Allen
fell
fast
asleep
for
thirty
miles
,
while
Bob
and
Mr
Weller
sang
duets
in
the
dickey
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
quite
dark
when
Mr
Pickwick
roused
himself
sufficiently
to
look
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
The
straggling
cottages
by
the
road
-
side
,
the
dingy
hue
of
every
object
visible
,
the
murky
atmosphere
,
the
paths
of
cinders
and
brick
-
dust
,
the
deep
-
red
glow
of
furnace
fires
in
the
distance
,
the
volumes
of
dense
smoke
issuing
heavily
forth
from
high
toppling
chimneys
,
blackening
and
obscuring
everything
around
;
the
glare
of
distant
lights
,
the
ponderous
wagons
which
toiled
along
the
road
,
laden
with
clashing
rods
of
iron
,
or
piled
with
heavy
goods
---
all
betokened
their
rapid
approach
to
the
great
working
town
of
Birmingham
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
rattled
through
the
narrow
thoroughfares
leading
to
the
heart
of
the
turmoil
,
the
sights
and
sounds
of
earnest
occupation
struck
more
forcibly
on
the
senses
.
 
<EOS>
The
streets
were
thronged
with
working
people
.
 
<EOS>
The
hum
of
labour
resounded
from
every
house
;
lights
gleamed
from
the
long
casement
windows
in
the
attic
storeys
,
and
the
whirl
of
wheels
and
noise
of
machinery
shook
the
trembling
walls
.
 
<EOS>
The
fires
,
whose
lurid
,
sullen
light
had
been
visible
for
miles
,
blazed
fiercely
up
,
in
the
great
works
and
factories
of
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
The
din
of
hammers
,
the
rushing
of
steam
,
and
the
dead
heavy
clanking
of
engines
,
was
the
harsh
music
which
arose
from
every
quarter
.
<EOS>
The
postboy
was
driving
briskly
through
the
open
streets
,
and
past
the
handsome
and
well
-
lighted
shops
that
intervene
between
the
outskirts
of
the
town
and
the
Old
Royal
Hotel
,
before
Mr
Pickwick
had
begun
to
consider
the
very
difficult
and
delicate
nature
of
the
commission
which
had
carried
him
thither
.
   
<EOS>
The
delicate
nature
of
this
commission
,
and
the
difficulty
of
executing
it
in
a
satisfactory
manner
,
were
by
no
means
lessened
by
the
voluntary
companionship
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
.
 
<EOS>
Truth
to
tell
<EOS>
,
Mr
Pickwick
felt
that
his
presence
on
the
occasion
,
however
considerate
and
gratifying
,
was
by
no
means
an
honour
he
would
willingly
have
sought
;
in
fact
,
he
would
cheerfully
have
given
a
reasonable
sum
of
money
to
have
had
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
removed
to
any
place
at
not
less
than
fifty
miles
"
distance
,
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
never
held
any
personal
communication
with
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
,
although
he
had
once
or
twice
corresponded
with
him
by
letter
,
and
returned
satisfactory
answers
to
his
inquiries
concerning
the
moral
character
and
behaviour
of
his
son
;
he
felt
nervously
sensible
that
to
wait
upon
him
,
for
the
first
time
,
attended
by
Bob
Sawyer
and
Ben
Allen
,
both
slightly
fuddled
,
was
not
the
most
ingenious
and
likely
means
that
could
have
been
hit
upon
to
prepossess
him
in
his
favour
.
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
endeavouring
to
reassure
himself
,
"
I
must
do
the
best
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
see
him
to
-
night
,
for
I
faithfully
promised
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
persist
in
accompanying
me
,
I
must
make
the
interview
as
brief
as
possible
,
and
be
content
that
,
for
their
own
sakes
,
they
will
not
expose
themselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
comforted

with

,

stopped
at

door

the
Old
Royal
.
 
<EOS>
Ben
Allen
having

,
and

Mr
Samuel
Weller
,
Mr

was

.
 
<EOS>
They

to
a
comfortable

,
and

Mr
Winkle
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Close
by
,
Sir
,
"

"
not

,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
is
a
wharfinger
,
Sir
,
at

.
 
<EOS>
Private

is
not
---
oh

,
no
,

,
not
five

,

.
<EOS>
"
Here

,

,

<EOS>
"
Take

,

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Tea

,

?
<EOS>
Dinner
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

.
 
<EOS>
Like

,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Very
good
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
,

to

,
and
then

,

<EOS>
"

"
   
"

"

<EOS>
"
If
YOU

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Soda
-

,
Sir
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
his

apparently

from
an

weight
,
by
having
at
last
got
an
order
for
something
,
the

.
 
<EOS>
Waiters
never
walk
or
run
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
a
peculiar
and
mysterious
power
of
skimming
out
of
rooms
,
which
other
mortals
possess
not
.
   
<EOS>
Some

Mr

Allen
by

,

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

and
Bob

in

,

started
forth
,
arm

,
to
Mr
Winkle
's
;
Bob

.
   
<EOS>
About

,

,

,

,

,
"
Mr
Winkle
.
<EOS>
"
The
steps
were
very
white
,
and
the

were
very
red
,
and

was
very

;
and

Mr
Pickwick
,
Mr

Allen
,

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
A
smart

-
girl
answered

,
and
started
on
beholding

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Winkle
at

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Give

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Say
I

;
but
I

-

,

.
<EOS>
"
The
girl
looked

Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
who
was
expressing

of
her

by
a

;
and
casting

and

which
hung

,
called
another
girl
to

.
 
<EOS>
The
sentinel
was
speedily
relieved
;
for
the
girl
returned
immediately
,
and
begging
pardon
of
the
gentlemen
for

in
the
street
,
ushered

into
a
floor
-

,
half

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Over

of
an

,
while
a

for

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very

to

at
the

,
Sir
,
"

girl
,

,

,
"
but
you
was

strangers

;

,

---
"

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

,

,

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

"
odous
creetur
;
"

,

,

,
and

with

and

.
   
<EOS>
Deprived
of
the
young

's

,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
proceeded

by

,

all
the

,

,

the

,

of
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
,
over

,
and
making

other

upon

,
all

which
afforded
Mr
Pickwick
unspeakable

and

,

yielded
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
proportionate

.
   
<EOS>
At
length

door
opened
,
and
a

in

,
with

face
the

,

,

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,

,

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hope
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

,

's

Mr

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly

that
he
was
in
the
presence
of
a
stranger
<EOS>
,
Mr
Ben
Allen
advanced
and
,
shaking
Mr
Winkle
most
affectionately
by

hands
for
about
five

,
murmured
,
in
some
half
-
intelligible
fragments
of

,
the
great
delight
he
felt
in
seeing
him
,
and
a
hospitable
inquiry
whether
he
felt
disposed
to
take
anything
after

,
or
would

"
till
dinner
-
time
;
"
which

,
he

and
gazed

with

,
as
if
he
had
not
the
remotest
idea
where
he
was
,
which
indeed
he
had
not
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
was
most
embarrassing
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
the
more
especially
as
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
,
evinced

at
the

---
not
to
say
extraordinary
---
behaviour
of
his
two

.
 
<EOS>
To
bring
the
matter
to
an
issue

,
he

letter

,
and
presenting

to
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
,
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
This
letter
,
Sir
,
is
from
your
son
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
see
,
by
its
contents
,
that
on
your
favourable
and
fatherly

of
it
,
depend
his
future
happiness
and
welfare
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
oblige
me
by
giving

the

and

,
and
by
discussing
the
subject
afterwards
with
me
,
in
the
tone
and
spirit
in
which
alone
it
ought
to
be

?
 
<EOS>
You
may
judge
of
the
importance
of

to
your
son
,
and
his

upon
the
subject
,
by
my

upon

,
without
any

,
at
so
late
an
hour
;
<EOS>
and
,
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
,
glancing
slightly

---
"
and
under
such

circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
this

,
Mr
Pickwick
placed
four
closely
-
written
sides
of
extra
superfine
wire
-
wove
penitence
in
the
hands
of
the
astounded
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
.
 
<EOS>
Then
reseating
himself
in
his
chair
,
he
watched
his
looks
and
manner
:
anxiously
,
it
is
true
,
but
with
the
open
front
of
a
gentleman
who
feels
he
has
taken
no
part
which
he
need

or

.
<EOS>
The
old
wharfinger
turned
the
letter
over
,
looked
at
the
front
,
back
,
and
sides
,
made
a
microscopic
examination
of
the
fat
little
boy
on
the
seal
,
raised
his
eyes
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
face
,
and
then
,
seating
himself
on
the
high
stool
,
and
drawing
the
lamp
closer
to
him
,
broke
the
wax
,
unfolded
the
epistle
,
and
lifting
it
to
the
light
,
prepared
to
read
.
<EOS>
Just
at
this
moment
,
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
whose
wit
had
lain
dormant
for
some
minutes
,
placed
his
hands
on
his
knees
,
and
made
a
face
after
the
portraits
of
the
late
Mr
Grimaldi
,
as
clown
.
<EOS>
It
so
happened
that
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
,
instead
of
being
deeply
engaged
in
reading
the
letter
,
as
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
thought
,
chanced
to
be
looking
over
the
top

at
no
less
a
person
than
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
himself
;
rightly

that
the
face
aforesaid
was
made
in

and
derision
of
his
own
person
,
he
fixed
his

on
Bob
with
such

,
that
the
late
Mr
Grimaldi
's
lineaments
gradually
resolved
themselves
into
a
very
fine
expression
of
humility
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
speak
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
Mr
Winkle
,
senior
,
after

for
there
ai
n't
a
man

either

a
-

"
   
<EOS>

Sam

the
time
until

Dunchurch
,
where
a

and
fresh

were

;
the
next
stage
was
Daventry
,
and
the
next
Towcester
;
and
at
the
end
of
each
stage
it
rained
harder
than
it
had
done
at
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
remonstrated
Bob
Sawyer
,
looking
in

,
"
this
wo

,

"
   
"

!
"

,

"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes

,

that

,
Uncomfortably

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Bob

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
AM

"

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Out

,

,
"

,

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
There
's

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
In
ten
minutes
"
time
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Sam

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
<EOS>
"

,
"
I

!
 
<EOS>
Eatansvill

,

<EOS>

,

,

;

,

GAZETTE
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beggin

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

"
It

!
"
<EOS>

's

"
blue
?
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

's

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

Eatanswill
?
"
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Is

<EOS>

The

,

"

<EOS>
Abhorred

<EOS>
,

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
He
CRAMMED

<EOS>
"
He

<EOS>

,

!

<EOS>
Mr

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

,

"
my
country
's
good
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
supposed
it
was
some
public
mission
,
"
observed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"
resumed
Pott
,
"
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
,
bending
towards
Mr
Pickwick
,
he
whispered
in
a
deep
,
hollow
voice
,
"
A
Buff
ball
,
Sir
,
will
take
place
in
Birmingham
to
-
morrow
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Sir
,
and
supper
,
"
added
Pott
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Pott
nodded
portentously
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
although
Mr
Pickwick
feigned
to
stand
aghast
at
this
disclosure
,
he
was
so
little
versed
in
local
politics
that
he
was
unable
to
form
an
adequate
comprehension
of
the
importance
of
the
dire
conspiracy
it
referred
to
;
observing
which
,
Mr
Pott
,
drawing
forth
the
last
number
of
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,
and
referring
to
the
same
,
delivered
himself
of
the
following
paragraph
:
---
          
HOLE
-
AND
-
CORNER
BUFFERY
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
reptile
contemporary
has
recently
sweltered
forth
his
black
venom
in
the
vain
and
hopeless
attempt
of
sullying
the
fair
name
of
our
distinguished
and
excellent
representative
,
the
Honourable
Mr
Slumkey
---
that
Slumkey
whom
we
,
long
before
he
gained
his
present
noble
and
exalted
position
,
predicted
would
one
day
be
,
as
he
now
is
,
at
once
his
country
's
brightest
honour
,
and
her
proudest
boast
:
alike
her
bold
defender
and
her
honest
pride
---
our
reptile
contemporary
,
we
say
,
has
made
himself
merry
,
at
the
expense
of
a
superbly
embossed
plated
coal
-
scuttle
,
which
has
been
presented
to
that
glorious
man
by
his
enraptured
constituents
,
and
towards
the
purchase
of
which
,
the
nameless
wretch
insinuates
,
the
Honourable
Mr
Slumkey
himself
contributed
,
through
a
confidential
friend
of
his
butler
's
,
more
than
three
-
fourths
of
the
whole
sum
subscribed
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
does
not
the
crawling
creature
see
,
that
even
if
this
be
the
fact
,
the
Honourable
Mr
Slumkey
only
appears
in
a
still
more
amiable
and
radiant
light
than
before
,
if
that
be
possible
?
 
<EOS>
Does
not
even
his
obtuseness
perceive
that
this
amiable
and
touching
desire
to
carry
out
the
wishes
of
the
constituent
body
,
must
for
ever
endear
him
to
the
hearts
and
souls
of
such
of
his
fellow
townsmen
as
are
not
worse
than
swine
;
or
,
in
other
words
,
who
are
not
as
debased
as
our
contemporary
himself
?
 
<EOS>
But
such
is
the
wretched
trickery
of
hole
-
and
-
corner
Buffery
!
 
<EOS>
These
are
not
its
only
artifices
.
 
<EOS>
Treason
is
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
We
boldly
state
,
now
that
we
are
goaded
to
the
disclosure
,
and
we
throw
ourselves
on
the
country
and
its
constables
for
protection
<EOS>
---
we
boldly
state
that
secret
preparations
are
at
this
moment
in
progress
for
a
Buff
ball
;
which
is
to
be
held
in
a
Buff
town
,
in
the
very
heart
and
centre
of
a
Buff
population
;
which
is
to
be
conducted
by
a
Buff
master
of
the
ceremonies
;
which
is
to
be
attended
by
four
ultra
Buff
members
of
Parliament
,
and
the
admission
to
which
,
is
to
be
by
Buff
tickets
!
 
<EOS>
Does
our
fiendish
contemporary
wince
?
 
<EOS>
Let
him
writhe
,
in
impotent
malice
,
as
we
pen
the
words
,
WE
WILL
BE
THERE
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
Sir
,
"
said
Pott
,
folding
up
the
paper
quite
exhausted
,
"
that
is
the
state
of
the
case
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
and
waiter
entering
at
the
moment
with
dinner
,
caused
Mr
Pott
to
lay
his
finger
on
his
lips
,
in
token
that
he
considered
his
life
in
Mr
Pickwick
's
hands
,
and
depended
on
his
secrecy
.
 
<EOS>
Messrs.
Bob
Sawyer
and
Benjamin
Allen
,
who
had
irreverently
fallen
asleep
during
the
reading
of
the
quotation
from
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
,
and
the
discussion
which
followed
it
,
were
roused
by
the
mere
whispering
of
the
talismanic
word
"
Dinner
"
in
their
ears
;
and
to
dinner
they
went
with
good
digestion
waiting
on
appetite
,
and
health
on
both
,
and
a
waiter
on
all
three
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
dinner
and
the
sitting
which
succeeded
it
,
Mr
Pott
descending
,
for
a
few
moments
,
to
domestic
topics
,
informed
Mr
Pickwick
that
the
air
of
Eatanswill
not
agreeing
with
his
lady
,
she
was
then
engaged
in
making
a
tour
of
different
fashionable
watering
-
places
with
a
view
to
the
recovery
of
her
wonted
health
and
spirits
;
this
was
a
delicate
veiling
of
the
fact
that
Mrs
Pott
,
acting
upon
her
often
-
repeated
threat
of
separation
,
had
,
in
virtue
of
an
arrangement
negotiated
by
her
brother
,
the
lieutenant
,
and
concluded
by
Mr
Pott
,
permanently
retired
with
the
faithful
bodyguard
upon
one
moiety
or
half
part
of
the
annual
income
and
profits
arising
from
the
editorship
and
sale
of
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.
   
<EOS>
While
the
great
Mr
Pott
was
dwelling
upon
this
and
other
matters
,
enlivening
the
conversation
from
time
to
time
with
various
extracts
from
his
own
lucubrations
,
a
stern
stranger
,
calling
from
the
window
of
a
stage
-
coach
,
outward
bound
,
which
halted
at
the
inn
to
deliver
packages
,
requested
to
know
whether
if
he
stopped
short
on
his
journey
and
remained
there
for
the
night
,
he
could
be
furnished
with
the
necessary
accommodation
of
a
bed
and
bedstead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
landlord
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
can
I
?
"
inquired
the
stranger
,
who
seemed
habitually
suspicious
in
look
and
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
of
it
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
landlord
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Coachman
,
I
get
down
here
.
<EOS>
Guard
,
my
carpet
-
bag
!
"
   
<EOS>
Bidding
the
other
passengers
good
-
night
,
in
a
rather
snappish
manner
,
the
stranger
alighted
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
shortish
gentleman
,
with
very
stiff
black
hair
cut
in
the
porcupine
or
blacking
-
brush
style
,
and
standing
stiff
and
straight
all
over
his
head
;
his
aspect
was
pompous
and
threatening
;
his
manner
was
peremptory
;
his
eyes
were
sharp
and
restless
;
and
his
whole
bearing
bespoke
a
feeling
of
great
confidence
in
himself
,
and
a
consciousness
of
immeasurable
superiority
over
all
other
people
.
   
<EOS>
This
gentleman
was
shown
into
the
room
originally
assigned
to
the
patriotic
Mr
Pott
;
and
the
waiter
remarked
,
in
dumb
astonishment
at
the
singular
coincidence
,
that
he
had
no
sooner
lighted
the
candles
than
the
gentleman
,
diving
into
his
hat
,
drew
forth
a
newspaper
,
and
began
to
read
it
with
the
very
same
expression
of
indignant
scorn
,
which
,
upon
the
majestic
features
of
Pott
,
had
paralysed
his
energies
an
hour
before
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
observed
too
,
that
,
whereas
Mr
Pott
's
scorn
had
been
roused
by
a
newspaper
headed
the
Eatanswill
INDEPENDENT
,
this
gentleman
's
withering
contempt
was
awakened
by
a
newspaper
entitled
the
Eatanswill
GAZETTE
.
   
<EOS>
"
Send
the
landlord
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
was
sent
,
and
came
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
the
landlord
?
"
inquired
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sir
,
"
replied
the
landlord
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Slurk
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
slightly
inclined
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Slurk
,
sir
,
"
repeated
the
gentleman
haughtily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
me
now
,
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
scratched
his
head
,
looked
at
the
ceiling
,
and
at
the
stranger
,
and
smiled
feebly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
me
,
man
?
"
inquired
the
stranger
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
made
a
strong
effort
,
and
at
length
replied
,
   
"
Well
,
Sir
,
I
do
not
know
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Great
Heaven
!
"
said
the
stranger
,
dashing
his
clenched
fist
upon
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
this
is
popularity
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
took
a
step
or
two
towards
the
door
;
the
stranger
fixing
his
eyes
upon
him
,
resumed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
,
"
said
the
stranger
---
"
this
is
gratitude
for
years
of
labour
and
study
in
behalf
of
the
masses
.
 
<EOS>
I
alight
wet
and
weary
;
no
enthusiastic
crowds
press
forward
to
greet
their
champion
<EOS>
;
the
church
bells
are
silent
;
the
very
name
elicits
no
responsive
feeling
in
their
torpid
bosoms
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
,
"
said
the
agitated
Mr
Slurk
,
pacing
to
and
fro
,
"
to
curdle
the
ink
in
one
's
pen
,
and
induce
one
to
abandon
their
cause
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
say
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
landlord
,
venturing
a
hint
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rum
,
"
said
Mr
Slurk
,
turning
fiercely
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
a
fire
anywhere
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
can
light
one
directly
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
landlord
.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
will
throw
out
no
heat
until
it
is
bed
-
time
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Slurk
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anybody
in
the
kitchen
?
"
   
<EOS>
Not
a
soul
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
beautiful
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
had
gone
,
and
the
house
door
was
closed
for
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
drink
my
rum
-
and
-
water
,
"
said
Mr
Slurk
,
"
by
the
kitchen
fire
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
,
gathering
up
his
hat
and
newspaper
,
he
stalked
solemnly
behind
the
landlord
to
that
humble
apartment
,
and
throwing
himself
on
a
settle
by
the
fireside
,
resumed
his
countenance
of
scorn
,
and
began
to
read
and
drink
in
silent
dignity
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
some
demon
of
discord
,
flying
over
the
Saracen
's
Head
at
that
moment
,
on
casting
down
his
eyes
in
mere
idle
curiosity
,
happened
to
behold
Slurk
established
comfortably
by
the
kitchen
fire
,
and
Pott
slightly
elevated
with
wine
in
another
room
;
upon
which
the
malicious
demon
,
darting
down
into
the
last
-
mentioned
apartment
with
inconceivable
rapidity
,
passed
at
once
into
the
head
of
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
and
prompted
him
for
his
(
the
demon
's
)
own
evil
purpose
to
speak
as
follows
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
we
've
let
the
fire
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
uncommonly
cold
after
the
rain
,
is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
really
is
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
shivering
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
n't
be
a
bad
notion
to
have
a
cigar
by
the
kitchen
fire
,
would
it
?
"
said
Bob
Sawyer
,
still
prompted
by
the
demon
aforesaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
particularly
comfortable
,
I
think
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pott
,
what
do
you
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pott
yielded
a
ready
assent
;
and
all
four
travellers
,
each
with
his
glass
in
his
hand
,
at
once
betook
themselves
to
the
kitchen
,
with
Sam
Weller
heading
the
procession
to
show
them
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
still
reading
;
he
looked
up
and
started
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pott
started
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
reptile
!
"
replied
Pott
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
reptile
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
about
him
for
fear
he
should
tread
on
some
overgrown
black
beetle
,
or
dropsical
spider
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
reptile
,
"
whispered
Pott
,
catching
Mr
Pickwick
by
the
arm
,
and
pointing
towards
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
reptile
Slurk
,
of
the
INDEPENDENT
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
we
had
better
retire
,
"
whispered
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
Pott
,
pot
-
valiant
in
a
double
sense
---
"
never
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Mr
Pott
took
up
his
position
on
an
opposite
settle
,
and
selecting
one
from
a
little
bundle
of
newspapers
,
began
to
read
against
his
enemy
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pott
,
of
course
read
the
INDEPENDENT
,
and
Mr
Slurk
,
of
course
,
read
the
GAZETTE
;
and
each
gentleman
audibly
expressed
his
contempt
at
the
other
's
compositions
by
bitter
laughs
and
sarcastic
sniffs
;
whence
they
proceeded
to
more
open
expressions
of
opinion
,
such
as
"
absurd
,
"
"
wretched
,
"
"
atrocity
,
"
"
humbug
,
"
"
knavery
,
"
"
dirt
,
"
"
filth
,
"
"
slime
,
"
"
ditch
-
water
,
"
and
other
critical
remarks
of
the
like
nature
.
   
<EOS>
Both
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
and
Mr
Ben
Allen
had
beheld
these
symptoms
of
rivalry
and
hatred
,
with
a
degree
of
delight
which
imparted
great
additional
relish
to
the
cigars
at
which
they
were
puffing
most
vigorously
.
 
<EOS>
The
moment
they
began
to
flag
,
the
mischievous
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
addressing
Slurk
with
great
politeness
,
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
look
at
your
paper
,
Sir
,
when
you
have

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
<EOS>

<EOS>
Uttering

<EOS>
Whether

,

)

,
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

---
on

.
   
<EOS>
They

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
52
.
<EOS>

,

Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

;

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

"

;
"

,
you
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
Heaving
a
long
-
drawn
sigh
,
Mr
Stiggins
paused
for
a
response
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
nodded
,
and
Mr
Weller
the
elder
gave
vent
to
an
extraordinary
sound
,
which
,
being
neither
a
groan
,
nor
a
grunt
,
nor
a
gasp
,
nor
a
growl
,
seemed
to
partake
in
some
degree
of
the
character
of
all
four
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Stiggins
,
encouraged
by
this
sound
,
which
he
understood
to
betoken
remorse
or
repentance
,
looked
about
him
,
rubbed
his
hands
,
wept
,
smiled
,
wept
again
,
and
then
,
walking
softly
across
the
room
to
a
well
-
remembered
shelf
in
one
corner
,
took
down
a
tumbler
,
and
with
great
deliberation
put
four
lumps
of
sugar
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Having
got
thus
far
,
he
looked
about
him
again
,
and
sighed
grievously
;
with
that
,
he
walked
softly
into
the
bar
,
and
presently
returning
with
the
tumbler
half
full
of
pine
-
apple
rum
,
advanced
to
the
kettle
which
was
singing
gaily
on
the
hob
,
mixed
his
grog
,
stirred
it
,
sipped
it
,
sat
down
,
and
taking
a
long
and
hearty
pull
at
the
rum
-
and
-
water
,
stopped
for
breath
.
   
<EOS>
The
elder
Mr
Weller
,
who
still
continued
to
make
various
strange
and
uncouth
attempts
to
appear
asleep
,
offered
not
a
single
word
during
these
proceedings
;
but
when
Stiggins
stopped
for
breath
,
he
darted
upon
him
,
and
snatching
the
tumbler
from
his
hand
,
threw
the
remainder
of
the
rum
-
and
-
water
in
his
face
,
and
the
glass
itself
into
the
grate
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
seizing
the
reverend
gentleman
firmly
by
the
collar
,
he
suddenly
fell
to
kicking
him
most
furiously
,
accompanying
every
application
of
his
top
-
boot
to
Mr
Stiggins
's
person
,
with
sundry
violent
and
incoherent
anathemas
upon
his
limbs
,
eyes
,
and
body
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sammy
,
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
"
put
my
hat
on
tight
for
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sam
dutifully
adjusted
the
hat
with
the
long
hatband
more
firmly
on
his
father
's
head
,
and
the
old
gentleman
,
resuming
his
kicking
with
greater
agility
than
before
,
tumbled
with
Mr
Stiggins
through
the
bar
,
and
through
the
passage
,
out
at
the
front
door
,
and
so
into
the
street
---
the
kicking
continuing
the
whole
way
,
and
increasing
in
vehemence
,
rather
than
diminishing
,
every
time
the
top
-
boot
was
lifted
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautiful
and
exhilarating
sight
to
see
the
red
-
nosed
man
writhing
in
Mr
Weller
's
grasp
,
and
his
whole
frame
quivering
with
anguish
as
kick
followed
kick
in
rapid
succession
;
it
was
a
still
more
exciting
spectacle
to
behold
Mr
Weller
,
after
a
powerful
struggle
,
immersing
Mr
Stiggins
's
head
in
a
horse
-
trough
full
of
water
,
and
holding
it
there
,
until
he
was
half
suffocated
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
throwing
all
his
energy
into
one
most
complicated
kick
,
as
he
at
length
permitted
Mr
Stiggins
to
withdraw
his
head
from
the
trough
,
"
send
any
vun
o
'
<EOS>
them
lazy
shepherds
here
,
and
<EOS>
I
'll
pound
him
to
a
jelly
first
,
and
drownd
him
artervards
!
 
<EOS>
Sammy
,
help
me
in
,
and
fill
me
a
small
glass
of
brandy
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
out
o
'
breath
,
my
boy
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
53
.
<EOS>
Comprising
the
final
exit
of
Mr
Jingle
and
job
trotter
,
with
a
great
morning
of
business
in
Gray
's
Inn
Square
---
concluding
with
a
double
knock
at
Mr
Perker
's
door
 
<EOS>
When
Arabella
,
after
some
gentle
preparation
and
many
assurances
that
there
was
not
the
least
occasion
for
being
low
-
spirited
,
was
at
length
made
acquainted
by
Mr
Pickwick
with
the
unsatisfactory
result
of
his
visit
to
Birmingham
,
she
burst
into
tears
,
and
sobbing
aloud
,
lamented
in
moving
terms
that
she
should
have
been
the
unhappy
cause
of
any
estrangement
between
a
father
and
his
son
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
kindly
,
"
it
is
no
fault
of
yours
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
foresee
that
the
old
gentleman
would
be
so
strongly
prepossessed
against
his
son
's
marriage
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
,
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
,
glancing
at
her
pretty
face
,
"
he
can
have
very
little
idea
of
the
pleasure
he
denies
himself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Arabella
,
"
what
shall
we
do
,
if
he
continues
to
be
angry
with
us
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
wait
patiently
,
my
dear
,
until
he
thinks
better
of
it
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
cheerfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
dear
Mr
Pickwick
,
what
is
to
become
of
Nathaniel
if
his
father
withdraws
his
assistance
?
"
urged
Arabella
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
,
my
love
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
I
will
venture
to
prophesy
that
he
will
find
some
other
friend
who
will
not
be
backward
in
helping
him
to
start
in
the
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
significance
of
this
reply
was
not
so
well
disguised
by
Mr
Pickwick
but
that
Arabella
understood
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
throwing
her
arms
round
his
neck
,
and
kissing
him
affectionately
<EOS>
,
she
sobbed
louder
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
taking
her
hand
,
"
we
will
wait
here
a
few
days
longer
,
and
see
whether
he
writes
or
takes
any
other
notice
of
your
husband
's
communication
.
 
<EOS>
If
not
,
I
have
thought
of
half
a
dozen
plans
,
any
one
of
which
would
make
you
happy
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
my
dear
,
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Mr
Pickwick
gently
pressed
Arabella
's
hand
,
and
bade
her
dry
<EOS>
her
eyes
,
and
not
distress
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
Arabella
,
who
was
one
of
the
best
little
creatures
alive
,
put
her
handkerchief
in
her
reticule
,
and
by
the
time
Mr
Winkle
joined
them
,
exhibited
in
full
lustre
the
same
beaming
smiles
and
sparkling
eyes
that
had
originally
captivated
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
distressing
predicament
for
these
young
people
,
"
thought
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
dressed
himself
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
walk
up
to
Perker
's
,
and
consult
him
about
the
matter
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pickwick
was
further
prompted
to
betake
himself
to
Gray
's
Inn
Square
by
an
anxious
desire
to
come
to
a
pecuniary
settlement
with
the
kind
-
hearted
little
attorney
without
further
delay
,
he
made
a
hurried
breakfast
,
and
executed
his
intention
so
speedily
,
that
ten
o'clock
had
not
struck
when
he
reached
Gray
's
Inn
.
   
<EOS>
It
still
wanted
ten
minutes
to
the
hour
when
he
had
ascended
the
staircase
on
which
Perker
's
chambers
were
.
 
<EOS>
The
clerks
had
not
arrived
yet
,
and
he
beguiled
the
time
by
looking
out
of
the
staircase
window
.
<EOS>
The
healthy
light
of
a
fine
October
morning
made
even
the
dingy
old
houses
brighten
up
a
little
;
some
of
the
dusty
windows
actually
looking
almost
cheerful
as
the
sun
's
rays
gleamed
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
Clerk
after
clerk
hastened
into
the
square
by
one
or
other
of
the
entrances
,
and
looking
up
at
the
Hall
clock
,
accelerated
or
decreased
his
rate
of
walking
according
to
the
time
at
which
his
office
hours
nominally
commenced
;
the
half
-
past
nine
o'clock
people
suddenly
becoming
very
brisk
,
and
the
ten
o'clock
gentlemen
falling
into
a
pace
of
most
aristocratic
slowness
.
<EOS>
The
clock
struck
ten
,
and
clerks
poured
in
faster
than
ever
,
each
one
in
a
greater
perspiration
than
his
predecessor
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
of
unlocking
and
opening
doors
echoed
and
re
-
echoed
on
every
side
;
heads
appeared
as
if
by
magic
in
every
window
;
the
porters
took
up
their
stations
for
the
day
;
the
slipshod
laundresses
hurried
off
;
the
postman
ran
from
house
to
house
;
and
the
whole
legal
hive
was
in
a
bustle
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
early
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
a
voice
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Mr
Lowten
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
,
looking
round
,
and
recognising
his
old
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Precious
warm
walking
,
is
n't
it
?
"
said
Lowten
,
drawing
a
Bramah
key
from
his
pocket
,
with
a
small
plug
therein
,
to
keep
the
dust
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
appear
to
feel
it
so
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
,
smiling
at
the
clerk
,
who
was
literally
red
-
hot
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
come
along
,
rather
,
I
can
tell
you
,
"
replied
Lowten
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
went
the
half
hour
as
I
came
through
the
Polygon
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
here
before
him
,
though
,
so
I
do
n't
mind
.
"
   
<EOS>
Comforting
himself
with
this
reflection
,
Mr
Lowten
extracted
the
plug
from
the
door
-
key
;
having
opened
the
door
,
replugged
and
repocketed
his
Bramah
,
and
picked
up
the
letters
which
the
postman
had
dropped
through
the
box
,
he
ushered
Mr
Pickwick
into
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
in
the
twinkling
of
an
eye
,
he
divested
himself
of
his
coat
,
put
on
a
threadbare
garment
,
which
he
took
out
of
a
desk
,
hung
up
his
hat
,
pulled
forth
a
few
sheets
of
cartridge
and
blotting
-
paper
in
alternate
layers
,
and
,
sticking
a
pen
behind
his
ear
,
rubbed
his
hands
with
an
air
of
great
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
you
see
,
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
he
said
,
"
now
I
'm
complete
.
<EOS>
I
've
got
my
office
coat
on
,
and
my
pad
out
,
and
let
him
come
as
soon
as
he
likes
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
got
a
pinch
of
snuff
about
you
,
have
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
have
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
for
it
,
"
said
Lowten
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
run
out
presently
,
and
get
a
bottle
of
soda
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
look
rather
queer
about
the
eyes
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
individual
appealed
to
,
surveyed
Mr
Lowten
's
eyes
from
a
distance
,
and
expressed
his
opinion
that
no
unusual
queerness
was
perceptible
in
those
features
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
of
it
,
"
said
Lowten
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
were
keeping
it
up
pretty
tolerably
at
the
Stump
last
night
,
and
I
'm
rather
out
of
sorts
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Perker
's
been
about
that
business
of
yours
,
by
the
bye
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
business
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bardell
's
costs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
mean
that
,
"
replied
Mr
Lowten
.
 
<EOS>
"
About
getting
that
customer
that
we
paid
the
ten
shillings
in
the
pound
to
the
bill
-
discounter
for
,

your

---
to
get

Fleet
,

---
about

him
to
Demerara
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr
Jingle
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Well
?
"
   
"
Well
,
it
's
all
arranged
,
"
said
Lowten
,
mending

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
agent
at
Liverpool
said
he
had
been

to
you
many
times
when
you
were
in
business
,
and
he

him
on

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
delighted
to
hear

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
say
,
"
resumed
Lowten
,
scraping
the
back

the
pen
preparatory
to
making

fresh
split
,
"
what
a
soft
chap
that
other
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
other
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
servant
,
or
friend
,
or
whatever
he
is
;
you
know
,
Trotter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
always
thought
him
the
reverse
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
so
did
I
,
from
what

I
saw
of
him
,
"
replied
Lowten
,
"

one
may

.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you

his
going
to
Demerara
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
And
giving
up
what
was
offered
him
here
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Treating
Perker
's
offer
of
eighteen
bob
a
week
,
and
a
rise
if
he
behaved
himself
,
like
dirt
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Lowten
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
said
he
must
go
along
with
the
other
one
,
and
so
they
persuaded
Perker
to
write
again
,
and
they
've
got

something
on
the
same

;
not
near
so
good
,
Perker
says
,
as
a
convict
would
get
in
New
South
Wales
,
if
he
appeared
at
his
trial
in
a
new
suit
of
clothes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Foolish
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
with
glistening

.
<EOS>
"
Foolish
fellow
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
worse
than
foolish
;
it
's
downright
sneaking
,
you
know
,
"
replied
Lowten
,
nibbing
the
pen
with
a
contemptuous
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
says
that
he
's
the
only
friend
he
ever
had
,
and
he
's
attached
to
him
,
and
all
that
.
 
<EOS>
Friendship
's
a
very
good
thing
in
its
way
<EOS>
---
we
are
all
very
friendly
and
comfortable
at
the
Stump
,
for
instance
,
over
our
grog
,
where
every
man
pays
for
himself
;
but
damn
hurting
yourself
for
anybody
else
,
you
know
!
 
<EOS>
No
man
should
have
more
than
two
attachments
---
the
first
,
to
number
one
,
and
the
second
to
the
ladies
;
that
's
what
I
say
---
ha
!
ha
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
concluded
with
a
loud
laugh
,
half
in
jocularity
,
and
half
in
derision
,
which
was
prematurely
cut
short
by
the
sound
of
Perker
's
footsteps
on
the
stairs
,
at
the
first
approach
of
which
,
he
vaulted
on
his
stool
with
an
agility
most
remarkable
,
and
wrote
intensely
.
   
<EOS>
The
greeting
between
Mr
Pickwick
and
his
professional
adviser
was
warm
and
cordial
;
the
client
was
scarcely
ensconced
in
the
attorney
's
arm
-
chair
,
however
,
when
a
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
,
and
a
voice
inquired
whether
Mr
Perker
was
within
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
<EOS>
"
said
Perker
,
"
that
's
one
of
our
vagabond
friends
---
Jingle
himself
,
my
dear
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
see
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
hesitating
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
think
you
had
better
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
you
Sir
,
what
's
your
name
,
walk
in
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
In
compliance
with
this
unceremonious
invitation
,
Jingle
and
Job
walked
into
the
room
,
but
,
seeing
Mr
Pickwick
,
stopped
short
in
some
confusion
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Perker
,
"
do
n't
you
know
that
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
reason
to
,
"
replied
Mr
Jingle
,
stepping
forward
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
---
deepest
obligations
---
life
preserver
---
made
a
man
of
me
---
you
shall
never
repent
it
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
to
hear
you
say
so
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
look
much
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thanks
to
you
,
sir
---
<EOS>
great
change
---
<EOS>
Majesty
's
Fleet
---
unwholesome
place
---
very
,
"
said
Jingle
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
decently
and
cleanly
dressed
,
and
so
was
Job
,
who
stood
bolt
upright
behind
him
,
staring
at
Mr
Pickwick
with
a
visage
of
iron
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
do
they
go
to
Liverpool
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
,
half
aside
to
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
evening
,
Sir
,
at
seven
o'clock
,
"
said
Job
,
taking
one
step
forward
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
heavy
coach
from
the
city
,
Sir
.
"
   
"
Are
your
places
taken
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
,
sir
,
"
replied
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
fully
made
up
your
mind
to
go
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
sir
,
"
answered
Job
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
regard
to
such
an
outfit
as
was
indispensable
for
Jingle
,
"
said
Perker
,
addressing
Mr
Pickwick
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
upon
myself
to
make
an
arrangement
for
the
deduction
of
a
small
sum
from
his
quarterly
salary
,
which
,
being
made
only
for
one
year
,
and
regularly
remitted
,
will
provide
for
that
expense
.
 
<EOS>
I
entirely
disapprove
of
your
doing
anything
for
him
,
<EOS>
my
dear
sir
,
which
is
not
dependent
on
his
own
exertions
and
good
conduct
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
interposed
Jingle
,
with
great
firmness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Clear
head
 
---
man
of
the
world
---
quite
right
---
perfectly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
compounding
with
his
creditor
,
releasing
his
clothes
from
the
pawnbroker
's
,
relieving
him
in
prison
,
and
paying
for
his
passage
,
"
continued
Perker
,
without
noticing
Jingle
's
observation
,
"
you
have
already
lost
upwards
of
fifty
pounds
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
lost
,
"
said
Jingle
hastily
,
"
Pay
it
all
<EOS>
---
stick
to
business
---
cash
up
---
every
farthing
.
 
<EOS>
Yellow
fever
,
perhaps
---
ca
n't
help
that
 
---
if
not
---
"
Here
Mr
Jingle
paused
,
and
striking
the
crown
of
his
hat
with
great
violence
,
passed
his
hand
over
his
eyes
,
and
sat
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
means
to
say
,
"
said
Job
,
advancing
a
few
paces
,
"
that
if
he
is
not
carried
off
by
the
fever
,
he
will
pay
the
money
back
again
.
<EOS>
If
he
lives
,
he
will
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
see
it
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
he
will
,
Sir
,
"
said
Job
,
with
energy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
undertake
to
swear
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
been
bestowing
a
score
or
two
of
frowns
upon
Perker
,
to
stop
his
summary
of
benefits
conferred
,
which
the
little
attorney
obstinately
disregarded
,
"
you
must
be
careful
not
to
play
any
more
desperate
cricket
matches
,
Mr
Jingle
,
or
to
renew
your
acquaintance
with
Sir
Thomas
Blazo
,
and
I
have
little
doubt
of
your
preserving
your
health
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jingle
smiled
at
this
sally
,
but
looked
rather
foolish
notwithstanding
;
so
Mr
Pickwick
changed
the
subject
by
saying
---
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
happen
to
know
<EOS>
,
do
you
,
what
has
become
of
another
friend
of
yours
---
a
more
humble
one
,
whom
I
saw
at
Rochester
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dismal
Jemmy
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jingle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jingle
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Clever
rascal
---
queer
fellow
,
hoaxing
genius
---
Job
's
brother
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Job
's
brother
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
now
I
look
at
him
closely
,
there
IS
a
likeness
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
were
always
considered
like
each
other
,
Sir
,
"
said
Job
,
with
a
cunning
look
just
lurking
in
the
corners
of
his
eyes
,
"
only
I
was
really
of
a
serious
nature
,
and
he
never
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
emigrated
to
America
,
Sir
,
in
consequence
of
being
too
much
sought
after
here
,
to
be
comfortable
;
and
has
never
been
heard
of
since
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
accounts
for
my
not
having
received
the
"
page
from
the
romance
of
real
life
,
"
which
he
promised
me
one
morning
when
he
appeared
to
be
contemplating
suicide
on
Rochester
Bridge
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
smiling
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
need
not
inquire
whether
his
dismal
behaviour
was
natural
or
assumed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
could
assume
anything
,
Sir
,
"
said
Job
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
consider
yourself
very
fortunate
in
having
escaped
him
so
easily
.
 
<EOS>
On
intimate
terms
he
would
have
been
even
a
more
dangerous
acquaintance
than
---
"
<EOS>
Job
looked
at
Jingle
,
hesitated
,
and
finally
added
,
"
than
---
than
-
myself
even
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
hopeful
family
yours
,
Mr
Trotter
,
"
said
Perker
,
sealing
a
letter
which
he
had
just
finished
writing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Job
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
much
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
the
little
man
,
laughing
,
"
I
hope
you
are
going
to
disgrace
it
.
 
<EOS>
Deliver
this
letter
to
the
agent
when
you
reach
Liverpool
,
and
let
me
advise
you
,
gentlemen
,
not
to
be
too
knowing
in
the
West
Indies
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
throw
away
this
chance
,
you
will
both
richly
deserve
to
be
hanged
,
as
I
sincerely
trust
you
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
you
had
better
leave
Mr
Pickwick
and
me
alone
,
for
we
have
other
matters
to
talk
over
,
and
time
is
precious
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
Perker
said
this
,
he
looked
towards
the
door
,
with
an
evident
desire
to
render
the
leave
-
taking
as
brief
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
brief
enough
on
Mr
Jingle
's
part
.
 
<EOS>
He
thanked
the
little
attorney
in
a
few
hurried
words
for
the
kindness
and
promptitude
with
which
he
had
rendered
his
assistance
,
and
,
turning
to
his
benefactor
,
stood
for
a
few
seconds
as
if
irresolute
what
to
say
or
how
to
act
.
 
<EOS>
Job
Trotter
relieved
his
perplexity
;
for
,
with
a
humble
and
grateful
bow
to
Mr
Pickwick
,
he
took
his
friend
gently
by
the
arm
,
and
led
him
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
worthy
couple
!
<EOS>
"
said
Perker
,
as
the
door
closed
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
they
may
become
so
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
?
 
<EOS>
Is
there
any
chance
of
their
permanent
reformation
?
"
   
<EOS>
Perker
shrugged
his
shoulders
doubtfully
,
but
observing
Mr
Pickwick
's
anxious
and
disappointed
look
,
rejoined
---
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
there
is
a
chance
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
may
prove
a
good
one
.
<EOS>
They
are
unquestionably
penitent
now
;
but
then
,
you
know
,
they
have
the
recollection
of
very
recent
suffering
fresh
upon
them
.
<EOS>
What
they
may
become
,
when
that
fades
away
,
is
a
problem
that
neither
you
nor
I
can
solve
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
added
Perker
,
laying
his
hand
on
Mr
Pickwick
's
shoulder
,
"
your
object
is
equally
honourable
,
whatever
the
result
is
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
that
species
of
benevolence
which
is
so
very
cautious
and
long
-
sighted
that
it
is
seldom
exercised
at
all
,
lest
its
owner
should
be
imposed
upon
,
and
so
wounded
in
his
self
-
love
,
be
real
charity
or
a
worldly
counterfeit
,
I
leave
to
wiser
heads
than
mine
to
determine
.
<EOS>
But
if
those
two
fellows
were
to
commit
a
burglary
to
-
morrow
,
my
opinion
of
this
action
would
be
equally
high
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
remarks
,
which
were
delivered
in
a
much
more
animated
and
earnest
manner
than
is
usual
in
legal
gentlemen
,
Perker
drew
his
chair
to
his
desk
,
and
listened
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
recital
of
old
Mr
Winkle
's
obstinacy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Give
him
a
week
,
"
said
Perker
,
nodding
his
head
prophetically
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
will
come
round
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
will
,
"
rejoined
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
not
,
we
must
try
the
young
lady
's
persuasion
;
and
that
is
what
anybody
<EOS>
but
you
would
have
done
at
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Perker
was
taking
a
pinch
of
snuff
with
various
grotesque
contractions
of
countenance
,
eulogistic
of
the
persuasive
powers
appertaining
unto
young
ladies
,
when
the
murmur
of
inquiry
and
answer
was
heard
in
the
outer
office
,
and
Lowten
tapped
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
little
man
.
   
<EOS>
The
clerk
came
in
,
and
shut
the
door
after
him
,
with
great
mystery
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
wanted
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
wants
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Lowten
looked
at
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
coughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
wants
me
?
 
<EOS>
Ca
n't
you
speak
,
Mr
Lowten
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
replied
Lowten
,
"
it
's
Dodson
;
and
Fogg
is
with
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
life
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
little
man
,
looking
at
his
watch
,
"
I
appointed
them
to
be
here
at
half
-
past
eleven
,
to
settle
that
matter
of
yours
,
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
them
an
undertaking
on
which
they
sent
down
your
discharge
;
it
's
very
awkward
,
my
dear
Sir
;
what
will
you
do
?
 
<EOS>
Would
you
like
to
step
into
the
next
room
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
next
room
being
the
identical
room
in
which
Messrs.
Dodson
&
Fogg
were
,
Mr
Pickwick
replied
that
he
would
remain
where
he
was
:
the
more
especially
as
Messrs.
Dodson
&
Fogg
ought
to
be
ashamed
to
look
him
in
the
face
,
instead
of
his
being
ashamed
to
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
Which
latter
circumstance
he
begged
Mr
Perker
to
note
,
with
a
glowing
countenance
and
many
marks
of
indignation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
my
dear
Sir
,
very
well
,
"
replied
Perker
,
"
<EOS>
I
can
only
say
that
if
you
expect
either
Dodson
or
Fogg
to
exhibit
any
symptom
of
shame
or
confusion
at
having
to
look
you
,
or
anybody
else
,
in
the
face
,
you
are
the
most
sanguine
man
in
your
expectations
that
I
ever
met
with
.
 
<EOS>
Show
them
in
,
Mr
Lowten
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
disappeared
with
a
grin
,
and
immediately
returned
ushering
in
the
firm
,
in
due
form
of
precedence
---
Dodson
first
,
and
Fogg
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
seen
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
believe
?
"
said
Perker
to
Dodson
,
inclining
his
pen
in
the
direction
where
that
gentleman
was
seated
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
said
Dodson
,
in
a
loud
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
cried
Fogg
,
"
how
do
you
do
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
well
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
knew
the
face
,
"
said
Fogg
,
drawing
up
a
chair
,
and
looking
round
him
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
bent
his
head
very
slightly
,
in
answer
to
these
salutations
,
and
,
seeing
Fogg
pull
a
bundle
of
papers
from
his
coat
pocket
,
rose
and
walked
to
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
occasion
for
Mr
Pickwick
to
move
,
Mr
Perker
,
"
said
Fogg
,
untying
the
red
tape
which
encircled
the
little
bundle
,
and
smiling
again
more
sweetly
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
is
pretty
well
acquainted
with
these
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
no
secrets
between
us
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
He
!
<EOS>
he
!
<EOS>
he
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
many
,
I
think
,
"
said
Dodson
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
Then
both
the
partners
laughed
together
---
pleasantly
and
cheerfully
,
as
men
who
are
going
to
receive
money
often
do
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
make
Mr
Pickwick
pay
for
peeping
,
"
said
Fogg
,
with
considerable
native
humour
,
as
he
unfolded
his
papers
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
amount
of
the
taxed
costs
is
one
hundred
and
thirty
-
three
,
six
,
four
,
Mr
Perker
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
comparing
of
papers
,
and
turning
over
of
leaves
,
by
Fogg
and
Perker
,
after
this
statement
of
profit
and
loss
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Dodson
said
,
in
an
affable
manner
,
to
Mr
Pickwick
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
you
are
looking
quite
so
stout
as
when
I
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
last
,
Mr
Pickwick
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Possibly
not
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
who
had
been
flashing
forth
looks
of
fierce
indignation
,
without
producing
the
smallest
effect
on
either
of
the
sharp
practitioners
;
"
I
believe
I
am
not
,
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
persecuted
and
annoyed
by
scoundrels
of
late
,
Sir
.
"
<EOS>
Perker
coughed
violently
,
and
asked
Mr
Pickwick
whether
he
would
n't
like
to
look
at
the
morning
paper
.
 
<EOS>
To
which
inquiry
Mr
Pickwick
returned
a
most
decided
negative
.
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
said
Dodson
,
"
I
dare
say
you
have
been
annoyed
in
the
Fleet
;
there
are
some
odd
gentry
there
.
 
<EOS>
Whereabouts
were
your
apartments
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
one
room
,
"
replied
that
much
-
injured
gentleman
,
"
was
on
the
coffee
-
room
flight
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
said
Dodson
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
that
is
a
very
pleasant
part
of
the
establishment
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
drily
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
coolness
about
all
this
,
which
,
to
a
gentleman
of
an
excitable
temperament
,
had
,
under
the
circumstances
,
rather
an
exasperating
tendency
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
restrained
his
wrath
by
gigantic
efforts
;
but
when
Perker
wrote
a
cheque
for
the
whole
amount
,
and
Fogg
deposited
it
in
a
small
pocket
-
book
,
with
a
triumphant
smile
playing
over
his
pimply
features
,
which
communicated
itself
likewise
to
the
stern
countenance
of
Dodson
,
he
felt
the
blood
in
his
cheeks
tingling
with
indignation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Dodson
,
"
said
Fogg
,
putting
up
the
pocket
-
book
and
drawing
on
his
gloves
,
"
I
am
at
your
service
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
Dodson
,
rising
;
"
I
am
quite
ready
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
happy
,
"
said
Fogg
,
softened
by
the
cheque
,
"
to
have
had
the
pleasure
of
making
Mr
Pickwick
's
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
do
n't
think
quite
so
ill
of
us
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
when
we
first
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
Dodson
,
with
the
high
tone
of
calumniated
virtue
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pickwick
now
knows
us
better
,
I
trust
;
whatever
your
opinion
of
gentlemen
of
our
profession
may
be
,
I
beg
to
assure
you
,
sir
,
that
I
bear
no
ill
-
will
or
vindictive
feeling
towards
you
for
the
sentiments
you
thought
proper
to
express
in
our
office
in
Freeman
's
Court
,
Cornhill
,
on
the
occasion
to
which
my
partner
has
referred
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
no
;
nor
I
,
"
said
Fogg
,
in
a
most
forgiving
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
conduct
,
Sir
,
"
said
Dodson
,
"
will
speak
for
itself
,
and
justify
itself
,
I
hope
,
upon
every
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
in
the
profession
some
years
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
have
been
honoured
with
the
confidence
of
many
excellent
clients
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
-
morning
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
morning
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
said
Fogg
.
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
put
his
umbrella
under
his
arm
,
drew
off
his
right
glove
,
and
extended
the
hand
of
reconciliation
to
that
most
indignant
gentleman
;
who
,
thereupon
,
thrust
his
hands
beneath
his
coat
tails
,
and
eyed
the
attorney
with
looks
of
scornful
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lowten
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Perker
,
at
this
moment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Open
the
door
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
one
instant
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perker
,
I
WILL
speak
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Sir
,
pray
let
the
matter
rest
where
it
is
,
"
said
the
little
attorney
,
who
had
been
in
a
state
of
nervous
apprehension
during
the
whole
interview
;
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
beg
---
"
   
"
I
will
not
be
put
down
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
hastily
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Dodson
,
you
have
addressed
some
remarks
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dodson
turned
round
,
bent
his
head
meekly
,
and
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
Some
remarks
to
me
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pickwick
,
almost
breathless
;
"
and
your
partner
has
tendered
me
his
hand
,
and
you
have
both
assumed
a
tone
of
forgiveness
and
high
-
mindedness
,
which
is
an
extent
of
impudence
that
I
was
not
prepared
for
,
even
in
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
sir
!
"
exclaimed
Dodson
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
sir
!
"
reiterated
Fogg
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
that
I
have
been
the
victim
of
your
plots
and
conspiracies
?
<EOS>
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
that
I
am
the
man
whom
you
have
been
imprisoning
and
robbing
?
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
you
were
the
attorneys
for
the
plaintiff
,
in
Bardell
and
Pickwick
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
we
do
know
it
,
"
replied
Dodson
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
we
know
it
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
Fogg
,
slapping
his
pocket
 
---
perhaps
by
accident
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
that
you
recollect
it
with
satisfaction
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
attempting
to
call
up
a
sneer
for
the
first
time
in
his
life
,
and
failing
most
signally
in
so
doing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Although
I
have
long
been
anxious
to
tell
you
,
in
plain
terms
,
what
my
opinion
of
you
is
,
I
should
have
let
even
this
opportunity
pass
,
in
deference
to
my
friend
Perker
's
wishes
,
but
for
the
unwarrantable
tone
you
have
assumed
,
and
your
insolent
familiarity
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
insolent
familiarity
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
turning
upon
Fogg
with
a
fierceness
of
gesture
which
caused
that
person
to
retreat
towards
the
door
with
great
expedition
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
care
,
Sir
,
"
said
Dodson
,
who
,
though
he
was
the
biggest
man
of
the
party
,
had
prudently
entrenched
himself
behind
Fogg
,
and
was
speaking
over
his
head
with
a
very
pale
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
assault
you
,
Mr
Fogg
;
do
n't
return
it
on
any
account
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
I
wo
n't
return
it
,
"
said
Fogg
,
falling
back
a
little
more
as
he
spoke
;
to
the
evident
relief
of
his
partner
,
who
by
these
means
was
gradually
getting
into
the
outer
office
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
"
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
resuming
the
thread
of
his
discourse
---
"
you
are
a
well
-
matched
pair
of
mean
,
rascally
,
pettifogging
robbers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
interposed
Perker
,
"
is
that
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
summed
up
in
that
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
they
are
mean
,
rascally
,
pettifogging
robbers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Perker
,
in
a
most
conciliatory
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
sirs
,
he
has
said
all
he
has
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
Now
pray
go
.
 
<EOS>
Lowten
,
is
that
door
open
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
,
with
a
distant
giggle
,
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
,
there
---
good
-
morning
---
good
-
morning
---
now
pray
,
my
dear
sirs
---
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
,
the
door
!
"
cried
the
little
man
,
pushing
Dodson
&
Fogg
,
nothing
loath
,
out
of
the
office
;
"
this
way
,
my
dear
sirs
---
now
pray
do
n't
prolong
this
---
 
Dear
me
---
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
---
the
door
,
sir
---
why
do
n't
you
attend
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
there
's
law
in
England
,
sir
,
"
said
Dodson
,
looking
towards
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
he
put
on
his
hat
,
"
you
shall
smart
for
this
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
couple
of
mean
---
"
   
"
Remember
,
sir
,
you
pay
dearly
for
this
,
"
said
Fogg
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
Rascally
,
pettifogging
robbers
!
"
<EOS>
continued
Mr
Pickwick
,
taking
not
the
least
notice
of
the
threats
that
were
addressed
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Robbers
!
"
cried
Mr
Pickwick
,
running
to
the
stair
-
head
,
as
the
two
attorneys
descended
.
   
<EOS>
"
Robbers
!
<EOS>
"
shouted
Mr
Pickwick
,
breaking
from
Lowten
and
Perker
,
and
thrusting
his
head
out
of
the
staircase
window
.
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
Pickwick
drew
in
his
head
again
,
his
countenance
was
smiling
and
placid
;
and
,
walking
quietly
back
into
the
office
,
he
declared
that
he
had
now
removed
a
great
weight
from
his
mind
,
and
that
he
felt
perfectly
comfortable
and
happy
.
   
<EOS>
Perker
said
nothing
at
all
until
he
had
emptied
his
snuff
-
box
,
and
sent
Lowten
out
to
fill
it
,
when
he
was
seized
with
a
fit
of
laughing
,
which
lasted
five
minutes
;
at
the
expiration
of
which
time
he
said
that
he
supposed
he
ought
to
be
very
angry
,
but
he
could
n't
think
of
the
business
seriously
yet
---
when
he
could
,
he
would
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
now
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
let
me
have
a
settlement
with
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
Of
the
same
kind
as
the
last
?
"
inquired
Perker
,
with
another
laugh
.
"
<EOS>
Not
exactly
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Pickwick
,
drawing
out
his
pocket
-
book
,
and
shaking
the
little
man
heartily
by
the
hand
,
"
I
only
mean
a
pecuniary
settlement
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
done
me
many
acts
of
kindness
that
I
can
never
repay
,
and
have
no
wish
to
repay
,
for
I
prefer
continuing
the
obligation
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
preface
,
the
two
friends
dived
into
some
very
complicated
accounts
and
vouchers
,
which
,
having
been
duly
displayed
and
gone
through
by
Perker
,
were
at
once
discharged
by
Mr
Pickwick
with
many
professions
of
esteem
and
friendship
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
no
sooner
arrived
at
this
point
,
than
<EOS>
a
most
violent
and
startling
knocking
was
heard
at
the
door
;
it
was
not
an
ordinary
double
-
knock
,
but
a
constant
and
uninterrupted
succession
of
the
loudest
single
raps
,
as
if
the
knocker
were
endowed
with
the
perpetual
motion
,
or
the
person
outside
had
forgotten
to
leave
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
what
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Perker
,
starting
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
a
knock
at
the
door
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
as
if
there
could
be
the
smallest
doubt
of
the
fact
.
   
<EOS>
The
knocker
made
a
more
energetic
reply
than
words
could
have
yielded
,
for
it
continued
to
hammer
with
surprising
force
and
noise
,
without
a
moment
's
cessation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Perker
,
ringing
his
bell
,
"
we
shall
alarm
the
inn
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
,
do
n't
you
hear
a
knock
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
answer
the
door
in
one
moment
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
clerk
.
   
<EOS>
The
knocker
appeared
to
hear
the
response
,
and
to
assert
that
it
was
quite
impossible
he
could
wait
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
a
stupendous
uproar
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
dreadful
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
stopping
his
ears
.
   
<EOS>
"
Make
haste
,
Mr
Lowten
,
"
<EOS>
Perker
called
out
;
"
we
shall
have
the
panels
beaten
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
,
who
was
washing
his
hands
in
a
dark
closet
,
hurried
to
the
door
,
and
turning
the
handle
,
beheld
the
appearance
which
is
described
in
the
next
chapter
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
54
.
<EOS>
Containing
some
particulars
relative
to
the
double
knock
,
and
other
matters
:
among
which
certain
interesting
disclosures
relative
to
Mr
Snodgrass
and
a
young
lady
are
by
no
means
irrelevant
to
this
history
 
<EOS>
The
object
that
presented
itself
to
the
eyes
of
the
astonished
clerk
,
was
a
boy
---
a
wonderfully
fat
boy
---
habited
as
a
serving
lad
,
standing
upright
on
the
mat
,
with
his
eyes
closed
as
if
in
sleep
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
seen
such
a
fat
boy
,
in
or
out
of
a
travelling
caravan
;
and
this
,
coupled
with
the
calmness
and
repose
of
his
appearance
,
so
very
different
from
what
was
reasonably
to
have
been
expected
of
the
inflicter
of
such
knocks
,
smote
him
with
wonder
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
clerk
.
   
<EOS>
The
extraordinary
boy
replied
not
a
word
;
but
he
nodded
once
,
and
seemed
,
to
the
clerk
's
imagination
,
to
snore
feebly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
do
you
come
from
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
clerk
.
   
<EOS>
The
boy
made
no
sign
.
 
<EOS>
He
breathed
heavily
,
but
in
all
other
respects
was
motionless
.
   
<EOS>
The
clerk
repeated
the
question
thrice
,
and
receiving
no
answer
,
prepared
to
shut
the
door
,
when
the
boy
suddenly
opened
his
eyes
,
winked
several
times
,
sneezed
once
,
and
raised
his
hand
as
if
to
repeat
the
knocking
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
the
door
open
,
he
stared
about
him
with
astonishment
,
and
at
length
fixed
his
eyes
on
Mr
Lowten
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
do
you
knock
in
that
way
for
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
clerk
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Which
way
?
"
said
the
boy
,
in
a
slow
and
sleepy
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
like
forty
hackney
-
coachmen
,
"
replied
the
clerk
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
master
said
,
I
was
n't
to
leave
off
knocking
till
they
opened
the
door
,
for
fear
I
should
go
to
sleep
,
"
said
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
clerk
,
"
what
message
have
you
brought
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
downstairs
,
"
rejoined
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Master
.
 
<EOS>
He
wants
to
know
whether
you
're
at
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Lowten
bethought
himself
,
at
this
juncture
,
of
looking
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
an
open
carriage
with
a
hearty
old
gentleman
in
it
,
looking
up
very
anxiously
,
he
ventured
to
beckon
him
;
on
which
,
the
old
gentleman
jumped
out
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
your
master
in
the
carriage
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Lowten
.
   
<EOS>
The
boy
nodded
.
   
<EOS>
All
further
inquiries
were
superseded
by
the
appearance
of
old
Wardle
,
who
,
running
upstairs
and
just
recognising
Lowten
,
passed
at
once
into
Mr
Perker
's
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pickwick
!
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
hand
,
my
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Why
have
I
never
heard
until
the
day
before
yesterday
of
your
suffering
yourself
to
be
cooped
up
in
jail
?
 
<EOS>
And
why
did
you
let
him
do
it
,
Perker
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
help
it
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
replied
Perker
,
with
a
smile
and
a
pinch
of
snuff
;
"
you
know
how
obstinate
he
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
do
;
of
course
I
do
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
heartily
glad
to
see
him
,
notwithstanding
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
lose
sight
of
him
again
,
in
a
hurry
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Wardle
shook
Mr
Pickwick
's
hand
once
more
,
and
,
having
done
the
same
by
Perker
,
threw
himself
into
an
arm
-
chair
,
his
jolly
red
face
shining
again
with
smiles
and
health
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
are
pretty
goings
on
---
a
pinch
of
your
snuff
,
Perker
,
my
boy
---
never
were
such
times
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mean
!
"
replied
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
think
the
girls
are
all
running
mad
<EOS>
;
that
's
no
news
,
you
'll
say
?
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
's
not
;
but
it
's
true
,
for
all
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
come
up
to
London
,
of
all
places
in
the
world
,
to
tell
us
that
,
my
dear
Sir
,
have
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
altogether
,
"
replied
Wardle
;
"
though
it
was
the
main
cause
of
my
coming
.
 
<EOS>
How
's
Arabella
?
"
   
"
Very
well
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
and
will
be
delighted
to
see
you
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Black
-
eyed
little
jilt
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
a
great
idea
of
marrying
her
myself
,
one
of
these
odd
days
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
glad
of
it
too
,
very
glad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
did
the
intelligence
reach
you
?
"
asked
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
came
to
my
girls
,
of
course
,
"
replied
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Arabella
wrote
,
the
day
before
yesterday
,
to
say
she
had
made
a
stolen
match
without
her
husband
's
father
's
consent
,
and
so
you
had
gone
down
to
get
it
when
his
refusing
it
could
n't
prevent
the
match
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
a
very
good
time
to
say
something
serious
to
my
girls
;
so
I
said
what
a
dreadful
thing
it
was
that
children
should
marry
without
their
parents
"
consent
,
and
so
forth
;
but
,
bless
your
hearts
,
I
could
n't
make
the
least
impression
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
thought
it
such
a
much
more
dreadful
thing
that
there
should
have
been
a
wedding
without
bridesmaids
,
that
I
might
as
well
have
preached
to
Joe
himself
.
<EOS>
"
Here
the
old
gentleman
stopped
to
laugh
;
and
having
done
so
to
his
heart
's
content
,
presently
resumed
---
   
"
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
the
best
of
it
,
it
seems
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
only
half
the
love
-
making
and
plotting
that
have
been
going
forward
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
walking
on
mines
for
the
last
six
months
,
and
they
're
sprung
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Pickwick
,
turning
pale
;
"
no
other
secret
marriage
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
<EOS>
no
,
"
replied
old
Wardle
;
"
not
so
bad
as
that
;
no
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
then
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
am
I
interested
in
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
answer
that
question
,
Perker
?
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
commit
yourself
by
doing
so
,
my
dear
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
you
are
,
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
asked
Mr
Pickwick
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
what
way
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
Really
,
"
replied
Wardle
<EOS>
,
"
you
're
such
a
fiery
sort
of
a
young
fellow
that
I
am
almost
afraid
to
tell
you
;
but
,
however
,
if
Perker
will
sit
between
us
to
prevent
mischief
,
I
'll
venture
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
closed
the
room
door
,
and
fortified
himself
with
another
application
to
Perker
's
snuff
-
box
,
the
old

proceeded
with
his
great
disclosure
in
these

---
   
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
that
my
daughter
Bella
---
Bella
,
who
married
young
Trundle
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
we
know
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
alarm
me
at
the
very
beginning
.
 
<EOS>
My
daughter
Bella
---
Emily
having
gone
to
bed
with
a
headache
after
she
had
read
Arabella
's
letter
to
me
---
sat
herself
down
by
my
side
the
other
evening
,
and
began
to
talk
over
this
marriage
affair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
pa
,
"
she
says
,
"
what
do
you
think
of
it
?
"
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
,
"
I
said
,
"
I
suppose
it
's
all
very
well
;
I
hope
it
's
for
the
best
.
"
 
<EOS>
I
answered
in
this
way
because
I
was
sitting
before
the
fire
at
the
time
,
drinking
my
grog
rather
thoughtfully
,
and
<EOS>
I
knew
my
throwing
in
an
undecided
word
now
and
then
,
would
induce
her
to
continue
talking
.
<EOS>
Both
my
girls
are
pictures
of
their
dear
mother
,
and
as
I
grow
old
I
like
to
sit
with
only
them
by
me
;
for
their
voices
and
looks
carry
me
back
to
the
happiest
period
of
my
life
,
and
make
me
,
for
the
moment
,
as
young
as
I
used
to
be
then
,
though
not
quite
so
light
-
hearted
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
a
marriage
of
affection
,
pa
,
"
said
Bella
,
after
a
short

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
,
"
said
I
,
"
but
such
marriages
do
not
always
turn
out
the
happiest
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
I
question
that
,
mind
!
<EOS>
"
interposed
Mr
Pickwick
warmly
.
"
Very
good
,
"
responded
Wardle
,
"
question
anything
you
like
when
it
's
your
turn
to

,
but
do
n't

me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your

,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Granted
,
"

Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
"
I
am
sorry
to

your

against

of
affection
,
pa
,
"
said
Bella
,
colouring
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
wrong
;
I
ought
not
to
have
said
so
,
my
dear
,
either
,
"
said
I
,
patting
her
cheek
as

as
a
rough

fellow
like

could
pat

,
"
for
your
mother
's
was
one
,
and
so

yours
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
that
I

,
pa
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
pa
,
I
wanted
to
speak
to
you
about
Emily
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
Mr
Pickwick
started
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
now
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Wardle
,
stopping
in
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
go
on
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
could
spin
out
a
story
,
"
said
Wardle
abruptly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
come
out
,
sooner
or
later
,
and
it
'll
save
us
all
a
great
deal
of
time
if
it
comes
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
The
long
and
the
short
of
it
is
,
then
,
that
Bella
at
last
mustered
up
courage
to
tell
me
that
Emily
was
very
unhappy
;
that
she
and
your
young
friend
Snodgrass
had
been
in
constant
correspondence
and
communication
ever
since
last
Christmas
;
that
she
had
very
dutifully
made
up
her
mind
to
run
away
with
him
,
in
laudable
imitation
of
her
old
friend
and
school
-
fellow
;
but
that
having
some
compunctions
of
conscience
on
the
subject
,
inasmuch
as
I
had
always
been
rather
kindly
disposed
to
both

them
,
they
had
thought
it
better
in
the
first

to
pay
me
the

of
asking
whether
I
would
have
any
objection
to
their
being
married
in
the
usual
matter
-
of
-

.
 
<EOS>
There
now
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
if
you
can
make
it
convenient
to
reduce
your
eyes
to
their
usual
size
again
,
and
to
let
me
hear
what
you
think
we
ought
to
do
,
I
shall
feel
rather
obliged
to
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
testy

in
which
the
hearty
old

uttered

was
not

;
for
Mr

's

had

down

and

,
quite

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Snodgrass!-since
<EOS>
last
Christmas
!
"
were

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Since
last
Christmas
,
"
replied
Wardle
<EOS>
;
"
that
's
plain
enough
,
and
very

we
must
have

,
not
to

it
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
it
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
ruminating
;
"
I
can
not
really
understand
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
easy
enough
to
understand
it
,
"
replied
the
choleric
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
been
a
younger
man
,
you
would
have
been
in
the
secret
long
ago
;
and
besides
,
"
added

,
after

,
"
the
truth
is
,
that
,
knowing
nothing
of
this

,
I
have
rather
pressed
Emily
for
four
or
five
months
past
,
to
receive
favourably
(
if
she
could
;
I
would
never
attempt
to
force
a
girl
's
inclinations
)
<EOS>
the
addresses
of
a
young
gentleman
down
in
our

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
that
,
girl
-
like
,
to
enhance
her
own
value
and
increase
the
ardour
of
Mr
Snodgrass
,
she
has
represented
this
matter
in
very
glowing

,
and
that

have
both

that
they

-

,
