resource
but
clandestine
matrimony
,
or
charcoal
.
 
<EOS>
Now
the
question
is
,
what
's
to
be
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
YOU
done
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
what
did
you
do
when
your
married
daughter
told
you
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
made
a
fool
of
myself
of
course
,
"
rejoined
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
interposed
Perker
,
who
had
accompanied
this
dialogue
with
sundry
twitchings
of
his
watch
-
chain
,
vindictive
rubbings
of
his
nose
,
and
other
symptoms
of
impatience
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
very
natural
;
but
how
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
went
into
a
great
passion
and
frightened
my
mother
into
a
fit
,
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
judicious
,
"
remarked
Perker
;
"
and
what
else
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
fretted
and
fumed
all
next
day
,
and
raised
a
great
disturbance
,
"
rejoined
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
last
I
got
tired
of
rendering
myself
unpleasant
and
making
everybody
miserable
;
so
I
hired
a
carriage
at
Muggleton
,
and
,
putting
my
own
horses
in
it
,
came
up
to
town
,
under
pretence
of
bringing
Emily
to
see
Arabella
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Miss
Wardle
is
with
you
,
then
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
she
is
,
"
replied
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
at
Osborne
's
Hotel
in
the
Adelphi
at
this
moment
,
unless
your
enterprising
friend
has
run
away
with
her
since
I
came
out
this
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
reconciled
then
?
"
said
Perker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
answered
Wardle
;
"
she
has
been
crying
and
moping
ever
since
,
except
last
night
,
between
tea
and
supper
,
when
she
made
a
great
parade
of
writing
a
letter
that
I
pretended
to
take
no
notice
of
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
my
advice
in
this
matter
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
said
Perker
,
looking
from
the
musing
face
of
Mr
Pickwick
to
the
eager
countenance
of
Wardle
,
and
taking
several
consecutive
pinches
of
his
favourite
stimulant
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
so
,
"
said
Wardle
,
looking
at
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
"
said
Perker
,
rising
and
pushing
his
chair
back
,
"
my
advice
is
,
that
you
both
walk
away
together
,
or
ride
away
,
or
get
away
by
some
means
or
other
,
for
I
'm
tired
of
you
,
and
just
talk
this
matter
over
between
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
not
settled
it
by
the
next
time
I
see
you
,
I
'll
tell
you
what
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
satisfactory
,
"
said
Wardle
,
hardly
knowing
whether
to
smile
or
be
offended
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
,
pooh
,
my
dear
Sir
,
"
returned
Perker
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
both
a
great
deal
better
than
you
know
yourselves
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
settled
it
already
,
to
all
intents
and
purposes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
expressing
himself
,
the
little
gentleman
poked
his
snuff
-
box
first
into
the
chest
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
then
into
the
waistcoat
of
Mr
Wardle
,
upon
which
they
all
three
laughed
,
especially
the
two
last
-
named
gentlemen
,
who
at
once
shook
hands
again
,
without
any
obvious
or
particular
reason
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
dine
with
me
to
-
day
,
"
said
Wardle
to
Perker
,
as
he
showed
them
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
promise
,
my
dear
Sir
,
ca
n't
promise
,
"
replied
Perker
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
look
in
,
in
the
evening
,
at
all
events
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
expect
you
at
five
,
"
said
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Joe
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
Joe
having
been
at
length
awakened
,
the
two
friends
departed
in
Mr
Wardle
's
carriage
,
which
in
common
humanity
had
a
dickey
behind
for
the
fat
boy
,
who
,
if
there
had
been
a
footboard
instead
,
would
have
rolled
off
and
killed
himself
in
his
very
first
nap
.
   
<EOS>
Driving
to
the
George
and
Vulture
,
they
found
that
Arabella
and
her
maid
had
sent
for
a
hackney
-
coach
immediately
on
the
receipt
of
a
short
note
from
Emily
announcing
her
arrival
in
town
,
and
had
proceeded
straight
to
the
Adelphi
.
 
<EOS>
As
Wardle
had
business
to
transact
in
the
city
,
they
sent
the
carriage
and
the
fat
boy
to
his
hotel
,
with
the
information
that
he
and
Mr
Pickwick
would
return
together
to
dinner
at
five
o'clock
.
   
<EOS>
Charged
with
this
message
,
the
fat
boy
returned
,
slumbering
as
peaceably
in
his
dickey
,
over
the
stones
,
as
if
it
had
been
a
down
bed
on
watch
springs
.
 
<EOS>
By
some
extraordinary
miracle
he
awoke
of
his
own
accord
,
when
the
coach
stopped
,
and
giving
himself
a
good
shake
to
stir
up
his
faculties
,
went
upstairs
to
execute
his
commission
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
whether
the
shake
had
jumbled
the
fat
boy
's
faculties
together
,
instead
of
arranging
them
in
proper
order
,
or
had
roused
such
a
quantity
of
new
ideas
within
him
as
to
render
him
oblivious
of
ordinary
forms
and
ceremonies
,
or
(
which
is
also
possible
)
had
proved
unsuccessful
in
preventing
his
falling
asleep
as
he
ascended
the
stairs
,
it
is
an
undoubted
fact
that
he
walked
into
the
sitting
-
room
without
previously
knocking
at
the
door
;
and
so
beheld
a
gentleman
with
his
arms
clasping
his
young
mistress
's
waist
,
sitting
very
lovingly
by
her
side
on
a
sofa
,
while
Arabella
and
her
pretty
handmaid
feigned
to
be
absorbed
in
looking
out
of
a
window
at
the
other
end
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
this
phenomenon
,
the
fat
boy
uttered
an
interjection
,
the
ladies
a
scream
,
and
the
gentleman
an
oath
,
almost
simultaneously
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wretched
creature
,
what
do
you
want
here
?
"
said
the
gentleman
,
who
it
is
needless
to
say
was
Mr
Snodgrass
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
<EOS>
the
fat
boy
,
considerably
terrified
,
briefly
responded
,
"
Missis
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
me
for
,
"
inquired
Emily
,
turning
her
head
aside
,
"
you
stupid
creature
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Master
and
Mr
Pickwick
is
a
-
going
to
dine
here
at
five
,
"
replied
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Leave
the
room
!
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
glaring
upon
the
bewildered
youth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
added
Emily
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bella
,
dear
,
advise
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Emily
and
Mr
Snodgrass
,
and
Arabella
and
Mary
,
crowded
into
a
corner
,
and
conversed
earnestly
in
whispers
for
some
minutes
,
during
which
the
fat
boy
dozed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
"
said
Arabella
,
at
length
,
looking
round
with
a
most

,
"
how
do
you
do
,
Joe
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
"
said
Emily
,
"
you
're
a
very
good
boy
;
I
wo
n't
forget
you
,
Joe
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
"
said
Mr
Snodgrass
,
advancing
to
the
astonished
youth
,
and
seizing
his
hand
,
"
I
did
n't
know
you
before
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
five
shillings
for
you
,
Joe
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
owe
you
five
,
Joe
,
"
said
Arabella
,
"
for
old
acquaintance
sake
,
you
know
;
"
and
another
most
captivating
smile
was
bestowed
upon
the
corpulent
intruder
.
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
's
perception
being
slow
,
he
looked
rather
puzzled
at
first
to
account
for
this
sudden
prepossession
in
his
favour
,
and
stared
about
him
in
a
very
alarming

.
 
<EOS>
At
length
his
broad
face
began
to
show
symptoms
of
a
grin
of
proportionately
broad
dimensions
;
and
then
,
thrusting
half
-
a
-
crown
into
each
of
his
pockets
,
and
a
hand
and
wrist
after
it
,
he
burst
into
a
horse

:
being
for
the
first
and
only
time
in
his
existence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
understands
us
,
I
see
,
"
said
Arabella
.
<EOS>
"
He
had
better
have
something
to
eat
,
immediately
,
"
remarked
Emily
.
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
almost
laughed
again
when
he
heard
this
suggestion
.
<EOS>
Mary
,
after
a
little
more
whispering
,
tripped
forth
from
the
group
and
said
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
dine
with
you
to
-
day
,
sir
,
if
you
have
no
objection
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
way
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
such
a
jolly
meat
-
pie
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
the
fat
boy
led
the
way
downstairs
;
his
pretty
companion
captivating
all
the
waiters
and
angering
all
the
chambermaids
as
she
followed
him
to
the
eating
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
the
meat
-
pie
of
which
the
youth
had
spoken
so
feelingly
,
and
there
were
,
moreover
,
a
steak
,
and
a
dish
of
potatoes
,
and
a
pot
of
porter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
eye
,
how
prime
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
SO
hungry
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Having
apostrophised
his
eye
,
in
a
species
of
rapture
,
five
or
six
times
,
the
youth
took
the
head
of
the
little
table
,
and
Mary
seated
herself
at
the
bottom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
have
some
of
this
?
"
said
the
fat
boy
,
plunging
into
the
pie
up
to
the
very
ferules
of
the
knife
and
fork
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
,
if
you
please
,
"
replied
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
assisted
Mary
to
a
little
,
and
himself
to
a
great
deal
,
and
was
just
going
to
begin
eating
when
he
suddenly
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
leaned
forward
in
his
chair
,
and
letting
his
hands
,
with
the
knife
and
fork
in
them
,
fall
on
his
knees
,
said
,
very
slowly
---
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
How
nice
you
look
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
said
in
an
admiring
manner
,
and
was
,
so
far
,
gratifying
;
but
still
there
was
enough
of
the
cannibal
in
the
young
gentleman
's
eyes
to
render
the
compliment
a
double
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
Joseph
,
"
said
Mary
,
affecting
to
blush
,
"
what
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
,
gradually
recovering
his
former
position
,
replied
with
a
heavy
sigh
,
and
,
remaining
thoughtful
for
a
few
moments
,
drank
a
long
draught
of
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
Having
achieved
this
feat
,
he
sighed
again
,
and
applied
himself
assiduously
to
the
pie
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
nice
young
lady
Miss
Emily
is
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mary
,
after
a
long
silence
.
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
had
by
this
time
finished
the
pie
.
 
<EOS>
He
fixed
his
eyes
on
Mary
,
and
replied
---
"
I
knows
a
nicerer
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
said
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
indeed
!
"
replied
the
fat
boy
,
with
unwonted
vivacity
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
her
name
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
yours
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mary
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
's
hers
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
boy
grinned
to
add
point
to
the
compliment
,
and
put
his
eyes
into
something
between
a
squint
and
a
cast
,
which
there
is
reason
to
believe
he
intended
for
an
ogle
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
talk
to
me
in
that
way
,
"
said
Mary
;
"
you
do
n't
mean
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
I
,
though
?
"
replied
the
fat
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
come
here
regular
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
rejoined
Mary
,
shaking
her
head
,
"
I
'm
going
away
again
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
,
in
a
tone
of
strong
feeling
;
"
how
we
should
have
enjoyed
ourselves
at
meals
,
if
you
had
been
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
might
come
here
sometimes
,
perhaps
,
to
see
you
,
"
said
Mary
,
plaiting
the
table
-
cloth
in
assumed
coyness
,
"
if
you
would
do
me
a
favour
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
looked
from
the
pie
-
dish
to
the
steak
,
as
if
he
thought
a
favour
must
be
in
a
manner
connected
with
something
to
eat
;
and
then
took
out
one
of
the
half
-
crowns
and
glanced
at
it
nervously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
understand
me
?
"
said
Mary
,
looking
slily
in
his
fat
face
.
   
<EOS>
Again
he
looked
at
the
half
-
crown
,
and
said
faintly
,
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
ladies
want
you
not
to
say
anything
to
the
old
gentleman
about
the
young
gentleman
having
been
upstairs
;
and
I
want
you
too
.
"
   
,
is
that
all
?
"
said
the
fat
boy
,
evidently
very
much
relieved
,
as
he
pocketed
the
half
-
crown
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
ai
n't
a
-
going
to
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
is
very
fond
of
Miss
Emily
,
and
Miss
Emily
's
very
fond
of
him
,
and
if
you
were
to
tell
about
it
,
the
old
gentleman
would
carry
you
all
away
miles
into
the
country
,
where
you
'd
see
nobody
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
I
wo
n't
tell
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
stoutly
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
dear
,
"
said
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
it
's
time
I
went
upstairs
,
and
got
my
lady
ready
for
dinner
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
go
yet
,
"
urged
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
,
"
replied
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
for
the
present
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
,
with
elephantine
playfulness
,
stretched
out
his
arms
to
ravish
a
kiss
;
but
as
it
required
no
great
agility
to
elude
him
,
his
fair
enslaver
had
vanished
before
he
closed
them
again
;
upon
which
the
apathetic
youth
ate
a
pound
or
so
of
steak
with
a
sentimental
countenance
,
and
fell
fast
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
so
much
to
say
upstairs
,
and
there
were
so
many
plans
to
concert
for
elopement
and
matrimony
in
the
event
of
old
Wardle
continuing
to
be
cruel
,
that
it
wanted
only
half
an
hour
of
dinner
when
Mr
Snodgrass
took
his
final
adieu
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
ran
to
Emily
's
bedroom
to
dress
,
and
the
lover
,
taking
up
his
hat
,
walked
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
got
outside
the
door
,
when
he
heard
Wardle
's
voice
talking
loudly
,
and
looking
over
the
banisters
<EOS>
beheld
him
,
followed
by
some
other
gentlemen
,
coming
straight
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
nothing
of
the
house
,
Mr
Snodgrass
in
his
confusion
stepped
hastily
back
into
the
room
he
had
just
quitted
,
and
passing
thence
into
an
inner
apartment
(
Mr
Wardle
's
bedchamber
)
,
closed
the
door
softly
,
just
as
the
persons
he
had
caught
a
glimpse
of
entered
the
sitting
-
room
.
<EOS>
These
were
Mr
Wardle
,
Mr
Pickwick
,
Mr
Nathaniel
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
,
whom
he
had
no
difficulty
in
recognising
by
their
voices
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
lucky
I
had
the
presence
of
mind
to
avoid
them
,
"
thought
Mr
Snodgrass
with
a
smile
,
and
walking
on
tiptoe
to
another
door
near
the
bedside
;
"
this
opens
into
the
same
passage
,
and
I
can
walk
quietly
and
comfortably
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
obstacle
to
his
walking
quietly
and
comfortably
away
,
which
was
that
the
door
was
locked
and
the
key
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
have
some
of
your
best
wine
to
-
day
,
waiter
,
"
said
old
Wardle
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
some
of
the
very
best
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
the
ladies
know
we
have
come
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Devoutly
and
ardently
did
Mr
Snodgrass
wish
that
the
ladies
could
know
he
had
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
He
ventured
once
to
whisper
,
"
Waiter
!
"
<EOS>
through
the
keyhole
,
but
the
probability
of
the
wrong
waiter
coming
to
his
relief
,
flashed
upon
his
mind
,
together
with
a
sense
of
the
strong
resemblance
between
his
own
situation
and
that
in
which
another
gentleman
had
been
recently
found
in
a
neighbouring
hotel
(
an
account
of
whose
misfortunes
had
appeared
under
the
head
of
"
Police
"
in
that
morning
's
paper
)
,
he
sat
himself
on
a
portmanteau
,
and
trembled
violently
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
wo
n't
wait
a
minute
for
Perker
,
"
said
Wardle
,
looking
at
his
watch
;
"
he
is
always
exact
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
be
here
,
in
time
,
if
he
means
to
come
;
and
if
he
does
not
,
it
's
of
no
use
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
Arabella
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
sister
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
,
folding
her
in
a
most
romantic
embrace
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Ben
,
dear
,
how
you
do
smell
of
tobacco
,
"
said
Arabella
,
rather
overcome
by
this
mark
of
affection
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
?
"
said
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
I
,
Bella
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
perhaps
I
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
did
,
having
just
left
a
pleasant
little
smoking
-
party
of
twelve
medical
students
,
in
a
small
back
parlour
with
a
large
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
,
"
said
Mr
Ben
Allen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
Bella
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
Arabella
,
bending
forward
to
kiss
her
brother
;
"
do
n't
take
hold
of
me
again
,
Ben
,
dear
,
because
you
tumble
me
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
At
this
point
of
the
reconciliation
,
Mr
Ben
Allen
allowed
his
feelings
and
the
cigars
and
porter
to
overcome
him
,
and
looked
round
upon
the
beholders
with
damp
spectacles
.
   
<EOS>
"
is
nothing
to
be
said
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Wardle
,
with
open
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
great
deal
,
"
whispered
Arabella
,
as
she
received
the
old
gentleman
's
hearty
caress
and
congratulation
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
hard
-
hearted
,
unfeeling
,
cruel
monster
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
little
rebel
,
"
replied
Wardle
,
in
the
same
tone
,
"
and
I
am
afraid
I
shall
be
obliged
to
forbid
you
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
People
like
you
,
who
get
married
in
spite
of
everybody
,
ought
not
to
be
let
loose
on
society
.
 
<EOS>
But
come
!
"
<EOS>
added
the
old
gentleman
aloud
,
"
here
's
the
dinner
;
you
shall
sit
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
;
why
,
damn
the
boy
,
he
's
awake
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
the
great
distress
of
his
master
,
the
fat
boy
was
indeed
in
a
state
of
remarkable
vigilance
,
his
eyes
being
wide
open
,
and
looking
as
if
they
intended
to
remain
so
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
alacrity
in
his
manner
,
too
,
which
was
equally
unaccountable
;
every
time
his
eyes
met
those
of
Emily
or
Arabella
,
he
smirked
and
grinned
;
once
,
Wardle
could
have
sworn
,
he
saw
him
wink
.
   
<EOS>
This
alteration
in
the
fat
boy
's
demeanour
originated
in
his
increased
sense
of
his
own
importance
,
and
the
dignity
he
acquired
from
having
been
taken
into
the
confidence
of
the
young
ladies
;
and
the
smirks
,
and
grins
,
and
winks
were
so
many
condescending
assurances
that
they
might
depend
upon
his
fidelity
.
 
<EOS>
As
these
tokens
were
rather
calculated
to
awaken
suspicion
than
allay
it
,
and
were
somewhat
embarrassing
besides
,
they
were
occasionally
answered
by
a
frown
or
shake
of
the
head
from
Arabella
,
which
the
fat
boy
,
considering
as
hints
to
be
on
his
guard
,
expressed
his
perfect
understanding
of
,
by
smirking
,
grinning
,
and
winking
,
with
redoubled
assiduity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
"
said
Mr
Wardle
,
after
an
unsuccessful
search
in
all
his
pockets
,
"
is
my
snuff
-
box
on
the
sofa
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
recollect
;
I
left
it
on
my
dressing
-
table
this
morning
,
"
said
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Run
into
the
next
room
and
fetch
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
went
into
the
next
room
;
and
,
having
been
absent
about
a
minute
,
returned
with
the
snuff
-
box
,
and
the
palest
face
that
ever
a
fat
boy
wore
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
the
boy
?
"
exclaimed
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nothen
's
the
matter
with
me
,
"
replied
Joe
nervously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
seeing
any
spirits
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
taking
any
?
<EOS>
"
added
Ben
Allen
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
're
right
,
"
whispered
Wardle
across
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
intoxicated
,
I
'm
sure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ben
Allen
replied
that
he
thought
he
was
;
and
,
as
that
gentleman
had
seen
a
vast
deal
of
the
disease
in
question
,
Wardle
was
confirmed
in
an
impression
which
had
been
hovering
about
his
mind
for
half
an
hour
,
and
at
once
arrived
at
the
conclusion
that
the
fat
boy
was
drunk
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just
keep
your
eye
upon
him
for
a
few
minutes
,
"
murmured
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
soon
find
out
whether
he
is
or
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
youth
had
only
interchanged
a
dozen
words
with
Mr
Snodgrass
,
that
gentleman
having
implored
him
to
make
a
private
appeal
to
some
friend
to
release
him
,
and
then
pushed
him
out
with
the
snuff
-
box
,
lest
his
prolonged
absence
should
lead
to
a
discovery
.
 
<EOS>
He
ruminated
a
little
with
a
most
disturbed
expression
of
face
,
and
left
the
room
in
search
of
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mary
had
gone
home
after
dressing
her
mistress
,
and
the
fat
boy
came
back
again
more
disturbed
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
Wardle
and
Mr
Ben
Allen
exchanged
glances
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Joe
!
"
said
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
go
away
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
looked
hopelessly
in
the
face
of
everybody
at
table
,
and
stammered
out
that
he
did
n't
know
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
"
said
Wardle
,
"
you
do
n't
know
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Take
this
cheese
to
Mr
Pickwick
.
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr
Pickwick
being
in
the
very
best
health
and
spirits
,
had
been
making
himself
perfectly
delightful
all
dinner
-
time
,
and
was
at
this
moment
engaged
in
an
energetic
conversation
with
Emily
and
Mr
Winkle
;
bowing
his
head
,
courteously
,
in
the
emphasis
of
his
discourse
,
gently
waving
his
left
hand
to
lend
force
to
his
observations
,
and
all
glowing
with
placid
smiles
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
a
piece
of
cheese
from
the
plate
,
and
was
on
the
point
of
turning
round
to
renew
the
conversation
,
when
the
fat
boy
,
stooping
so
as
to
bring
his
head
on
a
level
with
that
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
pointed
with
his
thumb
over
his
shoulder
,
and
made
the
most
horrible
and
hideous
face
that
was
ever
seen
out
of
a
Christmas
pantomime
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
starting
,
"
<EOS>
what
a
very
---
Eh
?
"
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
for
the
fat
boy
had
drawn
himself
up
,
and
was
,
or
pretended
to
be
,
fast
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
such
an
extremely
singular
lad
!
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
uneasily
at
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seems
an
odd
thing
to
say
,
but
upon
my
word
I
am
afraid
that
,
at
times
,
he
is
a
little
deranged
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
pray
do
n't
say
so
,
"
cried
Emily
and
Arabella
,
both
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
certain
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
amidst
profound
silence
and
looks
of
general
dismay
;
"
but
his
manner
to
me
this
moment
really
was
very
alarming
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
ejaculated
Mr
Pickwick
,
suddenly
jumping
up
with
a
short
scream
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
ladies
,
but
at
that
moment
he
ran
some
sharp
instrument
into
my
leg
.
 
<EOS>
Really
,
he
is
not
safe
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
drunk
,
"
roared
old
Wardle
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ring
the
bell
!
<EOS>
Call
the
waiters
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
drunk
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
,
"
said
the
fat
boy
,
falling
on
his
knees
as
his
master
seized
him
by
the
collar
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
drunk
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
're
mad
;
that
's
worse
.
 
<EOS>
Call
the
waiters
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
mad
;
I
'm
sensible
,
"
rejoined
the
fat
boy
,
beginning
to
cry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
what
the
devil
did
you
run
sharp
instruments
into
Mr
Pickwick
's
legs
for
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Wardle
angrily
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
would
n't
look
at
me
,
"
replied
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wanted
to
speak
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
want
to
say
?
"
asked
half
a
dozen
voices
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
The
fat
boy
gasped
,
looked
at
the
bedroom
door
,
gasped
again
,
and
wiped
two
tears
away
with
the
knuckle
of
each
of
his
forefingers
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
want
to
say
?
"
demanded
Wardle
,
shaking
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
;
"
allow
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
you
wish
to
communicate
to
me
,
my
poor
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
whisper
to
you
,
"
replied
the
fat
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
to
bite
his
ear
off
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Wardle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
come
near
him
;
he
's
vicious
;
ring

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
 
et

.

<EOS>

business
through
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
your
health
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
hard
there
,
"
interposed
the
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
,
with
sudden
energy
;
"
your
eyes
on
me
,
gen'l'm'n
!
"
   
<EOS>
Saying
this
,
the
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
rose
,
as
did
the
other
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
The
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
reviewed
the
company
,
and
slowly
lifted
his
hand
,
upon
which
every
man
(
including
him
of
the
mottled
countenance
)
drew
a
long
breath
,
and
lifted
his
tumbler
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
In
one
instant
,
the
mottled
-
faced
gentleman
depressed
his
hand
again
,
and
every
glass
was
set
down
empty
.
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
describe
the
thrilling
effect
produced
by
this
striking
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
At
once
dignified
,
solemn
,
and
impressive
,
it
combined
every
element
of
grandeur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Pell
,
"
all
I
can
say
is
,
that
such
marks
of
confidence
must
be
very
gratifying
to
a
professional
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
to
say
anything
that
might
appear
egotistical
,
gentlemen
,
but
I
'm
very
glad
,
for
your
own
sakes
,
that
you
came
to
me
;
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
gone
to
any
low
member
of
the
profession
,
it
's
my
firm
conviction
,
and
I
assure
you
of
it
as
a
fact
,
that
you
would
have
found
yourselves
in
Queer
Street
before
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
wished
my
noble
friend
had
been
alive
to
have
seen
my
management
of
this
case
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
it
out
of
pride
,
but
<EOS>
I
think
---
 
<EOS>
However
,
gentlemen
,
I
wo
n't
trouble
you
with
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
generally
to
be
found
here
,
gentlemen
,
but
if
I
'm
not
here
,
or
over
the
way
,
that
's
my
address
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
find
my
terms
very
cheap
and
reasonable
,
and
no
man
attends
more
to
his
clients
than
I
do
,
and
<EOS>
I
hope
I
know
a
little
of
my

.
 
<EOS>
If

any

to

,

,
I

,

,
when

come
to

.
 
<EOS>
Your
healths
,
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
this

,

Pell
laid

before
Mr
Weller
's
friends
,
and
,

clock
again
,
feared

was
time
to
be
walking
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
hint
Mr
Weller
settled
the

,
and
,

,
the

,
legatee
,

,

,

towards
the

.
   
<EOS>
The
office
of
Wilkins
Flasher
,
Esquire
,
of
the
Stock
Exchange
,
was
in
a
first
floor
up
a
court
behind
the
Bank
of
England
;
the
house
of
Wilkins
Flasher
,
Esquire
,
was
at

,

;

and
stanhope
of
Wilkins
Flasher
,
Esquire
,
were
at

;

Wilkins

,

,

to

;

of

,

,

;
and

,

,

,

,
"

,
"
when

.

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

;

!
"

Wilkins

,
Esquire
,

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
a

who

on

,

,

with

.
 
<EOS>
Wilkins
Flasher
,
Esquire
,

,

a

,

into

that

.
 
<EOS>
Both

had

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
"
Done
,

,

"

,

<EOS>
"
P
P
,
mind
,
"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
As

Mr

,

,

,

,

,

Mrs

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

;

to

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

---
"

,

"
   
<EOS>
A

,
and
the
accounts
were
produced
and
audited
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pell
's
bill
was
taxed
by
Sam
,
and
some
charges
were
disallowed
by
the
umpires
;
but
,
notwithstanding
Mr
Pell
's
declaration
,
accompanied
with
many
solemn
asseverations
that
they
were
really
too
hard
upon
him
,
it
was
by
very
many
degrees
the
best
professional
job
he
had
ever
had
,
and
one
on
which
he
boarded
,
lodged
,
and
washed
,
for
six
months
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
The
umpires
having
partaken
of
a
dram
,
shook
hands
and
departed
,
as
they
had
to
drive
out
of
town
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Solomon
Pell
,
finding
that
nothing
more
was
going
forward
,
either
in
the
eating
or
drinking
way
,
took
a
friendly
leave
,
and
Sam
and
his
father
were
left
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Mr
Weller
,
thrusting
his
pocket
-
book
in
his
side
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Vith
the
bills
for
the
lease
,
and
that
,
there
's
eleven
hundred
and
eighty
pound
here
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Samivel
,
my
boy
,
turn
the
horses
"
heads
to
the
George
and
Wulter
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
56
.
<EOS>
An
important
conference
takes
place
between
Mr
Pickwick
and
Samuel
Weller
,
at
which
his
parent
assists
---
an
old
gentleman
in
a
snuff
-
coloured
suit
<EOS>
arrives
unexpectedly
 
Mr
Pickwick
was
sitting
alone
,
musing
over
many
things
,
and
thinking
among
other
considerations
how
he
could
best
provide
for
the
young
couple
whose
present
unsettled
condition
was
matter
of
constant
regret
and
anxiety
to
him
,
when
Mary
stepped
lightly
into
the
room
,
and
,
advancing
to
the
table
,
said
,
rather
hastily
---
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
if
you
please
,
Sir
,
Samuel
is
downstairs
,
and
he
says
may
his
father
see
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
"
replied
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mary
,
tripping
towards
the
door
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sam
has
not
been
here
long
,
has
he
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mary
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
only
just
come
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
going
to
ask
you
for
any
more
leave
,
Sir
,
he
says
.
<EOS>
"
   
Mary
might
have
been
conscious
that
she
had
communicated
this
last
intelligence
with
more
warmth
than
seemed
actually
necessary
,
or
she
might
have
observed
the
good
-
humoured
smile
with
which
Mr
Pickwick
regarded
her
,
when
she
had
finished
speaking
.
 
<EOS>
She
certainly
held
down
her
head
,
and
examined
the
corner
of
a
very
smart
little
apron
,
with
more
closeness
than
there
appeared
any
absolute
occasion
for
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
them
they
can
come
up
at
once
,
by
all
means
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Mary
,
apparently
much
relieved
,
hurried
away
with
her
message
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
took
two
or
three
turns
up
and
down
the
room
;
and
,
rubbing
his
chin
with
his
left
hand
as
he
did
so
,
appeared
lost
in
thought
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
at
length
in
a
kind
but
somewhat
melancholy
tone
,
"
<EOS>
it
is
the
best
way
in
which
I
could
reward
him
for
his
attachment
and
fidelity
;
let
it
be
so
,
in
Heaven
's
name
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
fate
of
a
lonely
old
man
,
that
those
about
him
should
form
new
and
different
attachments
and
leave
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
right
to
expect
that
it
should
be
otherwise
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
added
Mr
Pickwick
more
cheerfully
,
"
it
would
be
selfish
and
ungrateful
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
be
happy
to
have
an
opportunity
of
providing
for
him
so
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
had
been
so
absorbed
in
these
reflections
,
that
a
knock
at
the
door
was
three
or

.
 
<EOS>
Hastily

,
and

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wery

,
thank'ee
,

,
"

;
"
hope
<EOS>
I
see

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

uncommon

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Here
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

I

aggrawatin

,
"

,

.

"

<EOS>
"

he

ai
n't
ekal

myself

wery

<EOS>

Wery

<EOS>
Wery

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Wery

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,

.

,

,

.

,

Wery

,

<EOS>
"
Wery

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
Sam

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

o
'

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
pike
!
"

Weller
,

;
"
I
'll
keep
a
pike
.
 
<EOS>
Say
good
-
bye
to
your
father
,
Samivel
.
 
<EOS>
I
dewote
the

of
my
days
to
a
pike
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
threat
was
such
an
awful
one
,
and
Mr
Weller
,
besides
appearing
fully
resolved
to
carry

,

's

,

,

,

---
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
Mr
Weller
,
I
will

.
 
<EOS>
I

with

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
the
wery
thing
,

,
"
said

Weller
,
brightening

;
"
o
'
course

can
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
no

,
"
said

,

;
"

,

.
<EOS>
Now

.
 
<EOS>
I

to
ask

advice
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
internal
laughter
occasioned
by
the
triumphant
success
of
his
visit
,
which
had
convulsed
not
only
Mr
Weller
's

,

,

,

,
during
the

of

pocket
-

,
suddenly

to
the
most

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
outside
a

minutes
,
Sam
,

?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
immediately
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
looked
uncommonly
wise
and

,
when
Mr

---
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
He

;
vague

of
some

widow
having
been

in

on

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
"

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
,

<EOS>

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

over

,

's

;

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Who

?
 
<EOS>
Not

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

's

,

,

;
and
,

,

one
Mrs
Winkle
was

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

;
"

,

,

---
"
   
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
.
 
<EOS>
Show
me
to
Mrs
Winkle
's
room
,
without
announcing
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
little
old
gentleman
uttered
this
command
,
he
slipped
five
shillings
into
the
waiter
's
hand
,
and
looked
steadily
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
sir
,
"
said
the
waiter
,
"
I
do
n't
know
,
sir
,
whether
---
"
   
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
'll
do
it
<EOS>
,
I
see
,
"
said
the
little
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
do
it
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
save
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
very
cool
and
collected
in
the
gentleman
's
manner
,
that
the
waiter
put
the
five
shillings
in
his
pocket
,
and
led
him
upstairs
without
another
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
room
,
is
it
?
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
go
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
waiter
complied
,
wondering
much
who
the
gentleman
could
be
,
and
what
he
wanted
;
the
little
old
gentleman
,
waiting
till
he
was
out
of
sight
,
tapped
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
said
Arabella
.
   
<EOS>
"
Um
,
a
pretty
voice
,
at
any
rate
,
"
murmured
the
little
old
gentleman
;
"
but
that
's
nothing
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
he
opened
the
door
and
walked
in
.
 
<EOS>
Arabella
,
who
was
sitting
at
work
,
rose
on
beholding
a
stranger
---
<EOS>
a
little
confused
---
but
by
no
means
ungracefully
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
rise
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
unknown
,
walking
in
,
and
closing
the
door
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Winkle
,
I
believe
?
"
   
<EOS>
Arabella
inclined
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Nathaniel
Winkle
,
who
married
the
son
of
the
old
man
at
Birmingham
?
"
said
the
stranger
,
eyeing
Arabella
with
visible
curiosity
.
   
<EOS>
Again
Arabella
inclined
her
head
,
and
looked
uneasily
round
,
as
if
uncertain
whether
to
call
for
assistance
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
surprise
you
,
I
see
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
,
I
confess
,
"
replied
Arabella
,
wondering
more
and
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
a
chair
,
if
you
'll
allow
me
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
He
took
one
;
and
drawing
a
spectacle
-
case
from
his
pocket
,
leisurely
pulled
out
a
pair
of
spectacles
,
which
he
adjusted
on
his
nose
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
me
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
,
looking
so
intently
at
Arabella
that
she
began
to
feel
alarmed
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
she
replied
timidly
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
nursing
his
left
leg
;
"
I
do
n't
know
how
you
should
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
my
name
,
though
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
?
"
said
Arabella
,
trembling
,
though
she
scarcely
knew
why
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
what
it
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Presently
,
ma'am
,
presently
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
not
having
yet
removed
his
eyes
from
her
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
recently
married
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
replied
Arabella
,
in
a
scarcely
audible
tone
,
laying
aside
her
work
,
and
becoming
greatly
agitated
as
a
thought
,
that
had
occurred
to
her
before
,
struck
more
forcibly
upon
her
mind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Without
having
represented
to
your
husband
the
propriety
of
first
consulting
his
father
,
on
whom
he
is
dependent
,
I
think
?
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
Arabella
applied
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Without
an
endeavour
,
even
,
to
ascertain
,
by
some
indirect
appeal
,
what
were
the
old
man
's
sentiments
on
a
point
in
which
he
would
naturally
feel
much
interested
?
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
deny
it
,
Sir
,
"
said
Arabella
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
without
having
sufficient
property
of
your
own
to
afford
your
husband
any
permanent
assistance
in
exchange
for
the
worldly
advantages
which
you
knew
he
would
have
gained
if
he
had
married
agreeably
to
his
father
's
wishes
?
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
what
boys
and
girls
call
disinterested
affection
,
till
they
have
boys
and
girls
of
their
own
,
and
then
they
see
it
in
a
rougher
and
very
different
light
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arabella
's
tears
flowed
fast
,
as
she
pleaded
in
extenuation
that
she
was
young
and
inexperienced
;
<EOS>
that
her
attachment
had
alone
induced
her
to
take
the
step
to
which
she
had
resorted
;
and
that
she
had
been
deprived
of
the
counsel
and
guidance
of
her
parents
almost
from
infancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
wrong
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
in
a
milder
tone
,
"
very
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
romantic
,
unbusinesslike
,
foolish
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
my
fault
;
all
my
fault
,
Sir
,
"
replied
poor
Arabella
,
weeping
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
;
"
it
was
not
your
fault
that
he
fell
in
love
with
you
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
it
was
,
though
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
looking
rather
slily
at
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
your
fault
.
<EOS>
He
could
n't
help
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
little
compliment
,
or
the
little
gentleman
's
odd
way
of
paying
it
,
or
his
altered
manner
---
so
much
kinder
than
it
was
,
at
first
---
or
all
three
together
,
forced
a
smile
from
Arabella
in
the
midst
of
her
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
your
husband
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
old
gentleman
,
abruptly
;
stopping
a
smile
which
was
just
coming
over
his
own
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
expect
him
every
instant
,
sir
,
"
said
Arabella
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
persuaded
him
to
take
a
walk
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
low
and
wretched
at
not
having
heard
from
his
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Low
,
is
he
?
"
said
the
old
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Serve
him
right
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
feels
it
on
my
account
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
Arabella
;
"
and
indeed
,
Sir
,
I
feel
it
deeply
on
his
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
the
sole
means
of
bringing
him
to
his
present
condition
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mind
it
on
his
account
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
It
serves
him
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
of
it
---
actually
glad
of
it
,
as
far
as
he
is
concerned
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
words
were
scarcely
out
of
the
old
gentleman
's
lips
,
when
footsteps
were
heard
ascending
the
stairs
,
which
he
and
Arabella
seemed
both
to
recognise
at
the
same
moment
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
gentleman
turned
pale
;
and
,
making
a
strong
effort
to
appear
composed
,
stood
up
,
as
Mr
Winkle
entered
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Father
!
"
cried
Mr
Winkle
,
recoiling
in
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
little
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
what
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
remained
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
ashamed
of
yourself
,
I
hope
,
Sir
?
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Still
Mr
Winkle
said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
ashamed
of
yourself
,
Sir
,
or
are
you
not
?
"
inquired
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Winkle
,
drawing
Arabella
's
arm
through
his
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
ashamed
of
myself
,
or
of
my
wife
either
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
!
"
cried
the
old
gentleman
ironically
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
to
have
done
anything
which
has
lessened
your
affection
for
me
,
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Winkle
;
"
but
I
will
say
,
at
the
same
time
,
that
I
have
no
reason
to
be
ashamed
of
having
this
lady
for
my
wife
,
nor
you
of
having
her
for
a
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Give
me
your
hand
,
Nat
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
in
an
altered
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Kiss
me
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
very
charming
little
daughter
-
in
-
law
after
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
"
time
Mr
Winkle
went
in
search
of
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
returning
with
that
gentleman
,
presented
him
to
his
father
,
whereupon
they
shook
hands
for
five
minutes
incessantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
,
I
thank
you
most
heartily
for
all
your
kindness
to
my
son
,
"
said
old
Mr
Winkle
,
in
a
bluff
,
straightforward
way
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
hasty
fellow
,
and
when
I
saw
you
last
,
I
was
vexed
and
taken
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
judged
for
myself
now
,
and
am
more
than
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
make
any
more
apologies
,
Mr
Pickwick
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
one
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
the
only
thing
wanting
to
complete
my
happiness
.
"
   
<EOS>
Hereupon
<EOS>
there
was
another
shaking
of
hands
for
five
minutes
longer
,
accompanied
by
a
great
number
of
complimentary
speeches
,
which
,
besides
being
complimentary
,
had
the
additional
and
very
novel
recommendation
of
being
sincere
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
had
dutifully
seen
his
father
to
the
Belle
Sauvage
,
when
,
on
returning
,
he
encountered
the
fat
boy
in
the
court
,
who
had
been
charged
with
the
delivery
of
a
note
from
Emily
Wardle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
Joe
,
who
was
unusually
loquacious
,
"
what
a
pretty
girl
Mary
is
,
is
n't
she
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
SO
fond
of
her
,
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weller
made
no
verbal
remark
in
reply
;
but
eyeing
the
fat
boy
for
a
moment
,
quite
transfixed
at
his
presumption
,
led
him
by
the
collar
to
the
corner
,
and
dismissed
him
with
a
harmless
but
ceremonious
kick
.
 
<EOS>
After
which
,
he
walked
home
,
whistling
.
    
Chapter
52
.
<EOS>
In
which
the
Pickwick
Club
is
finally
dissolved
,
and
everything
concluded
to
the
satisfaction
of
everybody
 
For
a
whole
week
after
the
happy
arrival
of
Mr
Winkle
from
Birmingham
,
Mr
Pickwick
and
Sam
Weller
were
from
home
all
day
long
,
only
returning
just
in
time
for
dinner
,
and
then
wearing
an
air
of
mystery
and
importance
quite
foreign
to
their
natures
.
<EOS>
It
was
evident
that
very
grave
and
eventful
proceedings
were
on
foot
;
but
various
surmises
were
afloat
,
respecting
their
precise
character
.
 
<EOS>
Some
(
among
whom
was
Mr
Tupman
)
were
disposed
to
think
that
Mr
Pickwick
contemplated
a
matrimonial
alliance
;
but
this
idea
the
ladies
most
strenuously
repudiated
.
 
<EOS>
Others
rather
inclined
to
the
belief
that
he
had
projected
some
distant
tour
,
and
was
at
present
occupied
in
effecting
the
preliminary
arrangements
;
but
this
again
was
stoutly
denied
by
Sam
himself
,
who
had
unequivocally
stated
,
when
cross
-
examined
by
Mary
,
that
no
new
journeys
were
to
be
undertaken
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
when
the
brains
of
the
whole
party
had
been
racked
for
six
long
days
,
by
unavailing
speculation
,
it
was
unanimously
resolved
that
Mr
Pickwick
should
be
called
upon
to
explain
his
conduct
,
and
to
state
distinctly
why
he
had
thus
absented
himself
from
the
society
of
his
admiring
friends
.
   
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
Mr
Wardle
invited
the
full
circle
to
dinner
at
the
Adelphi
;
and
the
decanters
having
been
thrice
sent
round
,
opened
the
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
anxious
to
know
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
what
we
have
done
to
offend
you
,
and
to
induce
you
to
desert
us
and
devote
yourself
to
these
solitary
walks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
?
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
singular
enough
that
I
had
intended
to
volunteer
a
full
explanation
this
very
day
;
so
,
if
you
will
give
me
another
glass
of
wine
,
I
will
satisfy
your
curiosity
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
decanters
passed
from
hand
to
hand
with
unwonted
briskness
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
,
looking
round
on
the
faces
of
his
friends
with
a
cheerful
smile
,
proceeded
---
"
All
the
changes
that
have
taken
place
among
us
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
<EOS>
I
mean
the
marriage
that
HAS
taken
place
,
and
the
marriage
that
WILL
take
place
,
with
the
changes
they
involve
,
rendered
it
necessary
for
me
to
think
,
soberly
and
at
once
,
upon
my
future
plans
.
 
<EOS>
I
determined
on
retiring
to
some
quiet
,
pretty
neighbourhood
in
the
vicinity
of
London
;
I
saw
a
house
which
exactly
suited
my
fancy
;
I
have
taken
it
and
furnished
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
fully
prepared
for
my
reception
,
and
I
intend
entering
upon
it
at
once
,
trusting
that
I
may
yet
live
to
spend
many
quiet
years
in
peaceful
retirement
,
cheered
through
life
by
the
society
of
my
friends
,
and
followed
in
death
by
their
affectionate
remembrance
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Pickwick
paused
,
and
a
low
murmur
ran
round
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
house
I
have
taken
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
is
at
Dulwich
.
<EOS>
It
has
a
large
garden
,
and
is
situated
in
one
of
the
most
pleasant
spots
near
London
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
fitted
up
with
every
attention
to
substantial
comfort
;
perhaps
to
a
little
elegance
besides
;
but
of
that
you
shall
judge
for
yourselves
.
 
<EOS>
Sam
accompanies
me
there
.
<EOS>
I
have
engaged
,
on
Perker
's
representation
,
a
housekeeper
---
a
very
old
one
---
and
such
other
servants
as
she
thinks
I
shall
require
.
 
<EOS>
I
propose
to
consecrate
this
little
retreat
,
by
having
a
ceremony
in
which
I
take
a
great
interest
,
performed
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
,
if
my
friend
Wardle
entertains
no
objection
,
that
his
daughter
should
be
married
from
my
new
house
,
on
the
day
I
take
possession
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
happiness
of
young
people
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
,
a
little
moved
,
"
has
ever
been
the
chief
pleasure
of
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
warm
my
heart
to
witness
the
happiness
of
those
friends
who
are
dearest
to
me
,
beneath
my
own
roof
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
paused
again
:
Emily
and
Arabella
sobbed
audibly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
communicated
,
both
personally
and
by
letter
,
with
the
club
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pickwick
,
"
acquainting
them
with
my
intention
.
<EOS>
During
our
long
absence
,
it
has
suffered
much
from
internal
dissentions
;
and
the
withdrawal
of
my
name
,
coupled
with
this
and
other
circumstances
,
has
occasioned
its
dissolution
.
 
<EOS>
The
Pickwick
Club
exists
no
longer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
regret
,
"
said
Mr
Pickwick
in
a
low
voice
,
"
I
shall
never
regret
having
devoted
the
greater
part
of
two
years
to
mixing
with
different
varieties
and
shades
of
human
character
,
frivolous
as
my
pursuit
of
novelty
may
have
appeared
to
many
.
<EOS>
Nearly
the
whole
of
my
previous
life
having
been
devoted
to
business
and
the
pursuit
of
wealth
,
numerous
scenes
of
which
I
had
no
previous
conception
have
dawned
upon
me
---
I
hope
to
the
enlargement
of
my
mind
,
and
the
improvement
of
my
understanding
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
done
but
<EOS>
little
good
,
I
trust
I
have
done
less
harm
,
and
that
none
of
my
adventures
will
be
other
than
a
source
of
amusing
and
pleasant
recollection
to
me
in
the
decline
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Mr
Pickwick
filled
and
drained
a
bumper
with
a
trembling
hand
;
and
his
eyes
moistened
as
his
friends
rose
with
one
accord
,
and
pledged
him
from
their
hearts
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
few
preparatory
arrangements
to
be
made
for
the
marriage
of
Mr
Snodgrass
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
had
neither
father
nor
mother
,
and
had
been
in
his
minority
a
ward
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
,
that
gentleman
was
perfectly
well
acquainted
with
his
possessions
and
prospects
.
 
<EOS>
His
account
of
both
was
quite
satisfactory
to
Wardle
 
---
<EOS>
as
almost
any
other
account
would
have
been
,
for
<EOS>
the
good
old
gentleman
was
overflowing
with
Hilarity
and
kindness
---
and
a
handsome
portion
having
been
bestowed
upon
Emily
,
the
marriage
was
fixed
to
take
place
on
the
fourth
day
from
that
time
 
---
the
suddenness
of
which
preparations
reduced
three
dressmakers
and
a
tailor
to
the
extreme
verge
of
insanity
.
   
<EOS>
Getting
post
-
horses
to
the
carriage
,
old
Wardle
started
off
,
next
day
,
to
bring
his
mother
back
to
town
.
 
<EOS>
Communicating
his
intelligence
to
the
old
lady
with
characteristic
impetuosity
,
she
instantly
fainted
away
;
but
being
promptly
revived
,
ordered
the
brocaded
silk
gown
to
be
packed
up
forthwith
,
and
proceeded
to
relate
some
circumstances
of
a
similar
nature
attending
the
marriage
of
the
eldest
daughter
of
Lady
Tollimglower
,
deceased
,
which
occupied
three
hours
in
the
recital
,
and
were
not
half
finished
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Trundle
had
to
be
informed
of
all
the
mighty
preparations
that
were
making
in
London
;
and
,
being
in
a
delicate
state
of
health
,
was
informed
thereof
through
Mr
Trundle
,
lest
the
news
should
be
too
much
for
her
;
but
it
was
not
too
much
for
her
,
inasmuch
as
she
at
once
wrote
off
to
Muggleton
,
to
order
a
new
cap
and
a
black
satin
gown
,
and
moreover
avowed
her
determination
of
being
present
at
the
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
Hereupon
,
Mr
Trundle
called
in
the
doctor
,
and
the
doctor
said
Mrs
Trundle
ought
to
know
best
how
she
felt
herself
,
to
which
Mrs
Trundle
replied
that
she
felt
herself
quite
equal
to
it
,
and
that
she
had
made
up
her
mind
to
go
;
upon
which
the
doctor
,
who
was
a
wise
and
discreet
doctor
,
and
knew
what
was
good
for
himself
,
as
well
as
for
other
people
,
said
that
perhaps
if
Mrs
Trundle
stopped
at
home
,
she
might
hurt
herself
more
by
fretting
,
than
by
going
,
so
perhaps
she
had
better
go
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
did
go
;
the
doctor
with
great
attention
sending
in
half
a
dozen
of
medicine
,
to
be
drunk
upon
the
road
.
   
<EOS>
In
addition
to
these
points
of
distraction
,
Wardle
was
intrusted
with
two
small
letters
to
two
small
young
ladies
who
were
to
act
as
bridesmaids
;
upon
the
receipt
of
which
,
the
two
young
ladies
were
driven
to
despair
by
having
no
"
things
"
ready
for
so
important
an
occasion
,
and
no
time
to
make
them
in
---
a
circumstance
which
appeared
to
afford
the
two
worthy
papas
of
the
two
small
young
ladies
rather
a
feeling
of
satisfaction
than
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
old
frocks
were
trimmed
,
and
new
bonnets
made
,
and
the
young
ladies
looked
as
well
as
could
possibly
have
been
expected
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
they
cried
at
the
subsequent
ceremony
in
the
proper
places
,
and
trembled
at
the
right
times
,
they
acquitted
themselves
to
the
admiration
of
all
beholders
.
<EOS>
How
the
two
poor
relations
ever
reached
London
---
whether
they
walked
,
or
got
behind
coaches
,
or
procured
lifts
in
wagons
,
or
carried
each
other
by
turns
---
is
uncertain
;
but
there
they
were
,
before
Wardle
;
and
the
very
first
people
that
knocked
at
the
door
of
Mr
Pickwick
's
house
,
on
the
bridal
morning
,
were
the
two
poor
relations
,
all
smiles
and
shirt
collar
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
welcomed
heartily
though
,
for
riches
or
poverty
had
no
influence
on
Mr
Pickwick
;
the
new
servants
were
all
alacrity
and
readiness
;
Sam
was
in
a
most
unrivalled
state
of
high
spirits
and
excitement
;
Mary
was
glowing
with
beauty
and
smart
ribands
.
   
<EOS>
The
bridegroom
,
who
had
been
staying
at
the
house
for
two
or
three
days
previous
,
sallied
forth
gallantly
to
Dulwich
Church
to
meet
the
bride
,
attended
by
Mr
Pickwick
,
Ben
Allen
,
Bob
Sawyer
,
and
Mr
Tupman
;
with
Sam
Weller
outside
,
having
at
his
button
-
hole
a
white
favour
,
the
gift
of
his
lady
-
love
,
and
clad
in
a
new
and
gorgeous
suit
of
livery
invented
for
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
They
were
met
by
the
Wardles
,
and
the
Winkles
,
and
the
bride
and
bridesmaids
,
and
the
Trundles
;
and
the
ceremony
having
been
performed
,
the
coaches
rattled
back
to
Mr
Pickwick
's
to
breakfast
,
where
little
Mr
Perker
already
awaited
them
.
   
<EOS>
Here
,
all
the
light
clouds
of
the
more
solemn
part
of
the
proceedings
passed
away
;
every
face
shone
forth
joyously
;
and
nothing
was
to
be
heard
but
congratulations
and
commendations
.
<EOS>
Everything
was
so
beautiful
!
 
<EOS>
The
lawn
in
front
,
the
garden
behind
,
the
miniature
conservatory
,
the
dining
-
room
,
the
drawing
-
room
,
the
bedrooms
,
the
smoking
-
room
,
and
,
above
all
,
the
study
,
with
its
pictures
and
easy
-
chairs
,
and
odd
cabinets
,
and
queer
tables
,
and
books
out
of
number
,
with
a
large
cheerful
window
opening
upon
a
pleasant
lawn
and
commanding
a
pretty
landscape
,
dotted
here
and
there
with
little
houses
almost
hidden
by
the
trees
;
and
then
the
curtains
,
and
the
carpets
,
and
the
chairs
,
and
the
sofas
!
 
<EOS>
Everything
was
so
beautiful
,
so
compact
,
so
neat
,
and
in
such
exquisite
taste
,
said
everybody
,
that
there
really
was
no
deciding
what
to
admire
most
.
   
<EOS>
And
in
the
midst
of
all
this
,
stood
Mr
Pickwick
,
<EOS>
his
countenance
lighted
up
with
smiles
,
which
the
heart
of
no
man
,
woman
,
or
child
,
could
resist
:
himself
the
happiest
of
the
group
:
shaking
hands
,
over
and
over
again
,
with
the
same
people
,
and
when
his
own
hands
were
not
so
employed
,
rubbing
them
with
pleasure
:
turning
round
in
a
different
direction
at
every
fresh
expression
of
gratification
or
curiosity
,
and
inspiring
everybody
with
his
looks
of
gladness
and
delight
.
   
<EOS>
Breakfast
is
announced
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
leads
the
old
lady
(
who
has
been
very
eloquent
on
the
subject
of
Lady
Tollimglower
)
to
the
top
of
a
long
table
;
Wardle
takes
the
bottom
;
the
friends
arrange
themselves
on
either
side
;
Sam
takes
his
station
behind
his
master
's
chair
;
the
laughter
and
talking
cease
;
Mr
Pickwick
,
having
said
grace
,
pauses
for
an
instant
and
looks
round
him
.
<EOS>
As
he
does
so
,
the
tears
roll
down
his
cheeks
,
in
the
fullness
of
his
joy
.
   
<EOS>
Let
us
leave
our
old
friend
in
one
of
those
moments
of
unmixed
happiness
,
of
which
,
if
we
seek
them
,
there
are
ever
some
,
to
cheer
our
transitory
existence
here
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
dark
shadows
on
the
earth
,
but
its
lights
are
stronger
in
the
contrast
.
 
<EOS>
Some
men
,
like
bats
or
owls
,
have
better
eyes
for
the
darkness
than
for
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
We
,
who
have
no
such
optical
powers
,
are
better
pleased
to
take
our
last
parting
look
at
the
visionary
companions
of
many
solitary
hours
,
when
the
brief
sunshine
of
the
world
is
blazing
full
upon
them
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
the
fate
of
most
men
who
mingle
with
the
world
,
and
attain
even
the
prime
of
life
,
to
make
many
real
friends
,
and
lose
them
in
the
course
of
nature
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
fate
of
all
authors
or
chroniclers
to
create
imaginary
friends
,
and
lose
them
in
the
course
of
art
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
is
this
the
full
extent
of
their
misfortunes
;
for
they
are
required
to
furnish
an
account
of
them
besides
.
   
<EOS>
In
compliance
with
this
custom
---
unquestionably
a
bad
one
 
<EOS>
---
we
subjoin
a
few
biographical
words
,
in
relation
to
the
party
at
Mr
Pickwick
's
<EOS>
assembled
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Winkle
,
being
fully
received
into
favour
by
the
old
gentleman
,
were
shortly
afterwards
installed
in
a
newly
-
built
house
,
not
half
a
mile
from
Mr
Pickwick
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Winkle
,
being
engaged
in
the
city
as
agent
or
town
correspondent
of
his
father
,
exchanged
his
old
costume
for
the
ordinary
dress
of
Englishmen
,
and
presented
all
the
external
appearance
of
a
civilised
Christian
ever
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Snodgrass
settled
at
Dingley
Dell
,
where
they
purchased
and
cultivated
a
small
farm
,
more
for
occupation
than
profit
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snodgrass
,
being
occasionally
abstracted
and
melancholy
,
is
to
this
day
reputed
a
great
poet
among
his
friends
and
acquaintance
,
although
we
do
not
find
that
he
has
ever
written
anything
to
encourage
the
belief
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
many
celebrated
characters
,
literary
,
philosophical
,
and
otherwise
,
who
hold
a
high
reputation
on
a
similar
tenure
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tupman
,
when
his
friends
married
,
and
Mr
Pickwick
settled
,
took
lodgings
at
Richmond
,
where
he
has
ever
since
resided
.
 
<EOS>
He
walks
constantly
on
the
terrace
during
the
summer
months
,
with
a
youthful
and
jaunty
air
,
which
has
rendered
him
the
admiration
of
the
numerous
elderly
ladies
of
single
condition
,
who
reside
in
the
vicinity
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
never
proposed
again
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bob
Sawyer
,
having
previously
passed
through
the
GAZETTE
,
passed
over
to
Bengal
,
accompanied
by
Mr
Benjamin
Allen
;
both
gentlemen
having
received
surgical
appointments
from
the
East
India
Company
.
 
<EOS>
They
each
had
the
yellow
fever
fourteen
times
,
and
then
resolved
to
try
a
little
abstinence
;
since
which
period
,
they
have
been
doing
well
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Bardell
let
lodgings
to
many
conversable
single
gentlemen
,
with
great
profit
,
but
never
brought
any
more
actions
for
breach
of
promise
of
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Her
attorneys
,
Messrs.
Dodson
&
Fogg
,
continue
in
business
,
from
which
they
realise
a
large
income
,
and
in
which
they
are
universally
considered
among
the
sharpest
of
the
sharp
.
   
<EOS>
Sam
Weller
kept
his
word
,
and
remained
unmarried
,
for
two
years
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
housekeeper
dying
at
the
end
of
that
time
,
Mr
Pickwick
promoted
Mary
to
the
situation
,
on
condition
of
her
marrying
Mr
Weller
at
once
,
which
she
did
without
a
murmur
.
<EOS>
From
the
circumstance
of
two
sturdy
little
boys
having
been
repeatedly
seen
at
the
gate
of
the
back
garden
,
there
is
reason
to
suppose
that
Sam
has
some
family
.
   
<EOS>
The
elder
Mr
Weller
drove
a
coach
for
twelve
months
,
but
being
afflicted
with
the
gout
,
was
compelled
to
retire
.
 
<EOS>
The
contents
of
the
pocket
-
book
had
been
so
well
invested
for
him
,
however
,
by
Mr
Pickwick
,
that
he
had
a
handsome
independence
to
retire
on
,
upon
which
he
still
lives
at
an
excellent
public
-
house
near
Shooter
's
Hill
,
where
he
is
quite
reverenced
as
an
oracle
,
boasting
very
much
of
his
intimacy
with
Mr
Pickwick
,
and
retaining
a
most
unconquerable
aversion
to
widows
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
himself
continued
to
reside
in
his
new
house
,
employing
his
leisure
hours
in
arranging
the
memoranda
which
he
afterwards
presented
to
the
secretary
of
the
once
famous
club
,
or
in
hearing
Sam
Weller
read
aloud
,
with
such
remarks
as
suggested
themselves
to
his
mind
,
which
never
failed
to
afford
Mr
Pickwick
great
amusement
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
much
troubled
at
first
,
by
the
numerous
applications
made
to
him
by
Mr
Snodgrass
,
Mr
Winkle
,
and
Mr
Trundle
,
to
act
as
godfather
to
their
offspring
;
but
he
has
become
used
to
it
now
,
and
officiates
as
a
matter
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
had
occasion
to
regret
his
bounty
to
Mr
Jingle
;
for
both
that
person
and
<EOS>
Job
Trotter
became
,
in
time
,
worthy
members
of
society
,
although
they
have
always
steadily
objected
to
return
to
the
scenes
of
their
old
haunts
and
temptations
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pickwick
is
somewhat
infirm
now
;
but
he
retains
all
his
former
juvenility
of
spirit
,
and
may
still
be
frequently
seen
,
contemplating
the
pictures
in
the
Dulwich
Gallery
,
or
enjoying
a
walk
about
the
pleasant
neighbourhood
on
a
fine
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
known
by
all
the
poor
people
about
,
who
never
fail
to
take
their
hats
off
,
as
he
passes
,
with
great
respect
.
 
<EOS>
The
children
idolise
him
,
and
so
indeed
does
the
whole
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
Every
year
he
repairs
to
a
large
family
merry
-
making
at
Mr
Wardle
's
;
on
this
,
as
on
all
other
occasions
,
he
is
invariably
attended
by
the
faithful
Sam
,
between
whom
and
<EOS>
his
master
there
exists
a
steady
and
reciprocal
attachment
which
nothing
but
death
will
terminate
.
     
<EOS>
